title: Calamities in Space
description: NASA had a calamitous week. First it discovered a fundamental flaw in the Hubble space telescope. Then it had to ground its space shuttle fleet after a second shuttle sprang a mysterious hydrogen leak in pre-launch tests. These events are a setback for astronomy, a warning for other big science projects and their backers in Congress and the White House, and an untimely black mark for the space agency.

title: Confusion Clouds Debut Of Leave Law
description: LEAD: CONNECTICUT'S family and medical leave law takes effect today, guaranteeing workers in private companies up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for a newborn or adopted child or a sick family member. But the State Labor Department has yet to provide detailed regulations, and some employers say they are unsure how the law will work.

title: A LESSON FOR THE PRINCIPAL
description: IMPROVING SCHOOLS FROM WITHIN

title: Postings: Howard Beach Offices;   Out of Retirement to Build Again
description: In an effort to broaden the economic base of Howard Beach, Queens, a local developer has created a sleek, two-story office building on the community's main commercial strip. The Pan-Bay Office Building, at 156-36 Cross Bay Boulevard, was completed at a cost of $2 million by Attillio W. Panzarella, who came out of retirement in Scottsdale, Ariz., to realize his vision of giving his old neighborhood an economic boost. The developer, now 70 years old, returned to A. J. Panzarella Realty to pursue the project.

title: Women Over 40 on L.I. Getting More Divorces
description: LEAD: AS the baby boom generation enters its middle years, divorce is increasingly becoming a midlife phenomenon in America, and Long Island appears to be following the trend.

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column on June 17 about ads in the subway system misstated the route of the IRT on the East Side in 1904. It ran on Fourth Avenue (now Park Avenue South) as far as 42d Street, not on Lexington Avenue.

title: Political Memo;   Democrats Try Not to Gloat And Begin Planning for 1992
description: Suddenly, Democrats are dusting off their sheet music and learning to sing ''Happy Days Are Here Again.''

title: So Many Weddings, So Few Hands
description: HERE comes the bride, and another, and another. Saturdays in June the brides are as plentiful at the Adamovichs' in Freeport as the high-performance powerboats that cruise the canal behind their home.

title: New Weapon Against Harbor Oil Spills
description: THE Coast Guard is preparing to install a system of radar and television cameras in New York Harbor that will alert ships' pilots to traffic conditions and emergencies, in an effort to prevent some of the oil spill accidents that have plagued the harbor area and, most recently, the Jersey Shore.

title: KOHL, THE MAN FOR THE GERMAN MOVEMENT
description: Whenever talk in Bonn turns to Helmut Kohl, someone inevitably recounts how some rival, imagining Mr. Kohl to be a bumbling provincial politician, challenges the Chancellor head on, only to be left sprawled in the dust.

title: Roberta Peters Recital
description: The soprano Roberta Peters is to sing works by Bach, Mozart, Strauss, Verdi, Debussy, Poulenc, Rodrigo and Rossini at 5:30 P.M. today in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, on Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. Warren Jones will be the accompanist. Tickets are $20. Information: (914) 232-1252.

title: After King, Mandela and 42 Years, a Pastor Retires
description: The Rev. Gardner C. Taylor admits he is just a bit frightened. He will not be preaching today. And he jokes that it may take him a while to find something to do on Sunday mornings.

title: Jeffrey Weber Marries Stacey Gillis in Carolina
description: Stacey Gillis, the daughter of Robert Gillis of Lake Wylie, S.C., and Acapulco, Mexico, and Mrs. Stanley Grey of Atlanta, was married last evening to Jeffrey Andrew Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Weber of New York. Rabbi Richard K. Rocklin performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Drorah Setel Marries John O'Donnell
description: Tracey Wren Drorah Setel, the daughter of Susan W. Setel and Eugene M. Setel of Buffalo, was married there last evening at the Buffalo Club to John Joseph O'Donnell, a son of Mrs. Granville Morse of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Edward F. O'Donnell. Rabbi Marcia Plumb and Cantor Sue Roemer officiated.

title: Argentina Beats Yugoslavia
description: Argentina's unlikely path in the World Cup took another fortuitous turn today as the defending champion withstood a courageous team from Yugoslavia and stultifying heat to win on penalty kicks and advance to the semifinals Tuesday in Naples.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Traditional Steakhouse in Port Chester
description: LEAD: THE Willett House is certainly worth knowing about, even now in only its third month of operation. To our knowledge it is the county's first steakhouse that brings with it the tradition of the acclaimed greats: the Peter Luger Steakhouse in Brooklyn, an establishment famous for its porterhouse steaks, and Manhattan's Palm, where, besides beef, lobsters come in sizes big, bigger and biggest.

title:
MUSIC;

Duplicating the Sound And the Look of Sousa
description: LEAD: KEITH BRION, who looks just a bit like John Philip Sousa, will become Sousa on July 10 when he dresses up in a duplicate of a Sousa costume from the early part of the century and takes his Peerless Sousa Band to the Stockton State College Performing Arts Center for a performance patterned after an original

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BOX AND COX

title: Rating the Orient-Express
description: FOR over a hundred years, the Orient Express, which ran from what is now Istanbul to Paris, was the world's most glamorous train - ''The King of the Rails.'' No other train possessed such an aura of romance, opulence and mystery. The mention of its name still evokes adventure and intrigue. It inspired six major films, 19 books and a fox trot, written in 1933. In its heyday, the 1920's and 30's, the Orient Express transported heiresses, international spies, European royalty, film stars and a few murderers between western Europe and Constantinople. The service was exemplary; the food legendary, and the ambiance the epitome of Continental sophistication.

title: Mets Fans by 3-1, Poll Shows
description: Adult Met fans outnumber their Yankee counterparts by almost 3 to 1 in New York City, a New York Times/ WCBS-TV News poll has found.

title: Review/Dance;   'Dr. Midnight' and Other Literate Works
description: The six new and recent dances presented by Beth Leonard and RoseAnne Spradlin on June 23 at the Bessie Schonberg Theater had the air of being company to their choreographers. There were no games or gimmicks; just blessedly adult and literate dance of consistent interest.

title: Gillian Prisk Is Wed
description: Gillian Mary Catherine Prisk and Alastair John Mackenzie Walton were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of San Giorgio in Portofino, Italy, by the Rev. John di Vito. The bride, an assistant buyer at Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, is a daughter of Mary Prisk of Timaru, New Zealand, and the late Dr. Howard D. Prisk. The bridegroom, an associate in the investment banking department at the First Boston Corporaiton in New York, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Walton of Melbourne, Australia.

title: Romanian Says He Advises Opponents in North Korea
description: A small group of high-ranking officials in North Korea have begun dissident activities against the leadership of the hard-line Marxist country, says a former senior Romanian official, who adds that he has been advising the Koreans.

title: Review/Theater;   Jekyll Tale Updated, To Music
description: ''Jekyll and Hyde,'' which opens Theaterworks/USA's second four-week season of free Off-Broadway summer theater for young people, is a musical that wants to entertain while putting over a serious message about the perils of substance abuse. Until it ends with an abrupt, heavy-handed clunk, the hourlong show at the Promenade Theater succeeds admirably in maintaining the precarious balance between being fun and conveying its warning against the pitfalls of quick chemical fixes.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Lawsuit Complicates Bid to Buy MGM/UA
description: Time Warner Inc. has sued the Pathe Communications Corporation for $100 million in a dispute arising from Pathe's attempt to buy the MGM/UA Communications Company.

title: Carolyn Voute and Kevin Murphy Wed
description: Carolyn Patricia Voute, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Voute of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Lawrence Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Murphy of North Chelmsford, Mass. Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: FUTURE LOOKS DIM FOR PORSCHE
description: Within the next few weeks, Porsche is expected to decide whether to continue its Indy-car program next year. Last week, Derrick Walker, the team's general manager, put very little gilding on his prognosis for 1991.

title: INNOCENTS UNDONE
description: ALL GONE

title: Miss Pohs Wed To D. J. Supino
description: Linda Jill Pohs, a daughter of Jack Pohs of New York and the late Lorraine Pohs, was married yesterday to David James Supino, a son of the late Renato J. Supino and the late Muriel Davies Supino of Demarest, N.J. The ceremony was performed at Cobble Brook Farm, the bridegroom's country home in Kent, Conn., by William C. Gawel, a justice of the peace in Kent.

title: SUMMER INTHE CITY, OUT AT THE BALL PARK
description: NEW YORK has two baseball teams, in two different leagues, playing in two distinct parts of the city, in two very different parks.

title: A Writer's Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   A Penetrating 'Dark Elegies' In an All-Tudor Program
description: Antony Tudor's ballets have sometimes looked like artifacts that dancers dust off by performing. The all-Tudor evening presented by American Ballet Theater on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House was an exception. And it was heartening to hear the cheers that greeted ''Dark Elegies,'' never the most accessible of Tudor ballets.

title: The Outlook on Taxes
description: BUDGETS for every household and school district in the state will change in coming months as a result of higher income and sales taxes and the new school financing formula that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through the Legislature in late June with lightning speed.

title: Triple Play;   The Rich Nations Get Richer. And Then?
description: The currencies and economies of the two Germanys become one today, solidifying the German role as leader of a bloc of European states that are themselves rushing toward economic union and a closer political federation. And next week, the leaders of the seven strongest industrial democracies - the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - gather in Houston for an economic summit meeting to survey the problems and opportunities of a world changed in subtle and not-so-subtle ways. It is a world they helped make but never expected to see so soon.

title: THE ARTIST IS A PEST
description: THE SORROW OF BELGIUM

title: ANS SOME WORDS FOR THE CHILDREN
description: THE READING CRISIS

title: Campus Life: Chicago;   Last Semester On Horizon For 'Tornado Man'
description: Come December, students at the University of Chicago will no longer be able to take courses from a professor known as the ''Tornado Man.''

title: Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: One word: experience.

title: Local Golf Pros Will Test Major Seniors
description: LEAD: CHUCK WORKMAN is a trick- shot artist. He can hit a golf ball off a foot-high tee with a club that is taller than he is, and he can hit a ball 250 yards with a putter.

title: Michael Robert Sachs Weds Karen E. Ficco
description: Karen Elizabeth Ficco, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ficco of Franklin, Mass., and Michael Robert Sachs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brice A. Sachs of Convent Station, N.J., were married yesterday by the Rev. James O'Leary at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Franklin.

title: Wine;   The Spanish Acquisition
description: IT'S THE LEAST WE COULD DO. AFTER ALL , their guy discovered us.

title: Ms. Blewer Wed To Clayton Young
description: Cecilia Folger Blewer, a daughter of Sondra G. Blewer of New York and John M. Blewer of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York to Clayton Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lien Young of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Mary Foulke performed the ceremony.

title: LOVE, DEATH AND 'WHEN DO WE EAT?'
description: WOODY ALLEN: New Yorker. By Graham McCann. (Polity/Basil Blackwell, $24.95.) Like all great clowns, Allen Stewart Konigsberg wants to be taken seriously, and Graham McCann has granted his wish. In ''Woody Allen: New Yorker,'' the comic invention known as Woody Allen is scrupulously analyzed for what it may reveal about the cosmic tensions of our age. After more or less apologizing for the comedies that predate ''Annie Hall,'' Mr. McCann, who teaches social and political theory at the University of Cambridge, concentrates on Mr. Allen's later movies, in which the big questions of love, death and ''when do we eat?'' ceased to be funny and became, instead, occasions to preach the need for commitment, faith and family ritual. The author, with the help of Hobbes, Plato, Freud, Kafka, Foucault, Malraux, Rousseau, Baudelaire, DuBois (Blanche) and Wittgenstein, sees Mr. Allen's films as a search for a humane form of comedy that ''absorbs skepticism,'' permitting us to trust. Mr. McCann is a talented writer, but his prose sometimes reaches the kind of critical density that Mr. Allen has hilariously parodied, to wit: ''Jokes are obliged to compete in the market-place of pleasures associated with laughter, and for that reason their materials must be less privileged, less personally limited, and their ludicrous context must be wider than obtains in daily extemporaneous provocations to laughter.'' Woody, read it and weep.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Allowing Death to Arrive
description: LEAD: THE family council of my uncle's nursing home meets on the first Sunday of every month. It's one way to make sure of a family visit. The subject this month was D.N.R. - ''Do not resuscitate.'' D.N.R. could prevent your aunt or your mother from spending the rest of her days like a vegetable.

title: Summer Salads With Rice
description: USING rice as a basis for summer salads offers myriad possibilities. There are many varieties of rice, many of them delicious served at room temperature and they can be enhanced with scores of seasoning combinations.

title: On County's Posture Parkland
description: This is in response to a recent letter by Stephen L. Elkins, Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, in which he asserts that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has made it a priority of his administration to ''aggressively acquire and preserve public parkland and open spaces.'' The facts belie this.

title: Patrick Jones Jr. WedTo Katherine Mellon
description: Katherine Hopkins Mellon, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon 3d of Far Hills, N.J., and Northeast Harbor, Me., and the late Charles Henry Mellon 3d, was married yesterday to Patrick Suydam Jones Jr., the son of Mrs. J. Clark Grew of Lake Forest, Ill., and Northeast Harbor and the late Patrick Suydam Jones. The bridegroom's stepfather, the Rev. J. Clark Grew, and the Rev. Paul Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor.

title: SONIC YOUTH MAKES A GIANT NOISE WITH A LITTLE POP
description: Putdowns of Sonic Youth were being sharpened long before the band's new album, ''Goo'' (DGC/Warner Brothers 24297; all three formats), turned up in record stores. The obvious prejudgment was that Sonic Youth, after a prolific and lauded career on independent labels, was selling out - going pop - because it had moved to a major label, David Geffen's DGC, thus turning its back on all that was feisty and scruffy and true. ''Goo'' works overtime to say it ain't so.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Clinton, Conn. $152,000

title: What's Doing In;   Nairobi
description: For many travelers Nairobi is a necessary stop on the way in and out of the African bush. While a safari may be the point of the journey to Kenya, Nairobi is a bustling African city that can tell you much about the continent, past and present.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Good Place to Sample Thai Cuisine
description: LEAD: VIBRANT Thai cooking, with its contrasts of spicy and cool, sweet and acidic, seems custom-made for perking up languid summer palates. A few years ago, gastronomic gurus were predicting that the cuisine of Thailand would be the next hot - in both senses of the word - food trend to sweep the country.

title: In Soviet Town, ''Anton Druzhinin' Means Power
description: In this provincial city 50 miles northwest of Moscow, the Communist Party is not a platform, a faith or a movement. It is essentially Anton F. Druzhinin.

title: Christina Blossom and Peter Raymond Are Wed
description: Christina Morris Blossom, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John McLean Morris of Woodbridge, Conn., was married to Peter Dana Raymond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana M. Raymond of New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: No Big Problem
description: It was a kidney stone that felled Kurt Stillwell, not the herniated disk that was first feared, and the Kansas City Royals' shortstop could be back in the lineup today against the Tigers, the Royals said yesterday.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD: DOG HORSE RAT. By Christopher Davis. (Viking, $17.95.) Very little changes in the lives of Van and Royal West after Van kills the brilliant college student who interrupts them while they're burglarizing his family's summer home in rural New York. Local rednecks, Van and Roy work out a cover story about shooting in self-defense.

title: Northeast Notebook: Waterboro, Me.;   After 20 Years, Lake Makes It
description: It has taken 20 years, but a 3,200-lot subdivision encircling 2,600-acre Lake Arrowhead, a manmade body of water in this town of 3,000 people 30 miles west of Portland, has finally caught on.

title: County Center Adapts For Hearing Impaired
description: LEAD: AN infrared listening system to enable the hearing impaired to understand speech and music more clearly has been installed in the County Center in White Plains.

title: Style Makers;   Georgina Godley, Fashion Designer
description: When Georgina Godley says she likes fashion's fast track, she's not talking status: she's talking stadium. The 35-year-old designer has taken two high-tech fabrics from the world of athletics - Gore-Tex and Lycra - and woven them into a new collection she calls sport couture.

title: Fiddlers Gathering for 15th Celebration
description: LEAD: THE 15th Annual Fiddling Celebration gets under way Wednesday at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, an event that each year delights thousands of country, folk, swing, Cajun, Celtic, bluegrass and jazz enthusiasts.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: In the obscure corners of the game of bridge can be found some colorful terms. The geographer can find the Chinese finesse, the Curse of Scotland and the Alcatraz Coup. The historian uncovers Byzantine Blackwood, the Morton's Fork Coup, the Duke of Cumberland's Hand and the Merrimac Coup.

title: Ideas & Trends;   Mathematicians Take the Measure Of the Insoluable
description: WHEN physicists talk about large numbers, they speak of things like the number of years since the universe began - about 10,000,000,000 - or the number of atoms in the universe: 1 with 100 zeros after it. But when mathematicians speak of large numbers, they come up with figures that leave the physicists' in the dust. And these are not just arbitrarily large numbers cooked up to prove a point. These are numbers that turn up naturally at the heart of important problems that are simple to state but seemingly impossible to solve.

title: No Headline
description: AS THOUSANDS CHEER

title: Tennis on TV: Too Much Talk
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Time to Forgive, but Never Forget
description: This year marks the hundredth anniversary of the Dodgers' first season in the National League. I'm observing the occasion by forgiving the late Dodgers owner, Walter O'Malley, for moving the team from Brooklyn to Los Angeles in 1958. Don't laugh; this represents a big step in my life.

title: Varied Views On Gun Control
description: With great apprehension, I read the recent article ''Debate Over Gun-Control Bill Intensifies,'' about the proposed banning of ''assault type'' weapons (which was later passed by the Legislature).

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: N. Dartmouth, Mass.;

Four Anchors For Shopping
description: LEAD: STORES opening this month in a new 276,000-square-foot shopping center on Route 6 are the latest additions to an area that in recent years has become a retail hub for southeastern Massachusetts.

title: Miss Drexel Wed To W.J. O'Farrell
description: Noreen E. M. Drexel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel 3d of Newport, R.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and William John O'Farrell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William James O'Farrell of Brightwaters, L.I., were married yesterday in Sayles Hall, a chapel at Brown University. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Michael Phillips, a cousin of the bridegroom, assisted by the Rev. Henry G. Turnbull, an Episcopal priest.

title: Karen Winston WedTo David C. Norman
description: Karen Eve Winston, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jan M. Winston of Westport, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to David Charles Norman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alex Norman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the Mansion at Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: Hers;   Ladies' Compartment
description: BEFORE TRAVELING through India recently, I had asked a friend, an old India hand, how it was for a woman alone. ''As long as you dress modestly, you should have few hassles in India,'' she said. ''I never experienced any real problems.'' I found India a puzzlement in almost every way, but most troubling was the huge cultural gap between the way I am perceived in New York City and the way I was perceived there. In New York, people ask what I ''do.'' It can be an obnoxious question, especially for those between jobs, yet it implies a basic utility to civilization. In Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and India, on the other hand, I was asked four questions, usually in the same order: What is your country? Are you alone? Are you married? No children?

title: Amanda L. Crandall Weds Robert Anthony DeMar 3d
description: Amanda Louise Crandall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Crandall of Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Robert Anthony DeMar 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. DeMar Jr. of Lincolnville, Me. The Rev. Cynthia Jarvis officiated at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: 'The Loony-Bin Trip'
description: To the Editor:

title: Is U.S.-Japan Pact a Fair Trade?
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Brokerage House That Is Learning to Love Junk
description: The raucous trauma that began one year ago has littered Wall Street with ''junk bond'' victims. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is fast becoming a memory. First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody & Company, saddled with junk bonds and bridge loans they could not sell, had to shift some of their holdings to their well-financed parent companies. And recently two senior investment banking executives responsible for the junk-bond department at Merrill Lynch & Company were pushed aside and replaced by new bankers.

title: Tech Notes;   From Sikorsky, to Fly By
description: It looks like a space ship and its job is to snoop. The RPV Cypher (above) was designed by the Sikorsky helicopter subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation to be a pilotless surveillance drone. About six feet in diameter and weighing 300 pounds, the vehicle can take off and land vertically and hover over targets. Inside the donut-shaped vehicle are two rotors which turn in opposite directions. The Cypher is designed to cruise at 80 knots for up to four hours and to go as high as 8,000 feet. Two-way data links would allow ground controllers to fly it and receive data from its sensors.

title: Diana Fortuna, State Aide in Capital, Is Married to David Yassky, a Lawyer
description: Diana Fortuna, the daughter of Walter H. Fortuna of Lapeer, Mich., and the late Marilyn Fortuna, and David Yassky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Yassky of New York, were married yesterday at the Harvard Club in New York. An interfaith ceremony was performed by Cantor Bernard Gruber and the Rev. Salvatore Umana, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about Quebec's economy misstated the Canadian province's gross domestic product in 1989. It was $129 billion, not $120 billion. A table with the article also misstated the percentage that Quebec contributes to Canada's gross domestic product. It was 23.6 percent, not 22 percent.

title: Seattle's Succulent Clams
description: INSTEAD of being called the Emerald City, for its abundance of parks and surrounding woods, Seattle might as easily and accurately be referred to as the clam city. Not just for the abundance of the grayish- to white-shelled bivalves that snuggle into the substrate in Elliott Bay, Puget Sound and waters beyond, but because the clams turn up on the tables of restaurants and homes throughout the city.

title:
Your Own Account;

Loosening the 401 (k) Rules
description: LEAD: There's usually little to cheer about when the Internal Revenue Service issues regulations on what companies and individuals must do to comply with legislated tax changes.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: An Artist and His City: Titian in Venice
description: About the Titian show that is here at the Ducal Palace, through Oct. 7, it should first be said that ''The Venus of Urbino,'' from the Uffizi in Florence, is absent. ''The Rape of Europa'' has not made the trip from the Gardner Museum in Boston, nor have ''Diana and Actaeon'' and ''Diana and Callisto'' moved from the National Gallery in Edinburgh. The ''Fete Champetre'' from the Louvre, sometimes attributed not to Titian but to Giorgione, is still in the Louvre. And as for Titian's trio of Bacchanals - ''The Worship of Venus'' and ''Bacchanalia of Andros'' from the Prado and the ''Bacchus and Ariadne'' from the National Gallery in London - they have likewise stayed put.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD: THE JOURNEY FROM PRAGUE STREET. By Hana Demetz. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) This sequel to Hana Demetz's moving autobiographical novel, ''The House on Prague Street,'' begins just after World War II in Czechoslovakia, then moves with dazzling speed through rural Bavaria, Munich, New York City and Cambridge, Mass., finally ending in Bethlehem, Pa., in the present.

title: Compact Camcorders Slug It Out
description: It's been a five-year battle in which nobody budged. At first it seemed that only one of the two contending formats in the compact camcorder field could survive. But as interest in camcorders rises to its seasonal summer peak, strife continues between the eight-millimeter and the VHS-C camcorder formats. Moreover, both sides have bolstered their positions with innovative and attractive new models.

title: Prints and Drawings By Latin Americans
description: THE Housatonic Museum of Art's collection numbers more than 500 works. They run from African sculptures to Pop Art, from a Mughal painting to a figurative sculpture by Lee Bontecou, from Giorgio de Chirico to Alfonso Ossorio and from lesser Dutch masters to Leonard Baskin. It's quite a gamut.

title: D. M. Cross Weds Andrea Krahmer
description: Andrea Clem Krahmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes R. Krahmer of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to David McNeill Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. A. Cross of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Jon Walton performed the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: Allison Michelle Miller Is the Bride Of Philip Alexander Buchanan Cooper
description: Allison Michelle Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Miller of New York, was married yesterday to Philip Alexander Buchanan Cooper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Kirkland Cooper of Pembroke, Bermuda. The Rev. Herbert A. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Defiance of Kremlin's Control Is Accelerating in Soviet Asia
description: While Moscow tries to find an accommodation with the rebellious Baltic republics, the shift of political authority from the Gorbachev Government to the provinces is accelerating here in the Islamic heartland of Central Asia.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

They're Redesigning My Life
description: LEAD: I WAS desperate. I had to find a place to live. I discovered this gem of an apartment hiding in a three-story white stucco box. I moved in three days later.

title: Corrections
description: The Evening Hours column last Sunday misidentified the buyer of an $11,000 donation at the New York City Opera Guild benefit auction. He is Dr. Robert Levine, not Dr. Walter Levin.

title: Campus Life: Boston College;   Social Problems Are the Focus Of a New Program
description: It's summertime and a student's thoughts turn to sun, sand, surf - and social consciousness?

title: Comics' Heroes Are Dwarfed By Movies
description: Comic-strip heroes are everywhere in the movies this summer - everywhere, that is, except where you might expect to find them.

title: SCIENCE, SORCERY AND THE TROPICS
description: LAUGHING DEATH

title: FORECAST FOR 'TODAY': CLOUDY
description: As a longtime (and now former) ''Today'' show watcher, I can only agree with the conclusions drawn in your profile of host Bryant Gumbel. His competence has never been in question. But as long as his abilities continue to be overshadowed by his outsized ego, loyal viewers and distinguished colleagues alike will continue to drift away.

title: Uncertainty for a Village of Chair Makers
description: IN 1826, Lambert Hitchcock opened a chair factory in a little village in northwestern Connecticut that later came to be known as Hitchcocksville. While the name didn't stick, the fortunes of the Hitchcock Chair Company and the people of the village have remained deeply intertwined.

title: A. G. Sill Is WedTo Muna Shehadi
description: Muna Shehadi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fadlou Shehadi of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrews G. Sill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Davis A. Sill of Southport, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Henry Morris, a Lutheran minister, at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Gorbachev Reinstates Citizenship of 3 Exiles
description: The Soviet Union has restored the citizenship of three emigre dissidents punished on charges of anti-Soviet slander in the 1970's, the official press agency Tass reported today. It said the decision was made by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev after an inquiry.

title: Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival to Begin on Aug. 1
description: Performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, Gunther Schuller conducting Charles Mingus's ''Epitaphs,'' and a Roots of American Music Festival celebrating blues, gospel and folk music are among the highlights of the 20th-anniversary season of Lincoln Center's Out-of-Doors Festival, which will run from Aug. 1 to 27 on the center's plazas and in Damrosch Park.

title: Leyritz Powers Yank Victory
description: Seven runs should have been enough tonight, but remember, this is the Yankees. In their season of misfortune, they have never done anything easily. And so, after taking a 7-0 lead in the third inning, they went through a typical struggle.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: AFTER the fires of controversy cool, an artist too strongly identified with the struggles risks oblivion. Indeed, it often seems these days to Bernarda Bryson Shahn that not many remember Ben Shahn, her husband and once one of America's most popular painters, who spent the last three decades of his life in Roosevelt, where she still lives.

title: Brave New World Seen for Robots Appears Stalled by Quirks and Costs
description: Steve Antenen runs the nation's biggest employment agency for laid-off robots. He has 70 industrial robots for sale on the fringe of this riverside community between Cincinnati and Dayton. All look impeccable, most having worked no more than a few thousand hours before their former owners, some of the nation's leading companies, showed them the door.

title: Getting A Chance At Camp
description: LEAD: FOR the last few weeks, most children have been dreaming of a carefree summer filled with play and laugher. But for 85 homeless children living with their families in several motels that line Route 1 in the Princeton area, dreams are in short supply.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Equipment Drags on A.T.&T.
description: A generation ago, telephones were mostly black and square. Corporate switchboards were full of tiny gears and wheels like an alarm clock, and the equipment in telephone-company central offices was crammed with copper wiring. One company made almost all of it: Western Electric, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: More Say To Tenants, Advocate Suggests
description: LEAD: TO rid public housing of drugs and crime, residents have to play a larger role in running the buildings they live in, a nationally recognized tenant rights advocate has suggested to a conference here on community efforts to combat drugs.

title: Varied Views on Gun Control
description: It was with shock and horror that I read ''Debate Over Gun-Control Bill Intensifies.'' Why shock and horror? Because the Governor wants to supersede the United States Constitution. Mr. Florio, the states are subordinate to the Federal Government, not vice versa.

title: Catherine Carver Wed in Virginia
description: Catherine Ruth Carver and Robert Cuyler McCurrach were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger. Anne Swartz was the maid of honor, and the bridegroom's father was the best man.

title: Mandela Ends Tour of U.S. With Oakland Appearance
description: A weary Nelson Mandela ended a grueling eight-city American tour today, transformed into a popular hero hailed by millions who a few months ago were probably giving scant attention to apartheid in South Africa.

title: Wall Street;   A Little Bad News in Aviation Leasing
description: The unquestioned assumption underlying many real estate investments of the last decade was that assets would always increase in value. But a friendly takeover announced last week, the $1.3 billion purchase of the International Lease Finance Corporation by the American International Group, highlights another sort of collateral whose unfaltering appreciation has been an article of faith with some investors: airplanes.

title: Pave It Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera;   Moore's 'Carry Nation, A Prohibitionist's Story
description: Perhaps the only way for New York opera audiences to get a look at Douglas Moore's ''Carry Nation'' is in the kind of production offered by New York University at the Reimann Opera Theater on Thursday night. Well-intentioned, half-prepared and often misjudged, it did, however, give the listener an idea of what this 1966 stage piece had in mind and a few sporadic moments of pleasure as well.

title: Headliners;   Whose Habitat?
description: Environmentalists, ever wary of President Bush's insistence that he is really one of them, were delighted in mid-June when his Administration declared the spotted owl a threatened species. The Government was expected to follow the move last week with a sweeping plan to control cutting in the old-growth forests that serve as the owl's habitat. Instead the Administration formed a study group, to report to the President by Sept. 1, and called for changing the Endangered Species Act to take into account other endangered life forms - like loggers. Federal officials say saving the owl would cost 28,000 jobs in the Pacific Northwest over the next 10 years. Andy Kerr, conservation director of the Oregon Natural Resources Council, called the Bush proposal ''the Tiananmen Square for American wildlife.'' But Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said, ''We take the Endangered Species Act seriously and will implement the law faithfully. We have set in motion a process to balance our responsibility in preserving the owl and the forests while protecting the economic lives of American men and women who live and work in the region.''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I GREW up in New Jersey, though I've spent years trying to figure out ways to move my career to a wilder place, preferably somewhere out West or in the mountains of Appalachia. But in the process of learning about the birds, mammals and plants of the state, I've discovered that many acres of New Jersey stand up quite well in comparison with other parts of the country.

title: Syphilis Screening To Expand In County
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of a sharp rise in the number of syphilis cases in the county in the last three years, the State Department of Health is recommending an expansion of screening for the disease in Westchester.

title: Social Security Fund for Tuition Is Proposed
description: As many as nine million Americans at all income levels could pay for college and vocational training by borrowing from the Social Security surplus, under a newly proposed educational loan program.

title: Jane L. Sarkin Is Bride Of Martin O'Connor 2d
description: Jane Lauren Sarkin, the daughter of Elaine S. Zheutlin of Hillside, N.J., and the late Dr. Stanley K. Sarkin, was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Elizabeth, N.J., to Martin Bradley O'Connor 2d, a son of Mary Louise O'Connor of Elizabeth and the late Judge Richard R. O'Connor. The Rev. Edward J. Snyder officiated. Mrs. O'Connor, a graduate of the Pingry School and the University of Vermont, is the features editor at Vanity Fair magazine in New York. Her father was a dentist. The bridegroom, a partner in the law firm of O'Connor, Morss & O'Connor in Elizabeth, is a graduate of Pingry and of Johns Hopkins University, with a J.D. degree from Seton Hall University. His father was a judge of the Superior Court of Union County, N.J., and a commissioner of the New Jersey Highway Authority.

title: Maura Jane O'Shea Weds
description: Maura Jane O'Shea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene K. O'Shea of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew John Devey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Devey of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Albertine officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Katonah. Mrs. Devey, 24 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Catholic University. She teaches at the Concord Road Elementary School in Ardsley, N.Y. Mr. Devey, 24, graduated from Widener College. He is a sales representative for Prime Source, a building supply firm in West Haven, Conn.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Bumpy Road Ends at Budget for New York City
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Sunday about the negotiations over the New York City budget misidentified a City Council member from Staten Island. He is Alfred C. Cerullo 3d.

title: State System Of Hospital Rates Drawing Fire
description: LEAD: ONCE touted as a national model of how to contain health care costs, New Jersey's hospital rate-setting system is facing the heaviest fire of its 11-year history. Hospital executives, insurance representatives, doctors and patients say the setup has grown into a bureaucratic nightmare, faltering under its own weight.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: In mid-June the Eastman Kodak Company introduced a new line of 35-millimeter cameras, featuring compact size, soft-edged styling and easy-to-use controls. But what may be the cameras' most unusual selling point is their instruction books.

title: Debbie Marion Becomes Bride
description: Deborah Mary Marion, a daughter of Mary Anne Marion of New Canaan, Conn., and John L. Marion of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Brearton Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony S. Murray of Darien, Conn. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Judge Refuses to Prevent Deaths of Monkeys in Federal Laboratory
description: A nine-year battle by animal rights groups to free monkeys used in Government research has been dealt a setback with a Federal district judge's refusal to stop Government plans to put to death three monkeys at the center of the controversy.

title: here Mandela and Jews Agree to Disagree;   Empty Words
description: To the Editor:

title: FORECAST FOR 'TODAY': CLOUDY
description: Bill Carter's article ''Forecast for 'Today': Cloudy'' (June 10) was excellent, but it doesn't go far enough. The emotion isn't there and it really needs to be. There, in front of millions every morning - most of them women, and mothers - is this outrageous misogynist, Bryant Gumbel. We watched as Jane Pauley was removed from the show, only to be replaced by the kind of woman many women find most threatening - the eternal plastic blonde - who mindlessly defers to this locker-roomJU bully. Now he has increased his blondes (cheerleaders?) to two, and has brought on a sports pal. NBC, in its wisdom, has offered this audience of women - what? A sports show! Male indulgence stuffed down our throats at breakfast.

title: Varied Views on Gun Control
description: I am sure that all the citizens of New Jersey join me in thanking the legislators and the Governor for the enactment of the law banning the possession of ''assault rifles.'' We can all be relieved that the streets of this state are now safe from the indiscriminate slaughter of our population by the owners of these weapons.

title: Postings: Park Slope Project;   Co-oping a Milk Wagon Barn
description: It has been decades since most city residents had milk delivered to their homes and longer still since milkmen used horse-drawn wagons.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Not Everyone Is Amenable to Amenities
description: LEAD: TRICIA SCHEURER and her fiance, Peter Schifano, solved their housing problem last February by deciding to buy a $200,000, three-bedroom town house in a 359-unit Holbrook development called the Colony.

title:
FOCUS;

Kangaroo Rat Slows Southern California Housing
description: LEAD: Riverside County is coming to grips with the problem of the Stephens kangaroo rat. If its plan succeeds, it will be able to protect an endangered species without crippling its home-building industry.

title: Where Mandela and Jews Agree to Disagree
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Louise Peterson Weds Gerald L. Sauer
description: The Punahou School Chapel in Honolulu was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Karen Louise Peterson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Peterson of Kailua, Hawaii, to Gerald Louis Sauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sauer of St. Louis. The Rev. John Heidel, a Congregational minister and the school's chaplain, performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Dance;   Darci Kistler as Swan Queen
description: There were unfamiliar dancers in two familiar works at the New York City Ballet's performance on June 23 at the New York State Theater.

title: Nan Rosengarten Weds Soeren Jensen
description: Nan Rosengarten, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Rosengarten of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Soeren Vagn Jensen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ole Vagn Jensen of Holsted, Denmark, were married yesterday. The civil ceremony was performed at the Copenhagen City Hall.

title: Early Opera Is the Latest Rage on Disks
description: Contrary to grim prognostications, opera is alive and well as it approaches the end of its fourth century. And while it is true that only relatively few modern works have attained repertory status, our generation has turned toward opera's first and second centuries with remarkable industry and concentration. Monteverdi, Cavalli, Handel, Lully, Rameau and Paisiello have become festival fare all over Europe and even in America and, for a broader audience, recorded documentation assures their permanence.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on June 17 about maps misstated the address for the 14th Street-Union Square business improvement association. It is at 124 East 15th Street, New York, N.Y. 10003.

title: Milton Filker, Labor Organizer, 73
description: Milton Filker, retired president of Council 52 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in Jersey City, died on Thursday at his home in Jersey City. He was 73 years old.

title: The Region;   Lawmaking In Suffolk: The Unusual As Usual
description: THERE they go again, said followers of the Suffolk County Legislature recently when its members passed the toughest local newspaper recycling legislation in the country. Business groups said the bill was an ill-conceived headline-grabber; environmental groups applauded it as a far-thinking way to help solve the county's garbage crisis.

title: Nostalgia Can Choke the Ongoing Stream of Your Life
description: Got any old bourbon bottles around the house? Empty cigarette packs? Cheap perfume bottles? Any junk left over from the 50's and 60's? Throw it out, quick. Otherwise somebody is likely to convince you that the detritus of popular culture from these two decades is worth saving, worth cataloguing, worth - I hate even to use the word - collecting. And if once you start to think this way nostalgia will choke the ongoing stream of your life, like kudzu in a Southern waterway. The whole notion of junk will be challenged. You will never be able to clean a basement or an attic again. Do I exaggerate? Am I extreme in considering the idea of ''collectibles'' to be a hazard on the same order as global warming? I think not.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD: RULING PASSIONS. By Susan Crosland. (Holt, $17.95.) As the widow of Anthony Crosland, one of Britain's most distinguished postwar cabinet ministers, Susan Crosland is on the inside political track. That she herself is a journalist and author makes her equally well placed in the newspaper and publishing worlds.

title: Robert T. Weltchek, Mayor, 65
description: Robert T. Weltchek, a former municipal judge and mayor of Springfield Township, N.J., died on Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit. He was 65 years old.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Cramming for the Vacation
description: LEAD: AS moviegoers, my husband and I have radically different styles. I read all the reviews and seek out the opinions of friends. Even before I've forked over the equivalent of the price of two good paperback books for my ticket, I can tell you not only who's in it and what it's about, but why the climactic scene in the shoe-polish factory doesn't work and what this particular flick is going to do for the director's career.

title: Sarah Paul WedsA. C. Bentley 2d
description: Sarah Paul, the daughter of Manuela Yona Paul of Brooklyn, N.Y., and the late David Tyler Paul of Chestnut Hill, Pa., was married yesterday to Alden Cody Bentley 2d, a son of Capt. and Mrs. Paul Cody Bentley 2d of New Hope, Pa., in a Quaker ceremony at Buckingham Friends Meeting in Lahaska, Pa.

title: Power Authority to Offer Energy-Saving Plan
description: The state agency that supplies power to downstate government agencies is arranging an energy-conservation program for its customers, picking the equipment, helping to install it and providing full financing for the purchase of efficient lighting equipment.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: How Will We Remember Mama?
description: I ONCE read that Johnny Carson added a codicil to his will stating if any of his sons dared write a book telling all, that son would be automatically cut out of his will. And do you remember what happened to Bette Davis, not to mention Bing Crosby? And who could forget Patti's book about Ron and Nancy?

title: Commercial Property: An Agenda for the 90's;   What the Real Estate Board Is Seeking in Incentives
description: IN what amounts to a platform for the economically troubled 1990's, New York's major owners and developers have asked City Hall for incentives that would make it more profitable to renovate existing office buildings or turn them into apartments, spur construction of back-office or other commercial space and reward landlords or builders who provide space for not-for-profit organizations and local services.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our kitchen cabinets are covered with a walnut-tone plastic laminate that we dislike. We would like to paint over it, and were wondering what kind of paint to use. If we do not like the paint after it is applied, will this make it more difficult to remove the old laminate later on if we decide to replace it?

title: Review/Dance;   The Gail Conrad Company In a Small-Scale Potpourri
description: Gail Conrad's new group, Dance Motel, squeezed its way onto a tiny stage at Birdland on Thursday night and looked perfectly at home there. That was just what Ms. Conrad wanted. Dance Motel is a company specifically intended for small spaces, and it had no trouble with Birdland's cramped quarters. One can even imagine it on a coffee table or a postage stamp.

title: A Third Midway Sailor Dies
description: A sailor who suffered critical burns and internal injuries in the June 20 explosion and fire aboard the aircraft carrier Midway has died, bringing to three the toll of those killed by the accident. The 22-year-old sailor, Robert Shane Kilgore of Simi Valley, Calif., died late Wednesday at Brooke Army Medical Center here.

title: This Alter Ego Helps Scripts Be Psychologically Sound
description: In the opulently appointed Beverly Hills offices of the Larry Thompson Organization, a story meeting is in progress. Mr. Thompson, an independent producer of TV movies, is developing an idea about a woman in trouble. Robert Kosberg, a Thompson protege, is doing most of the talking, while Dr. Carole Lieberman, a psychiatrist, listens, notepad in hand. The presentation is long, convoluted and rapid-fire, wound around a housewife whose mounting frustrations summon an unlikely disorder called psychogenic fugue. The producers first encountered the concept of fugue, a mental state akin to amnesia in which victims flee their lives by assuming new personalities, in a book about psychological casualties of war.

title: Susan C. Najafi Wed in Carolina
description: Susan Christine Najafi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hassan Najafi of Northfield, Ill., was married yesterday in Durham, N.C., to Dr. Andrew Michael Davidoff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Davidoff of New York. The Rev. Donald Fagerberg, a Lutheran minister, and Rabbi Milton Schlager performed the ceremony in the chapel of Duke University.

title: Maggie Scott Is Married to Michael David Hanna
description: Margaret Louise Scott, a daughter of Mrs. John Julian Scott of Garden City, L.I., and the late Dr. Scott, was married yesterday to Michael David Hanna, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian David Hanna of Belfast, Northern Ireland. The Very Rev. Robert Vidal Wilshire, Dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, where the Episcopal ceremony was performed, was assisted by the Canon F. Anthony Cayless.

title: Parents Scrambling For Summer Child Care
description: LEAD: FOR the past several months, Michelle O'Donnell, of Mystic, has been trying to complete her summer plans. She has not been searching for possible vacation spots, though. Ms. O'Donnell has been looking for someone to take care of her two sons, ages 5 years and 6 months, so she can return to work.

title: 'Quieter' Hamptons Fight To Retain Rural Qualities
description: LEAD: SHIMMERING ocean beaches and jazzy nightclubs juxtaposed with the quiet country life attract droves of vacationers to the Hamptons each summer.

title: Book Club for Blacks Finds Quick Support
description: BOOKSTORES kept making Janus Adams angry. Wherever she looked, the well-stocked shelves were virtually devoid of books by black authors or about black people and the black experience.

title: Traffic Alert
description: The Avenue of the Americas will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. from 35th to 50th Streets for the Avenue of the Americas Festival.

title: Lifestyle;   The Vanities, They Were Oh So Tepid
description: The rich of New York are decamping for their summer capital on the South Shore of Long Island and other watering holes, signifying the end of what is quaintly called the spring social season, although the revels spill over into summer. Some season. ''Was there a season this year?'' asked Bill Blass, who knows better. He ran a recent gala for the Hospital for Special Surgery, one of the season's few big benefits for which tickets sold out.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   At Hotels, Eclectic and International Fare
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some restaurants in hotels that are open for Sunday dining.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: Currency;   Canada's Dollar Holds Firm
description: So much for Meech Lake. That accord, meant to be a constitutional bridge tying French-speaking Quebec to English-speaking Canada, disolved last weekend. But the financial markets have felt nary a ripple. For the week, the Canadian dollar - still supported by high interest rates - was up 1 percent at 1.1633 to the dollar. The Toronto stock index on Friday was up 14.01 to 3544.6, an increase of 1.5 percent for the week. President Bush's acceptance of the possibility of a tax increase weakened the United States dollar against major currencies at the end of the week. And looking ahead to an economically united Germany, East German marks were to begin trading for West German marks today, an event currency traders will watch carefully.

title: THE FIRST JEFFERSONIAN
description: EMPIRE OF LIBERTY

title: In Thicket of Environmental Policy, Bush Uses Balance as His Compass
description: President Bush's decisions on knotty environmental problems, like those he made this week on offshore oil drilling and the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest, show a strong tendency to placate opposing interests and to soften the impact of difficult political calls.

title: 'My Fair Lady' Sparkles in Candlewood Staging
description: SINCE Rick Belzer took over as executive producer, artistic director and resident lighting designer seven years ago, the Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield has been displaying a sleek technical skill uncommon in professional summer stock theaters.

title: A Guidebook to the Soul Of a City in Confusion
description: Tward the end of John Guare's new play, ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' a young man named Rick takes center stage to describe the horrors that have befallen him in New York City. Rick, played by Paul McCrane, is a struggling actor who had hit town from Utah with visions of stardom. But now his eyes fight back tears, his mouth weakens with revulsion. Seduced and then discarded by a flashy confidence man who did him out of his money and sexual innocence at the Rainbow Room, Rick finds himself without means, without prospects, without self-respect and possibly without the devoted girlfriend he shunted aside for a reckless one-night stand.

title: Amazon Cruises
description: To the Editor: Your reply to the lady from Rego Park (Q & A, May 6) inquiring about Amazon river cruises was most informative but, unfortunately, failed to include the company that introduced cruising on the Amazon seven years ago and today operates more cruises there than any other line.

title: 'These People' Are Ruining Our Lives?
description: THERE'S a ghost haunting Long Island. Like most, it generally comes out at night, but this one prefers lighted rooms to dark paths, public meeting rooms to lonely beach cottages.

title: Women's Colleges Have Much to Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane Elizabeth NusbaumWeds Richard M. Feller
description: Jane Elizabeth Nusbaum, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Nusbaum of Buffalo, was married there last evening at the Kleinhans Music Hall to Richard Mark Feller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Feller of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Mason officiated.

title: On the Ice Continent
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation;   Old Glory: The Saga Of a National Love Affair
description: THE failed attempt in Congress in the last two weeks to enact a Constitutional amendment concludes, at least for now, the latest effort to use the law to protect the American flag from unpopular uses. But as in the past, more has been at issue than a neutral desire to defend what many have called a unique symbol of our existence as a nation. Battles over the flag have almost always been battles over how to define patriotism and, by implication, how to define America.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: From Jailhouse to Art

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. ALAN M. GOLDSTEIN;

Sorting Out a Defendant's State of Mind
description: LEAD: A PORT CHESTER woman accused of killing four children in May was recently declared mentally unfit to stand trial, based on the opinions of two psychiatrists. What does such an evaluation mean? How do the experts who advise the judge make their recommendations? What is the role of psychologists and psychiatrists in the courtroom?

title: Some Updates Unwelcome in New Encyclopedia
description: It took more than two decades for major league baseball to anoint the Baseball Encyclopedia, the venerable tome published by Macmillan, as ''the complete and official record of major league baseball.''

title: When an Opera Is Transformed Into a Dance
description: Although operas throughout musical history have contained dance sequences, our own century has seen the emergence of the totally danced opera. Such a transformation of an opera retains all its arias and choruses; the singers, however, are relegated to the orchestra pit or to the sides of the stage, and the dramatic action is entrusted to dancers. In the best danced operas, movement and music are so allied that each art enhances the other.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: What can - and does - happen to people who own a second home? Well, to start with, how about the en route hazard of traffic backed up to you-don't-even-want-to-think-where?

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Helping Transferred Employees to Move
description: LEAD: WHEN Dick Dwyer became sales manager for Eastman Kodak, he was transferred from the company's headquarters in Rochester, N.Y., to its regional offices in Manhattan. The promotion also required him to move closer to his new job.

title: Rocco Laterzo 2dWeds Gary Ryan
description: Mina Gary Ryan, a daughter of Mina H. Ryan and John M. Ryan, both of Norfolk, Va., was married there yesterday to Rocco A. Laterzo 2d, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Laterzo Sr. of Sherborn, Mass. Bishop A. Heath Light of the Diocese of Southwestern Virginia performed the ceremony at Christ and St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture in the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about the Brancacci Chapel in Florence carries an incorrect caption in some copies.

title: Let's Stop Selling Cancer to Children
description: Each day the merchants of nicotine lose more than five thousand customers who either die or quit. To replace these lost consumers, the tobacco industry spends billions to hook kids on cigarettes - since they know that half of all adult smokers started smoking by age 13, and that a full one-quarter started by age 11.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milwaukee;

Old Factories, New Visions
description: LEAD: THIS city and its suburbs have begun acquiring dormant industrial sites through negotiation or condemnation in the hope of turning those reminders of the area's manufacturing heritage into business or light-industry parks.

title: Food;   By The Charcoal's Red Glare
description: AFTER THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE WAS written in 1776, John Adams declared that America's birthday should be celebrated with ''pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports, guns, bells, bonfires and illuminations, from one end of this continent to the other, from this time forward for evermore.''

title: In the Arts, Tomorrow Begins With Yesterday
description: LEAD: ''Make it new,'' said Ezra Pound. ''Astonish me,'' said Gertrude Stein, and an answering chorus of those who also believed that the future should be today raised the banner of originality and innovation with the dawn of the 20th century. But now that we've reached the 1990's, it's nostalgia that's news.

title: 'Fair Lady' Sparkles in Candlewood Staging
description: SINCE Rick Belzer took over as executive producer, artistic director and resident lighting designer seven years ago, the Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield, Conn., has been displaying a sleek technical skill uncommon in professional summer-stock theaters.

title: Surprise Messenger
description: Rory Sparrow learned from a stranger that the Miami Heat had traded him to the Sacramento Kings.

title: American Blacks Talk of Change As Main Legacy of Mandela Visit
description: With the euphoria of his visit here still dominating her thoughts, Pearl Cleage is thinking about life after Nelson Mandela.

title: The Dicey Future at Chase Manhatan
description: The 1980's were a lost decade for the Chase Manhattan Corporation. It lost status, becoming merely the 32d-largest banking company in the world. It lost its top credit rating. And by the end of the decade it was even losing money.

title: Men vs. Women
description: To the Editor:

title: New& Noteworthy
description: AGENT OF INFLUENCE, by David Aaron. (Avon, $4.95.) A big-time mergers-and-acquisitions specialist discovers that his client, a wealthy Frenchman trying to take over the largest communications empire in the United States, is an agent for the K.G.B. Last year our reviewer, Donovan Fitzpatrick, called the novel ''an 'econo-thriller,' a frightening journey through the netherworld of corporate raiding, financial espionage, leveraged buyouts, scorched-earth maneuvers, poison pill ploys and Wall Street esoterica.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: In Japan, Tours On Layovers At Narita

title: A Rocky Journey For U.S. Cyclist
description: ''So you made it back to the Tour de France?'' an acquaintance asked Andy Bishop. ''It wasn't easy.''

title: U.S. Gets 100,000 Acres in Largest Gift of Land
description: More than 100,000 acres of wildlife refuges and historic areas, including the site of the bloodiest day of fighting of the Civil War, are to be given to the Federal Government on Tuesday in what officials believe is the largest single gift of land ever made to the nation.

title: Q and A
description: Volunteers at Parks in U.S.

title: Photo: Chaba Fadela performing at the club S.O.B. in Manhattan. (Jack Vartoogian)Review/Disco;   Arabic Funk Sound From Algeria
description: Around the world, traditional music is meeting and transforming Western pop. In Algeria, the result is rai, the Arabic funk that Cheb Sahraoui and his wife, Chaba Fadela, brought to S.O.B.'s on Wednesday and Thursday nights. It is music in which the melody lines are unmistakably from the Arab world - fervently sung, intricately inflected - while the backup meshes traditional rhythms with Western dance beats and instruments. ''Cheb'' and ''chaba'' mean ''young,'' and rai is clearly the music of an urban, modernizing generation. The lyrics are said to be daringly intimate for Islamic music; in translation on the couple's new album, ''Hana Hana'' (Mango/Island), they are declarations of fiery love and jealousy.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Data Bank/July 1, 1990
Wall Street;   Who Is Causing the Selling Pressure at AT&E?
description: Everyone agrees that the next few months will be critical for the AT&E Corporation, the San Francisco company that will finally start marketing its wristwatch paging device in Portland, Ore., in the next few weeks. Even if the long-promised product works, of course, the company's optimism about sales might not be borne out, but a flop would make disputes over sales projections totally moot.

title: Marybeth Longobardi Weds
description: Marybeth Longobardi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Longobardi of Crestwood, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Mountain Lakes, N.J., to Brandon J. Smith, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ledyard H. Smith of Parsippany, N.J. The Rev. Joseph J. Garbarino officiated. Mrs. Smith, a magna cum laude graduate of Boston College, is an assistant vice president at CIT Group/Equipment and Project Financing in New York. The bridegroom, a graduate of Villanova University, is the equipment operations manager at the CIT Group, which provides financing for industrial projects.

title: Ann Carey Weds In East Hampton
description: At the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton, L.I., yesterday, Ann C. Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Ward Carey of New York and East Hampton, was married to J. Christophe Loisel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Loisel of Brive-la-Gaillarde, France. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph V. Gallagher.

title: THE VOLTAIRE PROJECT: A COLLECTOR'S OBSESSION
description: I'm sure I must have heard his name a few times as I was growing up, but I don't think I ever actually read anything by Voltaire until the early 1960's when, as a halfhearted graduate student of English literature, carefully husbanding a student deferment during the Vietnam War days, I was assigned an essay comparing ''Candide'' and Samuel Johnson's ''Rasselas.'' Both books had first appeared in 1759. I went on to learn a good deal more about Dr. Johnson, but Voltaire had served his purpose, and was forgotten.

title: Yachting Cutdown
description: The list of teams endorsed to compete to be defender of the America's Cup has been cut from nine to the final four, the San Diego Yacht Club announced Friday. All of the groups are based in San Diego.

title: ADVICE FORMTHE TEACHERS
description: TEACHERS AT WORK

title: Eli Whitney Debevoise Dies at 90; Co-Founder of a Top Law Firm
description: Eli Whitney Debevoise, a prominent New York lawyer who served in numerous government posts, died in his sleep early yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90 years old.

title: John Kelly Weds Donna A. Shipley
description: Donna Anne Shipley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Shipley of Gardiner, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to John Matthew Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Kelly of Yonkers. The Rev. Brian C. Brennan officiated. Mrs. Kelly, 27 years old, is a cum laude graduate of Manhattanville College. Until recently she was a regional sales manager in unit investment trusts at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. Her father is the president of WFF Inc., a jewelry design and importing concern in Woodstock, N.Y. Her mother, Marianne Shipley, is an artist.

title: The World;   Without Yeltsin Is the Party Over?
description: ALTHOUGH he presides over three-fourths of the Soviet land mass and is probably the most popular Communist in the country, Boris N. Yeltsin does not expect a place of honor at his party's quinquennial reunion this week.

title: Outdoors;   Huge Salmon Is Allowed to Get Away
description: The largest Atlantic salmon ever caught in North America was hooked, landed and released by Ken Jamieson of Houston on the evening of June 23. Jamieson was fly fishing the ledge area of Cross Point Pool on the Ristigouche River in New Brunswick, Canada, about 35 miles upstream from where the river enters the Baie des Chaleurs.

title: Bye, Linden Tree
description: PROGRESS is always a relative thing. We value the improved quality of life it promises, yet lament when in its name the quality of life is diminished.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PYROTECHNIC DISPLAYS

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

On the Fourth, It Was a Grand Old Block
description: LEAD: MY memories of the Fourth of July are a collage, pictures of the moments that made up the annual block party that ran through my life up until last year: shopping at the local 5 & 10 cent store for a 7-year-old-sized hula skirt to go with the Hawaiian motif; watching my father and his best friend, our next-door neighbor, build a mini-rocket launcher out of boards left over from their fence-building project: fitting my knees under the plywood luau table filled with foods representing the various ethnic backgrounds of the neighbors; standing in my driveway with my friends, pleading with the s

title: Edward A. Spitz, Publisher, 88
description: Edward A. Spitz, founder of Guest Informant, a directory of tourist information distributed in 1,400 hotels across the country, died June 23 at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 88 years old and lived in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Patricia Grise Is Wed To Alexander E. Lloyd
description: Patricia Karen Grise, a daughter of Theresa A. Grise of Fairfield, Conn., and John P. Grise of Hartford was married in New York yesterday to Alexander Edward Lloyd, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger H. Lloyd of London. The Rev. Eugene G. Connolly performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Campus Life: Minnesota;   Female Dancers Banned at Games Of Men's Teams
description: The University of Minnesota has banned its dance line of 16 women from men's athletic events because the performances ''sexually stereotyped'' them. The women said they should decide that for themselves.

title: The Nation;   Why Patronage is Unlikely to Fade Away
description: POLITICAL patronage has often been pronounced dead, the victim of Civil Service laws, the merit system and modern political marketing that enables political candidates to bypass party leaders and appeal directly to voters.

title: Fashion;   Summer Heat Cure: the Cool of Silver
description: Silver and summer seem to go together like sand and surf. There's a lightness about the look of silver jewelry that complements lightweight clothing, especially this year's stark black and white styles.

title: Repairing Wobbly Wooden Fences
description: WOBBLY wooden fence posts should be repaired promptly before they cause other fence parts to loosen. Posts that have been in the ground for less than five years usually wobble because of improper installation; ordinarily, tightening them is fairly easy. In older fences, decay is more likely the culprit. Although strengthening a decayed post sometimes works, the best solution is to replace it.

title: SNEAKING OUT FOR A BACON BUTTY
description: THE FOLKS THAT LIVE ON THE HILL

title: Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: 1)Get someone who understands international business and sports marketing. The World Cup is the biggest sporting event in the world, and corporate affiliations can be used to generate funds for the United States program. But the current soccer leadership cannot even decide on a mascot.

title: ARTIFACTS FROM AFRICA SHOW THE SHAPE OF A PEOPLE
description: Many of the artifacts of Zaire on view at the American Museum of Natural History - curious people-shaped boxes, flamboyant feathered hats, exotic harps and fetish necklaces - are being shown for the first time since they were collected in Africa 75 years ago.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

WITH LAWRENCE BEFORE ARABIA
description: LEAD: DREAMING OF SAMARKAND. By Martin Booth. (Morrow, $19.95.) This intensely written, elaborately furnished novel by the author of the well-received ''Hiroshima Joe'' imagines the final years of James Elroy Flecker (1884-1915), a minor English poet, novelist and playwright who was determined to become ''like Keats, an English expatriate poet'' while toiling in the Levant Consular Service.

title: WHAT'S NEW AT FRISBEE U.
description: I found much to admire in the philosophy of education at Hampshire College (''What's New at Frisbee U.,'' by Chip Brown, June 10). The Frisbee image is one well abandoned, but the more rigid curriculum is a change to be approached with caution. America's colleges and universities are doing a fine job of shunting students into the myriad career tracks that have developed in our fin de siecle economy. Our doctors, lawyers, bankers, politicians and other professionals excel at operating within the strictures of tradition and self-centered economics. All too often, however, they work unburdened by concerns for moral, social or historical repercussion. They don't waste much energy taking chances on untried possibilities. The complexities of such reflection can slow down a day's work, even throw a career off track.

title: A Holistic Approach to Animal Medicine
description: PATIENTS of Dr. Stephen Tobin never have to worry about crowded waiting rooms. The Meriden veterinarian prefers to travel to the homes of ailing dogs, cats and other pets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a network schedule change, a picture caption on the Sunday Highlights page of the Television section today and an evening program listing carry outdated entries for CBS at 9 P.M. The TV film to be shown is ''Desperate for Love.''

title: Subway Service Disrupted
description: There will be no uptown subway service and limited downtown service on the West Side IRT's Nos. 1, 2 and 3 lines between 42d and 96th Streets until 5 A.M. tomorrow. The disruptions are due to a switch replacement.

title:
Charles F. Cummings;

State History Questions? Just Ask Him
description: LEAD: ASK librarians to vote on who comes closest to having an encyclopedic knowledge about New Jersey, and the likely winner would be Charles F. Cummings of the Newark Public Library. As a modest, scholarly man, however, he will be the first to challenge that characterization.

title: Rajen Dalal Wed To Linda Burch
description: Linda Marie Burch, a daughter of Rosemary Lenrow of Westport Point, Mass., and Robert A. Burch of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday at her mother's home to Rajen Kantilal Dalal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kantilal Delal of New Dehli. The Rev. J. Patrick Mauney, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: The Executive Computer;   Does Software Lose Credibility When It's Inexpensive?
description: How much is software worth? Is a $5,000 accounting program 100 times better than a $50 accounting program? Those are among the questions raised by Pacioli 2000, a new $49.95 accounting package for personal computers from, or compatible with those from, the International Business Machines Corporation. Pacioli appears to be the equal of other high-end accounting programs in every way but cost.

title: A 72 and 15 Stitches for Dent
description: Jim Dent will be going into the final round of the United States Senior Open on Sunday only a shot behind the lead, but his chances of playing at all almost vanished as a result of a hand injury before the third round today.

title: In Mexico, a Peasant Theater Puts Life on Stage
description: As theaters go, it is humble indeed: a clearing in the forest, some planks nailed together, a sound and light booth halfway up a tree, a few rudimentary props fashioned from wood and cloth. Making a virtue of necessity, the Peasant and Indigenous People's Theater Laboratory of Tabasco has become one of Latin America's most acclaimed and influential dramatic troupes by stripping away artifice and returning to theater's roots in storytelling.

title: Evening Hours;   Ashore, Afloat, Art Is Enriched By Merriment
description: Brooke Astor and Helen Hayes joined hands in Miss Hayes's rose garden above the Hudson River in Nyack, N.Y., Wednesday night to raise money for the restoration of the Tappan Zee Playhouse. The evening began with Mrs. Astor sailing up the Hudson with 105 of her friends and guests aboard the Imperator, Arthur Imperatore's 142-foot yacht, donated for the evening. Miss Hayes, meanwhile, gathered 125 of her Hudson Valley neighbors and an impressive roster of theater people in the terraced gardens outside her 19th-century house, Pretty Penny, to await the Astor contingent.

title: More Pitfalls in Life Insurance Investing
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our kitchen cabinets are covered with a walnut-tone plastic laminate that we dislike. We would like to paint over it, and were wondering what kind of paint to use. If we do not like the paint after it is applied, will this make it more difficult to remove the old laminate later on if we decide to replace it?

title: On Language;   Drop the Gun, Louie
description: IN THE WASHINGTON bureau of The New York Times hangs a framed poster titled ''Boulevard of Broken Dreams.'' It is a painting by Gottfried Helnwein - inspired by the nostalgia and realism in Edward Hopper's painting ''Nighthawks'' - of four legendary people in a dreary diner at night.

title: Forecast: Cloudy;   Bush Moves His Lips But Not His Troops
description: BENEATH their public optimism about striking a deal to reduce the budget deficit, the negotiators from the White House and Congress are uneasy. President Bush's surprising concession last week that higher taxes would be needed to cut the deficit got the budget talks started again. But even the President's reversal of his ''no new taxes'' pledge will not translate quickly into an agreement on increased taxes and reduced spending.

title: Shift in Suffolk Water Agency Points Up Role in Planning
description: LEAD: THE appointment of Michael A. LoGrande last week to a seat on the five-member Suffolk County Water Authority has turned up the pressure in an agency that supplies a million county residents with water and is currently being shaken by charges of improprieties against its chairman, Leon Campo.

title: Germans Revel as Economies Unite
description: At the stroke of midnight, East Germany today formally ceded its currency and economy to West Germany. Thousands of East Germans gathered in the center of the city broke into cheers, firecrackers popped and car horns blared.

title: Striking Performances Light Up 'Othello'
description: IT may be the same old story, but images appear anew and insights abound.

title: Review/Music;   A Flutist In Debut At Carnegie
description: It is probably fair to assume that Linda Eagleson, a flutist, was not at her best in her New York debut recital on June 23 at Weill Recital Hall. Fully 25 minutes after the concert was to start, the audience was informed that Ms. Eagleson's pianist, Ron Levy, had just arrived and was changing clothes.
