(The reason, Carnegie Hall employees said, was heavy traffic from New Jersey, which hardly qualifies as an act of God.) Such a wait would be enough to put any performer on edge.

title: When Life Was Slow and Mellow
description: TRY to remember a time when ''The Fantasticks'' was not a staple part of the American theatrical scene.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 1, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 6 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.95.) Chinese-American women and their mothers. 2 2 THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Bantam, $5.95.) Glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain. 3 1 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) The murder of a gossip writer in New York. 4 1 CAPITAL CRIMES, by Lawrence Sanders. (Berkley, $5.95.) A self-anointed messiah disrupts political and social life in Washington. 5 2 GARDEN OF LIES, by Eileen Goudge. (Signet/ NAL, $5.95.) The destinies of two women. 6 1 MURDER AT THE KENNEDY CENTER, by Margaret Truman. (Fawcett, $5.95.) The death of an aide to a Presidential candidate. 7 5 CREATURE, by John Saul. (Bantam, $4.95.) A siege of horror besets a high school football team. 8 5 DAY OF THE CHEETAH, by Dale Brown. (Berkley, $5.50.) America vs. a K.G.B. mole. 9 9 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 8 THE T-FACTOR FAT GRAM COUNTER, by Jamie Pope-Cordle and Martin Katahn. (Norton, $2.50.) Ways to reduce fat in one's diet.

title: PROFIT KEY WINS
description: Profit Key, the lone front-runner in a field of four, led all the way to win the $171,600 Dwyer Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park, but gave those who backed him at 3-5 some anxious moments.

title:
ART;

Eye-Opening Show of Hungarian Painting
description: LEAD: UNTIL very recently, an exhibition entitled ''Two Hundred Years of Hungarian Painting'' would have walked away with an obscurity prize. Now, because of all the attention focused on Eastern Europe, such a show is the height of relevancy.

title: Bensonhurst Jurors Irk Judge
description: Justice Thaddeus E. Owens yesterday testily explained for the ninth time the legal definition of riot to the jury deliberating the fate of the Bensonhurst defendant John S. Vento.

title: Days of Giants, Bummers and Dopes
description: No, it isn't myth, or the nostalgic yearning of elder or eldest codgers. The Golden Age of sport in New York did exist, not in the 20's, but in the 30's, the late 40's and the 50's, right up to a year on which I still block (when we awoke to discover that sport was only business, albeit the world's oldest business). So, as that radio man said, let us return to the thrilling days of yesteryear (behind the greenback curtain).

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our kitchen cabinets are covered with a walnut-tone plastic laminate that we dislike. We would like to paint over it, and were wondering what kind of paint to use. If we do not like the paint after it is applied, will this make it more difficult to remove the old laminate later on if we decide to replace it?

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bayville $255,000

title: Women's Colleges Have Much to Offer;   Equal Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Works in Progress;   Malodorous
description: THE METAPHOR IS TRIED AND true, the villain as stinker. But it is the literal reality that is exploited by new devices that detect the work of drug traffickers and terrorists. ''The vapors of drugs or explosives get on everything,'' says David H. Fine. ''The equivalent is a foul smell. If you kill a skunk on the highway, you can smell it on your car for days.''

title: Review/Dance;   A Lampoon By Tudor
description: As it grows older in changing times, Antony Tudor's ''Gala Performance'' has come to look more like a frivolous bonbon than the flinty commentary on ballet manners and tradition that it was doubtless meant to be. But the dancers who performed the Tudor-Prokofiev work on Monday night, when American Ballet Theater presented it at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the most part made the ballet work on that level.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: If the American players can afford to continue playing, the team will be in its prime in 1994. More important than improving our team, however, is the need to educate the American public about soccer and the international importance of the World Cup, to which we will be playing host in four years.

title: No Headline
description: 'VOTES FOR ALL'

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   New Potatoes, With Broccoli and Corn
description: This is the moment of the just-dug tiny new potatoes, which, like tomatoes in season, should be purchased frequently and eaten with gusto. If you cannot find wonderfully sweet corn, it is better to use frozen ears than to suffer with the starchy kernels from old ones. Some crusty Italian country bread completes the meal.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINON;

A Laser Beam Transports Mozart
description: LEAD: I THOUGHT I'd be one of the last of the holdouts. Then suddenly, without warning, I caved in. One day a holdout, the next day a sell-out. The suddenness shocked and pleased me. I was chagrined over my capitulation and enthusiastic over its results.

title: News Summary
description: Zambia's Leader Falters

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: Nineteen years ago today, on 7/1/71, the Post Office Department became the United States Postal Service and celebrated by issuing a stamp and its own cacheted first-day covers in all 40,000 post offices.

title: Pastimes: Gardening;   Xeriscaping Kelps When the Water Supply is Low
description: Xeriscaping, derived from the Greek ''xeros'' meaning dry, is a comprehensive approach to landscaping for water conservation. It combines several basic principles including proper planning, land use, mulching, soil preparation, low-flow irrigation, maintenance practices and proper plant selection.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: 1) Forget about trying to establish a quality professional league in the soccer-hostile United States.

title: Christina F. Labrie Wed To Malachy F. Cleary 3d
description: Christina Frances Labrie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Patrick Labrie of Pointe Claire, Quebec, Canada, and Malachy Francis Cleary 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cleary Jr. of New York and New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday by Msgr. Thomas Leonard at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Families Trade Work for Equity in Co-op
description: LEAD: THE former Riverside Elementary School in Torrington was full of dust and noise, as parents and teen-agers wearing hard hats cleared away piles of construction debris. Heavy lengths of discarded wood and old doors were dragged down hallways to gaping windows and pitched into Dumpsters parked below.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Construction spending for May.

title: Hollywood Writer Revives Classics
description: LEAD: FOR a serious screenwriter, Lawrence B. Marcus has some pretty unusual ideas about movies. He thinks that films - including those generally revered as ''art films'' - are ''for fun and not to be philosophical about.''

title: A Plague on Both Their Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: Dim Views of That First $20,000
description: To the Editor:

title: Addressing The Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: No-Hitter Oddity: Fans Get 2-in-1 Deal
description: Two nine-inning no-hitters on the same night 2,500 miles apart made Friday, June 29, 1990, a date that baseball oddity collectors can treasure forever.

title: Technology;   The 'Concept Car' Pushes Change
description: This month, the Ford Motor Company will introduce the 1991 Capri, a sporty new car to be built in Australia around a Japanese Mazda drive train. It will be aimed at the market made popular by Mazda's Miata. But unlike the Miata, which was conceived quietly at the company's design studios in California, the Capri began life in 1982 in full view as a ''concept car.'' Originally called the Barcetta, the Capri was desgined in Italy at Ford's Ghia studio around a Ford Fiesta drive train. The Barcetta was shown at auto shows around the world and reviewed by trade publications before the decision was ever made to manufacture it.

title: DEAN RUSK'S PERSONAL TRUCE
description: AS I SAW IT

title: FORECAST FOR 'TODAY': CLOUDY
description: Your article on the future of ''Today'' includes an assessment of Deborah Norville's performance by an NBC executive who is quoted as saying, ''She just doesn't get it.'' However, I believe it is the network executive who ''doesn't get it.'' The article points out that the show is losing a portion of the audience that advertisers are anxious to keep, namely younger women. Did it ever occur to these people that Bryant Gumbel might be the reason ''Today'' is losing a very important part of its audience?

title: Failure in Denver Hits Manhattan Co-op
description: Aftershocks from the collapse of the Silverado Savings and Loan Association in Denver are shaking a Manhattan cooperative near Lincoln Center, where residents have become the reluctant partners of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Serious, Not Savage, on the Deficit
description: Tax revenue increases. With those three words, President Bush last week ushered in feverish budget negotiations. Proposals that were taboo on Monday - like taxes on Social Security benefits or cuts in Medicare - suddenly became possible on Tuesday. Swinging into action, Congressional leaders promised to cut next year's budget deficit by $55 billion or more.

title: Review/Music;   Works From Quebec By Le Nouvel Ensemble
description: Le Nouvel Ensemble Moderne, a contemporary music group from Montreal, celebrated its first anniversary, slightly belatedly, with a free concert last Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. The group was formed last May, and made an impressive New York debut earlier this season. For its second New York City appearance, it presented a two-part program, the first half featuring some of its players in solo works and a duet, the second half offering music for the full ensemble, ably conducted by Lorraine Vaillancourt.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Before the European colonists came to the Americas and before the Mint in Philadelphia began striking coins in 1776, natives of thecontinent were using money in their transactions. Wampum, orshell-money, made from the quahog clam was the most common. Strings of white and purple shell buttons found their way from the East Coast to the interior.

title: A Changing Mortgage Market in County
description: THREE years ago, during the real estate boom, a professional couple in their 30's sold their ''starter'' house, a small two-bedroom in Harrison, for $150,000. By stretching their budget to the limits, they bought a three-bedroom split level in Rye for $295,000.

title: Victoria A. Goss Marries Judge Dennis F. Harrigan
description: Victoria A. Goss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Woodrow Goss of Ashburn, Ga., and Judge Dennis F. Harrigan, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harrigan of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., were married yesterday. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg of the United Church of Christ at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Erika Kossmann Becomes a Bride
description: Erika Smyth Kossmann, a daughter of Dr. Richard John Kossmann of Englewood, N.J., and the late Geralyn Smyth Kossmann, was married yesterday to Brewster Morey Miner, the son of Doris Wells Miner of Manhasset, L.I., and the late James Vincent Miner. The Rev. Harry Boyle performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

How It Would Be on a Perfect Fourth
description: LEAD: OVER the last few months I have devoted quite a bit of thought to what would make a perfect Fourth of July. I guess this is because the 30-odd Independence Day celebrations I have attended during my lifetime have all been pretty much the same: Family get-togethers with yard games and cookouts during the day, firecrackers and sparklers at dusk, fireworks at the local shopping mall at 9 P.M.

title: A 2d Threat Slows Play
description: Although the weather this year has been unusually cooperative at Wimbledon, where rain delays are more the rule than the exception, the air of unrest caused by a rash of bomb hoaxes here and the occasional real explosion in London has twice brought the tennis to a grinding halt.

title: Police Pistol Training Enters Electronic Era
description: NEW police officers in Ridgefield will get their initial handgun training in a classroom rather than at a target range.

title: Royal T. Guernsey 3d, Restaurateur, 42
description: Royal Thomas Guernsey 3d, a partner in Chez Panisse, the highly successful restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., died of AIDS last Friday at his home in Berkeley. He was 42 years old.

title: Sarah Lamport Becomes Bride
description: Sarah Ware Lamport and Henry Colin Wildman Laurence were married yesterday on the steamboat DeWitt Clinton in New York Harbor by the Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a Unitarian minister.

title: 'The Loony-Bin Trip'
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Houses
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Sees Cut in Nuclear Shells
description: The Bush Administration has proposed to the Western allies the eventual withdrawal of nuclear-tipped artillery shells now deployed by the United States in Western Europe, an Administration official said tonight.

title: For Family, Fireworks Are in the Blood
description: LEAD: THERE'S an old saying in the fireworks business: ''Once one has smelled the smoke, one is never again free.'' For nearly a century, August Santore's family, owners of Garden State Fireworks Inc., have smelled the smoke and lighted the skies around the world with their award-winning displays.

title: COCTEAU'S PALETTE
description: Jean Cocteau (1889-1963) lived as many lives as a cat, and most of them at the same time. Novelist, poet, playwright, film maker, diarist, critic, illustrator, painter and set designer - this Parisian prodigy knew everyone, tried everything and was invariably attracted to whatever he wasn't up to at the moment. In THE VISUAL ART OF JEAN COCTEAU (International Archive of Art/Abrams, $49.50), William A. Emboden, the research director of the Severin Wunderman Museum in Irvine, Calif., home of the world's largest collection of Cocteau artworks, contends that despite his successes as a writer - and probably because of them - Cocteau really wanted to excel in drawing and painting. For the last 12 years of his life, he worked almost exclusively as an artist, making paintings, murals, ceramics and tapestries, but he despaired of ever becoming as great as, say, his friend Pablo Picasso. Since then, the world has not much praised Cocteau's visual art, and Mr. Emboden rightly challenges this history of benign neglect. Picasso did dominate Cocteau's visual imagination, but Cocteau's witty sensibility sneaks through, most slyly in drawings he made under the influence of opium. Unfortunately, Mr. Emboden is so eager to defend Cocteau that he forgets to evaluate him. This uncritical essay, accompanied by 161 gorgeous color plates, will probably be useful as a reference work, but Mr. Emboden neither marshals the arguments to support his central thesis - that Cocteau ''significantly changed each art form in which he worked'' - nor offers much insight into what these seemingly derivative paintings and sketches have to tell us about Cocteau's more radically innovative novels, movies and plays.

title: Louise Brewster Wed to Mark Brockett
description: Louise Story Brewster, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Nichols Brewster of Wellesley and Marblehead, Mass., and Mark William Brockett, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Roger Ware Brockett of Lexington, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Randall H. Niehoff performed the ceremony at the Old North Congregational Church in Marblehead, Mass.

description: Philadelphia's fiscal problems grew worse Friday as a top credit agency lowered the city's municipal bond rating, essentially warning investors that the city's bonds were a speculative investment.

The Executive Life;

Making Japanese Bosses Stand Up and Applaud
description: LEAD: ''Just look at this stuff,'' said Philip Voss, the chief executive of Zotos International Inc., pointing to the Japanese lesson workbook in front of him. ''It's like coming down on Mars!''

description: Gertrud Michelson's ''When a Child Walks Away,'' [Opinion Page, June 10] evoked a sad nostalgia as I recalled a similar experience not many years after the author's.

You didn't have to read about it or know someone attending school. You simply had to walk through your neighborhood and glance at the cars parked curbside.

description: AT THE ASSEMBLY POINT FOR DENVER'S 1990 ST. PATRICK'S DAY Parade, a tall, slim woman resplendent in a Kelly-green coat and a glittery, green top hat darted through the genial confusion of skirling bagpipes, Irish wolfhounds, green balloons and teen-age beauty queens showing more goose bumps than cleavage.

Four Anchors For Shopping

description: Regarding ''Auctions Find Their Niche in Slow Housing Market'' [June 3] , Martin Ginsburg is quoted as saying, ''the value of the units subjected to the auction are permanently tainted.'' Nothing could be further from the truth, and Mr. Ginsburg should know better.

title: The Latest Political Litmus Test
description: President Bush's decision last week to limit offshore drilling demonstrates that hardly any politician can risk being seen as anti-environmental. The reason for this is the growth of the environmental consciousness among the American people.

title: Men's Style;   Cutting It Close
description: A BART, A FLATTOP, A SPIKE OR A FADE - BY any name, it's a crew cut, heralding summer's arrival as surely as clipped lawns and Kool-Aid. New-mown hair, it seems, is hip. But that's not all. Style makers will tell you it is also a bracing, low-upkeep alternative to last year's ubiquitous ponytail. ''Long hair is pretty much a thing of the past,'' says Todd Albright, who owns Total Look, a downtown Manhattan grooming salon. ''We're back to cleaner-looking times.'' Unlike the razor-shorn, military styles that were popular in the 1950's, crew cuts now tend to be shaped with scissors and a generous dollop of gel, Albright says. They also vary in length.

title: A Crying Need For Awareness
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Liberian Insurgents Isolating the Capital
description: Guerrillas fighting the Liberian Government have reportedly seized control of the city's main hydroelectric installation and water-treatment plant, cutting water supplies and disrupting power.

description: THE rrxhSupreme Court ended its term last week with a burst of dramatic and surprising rulings, but also with abundant reminders of the Justices's deep divisions over some of the most important questions on their docket.

description: Seven-year-old Anescah Stewart learned to fly a kite yesterday, and she felt like ''a sea gull or an airplane'' flowing freely in the wind.

Focus: Southern California;

Kangaroo Rat Slows Housing Projects

title: Sandra Ann Mills Marries
description: Sandra Ann Mills, the daughter of Mrs. Parks Smith Mills of Matthews, N.C., and the late Mr. Mills, was married yesterday to Clayton Robert Barker 3d, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Parker Jr. of Palm Bay, Fla. The bridegroom's father, a Baptist minister, and the Rev. Frank Mayes, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Covenant Presbyterian Church Chapel in Charlotte, N.C. Mrs. Barker, 31 years old and a magna cum laude graduate of Wake Forest University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, is a founder and the vice president of Eagle Capital Management, an investment counseling firm in New York. Her husband, 32, a graduate of Stanford University, received a J.D. degree from the University of Virginia. He is an associate at the Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom law firm in New York.

description: Alison Isdale Beach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Beach Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Allen Jaeger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Jaeger of Cedar Grove, N.J. The Rev. Vance E. Polley performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: James S. Wallerstein, Biochemist, 79
description: James Scheuer Wallerstein, a biochemist and the president of the Sarah S. Ollesheimer Fund, a college scholarship foundation in Mount Kisco, N.Y., died on Thursday at his home in Mount Kisco. He was 79 years old.

title: Managing;   Getting Mad, Then Getting Even
description: It's not fun for anyone. But more and more executives are bringing high-stakes lawsuits against their former employers, seeking large sums or high-ranking positions, employment lawyers and outplacement counselors say. Statistics are scarce, but the number of such lawsuits is rising, counselors say, as companies impose layoffs and executives hear reports of large court verdicts.

title: Popular Films Are Feeding the Series Maw
description: ''Ferris Bueller,'' a new NBC situation comedy based on the theatrical movie, has a most unusual opening scene. Charlie Schlatter, the young actor cast as the teen-age hero Ferris, walks over to his closet and removes a life-size cardboard likeness of the actor Matthew Broderick, who played Ferris in the 1986 movie. ''C'mon, Matthew Broderick as me?'' he says. ''No way.'' Then he saws the cardboard figure in half, turns to the camera and says: ''This is television. This is real.''

title: Barbara Kelly Wed to Gregory Hack
description: Dr. Barbara Anne Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kelly of Tenafly, N.J., and Dr. Gregory Adrian Hack, the son of Cornelius Q. Hack of North Smithfield, R.I., and the late Ann W. Hack, were married yesterday in the Presbyterian Church in Tenafly. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. James G. Emerson Jr. and the Rev. Craig W. Rule. Mrs. Hack, who will keep her name professionally, is an attending neonatologist at Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., and an assistant professor of pediatrics at the Tufts University School of Medicine. She graduated from Dartmouth College and received her M.D. degree from George Washington University. Her father is the vice president for program sales at Editel, a video post-production concern in New York.

title: 'From Combs to Keyboards': A Startling Tale of Ivory
description: LEAD: TRUE to its mission of exploring local history, the Connecticut River Museum in Essex has mounted an exhibition tracing the growth of the ivory-cutting industry that flourished during the 19th and early 20th centuries.

description: Kim Yancey and Christopher Paul Moore were married yesterday at the West End Collegiate Church in New York by the Rev. Kenneth A. Gorsuch, a minister of the Dutch Reformed Church. Anna Harris was the maid of honor, and Steven Getzoff was the best man.

title: POstings: Virginia in Jersey;   New Monticello
description: There are those who believe it would be impossible to improve on Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's sublimely handsome home near Charlottesville, Va. But Merrick Wilson, a developer and builder based in Pennington, N.J., is not among them. He points out that Monticello did not have a garage, Jacuzzi or multizone heating and air-conditioning.

title:
FORUM;

'We Want to Keep Working'
description: LEAD: I represent 700 workers at the Health-Tex Inc. plant, Danville, Va. Health-Tex, one of our country's quality names in children's wear, went through a faulty leveraged buyout in 1985. Although it was profitable before the buyout, it has been struggling since. Last October, the ten banks that control the debt put in a new management team.

Ignoring the sign above the Census Bureau's table that said he could ''Be Counted Here in 3 Minutes,'' he plopped down on the sidewalk to examine the form for nearly half an hour.

description: Liberty State Park, with its rows of American flags fluttering in the wind, has something very special to offer: an unrivaled view of lower Manhattan. The vista of New York Harbor includes Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, which stands a mere 1,750 feet away and seems close enough to touch.

description: A New Jersey grand jury is investigating allegations of point-shaving involving a New Jersey businessman and former North Carolina State basketball players, a North Carolina newspaper reported yesterday.

description: Once I got a fortune cookie that said: to remember is to understand. I have never forgotten it.

description: WHEN the Five-Mile River Grille opened in Rowayton three years ago, it had a trendy feel that suggested, ''Here today, gone tomorrow.'' But the restaurant has demonstrated staying power and improved considerably in the process.

title: Disturbed Children Focus of Parents' Group
description: SUPPOSE you had a child who threw a television out the window and attempted suicide three times before the age of 8. Or a teen-ager who ate boxes of raw cake mix and tried to stab you with a knife. How would you get help?

title: Headliners;   Japan's Princess Bride
description: Kiko-san! The wedding Friday of Japan's newest princess, Kiko Kawashima, to Prince Aya, the second son of Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko, culminated a year of gently demonstrated Kiko-mania. When the 23-year-old commoner, who is the daughter of a university professor, appeared at her first news conference wearing pearls, brokers soon began recommending pearl companies to clients. Teen-aged girls styled their hair after hers and learned to mimick her polite smile. Copies of her engagement ring to Prince Aya, a pair of intertwined catfish - the species he is studying as a zoologist - sell briskly as wedding souvenirs. All the hoopla has encouraged many Japanese to hope that Princess Kiko will open up the traditionally remote court. The princess, a graduate student in psychology at Gakushuin University in Tokyo, has expressed an interest in finishing her master's degree and pursuing a career, but whether she will be allowed to is uncertain. She has often hinted that she and her husband have separate pursuits. Prince Aya ''likes to study catfish,'' she said recently, ''and I like to study people and cognition.''

title: The Border Boom; Hope And Heartbreak
description: LEAD: LATE ON A COOL SUMMER evening, against a faint glow from the city lights below, 18 Mexicans struggled up the side of a towering hill in Nogales, Sonora, two miles from the Arizona border. Most were new arrivals at the northern edge of Mexico. Pushed from the south by rural poverty and unemployment, pulled to the north by the promise of jobs in American-owned factories, they had joined the productive work force of a new industrial revolution on the border.

title: CHINESE REPLACING REGIONAL OFFICIALS
description: While avoiding any shuffling of leaders in the closely watched central Government, China's leadership has moved stealthily in the last year to appoint new top officials in more than a third of the provinces and six of the nation's seven military regions.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Two Generations Without a Gap
description: LEAD: FROM his earliest days, our 15-year-old son, Eric, has had a special bond with my parents. Now, when other teen-agers might prefer to distance themselves from any adults, Eric becomes closer and closer to his grandparents.

title: Kathryn H. Meisle and Marcus B. Giamatti Wed
description: Kathryn Hunt Meisle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Layton Meisle of Camden, Me., was married yesterday to Marcus Bartlett Giamatti, a son of Mrs. A. Bartlett Giamatti of Hamden, Conn., and the late Mr. Giamatti. The Rev. Archie D. McRee performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Camden.

title: Borrowing Is Unreasonable Way to Bail Out Savings and Loans
description: I was startled and dismayed by ''The Bailout: No Savagery Required,'' your June 22 editorial supporting Government borrowing as the appropriate way to deal with the bailout of bankrupt savings and loans institutions. Borrowing may be politically expedient; it is, however, wrong, from both an economic and moral point of view. The straightforward, and least damaging way to deal with this fiasco, is to pay off the $130 billion loss with a temporary three- to four-year surcharge on income taxes.

title: Jazz Festival;   New Work By Brubeck Quartet
description: The JVC Jazz Festival brought the pianist Dave Brubeck and his quartet to the World Financial Center plaza on Thursday evening in a free outdoor concert so fortuitously timed that the rain didn't start until the drum solo in the finale, Paul Desmond's ''Take Five.''

title: ANOTHER CHANCE FOR A PRIME PIECE OF REAL ESTATE
description: More than four years have passed since the developer Donald Trump unleashed upon the world his first plan for ''Television City,'' a huge development that would put 7,600 apartments, one of the region's largest shopping malls, and the world's tallest building on the site of the former Penn Central rail yards between 59th and 72d Streets on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. And it's nearly as long since people have been complaining about the project, which the developer renamed Trump City when NBC television, the hoped-for anchor tenant, decided not to move its studios there, citing community opposition.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: She-Devil

title: The Music That Haunts 'Twin Peaks'
description: Even nonmusic lovers who watched David Lynch's ''Twin Peaks'' this past season must have recognized music's role in its eerie impact. Music is everywhere in this television soap opera, nattering ominously in otherwise seemingly banal scenes, investing them with dark purpose; bopping jazzily behind macho teenagers at play, rising to ecstatic (if properly soapy) climaxes where one might expect (James and Donna kissing) and where one might not (the discovery of Laura Palmer's corpse), setting up a creepy emotional counterpoint.

title: Deirdre Sheehan and D. A. Ewald Wed
description: Deirdre Marie Sheehan, a daughter of Mrs. Conrad P. Sheehan of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. Sheehan, and Douglass Alexander Ewald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Philip Ewald of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lawrence J. Sheehan, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Richard F. Van Wely, an Episcopal minister.

title: More Marcos Deliberations
description: The jury deliberated for a third day yesterday in the fraud trial of former Philippine First Lady Imelda Marcos. The panel reheard testimony about the transfer of millions of dollars from the Philippines for the purchase of Manhattan real estate. The jurors focused on two of four properties - the Herald Center, a retail building, and an office building at 200 Madison Avenue -which Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, Ferdinand, are accused of buying with embezzled funds. They recessed last evening and will resume today.

title: Amy J. WeinsteinBecomes a Bride
description: Amy Jill Weinstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Weinstein of Melville, L.I., was married to Eric Steven Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rosenberg, also of Melville. Rabbi Marc Gellman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I. Mrs. Rosenberg, 24 years old and a cum laude graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, is a copywriter at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc., a New York advertising agency. Her father is a partner at the law firm of Rothstein and Weinstein in Melville, and is a vice president of the Hirsch Optical Corporation in Farmingdale, L.I. Her mother, Susan Weinstein, is an independent real-estate title closer.

title: 140,000 Hulks, Every Year
description: New York City remains a dumping ground for abandoned cars. The dead hulks blight every neighborhood, inviting professional scavengers and showers of broken glass. The city has new authority to deter the trashing and boost revenues in the process. Why won't it seize the opportunity?

title: In Ruth's House, a Mix of Then and Now
description: ''Buy me some peanuts and Cracker Jack. I don't care if I ever smoke crack.'' It was sing-along time, the seventh-inning stretch at Yankee Stadium. A young man with wildly flowing red hair, seated in Row L in the topmost stands behind home plate, was giving a 1990's twist to an old standard.

title: New York State Cherry Crop Predicted Down
description: ''It doesn't look too good,'' said Lee D. Brown, a cherry grower, as he looked out over his trees here on the banks of the Hudson River.

title: V.A. PLANS Change IN MEDICAL GROUP
description: Ever since he jumped out of a grounded airplane during a rocket attack on Da Nang, Vietnam, 23 years ago, Ron Rossani has had recurring back problems. Bending to brush his teeth, he says, can leave him bedridden for days.

title:
Jersey City Journal;

Memorial Day Melee Causes Neighborhood to Reflect on Itself
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of Astor Place thought their street was the last place for a riot, until one happened. Now they concede that no street in an inner-city neighborhood is immune from unrest.

title: Clarifications on Grief Counseling
description: It has been refreshing to see the diversity of professional and community opinion around the validity and availability of bereavement counseling to assist mourners. However, the recent article (''One-to-One Counseling Gains,'' May 27) raises a number of issues that require clarification.

title: Bruce Willis Looks for the Man Within the Icon
description: Somewhere in Hell's Kitchen, hard by West 49th Street and 10th Avenue in Manhattan, there is an apartment with Bruce Willis's name on it. A railroad flat where, for $175 a month, he bivouacked as one of New York's small army of aspiring actors, it still remains, and not by accident, in the man's family. ''It's like a Museum of Bruce Willis, the early days,'' he says, at once wistful and amused. ''It's been only six years since the whole thing really turned around for me, and I like to keep that attitude, to remember what it was like. I like that guy more than all this movie star celebrity malarkey.''

title: Talking: Escrow;   Tracking Down Abuses
description: VIRTUALLY every homeowner who makes regular mortgage payments is charged a monthly amount that covers not only principal and interest but also the cost of real estate taxes and homeowner insurance.

title: Streetscapes: St. Monica's Church;   An Elegant Romanesque Edifice Ruined by Neglect
description: WHAT will ultimately seal the fate of the 1857 St. Monica's Church in Jamaica, Queens, is not the decline of the area after World War II, the congregation that left it in 1973, the vandals that have damaged it or even the conflicting city-state jurisdictions that short-circuit its landmark designation.

title: U.S. Savings Bailout Irks State Officials
description: REPORTS that the Federal cleanup of the savings and loan disaster will result in Connecticut residents paying $1,237 a person more to rescue the failed thrifts than they will receive in bailout benefits has angered state lawmakers and banking officials, and last week several were looking for ways to offset the situation.

title: All-American Sounds For Independence Day
description: IF ever there is a best day to celebrate our American musical heritage, it is on Independence Day, and at least three Fourth of July events will be doing just that.

title: Lodges in Rugged, Remote Maine
description: IN the autumn of 1880 the author and artist Thomas Sedgwick Steele arrived by canoe at a cluster of buildings on the shores of Chesuncook Lake, deep in the north Maine woods. ''These farm buildings stand alone in a wild, open tract of country,'' he wrote. ''The sight of them strikes you instantly as strange and unaccountable. At first you wonder and half believe yourself in the vicinity of Ararat and a debilitated ark. Then you shudder and give thought to a terrible suspicion - a smallpox hospital, perhaps!''

title: Pops and Fireworks On Campus at Danbury
description: THE Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury is ready to open its summer season, on Saturday, with pops and fireworks. The former will be provided by Skitch Henderson and the Ives Symphony Orchestra; the latter will light the skies over the campus of Western Connecticut State University.

title: Q and A
description: Joint Ownership of Co-op

title: Broadening Teen-Agers' Job Horizons
description: LEAD: AFTER a recent vocational outing for a group of Ossining Village eighth-graders, Shatequa Princess McRae sat talking about the future with two teen-age boys. Without hesitation, 13-year-old Shatequa guessed what her classmates were likely to predict as her life's work:

title: Fashion: On the Street;   A Spot of Shade To Tote Around
description: In summer more than any other season, it's the cooler head that inevitably prevails. That at least explains the profusion of caps and hats that have accompanied the recent rise in temperature and humidity. While these hats are utilitarian - with their wide brims and long bills, they deflect the sun quite nicely - they are also just plain fun.

title: Albany Lurches Toward Adjournment
description: Like a jalopy in need of a tune-up, the State Legislature lurched toward adjournment today, resolving some major issues and leaving others mired in partisan politics and confusion.

title: How Clubs and Beaches Court the Lifeguards
description: LEAD: POOLSIDE bulletin: All lifeguards are requested to stop discussing their contracts and resume flirting with swimmers.

title: NONFICTION
description: DAVE BARRY TURNS 40. By Dave Barry. (Crown, $16.95.) This book will probably be a popular fortysomething birthday present, but it is more like the card that comes with the gift. You know, one of those ''You're not getting older, you're just getting fatter and losing your hair'' cards. In fact, reading ''Dave Barry Turns 40,'' a collection of columns by the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist at The Miami Herald, is like going through the humor section of a greeting card store, except there are more laughs here. For example: ''If you pick up any current actuarial table and look up the average life span for a person of your particular age, sex, and weight, you'll realize that, statistically, you have to squint like hell to read the numbers.'' According to Mr. Barry, this is what happens at 40: Thin women eat entire chocolate cakes and the calories go into your body. Members of midlife marriages - ''in thickness as well as health'' - can now write 17-pound books on the way their spouses eat. Men undergo midlife crisis, the symptoms of which are ''wearing enormous pleated pants and designer fragrances ('Ralph Lauren's Musque de Stud Hombre: For the Man Who Wants a Woman Who Wants a Man Who Smells Vaguely Like a Horse')'' and buying ''a boat shaped like a marital aid.'' A woman experiences ''the change'' when her body, in a complex process, senses she ''has reached the stage in her life where her furniture is much too nice for her to have a baby barfing on it.'' Participant sports are limited to golf, fishing and ''shrieking at Little Leaguers.'' And politically, you might wake to find that ''you assign a lower priority to ending world hunger than to finding a cleaning lady.'' Finally, Mr. Barry compares attending a Rolling Stones concert in the 60's with attending one recently. This time the concert started punctually - ''probably because if it hadn't, one of the estimated 13,000 attorneys in the audience would have filed a lawsuit'' - and the crowd was high on knowing they had baby sitters on a weekday night. That Dave, he's a real card.

William Stayton, performed the ceremony.

title: Style Makers;   Robin Baron and Lauren Hanna; Jewelry Importers
description: Take young Americans who want to go into business together; add a cooperative husband of one of them who has a friend with a Moscow connection. Voila: In an amazingly short time there's a new New York company called Soviet Source. A range of jewelry designs, pins, earrings and necklaces fashioned from Soviet military medals and insignia will soon be in a number of stores including Henry Lehr and Henri Bendel.

title: Moscow Punishes a General For Assailing K.G.B.'s Ways
description: A former K.G.B. general and counterspy chief has been stripped of his rank and awards for saying publicly that Stalinist methods persist in the security and intelligence service.

title: SOVIETS OPEN LINE FOR LITHUANIA OIL TO HELP END CRISIS
description: The Soviet Union reopened the oil pipeline to rebellious Lithuania today to begin fulfilling its part of a compromise to end the impasse on the republic's move for independence.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD: ANGEL FALLS. By Paul Guernsey. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) In the beginning, ''Angel Falls'' seems to be simply an action-packed tale of cocaine and revolution in Caracas, Venezuela, but there's more to Paul Guernsey's second novel than fast plot. The characters are complex and sympathetic - even when you might expect them to be stereotypes, like the rock star Ronnie Neumon, lead singer of the Prowlers, an American rock band that becomes the catalyst for much of the action.

title: Don't Let Japan Open a Pi Gap With U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Statement
description: On Friday, a Superior Court grand jury in Washington declined to file criminal charges against three members of the Capitals hockey team who had been accused of rape by a 17-year-old girl. Yesterday, the Capitals released a statement asking forgiveness for the players: Neil Sheehy, a 30-year-old defenseman; Dino Ciccarelli, a 30-year-old right wing, and Geoff Courtnall, a 27-year-old left wing.

title: Making Allowances
description: Donald Trump was put on an allowance last week. As part of a rescue deal from his bankers that enabled the 44-year-old developer to meet an interest payment on a junk bond issue and narrowly avert personal bankruptcy, Mr. Trump was told that he cannot spend more than $450,000 a month on personal and household expenses for the rest of the year. He must scale back that spending to $375,000 a month next year and to $300,000 a month in 1992. Mr. Trump is said to have spent $583,000 on day-to-day necessities in May. The allowance does not cover expenses like mortgage payments and the costs of running his yacht and private plane. Trump, the allowance, gave vast new material to the cartoonists and the television talk show hosts and removed some of the sheen from Mr. Trump's carefully burnished image as an invincible entrepreneur of untold wealth. But while giving up some management control to the bankers, Mr. Trump still kept ownership of his multibillion-dollar empire. That could open the way for a comeback if New York real estate and Atlantic City casinos become hot properties again.

title: Carolyn M. Baker Married To Douglas Clark Dorsey
description: Carolyn Manchester Baker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Baker of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Bristol, R.I., to Douglas Clark Dorsey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dorsey of Irvington, Va. The Rev. Anne B. Kimball performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MUSIC MOVES OUTDOORS

title: How Much Risk Do Adventure Seekers Assume?
description: ''WHEN you challenge nature, you are a risk seeker,'' Dr. William Davis of the National Park Service said. ''You want that edge, that happiness, you want those endorphins to run around. So the approach to safety is different from the approach in a workplace. We do not keep people away, we don't put a sign out on the Grand Canyon, 'Danger, Large Hole!' ''

title: Chasing Speeders on the Sprain Brook
description: ONE recent weekday afternoon, State Trooper Richard Byrnes, driving an unmarked police car, pulled out of the state police station here and headed south on the Sprain Brook State Parkway in search of speeding motorists. ''We won't have to wait long,'' he said. His prediction proved correct. A moment later, an orange Corvette convertible zoomed around the state police car. Trooper Byrnes maneuvered around the traffic in pursuit and paced the Corvette at 83 miles per hour.

title: U.S. to Make It Easier to Gain Asylum
description: After a decade of debate, the Justice Department has drafted new rules to protect the rights of foreigners who seek asylum in the United States and fear persecution in their homelands.

title: How to Rebuild Public Television
description: LEAD: The playwright and president of Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel, describes his presidential program as an effort to bring ''spirituality, moral responsibility, humaneness and humility into politics.''

title: 4 Teen-Agers Killed as Train Hits Car in Chicago Suburb
description: An Amtrak train collided with a car Friday evening, killing four teen-agers, officials said.

title: Miss Norton Wed To C. C. Sprague
description: Catherine Mary Norton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Norton of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Charles Christopher Sprague, the son of Dr. and Mrs. B. Sheldon Sprague of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. James F. Trainor officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: As Protest, Performer Rejects Federal Grant
description: A performer who was to receive a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts said today that she would turn it down because the agency had rejected 4 of 18 grants recommended by its theater peer panel.

title: Father, Son and I.B.M.
description: To the Editor:

title: Biennial Seeds Should Be Planted Now
description: IT is time to sow seed. As odd as this may sound at this time of year, this is the proper time to plant the seeds of biennials. The plants have formed the odd-shaped cases that hold seed, called seedpods, and the seed is ripening inside. If this ripe seed is sown promptly, the seed will sprout quickly, and the roots of young plants will have a chance to take hold by early fall. They may even bloom next year, but certainly they will flower in 1992.

title: Susan Taylor and Geoffrey Harris, Investment Firm Executives, Marry
description: Susan Lyn Taylor, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dean Ross Taylor of Glyndon, Md., and Geoffrey Eric Harris, a son of Susanne Harris of Redondo Beach, Calif., and Dr. Paul Harris of Brooklyn, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Lawrence, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Glyndon.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended June 16

title: Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: The United States can improve its soccer team for 1994 by declaring a state of war and drafting all exceptionally talented athletes in the college ranks. Send them to boot camp for fundamentals. Then force-feed them pasta and endless films of the Italians' style of play. Finally, hope for divine intervention.

title:
DANCE;

Ballroom Style Glides Onto Concert Stage
description: LEAD: IN the shoes of Pierre Dulaine and Yvonne Marceau, featured dancers in the Broadway hit ''Grand Hotel'' and also the directors and stars of the American Ballroom Theater, social dancing rises to the realm of concert dance.

title: Wild Bill Shakespeare in Central Park
description: Ten, fifteen years ago it was still an exception. Now it seems almost to have become the norm. Like it or mistrust it, the updating of Shakespeare is no longer an oddity, but a theatrical convention that all but the most squeamish of traditionalists must surely learn to accept.

title: Postings: Bronx Plant;   Turning Garbage Into Fuel
description: Garbage will be turned into fuel, and 27 badly needed jobs will open up where too few are available, under a Swiss recycling company's plans to build a $26 million refuse-treatment plant in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: Hidden Valley 'Raring to Go' For Fresh Air
description: A sign at the back of the auditorium seemed to say it all: ''We can't wait to see you this summer.''

title:
ART;

The Emotional Force Of Nature as a Theme
description: LEAD: IN this era of heightened concern for the fragility of nature, artists are increasingly coming to regard outdoor subjects as timely. Fueling the trend, too, is a renewal of respect for images that are based on responses to the external, rather than the internal, world.

title: FORECAST FOR 'TODAY': CLOUDY
description: As a ''Today'' show viewer for the past five years, I watch because of Bryant Gumbel, a class act. He exudes affability and intelligence. His (in)famous memo was on target.

title:
ART;

A Distorted View of 2 Decades
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of his status as the so-called dean of American art dealers, Leo Castelli was invited by the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor to organize an exhibition entitled ''Two Decades of American Art: The 60's and 70's.'' The show is on view through Sept. 3.

title: Varied Views on Gun Control
description: The New Jersey Legislature recently took a first mincing step and passed a gun-control law, long overdue.

title: The Bush Plan to Help Latin America
description: LEAD: Recently, Latin America has slipped from our sights, lost amid the upheaval in Eastern Europe. This makes little sense.

title: World Markets;   Waiting for the Other Shoe in Mexico
description: The Mexican stock market has been one of the best performers in the world recently. It is up 52.3 percent this year and is the top performer for the last two and one-half years in the Financial Times world market index.

title: Mutual Funds;   When Small Is Beautiful
description: The long-heralded rebound of small-company stocks paid off for mutual fund investors during the first half of 1990. The 85 small-company stock funds had returned an average of 5.4 percent as of June 28, head and shoulders above the 2.2 percent logged by all stock funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., in Summit, N.J., which tracks mutual funds.

title: What to Say When the Film Is Unrated
description: How does a sexually explicit film with artistic credentials make an entrance in video stores? In September, Fox/Lorber Home Video will release ''In the Realm of the Senses'' by the Japanese director Nagisa Oshima. ''Beautiful,'' ''stunning,''

title: For Diverse Reasons, an Exodus Of County Arts Administrators
description: IT would seem that art professionals in Westchester are dropping like flies. As of today, Dominique Nahas no longer heads the State University's Neuberger Museum in Purchase; Barbara Bloemink joins the line of Hudson River Museum ex-directors; and Christopher Bruhl concludes his reign over the county's Council for the Arts. The Rye Arts Center, meanwhile, continues its search for an administrator to replace Christina Banks, who left on June 13.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: What could be more appropriate than for a famous grandmaster to celebrate his 80th birthday with a party in the form of a tournament? That is what Miguel Najdorf did on April 15 in Buenos Aires and it may well have been the first time in his chess career that he appeared as the impresario rather than as a player.

title: Dim Views of That First $20,000
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars;   It's Sleek, Fun and Mercedes
description: Among automobile stylists, Sergio Pininfarina is something of a hero. He has designed all those gorgeous Ferraris. He has blueprinted the very clean Peugeot 505 sedan. And Cadillac commissioned him to do its Allante sports model.

title: MISADVENTRUES IN THE SLAVE TRADE
description: MIDDLE PASSAGE

title: Negotiations Continue in Historic-District Case
description: LEAD: NEARLY a year after a Tarrytown man was sentenced to jail for disobeying a court order to remove an addition to his home, which is in a historic district, lawyers said last week that they were still trying to settle the case.

title: Ex-Gov. Moore Asks to Drop Guilty Pleas
description: Lawyers for former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. have asked a Federal court that he be allowed to withdraw his guilty pleas to five political corruption counts.

title: A LOST GENERATION OF AMERICANS IS COMING HOME
description: No one could blame David Diamond for being bitter. During the 1940's, the composer was considered among the most promising of his generation. He could count his fellow composers Aaron Copland and Leonard Bernstein among his friends, the conductors Serge Koussevitzsky and Dimitri Mitropoulos among his champions and the Boston Symphony Orchestra and New York Philharmonic among his interpreters. He seemed to be on his way toward a brilliant, if controversial, career.

title: Climb the Pyramid, Weave the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonnie Rattner Weds
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Bonnie Hope Rattner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Rattner of Wheatley Heights, L.I., was married last evening to Robert Alan Klugman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Klugman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated. Mrs. Klugman, 25 years old, graduated from Cornell University and the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School. She is an associate at the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling. Mr. Klugman, 26, graduated from Cornell and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. He is due to join UBS Securities in August as an investment banker.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;

Do We Really Need to See Wotan's Dimples?
description: LEAD: Do I really want to know that Wotan has dimples? That may not rank high among the esthetic issues raised by the Metropolitan Opera's recently televised ''Ring des Nibelungen'' and I apologize for bringing it up. But there they were, demanding my attention, those charming indentations in James Morris's cheeks, highlighted by tight camera work.

title: Dim Views of That First $20,000
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Ideas & Trends;   Small Farms Sell Shares in a Way of Life
description: AT the bottom of Long Mountain in South Amherst, Mass., where Hulst Road veers off into forests of maple and pine, one of the country's most promising experiments in food production is now in its fourth season.

title: Sailor Tuning Up His Image
description: Mokoto Namba, a champion yachtsman from Japan, went into the Liberty Cup Regatta this weekend more determined to win than ever. Not only did he have a losing streak in the New York race to improve upon, but also a new and bright yacht-racing image to uphold.

title: Welch Gains 13th Victory
description: Bob Welch became the first 13-game winner in the major leagues and Dave Henderson hit two two-run doubles as the Oakland Athletics beat Toronto, 9-4, today. The loss was the sixth in a row for the Blue Jays.

title: Susan Hart Ryan Marries William Craig in Vermont
description: Susan Hart Ryan, a daughter of Jane Curd Foley and Albert Preston Foley, both of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to William Emerson Craig, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Emerson Craig of Longmeadow, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the Community Congregational Church in Quechee, Vt., by the Rev. Richard Laubenheimer, who was assisted by the bridegroom's sister-in-law, the Rev. Susan McNeily Craig, a Congregational minister.

title: Can the U.S. Really Handle a World Cup?
description: Sitting around the Termini station the other day, I was observing trains every few minutes, fans carrying banners, the babble of languages, soccer headlines everywhere, and steaming caffe latte.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Can The U.S. Improve Its Soccer Team For 1994?
description: The offense, almost nonexistent in Italy, must develop fast wings and one or two center-forward strikers who are able to accept a pass and create a scoring opportunity. Then when the players have been picked, they must be present in every single exhibition game, so that when the real games start, America will have a cohesive team that has been together.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Brielle $329,000

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   When an Auction Ends in a Standoff
description: LATE in May, a Sheldon Good & Company real estate auction ended not in a sellout or partial sale, but in a standoff. People who thought they had bought 40 new condominium units at Millpointe in Wethersfield had their down payments returned within three days because the prices were insufficient to satisfy the mortgage.

title: METS FINALLY LOSE ONE
description: Two streaks of success came to an end in Shea Stadium yesterday when the Cincinnati Reds rallied to defeat the Mets, 7-4, and simultaneously clipped their winning streak at 11 games and Darryl Strawberry's hitting streak at 18.

title: Nicklaus Grabs Senior Lead
description: Nostalgia's superstars took their places today for what promises to be a classic finish Sunday at the 11th United States Senior Open.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Kiss of a Father

title: Wall Street Shrugs Off Tax Threat
description: Are higher taxes just what the economy, and the stock market, need? Wall Street seems to think so.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;

Unblighting A Warehouse
description: LEAD: THE redevelopment of a former Gimbels warehouse is the first Pittsburgh project to get funds under a state program designed to help convert blighted industrial sites.

title: DESPOT OF THE DREAM CIRCUIT
description: LEAD:

title: We Left the City, Didn't We?
description: WHEN I was growing up on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, it was a residential backwater where the windows of aging apartment buildings gave off row after row of soft yellow light on winter evenings. My neighbors were mostly elderly people with theatrical pasts or divorced women raising three children in two-bedroom apartments.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A Mother's Dream of Dance for Her Daughter Takes a Tumble
description: LEAD: IT sounds corny, but I always wanted a daughter to buy dolls for and dress in pink clothes and watch dance on stage in a ballet recital.

title: R. A. Campanioni, 34, a Philanthropist Aiding Gay Projects
description: Raul A. Campanioni, a stockbroker who ran a firm that served gay clients and donated heavily to gay causes, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Chelsea.

title: Review/Dance;   Ruzimatov In 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: Faruk Ruzimatov sometimes seems to be dancing in another world from his fellow performers on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House during this American Ballet Theater season. But Mr. Ruzimatov, a star import from the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, made the proceedings a good deal more colorful in his early moments as Prince Desire, in a role debut on Thursday night in Sir Kenneth MacMillan's staging of ''The Sleeping Beauty.''

title: Room and Board on Europe's Trains
description: Travel in a European sleeping car on a train with restaurant service has its own special mystique. A good meal, a bit of fantasy, and a new city to explore in the morning; such are the rewards still to be found. Here is a series of rides enjoyed this past January.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE COUNTY AIRPORT;

Noise, With a Measure of Objectivity
description: LEAD: SUMMERTIME and the living is noisy. Fireworks will soon be booming in the night sky; construction crews are on the roadways, and people sit in their backyards and hear airplanes they might not have noticed during the more insular months of winter.

title: NO, MEIN FUHRER
description: LETTERS TO FREYA

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the market for Japanese art misstated which branch of an auction house sold two pairs of 17th-century flower screens for $1 million each. It was Christies in New York.

title: Orwelllian Logic Is Rampant At the Brancacci
description: Despite the stunning advances made in the art and science of restoration over the last three decades, no technology can tell restorers whether a 15th-century fresco cycle should take precedence over an 18th-century marble altar. That problem arose during the restoration of the Brancacci Chapel in the Carmine Church here.

title: Data Update

LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Eastward, or Westward, Ho!
description: LEAD: LAST week, planning our annual vacation, I sat in the den poring over maps, guidebooks, calendars - and sipping a tall, cool, refreshing glass of Mylanta.

title: Peoria Set to Welcome Its Freed Native Son
description: Scott Heimdal, the 27-year-old American gold miner released Friday after two months in the captivity of Colombian guerrilla kidnappers, could be back in the United States as early as Tuesday, and his reception here promises to be a remarkable one: a homecoming for a man most Peorians have never met, in a town where he has not lived for years.

title: Villages Protest Parking Tax
description: LEAD: VILLAGES throughout New York say that the new sales tax on public off-street parking meters and parking field permits is creating a mare's-nest.

title: Costlier and More Dangerous Chemicals Foreseen in Saving Ozone
description: Ridding the environment of chlorine-based chemicals is necessary to save the atmosphere's protective ozone, experts say. But the price may include greater electricity consumption, costlier and less reliable refrigeration and automotive products, and increasing public exposure to toxic substances and explosives.

title: Campus Life: U.C.L.A.;   Amid Pressure, Expansion Plan Is Trimmed Again
description: For the second time, the Chancellor of the University of California at Los Angeles has scaled back the university's most ambitious long-range development plan in the face of pressure from community advocates and local politicians.

title: Lisa L. Boalt Is Married
description: Lisa Lamberton Boalt and William Jeremy Jeffrey were married yesterday at their home in South Salem, N.Y. The Right Rev. Robert Appleyard, the retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Pittsburgh, officiated. Mrs. Jeffrey, the daughter of J. Anthony Boalt of Palm Beach, Fla., and Mrs. George V. Hook of Giverny, France, graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall and attended Marymount Manhattan College. Mr. Jeffrey, a son of Mrs. Albert Faber of Greenwich, Conn., and the late William P. Jeffrey, is a vice president of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. He is a graduate of the Hotchkiss School and Yale University.

title: MOTHERS ARE A GIRL'S BEST FRIEND
description: ALTERED LOVES

title: NEW PERU LEADER IN ACCORD ON DEBT
description: Peru's President-elect, Alberto Fujimori, has reached a tentative agreement with the International Monetary Fund and other development agencies on a plan to stabilize his country's tottering economy, resume payment on at least some of its external debts and reintegrate Peru into the international financial system.

title: WHAT WE DON'T KNOW
description: Please inform Christopher Hitchens that the Latin phrase domus parva magni poetae, which appeared in his article ''Why We Don't Know What We Don't Know'' (May 13), should be translated ''the small house - or home - of (not for) a great poet.''

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago;   Towering Changes
description: The latest is the 40-story City Place at 676 North Michigan Avenue, which was developed by Fifield Companies of Chicago and completed in May. It has 140,000 square feet of office space on 13 floors, a 347-room Hyatt Regency Suites Hotel in the second through 25th floors and 30,000 square feet of retail space on the ground level.

title: Taking a Broader View Of Drugs in the Suburbs
description: LEE P. BROWN, Commissioner of the New York City Police Department, said in a speech here on Tuesday that it is ''wrong and dangerous'' to regard drug abuse and its criminal consequences as an inner-city scourge threatening the suburbs.

title: An Evening at Shea Is a Stroll in the Park
description: The endlessly blinking scoreboards at Shea Stadium have a naive charm. The following appeared on the screen together:

title: Cynthia Ziegler Is Married
description: Cynthia Ann Ziegler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon S. Ziegler Jr. of Muttontown, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I., to Daniel Paul Anastasi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Anastasi of Rockville, Md. The Rev. William C. Metzdorf officiated. The bride, 24 years old, and her husband, 25, are alumni of the University of Richmond. The bridegroom is a loan officer at the First Washington Mortgage Corporation in Greenbelt, Md.

title: Fashion;   New Colors Put Fun Into Jackets
description: This summer, lots of men seem to be shedding their navy blue blazers in favor of newly fashionable coats of crayon green, red or yellow, or slightly toned-down celery, tomato or gold.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The danger is we get caught up in it like it's a rock concert, like going to see Prince, where it's wonderful, but three days later you don't think about it anymore. If we allow that to happen, it's a travesty. If there's no connection between his struggle and ours, then the whole visit is really not the tribute to his life and work that it needs to be.''

title: Doing Divorces the Way They Were
description: Broken china, broken bones and a grand finale in which Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas dangle from a rickety chandelier - divorce isn't what it used to be. THE WAR OF THE ROSES, newly released on videocassette (1989, CBS/Fox, $89.98), is devoted to the idea that love is a minefield. When the Roses' marriage explodes, it becomes a dark, funny divorce to the death, a battle whose weapons include pate of dog. Directed by Danny DeVito, who plays a wise but slimy lawyer, the film was a big commercial hit. It also provoked strong negative responses from some viewers who weren't amused at the sight of a husband and wife trying to run each other over with cars.

title: Country Charm and a Celebrated Chef
description: LEN ALLISON, the celebrated chef at Hubert's in Manhattan, is a man on the move: half of the week in the city and half at Shelter Island's Chequit Inn.

title: Holly Drake and Todd Sylvestri Marry
description: Susan Holly Drake, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Drake of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Todd Michael Sylvestri, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco J. Sylvestri of Greenwich. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel.

title: Ms. Flink, Lawyer, Weds George Warga, Dentist
description: Andrea Flink, the daughter of Lois Flink of Hillsdale, N.J., and Richard A. Flink of Califon, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. George Warga, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Warga of Glenview, Ill. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg and the Rev. Nevin Kennedy, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club in Bedminster, N.J.

title: The Magic of the Manx
description: Manx people say that the Isle of Man sits in the center of the Irish Sea because two giants, one Irish and one English, were feuding over a woman. One night the English giant stole the woman away, and the Irish giant, whose name was Finn MacCoul, was so furious that he threw a handful of stone and mud after his enemy's retreating figure. In the darkness, it fell short of its mark and landed midway between them in the sea.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Shedding More Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Vincent Following Giamatti's Guidelines
description: The hearing Commissioner Fay Vincent will oversee Thursday on baseball's investigation of George Steinbrenner will be based largely on guidelines set last year by A. Bartlett Giamatti for his planned hearing on Pete Rose's gambling activities.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH HUBBLE
description: In the ancient city of Babel, the descendants of Noah tried to build a tower so high it would reach the heavens. In retaliation for their daring, the Book of Genesis tells us, God punished the builders, taking the language that had bound them together and fragmenting it into all the world's different tongues.

title: Milwaukee Council Censures Alderman Over Violence Threat
description: A black Milwaukee Alderman who has increasingly clashed with other city officials over racial issues has been censured by his colleagues on the Milwaukee Common Council. The Council criticized the Alderman, Michael R. McGee, because he supported a black political group that he said had tampered with the products of a local sausage manufacturer.

title: Just a Working Man
description: The three-day conference was about how Central Europe would handle the problems of democracy. But after about 70 minutes, it also became a conference on how to handle Lech Walesa.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Finish planting. Cultivate the ground lightly, weed and mulch to preserve soil moisture. Spray roses once again to protect them from black spot and mildew diseases. Use soil drench on primroses, yews and rhododendrons where black vine weevil adults are feeding. Last call to plant biennial seed.

title: Sports of The Times;   Contagious, Confounding
description: In the hours before the Mets climbed into first place Friday night, Darryl Strawberry turned to Bobby Ojeda, who was sitting at his adjacent locker while waiting to warm up as the starter against the Cincinnati Reds.

title: The World;   Islamic Fundamentalism Is Winning Votes
description: ELEVEN years after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was swept to power in the Iranian revolution, Islamic forces in Algeria, Egypt and Jordan have peacefully secured footholds on power at the ballot box. Elsewhere, Islamic fundamentalists are seeking or consolidating power through the use of arms and intimidation.

title: All About/Yellow Pages;   Changing Shopping Habits Keep Those Fingers Walking
description: Yellow Pages publishers are learning to behave less like utility companies and more like their advertising brethren on Madison Avenue. In the six years since the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Yellow Pages have gone from dowdy and predicatable - almost like the white pages - to venturesome and competitive. ''The Yellow Pages have always been perceived as a stagnant and stodgy medium,'' said Larry Small, a vice president of the Yellow Page Publishers Association, an American trade group. ''But people's shopping habits are changing. There is more catalogue shopping, more home TV shopping. If we spend all our time protecting our turf and none of our time exploring new terrain, that's short-sighted.'' The new era brought plenty of challenges, and some quick responses. Newly independent regional telephone companies began invading one another's territories, cloning local directories. Specialty Yellow Pages proliferated, aimed at Hispanics, the elderly, gay people, even weekend boaters. New gimmicks multipled, from tear-out coupons to ''audio text'' numbers that offered recorded messages with anything from sports scores to soap opera updates. Today, many publishers have retrenched, scrapping specialty directories. Yellow Pages titles in the United States, which surged from 5,800 in 1983 to 6,700 in 1986, have declined to 6,300. The most ambitious flop was the Southwestern Bell's ''Silver Pages,'' a directory for senior citizens offered in 90 cities that was dropped in 1988 after three years. The elderly, it seemed, didn't like being singled out.

title: The World;   Will Mandela's Triumphs Abroad Enlarge His Power Back Home?
description: WHEN Nelson Mandela's world tour ends on July 18, he will have received the praise of heads of state and badly needed hard cash for his African National Congress. But he is likely to find that his triumphs abroad will have only limited bearing on the A.N.C.'s fight to replace white minority rule at home.

title: For a Rose Fancier, The Older, the Better
description: THOMAS CHRISTOPHER loves Katharina Zeimet - a rose with origins in 19th-century Japan. He also likes Harison's Yellow, a rose favored by the pioneers, and Gallicas, roses that grew in France when it was Gaul.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: U.S. Cocaine Epidemic Shows Signs of Waning
description: After a decade of escalating cocaine use, researchers around the country say evidence is accumulating that the epidemic may have reached its peak.

title: Free and Clear
description: Before June 5, 1989, Fang Lizhi's fame was generally limited to the scientific community, where he was known as a distinguished Chinese astrophysicist. But then came the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, and Mr. Fang, who believes Marxism had failed in China, was accused of being an instigator. Mr. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, took asylum in the United States Embassy, where they lived as China's most well-known dissidents until last week, when China allowed them to take an American plane to London. A Chinese Government statement said Mr. Fang was being allowed to leave to seek medical treatment, and mentioned, as if it were news, that he and Miss Li had admitted opposing the Four Cardinal Principles of the Chinese Constitution, which include adherence to Marxism-Leninism. Most diplomats believe the United States' extension of most-favored-nation trading status to China, shortly before the release, played an important part in the negotiations. For now, Mr. Fang said at Cambridge University, where he will continue his research, ''We look forward to a period of peace and quiet.''

title: Miss Licht Weds Wallace Turner
description: Betsy Ann Licht, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Licht of Upper Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Wallace Richard Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Turner of Bay Shore, L.I. The Rev. Alan J. Edmiston, an Episcopal priest, and Joseph Suozzi, a former Justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, officiated.

title: No Headline
description: Guadeloupe To the Editor: We were so happy to wake up to discover the smiling face of Chef Gerard Virginius (Travel, April 22).

title: Susan Sherrerd Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. F. Sherrerd of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Moore Sherrerd to Steven Kent Vogel, a son of Prof. Ezra F. Vogel and Suzanne Hall Vogel, both of Cambridge, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our kitchen cabinets are covered with a walnut-tone plastic laminate that we dislike. We would like to paint over it, and were wondering what kind of paint to use. If we do not like the paint after it is applied, will this make it more difficult to remove the old laminate later on if we decide to replace it?

title: Federal Cash for Homeless: It's There but Tough to Get
description: Mary Rose Gerdes, lithe and lovely at the age of 63, smiles nervously and says in a fragile voice that this is how she used to be: ''a bag of bones'' and a recovering alcoholic living in a ''perpetual rage cage.'' Other words creep in, like pancreatitis and severe depression, to describe the conditions that caused her to lose her job and then her home.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Who's Who at the Party Congress
description: IVAN K. POLOZKOV

title: World Cup '90;   West Germany in Semifinals
description: With a week remaining in the 1990 World Cup, it seems foolhardy not to expect West Germany in a third consecutive final match when the tournament ends Sunday night in Rome.

title: Trevino Outduels Nicklaus in Stretch
description: In his seven months as a supernova on the Senior PGA Tour, Lee Trevino has done everything a 50-year-old golfer can do except win one of the tour's major championships and beat Jack Nicklaus.

title: Question Box
description: Oh, Brouthers!

title: No-Hitter, but With No Glory
description: Their season has been part folly and part frustration, but today the Yankees found a new low to their crazy summer.

title: Brawl in a French Cathedral
description: A fight erupted after Mass today at the cathedral in this northern suburb of Paris as traditionalist Roman Catholics, shoving the vicar aside, tried to move in to celebrate their own service in Latin. Punches were thrown, the organ sounded and candles went flying down an aisle as about 60 traditionalists tried to take over the main altar at the St. Maclou Cathedral. A policeman tried to mediate in the brawl, which continued for more than hour, ending when the Rev. Andre Berrere agreed to offer his Latin Mass in a side chapel.

title: Cuomo Demurs On Presidency; Meets Disbelief
description: A network television appearance by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today highlighted the paradox about the Governor's musings on the Presidency - the more Mr. Cuomo protests that he is not running, the more people seem to disbelieve him.

title: Evolution in Europe;   For Average East German, Wonder and Some Trepidation    Cottbus: From New Money, New Self-Respect?
description: For many East Germans, the first day of economic union yesterday stirred expectations of dreams fulfilled and wariness of possible new hardships. Here are reports from three cities.

title: Jet Makes Emergency Stop
description: A Northwest Airlines jet with 182 people on board made an emergency landing on Saturday at an airport here after the pilot shut down one engine because of an oil leak. There were no injuries, officials said.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   In Mayor's Courtroom, An Impassive Effi Barry
description: For two weeks now, Effi Barry, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s wife of 12 years, has stoically sat in Courtroom No. 2 at the Federal Courthouse here, a front-row spectator in the riveting drug trial of her husband.

title: Sharon Given Broad Power on Housing
description: The Israeli Government today approved Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's request for sweeping emergency powers to begin a crash housing construction program for Soviet Jewish immigrants.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bauer Is Surprise Leader
description: The Tour de France seemed to be thrown up for grabs today after four major riders, none of them favorites, stormed to the finish more than 10 minutes faster than most of the rest of the 198-man field.

title: PC/Computing Growth
description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company magazine PC/Computing has acquired the subscriber list of Personal Computing. The Dutch company VNU will stop publishing Personal Computing after its August issue.

title: Janine Golding and Neal Ochsner Wed
