description: Janine Meyers Golding, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Golding of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Neal Howard Ochsner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard Ochsner of Phoenix. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Harold Saperstein.

title: Allison Cocke Is Wed To Brad Scott Lerner
description: The marriage of Allison Cocke, the daughter of Kathryn Peterson Cocke of San Antonio, and Dr. Joseph Garber Cocke Jr. of Orlando, Fla., to Brad Scott Lerner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lerner of Plainview, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Gary Creditor officiated at the Southwest Craft Center in San Antonio, assisted by Cantor Morris Wolk.

title: Result of a Double Switch: 2 Effective Managers;   Merrill Makes Yankees Believe They Can Win
description: SUCCESS hasn't spoiled Stump Merrill. He still chews tobacco, still enjoys light beer, still jogs despite his doctor's orders and still manages every game as if he were in West Haven or Albany instead of the Bronx.

title: New U.S. Arms Initiative
description: President Bush is proposing the withdrawal of NATO's nuclear artillery shells and other measures to build Soviet confidence in the alliance's peaceful intentions. Page A8.

title: Few Bond Offerings Scheduled
description: Treasury financings this holiday-shortened week are confined to the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills today.

title: A 2d-Quarter Rebound for the World's Markets
description: What goes up must come down, and vice versa. And that is just what happened in the world's stock markets in the second quarter.

title: Referee Finally Gets Respect
description: AFTER 32 years of officiating in the National Basketball Association, Earl Strom said he finally feels as though he fits in.

title: Grand Army Plaza, Redressed
description: Strictly speaking, it's not really the center of Manhattan Island. And yet it is, this glorious space reigned over by the most unlikely of couples, the goddess Pomona and Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman. Especially now.

title: Jazz Festival;   Ella Fitzgerald, Bouncy and Aggressive
description: Ella Fitzgerald's show on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, started out slowly. Miss Fitzgerald, who had a cold or sinus problem, had a tough time navigating her tunes, and the upper register of her voice wasn't cooperating; it strayed off pitch and sounded uncharacteristically harsh.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bechtel Group Inc., San Francisco, appointed Mike Komes to direct marketing and strategy operations. Gary Bechtel was named to succeed him as president of the Becon Construction Co. subsidiary.

title: North Sea Hit by Oil Strike
description: Norway closed oil and gas wells today after the biggest offshore workers' union went on strike in the North Sea.

title: Detroit Journal;   One Man's Treasure, Another's Junkyard
description: In a rough-and-tumble shell of a neighborhood on Detroit's East Side, motorists lunge for the brakes when they get to Heidelberg Street.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Jazz Festival;   Stan Getz, Weaving His Moods
description: Stan Getz was very much the center of attention at his JVC Jazz Festival concert on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. The entire concert was played by his quartet - Kenny Barron on piano; Alex Blake on bass, and Terri Lyne Carrington on drums - or his sextet, which was the quartet with Eddie Del Barrio and Frank Zottoli on synthesizers.

title: R. A. Campanioni, 34, a Philanthropist Aiding Gay Projects
description: Raul A. Campanioni, a stockbroker who ran a firm that served gay clients and donated heavily to gay causes, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Chelsea.

title: Allison Plesur Is Married
description: Allison Plesur and Robert D. Lipman, associates in the New York law firm of Jackson, Lewis, Schnitzler & Krupman, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Howard Buechler officiated. The bride, 25 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Plesur of Hauppauge, L.I. Mr. Lipman, 29, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan R. Lipman of Buffalo. The couple graduated from the Cornell University School of Industrial and Labor Relations. She received a law degree from New York Law School and he received one from the Buffalo Law School.

title: Anti-Tax Protesters Demand Florio's Recall, for Starters
description: On the day they began paying new taxes on services and products varying from telephone calls to toilet paper, thousands of angry New Jersey residents took part in a cross-state convoy to the State House. There they chanted for the recall of Gov. Jim Florio and threatened to vote out of office all legislators who approved the new taxes last month.

title: Gorbachev's Last Chance - Democracy
description: For more than five years, Mikhail Gorbachev has preached the gospel of democracy. Starting today, with the 28th Communist Party Congress, he must begin to practice it or risk losing his remaining power base.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Behind the Taped Images In the Marion Barry Case
description: Whether the videotape introduced last week in the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. on drug and perjury charges demonstrates guilt or entrapment may be left to theologians of the law, but ordinary viewers have been finding it quite a show. Produced by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and brought to the nation by C-Span, the 90-minute feature, which is to be shown to the jury again today by the Washington Mayor's defense, is a farce with Dostoyevskian overtones.

title: Cardinal Leading Us Right to the Reformation;   Law of the Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on Saturday about ways in which Canada's constitutional crisis might affect United States-Canadian relations misidentified the Premier of British Columbia. He is William Vander Zalm.

title: Soviet Widow Mourns Doctor Slain in Queens
description: On the last evening of his life, Dr. Arkady Novikov and his wife, Galina, acted like typical New York tourists: They ate dinner with friends, then visited Chinatown, SoHo and Little Italy.

title: Mexico Acts to Sell Banks
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico sent a measure to the nation's lawmakers last week to sell the state-owned banking industry, which was nationalized in 1982, and permit foreign ownership of up to 30 percent.

title: Report Says General Knew Of Stealth Fighter's Failure
description: A top Air Force general knew that the Stealth fighter plane had missed its targets in its first combat mission, but he did not tell his superiors at the Pentagon, a classified report says.

title: Evolution in Europe;   In a Leap Toward Unity, 2 Germanys Meld Currencies
description: East Germans formed orderly lines across the land today to get their West German currency, irrevocably throwing in their lot with the capitalist world and turning into the home stretch toward reunification.

title: Jazz Festival;   All-Star Quartet Flouts Category and Decorum
description: The Beacon Theater on Saturday night was no place for anyone who expects live jazz to sound like recordings. The alphabetically billed quartet of Jack DeJohnette (drums), Herbie Hancock (keyboards), Dave Holland (bass) and Pat Metheny (guitar) tossed out marketing and genre categories along with decorum. They mixed acoustic and synthetic sounds in mainstream jazz pieces, usually a taboo; they pushed aside the strictures of pop-jazz tunes to delve where they pleased. The music was filled with the joy of risks taken and surmounted.

title: How to Ease Traffic on L.I.? How About by Driving Less?
description: After years of spending money on building and improving Long Island's roads, the State Department of Transportation has concluded that the best way to handle the traffic problems here is to also persuade people to drive less.

title: Bernice Hoffman Becomes a Bride
description: Bernice E. Hoffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Hoffman of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Daniel P. Natelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Natelson of Elizabeth, N.J. Rabbis Michael Gold and Stephen Steindel performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth El.

title: J. Walter Thompson Wins Nuprin Account
description: After a short review, J. Walter Thompson's New York office has won the estimated $30 million Nuprin account.

title: Bishop Warns Third Person on Abortion
description: The director of a second abortion clinic in Corpus Christi, Tex., said yesterday that she had received two warnings of excommunication from the same Roman Catholic bishop who recently excommunicated the director of another clinic and an obstetrician.

title: On Many Farms, a Season of Disaster
description: Stands of wheat that only recently stood golden and glistening in the sun are dry and broken now, dashing Charlie Joe James's hopes for a bountiful return for his year of money and labor. ''That's what the flood left,'' he said. Mr. James, who had planted 750 acres of wheat, is one of thousands of farmers from Texas north to Illinois and from Iowa east to Ohio who have been tormented by the winds, persistent rains and floods of 1990.

title: Soviet Effort for Patent Law Reform Gaining Momentum
description: Amid efforts by the Soviet Union to liberalize its stagnant economy, a seemingly quixotic movement to adopt a Western-style patent law is gaining momentum.

title: Evolution in Europe;   For Average East Germans, Wonder and Some Trepidation    East Berlin: 'It's Got to Be Better Than What We Had'
description: For many East Germans, the first day of economic union yesterday stirred expectations of dreams fulfilled and wariness of possible new hardships. Here are reports from three cities.

title: Yachting;   Liberty Cup Is Halted And Australian Wins
description: Bobby Wilmot of Australia won the Liberty Cup Regatta yesterday afternoon after the event was cut short by a severe thunderstorm that sent most of the traffic in New York Harbor scurrying for shore.

title: Chronicle
description: For the first time in its 143-year history, the New York Academy of Medicine has appointed a full-time president, DR. JEREMIAH A. BARONDESS, a leading internist and teacher who plans to concentrate on improving medical education and public health.

title: Jazz Festival;   Merging Downtown With Vanguard
description: Graham Haynes's show at the Equitable Center on Friday afternoon, as part of JVC Jazz Festival's Knitting Factory Goes Uptown series, did a smart thing. By merging participants in the downtown scene -the harpist and keyboardist Zeena Parkins as well as members of the band Bosho, including Chulo on bass and Yuval Gabay on drums and Kumiko Kimoto on percussion - with members of the jazz vanguard, it drew on the strengths of the two camps. The downtown scene, long on eccentric, hard grooves, and clever in making textures, is short on extended soloing techniques in the jazz tradition. The jazz vanguard, short on textural approaches to music and clumsy when appropriating popular music, is fine at soloing.

title: Filipino Rebels Hold Member Of Peace Corps, U.S. Reports
description: Communist guerrillas abducted a Peace Corps volunteer on the central Philippine island of Negros more than two weeks ago and continue to hold him, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Business Scene;   Times Are Tough For U.S. Builders
description: THE big new scare for the already sluggish American economy is coming from the construction industry, particularly home construction. Building loans are hard to get, customers are scarce and the unemployment rate among the nation's construction workers is 10.3 percent, higher than in any other industry.

title: Plant Trees. Then Protect Them.
description: Global warming poses an uncommon threat to life on the planet, but what can ordinary people do about it? Plant a tree. This requires a shovel, a stake - in the ground and the future - and a seedling. If people live in an urban hardscape, they may want to follow the advice of Andy Lipkis, founder of a growing California organization called TreePeople, who has prompted the planting of a million trees in Los Angeles.

title: Baseball;   Pirate's 4 Homers Bring 8-5 Victory Over the Giants
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates hit four home runs, including two-run shots by Barry Bonds, Sid Bream and Jay Bell, to beat the Giants, 8-5, today, and retain a one-game lead over the Mets in the National League East.

title: New Dailies Proliferate in Spain as Ads Surge
description: Although newspaper circulation has remained stagnant in Spain since the 1930's, publishers have been rushing to start new dailies in a scramble to tap the booming advertising market here.

title: On Your Own;   Connecting a Fairway
description: EVERY weekend for the last four months, Dan and Donna Doyle picked up debris, cut down trees and cleared paths in a park infested with litter and plagued by vandalism. Their purpose? To renovate the Buzzy Creek disk golf course in New Milford, N.J.

title: AGB Losing Its TV-Ratings Monopoly in Britain
description: Even as Robert Maxwell plans to challenge the A. C. Nielsen Company in the American television market, his market research company is suffering setbacks in Britain and Australia.

title: Fat Wallets and Fear Of Lean Times Ahead
description: In cities across East Germany, people greeted economic union without giddy celebration, sobered by its significance and a sense that capitalism would mean hardship for many. But some anticipated fulfilling dreams.

title: China Counts Its Billion-Plus Noses
description: Millions of census workers combed houses and shacks throughout the nation today as China launched a huge effort to count the largest population in the world and to find out just how big it is.

title: Review/City Ballet;   Ib Andersen in a Fitting Farewell as Apollo
description: Ib Andersen gave what was billed as his farewell performance in New York with the New York City Ballet on Friday night amid standing ovations and expressions of warmth and humor onstage from the company that he joined in 1980.

title: Congress Doesn't Get Paid Nearly Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Housing Crisis in Israel

title: Checkpoints Ruling Helps Gnaw at Foundations of Bill of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Higuey Journal;   Brief Voyage to a Better Life, or a Watery Death
description: For Jose Castillo and his small band of friends, a shimmering life of comfort and fast money lies just across the narrow, perilous strait that separates this country from Puerto Rico.

title: Florida's New Top Judge Faces Opposition
description: Justice Leander Shaw today became the first black to be Chief Justice of the Florida Supreme Court, but his position is threatened by anti-abortion groups that are seeking to remove him from the bench because of his rulings on abortion.

title: Chrysler Raising Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation will raise prices on most of its 1990 passenger cars on Monday. The nation's No. 3 auto maker said suggested retail price increases start at $60 for Dodge Daytona cars, which will have a base price of $9,805, and most Chrysler LeBarons, which will rise to about $12,555. The biggest increases are $160 on the Chrysler Fifth Avenue and Chrysler Imperial models, bringing their base prices to $21,020 and $25,655, respectively. Prices will not increase on Plymouth Sundance, Dodge Shadow, Eagle Premier and Dodge Monaco cars.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: Liberia Rebels Within 5 Miles Of the Capital, Spurring Panic
description: Rebel forces fought a fierce artillery and rocket duel today with Government troops on the northern outskirts of Monrovia, the capital.

title: Feeling the Itch
description: WHEN Greg Buttle, who anchored the Jets' linebacker corps, was released in August 1985 after nine seasons, he handed his playbook to the assistant trainer and vowed that he would never play football again.

title: Cardinal Leading Us Right to the Reformation
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Dates Hawkins Won't Forget
description: Andy Hawkins will likely never forget the no-hitter he pitched today, but to some degree, it will always be one of two dates that will forever mark his 1990 season.

title: Insurers Brace for Debate On How Industry Operates
description: In advancing a bill last month that would subject insurance companies to Federal antitrust laws, the House Judiciary Committee has set the stage for a long and bitter debate about the pricing and availability of insurance coverage.

title: Juliana Kelly Wed To Jonathan May
description: Juliana Kelly, the daughter of Anna Kelly of Southampton, L.I., and Michael J. Kelly of Woodside, Queens, was married yesterday to Jonathan Paul May, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. May of New York and Bridgewater, Conn. Judge Morton I. Riefberg of the Connecticut Superior Court, performed the ceremony at the Bridgewater home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Handling of Winfield Is Key Part Of Inquiry
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent's investigation into George Steinbrenner concentrates less on the Yankee owner's highly publicized payments to Howard Spira than on Steinbrenner's contentious relationship with his former player Dave Winfield.

title: RIGHT-TO-DIE BILL PASSES IN ALBANY
description: State lawmakers passed landmark legislation today allowing New Yorkers to designate surrogates to make health-care decisions - including decisions that could end life - if they become incompetent to do so themselves.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East-West Berlin, a Boomtown in the Making
description: On both sides of the crumbling remnants of the Berlin Wall, signs of an economic boom are everywhere, a direct result of the merger of the East and West German economies.

title: Outdoors: No Sleep, But Lots of Bass
description: I HAVE just had my first decent night's sleep in seven days. The other six evenings were devoted to the best fly fishing for striped bass I have experienced in more than 35 years.

title: Harold Fulgenzi Wed To Judy A. Frishberg
description: Judy Amy Frishberg, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick E. Loewus of New York and Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Samuel Frishberg, was married yesterday to Harold C. Fulgenzi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Fulgenzi of Hobe Sound, Fla. Judge Laura E. Drager of New York City Criminal Court performed the ceremony at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: On Your Own;   Go Fly A Kite For Competitive Fun
description: RON REICH barked out instructions to his three teammates as Top of the Line went through its team precision routine. The double lines of the stunt kites crossed, uncrossed and crossed again as the kites flew in formation, following each other through loops, figure-8's and square turns, and then instantaneously broke ranks, looped in different directions and reformed a new line with a new direction.

title:
On Your Own;

Taking to the Woods With Audubon Classes
description: LEAD: The traditional methods of studying the outdoors in the classroom can be as dry as dust: interesting subjects made dull by textbook pictures, charts and a field trips a semester.

title: Researchers Challenge Ideas on Dinosaur Arms
description: As though the reputation of Tyrannosaurus rex was not already horrific enough, two paleontologists now propose that the carnivorous dinosaur had powerful forelimbs that could easily grasp 400 pounds of writhing prey.

title: Result of a Double Switch: 2 Effective Managers;   Harrelson Sows Mets Importance Of Involvement
description: ''YOU can't rehearse for this job,'' Bud Harrelson was saying. ''They give it to you, and there it is.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Spin Hopes To Challenge Rolling Stone
description: AFTER a turbulent half-decade, executives at Spin magazine say they have fresh hope of challenging Rolling Stone as the pre-eminent magazine of music and youth culture.

title: Mets Rally in the 9th To Edge Reds, 3-2
description: The Mets, wasting no time wallowing in regret over the end of their 11-game winning streak, bounced back in the rain and slop in the ninth inning yesterday to edge the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2.

title: Gregory Vistnes Weds Jessica Primoff
description: Jessica Lynn Primoff, the daughter of Arlene Kelvin of Bayside, Queens, and the late Melvin Primoff, was married yesterday in White Plains to Gregory Scott Vistnes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lars Vistnes of Los Altos, Calif. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman and the Rev. Pamela Blair, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Mansion at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel.

title: Capital Spending Cut by RJR
description: Struggling with billions of dollars of debt after the largest leveraged buyout in history, RJR Nabisco Inc. has slashed capital spending this year as it seeks fresh loans to pay off old ones.

title: The Trevino-Nicklaus Heat
description: FOR nearly 20 years, their rivalry had simmered in the memories of Merion and Muirfield, but now it's boiling again: the wisecracking grandson of a Mexican gravedigger who has ascended to golf's royalty with a goofy swing against the calculating conglomerate who is considered by most aficionados to be the best golfer in history.

title: Mandela Arrives in Ireland
description: Nelson Mandela arrived to a rapturous Irish welcome today. The Irish, staunch supporters of the South African black nationalist leader, thronged Dawson Street in the center of the capital as Mr. Mandela arrived from the United States. On Monday, Mr. Mandela will talk with Prime Minister Charles Haughey and address the Irish Parliament before flying to London.

title: Limits Are Sought On Games, Practice
description: When delegates to the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention voted in January to shorten the college basketball season and reduce spring football practice, college presidents promised that more reductions would follow.

title: Cardinal Leading Us Right to the Reformation;   Where Is True Healing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Will the Abortion Fight Ever End?;   A Nation Held Hostage
description: Last week, in a pair of cases from Minnesota and Ohio, the Supreme Court wrote the latest chapter in the abortion story. It upheld state power to require pregnant minors to consult their parents or obtain a judge's permission before any abortion. The abortion question thus remains in the political arena, where the Supreme Court tossed it in the Webster case a year ago.

title: Books of The Times;   He's a Press Agent, Darn It, Not a PR Man!
description: The Sporting Life

title: Oil Price Slide Fails to Register At Gas Pumps
description: Crude oil prices are 20 percent lower than they were at this time last year, but the price of gasoline at the pump has not dropped.

title: Evolution in Europe;   For Average East Germans, Wonder and Some Trepidation    Potsdam: Vacations for Some, Pink Slips for Others
description: For many East Germans, the first day of economic union yesterday stirred expectations of dreams fulfilled and wariness of possible new hardships. Here are reports from three cities.

title: Ms. Pollack Weds Daniel Wollman
description: Debra Ann Pollack, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Pollack of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Eric Wollman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Wollman of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky performed the ceremony assisted by Cantor Jacob Mendelson at the Temple Israel Center in White Plains.

title: Jazz Festival;   Earthiness With a Chill
description: Although Nancy Wilson has never been the artistic equal of Ella Fitzgerald, Sarah Vaughan or Billie Holiday, since becoming popular in the early 1960's she has exerted a considerable influence on a younger generation of pop-jazz interpreters. And on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, where she headlined a JVC Jazz Festival benefit concert for Jazzmobile, one was struck especially by her impact on Anita Baker. The younger singer has not only adopted some of Miss Wilson's tricks of phrasing but copied her hair style and hand gestures as well.

title: Will the Abortion Fight Ever End?;   Catholics Vs. The Media
description: The liberal media are once again attempting to position themselves as our nation's exclusive moral guardian.

title: Accounts
description: * Silo Inc., Philadelphia, a subsidiary of the electronics retailer Dixons Group P.L.C., to Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific, with a budget of $5 million.

title: A Genuinely Affirmative Action
description: The Supreme Court ended its term last week with a stunning reaffirmation of Congress's power to keep the Constitution's promise of equality. For the sake of diversity, and not merely to remedy past discrimination, Congress may help minorities win a greater share of Federal benefits.

title: IN THE NATION New Taxes for What?
description: Bushspeak is not yet a sufficiently recognized language to explain the President's switch on taxes, which he says was not a switch, or not really a switch. Here is his concise attempt, faithfully reproduced from his news conference last week, to explain what it was instead:

title: Evolution in Europe;   Walesa Wins a Test Against Premier
description: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland decisively lost a test of strength with Lech Walesa this weekend, exposing his Government's precarious foundation of support and raising questions about whether his Cabinet could survive without changes.

title: Leading the Enigma Called Xerox
description: An enigmatic person may be provocatively appealing, but unfortunately for the Xerox Corporation's relations with Wall Street, an enigmatic company is usually seen as just plain annoying.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 1:

title: Cardinal Leading Us Right to the Reformation;   Remember John Jay
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines;   Perception Vs. Reality: Just How Bad Is Business?
description: IN the magazine industry these days, is the glass half empty or half full?

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Great American Bank Appoints a New Chief
description: LEAD: The Great American Bank, the nation's seventh-largest savings and loan association, but one with deep financial troubles, has announced the retirement of its chairman and chief executive, Gordon C. Luce, who is being succeeded by Robert L. Kemper, a former vice chairman of the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: Abortion Bill in Louisiana May Keep Democrats Away
description: Whatever chance New Orleans had to be the site of the 1992 Democratic National Convention has been seriously undermined by the anti-abortion legislation approved by the Louisiana Legislature last week, top party officials say.

title: James S. Wallerstein; Biochemist, 79
description: James Scheuer Wallerstein, a biochemist and the president of the Sarah S. Ollesheimer Fund, a college scholarship foundation in Mount Kisco, N.Y., died on Thursday at his home in Mount Kisco. He was 79 years old.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Keeping Emotions Under Control at Jogger Trial
description: For a week, the jury in the case of the Central Park jogger listened as Elizabeth Lederer, the prosecutor, led other victims through their recollections of fright and pain that night almost 15 months ago.

title: Reading Test Scores Decline For 9th and 10th Graders
description: The spring 1990 reading and mathematics achievement test scores for the New York City public schools show a sharp decline in reading scores among ninth and 10th graders, but otherwise are virtually unchanged from last year.

title: In North Carolina, the New South Rubs Uneasily With the Old Ways
description: Forty-five minutes down Interstate 85, researchers are pushing at the boundaries of medical science at the Duke University Medical Center, but there has recently been an epochal breakthrough here: nearly all the residents who had been using old pine outhouses have been able to replace them with indoor bathrooms.

title: A Datamarine Founder Is Ousted From Posts
description: It is not enough to come up with a successful product and build a company around it. The company must continue to be successful, as many founder-chief executives have learned.

title: On Your Own;   At Last, An End To Lost Locks
description: A mechanical engineer who became exasperated over the frequent loss of bicycle locks and cables belonging to his nine children has created a retractable lock that is fastened to the cycle.

title:
Sports World Specials: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;

A New Recruit For West Point
description: LEAD: LIKE the Yale bulldog and the Navy goat, the Army mule has become not only a famous mascot but also an important part of tradition at the United States Military Academy and a colorful adjunct to football games at Michie Stadium and other ceremonial functions.

title: James P. Hendrick, 88, Former Federal Official
description: James Pomeroy Hendrick, a lawyer who was an adviser to Eleanor Roosevelt and later became deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury, died yesterday in Conway, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in St. Croix in the Virgin Islands.

title: Stocks Outperform Expectations
description: The performance of stocks in the second quarter turned out to be less gloomy than many financial analysts had predicted. In spite of sluggishness in the economy, many financial analysts said the market's performance had exceeded expectations.

title: Article 580190 -- No Title
description: The world's largest jewelry retailer, Ratners Group P.L.C. of London, is expected to announce today that it is buying Kay Jewelers Inc., the last of the United States' large independent jewelry chains, for about $400 million in stock.

title: People
description: * Dale P. Brown has been named president and chief executive of Sive Associates, a Cincinnati marketing communications firm owned by Young & Rubicam.

title: Fraud Also Invaded Intelligence Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner Accuses Pathe of Double Sales
description: The $100 million lawsuit that Time Warner Inc. has filed against the Pathe Communications Corporation accuses the Italian company of trying to sell the same film distribution and home video rights twice.

title: Chronicle
description: Twenty teen-agers are in Moscow, participating in track meets, basketball games and summer camp. A girls' track team and a boys' basketball team, accompanied by ROBERT M. MORGENTHAU, the Manhattan District Attorney, were picked from Police Athletic League teams from throughout New York City. P.A.L. offers sports and cultural programs to 55,000 youngsters in 160 locations in the city.

title: Tourists Greet Bush's Mother
description: Tourists sang ''Happy Birthday'' to 89-year-old Dorothy Walker Bush today as she emerged from St. Ann's by the Sea Episcopal Church on the arm of her son, President Bush. ''Thanks for the greeting for my Mom,'' the vacationing President said.

title: Dr. Beckett Weds Douglas Shenson
description: Dr. Alexandra Beckett, the daughter of William R. Beckett of New York and Sheffield, Mass., and Hilary Schlessiger of New York was married yesterday to Douglas Shenson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Shenson of Los Angeles, by Cantor David Benedict at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Chronicle
description: Senator WYCHE FOWLER Jr., Democrat of Georgia, married DONNA HULSIZER of Washington on Saturday at the Central Presbyterian Church in Atlanta. It was a private ceremony attended by family members and close friends.

title: Media Critics Are Seeking To Turn Talk Into Print
description: About 18 months ago, J. Anthony Lukas, Ken Auletta, Frances FitzGerald and a clutch of other famous journalists began exploring the possibility of starting a magazine that would rip the hide off the media industry.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Things over there got better and better. Here they got worse and worse. The reason I'm confident is that I've seen the worst. No matter what comes now with the new money and the economic change, it's got to be better than what we had.''

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bush Urges Conciliatory Gestures for NATO
description: In a letter to Western European leaders, President Bush has proposed accrediting Eastern European and Soviet diplomats to NATO, reducing NATO forces close to the frontiers between the blocs, withdrawing nuclear artillery shells from Europe and declaring that nuclear weapons are to be used in conflict only as a last resort, NATO and Western officials said today.

title: Jodi Spiegel Weds Dr. Barry Fisher
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Jodi Beth Spiegel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Spiegel of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Fisher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Fisher of Atlantic Beach. Rabbi Sol Roth performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Music;   Late Mozart by Andrew Parrott
description: In recent years the Boston Symphony's Tanglewood Festival in the Berkshires has begun a week early. In other words, in the weekend before the first actual Boston Symphony concert the following Friday night, the festival presents chamber music and other exotica, usually not in the larger shed but in the smaller Theater-Concert Hall.

title: Market Place;   Notes at Harman: Sweet and Sour
description: THE sounds are not very sweet these days at Harman International Industries, maker of such top-of-the-line stereo speakers as Harman-Kardon, JBL and Infinity. Last week, Sidney Harman, the company's chief executive and a former Deputy Secretary of Commerce, told analysts that earnings for the 1990 fiscal year, to be released in August, would be 5 to 7 percent below last year's record high. And the stock hit a new low last week on the New York Stock Exchange, dropping to $11.25, from a 52-week high of $23.50. It closed slightly higher on Friday at $11.75.

title: Lower Rates Seen for Second Half
description: Credit market participants and analysts say they are optimistic that interest rates can decline further in the final six months of the year.

title: Political Memo;   About-Face on Taxes Is No Surprise to Public
description: While President Bush conceded last week that he was now vulnerable to charges that he had broken his word, his turnabout on taxes appears to have fulfilled public expectations.

title: The Dawn Brings a Record Tax Rise
description: At 5:45 A.M. yesterday the New York City Council, weary and a little testy, patted itself on the back and adopted a $28 billion city budget.

title: Construction Fades as Boom Loses Its Vigor
description: So many new towers are rising on the West Side of Manhattan that it is hard to believe the boom is over. But the construction workers who form lunchtime knots on the sidewalks and gather beneath the scaffolding know better.

title: Big Aims, Small Means on Cambodia
description: Time is the most certain enemy of the Bush Administration's Cambodia policy. The longer the current diplomatic stalemate continues, the closer dreaded Khmer Rouge forces come to battlefield victory, and the worse the prospects grow for free elections and a role for the non-Communist forces led by Prince Sihanouk.

title: England Stops Cameroon
description: In the most extended drama of this World Cup soccer tournament, England rallied to defeat Cameroon, 3-2, in overtime tonight, and the tremors could be felt as far away as Turin.

title: 'Grapes of Wrath': Raves and a Tony Do Not Breed a Hit
description: Maybe you think you don't need to see ''The Grapes of Wrath'' on Broadway. You probably read John Steinbeck's book somewhere around 10th grade and caught the movie on a rainy Sunday afternoon. Or maybe you've decided that you see too many homeless people on the streets to want to see them on a stage.

title: Horse Racing;   Storm Disrupts Belmont Card
description: A statewide simulcasting blackout of the races from Belmont Park yesterday left off-track bettors in the dark, along with many of the patrons who weathered a stormy and confusing afternoon at the track.

title: Evolution in Europe;   SOVIET COMMUNISTS CONVENING TODAY ON PARTY'S FUTURE
description: The Communist Party of the Soviet Union, divided, demoralized and endangered by democracy, is convening Monday for its 28th congress, where the main issue will be not so much where the party will lead the country but whether it will lead the country at all.

title: Metro Matters;   Maybe a Picture Can Be Worth 1,000 Votes Too
description: ''One look is worth a thousand words,'' Fred R. Barnard wrote in 1921 in Printers' Ink, a newspaper industry journal. A few years later, he amended his obscure aphorism.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: A Sad Place in History
description: Andy Hawkins of the Yankees became the first modern pitcher to lose a no-hit game with an eight-inning complete-game effort when Chicago scored four runs in the bottom of the eighth on two walks and three errors yesterday.

title: Review/Television;   Mastering the Movies, for a While
description: ''American Masters'' begins its fifth season at 9 tonight on Channel 13 (and at 10 tonight on Channel 50 and 4 A.M. tomorrow on Channel 13) with ''Preston Sturges: The Rise and Fall of an American Dreamer.'' Sturges was the first Hollywood screenwriter to also establish himself as a celebrated director. That was in 1940.

title: Tennis;   2 Champions Clash With Egos at Stake
description: The last time these two Wimbledon champions clashed on Centre Court, the one who won did an impersonation of the way the other had missed a volley and then tumbled over the net during their three-set quarterfinal match. When it ended, the loser wore a strawberry blond fright wig to his news conference.

title: An Iranian Aide Discounts U.S.
description: Iran's Interior Minister said today that the Government had no desire for better relations with the United States and insisted that Iran had done everything it could to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

title: Review/Art;   Courtland Collection Settles Into New Home
description: A new museum has taken rank immediately, and on more than one count, among the cardinal amenities of central London. The recent installation of the Courtauld Institute of Art in Somerset House has signaled the return to life of a long-disinherited palace.

title: Swing Isn't Sweet As Player Falters
description: Gary Player had so much trouble with his swing in the final round of the United States Senior Open that he rushed to the driving range shortly after the completion of the tournament today and hit golf balls until dusk.

title: Bridge
description: The Upper House, it seems, continues to have the upper hand in England. By winning the 16th match in the annual series against the House of Commons in April, the House of Lords increased its lead to 10-6.

title: Chronicle
description: The sculpture of LOUISE BOURGEOIS can be provocative and emotional. So can her views. When Ms. Bourgeois receives the 1990 Edward MacDowell Medal this summer at the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., she plans to talk about art education, candidly.

title: Report Cites Turnover, Despite Law, in Weapons Programs
description: Defense Department officials who manage the Pentagon's largest acquisition programs stay in their positions less than two years on average, despite a law requiring that they remain at least four years, a Congressional report says.

title: Bronx Street Marks Return Of Firehouse
description: There were cinnamon doughnuts and great rejoicing on one short block of the South Bronx yesterday morning. The rain was over and gone for the moment. This year's municipal budget negotiations were complete, and a firehouse was open again on East 150th Street.

title: Manhattan's Cable TV: Is the 'Dinosaur' Really Gone?
description: By 1993, the two cable-television systems in Manhattan - which has perhaps the greatest concentration of producers, network executives and eager-eyed video junkies of any place on the planet - are to carry 70 channels. That is twice as many as they carry now, but fewer channels than are on cable systems in Columbus, Ohio, or Fairfax County, Va.

title: Jazz Festival;   Embracing Tradition
description: Benny Green, the youngest performer this year in the JVC Jazz Festival's solo piano series at Weill Recital Hall, has a traditionalist's pedigree. The 27-year-old Mr. Green studied with the be-bop experts Walter Bishop Jr., Walter Davis Jr. and Larry Willis, and has been a member of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers. Mr. Green reveres the master be-bop pianists Bud Powell and Thelonious Monk.

title: An Inspired Franco
description: John Franco, the Met reliever, did not realize that the Cincinnati Reds, his former team, could be a source of inspiration for pitching harder, but yesterday, they apparently were.

title: Water-Main Break Halts Most Subways On West Side Lines
description: Subway service came to a halt on much of the West Side of Manhattan last night when water gushed from a broken main and flooded the tracks below Central Park West at West 81st Street.

title: New Yorkers Prove Elusive, But Census Is 99% Complete
description: The Census Bureau reported yesterday that 99 percent of the households in the United States that did not respond to first mailings of the 1990 census had now been counted, but that several areas, in particular New York State and City, still lagged far behind.

title: Beth Clearfield Is Married
description: Beth Clearfield, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Clearfield of Lower Burrell, Pa., was married yesterday at the Westin William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh to Reubin Simantov, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer Simantov of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Morris Landes officiated. The bride, 28 years old and a magna cum laude graduate of Yale University, is the director of programming at BBC/Lionheart Television, a distribution company in New York. The bridegroom, 30, is the president of the Reubin Simantov Company, a dealer in antique and estate jewelry in New York.

title: Marquis W. Childs Is Dead at 87; Won a Pulitzer for Commentary
description: Marquis W. Childs, a foreign correspondent, columnist, author and winner of a Pulitzer Prize for distinguished commentary, died Saturday at Children's Hospital of San Francisco. He was 87 years old. The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, where he wrote about Washington and the nation for 47 years, reported that Mr. Childs had died of ''infirmities.'' He had been in failing health for several months and was taken to the hospital Friday after lapsing into a coma at his home, the newspaper said.

title: When Will Pretoria Renounce Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: A Glorious Fourth
description: This year there is special reason to celebrate on the Fourth of July. The American polity has just passed an unusual test of wisdom and self-confidence. Americans have shown, tolerably well, that we understand what this country is about: not flags, not jingoism, but freedom.

title: Telepanel Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Q&A
description: Seeing Stars

title: Clinical Data reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $1,381,000, or 47 cents a share, for the quarter and income of $1,343,000, or 45 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations; discontinued operations for the year included a gain of $1,152,000 on sale of discontinued operations, and an extraordinary tax benefit of $408,000, or 14 cents a share, for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $258,000 and $280,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary charge from reversal of tax loss carryforward of $55,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit of $188,000 for the year. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Bad Back Idles Mattingly as Yanks Fall
description: In his most hopeful voice, Don Mattingly spoke tonight about missing just one game.

title: In Rats, More to Admire, More to Fear
description: As expressions like dirty rat, rat's nest, rat race and smell a rat suggest, the rat may be people's least favorite creature. But the few scientists who are studying it express nothing but admiration for the rat's instincts, ingenuity and tenacity.

title: Economic Pulse; Southern California;   Test for Peace Dividend: Boom or Bust in California
description: Southern California, perhaps more than any other region, offers a clear test of the American economy's capacity to convert from military to peaceful purposes.

title: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   DDB Needham Buys Baker Advertising
description: DDB Needham has acquired Baker Advertising, an agency based in Troy, Mich. DDB Needham did not disclose terms of the deal but said it would merge Baker with DDB Needham Detroit.

title: Advanced Computer Techiques reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Feeling Effects of Bush and the Bailout
description: Unlike the vast majority of Congressional incumbents, Representative John Hiler fights for his political life every two years, and this year President Bush's reversal on taxes promises to make that fight more difficult than usual.

title: The Media Business;   Ingersoll, in Swap, Sheds His U.S. Papers
description: Ralph McA. Ingersoll 2d, who aggressively acquired newspapers in this country over the last decade but has been under mounting financial pressure, left the newspaper business in the United States yesterday to run newspapers in Europe.

title: Richard B. Tuggle, 92, World War II Admiral
description: Richard Brittain Tuggle, a retired rear admiral who participated in several major battles in World War II, died Sunday at the age of 92. No cause of death was given.

title: Board of Education: 2 Veterans and 5 Newcomers
description: Gwendolyn C. Baker

title: Maax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $86,000 for the latest first quarter and $10,000 for year-ago period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Seven Oaks International reports earnings for Year April 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $229,000 and after an extraordinary credit of $173,000, or 3 cents a share. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,041,000.

title: West Germany Export Leader
description: West Germany was the world's biggest exporter for the first three months of 1990, regaining the lead from the United States, the International Monetary Fund reported on Sunday.

title: Construction Spending Drops 0.4%
description: The construction industry remained in a slump in May as spending dropped four-tenths of 1 percent for its second straight monthly decline, the Government said today.

title: Chronicle
description: As part of the settlement of her divorce from JOHN W. KLUGE, PATRICIA KLUGE got the house. Real-estate records in Charlottesville, Va., indicate that a 9.9-acre parcel, which includes a 45-room Georgian mansion, Albemarle House, was transferred to Mrs. Kluge on June 13, The Richmond News Leader reported yesterday.

title: Deal for Kay Is Valued at $410 Million
description: Ratners Group P.L.C., the world's largest jewelry retailer, announced in London yesterday that as expected it would acquire Kay Jewelers Inc., the third-largest American jewelry chain, for about $410 million in stock.

title: 'Waiting for Harold,' a L.I.R.R. Saga
description: On the first Monday of a major reconstruction project that will incovenience everyone who takes the Long Island Rail Road this summer, dozens of trains were late yesterday, scores of forlorn passengers waited at Pennsylvania Station for canceled trains, and Chris McEvoy spent more than three hours trying to go home.

title: Baseball;   White Sox Recover In 9th to Stay in First
description: Chicago's vaunted bullpen lost a three-run lead in the eighth inning tonight, but a run-scoring single by Carlton Fisk in the ninth gave the White Sox a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers. Chicago remained 4 percentage points ahead of Oakland in the American League West.

title: Horizon Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits from extinguishment of debt of $26,222 for the quarter and $89,576 for the year. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $135,000. d-Net income

title: For Satellite Watchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke's Chief in Europe To Head U.S. Division
description: After a year heading the Coca-Cola Company's operations in the European Community, M. Douglas Ivester is becoming president of Coca-Cola USA. The move was one of a number of management changes announced by the company at its Atlanta headquarters yesterday.

title: Brock Exploration reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Our Towns;   Country Cunning: A Mailbox Built To Endure It All
description: The idea had long lingered in William O'Keefe's mind, but it didn't take shape until three years ago, shortly after he found his dented and decapitated mailbox lying along a country road. Why not build an indestructible mailbox? Mr. O'Keefe, a service manager for a local oil company, had already lost seven mailboxes to vandalism. Many of his neighbors' mailboxes were also frequent targets for teen-age terrorists tossing cherry bombs or wielding Louisville Sluggers. Some residents even carried their mailboxes out in the morning and in at night, especially during the summer and on Halloween.

title: New View of Ocean
description: A NEW invention that is about to be tested at sea promises to give scientists a view of marine life that until now has been hidden from humans.

title: Ruling Overturns a Zoning Law; Judge Stresses Affordable Housing
description: In a case that may force restrictively zoned suburbs to open up, a state justice today invalidated an ordinance in North Salem, saying it ignored local and regional housing needs by failing to provide for affordable multifamily housing.

title: Citizens Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Jersey Steel reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Foreign Debt Of U.S. Rises
description: The United States sank deeper in debt in 1989, the Commerce Department reported today, as the nation's overall deficit with the rest of the world swelled by 25 percent, to $663.7 billion.

title: Challenger International Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $140,000.

title: Capriati Doesn't Measure Up to Graf
description: She lost, but lost with a grateful smile, too exhilarated by her lofty surroundings and venerable opponent to be very sorry about the way her Wimbledon adventure came to a halt.

title: Sports People: Professional Hockey;   Still Hurting, Lemieux Seeks New Treatment
description: Mario Lemieux, the Pittsburgh Penguins' star center, who missed six weeks of the past National Hockey League season while he sought therapy for his back, is scheduled for further treatment in Los Angeles this month.

title: Sandy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The Media Business: Advertising;   Shop Seeks To Spread Its Wings
description: BONNEVILLE COMMUNICATIONS has made its mark by spreading the word of God in an award-winning national public service campaign for its owner, the Mormon Church. Now the Salt Lake City agency is trying to translate its special brand of inspirational advertising into successful campaigns for selling secular products.

title: Company News;   Maxtor Acquires Miniscribe Assets
description: The Maxtor Corporation, manufacturer of computer disk drives, said it had completed the acquisition of the assets of the Miniscribe Corporation, which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, for $46 million. In its previously announced offer, Maxtor pledged up to $30 million in working capital for Miniscribe, which will be called the Maxtor Colorado Corporation.

title: Sports People: Baseball;   Date Set for Rose
description: A United States District Court judge in Cincinnati yesterday set July 19 as the date for Pete Rose's sentencing on felony tax charges.

title: Campeau Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a $47 million gain on the sale of assets and a $21 million restructuring charge. c-Included $98 million gain on the sale of assets.

title: Debentures Priced By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced a total of $1.3 billion in four-year and 10-year debentures through its regular selling group of securities dealers.

title: Company News;   Lockheed to Shut Office in Virginia
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, said it was phasing out its Fairfax, Va., office in a cost-cutting move involving an undetermined number of layoffs. Some of the 90 employees working in Fairfax will be transferred to the Lockheed Integrated Solutions Company in Santa Clara, Calif.; some will move to its Formtek office in Pittsburgh, and others will be laid off, said a Lockheed spokesman, Martin Belles.

title: New Retail Concepts Inc. reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $645,000, or 11 cents a share, and $112,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. The company said that increased revenue is primarily attributable to the commencement of the domestic manufacture and importation of No Excuses Jeanswear during fiscal 1990, and the conversion of manufacturers sales arrangements on November 1, 1989. Revenue represent net revenue.

title: More Than One Way to Aid Khmer Rouge
description: To the Editor:

title: Builders End Club in Japan
description: Top executives of leading Japanese building companies have disbanded a social club in an effort to meet United States demands for an end to bid rigging in the construction industry, company spokesmen said today. The 32-member club had met monthly since 1983 at breakfasts, golf competitions and other activities.

title: Two Pesos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,255,000, or 16 cents a share, from receipt of insurance proceeds from one of the company's insurance carriers relating to the Trade Dress litigation. c-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $1,309,000, or 17 cents a share, from receipt of insurance proceeds. d-After an extraordinary charge of $2,091,000.

description: A PROFESSOR at Tufts University, Anthony D. Cortese, thinks he is one of a kind - the first at any university to hold the title of dean of environmental programs.

Jazz Festival;   Some Latin and Some Late
description: The JVC Jazz Festival, which had been wheezing occasionally during the last week, sputtered to its end on Saturday night during the first show of the Latin Jazz Jam at Carnegie Hall. The concert, featuring the pianist Ramsey Lewis, the saxophonist Gato Barbieri and the pianist Eddie Palmieri, with the added guest pianist Papo Lucca, was neither jazz nor Latin music most of the time. Instead, it verged on instrumental pop sprinkled with Latin or jazz elements that were usually so badly played that the show seemed like an insult to the audience. The headliner, Eddie Palmieri, was late and rushed through only two pieces.

title: Company News;   Hercules Chief Retiring
description: David S. Hollingsworth, the chairman and chief executive officer of Hercules Inc., announced today that he plans to retire next year. He did not give a specific date. Mr. Hollingsworth, 62 years old, has been at the helm of the chemical company since March 1987. Mr. Hollingsworth joined Hercules 42 years ago and worked in or headed many of the its businesses including paper chemicals, flavors and fragrances and resins.

title: Stronger Warning for Women Is Required on Aspirin Labels
description: The Food and Drug Administration today announced a stronger warning against use of over-the-counter aspirin products by women in the last three months of pregnancy unless directed by a physician.

title: The Marcos Verdict;   Pariah, or Future President? Philippines Reacts to Verdict
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she was ''disappointed'' by the acquittal of Imelda Marcos, and banned the former First Lady from returning to the Philippines, asserting that Mrs. Marcos remains a threat to national security.

description: The Kollmorgen Corporation said it had repurchased all of the Kollmorgen shares that had been held by the Vernitron Corporation and settled all litigation resulting from last year's failed merger agreement and the recently concluded proxy contest by Vernitron.

description: Easy Goer worked five furlongs in 58 1/5 seconds yesterday, then drew post No. 1 as a field of seven was entered for the $350,000 Suburban Handicap tomorrow at Belmont.

description: The Government will hold an international auction in late September, via satellite, for properties worth more than $1 million each that were acquired from insolvent savings and loan institutions, Administration officials said today.

Mikhail Gorbachev is doing his best to keep his comrades from rocking the boat, trying to keep the Communist Party and the country together.

description: Scotland Yard is investigating the handling of 14 pieces of ancient Roman silver that Sotheby's is trying to sell for Lord Northampton and his family trust.

title: Intervoice Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Review/Music;   Sacred and Contemporary From Russia
description: One of a music lover's great joys is to discover a rich and unfamiliar vein of literature. So for one listener, the concert by Nikolai Kachanov's Russian Chamber Chorus (of New York) on Thursday evening in the St. James Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine offered among its many piquant pleasures a particular gratification. As serendipity would have it, only hours before, a new disk of Russian choral music had arrived from Centaur Records, containing Dmitri Bortniansky's intricate and fascinating Sacred Concerto No. 26, ''Lord God of Israel.'' And the Russian Chamber Chorus provided triumphant confirmation: a fine performance of a glorious and affecting creation, Bortniansky's Concerto No. 32, ''Lord Let Me Know of My End.''

title: Man Is Firing Needles at the Backs of Women

It said the amount of the reserves and adjustments would be $150 million, of which $80 million was related to its investment in certain securities of Servico Inc. and other transactions with Servico. Prime said proceeds from the sale of its Howard Johnson and Ramada franchises would result in a pretax gain of about $60 million in the quarter ending Sept. 30.

title: The Cosmos And Those No-Hitters
description: It's hard to bleed too profusely for Andy Hawkins of the Yankees because of the losing no-hitter he pitched Sunday when you know the story of Denny Pickett - I think it was Denny Pickett. It might have been Ronnie Madden, or Ernie Kumerow or Marco Dallesandro, but I'm pretty sure it was Denny Pickett. Denny was a left-handed pitcher in the Thillens Little League in Chicago many years ago, and about the size of a cork in a wine bottle. The biggest thing about him was his hat. And Denny hurled a no-hitter, too, one day, and lost.

title: After 6 Hours, Jury Acquits Sharpton of All Charges

title: First Full View of Extinct Worm-Like Animal
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered the first complete fossils of an armored worm-like animal that lived 550 million years ago. Until now, paleontologists have only been able to guess at the anatomy of these early complex creatures, known as halkieriids, by piecing together fragments of scales and shells.

title: French Air-Traffic Strike
description: French air-traffic controllers said today that they would strike for three days beginning on Tuesday. The action could wreak havoc with holiday traffic at the two main Paris airports, Orly and Charles de Gaulle. Air France said the strike, over staffing, would force it to ground 60 percent of its European and Mediterranean flights, but that longer flights would not be affected. France's chief domestic airline, Air Inter, said 60 percent of its local operations would be affected. The strike was called by the Communist-led CGT labor union.

Freer Australian Trade
description: Australia and New Zealand have lifted all trade barriers in a move to make them a stronger force in the Asia-Pacific region. As of Sunday, neither nation had border restrictions on trade in goods with the other. Tariffs, import licensing restrictions and tariff quotas had all been removed.

description: Both the House and Senate have approved expansions of a wonderful but little-known anti-poverty weapon called the earned income tax credit. This income supplement helps working parents with low wages by reducing their income taxes or, if they owe no tax, by paying them cash.

title: Alpha Industries Inc. reports earnings for Year to April 1
description: b-Net income The company attributed the 1990 loss to restructuring programs. The year included $11,431,000 in restructuring expenses. The company also said that as result of the restructuring, it projects profitable operating results for fiscal year 1991.

title: Food Lion Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
Reeds Jewelers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Company News;   New Printers Due at Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. is expected to introduce two new low-cost laser printers next week to beat back the competition that has been snapping up some of its market share.

title: Toyota Leads Quality Survey
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation's Cressida sedan had the lowest number of problems reported by car owners in an influential survey of quality conducted each year by J. D. Power & Associates.

title: CSX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $51,000,000, or 52 cents a share, which included a net gain of $52 million on sale of stock of CSX Energy Corp. to a unit of Enron Corp. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $21,000,000, or 21 cents a share and $26,000,000, or 25 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively,. Both periods included a net gain of $39 million, or 38 cents a share, on sale of Lightnet.

title: Company News;   Radisson In India Pact
description: The Indian Government's leading hotel corporation said today that it had signed a collaboration agreement with Radisson Hotels International of Minneapolis for consultancy services, staff training and marketing.

title: Viruses Said to Pirate Host's Genetic Material In Invasion Strategies
description: JUST when they thought they knew most of the nasty parasitic maneuvers of viruses, researchers are now finding a new and exceedingly devious way that the microbes exploit their hosts. They have discovered that viruses can pirate away copies of genes that control the health and well-being of the host and then turn those genes against the host species.

title: Joseph C.R. Licklider Dies at 75; Foresaw New Uses for Computers
description: Dr. J.C.R. Licklider, an early computer scientist who was credited with pioneering work that established the basis for concepts like time sharing and resource sharing, died last Tuesday at Symmes Hospital in Arlington, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: Good Night To a Sleepy Princess
description: American Ballet Theater's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House came to a grand finale on Saturday night with a performance of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' that most sumptuous of 19th-century ballets. There were several surprises. It was no surprise that Amanda McKerrow was a delicate Princess Aurora and that Julio Bocca was a vigorous and rather fiery Prince Desire. In the final act, however, Mr. Bocca's makeup included a short, elegant beard that Ballet Theater's heroes have not previously worn in this production. Far from being an affectation, it was a reminder that during the 19th century, the men dancing the romantic leading roles were often bearded. Mr. Bocca demonstrated that given the right ballet, the right dancer and the right beard, there is no reason why beards should be out of place in our own century.

title: Fashion;   Patterns
description: Perfumes in Print

title: Jazz in July Festival to Open at the Y
description: A concert of music by Thelonious Monk and Alec Wilder, and a program featuring two generations of jazz musicians, are among the highlights of the 92d Street Y's sixth annual Jazz in July, a festival of traditional and new jazz.

title: Ripken Wishes Record Came With a Victory
description: He'll take the record, but Cal Ripken Jr. would have been much happier with a victory.

title: Chronicle
description: In what must have been a most unusual service at the 300-year-old St. Paul's Cathedral in London, Fozzy Bear, Gonzo and Oscar the Grouch attended yesterday's memorial for JIM HENSON, who gave them life.

title: Santa Monica Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 6-for-5 stock split in Feb. 1990. Loan loss reserve was $5,738,000 for the latest 6 months compared with $5,573,000 for the year-ago six months. Total assets were $807,469,000 for the latest 6 months compared with $656,656,000 for the year-ago six months.

title: T Cell Sciences Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Tennis;   Status: Undefeated. Future: Rosy. Age: 10.
description: At a time when tennis prodigies seem to be surfacing every week, the latest hot prospect is a 10-year-old Californian, Venus Williams.

title: Synthetech reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Represents a tax-loss carryforward. c-Net loss The company said that sales of its Peptide building blocks products and other chemicals increased to $1,200,000 for the latest year from $281,000 for the prior period.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABB Asea Brown Boveri, Zurich, Switzerland, a Swiss-Swedish engineering company, said two of its units had received an order worth 700 million Danish kroner, or about $109 million, for 17 electric motor units from the Danish state railroad and an order from British Rail worth 150 million Swedish kronor, or about $105 million, for 20 freight locomotives.

title: Morgan's Foods reports earnings for Qtr to May 22
description: b-Included loss of $20,000 from discontinued operations.

title: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   Ayer Promotions
description: Ayer said it had promoted four executives to senior vice president: Donna F. Tuttle, chairman and chief executive of Ayer/Tuttle in Los Angeles; Mitchell Burg and Suzanne I. Kaufman, associate media directors, and Ephraim D. Goldstein, assistant director of marketing planning. Ayer also named as a director Glenn E. Corlett, its executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Metro Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income of $7,965,000, or $1.36 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $4,200,000 writedown of inventory. Figures for 1989 are restated.

title: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   Miscellany
description: Ogilvy & Mather said it had opened a full-service agency in East Berlin.

title: Review/Dance;   Temptation, Indolence, Exuberance And Loss
description: The program presented by the Nanette Bearden Contemporary Dance Theater on Friday night at the Pace Downtown Theater was a good mix of dances, from the Talley Beatty classic ''Mourners Bench'' to two inventive pieces by Walter Rutledge, the company's assistant artistic director.

title: Cycling;   Rider Taking Classical Approach
description: Somewhere between Mozart's ''Haffner'' Symphony (Kochel 385) and his ''Jupiter'' (K. 551), Gianni Bugno learned, allegro vivace, how to become a champion bicycle racer.

title: Faradyne Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,073 for the latest quarter and $16,583 for the year- earlier period.

title: Tranzonic Cos reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a cumulative effect of change in accounting principle of $701,500, or 19 cents a share.

title: Nantucket Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
Hubble Astronomers Add Up Their Losses
description: BECAUSE of the focusing defects found last week in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, virtually all the key instruments aboard will lose a major part of their capabilities and the most exciting scientific missions will have to be postponed until replacement instruments can be installed.

title: Zfax Image Corp. reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said revenues increased due to higher sales at its Dallas retail store. The company also said net loss rose because of costs associated with a September 1989 public offering of 1,150,000 common shares, increased efforts at the retail store and increased research costs related to its portable facsimile machine.

title: Canonie Environmental Servce reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Coney Island Man Arrested In Murder of Soviet Doctor
description: A 22-year-old Coney Island man has been charged with robbery and second-degree murder in the death of a Soviet cardiologist in Forest Hills, Queens, last month, the police said yesterday.

title: Review/Television;   Transforming a Man Into a Woman
description: One of the most important and consistently laudable series on public television is ''P.O.V.'' (for Point of View). Independent documentary makers are given an opportunity to show their work in as direct a context as possible. The content may be sensitive or even controversial, but the broadcasts are not saddled with wrap-around panel discussions intended to convey the impression of balance or objectivity. ''P.O.V.'' assumes that its audiences are savvy enough to make their own decisions. They do not need fretting politicians or damage-control experts to tell them what to think.

title: Business People;   Lehrman, Ex-Candidate, Joins Consulting Firm
description: Lewis E. Lehrman has found a way to merge his two passions - politics and business. Mr. Lehrman, the Republican and Conservative candidate who lost to Mario M. Cuomo in New York's 1982 gubernatorial election, recently left Morgan Stanley & Company, where he was chief operating officer of its asset management division, to become chairman of Lehrman Bell Mueller Cannon.

title: Sports People: Boxing;   A Bout Amid Sadness For Alex Stewart
description: A fight tonight at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., is supposed to be a tune-up for Alex Stewart, who is scheduled to fight the former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson in September. It also will be an emotional test.

title: International Semi-Tech Miroelectronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest first quarter's revenue figures included revenues from 100 percent of the Canadian operations and 41 percent of the equity interest of Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd. The company said during the fourth quarter of 1989, its ownership in Semi- Tech Microelectronics (Far East) fell to about 41 percent from 51 percent. It said due to this reduced investment, Semi-Tech has been accounted for on an equity basis in the first quarter and reported revenues can not be compared. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ADS Associates Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Yen Trader Is Punished
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said Friday that it had expelled and fined the last of four traders in Japanese yen futures who pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the F.B.I. investigation of illegal trading at Chicago's two futures exchanges.

title: Ms. Batista Wed To Herve Aaron
description: Marina Batista and Herve Aaron were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Eugene Merlet.

title: Serbia Referendum Snubbed By the Albanians in Kosovo
description: Voters in Serbia cast ballots today in a referendum whose passage could delay free, multiparty elections and reduce the autonomy of the Yugoslav republic's restive Kosovo region.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Reviewing Nuclear Aims
description: President Bush's proposal that NATO's nuclear weapons should become an arms system of ''last resort'' maintains the alliance's position that it has a right to use nuclear weapons first in response to a Soviet conventional attack. But Bush Administration officials say that the ''last resort'' suggestion is more than a simple reiteration of past policy.

title: Morrison Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Included a loss of $2.5 million from discontinued operations. c-Included a loss of $4,000 for the quarter and a gain of $424,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: World Cup '90;   Naples Loves Maradona, but Loves Italy More
description: Some fans in Naples may suffer from conflicting twitches Tuesday when Diego Maradona of Argentina takes the field against Italy in the semifinals of the World Cup.

title: Charles F. White, 86, Ex-M&M Mars Head
description: Charles F. White, retired president of M & M Mars in Hackettstown, N.J., died on Saturday at Hershey Medical Center in Hershey, Pa. He was 86 years old and lived in Lewisburg, Pa.

title: Review/Recital;   A Concertmaster With Varied Coloration
description: Xiao-lu Li studied the violin in Shanghai and played in orchestras there until 1983, when he came to the United States to study. Now he teaches at North Carolina State University and is the concertmaster of the Greensboro Symphony Orchestra. On Saturday evening at Weill Recital Hall, he showed that he is also a capable and sometimes eloquent recitalist.

title: The Public Must Reject 2 Live Crew's Message;   Clearly Obscene
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: JOHN CHANCELLOR is recovering nicely after double-bypass surgery last Wednesday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York and is to be released this weekend. Mr. Chancellor, 62 years old, had suffered chest pains after returning to New York last week from the tour for his new book, ''Peril and Promise.''

title: Cuban Dancer Wins World Ballet Contest
description: A Cuban dancer has won first prize at the International Ballet Competition day while the principal dancer of the Houston Ballet has won the top award for women.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
WNYC Chief Moves To Reshape TV Station
description: In his first 100 days as president of the WNYC Communications Group, Thomas B. Morgan has quietly begun to restructure New York City's television station to make it more responsive to the specific needs of local viewers.

title: Hubbardton Journal;   State Wary Of Giving Old Battles New Life
description: If the fight on July 7, 1777, was the Battle of Hubbardton, the current one may come to be known as the Battle of the Battle of Hubbardton.

title: Helian Health Group reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Summer Renovations Close 2 Museums
description: Museum of the Moving Image and the New-York Historical Society - will be closed for renovations for two or three months beginning today.

title: Carnival Cruise reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the decline in net income in the latest 6-month period is attributable to lower results during the first quarter when Holland America's Westerdam was out of service for the entire quarter and the carnivale was out for 6 weeks undergoing a major refurbishment.

title: 202 Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Waterhouse Investor ServFices reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a charge of $364,162 from a writedown of the company's investment in a bank.

title: International American Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included charge for write-off of goodwill of $18,662,000 and an after- tax charge for asset writedowns of $2,400,000. c-After income of $800,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. d-Net income The latest year's loss before adjustment included charge for write-off of goodwill of $18,662,000 and a charge for asset writedowns of $11,300,000, after taxes. Latest quarter's shares outstanding are fully diluted, and year-ago quarter's shares outstanding and share earnings are also fully diluted.

title: Restrictions Put on Right To a Lawyer
description: Reversing a decision that had made New York's right to legal counsel the most far-reaching in the nation, the state's highest court ruled today that representation by a lawyer could be restricted in some cases.

title: KV Pharmaceutical Co.  reports earnings for 12mo March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Stress and the Radish
description: Pollen of radish plants subjected to environmental stress is less successful in siring seeds when in competition with pollen from radish plants grown in a more favorable environment, scientists reported in a recent issue of the journal Science. The authors, Dr. Helen J. Young, assistant professor of biology at Barnard College, and Dr. Maureen L. Stanton, associate professor of botany at the University of California at Davis, say this is the first study to demonstrate that the environment plays a role in determining how well pollen succeeds in producing seeds.

title: Chess
description: The World Cup Open Tournament, which ended in early June at the Hotel Ismailov in Moscow, demonstrated once again that it is difficult to be fair to everyone at the same time. This Grandmasters Association production was intended to obtain 12 qualifiers for the next World Cup cycle of elite competitions to be held in the 1991-92 period. But its plan of culling the finest aspirants collided with its plan of having broad geographical distribution.

title: Shorewood Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Company News;   300 Railway Workers Cut At Santa Fe
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation handed layoff notices to 300 Santa Fe Railway Company employees today and said it would cut the railroad's work force by an additional 1,200, or about 7.5 percent, by the end of 1992.

title: King vs. Douglas: Case Begins in Federal Court
description: A lawyer for Don King told a Federal Court jury yesterday that the promoter was wrongly depicted as responsible for the delay in recognizing James (Buster) Douglas as champion after Douglas scored a 10th-round knockout of Mike Tyson for the heavyweight championship February in Tokyo.

title: Group Tries to Think Like the Fed
description: As the Federal Reserve's top policy makers met today in Washington, 31 business people and economic analysts convened at the grand old Toledo Club to imitate - and thereby fathom immediately - the thinking of the people who determine the nation's interest rates and availability of money.
