title: Thousands of South African Blacks Stay Off Jobs
description: Hundreds of thousands of blacks stayed home from work across South Africa today at the start of a weeklong campaign organized by the African National Congress and its allies to protest factional violence in Natal, which has taken more than 3,000 lives.

title: The Marcos Verdict;   Marcos Is Cleared of All Charges In Racketeering and Fraud Case
description: Imelda Marcos, the widow of the former Philippine President, was acquitted yesterday of charges that she raided the country's treasury and invested the money in the United States.

title: Warrentech reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Share earnings are less than one cent. Revenues represent net revenues.

title: The Media Business: Advertising - Addenda;   Accounts
description: Leon's Furniture Ltd., to W.B. Doner & Co.

title: Attention, Claims Adjusters! Willis Is Back in 'Die Hard 2.'
description: ''John,'' wails Holly McClane (Bonnie Bedelia), at the end of a second Christmastime showdown involving armed-to-the-teeth terrorists, helpless hostages and her husband (Bruce Willis) in the role of a one-man army, ''Why does this keep happening to us?'' The answer isn't hard to see.

title: 3Com Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Reflected a $2.5 million, or 5 cents a share, one-time accrual for the relocation of 3Com's corporate offices.

title: A Business Channel Fails
description: The first European television business channel said last week that it was bankrupt and would go off the air.

title: Fashion;   Sprightly Clothes for Cruise or Career
description: It is difficult for some European designers to understand the range of what is known in this country as the resort-cruise season. Indigenous to the United States retailing trade, the season used to refer to clothes for warm climates offered by the stores here in midwinter.

title: Books of The Times;   An Easy Routine in India, Disrupted by a Child
description: The World of Nagaraj

title: WordPerfect Offspring
description: SUCCESSFUL programs create little industries of their own. Add-on software offers features the original programmers forgot, or different ways to do the same things. Books supplement and frequently improve on the manuals, or provide information for people using illegal copies who never had an official manual in the first place.

title: Taurus Footwear reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $230,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago first quarter was restated. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Killings of Palestinians Dipped in June
description: Eight Palestinians were killed last month by Israeli troops in violence related to the uprising, the lowest total since the unrest began 31 months ago.

title: Herbert L. Bruce, 89, Black Tammany Chief
description: Herbert L. Bruce, the first black Democratic district leader to be elected in New York City, died Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Designcraft Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the decrease in sales in the latest first quarter was due primarily to the sale of various businesses during fiscal 1990.

title: The Public Must Reject 2 Live Crew's Message;   Insensitive, Stupid
description: To the Editor:

title: New York State New Competitor for OTB
description: After an all-night marathon of negotiations and over the bitter opposition of some New York City officials, the State Legislature today approved far-reaching changes in New York's regulation of horse racing that will clear the way for competition to the city's virtual monopoly over offtrack betting.

title: Meadow Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Sales represent net sales. Results for 1989 are pro forma and assume Direct Action Marketing Inc. merger was completed on February 1, 1989.

title: Israeli Arab Poet Is Set Free, But Court Silences His Song
description: An Israeli Arab poet charged with inciting violence through nationalistic verse was released from house arrest Sunday night pending trial.

title: Market Place;   Government Bond Gains Are Global
description: WITH economies less than exuberant in most parts of the world, the last three months provided the holders of international government bonds with the best performance since 1987.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Humorlessly, a Long-Ruling Party Looks at Itself
description: Mocked by the people, scolded by its leader and stripped of its monopoly, the Communist Party settled into town today in something of a red funk, a septuagenarian patronage machine in need of a new patron.

title: King World Products reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Income was affected by non-cash charges for amortization and depreciation resulting from the acquisition of WIVB-TV in Buffalo, which decreased primary earnings per share by 6 cents for the period. c-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $2,905,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: Volunteers Pay to Help Scientists Conducting Ecological Research
description: AS a small boat crowded with researchers, instruments and canisters of water etched radiating circles on the glassy surface of Lake Naivasha, and fish eagles swooped from the trees, a voice sang out from on board: ''Temperature, 22. Oxygen, 5.7.''

title: The Savings Debacle: How Safeguards Failed;   A Blend of Tragedy and Farce
description: Behind the collapse of the nation's savings and loan industry is the story of how the public and private safeguards intended to insure the financial health and integrity of the savings system failed.

title: T.H. Johnson, 46, West Point Professor And Director of Lab
description: Col. Thomas H. Johnson, director of the Science Research Laboratory at the United States Military Academy, died on June 26 at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 46 years old and lived in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y. The academy reported that he died of lymphoma.

title: N and R Lines Will Undergo Repairs for Seven Weekends
description: Riders of the N and R subway lines between Manhattan and Queens will face some trying weekends for the next month and a half as the Transit Authority halts service on sections of those lines for repair work, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was teaching second grade at a time Negroes were being called blacks, and my children had difficulty accepting that, because the word 'black' was so negative. So we spent a whole year making beautiful things out of black construction paper and black materials.''

title: A.T.&T. Buying 3 Units of Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation, the financially troubled company that pioneered telegraph and telex services, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its telex, computer mail and computer data transmission services to A.T.&T. for $180 million.

title: Mitchell Chasin Weds Amy Alkoff
description: Amy Ellen Alkoff and Dr. Mitchell Craig Chasin were married last evening at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club by Rabbi Philip M. Weinberger and Cantor David Shiff.

title: Bank Fund and C.D. Yields Are Lower for Fifth Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were off slightly for the week ended yesterday. It was the fifth consecutive drop.

title:
Real Estate;

Wanted: Help To Convert A Castle
description: LEAD: A MOATED 15th-century English castle called Herstmonceux, nestled on 531 acres of park and farmland in the unspoiled countryside of East Sussex 65 miles from London, is being offered as the centerpiece of an unusual commercial venture.

title: Hold the Fireworks
description: The biggest fireworks display I ever saw contained a gigantic portrait of Lyndon Johnson's face. It was at the close of the Democratic National Convention that nominated Johnson for President in Atlantic City during the summer of 1964.

title: Israel's Envoy to Egypt Quits, Citing Rightists
description: Israel's Ambassador to Egypt, Shimon Shamir, resigned today, saying he could not reconcile his political views with those of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new right-wing Government.

title: The Pop Life
description: Connick the Versatile ''I've learned that people latch onto labels and stereotypes,'' Harry Connick Jr. said in a recent conversation. ''There was a period when I was asked in every single interview how I liked being the new Frank Sinatra. It's nice to be compared to him, but with the release of my two new albums, I think people will soon realize that I do a lot more than interpret old songs.''

title: Group Withdraws Offer for Talman
description: An investor group dropped its $700 million offer for the Talman Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Illinois, the state's largest savings institution. Talman said in a statement that a Chicago-area banker, Harrison I. Steans, leader of the investment group, had abandoned the buyout because the savings and loan association's revised earnings projections fell below his original expectations.

title: Kurile Island Deal Rejected
description: Japan today rejected as premature a Soviet proposal to share ownership of Soviet-held islands in the Kurile chain, which Japan claims. The issue is a longstanding sore point that has prevented the Soviet Union and Japan from signing a peace treaty to formally end World War II. Earlier this week, a political commentator, Vsevolod Ovchinnikov, wrote in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, that the dispute over the islands could be settled if Tokyo and Moscow agreed to place the islands under United Nations trusteeship.

title: Critic's Notebook;   As Tanglewood Marks a 50th, Let the Cavils Not Be Sounded
description: Coming up on Friday: the 50th anniversary of the Berkshire Music Center at the Tanglewood Festival. So it's memory time - memories not only of the beginnings of the Music Center but also of the festival itself.

title: Baseball As a Potion
description: The lockout that was the plague and scourge of America during much of the month of March seems to have receded into the mists of history, like the Peloponnesian War. At most, a reference to it is occasionally made.

title: Brenda Lansdown, Who Devised a Way To Teach, Dies at 86
description: Brenda Lansdown, a retired professor of education who introduced new teaching methods in China, died on Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. She was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass. The cause of death was pneumonia, said Harriet Harvey, a friend.

title: Child-Custody Cases Test Frontiers of Family Law
description: Michele G. and Nancy S., a lesbian couple, had lived together for 11 years when they decided to rear children. Ms. G. found a sperm donor, took part in the artificial insemination of Ms. S. and was present in June 1980 at the delivery of a baby girl. On the child's birth certificate, Ms. S. was listed under ''mother,'' Ms. G. under ''father.''

title: Officer Tells Jury of Finding Battered Jogger
description: A New York City police officer quietly described to a rapt Manhattan jury yesterday the grisly scene when he turned the headlights of his radio car onto the blood-soaked body of a jogger who was raped and nearly beaten to death in Central Park last year.

title: Call the Second Amendment Freedom Insurance;   Revolutionary Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Jurors in Sharpton Trial Had Doubts Over Funds
description: The jurors in the fraud and larceny trial of the Rev. Al Sharpton voted to acquit the minister in six hours on Monday because the prosecutors had failed to prove that he had benefited from the $250,000 he was accused of having stolen, two jurors said yesterday in interviews.

title: China and Indonesia Sign a Pact To Restore Ties Severed in 60's
description: China and Indonesia signed an agreement today to restore diplomatic relations next month, ending a 23-year rift between the two most populous nations in East Asia.

title: Sports People: Boxing;   Pryor Is Determined
description: Aaron Pryor, armed with an ophthalmologist's report saying he has enough vision to continue boxing, is stepping up his bid to be cleared for bouts in Canada and New York State.

title: Woman Gets $3.75 Million Over Diaper Soap
description: A West German chemical company has agreed to pay $3.75 million to a woman who said her leukemia was caused by a detergent used to launder her diapers when she was a baby.

title: Dow Rises 12.37 in Sluggish Trading
description: Stocks advanced yesterday for the fourth straight session, but with many traders and investors stretching their Fourth of July holiday, activity continued sluggish and is expected to remain so at least until Monday.

title: Now, Custom Chips While You Wait
description: In Silicon Valley, where fast-food restaurants and instant-copy centers are part of the way of life, the establishment of a same-day service for computer chips was only a matter of time. This week, Chip Express, a spinoff of the Israeli electronics manufacturer Elron Electronic Industries, will open its doors in Santa Clara, Calif., offering custom semiconductor prototypes within hours.

title: Track Fire Delays Subway Service 3 Hours
description: Tens of thousands of homebound subway riders on the IRT suffered new disruptions yesterday when a track fire knocked out service north of 96th Street for almost three hours.

title: Evolution in Europe;   SOVIET HARD-LINER ASSAILS GORBACHEV ON HIS LEADERSHIP
description: The conservative pillar of the Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, roused delegates to the nationwide congress of the Communist Party today by deploring the five years of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rule as a period of wavering and ''blind radicalism.''

title: Image Entertainment Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of $1,340,000 related to the write-off of certain production costs, reevaluation of production cost amortization and establishment of reserves for royalty advances, sales returns and excess inventory. c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Sports section on Sunday about the baseball commissioner's investigation of George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, misstated the date of A. Bartlett Giamatti's death. Mr. Giamatti, who preceded Fay Vincent as commissioner, died on Sept. 1, 1989.

title: Sanifill Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that due to a recent acquisition being accounted for as a pooling-of-interests, it has restated its earnings for the first quarter 1990. On May 16 Sanifill reported net income for the first quarter 1990 of $460,187, or 8 cents a share, on revenue of $3,778,686. The comparative results for first quarter 1989 were reported as net income of $306,159, or 5 cents a share, on revenue of $2,692,416. The company said that it recently completed the acquisition of a sanitary landfill and two non-harzardous special waste disposal sites. The company declined to specify which acquisition required the restatement.

title: A Blind Man Drives an Auto, But Crashes and Is Arrested
description: A blind man today fulfilled his long-held desire to drive but was arrested after he struck a telephone pole after a three-mile ride through the streets here.

title: Topics of The Times;   CUNY Edges Yale
description: The City University of New York, no stranger to distinction, has a new one: Its undergraduate body yields more corporate executives than any other school.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. The Living Section begins on page 37 and Business Day on page 43.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Excerpts From Speeches at the Communist Party Congress
description: Following are excerpts from speeches by Yegor K. Ligachev, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov and Eduard A. Shevardnadze today and Aleksandr N. Yakovlev on Monday to the Soviet Communist Party congress, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Global Output Slowed in '89
description: With economic growth at a virtual standstill in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, global economic output slowed last year and is expected to slow more this year, according to the United Nations World Economic Survey for 1990, published today.

title: New Imcera President Seen as Heir Apparent
description: The Imcera Group Inc., formerly the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, yesterday named M. Blakeman Ingle as president and chief operating officer, making him the heir apparent. The company also lost its chief financial officer, John A. Edwardson, who has been hired by the union group seeking to buy United Airlines.

title: Town Is a Manchester By a Different Name
description: It's official. Manchester has been renamed Manchester-by-the-Sea, to distinguish it from the four other New England Manchesters and 18 other Manchesters in the United States.

title: APSB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Evolution in Europe;   Little Opposition Expressed by the West to Bush's Plans to Revamp NATO
description: President Bush's proposal to define NATO's nuclear arms as ''weapons of last resort'' and to make other changes in alliance strategy has stirred considerable concern in some Western European capitals, but no outright opposition.

title: McDonnell Douglas Close to Korean Pact
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that a final deal may be at hand for the Government to sell 120 of the company's F-18 fighter jets to South Korea. The deal would be worth about $2.7 billion to McDonnell Douglas, which builds the attack fighter for the U.S. Navy and also provides it to several foreign nations.

title: Mentor Graphics Sees Profit Decline
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said it expects to report second-quarter earnings of only 5 to 10 cents a share, down from 29 cents a year earlier. Revenues of $100 million to $103 million are expected for the quarter, down from $106 million. The company said the projected results would be significantly less than expected.

title: Baseball;   Mattingly Improves but Stays on Sidelines
description: Don Mattingly's sore and stiff back showed improvement today, but the Yankee first baseman won't attempt a return to the lineup until Friday and may be asked to wait until after the three-day break for the All-Star Game.

title: Factory Orders Up 2.1% in May
description: Orders received by the nation's factories climbed a healthy 2.1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today, but the $5 billion rise was mainly attributed to higher production by auto makers worried about a possible strike this fall.

title: Hockey;   Trottier Released by Islanders; Club Buys Out His Contract
description: Bryan Trottier, the last active member of all four of the Islanders' Stanley Cup championship teams, yesterday received his release from Bill Torrey, the team's general manager.

title: Bassett Furniture Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: USAir Terminal
description: biUSAir Group Inc. said it planned to develop a new $250 million terminal at Philadelphia International Airport. The 41-gate terminal is scheduled for completion in the third quarter of 1993. USAir said preliminary plans call for 22 jet gates, some capable of handling wide-bodied aircraft, and 19 gates for its USAir Express regional airline affiliate.

title: Chronicle
description: KATHARINE HEPBURN, an amateur painter since the 1930's, has offered one of her paintings to an auction that will benefit a wildlife organization in East Lyme, Conn. Miss Hepburn said it is the only work she has ever permitted to be sold or, for that matter, to be seen by the public.

title: In Zambia, Anger Over the Economy
description: In riots here last week, residents of Mutendere Township, a dusty place of dirt roads and shabby housing, burned the flag of the nation's sole political party.

title: Raycomm Transworld IndusFtries reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $467,000, or 5 cents a share, which included a $637,000 gain on disposal. The year also included an extraordinary credit of $66,000, or 1 cent a share, from abandonment of a foreign subsidiary.

title: Taj Mahal Casino Data
description: The first operational quarter for Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort, which opened in April, showed a pattern of earnings roughly in line with Atlantic City trends, analysts said yesterday.

title: COST OF CLEANUP AT NUCLEAR SITES IS RAISED BY 50%
description: The Energy Department today raised by 50 percent its estimate of the cost of cleaning up radioactive and toxic wastes at nuclear weapon production sites around the country over the next five years.

title: Court Tells Princeton Clubs They Must Admit Women
description: In a decision that marked the end of an era embodied and romanticized by F. Scott Fitzgerald, the Supreme Court of New Jersey yesterday ordered the last two remaining male-only undergraduate clubs at Princeton University to begin admitting women.

title: Witness in Barry Trial Now Denies Exceeding Agents' Instructions
description: Concluding five days on the witness stand in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., Rasheeda Moore today recanted earlier testimony that she had exceeded some instructions Federal agents gave her before the start of the undercover operation that resulted in the Mayor's arrest on charges of smoking crack.

title: Selectronics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Current year figures included results for Microlytics, Selectronics' subsidiary. The company said its results for the 12-month period ended March 31, 1989, are presented for comparative purposes since the restated record of combined results for the merged companies does not begin until the three- month period ended March 31, 1989.

title: Town Weighs Whether Sand Is Everyone's
description: To Jack Canning, a real-estate man from New Hope, Pa., and his wife, Linda, who raises miniature horses, the seashore is a special place, almost mystical.

title: Saks Hasn't Met Its Goals In First Half, Memo Says
description: The first-half performance of Saks Fifth Avenue has fallen short of its own projections and those of its new owner, a confidential memorandum shows.

title: Valley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a charge of $5,905,000 from writedown of assets. c-Net loss

title: Bronx Gunman Was Obsessed, Prosecutor Says
description: The prosecutor called the shooting a near-perfect crime, the well-planned act of a man obsessed with his neighbor's loud stereo, convinced of racism where there was none and determined to resolve himself what the police, the courts and others would not.

title: Baseball;   Leary Posts 11th Loss As Yankees Struggle
description: A primer on Leary's difficult season: 10 losses when the night began, 6 defeats in his last 7 starting assignments and continued nonsupport by his teammates, who totaled 20 runs in his 3 victories but a mere 24 in his losses.

title: Woman in the News;   New Chief for School Board; Gwendolyn Calvert Baker
description: Dr. Gwendolyn Calvert Baker, elected yesterday as the new president of the New York City Board of Education, is an ardent champion of multicultural education, the idea that children can be taught to appreciate and respect the human coat of many colors. It is a subject that was bred in the bone.

title: Metro Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a loss before accounting change of $19,504,000. c-Included a loss before accounting change of $10,700,000 and also included a cumulative effect of accounting change of $7,965,000, or $1.36.

title: Hungary Joint Ventures
description: The number of joint-venture companies in Hungary has grown more than sixfold in the last year, official figures showed today. The Ministry of International Economic Relations said there were 1,800 joint ventures in the country, compared with 280 at the end of June 1989. Three hundred of them registered in June alone,

title: Book Notes
description: The Other Burton Novels on the best-seller list are usually written by well-known authors, but the nonfiction list almost always includes books by little-known authors or books that survived small first printings. ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' by Allan Bloom (Simon & Schuster), and ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' by Paul Kennedy (Random House), had first printings of fewer than 10,000 copies. Yet both landed on the hard-cover best-seller list, ultimately selling hundreds of thousands of copies.

title: Bronx School Board Superseded
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday superseded a Bronx school board after it failed to name a superintendent or acting superintendent.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Romanian President Backs Economic Reform Program
description: President Ion Iliescu today declared his support for the Government's economic reform program but said introducing a market economy would pose a difficult challenge.

title: Prison Term In Fraud Case
description: The president of a small military contractor based here was sentenced today to three years in prison and a $750,000 fine for his role in a 10-year scheme to avoid testing bolts that the company manufactured for use on military aircraft.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Yugoslav Mass Grave Linked to Communists
description: A mass grave discovered last week in northern Yugoslavia may contain the remains of a large number of people executed by the victorious Communist guerrillas in 1945, a Croatian newspaper reported today.

title: New Airbus Order
description: The French state-owned domestic airline Air Inter has signed a contract with Airbus Industrie for seven Airbus A321 planes and has taken options on eight more, Airbus Industrie said in a statement. Air Inter also exercised its five remaining options on the A320 model. The airline has ordered a total of 24 Airbus A320's. Air Inter will receive the A321's between mid-1994 and the end of 1996 and will use the aircraft on its trunk routes, most of which are between Paris and other French cities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-8

title: Economic Scene;   College Tuition: A Better Idea?
description: THE problem: The earnings gap between those who went to college and those who did not has never been greater. Yet tuition subsidies for all but the poorest students have become scarcer than Taittinger in Teheran. Loans at market-rate interest are generally available to students who need them. But not surprisingly, the children of financially pressed parents are loath to begin their working lives burdened with tens of thousands of dollars in education debts.

title: Gustave Harrow Is Dead at 60; Assistant State Attorney General
description: Gustave Harrow, a lawyer and former assistant New York State Attorney General who was a leader in shaping art legislation, died on Saturday. He was 60 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Evolution in Europe;   U.S. Is Hoping to Sweeten German NATO Membership
description: The United States is hoping that Moscow will quickly drop its opposition to the membership of a united Germany in NATO if the Western allies agree this week on a plan aimed at making the alliance less threatening to the Soviet Union, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Mecca Death Toll Is Confirmed; King Calls It Fate
description: The Saudi Interior Minister, Prince Nayef, said today that 1,426 Muslim pilgrims died in a stampede in a pedestrian tunnel linking this city with a tent camp for pilgrims.

title: Sports People: Baseball;   3 Seek Exoneration
description: Three players in the St. Louis Cardinals organization have rejected an offer to settle charges of disorderly conduct that were filed against them as a result of a fight in Covington, Ky., the players' lawyer said yesterday.

title: Audiovox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the sales increase in the quarter was a result of increases in cellular and security product sales.

title: Carolina Educator: Bold Leader or Big Spender?
description: When James B. Holderman took over as president of the University of South Carolina in 1977, the school was considered by many as a ''good party school'' but very little else.

title: Chronicle
description: CALVIN KLEIN was admitted to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center last night for observation and treatment of broken ribs and lacerations to the head after he fell from a horse, said MARY CIALONE, night administrator at the hospital. She said the fashion designer suffered the spill in the Hamptons and was flown from Long Island by helicopter. She said his condition was stable and his injuries were not life-threatening.

title: MANDELA HOPEFUL ON BRITISH TALKS
description: Nelson Mandela expressed optimism today about the prospects of narrowing his differences with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over economic sanctions against South Africa, and backed off from comments that had suggested that Britain should negotiate with the Irish Republican Army.

title: American Rice reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said comparable figures are unavailable; company commenced operations on April 30, 1988. The company also said for the 11 months, April 30, 1988 to March 31, 1989, net income was $84,000, or 1 cent per share, on sales of $180,163.

title: Coors Completes Brewery Purchase
description: The sale of Stroh's brewery in Memphis to the Adolph Coors Company was made final in a deal under which Coors will make beer outside of Golden for the first time in its 117-year history. The Stroh Companies will continue to operate the 500-employee brewery until Sept. 1, when Coors will assume responsibility for operations. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Banks With Stakes in Borrowers Are in Spotlight
description: The eagerness shown recently by many bankers to restructure the debt of RJR Nabisco Inc. has put the spotlight on an unusual feature of the leveraged buyout phenomenon: banks that own equity stakes in their borrowers.

title: Drakewood Specializes In Interim Executives
description: Temporary top executives are in vogue, and Ronald J. Diorio stands ready to supply them.

title: Mortimer H. Gold, 91, Queens Philanthropist
description: Mortimer H. Gold, a philanthropist who produced variety shows, circuses, carnivals and athletic events to benefit charitable organizations in Queens, died yesterday at Jamaica Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates. He died after a stroke, his family said.

title: Sports People: College;   Miami Reconsiders
description: The University of Miami now says that joining an expanded Metro Conference is an attractive option.

title: The Hispanic Voice of New York: A 2d Theater Festival Chimes In
description: Any doubts about the supremacy of New York as a prime center for Hispanic theater may be swept away with the arrival tomorrow of a new, and second, theater festival dedicated to the art of Spanish-language stagecraft.

title: Food Notes
description: American Cheese

title: 'Yaaahh!' Fresh Air Vacations Start
description: Cheryl Quaye, station manager for the Fresh Air Fund, surveyed the swarm of children at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan yesterday morning and decided the time had come. Lifting her bullhorn, she bellowed, ''Are you ready to go?''

title: Horizontal Drilling, or How to Revive Oilfields
description: In the long history of the Texas oil industry, there has rarely been a gusher as powerful as either of those that burst to the surface in the aging oil patch southwest of San Antonio last month. In an area regarded as well past its oil-producing prime, the wells surged with 20,000 and 12,000 barrels a day, respectively, in a field where most wells produce less than 500.

title: Court Ruling Encourages Affirmative Action
description: A ruling by the Supreme Court that lucrative broadcast licenses may be distributed in a way that favors blacks and other minority members means that a variety of Federal programs requiring minority participation are now free from uncertainty and challenge, several legal scholars and civil rights lawyers say.

title: For Eastern Europe, U.S. Teachers
description: At first glance the people queued in front of Pan Am's ticket counter at Dulles International Airport looked like college students headed for a summer biking tour through England or France. A closer look suggested otherwise: their duffel bags bulged with English textbooks and Shakespeare anthologies, and their destination was Budapest.

title: Prices Rise in a Shortened Session
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly yesterday and interest rates dipped at the close of an abbreviated trading session.

title: Sports People: Baseball;   Padres' McKeon Wants One Fewer Hat
description: Perhaps discouraged by the San Diego Padres' slump, in which the team has lost 14 of its last 19 games, Jack McKeon, the club's manager and vice president of baseball operations, said yesterday that he would like to give up his job in the dugout and concentrate on operational duties.

title: An American Takes Aim At Reign of Dry Italian Pasta
description: UNLIKE most foods, when it comes to pasta, fresh is not always better. And with dry, factory-made pasta, imported usually is better than domestic. Until now.

title: Brazilian Wonder Turns Out Bolivian
description: One year after the lively song ''Lambada'' and the sensual dance of the same name arrived from Brazil and took first France and then Europe by storm, France's society of composers has ruled that the song is in fact Bolivian.

title: Chronicle
description: MENACHEM BEGIN was recovering yesterday in Shaarei Tzedek Hospital in Jerusalem after an operation to repair a fractured hip. He is expected to make a complete recovery, said the hospital's director, DR. YONATHON HALEVY. It was the former Prime Minister's second hospital stay since May, when he was hospitalized for two weeks with pneumonia.

title: It's Summertime, So Pass the Mayo
description: MAYONNAISE is the sauce that holds summer together. From potato salad to cole slaw to sandwiches, mayonnaise is the common chord, and as the mercury shoots up, so do its sales.

title: China Dissidents Lose Sway in Exile
description: Teacher Fang and Teacher Li, as their admirers know them, still carry Chinese passports, and it is not impossible that they would return to a changed China. But many Chinese here say, with regret, that one lesson of the last year is that exiles can have little impact on the motherland and that distance makes them almost irrelevant.

title: Bronx Woman Held in Death Of a Foster Child, 22 Months
description: A 30-year-old Bronx woman was arrested last night and charged with second-degree murder in the death of her 22-month-old foster child, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: World Cup '90;   Jubilant Argentines Fill Streets
description: Seconds after Sergio Goycochea smothered Italy's last penalty shot, ecstatic Argentines poured into the streets in the capital city today to celebrate Argentina's advance to the World Cup soccer final.

title: Patten Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment of $2,500,000, or 14 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and the year included an extraordinary credit of $331,000, or 2 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt.

title: Daily News Unions Ask Cuomo for State Inquiry
description: After five months of fruitless contract talks, union leaders at The Daily News yesterday urged Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to back a state inquiry into their dispute with management, and top state officials said they would meet with both sides tomorrow to consider the idea.

title: Independence Day
description: FIREWORKS

title: World Cup '90;   Argentina Eliminates Italy on Penalty Kicks
description: Hot lava has gushed from Mount Vesuvius and earthquakes have rattled the city and foreign navies have sailed into the harbor, and now this city will be known throughout Italy for a sporting version of disaster: the defeat of the Italian national soccer team.

title: Champion Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to June 1
description: b-Net loss

title: Man Acquitted On Major Count In Racial Killing
description: The third trial in the Bensonhurst racial killing ended yesterday when jurors acquitted a young white man of intentional murder but could not reach a verdict on a second murder charge and on a riot charge.

title: Iran-Iraq Talks Produce Progress On Ending Long Confrontation
description: The Foreign Ministers of Iraq and Iran today held their first direct talks since their 1988 cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. The talks could open the way to a summit meeting between Presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and the negotiation of a peace treaty to end 10 years of hostility.

title: 24 Women Say They Were Hit By Blown Darts
description: At least 24 women have told the police that they were hit by a needle or dart in the last eight days while walking in midtown Manhattan, the police said yesterday.

title: Dataflex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IEH Corp.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $759,167 from write-down of inventories. c-Net income and included a pre-tax charge of $27,000 from settlement of litigation.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING

title: Call the Second Amendment Freedom Insurance;   Unequal Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: American List Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
For Poles, Baseball And Rotary Foster American Dreams
description: On Wednesday nights, the Rotarians meet at the Doctor's Club. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, Little League ballplayers practice at a sports field in a Warsaw neighborhood. And on Fridays, the Lions' Club gathers in the dining room of a suburban office building.

title: As the Army Cuts Back . . .
description: LEAD: The armed forces are cutting back - and the chief victims will be black Americans, who comprise the heart and guts of the nation's military strength. Hardest hit will be the Army, where more than 30 percent of the enlisted soldiers and a majority of the combat noncommissioned officers are black.

title: Paul Strand Photos To National Gallery
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington is to receive 6 photographs by Paul Strand from a collection of more than 50 held by the Southwestern Bell Corporation.

title: Vitran Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a $262,000 gain on the sale of property for the quarter, and the 6 months included a $517,000 gain on the sale of property. The company said increased sales reflect an acquisition in the third quarter of 1989. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ousted U.S. Research Leader to Join Computer Consortium
description: Craig I. Fields, who was removed as director of the Defense Department's long-range research agency in April, will become the No. 2 executive and eventually the head of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, a computer industry consortium in Austin, Tex.

title: Anatoly Grishchenko, Pilot at Chernobyl, 53
description: A Soviet helicopter pilot who contracted leukemia after trying to douse the fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in 1986 has died, a hospital spokeswoman said today.

title: Tennis;   At Wimbledon, Garrison Ends Seles's Streak
description: Zina Garrison, on a diet of disappointment from the start of the year in which she had pegged herself as long overdue for a Grand Slam victory, earned a visit to her second Wimbledon semifinal today by outlasting Monica Seles, the French Open champion, 3-6, 6-3, 9-7.

title: Juice Bowl Unit Sold by Campbell
description: The Campbell Soup Company says it has sold its Juice Bowl Products subsidiary because it no longer fits in with the company's plans. Juice Bowl was sold to ABA Holding Inc. for an undisclosed amount. ABA Holding is the United States arm of Looza N.V., a Belgian fruit juice company.

title: Town Built on Indian Land Lost Its Chance to Plan Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Rowing;   U.S. Biggest Henley Entry
description: The chance to compete at the Henley Royal Regatta continues to exert its attraction to American rowers, with the 30 entries from the United States representing the largest foreign contingent from the 17 nations competing at this year's regatta.

title: Washington Talk;   On Taxes, Bush Shows None of His '88 Agility
description: George Bush's 1988 campaign against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was widely seen as a model of sure-footed politics, a message a day, a theme a week, a relentless march to the White House.

title: Fleet Norstar Sued By Shareholders
description: Five shareholders are suing Fleet Norstar Financial Group Inc. and accusing it of concealing the extent of problem loans at the company's banks. Three lawsuits filed in United States District Court in Providence contend the company's failure to make timely disclosure of its loan problems artificially inflated its profits and the price of its stock.

title: Baseball;   Twins' Tapani Beats Clemens and Red Sox
description: Kevin Tapani scattered seven hits in seven and one-third innings, outdueling Roger Clemens tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Boston Red Sox, 7-3.

title: About Education
description: President Bush has repeatedly supported the idea of youth community service but has not offered to finance such a program. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, for one, is trying to put money behind the concept - $65 million for service programs in the schools -with the National Community Service Act of 1990. Already approved by the Senate, it has a companion bill in the House, sponsored by Representative Gus Hawkins, Democrat of California, that is expected to come to a vote after the July 4 recess.

title: Rebates Are a Reason for Vehicle Price Increases by Big 3
description: With sales sluggish, the Big Three domestic auto makers recently announced midyear price increases, a move that illustrates the curious economic logic that governs the pricing strategy in Detroit these days.

title: Africa Study of AIDS Drug Finds Immune-Cell Rise
description: A new study in Africa by the World Health Organization has shown that a drug chewed as a wafer boosted the number of immune cells in a small number of AIDS patients whose immune cells had been damaged by the AIDS virus, an official of the international agency said yesterday.

title: Mainframes Aren't Museum Pieces
description: When makers of personal computers and work stations talk about mainframe computers, they often call them dinosaurs.

title: Evolution in Europe;   As Soviets Leave Hungary, Dispute Arises Over the Bill
description: As they pull out of Hungary, Soviet troops are leaving behind a legacy that to Hungarians somehow befits the 45-year occupation - rows of grubby, rundown barracks, shoddy apartment buildings, fields of unexploded artillery shells, oil and other waste dumped directly into the ground.

title: Youth in America - 50 Years Apart
description: LEAD: Today marks the 214th birthday of the American idea. On a recent Sunday, I had an experience that lit up the mixed fortunes of that idea in my lifetime: the difference between having been young in America decades ago, and being young now.

title: Markets Closed
description: Markets for trading stocks, bonds, currency and commodities will be closed today in the United States in observance of the Fourth of July. They will re-open tomorrow.

title: Winner in Nebraska at Last; The Margin: 0.047 Percent
description: Forty-eight days after the closest such contest in modern history, Ben Nelson, an Omaha lawyer, has been declared the winner of the Democratic primary for governor of Nebraska.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on June 23 about the Tobu Department Store Company of Japan misstated the value of the assets of the Tobu Railway Group, which owns it. Tobu Railway has assets of more than 700 billion yen, or about $4.6 billion, not $700 million.

title: Half of Cities in U.S. Say Revenue Fails To Cover Spending
description: More than half the nation's cities and towns expect spending to exceed revenue in the current budget year and two-thirds of the municipalities say budget problems are worse than a year ago, according to a survey released Monday.

title: Northwest Is Said to Study a Buyout of Eastern
description: Northwest Airlines is pursuing a possible buyout of Eastern Airlines and is scheduled to hold talks with Eastern union representatives, a union official said yesterday.

title: Liberian Rebels Close In on City Center
description: Liberian rebel forces were reported to be advancing slowly toward downtown Monrovia from the suburbs of the Liberian capital today in street-to-street fighting against Government forces. A senior Bush Administration official said the Liberian President, Samuel K. Doe, was ''in deep trouble right now.''

title: NDC Automation reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Eating Well
description: FOR years Americans have been popping vitamin pills as if they were lemon drops: a little vitamin A because they don't eat enough yellow vegetables; some vitamin C in place of orange juice in the morning; a vitamin B12 pill for the vegetarian.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Albanians Take Refuge in Embassies
description: Hundreds of Albanians rushed foreign embassies in that country's capital in recent days in an effort to flee the hard-line Communist country, diplomats said today.

title: Beeba's Creations Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included one-time charge of $2.4 million from write-off of minority interests in manufacturing operations in Jamaica and Costa Rica for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Progress Made at Talks Between Two Koreas
description: Senior officials from North Korea and South Korea resumed talks today and immediately reported progress in setting up a meeting between their Prime Ministers.

title: Strawberry Hits 2 as Mets' 4 Homers Back Viola's 12th Victory
description: After blitzing their way through June with 21 victories in 28 games, the Mets made it two straight in July last night when they hammered the Houston Astros, 12-0. And they did it with a barrage of epic hitting that included four home runs, two of which banked against the scoreboard in remote right field.

title: Topics of The Times;   Fashion Report
description: On a hot day last month a New Yorker who's run out of wardrobe went shopping along Lexington Avenue. She didn't know what she wanted, so decided to look at what everyone else was wearing. What she saw in one short block was this:

title: Trenton Education Chief Calls for New Creativity
description: Dr. John Ellis, New Jersey's new Education Commissioner, appealed today to all state residents to help find creative solutions to problems facing the state's troubled urban schools.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the economic strength of a unified Germany misidentified an international real estate advisory firm. It is Jones Lang Wootton.

title: Bridge
description: The least-exciting suit combination in the game, one would suppose, consists of a small tripleton opposite another small tripleton. But it can be meaningful in the play, for reading the opponents' high-card points, and it can represent a serious problem in the bidding.

title: Chapman S. Root, 65, A Coca-Cola Bottler
description: Chapman Shaw Root, a former chairman of the country's largest Coca-Cola bottling company, died on Monday at Emory Hospital in Atlanta. He was 65 years old and lived in Ormond Beach. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. Root inherited Associated Coca-Cola Bottlers, which had plants in Pennsylvania, Florida, New York and New Jersey, from his grandfather. He headed it , from 1951 until 1982, when he sold his 57.5 percent interest to the Coca-Cola Company for $417.5 million.

title: H.E.R.O.  Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Boxing;   Trump Tells of a Deal For Tyson vs. Douglas
description: While Mike Tyson was losing his heavyweight title to James (Buster) Douglas last February in Tokyo, Donald Trump and Don King, promoter of both fighters, were apparently agreeing that Trump would get the live-site rights to a Douglas-Tyson rematch at Convention Hall, which adjoins Trump Plaza, in Atlantic City.

title: Corolla's Sales Surpass Model T's
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation's Corolla has passed Ford's Model T to become the second best-selling car in history, with more than 15 million produced, a company spokesman said today.

title: Crazy for the Red, White and Blue
description: A man who went shopping for his wife's birthday last week bought her a shirt covered with stars and stripes - and marveled at social change. Not many years ago, Abbie Hoffman was arrested for wearing a shirt like that. Now the flag's bold graphics turn up everywhere, unchallenged.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: BRIEFS
description: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri A.G., the Swedish-Swiss engineering group, said it had agreed to acquire CCC, a Spanish electrical engineering company that has seven plants and 2,900 employees.

title: About New York;   Laundry a Bore? Pedal Lifecycle During Dry Cycle
description: Any comprehensive tour of the VideoTown Laundrette on the West Side of Manhattan would begin with the copying machine, just to the left of the front door. It's five cents a page. Then come the videotapes, between 6,000 and 7,000 of them. There are Raisinets and Goobers in bins and a popcorn machine on the counter.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Hillenbrand Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: AIR TRAFFIC SLOWS IN FRENCH STRIKE
description: Timing their action to coincide with the start of the European vacation season, French air traffic controllers began a three-day strike today that resulted in the cancellation of two-thirds of flights in and out of Paris.

title: Oil Activity Has Shifted From U.S.
description: For the first time, oil companies operating in the United States are spending more to look for oil abroad than at home, and most of their production and reserves are outside the United States, Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, said yesterday.

title: Stock Options At Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation has granted some top managers stock options to keep their compensation packages competitive, a company spokesman said on Monday.

title: Picnics: Declaring the Spirit of a People
description: IT is a meal for our times - providing at once a respite from frenzy even as it affords the opportunity for social tolerance. It is the picnic. And on this Day of Independence, there is perhaps no more appropriate way to celebrate.

title: And Thank God It's Wednesday?
description: FOR many Americans, today is like a firecracker that fizzled in mid air.

title: Johnson Products Co.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $277,000, or 7 cents a share for the quarter and $510,000, or 13 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $41,000, or 1 cent a share and $630,000, or 16 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter and 9-month income from continuing operations of $482,000, or 12 cents a share and $877,000, or 22 cents a share, respectively, included a pretax gain of $130,000 in the quarter and 9-month on partial recovery of a note, and a pretax gain of $369,000 in the 9 months only on sale of an investment. Year-ago 9-month income from continuing operations of $1,271,000, or 32 cents a share, included a pretax gain of $2,200,000 on the sale of land.

title: Oil Rig Strikers Defy Norway
description: Wildcat strikes on Norway's North Sea oil and gas platforms cut most production today in defiance of a back-to-work order by the Government.

title: Federated's New Buying Strategy
description: Federated Stores Inc. is developing a new, more centralized buying strategy that could save it millions of dollars and enable it to lower its prices. But the approach, which is central to Federated's plan to emerge from the company's five-and-a-half-month-old bankruptcy, could reduce the autonomy of the company's nine chains, which include Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, and make their merchandise more nearly uniform.

title: World Cup '90;   England Asks for Heart, Spirit, Luck
description: Their swagger has been unmistakable throughout the World Cup. Since the final rounds of the tournament began last month, West Germany's players have talked, acted and performed as if they always knew they would advance at least this far, to the semifinals.

title: Solidarity Experiences Founders Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: Western Microwave Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: The second-quarter loss was attributable to cost overruns on several contracts, which were not anticipated in the first quarter cost estimates; costs associated with restructuring the company's support organizations; an increase in the warranty expense reserve to cover potential future product returns; and a reserve established to cover certain legal expenses in connection with recent litigation. The four items accounted for approximately $650,000 during the second quarter. The company also announced it has received a demand letter from Intersil Inc. for payment of approximately $807,000, which represents 50 percent of the costs that Intersil has incurred from November 1987 through February 1990 in connection with the cleanup of soil and groundwater contamination detected with the cleanup of soil and groundwater contamination detected under the two companies' properties.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: CORNISH hens are ideally suited for barbecuing or broiling. They weigh only about a pound each, so they cook relatively quickly. And they have firmer, moister flesh than chickens, so they don't dry out as quickly.

title: Lloyd W. Hazleton, 79, Biological Researcher
description: Lloyd Walter Hazleton, retired president of Hazleton Laboratories Inc., a biotechnology research company, died on Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 79 years old. Dr. Hazleton and his wife, Harriet, founded the company in 1946 on the grounds of an old country schoolhouse in Fairfax, Va. It became one of the world's largest biological testing services, dealing with new chemicals and chemical compounds.

title: Wine Talk
description: It seems only fitting, on Independence Day that we forgo what used to be known as the Old World and set out a few of our own good wines for consideration. Traditionally, this is an occasion to talk about ''picnic wines'' and such. The fact is that even in summer we sit down fully clothed at a table for most meals, and if wine is drunk it is not going to differ markedly from what we drink in winter.

title: Call the Second Amendment Freedom Insurance;   Archaic Rights?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the breakdown of safeguards in the savings and loan industry included one accounting firm erroneously in a list of firms that have been sued by the Government over their auditing of failed savings institutions. Coopers & Lybrand has not been sued by the Government. As auditor for a private financial company, the firm was sued by an Oklahoma savings and loan that did business with the financial company. The Government inherited this suit when it assumed control of the Oklahoma savings and loan.

title: Entrapment as Defense: Merely Showing That There Was a Trap Is Not Enough
description: The videotape of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. smoking what prosecutors say is crack in a hotel room provides several openings for his lawyers to raise an entrapment defense, lawyers and legal scholars say. But while it may be easy to raise the issue, it will be extremely difficult for Mr. Barry's lawyers to succeed in making their case.

title: Review/Television;   The Patriotic Tradition: Effusing on Americana
description: The Independence Day tradition of effusing over things American is honored tonight by ''On the Fourth of July with Charles Kuralt.'' The hourlong CBS News special at 10 P.M. is a quilt of swatches from the garrulous Mr. Kuralt's reports of recent years for ''Sunday Morning'' and ''On the Road.''

title: Literacy Cup That Erred
description: There was just one thing wrong with a commemorative cup sold to benefit the city's literacy program: the Mayor's name was misspelled. The cups marked the 10th anniversary celebration of Baltimore's redeveloped waterfront this week. They declared that proceeds would benefit ''the literacy initiative of Baltimore City's Mayor, Kurt L. Schnoke.'' Mayor Schmoke said, ''I guess I'll just have to stay around for another 10 years and see that they get it right next time.''

title: Microwave Cooking
description: WHILE a microwave oven is great for summer main courses, when you are trying to avoid kitchen heat, it is also a cool way to prepare for one of the easiest, most informal ways of entertaining, the cocktail party. Despite the microwave oven's reputation as being good only for preparing small quantities, it can cook enough for large groups.

title: Chronicle
description: ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER says that his marriage to SARAH BRIGHTMAN is over. And that he has a new close friend.

title: Where's Mr. Bush on the Arts?
description: ''Granted, the guy is walking a tightrope in a hurricane,'' a member of the art world said last week about John Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. ''But he has to take a stronger position.''

title: Dixieland Jazz Concert
description: A free outdoor performance of Dixieland jazz is to be given by the Smith Street Society Band at 1 P.M. today in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum is to be open today from 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Admission is $6 ($3 for students and the elderly). Information: 879-5500.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CBS Records, New York, a unit of Sony Corp., named Marvin Cohn president of CBS Music Publishing.

title: Notebook: Boxing;   Ex-Olympian Leaves Earlier Criticism Behind
description: Riddick Bowe, the undefeated heavyweight (17-0, 15 knockouts), will headline his first network television card for CBS on Sunday against Art Tucker in Atlantic City.

title: American Freed in Ecuador Savors Home and the Town That Saved Him
description: After 61 days in captivity in the Colombian jungle, Scott Heimdal has returned to the Illinois city that passed collection plates and held bake sales to raise $60,000 to free him.

title: Carolina Freight Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: b-Net income

title: France to Attend Talks on Atom Arms Curb
description: France said today that for the first time it would attend talks on curbing the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: David Byrne Concert Today
description: David Byrne and his Pan-American band, Rei Momo, are to give the final concert of their tour at 3 P.M. today at Rumsey Playfield in the middle of Central Park at 72d Street. The concert, which was rained out on Sunday, is presented by Summerstage (360-2777); admission is free.

title: R.P. Scherer reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Reflects restructuring and other non-recurring charges of $15 million and increases of interest and goodwill amortization expenses, pursuant to the acquisition of the company in June 1989, of $34.4 million and $2.7 million, respectively. The year also included income from discontinued operations of $618,000. c-Net income and included non- recurring charge of $9 million and also included income from discontinued operations of $1,546,000 and an extraordinary credit of $932,000.

title: Ruling on Allegheny Near
description: United States Bankruptcy Judge Joseph Cosetti could confirm a bankruptcy reorganization plan for the Allegheny International Inc. as early as this week, officials close to the company and its creditors said today.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Coat of Arms Is Restored
description: Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to replace the Communist state emblem with Hungary's traditional coat of arms.

title: Safety Board Blames Captain In '89 Jet Crash in East River
description: Transportation Safety Board today put the blame for the crash last year of USAir Flight 5050 squarely on the plane's captain, saying he had failed to take several actions that would have prevented the jet from skidding off the end of the runway at La Guardia Airport.

title: Growing Up in Flanders When the Nazis Came
description: The problem with being an author who writes in Dutch, as Hugo Claus does, is that parts of the world outside the Netherlands and Belgium may never find out you exist, let alone ever read your books.

title: Peter Kash Weds Donna Friedman
description: Donna Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Friedman of Monsey, N.Y., was married yesterday at Shaare Tova Synagogue in Kew Gardens, Queens, to Peter Morgan Kash, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kash of Bellmore, L.I. Rabbi Harvey Goldscheider and Cantor David Rosenzweig performed the ceremony.

title: The Rout of the Ozone Killers
description: The chemicals that destroy the earth's fragile protective layer of ozone will be largely phased out by the year 2000 under an agreement reached at a 93-nation meeting in London last week. That's a costly but vital step in averting a significant threat to the global environment.

title: Dow-Datatimes Deal
description: Dow Jones Information Services and Datatimes have agreed to a joint marketing and service deal to combine their electronic libraries, the two companies anounced on Monday. Datatimes is a subsidiary of the Oklahoma Publishing Company, with a minority share owned by Dow Jones & Company. The arrangement will allow researchers to search electronically through the computerized files of 640 newspapers, magazines, news services and financial data sources. More than 450 sources will be available for simultaneous access.

title: Scarce Metal Hits $7,000 An Ounce
description: The price of rhodium, a little-known but environmentally important precious metal, soared by $1,000, to a record $7,000 an ounce today, and some analysts expect the metal to climb higher before speculative pressures subside.

title: Why Ali Loved Flag Burnings
description: LEAD: My friend Ali told me that when he was a young boy growing up in Jordan during the 1960's, he used to like to go to the movies. But before the film could start, he is embarrassed to say, a huge likeness of King Hussein would appear on the screen, and everyone had to stand and sing along while a military band played the

title: Call the Second Amendment Freedom Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial for John Faulk
description: A memorial concert for John Henry Faulk, the Southern humorist and radio personality, is to be held at 5:30 P.M. on Monday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. In 1962, Mr. Faulk, who had a show on CBS radio, won a libel suit against Aware Inc., which was devoted to alerting broadcasters and advertisers about those in the entertainment industry it felt had ties to the Communist Party. He became a champion of First Amendment rights. Mr. Faulk died of cancer on April 9 at the age of 76. The program is to include readings from his stories and essays, and performances by Pete Seeger, Odetta and others. The gathering is to be free and open to the public.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A WOMAN whose name means nothing in social circles reports:

title: Angola Rejects Rebel Relief-Aid Plan
description: Saying it fears a trap laid by the United States, the Government of Angola has rejected a proposal by Jonas Savimbi, the American-backed rebel leader, for the creation of safe routes by which food and medicine can be supplied to famine-stricken areas under guerrilla control.

title: After Her Acquittal, Marcos Is Now Facing Civil Cases
description: Rejoicing in court and at church and at restaurants and parties, and in front of an endless procession of cameras, Imelda Marcos has expressed her gratitude in the last two days to the American justice system for clearing her of criminal charges.

title: INSIDE
description: Liberian Rebels Advance

title: Snooky Lanson, 76; Sang on a TV Show And in Nightclubs
description: Snooky Lanson, a singing star of the popular 1950's television show ''Your Hit Parade,'' died on Monday at St. Thomas Hospital here. He was 76 years old.

title: Books of The Times;   Soviet and American Minds Meet in Their Essays
description: Openings

title: Tennis;   Lendl Faces Another Little-Known Foe
description: Both Ivan Lendl and Brad Pearce have declared themselves on a mission to win Wimbledon, but beyond the fact that each recently became the father of a baby daughter, the resemblance between them ends right there.

title: Credit Extension For Control Data
description: A group of banks led by the Bank of America has extended its credit agreement with the Control Data Corporation and offered expanded borrowing privileges to the computer company. The agreement, first signed in July 1988, would have expired on Saturday.

title: Americans Sense a New Patriotism
description: Blacks are playing a more prominent role than ever in this year's Independence Day celebration, which comes as blacks seem to be experiencing a growing sense of participating in the nation's rituals and history.

title: Evolution in Europe;   German Unity by Year's End Now Almost Certain
description: The East German Government's decision to call for all-German elections on Dec. 2 now makes it almost certain that Germany will be reunited by the end of this year, West German Government officials say.

title: U.S. May Ban PAC's With Foreign Ties
description: Spurred by pressure from lawmakers who maintain that foreign corporations are exerting undue influence on the American political system, the Federal Election Commission has agreed to consider banning the political action committees of such companies' American subsidiaries.

title: Humanitarian Aid for Romania Is Best
description: To the Editor:

title: German Art May Move To a Museum
description: A plan has emerged from the Quedlinburg treasures court case in Dallas to move the contested artworks from two bank vaults to the Dallas Museum of Art where they may go on display, a museum official and a lawyer involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Marion R. Hart, 98; Made 7 Solo Flights Across the Atlantic
description: Marion Rice Hart, a sportswoman and author who sailed a ketch around the world and in her later years made seven solo flights across the Atlantic, the last at 83 years old, died on Monday. She was 98 years old and lived in Berkeley, Calif. She previously lived in Washington and Manhattan.

title: Lima Journal;   What's Hawked at Curbside? Dolares
description: With his white jogging shoes padding on the pavement, Fernando Pantigoso loped alongside a slowing car and offered the day's special - the United States dollar at 65,000 intis.

title: Saatchi Set To Sell Unit
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the London-based advertising conglomerate, said today that it had agreed to sell the Gartner Group, an American consulting firm, for $70 million.

title: 2 Leading Foes of One-Party Rule Are Reported Arrested by Kenya
description: The two leaders of Kenya's unofficial opposition and the most outspoken advocates of a multi-party state were arrested here tonight after weeks of harassment.

title: In Bulgaria, the Official Party Must Go
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPER IS BOMBED IN JOHANNESBURG
description: A bomb exploded today at the offices of an Afrikaans-language weekly newspaper that reported the existence last month of a right-wing plot to kill President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela.

title: Mandela Calls British Talks 'Productive'
description: Nelson Mandela met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for three hours today and said afterward that the two ''made progress,'' although they failed to agree on the use of economic sanctions and violence in ending apartheid.

title: All Except the Texas Heat Is Under Rug for Summit
description: In the ''war room'' tucked inside a nondescript suite in a high-rise building here, volunteers staff a bank of telephones in front of a wall-size map.

title: Review/Music;   Outdoor, Free and American
description: The National Chorale has been singing at free concerts of American music in parks around the New York area since 1980. The group began this year's series with a brief historical sampler in Damrosch Park on Tuesday evening. The performance was carried live by WQXR, which is broadcasting concerts from Damrosch Park on Tuesdays this month.

title: Washington Talk;   Where Right Spin Can Mean You're In
description: When President Bush appointed a Washington lawyer named Stephen Potts to the Administration's top ethics post two weeks ago, the choice seemed curious at first.

title: Herman Goldfarb, 68, Is Dead; Executive Helped Crime Inquiry
description: Herman Goldfarb, an insurance broker who worked undercover in an inquiry into organized crime in the New York garment industry in the early 70's and who later, while in the Federal witness-protection program, was tried for ordering the murder of a man who had threatened to reveal his identity, died on Sunday in San Diego. He was 68 years old and lived in Solana Beach, Calif.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JULY 5, 1990
description: International

title: People
description: * Kathy Harrington, president and chief creative officer of Stern Walters Partners, a Chicago agency, has been named to the additional post of chief executive.

title: A Stylistic Departure For I.B.M.
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation has decided to put on a happy face. A new corporate advertising campaign for I.B.M., which as the behemoth of the computer world has been unable in recent years to move as quickly into new markets as some of its competitors, creates an image of a revitalized company that cares about its customers and is more than happy to take on all comers.

title: Myra S. Eckstein, Student, Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Myra S. Eckstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eckstein of Great Neck, L.I., to Alon Y. Mogilner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Mogilner of Brooklyn, took place yesterday. Rabbi Jacob M. Sable officiated at the Great Neck Synagogue. Mrs. Mogilner, 24 years old, graduated cum laude from New York University, where she also received an M.A. degree and where she is studying for a Ph.D. in political science and Middle Eastern studies. Her father is the president of H. Eckstein & Sons, a dry-goods concern in Manhattan. Her mother, Nadine Eckstein, is a designer of silver sculpture.

title: Picnic Gear Is Compact, Cool and Light
description: LEAD: GONE are the days of carrying extra weight for a lunch on the lawn, supper in the park or a barbecue on the beach. This is the summer of light, compact and cool picnic gear.

title: Currents;   From the Master, More Rug Designs
description: THE Frank Lloyd Wright rug collection of F. Schumacher & Company has four new designs reinterpreting Wright's designs for a room in the 1902 Arthur Heurtley House in Oak Park, Ill.; two drapery panels for the 1906 Avery Coonley House in Riverside, Ill., and a 1926 cover design for Liberty magazine.

title: Review/Dance;   Feet, Bringers of Thunder: Rat-a-Tat-Tap at Apollo
description: The thunder that came from the Apollo Theater on Monday night was not an early fireworks celebration honoring the Fourth of July. It was a brilliant pyrotechnical display of tap dancing, presented by Dancing in the Streets as the final event in Rat-a-Tat-Tap, its festival of percussive music and dance.

title: U.S. Court Opens Way For Cuts in Lilco's Rates
description: A Federal Court of Appeals ruling has put an end, at least for now, to the drawn-out litigation between Suffolk County and the Long Island Lighting Company over the utility's rate increases while it was building the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Our Public Schools Encourage Mediocrity
description: To the Editor:

title: Networks Wary on '94 World Cup Rights
description: Although this year's World Cup soccer champion will not be crowned until Sunday, wrangling has already begun over who will televise the 1994 World Cup tournament in the United States.

title: Lessons in the Cracker Market
description: Few products looked more promising. When RJR Nabisco introduced a bite-size version of graham crackers last fall, the company was abuzz. In the in-house lingo, the sweet, crispy snack was very ''more-ish'' (you wanted more of it) and had ''high poppability'' (you wanted to pop it in your mouth).

title: Target Practice, With Public Money
description: The U.S. Army spends about $5 million a year to support civilian target shooting - for reasons that no longer make sense.

title: Out-of-Doors Festival Set for Lincoln Center
description: Performances by the Merce Cun-ningham Dance Company, Gunther Schuller conducting Charles Mingus's ''Epitaphs,'' and a Roots of American Music Festival celebrating blues, gospel and folk music are among the highlights of the 20th-anniversary season of Lincoln Center's Out-of-Doors Festival, to run from Aug. 1 to 27 on the center's plazas and in Damrosch Park.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Russian Playwrights Discuss Role of Union
description: It may have something to do with the way theater mirrors life, but the disagreement among a group of visiting Russian playwrights brought to New York's theater district a taste of what's going on in larger Soviet stages these days.

title: Dr. Farahe Maloof, 69; Headed Hospital Unit
description: Dr. Farahe Maloof, a former chief of the thyroid unit of Massachusetts General Hospital, died Monday. Dr. Maloof, a resident of Milton, Mass., was 69 years old.

title: A Tribute by Nannies To One of Their Own
description: There was a moment of suspense in the radio studio. Four women waited for the first caller to pierce the intimacy of the soundproof room where Diane Rehm moderates a popular talk show here each weekday morning on WAMU.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: Berlin Project Is Approved
description: West Berlin has approved plans for West Germany's biggest company, Daimler-Benz A.G., to build offices on a Berlin wall wasteland.

title: Review/Music;   Pedestrians Help Make Performance
description: Christopher Janney, a composer who specializes in environmental sound installations, wired up the Fifth Avenue staircase of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday afternoon for a three-hour presentation of his ''Soundstair,'' a pedestrian-participation work. The performance, which was part of the Rat-a-Tat-Tap festival of percussive music and dance, was offered as a celebration of the 25th anniversary of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: U.S. Banks Cut Global Business As Rivals Grow
description: Once the pacesetters for global expansion in the financial industry, American banks are retreating from foreign markets, losing business and stature to competitors from Europe and Japan.

title: Germans Top English With Penalty Kicks
description: For the second time in two nights, a game of soccer turned into a game of chance to decide which of two quality teams would advance to the final of the World Cup.

title: Evolution in Europe;   In Leninallee, Cans, Bottles and Papers: It's the West's Waste
description: Mirko Kontze, a sturdy East Berlin street cleaner, has his own way of measuring the arrival of Western capitalism: it is bringing a lot of garbage to his part of town.

title: Becker and Lendl Beat Elements and Rivals
description: Although the rain stopped, the chill and gale persisted. But the Wimbledon committee, evidently of a mind that their male quarterfinalists could keep a stiff upper lip at this critical stage of the tournament, hustled all four matches onto the nearest available court late this afternoon.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Total in Dart Attacks Rises to 26 Women
description: A man shooting darts through a homemade dart pipe has struck two more women in midtown, making the total of victims 26, the police said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   NATO Leaders Gather, In Search of a Purpose
description: When President Bush and the 15 other leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gather in the palace of Lancaster House on Thursday morning, they will begin the most crucial summit meeting since the alliance came into being 41 years ago.

title: Metro Matters;   Life, Liberty And the Pursuit Of Realty Rights
description: George Washington never slept in Hendrick I. Lott's farmhouse. But after being routed in the Battle of Brooklyn Heights, remnants of his army that were not evacuated to Manhattan were said to have fled across Lott's farm.

title: On the Streets of New York, It's Motorists vs. Ambulances
description: With red lights flashing and siren blaring, an ambulance weaved in and out of traffic in upper Manhattan recently, racing to get a woman who had suffered a heart attack to St. Luke's Hospital at Amsterdam Avenue and 114th Street.

title: Review/Music;   Easy Sound of Patti Page
description: Patti Page has maintained her balance in the tricky and treacherous world of pop music for more than 40 years by staying with the kind of simplicity that has enabled Perry Como to have an equally long career. Miss Page opened a three-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza) on Tuesday singing a program made up mostly of songs that she has been singing for years or that fit the pop and country-western styles of the late 1940's and early 50's when her career developed.

title: For Veterans, Wheelchairs Give the Day Somber Tone
description: Forget the fireworks, the tricolored bunting draped over picnic tables and the jostle of the beach crowds.

title: Items Worth $45 Million Missing From a U.S. Lab
description: The General Accounting Office, investigating charges that equipment was stolen from the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California to buy illegal drugs, says an inventory shows that items worth more than $45 million are missing.

title: Currents;   New Waves In Quilting
description: AT ''Visions: A New Decade,'' an exhibition of 83 quilts at the Museum of San Diego History, there are quilts that depict trees of the Pacific Northwest and a Mexican celebration of the Day of the Dead. But the newest trend is quilts that look three dimensional. Joyce Marquess Carey of Madison, Wis., created a series of three quilts called ''Glad Rags 5, 6, 7,'' top left, that look as if they are banners waving in the air.
