She also designed ''Red Squares,'' bottom left, a political cartoon made from jacquard-woven portraits of former Communist leaders.

title: San Jose Journal;   When Raising the Flag Is Sure to Raise a Storm
description: It was to have been like thousands of other statues honoring local heroes that stand in public parks across the nation, a monument quickly transformed into a pigeon perch and another source of that eternal question of children: ''Who was that dude?''

title: In Italy, a Gloomy Day After
description: Moments after Argentina bounced Italy out of the World Cup competition Tuesday night, window shutters flew open at an apartment overlooking Via di San Stefano del Cacco, a narrow street in Rome's historic center.

title: Botanic Garden Loses a Leader, Gains a Legacy
description: There was no final ceremony for Donald E. Moore, who retired Saturday after 10 years as president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Toxic Shock Toll Plummets
description: Toxic shock syndrome has declined sharply since 1980, largely because of changes in tampons, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reports.

title: Stocks Fall In London
description: Stock prices closed lower today on the London Stock Exchange, depressed by mounting concern about the strengthening pound.

title: Bridge
description: Imaginative players sometimes reject an obvious safe lead in favor of a risky one.

title: Market Place;   A Savings Bank Bucks the Trend
description: IN the early 1980's, when almost everyone believed that growth was great for a bank, the Jamaica Savings Bank followed a radically different course. It deliberately allowed assets to shrink.

title: Wage Pacts Reached In Care of Retarded
description: Workers for four private agencies serving mentally retarded people and emotionally disturbed children have reached tentative union contract agreements. The workers are to vote on the agreements this week.

title: Karl Allison, 42, Director of Planning For Spoleto U.S.A.
description: Karl Allison, the director of planning and development for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. and a former Broadway and Off Broadway producer, died yesterday in a hospital in Perugia, Italy. He was 42 years old.

title: NATO's Most Crucial Summit
description: In London today, NATO, which has lost its original reason for being, is opening its most crucial summit meeting in its existance. Page A8.

title: Mergers Up In Europe as Barriers Fall
description: The lure, and the fear, of 1992 are continuing to drive the pace of mergers and acquisitions in Europe, and more and more they are opening doors that had been closed in the past.

title: A 'Last Resort' for NATO
description: President Bush wants to reduce NATO's reliance on nuclear arms and on early nuclear first use. But he also wants to preserve a nuclear option for the alliance. He has found a reasonable way to do both by proposing to turn nuclear arms into ''weapons of last resort.''

title: Soccer, Like Life, Is a Lottery
description: Here's something we can all root for in the World Cup final on Sunday: the lighting system. If the fuses should happen to blow during a tie breaker at Olympic Stadium on Sunday night, we would all be treated to the spectacle of the biggest tournament in the world being decided by chance.

title: Sperm Count Goes Down In Summer
description: Men who live in temperate climates produce significantly less sperm in summer than in winter, researchers report, a finding that partly accounts for fewer births in the spring.

title: Benefactor Arrested For Defacing Sign
description: A wealthy entrepreneur, known here for helping to beautify the town, has been arrested for spray-painting a real-estate sign near his house.

title: Land-Buying Drive by Pentagon Runs Into Stiff Resistance in West
description: The Pentagon is pressing its biggest land-buying drive since World War II, seeking to add nearly 4.5 million acres to its 25 million acres nationwide.

title: ERA OF FREE TRADE TO BEGIN IN BRAZIL
description: Breaking with decades of protectionism, Brazil's new Government has decided to open the nation's economy, the eighth largest in the West, to imports and free trade.

title: Job for Beber Silverstein
description: Ed McCabe, who made a name for himself and Frank Perdue through his copywriting for the chicken seller, will try to do the same for Mel Coleman, a Colorado rancher. Mr. McCabe's new agency, Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners, has won the advertising account of Coleman Natural Meats, a Denver producer of beef and lamb.

title: Troubled Times for Architecture Industry
description: The virtual evaporation of significant new construction projects in New York City is deeply hurting the architectural profession, forcing firms to lay off employees, cut their fees, diversify their practices and search for work in other cities and countries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Fourth of July reminds me that I am an American. Do I need to say anything else?''

title: The City Council Passes a Tax Test
description: New York's City Council has survived its first major test under the new City Charter. Negotiating with a new Mayor, David Dinkins, and without its old partner, the Board of Estimate, the Council approved a $28 billion budget that deals responsibly with the city's weakening economy.

title: Personal Health
description: Sweltering summer days and school vacations prompt millions of Americans to head for the country or the shore, move to a cabin in the woods or take in the sights in different parts of the country. Most travel by car.

title: Books of The Times;   Overcoming a Lifetime's Motivations to Drink
description: That Place in Minnesota

title: Currents;   For Babies With Little Else to Smile At
description: THE Variety House for Children in Manhattan, one of a handful of residential treatment centers and nurseries for small children handicapped by AIDS, cocaine addiction or other conditions, is cozy and full of whimsical details, like wood cabinets inlaid with animal motifs and floor tiles that form a whale.

title: End of the Party
description: The party is a corpse. Unless Mikhail Gorbachev at last acknowledges its death, one day he will be buried with it.

title: HEALTH: Cheating on Insurance;   Insurers Say Growing Fraud In Health Care Costs Billions
description: Most of the expectant couples who turned up for the delivery orientation at a hospital in Southern California two years ago were thrilled when an administrator told them, over coffee and doughnuts, that the hospital would offer a discount on their care.

title: Our Public Schools Encourage Mediocrity
description: To Preserve Choice To the Editor:

title: One Man, Three Homes, One Mission: Preserving Architectural Treasures
description: SOME people collect salt and pepper shakers. Joseph Pell Lombardi collects houses.

title: Is a Character Intense? Call Stephen Lang.
description: Stephen Lang is playing another edgy guy.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Diner's Journal column of Weekend on Friday misidentified the new chef at 150 Wooster, a restaurant owned by Brian McNally.

title: Parents Divided on Using Siblings in Marrow Case
description: A judge has been asked to order blood tests on 3-year-old twins to determine whether they might be potential bone marrow donors for their half-brother, who is suffering from leukemia.

title: Vicki Stein Dies at 67; Social Reform Leader
description: Vicki Stein, founder of Victims Assistance Services of Westchester County, a group of professionals formed with state and county money to help victims of domestic violence and other crimes, died on Monday at White Plains Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The favorite horse of QUEEN ELIZABETH II, which she rode in 18 Trooping the Color ceremonies, died Tuesday after a stroke. A spokesman for Buckingham Palace said that Burmese, a 28-year-old mare, would be buried in the park at Windsor Castle, which is 22 miles west of London.

title: Our Public Schools Encourage Mediocrity;   A Success Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Improvement
description: SANDING a wood floor to refinish it is not too difficult, but it is dusty, noisy and time consuming. A floor thickly covered with paint should be chemically stripped first, to reduce the amount of sanding necessary.

title: Amid Praise, Mexican Chief Draws Fire on Rights
description: As a candidate for President in 1988, Carlos Salinas de Gortari promised that he would modernize the Mexican economy and usher in an era of true democracy.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Gives Leadership 2 Years To Rejuvenate the Soviet Economy
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that if the troubled Soviet economy failed to begin rebounding in two years, then the Communist leadership of the party would quit ''of its own accord.''

title: Currents;   A Moscow Of Dream And Reality
description: ''ARCHITECTURAL Drawings of the Russian Avant-Garde,'' 150 drawings done from 1917 to 1934, reveals as much fantasy as Socialist Realism. The drawings, at the Museum of Modern Art, include some for projects that were not built, among them a glass pyramid drawn in 1930 that resembles I. M. Pei's addition to the Louvre in Paris; a 1924 proposal for a newspaper building with rotating upper stories. There are also several versions of the Lenin Mausoleum.

title: LIBERIAN OFFICER IS SAID TO DESERT
description: The chief of President Samuel K. Doe's personal security force deserted today as Liberian rebel forces fired captured artillery and mortars at Government positions and inched closer to the center of Monrovia, the capital, United States officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the seven years that he was New York City's Parks Commissioner, HENRY J. STERN was noted for talking to trees and protecting the sex life of the dragonfly. Now, he will be a gadfly. The Citizens Union, the New York City watchdog organization that sometimes bites, has elected him its first fulltime president.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Britain's Writers Embrace the Offbeat
description: When readers think of innovation and experimentation in the recent novel, they think of writers like Jorge Luis Borges, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Mario Vargas Llosa, Carlos Fuentes, Milan Kundera, Thomas Pynchon and Donald Barthelme. They think of the alternatives to naturalism produced by the magical realists from Latin America and Eastern Europe, and by American innovators reacting to the social and political confusions of the 1960's. They do not tend to immediately think of writers from Britain, that stalwart island of tradition.

title: Caroline Bowers Is Wed
description: At the Swan Club in Roslyn, L.I., Caroline M. Bowers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bill Bowers of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday to Howard M. Hyams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Hyams of Baldwin, L.I. Rabbi Charles G. Agin officiated. Mrs. Hyams, 28 years old, graduated from the University of Hawaii and the Fashion Institute of Technology. Mr. Hyams, 33, is a designer for Maidenform in Bayonne, N.J.

title: On the Fourth, Feeling Cooked On a 93 degrees Grill
description: Some celebrated the Fourth of July by gorging themselves on hot dogs and ice cream. Others in the metropolitan area fed the homeless. Almost all tried to escape the withering heat, whether at the beach, in swimming pools or even at an indoor ice-skating rink.

title: Madrid Journal;   Spain Frets a Bit as Third-World Tide Sweeps In
description: Over the last five centuries Spain has successively expelled Arabs, Jews, Masons and Protestants. In the same period, millions of Spaniards left the country, emigrating first to the New World and more recently to northern Europe, where they found work, sent for their families and became part of local societies.

title: Ostracism, He Taught, May Be the Worst Part of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Warrants for Traps and Stings
description: The videotape showing the hotel encounter between Mayor Marion Barry of Washington and an F.B.I. informant, now playing repeatedly at his trial and on television, means many things to many people. To the prosecution it proves cocaine use and perjury in denying using drugs. To the defense it spells entrapment - Government overreaching to nail a troublesome black leader. To the public it may mean both, with a heavy layer of disgust at the behavior of this once-promising public figure.

title: Events: Insider's View of a Wright Home
description: Remembering Wright, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-996-1100.

title: Review/Dance;   American Festival Offers Masters and Others
description: The American Dance Festival's summer season has entered the 1990's with a performance series entitled American Masters Plus.

title: Canseco Is Vote Leader As All-Stars Are Listed
description: Jose Canseco, the top vote-getter among all players, was one of three Oakland Athletics voted by the fans to the American League starting team for the All-Star Game Tuesday night at Wrigley Field. Ryne Sandberg of the hometown Cubs topped the balloting in the National League.

title: New Nike Commercials Promote Good Conduct
description: Nike plans to start a $5 million advertising campaign next week in which its spokesmen promote not sneakers but good behavior.

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: Financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday for the Fourth of July.

title: Entrepreneurs Flourish As India Makes Reforms
description: In the last decade, many young, aggressive entrepreneurs have flourished in India by forming ventures with foreign corporations, tapping the subcontinent's vast domestic markets and challenging the traditional power of older, family-held industrial empires.

title: Surging Mets Stumble a Bit, Then Overcome Astros
description: The Mets are so immovable these days that they win even when Dwight Gooden pitches on a sweltering night with a blister on his index finger and loses a 4-0 lead in the late innings. And that's precisely what they did last night before a sellout crowd of 48,072 fans in Shea Stadium.

title: G.M. Hopes Solar-Car Race Will Aid Student Engineers
description: Solar power never regained the enormous attention it commanded during the Arab oil embargo of the 1970's, but the General Motors Corporation hopes a race of solar-powered cars it is sponsoring will help persuade students to consider careers in engineering.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Other Moves on Embassies
description: The mass attempt of the Albanians to gain freedom by storming diplomatic missions in Tirana over the last few days was apparently provoked by other similar attempts on a smaller scale in recent months.

title: Agonizing in Sweden: Welcome or Ouster for 150 Soviet Jews?
description: Torn by a desire to limit immigration and uncertainty over how to react to the changes sweeping the Soviet Union, Swedes are agonizing over whether the country should give asylum to about 150 Soviet Jews who arrived over the last year.

title: Peru Suspends Cuba Pact
description: Peru has indefinitely suspended a year-old trade pact with Cuba because Havana missed a $5.2 million payment last month, a spokesman for Peru's Central Reserve Bank said today. The payment was due on June 8, but Cuba neither paid nor asked Peru for refinancing, said Juan Zuniga, the bank spokesman.

title: After Seven Months, Ramos Is Going Home
description: Almost seven months after suffering a severe brain injury in an car accident, the Trail Blazer forward Ramon Ramos left a hospital rehabilitation center in Portland, Ore., on Tuesday.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Former Comex Head Joins Securities Firm
description: LEAD: Arnold F. Staloff, who in April resigned under pressure as president and chief executive of the Commodity Exchange, has been named president and chief executive of Bloom & Company, a Philadelphia securities firm.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Poland Drops Demand For German Guarantee
description: Poland today dropped its demand that the two Germanys guarantee its borders in a treaty before they unite.

title: Talks in Taiwan Urge a Popular Presidential Vote
description: After five days of strenuous national debate, a national conference on this island's future concluded today with a call for popular presidential elections.

title: The Lilies of Summer
description: LILIES have loomed larger in the human imagination for a greater stretch of history than any other flower except roses. One species, the Madonna lily (Lilium candidum), is depicted in frescoes in Crete dating about 1500 B.C. The fairly small flowers of this plant are so dazzling in their whiteness that they have become the stuff of myth and theology. An ancient Greek tradition holds that this lily originated when Juno suckled the infant Hercules, where drops of her milk fell to earth.

title: Planning Is Begun on South Africa Aid Bank
description: Nelson Mandela and the Rockefeller Foundation have begun to plan the creation of a South African development bank to change the country's white-dominated economy through foreign investment.

title: Germans To Have One Team
description: There will be a unified German team for the Winter and Summer Olympics in 1992, the presidents of the two national Olympic committees announced today.

title: Pratt Recalls Some Jet Engines
description: Pratt & Whitney Inc. has recalled more than three dozen of its newest and largest jet engines because of a compressor problem that if left unchecked could prompt an engine to shut down during a flight.

title: Founder of Kaypro Sees Life in the Company Yet
description: Innovation and unorthodoxy have long ruled at the Kaypro Corporation, reflected in the design of its personal computers and the style of its headquarters, a secluded compound near a beach, where employees munched health food from the company snack bar while they worked.

title: Black Minister Recruits More Men for the Church
description: Not long ago, the Rev. Jonny Ray Youngblood looked around his Brooklyn church and decided he was lonely. ''I was just about the only man there,'' he said.

title: INSIDE
description: Show and Tell, Texas Style

title: A Fidelity Link With Nuveen
description: In a move that may foreshadow broad changes in the retail investment market, Fidelity Investments has agreed to market a popular product of John Nuveen & Company to Fidelity's mutual fund and brokerage customers.

title: Talking Deals;   A Polaroid First In Minolta Accord
description: The Polaroid Corporation's agreement last week to let the Minolta Camera Company of Japan take over the job of marketing Polaroid's most sophisticated instant camera to consumers was not the kind of deal anyone would have embraced around Polaroid's headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., until relatively recently. The deal, which applies only to United States sales, means the camera will no longer carry Polaroid's name here, only Minolta's.

title: Review/Dance;   Waiting Impatiently for the Train to Chaos
description: O Vertigo Dance is a company of fast, hard movers with strong presences and that indefinable French chic, though here on the scruffy side. Or so it seemed from an appearance here by the Canadian dance company on Tuesday night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, where it performs through Saturday. At the handsome new Studio Theater - a cathedral-like structure that is at once functional and suitably rustic for this festival in the woods - was just the right place for the company's ''Broken Wings (Train d'Enfer).'' The problem was the piece itself.

title: Parent & Child
description: WHEN her stepson was 10 years old, Sally Jo Dady would punish him by sending him to his room. ''A few years later that stopped working because he had magazines, a radio and a TV in there,'' said Mrs. Dady, who lives in Minneapolis. ''He would think being sent to his room was great.''

title: Rest-Home Resident, 90, Cleared of Killing 3
description: A 90-year-old man who often quarreled with others at the retirement home where he lived has been acquitted of thrashing three fellow residents to death with his heavy oak cane.

title: Boston Jury Convicts 2 Christian Scientists in Death of a Son
description: Two Christian Scientists were convicted of manslaughter today in the death of their 2-year-old son because they relied on prayer to treat him rather than seeking conventional medical care.

title: Review/Television;   With Sammy Davis, the Spirit Lingers
description: It's called ''Frank, Liza and Sammy: The Ultimate Event.'' Actually, it's a tape of Frank Sinatra, Liza Minnelli and Sammy Davis Jr. in a 1989 concert in Detroit. The show, sponsored by a beer company, was part of a national tour. Ms. Minnelli had replaced Dean Martin in the early rounds. With the recent death of Mr. Davis, the Showtime special - produced by George Schlatter and being repeated tonight at 6:30 - takes on new, more poignant contours. This is the star, who always thought of himself primarily as a cabaret performer, when he was still operating close to full power.

title: A Chilling Prospect
description: The Rev. Donald Wildmon of the American Family Association has not been a strong supporter of the free expression that some Americans, on their Independence Day, celebrated as a precious constitutional right.

title: Yields Post Modest Rise
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly higher for the week ended Tuesday.

title: Maurice Girodias, A French Publisher And an Author, 71
description: Maurice Girodias, a French publisher whose early editions of such books as Vladimir Nabokov's ''Lolita'' and Henry Miller's ''Tropic of Capricorn'' led him into long battles with French censors, died here today at the age of 71, apparently of a heart attack.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alliant Computer Systems Corp., Littleton, Mass., a manufacturer of standards-based parallel supercomputers, appointed Ronald H. Gruner vice chairman. He will remain chief executive but be replaced as president by Craig J. Mundie, who also becomes chief operating officer.

title: Lefebvre Backs Ejectees
description: The American League president, Bobby Brown is scheduled to announce today or tomorrow the disposition of the case involving the brawl between Seattle and Milwaukee at the Kingdome last Saturday, but Manager Jim Lefebvre of the Mariners is saying already that he will appeal any suspensions or ''outrageous'' fines against his players.

title: Dummy Arms Cause Closing of Terminal
description: Six Pan American World Airways flights were delayed up to 20 minutes yesterday when a shipment of dummy handguns and hand grenades used for security training was halted at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Scenes and Faces to Put on the Floor
description: ELSIE VAN SAVAGE of Brunswick, Me., has hooked rugs with boats on them, or business logos, or favorite foods or images associated with special trips.

title: Evolution in Europe;   In Fabled Samarkand, Newborns Fight for Life
description: There is a dark side to the stunning fruitfulness of this ancient oasis city that teems so with market produce and some of the most prolific citizenry in the Soviet Union.

title:
Should the West Bail Out Gorbachev?;

No, It Will Put Moscow On Welfare
description: LEAD: At the Group of Seven's Houston meeting, the biggest item on the agenda will be economic aid to the Soviet Union. Now that the cold war is over, the Soviet Union seems like just one of the boys.

title: Accounts
description: * Intelligy Corp., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill Advertising, San Francisco, for the introduction of Wings, a collection of educational toys, games and activities for small children.

title: Evolution in Europe;   24-NATION GROUP EXPANDS AID PLAN IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: Foreign ministers from 24 leading industrial nations agreed today to expand their economic aid program for Poland and Hungary to include the emerging East European democracies of Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and East Germany.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page on Friday about efforts to limit certain First Amendment protections incorrectly described the status of a lawsuit over whether panhandling may be prohibited on the New York City subways. The suit is on appeal before the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, not the Supreme Court.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOAN COLLINS is to return to the London stage in September as the sophisticated divorcee in Noel Coward's ''Private Lives.'' The play will be produced by MICHAEL CODRON, who has introduced the playwrights Tom Stoppard, Alan Ayckbourn and Michael Frayn to the West End.

title: An Aggressive Easy Goer Wins Suburban
description: Easy Goer tuned up for his showdown at Arlington Park next month with a contemptuously easy 3 3/4-length victory over De Roche yesterday in the $399,000 Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Currents;   'But I Dialed Singapore!'
description: TO amuse children strapped into car seats there is the yellow Kiddi Car Phone, which has blue and white buttons and a red antenna that clicks when it is raised. The ''cellular phone,'' made by Fisher-Price, comes with a suction cup to attach to a car window.

title: 19 People in Crowd Are Hurt By an Errant Fireworks Shell
description: Nineteen people were injured tonight when an errant shell from the town's Fourth of July fireworks display shot into a crowd of 5,000 people, the authorities said.

title: Robber Commits Suicide
description: A man robbed a convenience store in suburban Lakewood on Tuesday, was quickly cornered by the police and then shot himself to death after asking them to kill him, the authorities said. The man was identified today as Darcy Willey, 24 years old, of Tacoma.

title: Fast Computer From NEC
description: The NEC Corporation today announced what it said is the world's fastest mainframe computer.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Happy Is the Day! Marks for the Soviet Army
description: ''We'd like to cash a check,'' the Soviet Army told West Germany's central Bundesbank today as it withdrew millions of marks to pay its troops stationed in East Germany.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Albania Said to Weigh Passports for the Restive
description: Western diplomats said today that the Albanian Government was considering whether to issue more than 10,000 visas and passports to hundreds of Albanians seeking asylum in embassies in Tirana, the capital, and thousands of other disgruntled citizens.

title: CHRONICLE
description: East Germans, long deprived of Western rock-and-roll, will get the chance to see the most enduring band of all, the ROLLING STONES. The group, which played to 80,000 people in the Olympic Stadium in West Berlin last month, will return to Germany in August for an extra concert on its world tour, this time in East Berlin. In 25 years on the road, the Stones have never played in East Germany, promoters for the group said.

title: Small Renoir at Louvre Is Stolen in Daylight
description: A small painting by Pierre Auguste Renoir, ''Portrait of a Seated Woman,'' was cut from its frame and stolen in broad daylight from a third-floor gallery at the Louvre Museum today, museum authorities announced.

title: Dollar Drops Against Yen in Europe
description: The dollar fell below 150 yen in slow European trading today amid growing speculation that interest rates will decline in the United States.

title: Decision Near On a Pipeline From Canada
description: An ambitious plan to deliver natural gas from Canada's abundant western reserves to six energy-hungry Northeastern states has pitted neighbor against neighbor and community against community, as well as leading to an uneasy coalition of environmentalists and domestic gas producers against the whole idea.

title: Columbia Gas Selects Chief for 2 Subsidiaries
description: James P. Holland was elected chairman and chief executive of the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation and the Columbia Gulf Transmission Company this week. He replaces John D. Daly, who will become executive vice president and a director of the Columbia Gas System, the parent of the two companies, which are both based in Charleston, W. Va.

title: Q&A
description: Painting a Stone Fireplace

title: A Sparkler By Jackson Halts Yanks
description: Just when it looked as if the Yankees might salvage the final game of their latest trip through trouble, along came Bo Jackson. The result: another loss. Jackson rubbed out a momentary Yankee lead tonight when he crushed a three-run homer to center field in the seventh inning, a homer that resembled a fiery shooting star.

title: Steinbrenner Gives His Side At Vincent Hearing Today
description: George Steinbrenner finally gets to tell his side today. And what he chooses to say in a hearing before Commissioner Fay Vincent might play an important part in determining the Yankee owner's future in baseball.

title: Close to Home
description: ''NOW down here is a rental unit, very nice for income. Or when I get old I could put my nurse-companion there. Or if I get rich I could move to the country, rent out the other three floors and keep this as my pied-a-terre.'' I sigh. I have seen photographs of just the kind of simple but elegant city flat I have in mind in a British magazine called World of Interiors.

title: U.S. Pins Hopes on Guatemala Army
description: The United States, losing faith in the civilian Government, has turned to this country's military to insure stability and combat growing drug trafficking, Western diplomats and Guatemalan officials say.

title: Trottier's Preference
description: Bryan Trottier, whom the Islanders released Tuesday, may not be leaving the New York area.

title: Human Growth Hormone Reverses Effects of Aging
description: Treatment with human growth hormone can significantly reverse many effects of aging on the body, a new study has found.

title: Houston Ballyhoos Its Rebirth, Again
description: For Mayor Kathryn Whitmire, the Economic Summit of Industrialized Nations, to be held here next week, is ''probably the biggest thing to happen in Houston since the Johnson Space Center came to town.''

title: Ruling May Lead to Big Rise in States' Medicaid Costs
description: Judging by Pennsylvania's experience, the states face substantial costs if hospitals and nursing homes take advantage of a recent Supreme Court decision affirming their right to sue states for higher Medicaid reimbursement rates.

title: What's Mandela's Plan?
description: To the Editor:

title: Should the West Bail Out Gorbachev?;   Yes, Targeted Aid Wouldn't Be Wasted
description: When the heads of the leading industrial democracies meet in Houston next Monday, President Bush will face a question he has been trying to avoid: what can the West do to help Mikhail Gorbachev?

title: JUDGE CHALLENGED AT TRIAL OF BARRY
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed court papers today arguing that a Federal judge should admit two supporters of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. who had been barred from the Mayor's drug and perjury trial.

title: Strawberry's 3-Run Blast Carries Slugging Mets Past Braves
description: For teams in the National League, it's a bad enough fate to have the Mets on your schedule right now. There is, of course, no choice but to play them. There is also, though, no choice worse than to try to outslug them.

title: Paul Wynne, Who Aired Diary on AIDS, Dies at 47
description: Paul Wynne, a broadcast journalist whose on-the-air diary about AIDS made television history, died of AIDS today at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here. He was 47 years old.

title: Who Pays for the Clean Air Act?
description: This time around, Washington couldn't be prouder. Twenty years ago, when the major provisions of the Clean Air Act were passed, the word ''cost'' was hardly mentioned. Now, with the bill in a House-Senate conference, the debate over amendments to the act is filled with figures purporting to capture the cost of the tiniest provision.

title: Altos Computer
description: The Acer Group, the largest personal computer maker in Taiwan, said it had signed an agreement to buy Altos Computer Systems of San Jose, Calif., for $8.35 a share in cash. The transaction is valued at about $94 million. After the acquisition, which has been approved by the boards of both companies, Altos is to be operated as an independent subsidiary of Acer. Altos, which makes multi-user computer systems, had sales of $140 million in 1989.

title: No Change Seen at Fed On Rates
description: Despite pressure from the White House and Congress to lower interest rates quickly to try to prevent a recession, the Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to hold rates unchanged for the time being.

title: Central Park Witness Says Rape Victim 'Hung to Life'
description: The surgeon who treated the woman who was raped and beaten in Central Park last year said she was in ''deep shock and barely alive'' when an ambulance crew rushed her to the Metropolitan Hospital Center.

title: Japan Goals For 1990's
description: The Government ministry that helped engineer Japan's export-fueled economic boom says that in the 1990's Japan must turn inward and set its own house in order.

title: Review/Theater;   New Love? Or Just A New Life?
description: At the outset of ''A Silent Thunder,'' Eduardo Ivan Lopez's sentimental romance at the Apple Corps Theater, Kimiyo, an Okinawan teen-ager working in her uncle's tailor shop, takes a man's suit off the rack and dances around the room softly singing Simon and Garfunkel's ''Condor Pasa.'' She is interrupted in this reverie by the arrival of Cpl. Joe Santana, U.S.M.C., who has come to collect his suit - as it happens, the very suit Kimiyo is waltzing with. Kimiyo's fantasy suddenly expands its horizons.

title: Chronicle
description: The new director of the venerable Comedie Francaise is JACQUES LASSALLE, a distinguished actor and stage director who has headed the National Theater of Strasbourg since 1983. He succeeds Antoine Vitez, who died suddenly in May.

title: Louisiana's Arrogant, Insulting Abortion Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax on Securities Sales Is Viewed as Unlikely
description: A tax on the sale of securities is among dozens of revenue-raising ideas being discussed in the White House and in Congress, but officials said the odds now seemed to be strongly against such a tax.

title: Irving Berlin Was Swell to Cole Porter
description: To the Editor:

title: A Murchison Will Lead Falcon Oil and Gas
description: The Falcon Oil and Gas Company, a successful production and exploration company based in Odessa, Tex., said yesterday that it had named Spencer M. Murchison as president and chief executive.

title: Olive Ann Burns, 65, an Author Whose Illness Inspired Her Book
description: Olive Ann Burns, whose illness with lymphoma prompted her to write the 1984 novel ''Cold Sassy Tree,'' died on Wednesday. She was 65 years old and lived in Atlanta.

title: Ernst Barred From Taking New York Work for 45 Days
description: An administrative law judge has barred one of the world's largest accounting firms from accepting any new public audit work in the New York region for 45 days. The order, naming Ernst & Whinney, which has since merged with Arthur Young to form Ernst & Young, results from defective audits that the firm is said to have performed nearly 10 years ago for the United States Surgical Corporation in Norwalk, Conn.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the departure of Ralph McA. Ingersoll 2d from the United States newspaper business to run newspapers in Europe misidentifed the paper he operates in Ireland. It is The Irish Press, not The Dublin Press.

title: 2 Lanes to Close On F.D.R. Drive For Three Years
description: The traffic capacity of an 11-block section of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be choked off by one-third or more during roughly three years of repairs beginning later this month, New York State officials said yesterday.

title: Late-June Vehicle Sales Rose 12.5%
description: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks jumped 12.5 percent in late June, surprising analysts and raising hopes among auto executives that the industry had turned a corner after a nine-month slump.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   For Bush, Life on the Run Catches Up
description: You may find this hard to believe, but President Bush originally wanted to make a day trip out of his visit to London for the meeting of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Euthanasia Bid in Washington State
description: Nancy Wallace walked up to a pair of strangers on a street in downtown Seattle the other day and started talking about the emotional torture brought on by the slow death of her mother.

title: A Corporate Doctor Is Getting Fewer Calls
description: There was a time when Victor H. Palmieri was flying so high he would have balked if clients tried to call the shots. Now, he'd be grateful if they would simply call.

title: Finland May Let Soviet Jews Use Airport on Way to Israel
description: Soviet Jews could begin to fly to Israel next week from an airport in Finland, the Foreign Minister has said. The operation would make Finland the fourth major route for Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union, along with Hungary, Romania and Poland.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Chronicle
description: SPIKE LEE is going into retailing. On July 22, a day before his movie ''Mo' Better Blues'' opens, Spike's Joint will open in a brownstone in Brooklyn.

title: Hans-Rudolf Kurz, Military Historian, 75
description: Hans-Rudolf Kurz, a Swiss military historian who headed an international inquiry into the World War II record of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, died on Friday. He was 75 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. Kurz headed a commission of five historians that the Austrian Government named in 1987 to investigate accusations that Mr. Waldheim had links to Nazi war atrocities.

title: B. Traven's Secret Has Been Long Known
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Sound Is So Polluted It Faces Long-Term Damage, Scientists Say
description: Parts of Long Island Sound are so polluted that it faces severe long-term environmental damage, say scientists, government officials and conservation groups.

title: Ulster Negotiations Delayed As Dublin Considers Its Role
description: British and Irish officials said today that the unresolved question of when Dublin would enter proposed talks about returning a large degree of self-rule to Northern Ireland remained an obstacle to setting a date in the fall for beginning negotiations.

title: Prosecutor to Ask Probation For Two Christian Scientists
description: The prosecutor will recommend probation for two Christian Scientists found guilty of manslaughter in their son's death, a spokesman for the prosecutor said today. A lawyer for the parents said the judge has said she will not jail them.

title: French to Help Poles Build Hotels
description: Two French companies and a Polish concern signed an agreement to build 30 two-star hotels in Poland, the official news agency P.A.P. said.

title: Milton Gabel, Dentist, 83
description: Dr. Milton Gabel, a dentist who practiced in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 83. His daughter, Sukhreet, said he died of complications from prostate cancer.

title: 2 Barry Supporters Get New Bid to Attend Trial
description: A Federal appeals court today opened the way for two vocal supporters of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to attend his drug and perjury trial, from which they have been barred by the trial judge.

title: Pop/Jazz;   A Maverick Upholding Traditional Values
description: Merle Haggard has gone political again. More than 20 years after his hit song ''Okie From Muskogee'' made him one of the most outspoken tongue waggers in country music, Mr. Haggard, who is to perform tomorrow night at the Ritz with his 10-piece band, the Strangers, has decided to protest the protesters in a new song called ''Me and Crippled Soldiers.''

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Cuomo Requests Inquiry on Sale Of L.I. Raceway
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo asked the State Investigation Commission yesterday to investigate the purchase of Roosevelt Raceway with publicly assisted financing in 1984.

title: Raising Questions in 9 All-Stravinsky Concerts
description: ''I think of the Summergarden series not as a group of unrelated concerts but as a museum exhibition with nine related events,'' said Paul Zukofsky, the violinist and conductor who has been directing the Museum of Modern Art's free outdoor concerts since 1987. ''In the same way the museum will exhibit a painter's work in depth, these concerts let us explore different aspects of composers.''

title: John A. Ludlow, Broker, 95
description: John A. Ludlow, a New York broker and former governor of the American Stock Exchange, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Cedar Grove, N.J. He was 95 years old and lived in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: 12 Yards, 1 Swift Kick May Determine Final
description: No soccer goalkeeper wants to be judged on stopping penalty kicks from only 12 yards.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Barbara L. Rambo, a senior vice president, to manage its Northeast-Southeast institutional group in New York.

title: Market Place;   Ranking The Money Managers
description: MANY stock indexes hit record highs this year, but most money managers earned less in the market in the first six months than they would have earned with Treasury bills, according to CDA Investment Technologies.

title: Health Funds Post Strong Gains
description: With health and environmental funds leading the way, mutual stock funds turned in a strong performance in the second quarter of this year. But as a group general equity funds still did not perform as well as the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index.

title: Chronicle
description: How can PRESIDENT BUSH elbow a potential 1992 opponent, MARIO M. CUOMO, while keeping his distance from the very uphill campaign for Governor that PIERRE A. RINFRET is waging against Mr. Cuomo?

title: Chilmark Raises UJB Stake to 6.7%
description: The Chilmark Management Corporation has raised its stake in the UJB Financial Corporation to 6.7 percent from 5.2 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chilmark said the shares had been purchased for investment purposes only. UJB is a Princeton, N.J., banking company that owns United Jersey Bank.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about public access to the beach in Belmar, N.J., referred incorrectly to a former candidate for town office, Roy N. Colin. Mr. Colin ran for commissioner unsuccessfully in an election in which Mayor Maria Hernandez was recalled; Mr. Colin was not recalled.

title: Books of The Times;   An Appropriated Title, Revisionist Sentiments
description: Eminent Victorians

title: Lab Says Most Missing Equipment Is Found
description: The Lawrence Livermore Laboratory said Thursday that it has accounted for all but a fraction of the more $45 million in equipment that had been reported missing.

title: UAL Suspends Jet Purchase Talks
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said today that it had suspended negotiations for a large aircraft purchase at the request of the employee group trying to buy the company.

title: North Korean Exile Says Kim Staged Incident in 1950 War
description: A former North Korean ambassador to Moscow, now in exile here, says that the North Korean leader invented a border incident with the South to start the Korean War in June 1950.

title: PRAGUE ASSEMBLY RE-ELECTS HAVEL
description: Parliament re-elected Vaclav Havel as President today, completing the first phase of Czechoslovakia's transition from four decades of Communist rule back to a Western-style democracy.

title: ...And in U.S. Court, Spira Pleads Not Guilty
description: Howard Spira yesterday pleaded not guilty to charges that he tried to extort money from George Steinbrenner and that he threatened the Yankees' owner and Dave Winfield, the former Yankee outfielder. The scheduling of his trial was put off until July 23 because the judge assigned to the case has been a guest of Steinbrenner at Yankee games.

title: WESTERN LEADERS CALL FOR NEW NATO TO ASSURE SOVIETS
description: President Bush and other Western leaders opened a crucial summit conference today with calls for a reshaped NATO alliance that would both reassure the Soviet Union of the West's peaceful intentions and guard against a possible revival of Soviet expansionism.

title: Up and Down The Freight Elevators
description: Desperate for sympathy and understanding, George Steinbrenner had made himself available recently to any radio or television microphone within a million-mile radius of Yankee Stadium. But when 30 Rockefeller Plaza watchers arrived early yesterday for Commissioner Fay Vincent's inquiry concerning payments to Howard Spira for information discrediting Dave Winfield, the Yankees' principal owner was not sighted near the lobby elevators.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Vibes and Guitar

title: Preserving Old Values In an Africa That's New
description: Among the modern arts of Africa is film, and eight examples of modern African cinematography will be shown - one film at 4 P.M. and again at 6:30 every Saturday through Aug. 25 - at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street.

title: Youth, 14, Dies After Fireworks Explode in Can
description: A 14-year-old Bengali youth who had come to New York City a few months ago died yesterday, one day after he was hit by metal shards while watching firecrackers being set off at a Fourth of July block party sponsored by the Hell's Angels, the police said.

title: King's Behavior Not Unusual, Arum Testifies
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter who has had a longtime rivalry with Don King, gave testimony yesterday before a Federal Court jury that appeared to support King.

title: Review/Art;   Alice Aycock's Mighty Sculptures
description: For the last three years, visitors to the Storm King Art Center here have been able to look across a broad field studded with giant steel sculptures by Mark di Suvero and see the white silhouette of Alice Aycock's ''Three-Fold Manifestation II.''

title: Judge Refuses to Bar Group From Meeting in U.S. Forest
description: A Federal district judge today rejected a legal foundation's request that he bar the environmental group Earth First from holding its annual meeting in a national forest in Montana next week.

title: Serbia Suspends Government of Albanian Region
description: The Parliament of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia today suspended the Assembly and the Executive Council of the Kosovo region, which has a 90 percent ethnic Albanian population and has been the scene of ethnic disorders.

title: Pryor to Be Tested
description: Aaron Pryor will have an eye examination by a New York Athletic Commission doctor today to determine if can resume fighting in the state.

title: How Campus Separatism Can Begin to End;   The Road Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Dozens Arrested in Miami at Haitian Protest
description: Police officers in riot gear arrested about 50 people at a demonstration today by Haitian-Americans at a shopping center where they said a Haitian immigrant was beaten by Hispanic employees last week.

title: Judge Limits Fernandez Role In Hiring of Superintendents
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez was handed his first significant setback yesterday when a state judge in Queens declared that the Chancellor may not interfere in the selection of district superintendents by New York City's 32 community school boards.

title: Reckitt & Colman Reassigns Brands
description: Days after it completed most of its purchase of the Boyle-Midway division of American Home Products, Reckitt & Colman Inc. said yesterday that it would reassign $40 million in advertising for the division's brands.

title: Work Wear Deal
description: G & K Services Inc. said it had signed an agreement to purchase the stock of the Work Wear Corporation of Canada Ltd. for about $68 million in cash and the repayment of $12 million in long-term debt. Work Wear is Canada's largest uniform leasing company with revenues of about $62 million in 1989. It is an indirect subsidiary of the Work Wear Corporation, a leading American uniform manufacturer owned principally by Paine Webber Capital Inc.

title: Credit Card Fraud Charged
description: Visa International and Mastercard International filed a multimillion-dollar fraud lawsuit today contending that a vast telemarketing scheme with nationwide tentacles recruited small companies to launder credit card charges.

title: Schoeller Closes Yarn Plant in U.S.
description: Schoeller Inc.'s plant here will close immediately, putting about 240 people out of work, the Switzerland-based company announced. The company's president, Allen Booth, said from the United States headquarters in Hackensack, N.J., that the decision to close the acrylic yarn-spinning plant had been influenced by low overseas labor costs and recent domestic fashion changes that favor natural fibers.

title: Rite Aid Badgering Claimed
description: The Rite Aid Corporation, the drugstore chain that was charged, along with its president, with trying to bribe an Ohio state pharmacy official, was singled out and badgered by state regulators, the company's lawyer asserted before a jury today.

title: Los Angeles Journal;   Brevity Follows Marathon In Retrial
description: The McMartin Preschool child-molesting case, which produced the longest criminal trial in American history, is expected to go to a jury next week for the second time. Its dimensions have so outgrown its substance that longtime observers now sound like baseball fans: they talk statistics.

title: Review/Film;   The Jetsons In a Future Steeped In the Past
description: Nothing fades faster than the future, or at least our fanciful notions of what the future ought to be. And ''Jetsons: The Movie,'' a full-length animated version of the 1962 television show that was conceived by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera as ''the flip side of the Flintstones'' (in Mr. Hanna's words), has faded quite a bit.

title: How Campus Separatism Can Begin to End
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rejects A 'Poison Pill'
description: The Delaware Chancery Court ruled today that National Intergroup Inc., a beleaguered company whose businesses include metals, retail stores and wholesale drug distribution, must submit its amended shareholder rights, or ''poison pill,'' plan to a shareholder vote before it can be declared effective.

title: To Safeguard Taxpayers on S & L's
description: The Government has sold 155 failed savings and loan associations to new owners in the past three months. That's three times what it sold in the preceding seven months. The speedup is a good sign; the Administration is at last getting a grip on this monster task. But it remains under heavy obligation to collar the crooks who made off with the money, and guard the taxpayers' interest.

title: Sidney Fread, 74, Dies; A Corporate Executive
description: Sidney Fread, an executive in New York for several companies, died last Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 74 years old and lived in Phoenix. His family said he had died of lung cancer.

title: Three Howard Beach Retrials Are Scheduled for Aug. 28
description: Justice Thomas A. Demakos of State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday scheduled Aug. 28 for the retrials of three defendants in the 1986 Howard Beach racial-attack case.

title: Frances Ward Harrington, Editor, 86
description: Frances Ward Harrington, a retired magazine editor, died on Wednesday at Caleb Hitchcock Medical Center in Bloomfield, Conn. She was 86 years old and lived in Duncaster, a retirement community in Bloomfield.

title: Garrison Stuns Graf in Wimbledon Semifinal
description: The defending champion, Steffi Graf, no longer invincible in her own eyes or in those of the players waiting in line to dethrone her, was upset today, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, by Zina Garrison of Houston in the semifinals at Wimbledon.

title: Deadlock Cited In Futures Case
description: A jury considering the fate of the first traders to be tried in the Government's investigation of the world's largest futures exchanges said today that it had reached a partial verdict but was deadlocked on the remaining charges.

title: Strike Falters in Norway
description: Wildcat strikes on Norway's North Sea oil and gas platforms began to break down after workers on one of the most important fields decided to go back to work.

title: Gorbachev Appears Certain of Election To Keep Party Post
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev appeared today to have staked an unassailable claim to go on heading the Soviet Communist Party as delegates to the 28th Congress quarreled over the future of Communism, which was described by one delegate as ''sick.''

title: No Headline
description: Tables Delayed

title: Ex-Union Official Convicted of Racketeering
description: A former carpenters union official in New York City who was the central figure in an assault case against John Gotti has been convicted of labor racketeering and sentenced to a prison term of one to three years.

title: LAW: At the Bar;   The lawyer whose business card was so effective that it could lead to unwanted litigation.
description: Even the most innocuous paraphernalia of a lawyer, it seems, can be the stuff of litigation. Along with burning flags and the right to die, the United States Supreme Court recently ruled on the propriety of a lawyer's letterhead, the latest of several cases it has considered on lawyer advertising.

title: Review/Art;   The Group Show as Crystal Ball
description: THE group exhibition, that end-of-season ritual, is upon us, and with it comes the opportunity to take the art world's pulse. This year, these shows seem to be everywhere, uptown and down, with something to offer nearly every esthetic palate. Many of them are simply reprises of each gallery's stable of artists, but several exhibitions in SoHo, of which six are reviewed here, concentrate on emerging or little-known artists and offer some signs of things to come.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bank of Montreal said it had com-pleted the estimated $23 million (Canadian), or $19.8 million (United States), sale of its 20 percent stake in Banque Transatlantique, a French bank, to the bank's largest shareholder, Credit Industriel et Commercial de Paris.

title: Kuwait Stance on OPEC
description: Kuwait's new oil minister, Rashid Salim al-Ameeri, ended talks today in Algiers with OPEC colleagues and said his nation was cutting excess output and could be flexible on its demands for a bigger quota.

title:
Expensive Properties;

Expanding the Choices In Million-Dollar Homes
description: LEAD: In the luxury housing market of Westchester County, million-dollar residences are frequently built on speculation and sold to buyers as is. But at the Pinnacle, the colony of 16 expensive houses that Kenneth Rubinstein is developing near Purchase, N.Y., buyers are being offered the chance to select a home at the blueprint stage and to make design changes.

title: Pickens to Add To Koito Stake
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who has been rebuffed in his attempts to get seats on the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company, said on Wednesday that he planned to increase his stake in the Japanese auto parts supplier.

title: Dow Drops 32.42 Points, To 2,879.21
description: In a matter of hours yesterday, stocks gave up much of what they had gained in the last five sessions.

title: Growth Hormone and the Drive for a More Youthful State
description: For the last 18 months or so Frederick McCullough has been like Popeye, or Tony the Tiger, or some other cartoon character with hyperbolic energy: shinnying up to the roof to put new concrete around the chimney, washing the aluminum siding around the house, and mowing and re-mowing the lawn.

title: Washington at Work;   Jim Sasser, Reluctant Budget Chief Who Cornered President on Taxes
description: Senator Jim Sasser has detested math since grade school. He says he has no taste for intricate things, unless that means tinkering with the engine of a rust-coated 1967 Jaguar, now sidelined in the Senate garage, that he has been trying to fix up for years.

title: Joseph A. LaPlante, Law Professor, 67
description: Joseph A. LaPlante, an author and a professor emeritus at the University of Connecticut School of Law, died on Sunday at his home in West Hartford. He was 67 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Friday

title: Hospitals Battling Specialists Over Revenues From Testing
description: Squeezed by Government and employer efforts to reduce costs, many hospitals are battling with specialist physicians over the revenues generated by advanced testing equipment and life-support machines. Some of the fights over these lucrative procedures are ending up in court.

title: Yanks Must Pay $225,000 For Winfield Tampering
description: The Yankees were ordered yesterday to pay $200,000 to the California Angels and were fined $25,000 by Commissioner Fay Vincent, who ruled that George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, had tampered with Dave Winfield after the outfielder was traded to the Angels.

title: Fernandez Rebuffs Testing Agency, Halting an Exam
description: The Board of Examiners, the agency that tests New York City's teachers and other school system employees for licenses, has been blocked by the Schools Chancellor from completing a test that would have enabled some employees to become supervisors.

title: TV Weekend;   An Evening of Series, With Art, Love and War
description: Series on Channel 13 are beginning and ending in unusual profusion on Sunday.

title: The Rule of Jean Renoir's Game: Art Is Life
description: ANNA MAGNANI seems a bit too old, a bit too plump and awfully tired as she begins her role as a commedia dell'arte actress in ''The Golden Coach,'' Jean Renoir's unlikely 1952 film about an 18th-century Italian troupe performing in Peru. Magnani's character, Camilla, has an ingenue's innocence and effortless charm, but she is played by a middle-aged woman who seems uncomfortably stuffed into a funny, harlequin-patterned dress. Renoir recalled in his autobiography that after spending half the night in clubs, Magnani would arrive on the set hours late, with heavy bags under her eyes, unable to remember her lines. He had to coax her into facing the cameras, but once he did, within minutes she looked younger and became Camilla: a woman who gains the love of an actor, a matador and the viceroy, only to find herself alone on stage at the end of the film.

title: People
description: * James Caporimo, an art director at Waring & LaRosa, has been promoted to senior vice president, creative.

title: Ex-GTE Colleagues Now at FPL Group
description: James L. Broadhead and Stephen E. Frank, former colleagues at the GTE Corporation, will be working together again at the parent of the Florida Power and Light Company.

title: KEY RATES
San Francisco's Mayor Ousts Homeless Camp
description: After months of charges that he was waffling on the matter, Mayor Art Agnos has ordered the police to break up a sprawling encampment of homeless people just outside City Hall.

title: Licensing Panel Rebuffed
description: The Board of Examiners, which tests New York City's teachers, has been blocked by the Schools Chancellor from giving a test that would have enabled some employees to become supervisors. Page B1.

title: Mattingly Day-to-Day
description: Don Mattingly, who suffered back spasms Monday in Kansas City, Mo., underwent more treatment yesterday at Yankee Stadium and was examined by the team physician, Dr. Stewart Hershon. His condition was listed as day-to-day. The team will decide today whether he will play in tonight's doubleheader against Minnesota.

title: At the Movies
description: Figgis in Binghamton

title: Fairs And Festivals
description: Today

title: Fire Out of Control in Alaska
description: A raging fire today forced residents of a small town to abandon their homes, burned a Coast Guard station and other buildings, and blocked the Alaska Highway, the main road into the state.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds decreased $2.24 billion, to $382.70 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds decreased by $222.8 million, to $91.61 billion. The assets of the 250 general-purpose funds were down by $723.9 million, to $133.21 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $1.29 billion, to $157.88 billion, the institute said.

title: Liberian Troops Reported to Loot Capital Shops as Rebels Advance
description: Troops looted shops today as rebels tightened their stranglehold on the Liberian capital and President Samuel K. Doe clung to power.

title: Sundstrand Sees Drop in Earnings
description: The Sundstrand Corporation said it expected second-quarter earnings to be down about $7 million because of losses from its Brazilian operation. In May, when business in Brazil almost came to a halt because of the Government's anti-inflation program, Sundstrand's Brazilian operation reduced its work force of 429 by 30 percent, to 318.

title: Olongapo Journal;   Sailors Can't Paint the Town, So Sin Trade Pales
description: In this sleazy, honky-tonk town, which grew up out of the huge Subic Bay Naval Base to service it, the effect of new threats by Communist insurgents to kill Americans can be measured in beer.

title: Review/Television;   West Africa's Echoes in New Orleans
description: America's music has been forged as much in ghettos and rural backwaters as in the concert hall, and the folklorist Alan Lomax has been bringing it to outsiders since the 1930's. In recent years, he has set out with a video crew, and the results can be seen on ''American Patchwork,'' a PBS series that begins this weekend. (In New York it can be seen on Channel 13, Sunday at 7 P.M., and on Channel 31, next Friday at 9 P.M. ) In ''Jazz Parades: Feet Don't Fail Me Now,'' the first installment of ''American Patchwork,'' Mr. Lomax looks beneath the jaunty surface of New Orleans street parades and traditional jazz. He finds not just joyous music, but echoes of West African traditions and local history, including the complex racial tensions between blacks and Creoles and whites, transformed into strutting rhythms, flamboyant costumes and high-stepping dances.

title: Justice Department Files Antitrust Suit Against Architects
description: The Justice Department filed a suit today against the American Institute of Architects contending that the professional group unreasonably restrained price competition.

title: Sketch Out on Dart Attacker
description: A composite sketch of the man who is said to be shooting darts at women in Manhattan was released yesterday by the police.

title: Cut the Custodians Down to Size
description: For years, it's been difficult to tell who's in charge of New York City's schools: the custodians, who manage day-to-day maintenance of the buildings, or the Board of Education. What is clear is that the custodians have too much power.

title: 4 U.S. Crews Gain at Henley; Harvard Freshmen Defeated
description: Four of the six eight-oared crews from the United States entered in the Thames Challenge Cup advanced today at the 151st Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Dinkins and Holtzman Contributors Handling City Bonds
description: Five investment concerns were recently selected to be underwriters for $6 billion in New York City bonds, and it now turns out, to no one's great surprise, that all five were major contributors to the campaigns last year of Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.

title: Arts Panel Seeks Review For Four Rejected Grants
description: The theater panel of the National Endowment for the Arts has denounced the agency's rejection of 4 of 18 grant recommendations and will urge a reconsideration of the decision, the panel's chairman, Philip Arnoult, said yesterday.

title: Ozone Action by Japan
description: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry said on Wednesday that it was increasing financial help to industries that must limit the use of substances that damage the earth's ozone layer. Ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons are to be phased out by the year 2000 and methyl chloroform by 2005 under an international agreement known as the Montreal Protocol. To meet these deadlines, the ministry will provide low-interest loans and tax incentives to companies that make efforts to recycle and re-use the substances, a ministry official said.

title: Major League Action Without Bats or Balls
description: Baseball squeezed in some games between hearings yesterday. But there was lots of action off the field.

title: What's a Doctor of Law but Hyperbole Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns;   For Some People, Independence Is a Daily Worry
description: The day before Independence Day, Rick Brenner was as independent as ever, leaving the group home at dawn to catch the 6:32 train into the city for his clerical job at the American Petroleum Institute. He's been working there 15.8 years, makes $16,883.

title: Restaurants
description: Arqua

title: Railroad Collision Injures 6
description: An Amtrak train collided with a tractor-trailer rig today at a railraod crossing, injuring six people, including the engineer. The New York-bound train, the Crescent, remained upright, and only the engine and the first set of wheels on the second of eight cars derailed. The accident occurred at a crossing off Mississippi Route 11 shortly before 11 A.M.

title: Chronicle
description: When only 37 people showed up on the first day of a conference to hear leading French Socialists speak, the conference chairman, OLIVIER STIRN, France's Minister of Tourism, leaped into action. On the second day, as former Prime Ministers PIERRE MAUROY and LAURENT FABIUS and Defense Minister JEAN-PIERRE CHEVENEMENT were about to speak, an enthusiastic crowd suddenly appeared.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This century has been marked by war and suffering on an unparalleled scale.

title: 2 Die, 600 Seized in Britain In Riots Over Soccer Defeat
description: Moments after West Germany squeaked past England in Turin, Italy, to advance to the final of the World Cup soccer tournament, people spilled out of pubs and parties throughout England on Wednesday and went on rampages that ended with two deaths and 600 arrests.

title: 5 Paris Museums Shut After Art Thefts
description: Five Paris museums were closed and security was tightened at the Louvre today after three daring art thefts.

title: Review/Film;   A Cat That Can Show People's True Colors
description: Whimsy and politics make extremely strange bedfellows, at least in ''The Cassandra Cat.'' This 27-year-old political allegory from Czechoslovakia, opening today at the Public Theater, is the story of a bespectacled cat who brings chaos to a small town when his glasses are removed. Without those blinders, people literally show their true colors. The unfaithful turn yellow, thieves are gray, lovers turn red and liars are purple.

title: Mitch Snyder, 46, Advocate of Homeless
description: Mitch Snyder, who became a national figure in giving the movement in support of homeless people a public voice and face throughout the 1980's, was found hanged today in an apparent suicide.

title: Detroit Signs Chevrier
description: The Detroit Red Wings announced that they have signed the free-agent goaltender Alain Chevrier, who spent last season with the Chicago Blackhawks and the Pittsburgh Penguins. Chevrier, 29 years old, was signed to a one-year contract, said General Manager Jimmy Devellano.(AP)

title: Israeli Laborites Defer Action on Party Chief
description: The Labor Party's leadership bureau refused to take any position today on Labor's bruising contest for party leadership and left the party leader, Shimon Peres, and his challenger, Yitzhak Rabin, to continue quarreling for three more weeks.

title: New York Rainy Days Mean Using Headlights
description: Motorists will have to turn on their headlights whenever it rains or snows, under a measure signed into law today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The new law, which takes effect on Jan. 1, is intended mostly to help drivers see other cars in bad weather.

title: Diner's Journal
description: El Dorado Petit

title: Burmese Military Slow In Handing Over Power
description: It took the military government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, over a month to count the votes in the stunning election of May 27, in which the main opposition party won more than 80 percent of the seats.

title: Trouble Will Follow Bible-Club Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Cobblestones to Make A Comeback in SoHo
description: The historic sections of a pair of SoHo streets will take on a purer 19th-century look during the next two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a New Jersey Supreme Court order for two eating clubs at Princeton University to admit women misidentified Sally Frank, the alumna who sued the clubs 11 years ago. She is a professor at New York Law School, not at New York University Law School.

title: Third Witness Says Barry Used Cocaine
description: A third witness testified today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial that she had seen him use cocaine.

title: Auctions
description: $15 Million Cabinet

title: 9 Men Out, Suspended for Brawling
description: In a sweeping mass suspension for an on-the-field brawl, Bobby Brown, the president of the American League, yesterday suspended four Seattle Mariners, four Milwaukee Brewers and Manager Tom Trebelhorn of Milwaukee for their actions in a 28-minute fight between the teams last Saturday night in Seattle.

title: Dollar Ends Mostly Higher In a Slow Trading Session
description: The dollar closed mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday in light and uneventful trading.

title: Chronicle
description: Gene Hackman may have narrowly avoided a heart attack when he checked into a hospital in Portland, Ore., complaining of chest pains. ''We think we got him just in the nick of time,'' DR. HERBERT SEMLER said after he treated the actor for partial blockage of a coronary blood vessel at St. Vincent Hospital and Medical Center.

title: Review/Photography;   Tracing Photojournalism to Define It
description: Despite their enormous impact on everyday life, the images that appear in newspapers and magazines remain relatively unexamined. Even the definition of photojournalism is still subject to debate. Does photojournalism have an esthetic and tradition of its own, or is it merely a term for pictures that are reproduced and seen by a large and largely uncritical public?

title: Albanian Dissidents Renew Rush on Foreign Embassies
description: Hundreds of Albanians flocked to foreign embassies in Tirana today in a new rush to flee Europe's last Stalinist state and the Albanian Ambassador to Italy said his Government would allow refugees who had committed no crime to emigrate.

title: America's Future
description: Children were the theme of the International Design Conference in Aspen this year. For a week the participants heard architects, designers, teachers, psychologists and others talk about the needs of children. And all about, their own children played on giant balls, painted, built constructions and generally demonstrated the wonders of youthful imagination.

title: Debt Outlook For Ecuador
description: Ecuador's central bank said on Wednesday that $437 million of the country's $11.2 billion foreign debt might be eligible for relief under President Bush's recent proposals to relieve Latin America's debt burden.

title: After NATO: Concert of Europe
description: Despite President Bush's invitation to Mikhail Gorbachev to attend a future NATO meeting, the United States and the Soviet Union are miles apart on how to construct a new security order in Europe. Washington wants to hold on to NATO and bring a unified Germany into the Western alliance. Moscow wants a collective security system in which the 35 members of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe would jointly build a new European order.

title: Easy Goer Nears Stride in Battle to Regain Form
description: Easy Goer's 3 3/4-length victory in the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park on Wednesday was not just proof that he is back to where he was in his prime last season. It was also the same kind of experience that set him up for the best performance of his career a year ago.

title: Steinbrenner Has Day In Baseball's Court . . .
description: George Steinbrenner was the lone witness during a daylong hearing before Fay Vincent yesterday. The baseball commissioner, seeking more information from the Yankees owner about his activities, will hold a second session today.

title: Woman Leaps, Halting 4 Trains on a Hot Day
description: About 4,000 sweltering passengers were stranded for an hour inside subway cars on the West Side of Manhattan yesterday morning after a woman jumped to the tracks from between two cars of an uptown No. 1 train, the transit police said.

title: Phil Boggs, 40, Diving Champion Who Won Olympic Gold Medal
description: Phil Boggs, who dominated United States diving competition during the 1970's, died on Wednesday. He was 40 years old.

title: Thompson, Free Agent, Goes to Nuggets' Camp
description: A week after watching his dream of being drafted into the National Basketball Association go unfulfilled, the former Syracuse guard Stevie Thompson is headed for a tryout with the Denver Nuggets at their free-agent camp later this month.

title: Economic Scene;   The Huge Costs Of German Unity
description: WEST GERMANY has now won its friendly takeover bid of East Germany, gaining not only a lot of real estate and 16 million more Germans, including 10 million workers, but also a host of decrepit factories, rundown roads and other poor public facilities.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: Jackson to Run For Lobby Post In Washington
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson announced today that he would run for the office of ''statehood senator'' from the District of Columbia, a new post created by the city government to lobby Congress for statehood.

title: White House Spurns Expansion Of Nation's Anti-Poverty Efforts
description: After considering a variety of ambitious options, the Bush Administration has decided against proposing any major new program or strategy to combat poverty at this time, Administration officials said today.

title: Ducking the Constitution
description: At the end of its term last week the Supreme Court looked the Constitution right in the eye - and blinked at its meaning. The Court ruled that the Sixth Amendment's confrontation clause doesn't mean what it seems so clearly to say. That's the clause that says, ''In all criminal prosecutions the accused shall enjoy the right . . . to be confronted with the witnesses against him.''

title: Treasury Prices Fall in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose slightly in fairly light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for the release this morning of June employment data.

title: Not Quite the Fountain of Youth
description: The report that injections of synthetic human growth hormone seem to reverse some of the effects of aging is much to be welcomed. Previous recipes for stalling age included regular, strenuous exercise and going on a near-starvation diet. But there are a few catches before couch potatoes and epicures can set their hopes high.

title: Suspect Shot in Robbery Attempt at Jewelry Store
description: A police officer eating lunch in the back room of a midtown jewelry store shot and critically wounded one of about eight men who tried to rob the store yesterday, the police said.

title: Review/Jazz;   Grizzled Tone, Sure Logic
description: The saxophonist Dewey Redman presented a relaxed first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, mixing be-bop, a standard and an original tune. Mr. Redman, who is known for his collaborations with the saxophonist Ornette Coleman, is a spare improviser, and in his hands solos unfold surely, phrase by phrase, pushed along by his slightly grizzled tone and steady logic.

title: Medicare Cleared in Hospital Closings
description: Most of the 140 rural hospitals around the nation that shut down from 1985 through 1988 had been losing money because of high operating costs rather than inadequate government subsidies, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

title: Thrift Office Will Open Its Cases
description: In a sharp policy reversal, Bush Administration regulators said today that enforcement proceedings regarding failed savings and loans would be open to the public. They inaugurated the policy by detailing charges in four pending cases, including the one involving Neil M. Bush, the President's son.

title: Foreman Bout Set
description: George Foreman, hoping to earn a shot at the heavyweight title, will continue his comeback against Ken Lakusta, the Canadian champion, on July 31 in Edmonton, Alberta.

title: INSIDE
description: Jackson Seeks a Post

title: Upset Victory Is the Product of Hard-Won Confidence
description: Zina Garrison's story is one of humble beginnings, painful transitions, and misplaced self-esteem, almost the stuff of soap opera.

title: Fredrika Blair-Hastings, Author, 71
description: Fredrika Blair-Hastings, author of a 1986 biography of the dancer Isadora Duncan, died on July 1. She was 71 years old and lived in Carmel, Calif.

title: Sherman Act's 100 Years Of Protecting Competition
description: The Sherman Antitrust Act, which this year marks its centennial, has had a long history of both vigorous enforcement and virtual oblivion. In recent years it has not been as widely used by the Government to challenge many kinds of business agreements once viewed as improper.

title: Court Clears Sale Of Amdura Unit
description: The Amdura Corporation said the United States District Court had approved the sale of the assets of the company's Coast-to-Coast Stores subsidiary to the Servistar Corporation. Amdura said it expects the sale to close within 35 days.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;

Chartwell Purchases Additional Avon Stake
description: LEAD: A partnership led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis-based corporate raider, and the Amway Corporation said yesterday that it had sold a large block of the common stock of Avon Products Inc. to the investment group Chartwell Associates L.P.

title: IRAN'S CHIEF LINKS AID TO BETTER TIES
description: In what appeared to be a forceful appeal for economic and humanitarian aid from the West, President Hashemi Rafsanjani was quoted today as saying there was a direct tie between foreign aid and improved relations with his Government.

title: Dispute Over Seal Killings Divides South Africans
