description: A bitter environmental controversy has erupted in South Africa over the Government's plan to let a company from Taiwan kill up to 30,500 Cape fur seals each year along the windswept Atlantic coastline.

title: Review/Dance;   Tango-Based Ballet From Johan Renvall
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has never seemed quite the right place for the classical ballet, though certainly it has presented some stellar ballet attractions over its 58 seasons. For one thing, the stage of the Ted Shawn Theater here is a little small for bravura ballet dancing. And the festival has a long and vivid modern dance history. Still, it was clear from the whoops and cheers that greeted Johan Renvall and Stars of American Ballet on Tuesday night that there is always room for a little ballet razzle-dazzle. And the ensemble and its program do fit tidily into the Pillow's program of encouraging things new.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: On Stage
description: A London-Pittsburgh Project

title: East German Auto Plant on the Brink
description: The putt-putting, pollution-spewing, low-power Trabant automobile has long been the butt of jokes, including bumper stickers that say, ''Zero to 60 in 15 minutes.''

title: Accounts
description: * Yamaha Motor Corporation, to Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific, for its RIVA motor scooter.

title: Soviet Debate: Do Party Cells Have a Place?
description: From the press gallery of the cavernous Kremlin hall where the Communist Party is holding its 28th congress, it is clear that this is not an ordinary political convention.

title: McDonnell Raises MD-80 Deliveries
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had increased deliveries of its MD-80 aircraft in the second quarter to 34 planes, up from 24 in the corresponding period last year. The increase raised MD-80 deliveries for the first six months to 59, a company record, said John Thom, a spokesman for McDonnell's Douglas Aircraft unit in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Bond Gives Up on Cup
description: Alan Bond, the Australian financier whose companies have debts of more than $4 billion, has ended his 17-year association with the America's Cup, saying he will not be involved in the 1992 challenge off San Diego.

title: A Soprano at Caramoor
description: Heidi Grant is to be the soprano soloist with the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble in Bach's Cantata No. 209 at 9 tonight in the Venetian Theater at Caramoor, on Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. The all-Bach program also includes the First and Third Orchestral Suites, and the Concerto in D minor for Two Violins. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Cameroonian's Makassi Sam Fan Thomas, Kilimanjaro, 531 West 19th Street (627-2333). Sam Fan Thomas, from Cameroon, sings music called makassi that has all of French-speaking Africa dancing, with three chords and a lilting beat that sets hips swaying. The last time Mr. Thomas appeared in New York, he had a Paris-based band that was irresistible; this time, with musicians from Cameroon, he may be even better. Tomorrow at about 11:30 P.M.; admission is $15.

title: Welch's 10-Game Streak Is Stopped
description: Teddy Higuera allowed two hits in seven innings and Gary Sheffield and Greg Brock each hit home runs today as the Milwaukee Brewers ended Bob Welch's streak of 10 consecutive victories and beat the Oakland Athletics, 4-3.

title: Raising Taxes Will Strengthen Bush
description: Democrats and many Republicans believe that President Bush's endorsement of higher taxes will hurt him politically. But they ignore the four major benefits that a successful resolution of the U.S. budget problem would provide.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Madison Ave. Turns an Ear To Rap Music
description: YO, Madison Avenue!

title: Another Victim of Ohio Flood
description: The police today recovered a body believed to be that of a 26th person killed by the flash flood that ravaged this eastern Ohio village last month. Discovery of the body, which was found on the shore of the Ohio River, left as many as seven people still unaccounted for. The exact figure is uncertain because of difficulties in obtaining a firm count on the number of people who lived in the area on the day of the flood.

title: The Waterloo Festival
description: Gerard Schwarz is to conduct the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in Mussorgsky's ''Night on Bald Mountain,'' David Diamond's Symphony No. 3 and Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow in the opening concert of the Waterloo Festival at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J., at Exit 25 on Route 80. Alexander Toradze is to be the soloist in the Rachmaninoff. Tickets are $12.75 to $20. Information: 307-7171 or (201) 507-8900.

title: 3 More Kenyans Seized Calling for Opposition
description: The authorities today detained three more prominent Kenyans linked to recent calls for a legalized opposition in this one-party state, including the son of a former vice president and two lawyers.

title: World Bank Lending Drops
description: Lending by the World Bank, the biggest source of aid to the third world, has declined in the last 12 months for the first time since 1985, the bank reported today.

title: A Democratic Protection Racket
description: Congress may be on the verge of missing a historic opportunity to clean up this country's campaign laws - laws that give near-ironclad protection to incumbents in the House, promote the role of special interests over individual citizens and hide the amount of money that these special interests funnel into national campaigns.

title: Wildfires Still Raging in Alaska, Still Threatening Crossroads Town
description: Wildfires charred about 400 square miles of forests and tundra by today, and still threatened the town of Tok, where firefighters kept up a house-to-house battle against wind-driven flames.

title: Liberian Foes Clash Near Doe Mansion
description: Rebel forces attacked the port of Monrovia today and fought a battle less than two miles from the executive mansion where President Samuel K. Doe is trying to stay in power.

title: Jean Dabry, French Navigator, 89
description: Jean Dabry, navigator for Jean Mermoz on several of the French pilot's pioneering flights in the 1930's, died on Wednesday. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. On May 12, 1930, Mr. Dabry and Mr. Mermoz completed the first nonstop flight between Africa and South America, crossing the South Atlantic from Senegal to Brazil in 21 hours and 14 minutes. Four years later, they completed the first commercial flight between Paris and Buenos Aires.

title: Chinese Dissident Criticizes U.S. on Human Rights
description: Fang Lizhi, China's leading dissident, said in an interview broadcast tonight that the United States had a ''double standard'' for human rights that was tougher on the Soviet Union than on China.

title: Store's Sign Leads To Anti-Bias Protests
description: The owner of a pharmacy posted a sign reading, ''The black Americans from the manor are not welcome here - they are thieves,'' on Tuesday, and protesters have been gathering outside the store.

title: Twins Plead Innocent In Glen Ridge Case
description: The former co-captains of the Glen Ridge High School football team have pleaded innocent to sexually assaulting a mentally handicapped girl more than a year ago.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The National Press Club in Washington has received a $1 million endowment to improve its library. The money was given, after a year of negotiation, by ERIC FRIEDHEIM, the founder and editor in chief of The Travel Agent, a travel industry publication. Mr. Friedheim, 80 years old, has been a club member since 1934.

title: Christian Scientists Are Given Probation for Death of Child
description: A judge here handed down a sentence of 10 years' probation today to two Christian Scientists convicted of manslaughter in the death of their 2-year-old son. As a condition of the probation, the parents must take their three other children to a pediatrician for regular examinations.

title: Paper, Once Written Off, Keeps a Place in the Office
description: A decade ago, computer companies trumpeted the arrival of the ''paperless office.'' It would be a workplace where memos and reports would be instantly distributed over electronic networks to be read on computer screens around the world, and where high-capacity memory disks would replace file cabinets.

title: Passive Smoking Study Refused to Be Taken as the Last Word
description: To the Editor:

title: BAT Strikes Back
description: I am the Hubble telescope. I was destined to see the outermost edge of the universe. Much big talk accompanied my creation.

title: Digital to Highlight Midrange Computers
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation will open its annual DEC World computer trade show Monday in Boston with a range of computer hardware and network announcements aimed at strengthening the computer maker's line of proprietary midrange computers.

title: Control Data Acts To Sell VTC Unit
description: The Control Data Corporation is again seeking buyers for VTC Inc., its 400-employee semiconductor maker in Bloomington. Contol Data reached an agreement in the spring to sell the unit to Seattle Silicon of Bellevue, Wash., for an undisclosed amount, but delays in arranging financing have cost Seattle Silicon its exclusive purchase rights. VTC is Control Data's last big money-losing operation. Control Data, also based in Bloomington, created $100 million in reserves last year to compensate for the losses it expects to incur on the sale.

title: Henry Allen Lord Mali, Executive, 58
description: Henry Allen Lord Mali, a New York textile executive, died on Thursday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan and Norfolk, Conn. He died of complications from leukemia, his family said.

title: William McCarthy, 73, Retired Police Official
description: Willliam McCarthy, a former First Deputy Commissioner of the New York Police Department, died on Thursday at the hospice of the Colonial Palms Nursing Home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Pompano Beach.

title: Fernandez Plans to Appeal Decision on Superintendents
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday that he would appeal a State Supreme Court decision that limits his authority in the hiring of school district superintendents.

title: Standard-Parts Debate Clouds Choices for Users of Cable TV
description: Consumers' easy access to cable television's wide range of extra programs is being impeded by the inability of cable operators and television manufacturers to agree on standardized equipment.

title: Fixed Mortgages Slip
description: Fixed-rate home mortgage rates averaged 10.06 percent this week, down from 10.15 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.46 percent this week, up from 8.45 percent the week before.

title: British Air Purchasing Boeing 747's
description: British Airways P.L.C. placed an order today for Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets, Rolls-Royce engines and components that could ultimately be worth more than $8 billion.

title: Tunis Journal;   In a Jobless Land, the Way Up Means a Visa Out
description: By the time the steel gate in the French Embassy wall opened early in the afternoon, the line of Tunisians seeking visas to visit their former colonial power stretched and snaked around a corner and down a street, where Saida Khemeiri let it be known that she had beaten the system.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Excerpts From Speech by Yeltsin Before 28th Party Congress
description: The following excerpts are from a speech before the Communist Party congress by Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic and a leader of the congress's insurgent minority, as translated by The New York Times.

title: Byron Rubenstein, 74, Rabbi in Connecticut
description: Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein, leader of the congregation at Temple Israel in Westport, Conn., for 23 years before he retired in 1982, died on Thursday at Mediplex of Westport. He was 74 years old and lived in Westport.

title: Morris Stifles Royals With One-Hit Shutout
description: Jack Morris, retiring the last 25 batters, pitched a one-hitter tonight and Cecil Fielder hit his 28th home run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Kansas City Royals, 4-0.

title: Ex-Savings Chief Curbed
description: A Federal judge ordered Thomas Spiegel, the former head of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, to post a $1 million bond today and placed severe restrictions on his financial movements while ruling on the legality of a Government case against Mr. Spiegel, a Government attorney said.

title: Japan Chain Buys U.S. Beef Processor
description: The Kyotaru Company, a leading Japanese restaurant chain, has bought Best Western Foods Inc. for $41.5 million. Masakazu Yoda, a Kyotaru spokesman, said the purchase of Best Western Foods, a Los Angeles beef-processing company, was part of a strategy to enter the processed-beef supply field.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Shopping for CD's
description: Yields on bank certificates of deposit rose briefly in May but have slipped gradually since, and rate analysts expect them to move lower through most of 1990. Investors may want to lock in current interest rates. Certificates of deposit are as safe as Treasury securities, while requiring far smaller minimum investments. Rate changes run in cycles as long as two and a half years; the present down cycle is in its 14th month, making short-term certificates the best buys. The table below shows the current national averages. In some parts of the country, sharp-eyed consumers can do better. Some institutions, after merging with or acquiring troubled savings and loan associations, are offering bonus rates to lure or retain depositors; these can be as much as one-half a percentage point over the regular rate. $ Maturities Current May High July '89 6 months 7.91% 8.01% 8.79% 12 months 8.10% 8.18% 8.83% 30 months 8.10% 8.20% 8.66%

title: 100 POSSIBLE CASES OF SAVINGS FRAUD GIVEN U.S. PRIORITY
description: Stung by criticism that it has moved tentatively and ineffectively to prosecute savings and loan fraud, the Bush Administration has selected 100 savings institutions for priority investigation, Government officials disclosed today.

title: Deborah S. Lee Becomes a Bride
description: Deborah Susan Lee, a doctoral candidate in clinical developmental psychology at Bryn Mawr College, and Steven Kenneth Fleischmann, a doctoral candidate in sociology at the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at Black Point Bluff in The Sea Ranch, Calif. Bruce F. Allen, a lawyer who was appointed a judge pro tem for the ceremony, officiated.

title: Intergroup Suitor Backed by Court
description: A Delaware court paved the way for an investor group to proceed in its takeover attempt of National Intergroup Inc., a Pittsburgh-based holding company of metals and pharmaceuticals. Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett of the Delaware Chancery Court ruled that Centaur Partners Group might proceed with its appeal to the Delaware Supreme Court.

title: Seattle Gives Cheers To the Arts of Russia In Goodwill Festival
description: During a single night here this week, theatergoers gave a standing ovation to a performance of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' performed in Russian, another audience rose to its feet to celebrate the Bolshoi Ballet's return to America, and a long line snaked outside the entrance of a gallery showing five centuries of treasures from Moscow.

title: Passive Smoking Study Refused to Be Taken as the Last Word;   Evidence Is Strong
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   NATO: AT A GLANCE
description: Its ground forces in reserve units in the area total 4,136,000. The study said NATO had 21,900 main battle tanks in Europe, along with 34,000 armored combat vehicles and 1,100 armored helicopters.

title: Beliefs
description: For a year the United States has been embroiled in a fitful debate over obscenity. That is not necessarily bad. A country indifferent to such a question would probably be a country that no longer cherished any beliefs deeply enough to care whether they were transgressed. Or it would be a country so monolithic and complacent in its mores that affronting them was unimaginable.

title: Iberia Air Bid In Argentina
description: An investment group led by the Spanish national airline Iberia was the sole bidder today for a significant share in Argentina's national air carrier Aerolineas Argentinas.

title: 60% Recycling Goal Urged in New Jersey
description: New Jersey officials should set a goal to recycle 60 percent of the state's garbage by 1995, a task force commissioned by Gov. Jim Florio recommended today.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Yeltsin Warns Soviet Party Its Time for Reform Is Short
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, champion of the slender insurgent minority at the Communist Party congress, warned the party today that it must change everything from its name to its undemocratic methods or soon be ''dragged from legal power'' by a disgusted Soviet public.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS What A Crazy Idea
description: Waves of speeches roll by, reduced by the translator's monotone to a lulling sea song. It's hard to stay attentive. The Central Committee propaganda wheel who is reading out extracts, remarkably precise and objective at that, looked up and said: ''Oh dear, I've mixed up my papers. It doesn't matter; the speaker's point was that we have to overcome the crisis of socialism,'' and he went on to the next speech.

title: CHRONICLE
description: American and Soviet space travelers who had a historic rendezvous in space 15 years ago will hold a reunion on the ground at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla., on July 26. Two former American astronauts, TOM STAFFORD, 60 years old, and DEKE SLAYTON, 66 years old, will rejoin two Soviet cosmonauts, ALEKSEI LEONOV, 56 years old, and VALERY KUBASHEV, 55, to celebrate the only international joint manned space mission.

title: Review/Dance;   A Playful Approach to Perceptions
description: John Martin, the critic who perhaps did the most to introduce modern dance to the nation in the 1930's and 40's, noted that unlike ballet, the new art form was ''a system, not a point of view.''

title: Is the Penalty Shootout Here to Stay? FIFA Says Yes.
description: After Argentina proved itself better than Italy at penalty kicks in the semifinals of the World Cup last Tuesday night, the president of the world governing body of soccer, Joao Havelange, received a fax from a distraught Italian woman complaining that her country should not have been eliminated in such an unfair manner. She suggested that the game should be replayed in its entirety.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 25 about a West Virginia man's indictment on Federal charges of racketeering and conspiracy misstated his religious affiliation. A recent letter from a reader pointed out that the man, Keith Ham, was expelled from the Hare Krishna organization in 1987; he leads a splinter group.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Text of the Declaration After the NATO Talks
description: Following is the text of the final declaration issued by the NATO summit conference here today:

title: Dow Rises 25.74 Points In Light Day
description: Stocks advanced briskly yesterday, making up most of their sharp selloff the day before. But with many traders taking a long Fourth of July holiday, volume dropped to the lowest level of the year.

title: Philippines Given Advice
description: The Philippines should improve its investment climate and work harder to sell itself abroad, a special representative of President Bush said today.

title: The Trials of St. Agnes's Library
description: LEAD: What is the biggest bargain in the world?'' my grandmother used to quiz me periodically. Before you picture an old woman peering at store ads, picture this: My grandmother had a doctorate in physics and she studied toward that attainment in the place where most immigrant children studied - the library.

title: Officer Is Found Guilty In Slaying of a Motorist
description: A 26-year-old police officer was convicted yesterday of shooting an unarmed motorist to death in a burst of anger over a traffic dispute.

title: VW Raises Prices
description: Volkswagen U.S. raised prices by an average of 2 percent on its 1991 Golf, GTI, Jetta, Passat and Vanagon models arriving at dealers now. Pricing for the full Volkswagen model line will be announced this fall when the remaining 1991 vehicles become available, it said.

title: Sharper Data for Rent Guidelines
description: New York City's rent control laws force landlords, tenants and bureaucrats into periodic confrontations: how much rent is fair for what kind of housing? A recent tax law creates a new, solid basis for such discussions - one that turns out to support the landlords' position.

title: New Force In Fashion: 'Dart Man'
description: Standards of dress have subtly shifted in midtown Manhattan, and for once the culprit is not an avant-garde French designer or a trend-setting socialite. The mysterious attacker known as the Dart Man is to blame.

title: About New York;   Brushing Up On 7 Million Facts In the Naked City
description: It was an unlikely band of conspirators, the 13 who gathered, one flight up, in a nondescript building along a lackluster strip of East 49th Street. Unlikely, because they were smiling and chatty even as they were planning new strategies for conquering the streets of New York and telling all to invading out-of-towners.

title: Explosion Kills 17 at Petrochemical Plant in Texas
description: A fiery explosion at a petrochemical plant near the Houston Ship Channel killed 17 workers and injured five others, the authorities said today.

title: Navratilova Going for No. 9
description: Martina Navratilova is known as the golden oldie at Wimbledon, where she is an eight-time singles champion, holds the record for singles victories with 98, and is poised to set another record Saturday if she can use her 11th appearance in the women's singles final to achieve a ninth title.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Albanians Reportedly Stream Into Embassies in the Capital
description: About 3,000 Albanians crowded into Western embassies in the Albanian capital today, and the Austrian news agency reported that 10,000 jammed the streets, some of them fleeing police beatings in Europe's last Stalinist state.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Calming the Waters
description: For a minute there this morning, it almost looked as if the United States had come close to agreeing to include surface naval forces in arms-reduction talks with the Soviet Union, something the United States Navy has stoutly resisted for years.

title: Fed Voted in May Against Lower Rates
description: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their May meeting that inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, minutes of the meeting released today show.

title: Books of The Times;   The Wild West in the Everglades
description: Killing Mister Watson

title: Simplify French Spelling if You Must, but Spare That Circumflex
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   An Alliance for a New Age: Has NATO Donned a Velvet Glove?
description: ''Spectacular!'' said one of President Bush's aides today as the NATO summit conference ended. ''Got everything we wanted!'' said a second senior adviser.

title: Evolution in Europe;   GERMANS IN TALKS ON POLITICAL UNITY
description: The treaty is also likely to detail the timing for East Germany to accede to West Germany under Article 23 of the West German Constitution, which allows former German states to join the federal republic upon their request.

title: Ford-Portugal Deal On Plant Reported
description: Portuguese Government officials declined to confirm a newspaper report that the Ford Motor Company had chosen Portugal for a new leisure vehicle production plant worth about $2 billion. The sum would be the largest single foreign investment in Portugal, whose economy has been booming.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Comments By Soviets On NATO
description: Following are excerpts from a statement yesterday by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union as translated and transmitted by the official Soviet press agency Tass.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Associated British Foods P.L.C., London, said it might make an offer for British Sugar and other food manufacturing companies of Berisford International P.L.C.

title: Sulaiman Laments His Actions
description: Jose Sulaiman, the president of the World Boxing Council, told a Federal Court jury in Manhattan yesterday that while a postfight videotape showed him saying he was withholding recognition from James (Buster) Douglas hours after Douglas knocked out Mike Tyson for the heavyweight championship on Feb. 10, he did not really mean it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Sunday about the negotiations over the New York City budget misidentified a City Council member from Staten Island. He is Alfred C. Cerullo 3d.

title: JOB FIGURES DEPRESS BOND PRICES
description: Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury securities plunged. The sharp price declines were fed by conflicting employment data released by the Government before trading began in New York and the losses became even more pronounced during the session.

title: Europe Studies Women's Jobs
description: Many female workers in the European Community are unable to get as much work as they want and are often overqualified and underpaid for the jobs they hold, according to a study presented this week by the European Community's Executive Commission.

title: Japan Reduces Rice Payments
description: Amid United States pressure to open its rice market, the Japanese Government decided today to cut the price it would pay to rice farmers this year by only 1.5 percent.

title: KEY RATES
Europe Reclaims Its Liberal Language
description: Le Monde's editorial director, Andre Fontaine, remarked not long ago that European intellectuals, West and East-Central, were themselves undergoing a historic unification, having come to ''all use the same words and concepts and speak of the same things.'' Today in Budapest and in Paris, in books about politics and culture, in discussions at literary conferences, there is talk of rights, individual autonomy, pluralism, humanism, reform, progress.

title: Seymour Baumrind, Rabbi, 70
description: Rabbi Seymour Baumrind, rabbi emeritus of the Lake Success (L.I.) Jewish Center, died of a heart attack on June 29 while vacationing at St. Agathe, Quebec, his son said. Rabbi Baumrind was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jury Claims Deadlock In a Shooting Case
description: Jurors in the trial of Rafael Rivera Garcia, the Puerto Rican artist and university professor accused of trying to kill his next-door neighbor, told the judge last evening that they are hopelessly deadlocked on most charges.

title: In Moscow, New Yorkers Take 2 Prizes
description: Two New York City singers, Deborah Voigt and Hans Choi, won top honors today in the voice categories at the ninth Tchaikovsky International Music Competition.

title: Official Who Released Nuclear Data Resigns Post
description: The manager of the Hanford nuclear reservation, who ordered the release of documents showing the worst environmental abuses in the nuclear weapons complex, said yesterday that he was resigning to accept a job in private industry.

title: Cycladic Art May Be Sold, British High Court Rules
description: The British High Court turned down a request by the Greek Government today to halt a sale of Cycladic sculptures scheduled at Sotheby's on Monday.

title: Patents;   New Cream To Combat Wrinkles
description: The quest for relief from wrinkles, a hallmark of aging, goes on. This week, two medical researchers in Madison, Wis., patented a cream they said embodies a natural process for reclaiming skin damaged by sun and old age.

title: Snyder Told His Colleagues Of Being Audited by I.R.S.
description: Six weeks before his suicide, Mitch Snyder told a meeting of his co-workers at the Community for Creative Non-Violence that he was being investigated by the Internal Revenue Service in connection with royalties he received from the 1986 television film of his life story, a spokeswoman for the organization said today.

title: Peru: No Vietnam in the Andes
description: President Bush's offer of military aid for Peru's antidrug campaign raises fears that he'll involve the U.S. in another Vietnam. Those fears are unwarranted. A tough military strategy in the Andes, coupled with substantial development aid, is essential to antidrug policy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 21 about a demonstration by environmentalists against wood cutting in Northern California misstated the increase in logging by the Pacific Lumber Company since its takeover by the Maxxam Group. From 1985 to 1989, logging rose by slightly more than 100 percent.

title: Tokyo Leader Bars Aid to Soviets Until Settlement of Island Dispute
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said today that ''it will not be possible'' for his Government to take part in economic assistance to the Soviet Union until Moscow has settled a 45-year-old territorial dispute over islands in the Kurile chain.

title: Blues Make Bid For Stevens
description: After feathering Brett Hull's financial nest, the St. Louis Blues are ready to do the same for Scott Stevens.

title: Simplify French Spelling if You Must, but Spare That Circumflex;   'Foodbowl,' as in Soccer
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Criminal Justice;   The Diverse Uses of Probation
description: To the Editor:

title: Bug Strips' Health Risk Is Revised
description: In 1987 a Government report cited a chemical in pest strips as a probable cause of cancer, and the insect-control devices seemed to disappear from store shelves. Now the Government is preparing a new report that the two American makers of the strips hope will revive their sales.

title: Victory With Vision in Europe
description: After World War I, the victors carved Europe into unstable pieces and imposed a peace that scarred winners and losers alike. Germany was truncated geographically, and doomed to poverty by reparations.

title: Gannett Expects Earnings Decline
description: The Gannett Company said it expects its second-quarter earnings to be lower than a year earlier, in its first quarterly drop since the company went public 22 years ago. Sheila Gibbons, a spokeswoman for the nation's biggest newspaper company, said Gannett would issue its actual earnings report for the April-June period in a few weeks. Gannett stock dropped 62.5 cents a share today, to $36.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mets Waken With 6 Runs In the Eighth
description: The innings had merged quietly one into the other. The threats, mild menaces at best, had unraveled without much inspiration. It appeared that the Mets' offense was fated to rest.

title: North Testifies at Grand Jury
description: Oliver L. North, the former Reagan White House aide convicted in the Iran-contra affair, on Friday made his fourth appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating the affair. Government officials have said the panel is looking into whether Reagan Administration aides not yet charged helped to deceive Congress about the sale of arms to Iran and covert military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: In a Dry Corner of Chile, a Pilgrimage to Grief
description: One recent day, a 73-year-old man in a suit, tie and hat paced beside an open pit in the desert sands a few hundred yards from the Pacific Ocean and cried out in anguish for the son executed in 1973.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgaria's Leader Quits Post Over Crackdown on Protest
description: President Petar Mladenov quit today over accusations that he ordered tanks to disperse an anti-Government protest in December, and his resignation set off rejoicing by thousands of Bulgarians.

title: Ban on Discovery Airways
description: The Government today ordered the Hawaii-based Discovery Airways closed down in one week, accusing the three-month-old carrier of violating United States laws on foreign ownership.

title: Renamed Exxon Valdez Will Ply Different Waters
description: The Exxon Valdez, the tanker that caused the nation's worst oil spill, will be returned to service next month under the name Exxon Mediterranean and will ply the seas half a world away from Alaska, the company that owns the vessel said today.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Atlantic Community must reach out to the countries of the East which were our adversaries in the cold war, and extend to them the hand of friendship.'' - The leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. [1:6.] ''In London it was declared that the West extends its hand to the East. For our part, we are ready to extend our hand toward them.'' - Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. [1:4.]

title: Foes of Stalin Deserve Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Suburbs Are Wary of Bears' Wanderlust
description: More and more lately, young and wayward black bears have been popping up in the leafy outer suburbs of metropolitan New York, providing residents with nervous amusement and testing the wits of the police.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Poland Ousts Its Top Communist Cabinet Members
description: Responding to growing social and political turmoil, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki dismissed the most prominent remaining Communists from his Cabinet today and pledged that Poland would soon hold fully free elections for Parliament and the presidency.

title: An 'Embarrassed' Herzog Quits as Cardinals' Manager
description: Whitey Herzog resigned as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals today, saying he was embarrassed by the play of a team he had made into one of the best of the 1980's. He accepted blame for the club's poor performance this season.

title: Dinkins Campaign Audit Unfinished Months Later
description: Eight months after the mayoral election, Mayor David N. Dinkins's campaign finances are still being audited by the city, and the costs of the audit are reducing the amount of surplus campaign funds the Mayor will return to the city under the new campaign finance law.

title: Bridge
description: All players are familiar with the post-mortem, which is favored by some but abhorred by others. But few are aware of the pre-mortem, which can be accurate in the hands of a master. The diagramed deal took place in a high-stakes rubber-bridge game in Toronto, and the North-South cards were held by Sam Kehela and Willy Lebovic, who won a National Men's Pair title together 27 years ago.

title: INSIDE
description: Unemployment Edges Down

title: Evolution in Europe;   Ethnic Strife Persists in Yugoslav Republics
description: Yugoslavia's biggest republic, Serbia, cracked down on the opposition and the press in a provincial hotbed today, while another republic, Slovenia, was ordered to rescind its sovereignty declaration.

title: In Texas City, Newcomer Brings Abortion Turmoil
description: Until recently, Corpus Christi was like most other cities when it came to the subject of abortion. There were strong feelings on both sides, but other questions, like whether to increase property taxes, seemed more urgent.

title: Norman Mather, 76, Engineering Professor
description: Norman Wells Mather, professor emeritus of electrical engineering at Princeton University, died on Tuesday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 76 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Sonics Hire Motta's Son
description: Kip Motta says he probably won't be talking basketball anymore with his father, Dick Motta, head coach of the Sacramento Kings. That's because Kip, who was a Washington State University assistant basketball coach for the last three years, was hired on Thursday as an assistant to the Seattle SuperSonics' head coach, K. C. Jones.

title: Edberg Beats Lendl and Faces Becker in Final
description: Ivan Lendl's preparation for the 1990 Wimbledon may have been epic, but today, the curtain came down on him one round too early. At the very moment he most needed it, Lendl ran out of his supply of inspired ambition, or zazrany, as they call it back in his discarded homeland of Czechoslovakia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about immigrants in Spain misidentified the nation that formerly controlled Guinea-Bissau. It is Portugal, not Spain.

title: Davis to Get a Start
description: Mark Davis, who won the National League Cy Young Award last year as a relief pitcher with San Diego but has been a major disappointment for Kansas City in the bullpen this year, is going to get a chance at starting.

title: Jobless Rate Slides Again; Hope for Easier Credit Dims
description: In a report that further reduced hope for early Government action to lower interest rates, the Labor Department said today that the unemployment rate edged down another notch in June, to 5.2 percent, and that the number of new jobs rose to a higher level than most analysts expected.

title: Renault Seeks All of Mack Trucks
description: Mack Trucks Inc., an ailing company that still bears the most famous name in American truck making, announced yesterday that it had received a $100 million takeover bid from Renault, the French state-owned maker of autos and trucks.

title: Patents;   A Picture-Framing Kit That Children Can Use
description: For parents who feel compelled to exhibit their children's latest fingerpaintings, a graphics designer in New York City has patented a picture frame that is simple enough for small children to assemble themselves.

title: A Law on the Books Lets Citizens Strike Back at Parking Bureau
description: To the Editor:

title: Travels in the U.S.: Savings Via Coupon Or Club
description: More and more vacationers are seeking significant discounts on hotel rooms in the United States through special clubs or coupon books. Those savings can extend, too, to some rental cars and short-term condominium rentals.

title: Parents Are Suing Parents In Long Island Murder Case
description: Three months after Robert Golub was convicted of the murder of Kelly Ann Tinyes in Valley Stream, her parents have sued his parents, contending that Mr. and Mrs. Golub bear partial responsibility for the girl's death because they had failed to supervise their son properly.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With the Perils of Parking a Car
description: In big cities many drivers justify the expense of parking in lots or garages by pointing to the security they can provide. Yet it is not uncommon for owners to return for their cars and find dented fenders or scratched finishes. Sometimes, property is missing. And occasionally the car itself is gone - stolen. Consumer advocates and law-enforcement officials say there are ways to reduce the risk of theft or damage and improve the chances of recovering the costs of such losses.

title: The Beat Goes On for Young Rhythmic Gymnast
description: Michel Couturier still chuckles when he recalls the night he and his wife received a phone call at their Greenwich Village apartment from the excited rhythmic gymnastics coach at the United Nations International School on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Surprise! VCR to Beat Was Born in the U.S.A.
description: A tiny Arizona company has begun to market a new generation of videocassette recorder that could re-establish an American presence in consumer electronics, an industry dominated by Far East producers for the last 20 years.

title: Another Tough Loss For Hawkins
description: Andy Hawkins must be wondering what torture he has to endure to squeeze out a victory as a pitcher for the Yankees.

title: Strike Continues in Norway
description: An illegal strike by offshore oil workers forced the Norwegian state oil company to shut down production again today, although other strikers were back at work.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Beaten Jogger Fought On, Nurse Testifies
description: Nine hours after being left for dead in the mud, the woman known as the Central Park jogger lay in a hospital bed, still struggling and kicking as if trying to fight off her assailants, a nurse testified yesterday in a hushed Manhattan courtroom.

title: F. K. Henri Henrion, Graphic Designer, 76
description: F. K. Henri Henrion, an international graphic designer and educator, died on Thursday at his home in London. He was 76 years old.

title: Big Board Fines Shearson For Actions in Merger Talks
description: The New York Stock Exchange censured Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday and fined the brokerage house $500,000 for improper actions during the firm's 1986 merger discussions with the E. F. Hutton Group, Wall Street executives said.

title: After Crisis, Unused Beds Increase In Hospitals Across New York City
description: Five months after New York City's worst episode of hospital overcrowding in at least a decade, there is an abundance of vacant beds in many parts of town, and hospital experts are debating whether the overcrowding was an aberration or an omen.

title: Shuttle Leak Testing Is Set by Space Agency
description: The National Areonautics and Space Administration said today that tests were planned on two coasts starting this weekend to isolate the source of hydrogen leaks that have grounded the nation's fleet of space shuttles.

title: Mildred S. Olmsted, Leader of Pacifists And a Suffragist, 99
description: Mildred Scott Olmsted, a longtime antiwar campaigner who was national executive director of a leading pro-disarmament group, died Monday at her home in Rose Valley, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. She was 99 years old.

title: Police Guard Is Gone, but Koch Is Not Unprotected
description: The Police Department has taken away the six-member security detail assigned to former Mayor Edward I. Koch since he left office on Dec. 31. The department's action was based on the decision that police protection was ''no longer warranted,'' a police spokeswoman said.

title: Has Anybody Seen the Soccer Fans?
description: Where have all the people gone?

title: 3 U.S. Teams Advance
description: Those traditional American rowing rivals, Yale and Harvard, advanced along with Temple today to the quarterfinals of the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: Louisiana Bill Would Require Warnings on Recordings
description: The first bill in the United States requiring warning labels on record albums with potentially offensive lyrics was passed last night by the Louisiana State Senate by a vote of 29 to 9. The bill, an amended version of legislation approved by the state's House of Representatives on May 10, requires warning labels on recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, illegal drug use, child abuse or satanic worship.

title: N. C. Wyeth, Inventor, Dies at 78; Developed the Plastic Soda Bottle
description: Nathaniel C. Wyeth, a Du Pont engineer who invented the plastic soda bottle, died Wednesday at the Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Glen Cove, Me. He was 78 years old and lived in Tenants Harbor, Me., and Chadds Ford, Pa.

title: Truck Driver Killed in Holdup
description: The driver of a Pepsi-Cola delivery truck was fatally shot yesterday during a holdup in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said. The driver, Hank Fallacaro, 35 years old, of Brooklyn, was shot once in the chest shortly after noon at 630 Central Avenue while making deliveries, said Patrolman Fred Weiner, a police spokesman. Mr. Fallacaro died about six hours later in Kings County Hospital. The police are seeking two men who were seen running from the scene of the shooting. The amount of money stole was not immediately known.

title: Homeless Man Is Charged In Tossing Boy to His Death
description: A homeless man with a long criminal record has been charged with the slaying of a 3-year-old boy who was thrown to his death Sunday from the roof of a seven-story building in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: Dropout Unit's Head Is Sentenced in Theft
description: A former New York City schools official who admitted stealing $610,000 from a dropout program was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation as part of a plea agreement requiring him to make full restitution.

title: Marjorie M. Bitker, 89, Ex-Trustee of Barnard
description: Marjorie M. Bitker, a writer and former trustee of Barnard College, died on Tuesday at Columbia Hospital in Milwaukee. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patents;   Wristwatch Provides Measure of Heart Rate
description: For people worried about overexerting themselves during exercise, two electrical engineers in Aloha, Ore., have invented a wristwatch that they say also provides an accurate reading of heart rates using just a touch of the fingers.

title: Vincent Sets Timetable For Steinbrenner Ruling
description: George Steinbrenner may know in two weeks just how his entanglements with Howard Spira and Dave Winfield will affect his future in baseball.

title: Fall at Window Kills an Infant In Kew Gardens
description: An 18-month-old fell four stories to his death yesterday in Queens because a window guard had been improperly installed, the police said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Daughter of Brezhnev Wins Return of Seized Valuables
description: Galina Brezhnev, daughter of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the late Soviet leader, has won a lawsuit claiming a variety of valuables confiscated when her husband was sentenced to prison.

title: Patents;   Red Dye Is Produced From Carrot Cultures
description: Two Israeli researchers this week patented a method for producing an intense red dye for foods and cosmetics from carrot cells grown in petri dishes.

title: In East Europe, Cries for Change
description: President Petar Mladenov of Bulgaria resigned yesterday over charges that he had ordered tanks to disperse an anti-Government protest in December, and his resignation touched off rejoicing by thousands of Bulgarians. After students demanded that Mr. Mladenov quit, he submitted his resignation to the newly elected Parliament ''in order not to be a reason to increase political tension,'' Bulgarian television said.

title: In Louisiana, Veto On Abortion Bill
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer today vetoed a bill that would have outlawed all abortions except those performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, and the State House of Representatives quickly voted to override his veto after a short but emotional debate.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East German Unions Trying to Be Eastern Europe's Strongest
description: After decades of docile behavior under the old Communist Government, East Germany's trade unions are flexing their muscles this week to make sure that workers' interests are not brushed aside as the nation rushes toward a free-market economy.

title: Bumpily, Rinfret Begins Unorthodox Quest
description: Describing himself, Pierre A. Rinfret often uses the line, ''what you see is what you get.''

title: Behind Japan's Birth-Rate Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweeney Schriner, Hockey Player, 78
description: David (Sweeney) Schriner, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame and of two Stanley Cup teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the 1940's, died after a lengthy illness, the National Hockey League announced Thursday. He was 78 years old.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Romanian Party Plans to Recast Itself Soon
description: A leader of Romania's governing National Salvation Front said today that the party would recast itself as a center-left social democratic movement and remove members who failed to toe the democratic line.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Cheney to Sign Accord With Greece on Bases
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney arrived in Greece today for a four-day visit to inspect U.S. military bases and to sign an agreement for an eight-year extension of base rights.

title: NATO ALLIES, AFTER 40 YEARS, PROCLAIM END OF COLD WAR; INVITE GORBACHEV TO SPEAK
description: President Bush and the other leaders of NATO today issued a declaration to end four decades of cold war by proposing to act jointly with Moscow and other East Europeans in stating that ''we are no longer adversaries.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES BROWN could finish his prison sentence for aggravated assault at home if he completes the paper work. Since he is within one and a half years of being eligible for parole, he meets a requirement for extended work release, said FRANCIS X. ARCHIBALD, spokesman for the South Carolina Department of Corrections.

title: Mexican Leader Orders Curb On Police Use of Roadblocks
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has ordered the lifting of police roadblocks and imposed curbs on other activities of security forces, to crack down on human rights abuses.

title: Military's Accounting Offices Being Merged to Pare Costs
description: To tighten control over military spending and save up to $150 million a year, the Pentagon plans to consolidate the separate accounting and finance offices of the Army, the Air Force, the Navy and the Marine Corps.

title: Your Money;   A Few Deductions About New Taxes
description: No sooner had the words ''tax revenue increases'' formed on Presidential lips than citizens began asking what to expect and how to protect themselves. Four tax and investment professionals, despite some wisps of clouds in their crystal balls, ventured to respond to those questions.

title: Old Jewelry Also Stolen From Louvre
description: An inventory that was ordered after the theft of a Renoir painting from the Louvre has disclosed that a dozen pieces of ancient Roman jewelry were also stolen from the museum, officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about the French publisher Maurice Girodias omitted his survivors. He was survived by his second wife, Lilla; two daughters from a previous marriage, Valerie and Juliette; two sisters and a brother.

title: For Minority Broadcasters, a Role in What Is Seen and Heard
description: Radio and television executives say Federal Communications Commission policies giving special consideration to minority applicants for broadcast licenses have resulted in a modest increase in the diversity of programming.

title: N.F.L. Sues Association
description: Jack Donlan, executive director of the National Football League Management Council, says the Players Association insists it is not a labor union but continues to act like one. So on Thursday in Minneapolis, the council and the league's 28 teams filed an antitrust suit in Federal Court against the Players Association, charging the association with illegally coordinating player-agent activity in negotiations involving rookies and veteran free agents. (AP)

title: A Juvenile Jekyll With a Subtle Drug Message
description: ''I feel strong,'' sings the protagonist of ''Jekyll and Hyde'' after downing a potion he has concocted in his laboratory. ''I feel brave. For the first time ever, I even had to shave.''

title: Witness Testifies she sold Crack to Barry Many Times
description: A former city employee testified today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial that she sold crack to the Mayor on more than 20 occasions in 1988, sometimes handing it over at her home after he arrived by limousine, other times delivering it to him at hotels and at a city office building.

title: Results of Pryor Exam
description: Aaron Pryor won't be able to fight in New York until at least September, when the doctor who examined him yesterday will present his conclusions to the New York Athletic Commission's medical board.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 7, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Mutual Funds;   Picking Apart the Returns
description: Robert G. Maddern, an investor in Killingworth, Conn., knows the Fidelity Municipal Bond Fund is doing well. But how well? He got different answers from the three newspapers and magazines in his mailbox recently. Because they arrived so close together, the discrepancy caught his eye.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ANIMAL EXPERIMENTATION: The Consensus Changes. Edited by Gill Langley. (Chapman & Hall, Cloth, $45; Paper, $15.95. This book asks not only if animal experiments are ethically advisable, but if they are scientifically advisable. In doing so, ''Animal Experimentation'' questions the validity of animal research without either being hysterical or trying to discredit all such experiments.

title: Very Bad Dream
description: You could say Glenallen Hill of the Toronto Blue Jays got caught in a spider's web. Hill had a lot of explaining to do yesterday. He missed Toronto's 4-2 victory over Seattle because he injured himself Friday night trying to escape imaginary spiders in a nightmare. ''I have a phobia about spiders,'' Hill said. ''In the nightmare, I was trying to get away from spiders.''

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: The World;   Moscow's Party Congress Is No Party
description: One worker to another: ''How come I didn't see you at the last party congress?''

title: Robertson Takes a Role That Fits His Character
description: LEAD: OF ALL the roles Cliff Robertson has played in a stage, film and television career that began on Broadway in 1953, he estimates there have been 40 major ones, including his portrayal of ''Charly'' in that Academy Award-winning movie of 1968.

title: MOTHERS: TIRED OF TAKING THE RAP
description: It is not a question of fixing blame or exonerating from blame, but of understanding the centrality of the early relationship between parent and child. The infant makes of its world what the world presents to it, mediated by the mother. In this sense, the mother is central and powerful. We know the mother has environmental limits to her power; the baby does not.

title: U.S. READY TO LET SATELLITES GO UP ON SOVIET ROCKETS
description: The Bush Administration has decided to allow American commercial satellites to be launched on Soviet rockets for the first time, Government and industry officials say.

title: The Descent to the Bottom Line
description: LEAD:

title: Beckenbauer Might Assist
description: Franz Beckenbauer, the coach of West Germany's soccer team in the World Cup and a former player for the Cosmos, is expected to join the organizing committee for the 1994 World Cup in the United States.

title: If Mozart Has Arrived, Can Kochel Be Far Behind?
description: Bupleurum is the genus name for Hare's Ear, a plant marked by a single, earlike leaf that sheathes the top of its stem. It is a member of the order Umbelliferae, which also includes carrots, parsley, dill, lovage and hemlock. In the 19th century a new species of Hare's Ear was identified by one Professor Fenzl, who, following the custom of naming rare plants for distinguished botanists, called his discovery Bupleurum Koechelii. Thus is immortalized the botanical research of Ludwig Alois Ferdinand Ritter von Kochel, who had himself discovered new plants in the course of many voyages.

title: Is It or Isn't It? A Van Gogh Languishes in Limbo
description: They are the masterpieces on the museum walls, the unvarying stars in our artistic firmament, the van Goghs and Goyas and Rembrandts and van der Weydens. In our youth, we stood before them, notebook in hand, feverishly analyzing them for art-history classes. Later, as we revisited them through the years, they became dear friends.

title: Streetscapes: 129 East 17th Street;   The 'Oldest' Apartment House
description: A favorite stop on ''Lost New York'' walking tours is the site of the demolished Stuyvesant apartments of 1870 at 142 East 18th Street, believed to be the first genteel apartment house in a city then divided between private houses and tenements.

title:
FORUM;

One Company's Short-Lived Loyalties
description: LEAD: It happened pretty suddenly, although she had seen the clouds forming. One day my wife's California-based company was selling millions of dollars worth of software; as manager of technical support for the company's Eastern office, in New Jersey, she was hiring new people week after week. Next day, it seemed, sales were off, costs had to be cut sharply, and a call came to her from headquarters:

title: They All Love Her
description: WOMAN OF THE AEROPLANES

title: The Conflict Within George Bush
description: Being tired of reading George Bush's lips, I was reading some of my old newspaper clips the other day, and there in the middle of The Times's Op-Ed page of May 2, 1979, was a big headline: ''George Bush for President?''

title: Arts Groups Seek Ways To Live With Budget Cut
description: LEAD: IN the wake of a 42 percent budget cut for the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, a coalition of state arts organizations has pledged to cope with cutbacks while continuing to fight for full financing for next year.

title: Broadcasters Mar Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Erik Weiner to Wed Carolyn Roska
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jose C. Roska of Bloomsburg, Pa., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Carolyn Kangleon Roska and Erik Helge Weiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Erik Weiner of Falkoping, Sweden.

title: POLISH PARLIAMENT REBUFFS PREMIER
description: In another blow to the political standing of the Government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the Polish Parliament has rejected two of the five Cabinet changes he proposed on Friday.

title: Penny-Wise and Pound Foolish
description: I totally agree with Robert McMillan. This board has completed its mission in that Shoreham will not operate as a nuclear facility. It, therefore, makes no sense to pay for the election of a board that basically will have nothing to do ''except put out press releases.''

title: U.S. Weighs a Shift on Cambodia Policy
description: The Bush Administration is beginning quietly to reconsider its policy of supporting a guerrilla insurgency against the Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia, officials say.

title: Smaller Colleges Thrive
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners;   Bye, George?
description: In baseball, at least, possessions can cry out for new owners. In recent years, much wailing has been heard from the New York Yankees, whose principal owner, George Steinbrenner, faced league disciplinary action on two fronts last week amid persistent speculation that he just might be thrown out of the game. After finding Steinbrenner guilty of tampering in the case of Dave Winfield, the outfielder who was traded to the California Angels in May, Commissioner Fay Vincent fined him $25,000 and ordered him to pay the Angels $200,000. Now Vincent is looking into a case involving Steinbrenner and one Howard Spira, who Steinbrenner is suspected of having paid $40,000 for information that discredited Winfield, with whom he feuded for years. Vincent is expected to decide Steinbrenner's fate - he could even be ordered to sell his team - this month.

title: Emergency Room Remains Open
description: As I read your article ''Community Hospitals Adapt to Changes'' (May 27), I found it to be quite enjoyable and unfortunately accurate in describing the financial plight of most of New York States' community hospitals. There is a real financial crisis in the hospital industry due to reimbursement patterns of Medicaid, Medicare and third-party payers.

title: Laura B. Vail Wed To J. H. Wooster
description: Laura Bicknell Vail, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Vail of Hopkinton, N.H., was married yesterday to James Hendrie Wooster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Wooster of Concord, Mass., at Trinity Episcopal Church on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. The Rev. Gary Eley performed the ceremony.

title: Vatican Alludes Harshly to Right-to-Die Bill
description: The official Vatican newspaper today assailed right-to-die legislation, alluding to a bill passed by the New York State Legislature this month.

title: Sarah Ross Gant To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Gant of New Vernon, N.J., have announced plans for an August wedding for their daughter Sarah Ross Gant and Michael Anthony Mandanis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mandanis of San Rafael, Calif.

title: In Brussels, Art Nouveau Flourishes
description: LEAD: Brussels is understandably proud of its splendid Gothic and Baroque showplaces: St. Michael's Cathedral, the Guildhouses in the Grand' Place, the Hotel de Ville. Only recently, however, has the city come to realize that its days of architectural glory extended well beyond the 17th century. Not until the 1960's was there widespread acknowledgement that during the fin de siecle, young architects like Victor Horta, Paul Hankar and Henry Van de Velde were among the most innovative and influential in Europe.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: Miss Bullitt Wed To H. S. Burnett
description: Clarissa W. Bullitt and H. Stephen Burnett were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony. Mrs. Burnett, a daughter of Mrs. Francis J. Seidner of Washington and the late John C. Bullitt, graduated from Columbia University, where she is a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology. Her father was a partner in the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling.The bride's stepfather and her mother, Lee Seidner, own the Seidner Gallery in Washington. Mrs. Burnett is a granddaughter of Edward R. Wardwell, who retired as a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell.

title: World Markets;   Smaller Countries May Have the Edge
description: Think small. That's the theme among many portfolio managers who are looking into the second half of the year without great expectations for the world's equity markets. They are going for smaller stock markets in Europe and Asia and picking stocks carefully rather than counting on the overall growth of a market.

title: Russian Villagers In Yonkers
description: THE Untermyer Performing Arts Festival, held amid the magnificent formal gardens and fountains of Untermyer Park in Yonkers, overlooking the Hudson, has brought the county first-rate artists in various disciplines for a dozen years now.

title: Lolly Jewett to Wed Abner Oakes 3d>
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lincoln Jewett of Darien, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Laura Jewett and Abner Oakes 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Oakes 3d of Hamden, Conn.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The economic summit of industrialized nations begins in Houston. Through Wednesday.

title: Slovenia Defies Belgrade Call To Cancel Sovereignty Move
description: The Slovenian republic today defied demands from Communist federal leaders in Belgrade to annul a declaration of full state sovereignty.

title: Sports of The Times;   Last Look at Italy's World Cup
description: So who's going to win the World Cup final today? I look for signs.

title: Solar Derby
description: The idea is appealingly Soap Box Derbyesque - a bunch of young people competing with their homemade cars. Of course, the scale is slightly inflated. Tomorrow morning, student teams from 32 colleges and universities will begin an 11-day, 1,700-mile race through eight states - from Walt Disney World in Florida to the General Motors Technical Center in Warren, Mich. - in solar-powered vehicles of their own design.

title: Monkeys in Laboratory Dispute Are Killed
description: A spokeswoman for the Government's National Institutes of Health said today that researchers had performed a final set of brain experiments on three monkeys that became a symbol for the animal rights movement and then humanely put them to death.

title: Reflections on World Cup 1990
description: One cannot be totally disappointed with the United States team's performance in the World Cup tournament, although the United States team has a few weaknesses. The first was poor ball-controlling techniques, and the second was the long passing of the ball. The improvement in these areas would require good coaching and playing many matches with international teams in the next four years to be exposed to the international standard of play.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

The Sweet Life of Honey Shugart
description: LEAD: BIRD OF PARADISE. By Vicki Covington. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Honey Shugart, the protagonist of Vicki Covington's fine second novel, is not only as sweet as her name doubly suggests, she's also perky - ''blessed with old-age agility,'' as she puts it - a right-minded, racially progressive, environmentally aware and mobile Miss Daisy.

title: Mary Curtis Weds John Ulin in West
description: Mary Alison Curtis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen James Curtis of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., was married yesterday to John Charles Ulin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Irwin Ulin of New York. Judge Frank Baffa of Los Angeles County Superior Court officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Rachel Countryman Is Bride of John W. Bracker
description: Rachel Carole Countryman, the daughter of Joan C. Countryman of Philadelphia and Peter Countryman of West Lafayette, Ind., was married yesterday to John Wescott Bracker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Earl F. Bracker of Concord, Mass., at the Germantown Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends in Philadelphia.

title: Death-Defying Acts
description: WRESTLING WITH THE ANGEL

title: Tips on Buying Garden Hose
description: WHEN buying garden hose, choose either rubber hose or hose made of reinforced rubber and vinyl. Both are more durable, although more expensive, than hose made only of unreinforced vinyl.

title: A Fair That's Full of Style
description: WHEN the glass blowers light their furnaces at the Allaire Craft Fair on Saturday, the fiery glow will echo flames that lighted a bog-iron forge at the same site nearly 200 years ago.

title: Business Says Enough Is Enough
description: Re: ''The Builders Are Trying to Undercut Us'' (May 27).

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

What Grows the Best At the Seaside
description: LEAD: Gardeners are learning to cope at the seaside. For example, a small gateway sign, ''Welcome to My Garden,'' leads to a verdant oasis Marie Donnelly has created on her one-acre property in Southampton, L.I. Sheltered from ocean winds and salt spray by privet and mixed shrubbery, the tranquil garden bears testimony to her concern with space, form and color.

title: Review/Dance;   Fiorello Festival Honors Modern Tradition
description: The new Fiorello Festival of dance got off to a model - and often exhilarating - start on Friday night with a program of work by Beverly Blossom, Janis Brenner and Jeanette Stoner. The evening was a tribute in its way to the Hanya Holm-Alwin Nikolais-Murray Louis tradition of modern dance to which the three belong. For this was physically articulate dance to a rare degree. It was also dance that reveled unashamedly in that articulation. And it had a special sensitivity toward the placement and juxtaposition of bodies in space, a sensitivity enhanced by strong lighting designs and the spacious feeling of the stage at the La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts at Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street, where the festival programs run through July 28.

title: New Procedures Proposed for Homeless
description: A NEW approach to Westchester's costly homeless problem that emphasizes control and assessment rather than placement of the 4,500 residents in need of housing has been proposed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, to cautious praise and some misgivings.

title: Even Grown-Ups Find Action In the State's Soccer Leagues
description: LEAD: DUSTY BURGER'S introduction to soccer came almost by accident. ''When I was 12 or 13, I knew more friends going out for the soccer team than the football team,'' recalled Mr. Burger of his childhood in Darien. ''But I thought it was soccer baseball, using bases, not regular soccer.

title: On Financing For Folk Arts
description: In an article on the role of New Jersey's former Assistant Secretary of State, Alvin S. Felzenberg, in promoting an artistic renaissance in the state (''State 'Guardian' of Arts Assumes National Endowment Role,'' May 20), the sole criticism voiced was by Fred Thomsen, president of the New Jersey Folklore Society.

title: Torturous Nights In an Easy Chair
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy Take Third Place
description: Salvatore Schillaci took the goal-scoring lead for the World Cup and lifted Italy to third place in the soccer championship tonight, putting in a penalty kick with six minutes left for a 2-1 victory over England.

title: Aid Can Answer a Soviet Question
description: Secretary of State James Baker says the United States won't stand in the way of allies who want to offer aid to the Soviet Union. And the Bush Administration is prepared to send technical assistance, but not to extend credits.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Airline Group Fights German Security Levy

title: MOTHERS: TIRED OF TAKING THE RAP
description: Janna Malamud Smith's article ''Mothers: Tired of Taking the Rap'' (June 10) certainly hit home. The 1980's saw anti-momism as a growth business. Look at the dialogue in popular television programs like ''Thirtysomething'': ''My mother is coming for a visit.'' Nudge, nudge, wink, wink. Lots of eye rolling and in-joking among the cast. Same thing in ''Roseanne.'' As portrayed, the moms are neither venal nor dumb, hardly justifying the antipathy of their children. They are just bumbling along like the rest of us, trying to be loved (or at least, liked), and slightly puzzled that they're not, as am I, the viewer.

title: A Woman and Her Dog Fight Disasters
description: LEAD: THE call came from Washington on a December Friday, shortly after a 1988 earthquake had leveled schools, homes and factories in Armenia. It was the United States Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance calling: how soon could Caroline Hebard be ready to board a plane for the Soviet republic?

title: Jonathan R. Hock Weds Ms. Brown
description: Laura S. Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Brown of Washington and Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married last evening at the Washington Hebrew Congregation to Jonathan R. Hock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Hock of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Bruce Lustig and Cantor Michael Manevitch officiated.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

Out in Left Field
description: LEAD: SOME OF MY BEST FRIENDS ARE CRAZY: Baseball's Favorite Lunatic Goes in Search of His Peers. By Jay Johnstone with Rick Talley. (Macmillan, $18.95.) Jay Johnstone, formerly a journeyman baseball player and now a radio broadcaster, teams up with the sportswriter Rick Talley to lament the loss of fun and caring amid today's ballplayers in ''Some of My Best Friends Are Crazy.

title: France
description: To the Editor: This letter is in response to Sylvia Steinbrock's complaint (Letters on Travel, May 6) about the 900 number of the French Government Tourist Office. As a tour operator specializing in travel, to France only, I feel that the 900 number is an excellent initiative to help travelers get the information they seek to arrange their trip to France. I have visited this information center and tested the service by calling. I found the staff professional, courteous and knowledgeable about France.

title: Every Boy Has His Day
description: MY LIFE AS A DOG

title: Hawkins House A Symbol of Success
description: I enjoyed reading the article ''Suffolk Wrestling With Fate of Estates'' (May 13), which focused on the fate of several historic homes on the island.

title: Harold Hirsch, 82; Started White Stag, Sportswear Concern
description: Harold S. Hirsch, founder of the White Stag Manufacturing Company, a leading maker of casual sportswear, died of cancer at his home here Wednesday. He was 82 years old. Mr. Hirsch, who became one of Portland's most prominent civic leaders, was a pioneer in the manufacture of outdoor clothing.

title: Thwarting Theft
description: To the Editor: After reading about the man who had his wallet stolen or rifled four times on three continents (''An Easy Mark to Pickpockets of 3 Continents,'' Travel, May 20), I would like to offer my own experience on a trip to Sicily.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: GLORIA SPADARO;

Confronting and Rising Above Lupus
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES disease gives rise to heroism. Such is the case of Gloria Spadaro, a 50-year-old registered nurse, who learned 15 years ago that she had a chronic inflammatory disease, lupus.

title: Steven Spielberg Promises: 'Th-Th-That's Not All, Folks'
description: At first glance, it seems like old times. In a warren of cubicles within a modern office building in the San Fernando Valley, teams of young, casually dressed animators labor furiously to supply their daily quota of raw cartoonage. Production schedules and colored pencils litter the desks and drawing boards; walls and bulletin boards are festooned with sketches of familiar-looking ducks, rabbits and road runners. All remaining vertical surfaces are covered with comic strips, silly photographs and - in a tradition as old as Hollywood animation itself - rude caricatures of the boss.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a program in which low- and moderate-income families earn equity in cooperatives by helping in the buildings' renovations misstated the amount to be paid by residents of a building in Torrington. Depending on their income, it is $250 to $525 a month including mortgage, utilities, property taxes and insurance.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-9

title: Managing;   Turning a Boss Into a Client
description: Kathryn H. Tunheim liked her job as Honeywell Inc.'s vice president of public relations, but she was hankering for the excitement of running a profit center. Honeywell, meanwhile, wanted to halve the head count in Ms. Tunheim's department.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

2 Bills Grapple With Affordable Housing
description: LEAD: A MAJOR question facing New Jersey is how it will meet its affordable-housing needs in the 1990's, and state lawmakers hope that two bills now working their way through the Legislature will help provide the answer.

title: For Seniors, Discounts on Plane and Train Fares
description: Slipping past the 50th birthday may be a trauma, but the sting should be eased somewhat by the travel discounts that start to become available then. One friend laughed about using her senior citizen card to discount a motel room for an assignation, but why not?

title: Annual Camden Show Offers a Lively Selection of 44 Works
description: THIS city looks better than it did 10 years ago, but not as prosperous as it appears in William Hoffman's painting of it - one of 44 works that are now on view in the Stedman Gallery on the Rutgers-Camden campus.

title: Lakehurst Journal;   Navy Wants to Stop Paying for Borough Services
description: FOR years, this sandy, mile-square Ocean County municipality and the sprawling Naval Air Engineering Center here have enjoyed a harmonious, almost symbiotic relationship.

title: Tina M. Webster Wed To Thomas M. Loose
description: At the First Congregational Church in Williamstown, Mass., Tina Maureen Webster and Thomas Maxwell Loose, both 23 years old and graduates of Williams College, were married yesterday by the Rev. David Williams.

title: Campus Life: Bennington College;   Trying to Shake Off 'Anything Goes' Image
description: Long known for its free-spirited environment, Bennington College is trying to shake off the image that, in the words of one administrator, ''anything goes here.''

title: Date Update
Postings: Landmark for Sale;   Nast's House
description: In Morristown, N.J., $1.2 million will buy a National Historic Landmark: a Second Empire-style house with 10 bedrooms, four bathrooms, a brass plaque at the door and memories of the illustrator and cartoonist Thomas Nast, who lived there from 1872 until his death in 1902. But it will not buy an oyster ranch - although Mark Twain suspected there was one in the house.

title: Topics of the Times;   Luggage, Lost and Found
description: One day last week a young woman about to take a very long plane trip packed herself a kind of CARE package. There was cheese, prosciutto, bread, a tomato and a mango because she distrusts airline food. Two newly purchased shirts and a sweater because she is wary of air-conditioning. And three books, also newly purchased, in case the flight attendant ran out of magazines before she got to her seat.

title: Maradona Raises the Stakes
description: He has already given one gift to his daughters in this soccer season: a wedding.

title: Albania Shuffles Top Officials as Unrest Persists
description: Albania's ruling Communist Party, challenged by increasing public dissent, reshuffled top party and Government officials today after a tumultuous week in which about 5,000 Albanians poured into Western embassies seeking refuge from Europe's last Stalinist state.

title:
Your Own Account;

Psst! Want a Hot Tip?
description: LEAD: With Wall Street in tatters, thousands of brokerage employees laid off and those who remain shell-shocked, how valuable is the research you're getting from your stockbroker?

title: Evoking the Spirit of Billie Holiday
description: TO date, the most sensible attempt to capture the elusive mystique of the great Billie Holiday in theatrical terms is ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill,'' Lanie Robertson's ''drama in the form of a cabaret act,'' as the playwright has described it.

title: Underticket Races Hold Political Heat
description: AS Connecticut's political faithful prepare to gather in Hartford for the state party conventions, the spotlights and headlines will focus on the candidates seeking the nominations for governor. But the tops of the tickets will probably be determined without much drama.

title: Reflections on World Cup 1990
description: I was disappointed to read the article concerning the Ireland-Romania soccer match (''Ireland Tops Romania, Ending 0-0 Game on Final Penalty Kick,'' The Times, June 26). Instead of quoting the Irish coach's remarks on tactics you quoted his remarks on drinking. The article had many other slurs and subtle insults. The Irish coach is English: read it again from an Irish point of view and see why I feel the way I do.

title: Aristotle's Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping Score On Grammar
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Five U.S. Teams Face a Cup Lockout
description: Organizers for the next America's Cup match are moving swiftly ahead with plans for a 1992 event. But complaints of unfair play are surfacing from American teams who have been locked out unexpectedly from the competition.

title: Molly Cliff to Wed Matthew Bersani
