description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Cliff of New York have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Mary Farrell Cliff and Matthew Donald Bersani, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank A. Bersani of Syracuse.

title: Campus Life: Lafayette College;   Saving Streams (And For Credit): An Idea Spreads
description: It started with a casual conversation between a swimming coach and a fisherman. Now the resulting project - preserving the environmental quality of streams in eastern Pennsylvania -has grown to involve students from a half-dozen schools.

title: The Super-duper Bowl
description: One billion people - a fifth of Earth's population - will watch the final game of the World Cup soccer championship on television today, according to utterly unreliable estimates of the contest's popularity. Even if that's an exaggeration, it doesn't diminish the fact that soccer has more fans than any other sport on this planet. Today's face-off in Rome between Argentina and West Germany will draw more viewers than a decade of Super Bowls.

title: Laura Ann Kirby, Teacher, Is Married
description: Laura Ann Kirby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Kirby of Amelia Island, Jacksonville, Fla., was married yesterday in Woodstock, Vt., to David Francis Melbourne Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melbourne of Darien, Conn. The Rev. William P. Gallagher and the Rev. Henry A. Albeke officiated at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church.

title: Peter Kemp Weds Donna M. Soares
description: Donna Marie Soares, the daughter of Dr. Anthony T. and Dr. Louise M. Soares of Trumbull, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Walton Kemp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Kemp of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. M. Joseph Joaquin officiated at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Trumbull.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, NY. $280,000

title:
DINING OUT;

Like a Small, Charming Place in Provence
description: LEAD: FIVE months ago, a tiny gem of a restaurant serving Provencal food opened in the attractive Hunterdon County town of Lambertville. It is owned by Jean Michel Dumas, who used to be chef at the Inn at Phillips Mill in New Hope, Pa., and his wife, Sue.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

Funny Bunny
description: LEAD: The heroes of the Warner Brothers studios in the 1940's were fearless, debonair, tough yet lovable: Bogart, Cagney, Bugs Bunny. Bugs Bunny? Yes, says Joe Adamson in BUGS BUNNY: Fifty Years and Only One Grey Hare (Holt, $35). Impudent, irrepressible, unflappable, Bugs became just as real to many filmgoers as Hollywood's flesh-and-blood fantasy figures.

title: London's Garden Halls
description: The well-known English indifference to fashion does not apply to plants. A visit to the halls in Westminster in London where the Royal Horticultural Society stages 12 shows each year reveals that black pansies and hellebores (the claret colored ones above all) are now in favor. And ''geraniums are making a comeback, you know,'' one frowzily dressed English matron excitedly assures her friend as they look over a display of pelargoniums. There's not a stiff upper lip to be seen in the vicinity of clematis or roses. The English are passionate about gardening and show it.

title: Presenting the Bolshoi: It's a Long Way From Sol Hurok
description: When it opens on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, the Bolshoi Ballet will not look too different from the way it did on recent visits. During the two-week engagement, the company will present a familiar quota of full-evening classics and spectacles - from ''Swan Lake'' and ''Romeo and Juliet'' to ''Ivan the Terrible,'' a modern-day signature work by Yuri Grigorovich, director and chief choreographer of the Moscow troupe for the last 26 years.

title: Israel Is Watching
description: EVERY SPY A PRINCE

title: Race Cars as Actors Fuel the Eye in 'Thunder'
description: The opening scene of ''Days of Thunder'' promises the real thing. The camera pans over the stands at Daytona, Fla., into the paddock, across the rows of trailers and down to the stock cars lined up on the grids as they begin to follow the pace car round the track. Then, as the green flag drops, there's the thunder of 44 V-8 engines at full throttle drowning out the movie music in a roar that shakes the theater.

title: Gentle Scents Enhance a Flower Bed
description: IT had rained the night before, and all the plants were washed clean. They looked fresh and green. There was also a fragrance in the yard, but it was not apparent where it was coming from. Only a few plants were in bloom, as it was a between time, past the glories of spring, but not quite ready for the opulence of annuals. Yet a gentle fragrance persisted. Perhaps it was coming from a neighbor's yard.

title: 66 Killed in Fierce Battle in East Sri Lanka
description: Intense fighting broke out in eastern jungles today after soldiers surrounded an important rebel base and cut off sea and land escape routes, military officials said.

title: 'The Reluctant King'
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life;   Inroads by Unions Among Assistants In Graduate Study
description: After a flurry of union agitation at universities around the nation, graduate teaching assistants have made significant gains in their campaigns for better pay, benefits and working conditions.

title: Headliners;   Beyond Faith
description: Some of the Boston jurors were in tears last week when they returned a verdict after a two-month trial, convicting two Christian Scientists, David and Ginger Twitchell, of manslaughter in the death of their 2-year-old son. Following the precepts of their religion, the Twitchells relied on prayer instead of seeking conventional medical care to treat their son, Robyn, who died in 1986 of a bowel obstruction. It was the fourth time in 15 months that Christian Scientists have been convicted of manslaughter or neglect in cases where their children have died. The Twitchells, who had faced a maximum punishment of 20 years in prison, were sentenced to 10 years' probation and were ordered to take their three other children to a pediatrician for regular examinations. They are appealing the conviction. ''This has been a prosecution against our faith,'' Mr. Twitchell said after the verdict. ''What challenged our faith was when our child died.''

title: Greekfest '90: Peaceful Fun in the Sun
description: The guys said they came to look at the girls. The girls said they came to look at the guys. Everybody said they were not looking for trouble.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: When it comes to pure skills, the best man in baseball is Jose Canseco. We have a modern Babe Ruth on our hands.

title: U.S., After Letter From Shamir, Looks Anew at Pushing for Middle East Peace Talks
description: After considering a recent letter to President Bush from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, Administration officials have concluded that another attempt to organize Israeli-Palestinian talks may be justified.

title: Gorbachev Heads Off Confidence Vote
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev brought his unruly party congress under control today, heading off a series of up-or-down votes on his leadership team that had threatened to become a vote of confidence on Mr. Gorbachev's programs.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Even experienced camera hands who can explain the difference between single-servo auto focus and off-the-film automatic flash exposure are hard-pressed when it comes to binoculars. Friends accustomed to receiving advice on all things optical are often met with confusion when they ask ''What's the best exit pupil diameter?'' and ''Should I buy a roof prism model or one with a Porro prism?''

title: Y? Because He Likes Mickey Memorabilia
description: LEAD: THEY call him the Mickey Mouse doctor - and he grins from ear to ear.

title: Wedding Plans For Libby French
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Lafayette French of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Druecker French, and Kenneth Andrew Toudouze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Paul Toudouze of San Antonio.

title:
Focus: New Hampshire Lakes;

New Hope For Sales of Second Homes
description: LEAD: The Lakes Region of New Hampshire is moving into the summer tourist season with real estate professionals hopeful that sales of second homes and vacation properties will increase this season after nearly two years of slow sales and plummeting prices.

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: East Islip $170,000

title: Postings: Subsidy for a Private Project;  $25,000 Discounts for Qualified Buyers
description: Housing advocates have long complained that affordable-housing projects in New York City could not receive aid from the city or the state unless they were built on city-owned land to keep development costs to a minimum.

title: Marcy Levinson Weds W. L. Williams
description: Marcy Levinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joel D. Levinson of Mountainside, N.J., was married last evening in Summit, N.J., to Dr. Wyman L. Williams, the son of Mrs. Don Bradford of Greenwood, Ind. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated at the Grand Summit Hotel.

title: Moving On
description: The man who pioneered the trust-fund program for The Athletics Congress and who was a key executive in long-distance running during the last decade, Alvin Chriss, has announced his resignation from TAC. In addition to his work for the trust fund, designed to help athletes receive money for on-track and off-track activities while retaining their amateur status, the 60-year-old Chriss recently represented TAC in drug-testing appeals. (AP)

title: Perspectives: Changeover in the Housing Agency;   Putting a Dinkins Imprint on a Koch Plan
description: The word that leaps from Felice Michetti's lips as she seeks to articulate the special stamp that the administration of David N. Dinkins will put on city-assisted housing programs is affordability.

title: Action Outshines Stars in C.F.L.
description: Nearly 20,000 fans mill merrily into Lansdowne Park for an evening of pro football unlike any to be found on a Sunday afternoon in Mile High Stadium or Candlestick Park or Soldier Field during the fall.

title: Currency;   The Dollar's Down Again
description: For those planning a trip to England this summer, the news in recent weeks has not been so good. Since the beginning of June, the pound has risen by 10.5 cents, to $1.7865, from $1.6810. This is a 6 percent increase - or, put another way, a 6 percent cut in the budget for American travelers. And four cents of the pound's rise came in the last week. John Major, Chancellor of the Exchequer, aided the rally with a speech in the House of Commons. The Chancellor said interest rates in Britain would have to remain high because of the continued rapid growth in loans, which spur spending and aggravate inflation. Meanwhile, for those Americans who are going to Germany, the news has been only half as bad, with the dollar falling 2.8 percent since June 1.

title: Give Consumer a Break And Regulate Cable TV
description: To the Editor:

title: VINCENT IS BESEIGED IN FIRST FULL SEASON
description: After calling George Steinbrenner to account for charges brought by a self-described gambler, after ordering the Yankees to pay $200,000 in compensation and $25,000 in fines for tampering, Fay Vincent was asked if baseball had been damaged during the unpleasant week that was.

title: Carolyn P. Sawin To Wed in August
description: Edward A. Sawin Jr. of Philadelphia has announced August wedding plans for his daughter Carolyn Patterson Sawin and Timothy Crawford Wilson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Wilson of Irvington, N.Y.

title: Nassau Museum Is at a Crossroads a Year After Changes
description: LEAD: ONE year after reorganizing and operating as a private institution, the Nassau County Museum of Art once again finds itself at a crossroads, searching for new leadership.

title: From a Writer's Standpoint, Rewards Are Worth the Risks
description: The screenwriter Shane Black went off to his cabin for four months recently and emerged with an original screenplay that he then sold in an auction among the studios for $1.75 million. While the price tag made national news, less noticed was the fact that Mr. Black could have sold it for more but elected to take less - so that he could name the producer he wanted to work with.

title: The Singapore Sting
description: Frequent visitors to Singapore know that amid the city's wonders there are occasional flies in the Tiger Balm. Forty-eight-hour deliveries are frequent from Singapore's 24-hour tailors. Happy hour comestibles in the city's bars and lounges are far below Western standards in quantity and variety if not in quality. These, however, are minor matters. Of more concern are the deceptive or patently fraudulent schemes employed by at least some of the local merchants to fleece tourists. One of the most lucrative and widely practiced of these involves selling off-brand equipment to photographers who assume they are buying Pentax, Canon, Nikon or other name-brand products.

title: Ideas & Trends;   Despite the Heat Summer in the City Has Always Been An Outdoor Affair
description: The temperature has reached into the 90's and the public pollers still have not tumbled to the fact that what most often crops up in conversation these days is not perestroika, not racial unrest, not savings and loan scandal, not even traffic. It is weather, a subject that in New York City has always been known to go to extremes.

title: 'Tell Them I'm Carrying Their Baby'
description: AN OPEN ADOPTION

title:
Northeast Notebook: Barrington, R.I.;

Developers Bucking Slump
description: LEAD: TWO developers of high-end houses in Rhode Island say they are finding buyers despite a 10 percent drop in real-estate sales throughout the state since last year.

title: The Second Cemetery of Paris
description: Some days, when Paris gets just too speedy, I prefer sweet-scented conifers to chestnuts in bloom, a tranquil, narrow path to a vibrant, wide avenue. Though it's rush hour, I can actually hear birdsong, and only very distantly a faint susurrus of traffic. Far from the melee of tourist buses, I relax in the peace and quiet of the Montparnasse Cemetery.

title: English Fare Boring? Well, Not Desserts
description: EVEN in the dark days of stringy beef and overcooked cabbage, the English knew how to make desserts. Recently I spent a week in a tranquil seaside hotel in Lyme Regis, Dorset (the location of ''The French Lieutenant's Woman''), where the menu could have been a reprint from Escoffier's reign at the Savoy.

title: Saving the Past in Austria
description: LEAD: Salzburg is a charming city with the touristic advantage that most of its points of interest lie within easy walking distance of the center. Thus the foreign visitor seldom wanders far beyond such well-publicized sights as the Fortress, the Dome, the Mirabell Gardens, the Mozart dwellings and the little shops in the Getreidegasse selling kitschy trinkets, chocolate Mozart Kugeln and

title: Summary of Action in New York Legislature's 213th Session
description: In a flurry of last-minute activity during the final days of its 213th Session, the New York State Legislature approved measures to create a children's health insurance program, to cap the fees that doctors may charge the elderly and to pump $420 million into New York's hospital system.

title: This Is the Army, Mrs. Jones
description: UNCLE SAM'S BRIDES

title: Light Bulbs
description: To the Editor: Travelers who like to read must be annoyed by the tiny light bulbs found in most American motel rooms - small because many guests seem to think it is their right to take the larger ones as a part of the service.

title: Style Makers;   Wilbert Murdock, Sports Technologist
description: Growing up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Wilbert Murdock was interested in the martial arts and in contact sports like boxing. He was a good student, especially in math and science, and today he gives talks in schools to encourage minority youngsters to pursue careers in technical fields, often showing the relationship of science and sports.

title: Steinbrenner May Have Ally in Fehr
description: George Steinbrenner may have found an unexpected ally in the Major League Baseball Players Association because the union believes the Yankees owner may have erroneously been found guilty of tampering.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

There's No Place to Hide
description: LEAD: OPENING up the house in the early summer mornings, during the before-the-children-wake-up hours, is such an exhilirating feeling, cleansing the body and soul. The birds are bustling and hovering over their young in birdhouses hanging from our cherry trees. The morning air rushes in on my sleepy night-face, coaxing it to greet the day.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Glendale, Calif.;   2 Office Towers Rising at Last
description: The catalyst was the city-subsidized Glendale Galleria, which opened in 1976. With 265 stores in 1.6 million square feet, it generated $350 million in sales and $3.5 million in city sales taxes last year. Builders were also drawn by the city's proximity to downtown Los Angeles and the Glendale, Ventura and Golden State Freeways and the lack of a business license tax, said Jeanne Armstrong, Glendale's Redevelopment Director.

title: Liberian Rebels Cut Off a Government Stronghold
description: Rebel forces continued their siege of Monrovia today, preventing food, water and fuel from entering the encircled Government stronghold in the city's densely populated center.

title: No Women Allowed
description: To the Editor:

title: Birth Pains;   Now Playing on the World Stage: The Taming of the New
description: THIS is an extraordinary summer in international affairs, a summer when the leaders of the West are trying to keep the mighty steed of change from galloping away from them, trying to tame it and guide it.

title: Support Group For Stepmothers Re: ''Stepmothers Fight the Evil Image'' (April 29).
description: ''It'' began when we responded to an ad in the newspaper that read ''Second Wives/Stepmothers support group forming. . .contact. . .''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Needed: Homesick Club For a Mother
description: LEAD: AS I drove my 15-year-old daughter to the airport for a tour out West, I couldn't help but wonder where all our summers have gone. Before ever realizing that her summers as a child were limited in number, I suddenly saw that we had practically used them all up.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Paul S. Timpanelli;

Bridgeport Looks to Neighbors for Help
description: LEAD: THE Bridgeport Regional Business Council, a private organization, represents 1,400 businesses in Bridgeport and two of its suburban neighbors, Stratford and Trumbull. Paul S. Timpanelli, who has been the full-time president of council since December 1988, was the First Selectman of Trumbull for six years and still lives there.

title: 'Cocktail Hour' Staged At Westport Playhouse
description: ''THE COCKTAIL HOUR'' is A. R. Gurney's portrait of a middle-aged playwright who has written a play about his upper middle-class WASP family and called it ''The Cocktail Hour.''

title: Sarah Von Culin Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Pearson Von Culin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Von Culin of Pottersville, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Mark Treanor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Treanor of Convent Station, N.J. The Rev. Mark R. Summer, a Lutheran minister, assisted by the Rev. Boniface J. Treanor, a Roman Catholic priest and the bridegroom's uncle, performed the Lutheran ceremony at Zion Lutheran Church in Oldwick, N.J.

title: Design;   SITTING PRETTY
description: It's the bigness that first inspires fear. Then, having to make what seem like endless decisions. Never mind the financial investment or the shopping time involved. Even the sanest of folks can find buying a sofa a daunting experience. For starters, consumers will usually be bombarded with questions from a pleasantly inquiring salesperson: what size and shape will fit the space? Which among thousands of fabric samples are right? Should the arms be straight or scrolled, the cushions filled with down or poly-Dacron? Is a frame made of hardwood and kiln-dried preferable? Often sofa lingo can seem foreign, and the prices out of this world, too.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE: A New Face For NATO;   Military Must Change As the Threat Wanes
description: The military strategy outlined by NATO leaders for adapting to the end of the cold war marks a break with 40 years of military planning and deployment. But the new concepts - including multinational units and smaller and more mobile forces - will pose a challenge to those who must put them into action.

title: Wall Street;   T-Shirts: In Leaner Times, the Little Guys Are Losing
description: It's getting scrappy out there in the T-shirt market. Producers' capacity was stretched last year, as sales exploded by nearly 30 percent. To avoid getting shorted this season, many wholesalers double-ordered the shirts, the sort on which decals and slogans are printed.

title: U.S. Viewers Get A Faulty Picture
description: Watching soccer on television in the United States is like watching a great party going on across the street from your house.

title:
Headliners;

Lesbian Child-Custody Case Redefine Family Law
description: LEAD: THE increasing affirmation of the social and civil rights of homosexuals is causing a legal redefinition of the institutions of marriage and family. The child custody disputes that are the grist of the evolving case law are attended not only by the usual anguish of acute family crises but also by a special uncertainty:

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar. Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off. The deck was last painted several years ago, and much of it is now peeling. Where the cedar wood is exposed, it is gray and dull looking.

title: Dana Spector Wed to Scott L. Kimmel
description: Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Dana Irene Spector, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Spector of Kings Point, L.I., and Scott Lauren Kimmel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kimmel of Buffalo. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated.

description: ONLY a year ago the 1990's seemed bound to be the age of Japanese influence, as the biggest Pacific power approached the Pacific Century.

title: Goodyear's Pipeline, A White Elephant
description: LEAD: It seemed to be a sound strategic move. Faced with mounting competition and sluggish growth in its core tire business, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company decided in 1983 to smooth out the bumps and potholes in its earnings performance by diversifying.

title:
The Executive Life;

Hard-Working Executive, Hard-Working Vacation
description: LEAD: Last summer, Laura Farnsworth, a marketing representative for the International Business Machines Corporation, left the confines of her urban office in Dallas to spend almost a month hunkered down in southern Siberia studying the nocturnal mating habits of the Siberian dwarf hamster. Each night from 10 P.M.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: NEW YORK 1913: The Armory Show and the Paterson Strike Pageant, by Martin Green. (Collier/Macmillan, $14.95.) In 1913, just about the time that the famous show at the 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington Avenue was introducing New Yorkers to the likes of Picasso and Duchamp, Big Bill Haywood and the Wobblies were organizing a different kind of insurrection: a march up Fifth Avenue by 1,200 New Jersey millworkers striking for an eight-hour day. By drawing parallels between these two events, Richard Snow said here in 1988, Martin Green has created a book that is ''full of fascinating things, and alive with the vigor of the eloquent men and women who were so sure they were about to create a renaissance through the fusion of art and politics.''

title: Reflections on World Cup 1990
description: In ''And Maradona Was Waiting,'' (The Times, June 25) about the contest between Argentina and Brazil, George Vecsey opened with the following statement: ''He (Diego Maradona of victorious Argentina) wore the fabled yellow jersey of Brazil like a trophy from a primitive war. He waved it at the stands as if brandishing the pelt of a vanquished enemy.'' Vecsey closed with this sentence: ''In the jungle, the reward is lunch. In the World Cup, it is a yellow shirt worn by an Argentine player waving at a crowd of Brazilians.''

title: Yanks Win as Tolleson Races In on Kelly's Hit
description: The Yankees got another uninspiring pitching effort from Jimmy Jones yesterday, but one of three rookies in the lineup delivered a big home run and the Yanks scored a 5-4 triumph in 12 innings over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Tech Notes;   A Robot With the Brains, Build and Gait for Mars
description: If there is life on Mars, it may one day be rudely awakened by Ambler, a 12-foot-tall, six-legged walking robot being developed for National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Carnegie-Mellon University's Robotics Institute. With the software ''brains'' and motor skills to explore rugged terrain, Ambler could bring a new dimension to exploration of the solar system, NASA and University officials say. Because the robot literally walks, it can traverse rough terrain by stepping over crevices and large boulders, allowing it to reach areas on the Moon or Mars inaccessible to wheeled vehicles or too dangerous for humans.

title: Massachusetts Lawmakers Pass Bill to Raise Income and Gas Taxes
description: After three weeks of bitter negotiations that often lasted late into the night, the Massachusetts Legislature today sent a $1.6 billion tax package to the desk of Governor Michael S. Dukakis. The Governor's press secretary said Mr. Dukakis would sign the bill early next week.

title: Major Dilemma For Yankee Fan
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Headliners;   Ambling Along
description: Imelda Marcos had the shoes; now she has walked. In a case that began four years ago, Mrs. Marcos, the widow of former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was acquitted by a Federal court jury in Manhattan last week of helping her husband loot $200 million from the Philippine treasury and then investing the proceeds in art, jewelry and prime New York City real estate. Though the charges against her included defrauding American banks, jurors said afterward that they questioned whether Federal prosecutors had the right to charge her with other offenses that she and her husband were said to have committed in the Philippines. When the Marcoses fled to Hawaii in 1986, she was seen as the free-spending wife - thousands of pairs of shoes were found in her Manila palace closets - of a corrupt despot. But after Mr. Marcos died last year, there seemed much less interest in punishing his spouse. Said one juror, ''Just because she was married to him doesn't make her guilty.''

CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Nature Makes a Peerless Neighbor
description: LEAD: MY husband and I are adding onto our house - again. Over the years, we have enlarged the kitchen, turned an unfinished attic into living space and added to the living room. Now are adding a master bedroom.

title: By Old Carriage Roads on the Hudson, a New Hiking Trail
description: EACH week, after Robert Marshall completes his clerical duties for Metro-North, he returns to his home here, sheds his coat and tie, picks up his block and tackle and a couple of giant pry bars, and goes out to do his other work. Mr. Marshall, 54 years old, is a trail blazer. He has just designed and completed, with the help of volunteers from the Mohican Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club, a new eight-mile looped hiking trail on the east bank of the Hudson, just a few miles north of the Bear Mountain Bridge. Mr. Marshall is the trails chairman for the chapter.

In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Promoting the County's Business Virtues

description: Harvard advanced two of its boats today to Sunday's finals of the 151st Henley Royal Regatta, and those two will be the only United States representatives still competing from the 30 entered this year.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN Cape May
description: Technically, Cape May, N.J., is a beach resort. But the rather uninspiring stretch of sand there, packed though it may be on summer afternoons, is not the main point of this exuberantly Victorian town at the southeastern tip of New Jersey. Cape May, a National Historic Landmark, is made for strolling, for porch-sitting, for steeping oneself in the atmosphere of another era.

title: About Men;   Reunion In Da Nang
description: We are four of us, men in our early 30's, squatting on crude stools on a sidewalk in Da Nang, a perpetually sunny city on the central coast of Vietnam. At midmorning, the streets are crowded, noisy. The heat is unbearable. All four of us order iced coffee. For long moments, we stay silent, awkward. It has been 15 years since we were last together.

title: NONFICTION
description: LUMP IT OR LEAVE IT. By Florence King. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) In her new collection of essays, Florence King comes on - as usual - like someone with Tourette's syndrome at a diplomats' ball. At a time when what she likes to call ''caring 'n' compassion'' have sissified American public discourse, Ms. King does not believe in coddling the reader. The pages of ''Lump It or Leave It'' are splattered with the gore of sacred cultural cows: schoolteachers (''the Educationist Mafia''), the United States Constitution (''Mr. Nice Guy's hankie'') and democracy itself (''the crude leading the crud''). With the mouth of a truck driver (one given to protestations of hot flashes) and the mind of a Jesuit, she can write a mean tour de force, commuting felicitously from lit crit to historical commentary to buzzword-bashing satire to the Dixie-style memoir-comedy she patented in her splendid debut, ''Southern Ladies and Gentlemen.'' So bracing is Ms. King's oxymoronic literary persona - Republican sometime-lesbian, Hamiltonian scholarship student, cussing moralist, funny scold, anti-virginal spinster, etiquette-crazy anarchist, Southern intellectual - that I enjoyed the mildly self-serving essay on fame and her unintentionally elitist tirade against college diplomas and even the stretch of book reviews reprinted from Newsday. I got only a little nervous when she turned her reductio ad absurdum archness on school prayer (have two Protestant prayers a week, two Catholic and one Jewish) and abortion (give them routinely to rape victims). And reading her bizarrely gratuitous attack on Michael Dukakis's campaign manager, Susan Estrich, her incest-is-a-feminist-conspiracy argument and a militantly charmless reappraisal of Andrea Dworkin made me feel as if I were watching a favorite eccentric teacher turn into a nasty drunk.

title: German Aid to Iraq Reported
description: West German companies helped build a weapons factory in Iraq where a cannon was to be made, the German news magazine Der Spiegel said today. The Hamburg-based weekly said confiscated documents showed that the factory near Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, was designed to produce guns. Specialists fear that it was also the site where a cannon with a barrel 150 yards long and a range of 600 miles was to be built.

title: Eight Conductors Are Passing the Baton at Caramoor
description: THERE is more to ponder at the Caramoor Music Festival this summer than music's relationship to nature, or the stoicism of a wind player with a fly buzzing about his mouthpiece.

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor: I would like to warn prospective travelers in Portugal of the possible theft of their luggage from a van or station wagon. I remember vividly my shock and disbelief when five suitcases were stolen from our locked Ford while it was parked in a deluxe hotel parking lot. The remaining 10 days of our stay were largely devoted to replacement of my husband's prescription medicines, some clothing and other necessities. The police in Setubal, where the theft occurred, treated our complaint as a run-of-the-mill daily occurrence, and all of the guests at the pousada where we stayed the following night had similar experiences to recount.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Tributes Paid In a Manner That's Fitting
description: The memorial service has become an increasingly frequent rite for those close to the fashion industry. In the last few weeks alone, there have been tributes to three notable figures who died recently: the designer Halston, the model Pal Henry and the publicist Keezia Keeble.

title: MOVIES OF THEIR OWN
description: The camera focuses in on a stand of timber, trees in a quiet wood. The day has a look of fall to it, arcs of sunlight cutting through the spare foliage, the ground blanketed with leaves turned brown and bone dry. A breath of wind sends the leaves scuttling and, suddenly, a black fedora sails gently into the frame. The hat barely settles on the ground before the breeze lifts it up again and sends it, slowly spinning and tumbling end over end, into the distance until it is gone.

title:
The Nation;

A Rising Tide of Violence Leaves More Youths in Jail
description: LEAD: A rising number of the country's adolescents are being arrested for violent crimes, with a record 100,000 of them confined in correctional institutions on any given day. Although the number of young people is declining as the country's population ages, experts say an increase in poverty, drug use and single-parent families is feeding the problem and compelling states to re-examine juvenile justice programs.

description: About 300 Haitians chanted and marched peacefully Saturday outside a shopping center where police had violently broken up a demonstration two days earlier.

title: Navratilova Captures Ninth Singles Title
description: She straddled the net to acknowledge a badly beaten opponent and then, her courtside courtesies complete, Martina Navratilova sank down on her sore, old knees for an instant of silent communion with the tennis court she loves best.

title: Teachers' Union Seeks End to Tracking Policy
description: The nation's largest teachers' union issued a report today calling for a gradual end to the tracking policy of grouping students according to past performance.

title: Dance Keeps Cambodian Culture Alive
description: DRESSED in a beaded gold velvet costume so tight she had to be sewn into it, with stacks of golden bracelets encircling her wrists, silk flowers in her hair and her face and lips painted, Somaly Hay looked nothing like a boy. But she was wearing the costume of a young prince, in accordance with the traditions of Cambodian classical dance.

title: Talking: Resorts;   Finding Condo Tenants
description: A FANTASY of many buyers of resort condominiums is that when they are not using them their units will be rented by contented, careful vacationers. The upbeat sales literature for the resorts often encourages such expectations.

title: Patricia Shelley Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Gene Shelley of Scottsdale, Ariz., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Patricia A. Shelley and Serge J. L. Bushman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Bushman of New York.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Barrington, R.I.;

2 Developers Bucking Slump
description: LEAD: TWO developers of high-end houses in Rhode Island say they are finding buyers despite a 10 percent drop in real estate sales throughout the state since last year.

title: From Remotest Russia, Warmhearted Traditions
description: ''The Russian Village'' is an ingeniously convenient name for an unusual, warmhearted presentation of songs and folk dances from the northern Russian countryside that will begin a week of performances today in the New York City area.

title: Closing Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Finale Today
description: After a grand month of play, along with hooligans, penalty kicks, Italian flags and young men's faces painted in their national colors, the 1990 World Cup ends Sunday with a championship match in which West Germany is favored to defeat the team it lost to in the 1986 final, Argentina.

title: Life, Death And Government
description: When the advances of technology outstrip the quickening of ethical and moral values in a society, why then do we turn to the law for solutions? The ''right to die'' bill in in the New Jersey Legislature (''Bill to Allow Living Wills Draws Criticism,'' May 20) is yet another symptom of our dependence on government to make more and more of life's decisions.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE COUNTY COURTHOUSE;

The Pros and Cons of Security Often Lie in a Beep
description: LEAD: THEY may be part of a system with the formal sounding name of ''vertical security,'' but for at least one regular visitor, the metal detectors at the County Courthouse here are merely a nuisance.

title: Bulgarian Protest Continues Despite Ouster of President
description: Hundreds of intellectuals whose protests helped push President Petar Mladenov from office said today that they would not end their protests until other demands were met.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SEED OF SARAH: Memoirs of a Survivor. By Judith Magyar Isaacson. (University of Illinois, $18.95.) European culture may have failed the human race during the crucial Holocaust years, but it is vindicated in this memoir in the person of the young Judith Magyar. If the Hungarian teen-ager had the strength to survive Auschwitz, it was due to scraps of quotations from the classics (Sunt lacrimae rerum - ''There are tears for things''), songs and snatches of Hungarian poetry (''Life is a gift, sacred and choice / All who live /Rejoice, rejoice'').

title: Nora FitzGerald Married to Peter Finn
description: Nora Patricia FitzGerald, the associate editor of Connecticut magazine, and Peter Finn, a reporter, were married yesterday at St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in North Branford, Conn., by the Rev. Daniel F. McSheffrey. The bride, who will keep her name, is 29 years old and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. FitzGerald of Branford, Conn. Her husband, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Finn of Dublin.

title: FERNANDEZ TAKES CHARGE
description: Having been quoted by James Traub in his article, I would like to clarify the context of my remarks. As I noted, the chancellor's first steps have been to increase the system's central command position, as part of a strategy aimed at producing greater school-based autonomy and accountability. The fact that this move has not yet changed the climate of our schools is not, however, a criticism. The rush to make quick judgments has been a roadblock to school reform.

title:
WINE;

Modest Whites of Loire For Summer Chateaux
description: LEAD: WHEN looking for wine to have with summertime meals, consider bottles from the Loire Valley, in France. While not as well known in the United States as products from Bordeaux or Burgundy, a wide range of fresh, fruity Loire Valley whites are offered, at quite reasonable prices, by local restaurants and retail outlets.

title: On Language;   O Solecism Mio
description: At the biannual meeting of the Judson Welliver Society, the association of former White House speechwriters, the Kennedy Administration's Ted Sorensen rose to assail my use of biannual in the invitation: ''This word means 'twice a year,' not 'every two years'; either Mr. Safire has erred and should have said biennial, or I have not been invited to all the meetings.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

U.S. Offers A Dubious Model Of Freedom
description: LEAD: THE spirit of individual worth and dignity, suppressed for so many decades by state terrorism, is ascending in Eastern Europe, South Africa and elsewhere. Peoples in many countries are seeking what we have in abundance: the freedom to express ourselves, to choose candidates offered by a pluralistic political structure, to see our viewpoints reflected in public policy and our market decisions direct the economy.

title: New Jersey Computer Official Is Held in Car-Repair Bribery
description: An executive of the second largest company that processes claims for New Jersey's pool for high-risk drivers was arrested today on charges of accepting bribes to allow body shops and appraisal companies to inflate repair bills, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Three Voices And the Dangers Of Compromise
description: Contemporary pop is so overrun by commercial formulas these days that marketing considerations exert a powerful influence on the way a record company presents a new singer to the public.

title: A HOSTAGE RELEASE PREDICTED BY IRAN
description: The official Iranian press agency reported today that a Western hostage held in Lebanon, probably a European, was expected to be released shortly.

title: Breaking Up?
description: They have been teammates on the Indy-car circuit for a year and a half, but for Mario Andretti and his son Michael, that could end if there is substance to the speculation that Michael, 27 years old, will drive on the international Formula One circuit next year.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar. Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off. The deck was last painted several years ago, and much of it is now peeling. Where the cedar wood is exposed, it is gray and dull looking.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: DR. DAVID K. BLOOMGARTEN;

Helping Prevent Bones From Getting Brittle
description: LEAD: IT is one of those things that is hard for a 35-year-old woman to think about now - osteoporosis. But each year more than 1.3 million elderly people, mostly women, suffer fractures because of osteoporosis, a reduction in the bone mass that could have been prevented had steps been taken at an earlier age.

title: Sports of The Times;   The Fiasco of the 1990 Yankees
description: Eventually the Yankees announced the attendance as 25,120, but according to American League policy, that total included tickets that were sold but not necessarily used. At the start of Friday's twilight-night doubleheader with the Minnesota Twins, the spectators were so scattered they hardly outnumbered the pigeons swooping back and forth above the screen behind home plate and into the rafters under the upper deck.

title: Island Struggles With Increasing Toll of Children With AIDS
description: At 3 1/2 years of age, Peter likes to play with keys and ars and to swing on his swing set. Recently, his foster mother found him emptying onions out of the kitchen vegetable bin. By the time she spotted him, he had peeled every onion and was lying among the skins. Like any other child his age, he has a penchant for getting into mischief.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Hard-Won Lessons (for Mom and Dad) of Little League
description: LEAD: Daddy wants his son to play Little League baseball. Mommy isn't so sure.

title: Khomeini's Tomb Attracts Pilgrims
description: Here on the barren, sun-parched flats on the southern outskirts of Teheran, the Iranian Government is building a shrine to rival all but the greatest attractions of Islam - the final resting place for the man known here simply as the Imam.

title: Reflections on World Cup 1990
description: I strongly object to part of ''A Defeat Revives a Dream,'' (The Times, June 15). George Vecsey writes: ''The home-grown players do not develop the knack of scoring. Mussolini once lamented that his nation was a nation of waiters. It is not stretching the truth to say that Italy is currently a nation of midfielders.''

title: Michael Keohane Weds Ms. Mayer
description: Elizabeth Emma Mayer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Mayer of New York, was married yesterday in Laurel Hollow, L.I., to Michael William Keohane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Keohane of Livingston, N.J. The Rev. Burton Davison, a Methodist minister, conducted the nondenominational ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Newton, the bride's uncle and aunt.

title: Review/Music;   Alumni Sing at Tanglewood Gala
description: Tonight's opening concert of the Tanglewood season had the air of a class reunion. The festival's educational adjunct -the Tanglewood Music Center - is 50 years old this summer, and there were distinguished alumni in every size, shape and form trundling on and off the stage of the Shed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm 51, and I'm probably too old to handle four or five immersion realities at the same time.''

title: A Passion for Chocolate
description: Why all this fuss about Belgian chocolates, one wonders, as more and more of them appear on the grander avenues of the grander cities. Their current prominence seems to be due to the newly sophisticated marketing of the Belgian bonbon, and to the growing chocolate consciousness of the Western world.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's no news to most of us that life can be, and very often is, ornery. What's given with one hand is taken away with the other. Nice things happen at inopportune times (there's no opportune time for bad things), perfect plans are marred by the unexpected, sure things turn out to be not so sure, and small gambles that are almost certainties backfire.

title: Pauline Artioli Plans To Wed M. N. Findlay
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Artioli Jr. of Somers, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Pauline Ann Artioli and Michael Nielsen Findlay, a son of Mrs. E. Andrew Deeds of Charlotte, Vt., and David B. Findlay Jr. of New York.

title: Jean Paris, 62, Director Of Design for Cartier
description: Jean Paris, a former vice president and director of design for Cartier Inc. of New York, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: The Bitter Fight Over the Manville Trust
description: Hordes of lawyers will fill the benches of a courtroom at the United States Courthouse in Brooklyn tomorrow to watch what will happen with more than 500 plaintiffs who say they have suffered from inhaling asbestos at the Brooklyn Navy Yard more than 25 years ago. But the stakes are significantly greater than for just those former shipyard workers or their families.

title: The Characters Are in Charge
description: LYING TOGETHER

title: A Hideaway Treasure On The East End
description: IT is time for the annual phone call from my New Jersey friends asking where to eat in the Hamptons. My No. 1 recommendation for this season is East Hampton's Fresno. Forget the ''this season'' disclaimer; Fresno may be the best restaurant on the East End.

title: U.S. Soccer: Lights, Camera, Action!
description: The distance the United States soccer program must travel before the next World Cup in 1994, America's first turn at being host to the world's largest sporting event, is formidable. Without the opportunity to look back and see how far the sport has progressed in such a short time, America's task might seem insurmountable.

title: Deirdre Schaus and Christopher Painter Marry
description: Deirdre Olivia Schaus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday in Jamestown, R.I., to Christopher Enfield Painter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitfield Painter Jr. of Concord, Mass. The Rev. William J. O'Neill officiated at St. Mark Roman Catholic Church.

title: Poland's 'Big Bang' Gets a Bad Rap
description: To the Editor:

title: Karah Henry and Marc van Gelder Are Married
description: Karah Henry, a daughter of Frances McDonald Henry of Durham, N.C., and John F. Henry of Mattydale, N.Y., was married yesterday in Amsterdam to Marc C. van Gelder, a son of Mieke J. and Bob F. van Gelder-van Teeseling of Bussum, the Netherlands. The Rev. E. E. van Steenis, a minister of the Dutch Remonstrant Protestant Church, performed the ceremony at St. Vitus Church in Naarden, the Netherlands. The bride, a graduate of Yale University, was until recently an officer of the Mellon Bank (East) in Philadelphia. The bridegroom is a graduate of Erasmus University in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, with an M.B.A. degree from the University of Pennsylvania. He is to join the Amsterdam office of McKinsey & Company, management consultants, as an associate in September.

title: Commercial Property: Air Rights;   Developer Cuts a Deal With a White Plains Church
description: One of the first development-rights transfers in Westchester County has been concluded, setting the stage for a two-tower, half-million-square-foot commercial project in White Plains that would draw one-fifth of its bulk from the little country Gothic church beside which it would rise.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: Rickey Henderson. He is at or near the top in nine offensive categories. He also closes the outfield gaps as effectively as any left fielder in baseball.

title: Americans Should Travel Wherever They Wish;   Cuba Wants Tourists
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Year of Rebuilding, Tornado's Wrath Remains
description: LEAD: IT started somewhere near the Canadian border and barreled through upstate New York into northwestern Connecticut, shattering the quiet of a muggy July afternoon and forever changing the lives of people unaccustomed to the capricious fury of a killer tornado.

title: >A Show of Shapes, From 10 Sculptors
description: AT Krasdale Foods here is a show by the 10 artists who inaugurated the Food Center Sculpture Park last summer. The selection of 44 works - several of them prints and drawings - complements the outdoor display, and a good thing too, for this is scattered like a treasure hunt over the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center's 329 acres.

title: FICTION
description: TOWARD WHAT BRIGHT GLORY? By Allen Drury. (Morrow, $22.95.) In his 17th novel, Allen Drury has set himself the task of resurrecting campus life at Stanford University in the last academic year before World War II. From the vantage point of roughly a half-century, the period seems (as Evelyn Waugh described pre-Great War Oxford) as ''lost as Lyonnesse.'' However, in ''Toward What Bright Glory?'' Mr. Drury is less than successful in finding it again - and in making the reader care about his little California community. His is a world of wet-towel-snapping fraternity brothers, dumb football players and, of course, a wise, kindly university president. Indeed, the book is a platoon-movie novel. The usual suspects rounded up by Mr. Drury include a German-American Nazi sympathizer, a nisei who wants to be treated like a nonhyphenated American, a sensitive black, a South Carolina cracker, various Betty Coed paper dolls and - last but not least - the editor of the university daily, who has just returned from a trip to Germany and wants to use his paper to awaken the community to the Nazi menace. (The editor, Tim Bates, keeps notes on his fellow students, presenting Mr. Drury with a mother lode of quick and easy descriptive passages that do not have to be woven into the plot or otherwise tax the author's creativity.) If you think the title is pretentious, try the novel's prose. Mr. Drury has done better and, one hopes, will again.

title: Etienne Chatiliez Fishes His 'River' For Clues to Life
description: Etienne Chatiliez is the big noise these days in popular French cinema. In 1988, after directing some 70 television commercials notable both for their humor and their against-the-techno-glitz-grain narrative qualities, he made a resounding leap into feature film with ''Life Is a Long Quiet River,'' which opens in New York on Friday at the Paris Theater.

title: Jaworski Cut
description: The Kansas City Chiefs have put Ron Jaworski, the quarterback, on waivers and that means the 16-year pro, who led the Philadelphia Eagles to the 1981 Super Bowl, might have to call it a career. He's 39 years old and had signed as a Plan B free agent with the Chiefs last season, but appeared in only six games before suffering a sprained knee and spent the rest of the season on injured reserve.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Weighs Mideast Talks

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FOR GOOD CAUSES

title: The Region;   Connecticut Begrudgingly Considers an Income Tax.
description: About 20 years ago, Connecticut politicians tried tinkering with the state's tax system and brought on a political clampdown. They created and passed an income tax for the first time, but within weeks the law was repealed under a storm of public outrage. Tax reformers went underground, and a new generation of income-tax hard-liners within the state's majority Democratic party came to power.

title: Jose Durand, Professor And Author, Dies at 64
description: Jose Durand, a professor in the department of Spanish and Portuguese of the University of California at Berkeley, died last Sunday while on a sabbatical in his native Lima, Peru. He was 64 years old.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

My World of Wrinkles
description: LEAD: ''MOM!'' my daughter calls to me. ''Did you know that in seven years, when I'll be 16, your body will have stopped producing eggs?'' She has just finished reading about the human reproductive system. I am supposed to be thrilled that she is reading a book instead of Archie comics.

title: For a Kinder and Gentler World
description: A JOURNEY OF FAITH

title: How Old, Sweet Prince?
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress and the Monk
description: In late September of this year, Congress will have a splendid opportunity to honor itself and the name of the United States - and correct a great wrong done to a monk who leads a nation from exile.

title: Lifestyle;   Whiny Annoyance, or Watery Fun?
description: Flotillas of speedy little watercraft piloted by individual riders, some of them hardly old enough to ride a bicycle, are swarming the shores, lakes and rivers of the Northeast and are generating the kind of excitement and controversy that first accompanied snowmobiles and dirt bikes.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fairfield
description: Fairfield, a 30-square-mile Connecticut town on Long Island Sound that Leonard Bernstein and Jason Robards call home, has the energy and cosmopolitan air of a small city.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: Attitude cannot be taught. Gregg Jefferies has my vote.

title: Misuse of Savings Bailout Reported in Texas Purchase
description: An Arizona insurance executive with a history of legal and regulatory problems was allowed to buy 15 insolvent Texas savings and loan associations with borrowed money in 1988 and was promised $1.85 billion in Federal subsidies. Congressional investigators call the arrangement the worst abuse found in the Federal bailout program.

title: The Yankees' Week That Was
description: SUNDAY Three weeks after almost being released, Andy Hawkins pitches a no-hitter in Chicago and loses, 4-0. The Yankees commit three errors in the eighth inning to allow the runs. Hawkins becomes the first pitcher in 23 years to lose a complete-game no-hitter, the first in modern baseball history to pitch an eight-inning complete-game no hitter.

title: Barry's Ordeal Accents City's Racial Divisions
description: In recent days the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has sprawled far beyond the courtroom, becoming a painful morality play that has transfixed this city and generated extraordinary soul-searching among its citizens.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Gathering of Golf Elders

title: Barbara Clayton and George Shinopoulos Wed
description: Barbara Hall Clayton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Clayton of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday in Waitesfield, Vt., to George Shinopoulos, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Shinopoulos of Boston. The Rev. Paul Martz conducted the Presbyterian ceremony at the Federated Church.

title: FERNANDEZ TAKES CHARGE
description: James Traub depicts well the problems of corruption and inertia Joseph Fernandez faces as chancellor of the New York City schools system (''Fernandez Takes Charge,'' June 17). But his article overlooks one ironic aspect of the situation, namely that Stanley S. Litow and Robin Willner, the powers who installed Fernandez, were themselves rewarded with posh jobs as his top lieutenants. In other contexts, people would be yelling conflict of interest.

title: Held Captive by Cleopatra
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD: PEOPLE IN TROUBLE. By Sarah Schulman. (Dutton, $17.95.) In her ambitious fourth novel, Sarah Schulman drops the tough-girl Raymond Chandlerisms that were both the strength and the limitation of her last book, ''After Delores,'' in favor of prose that is spare, quick and flexible. Her range of subject and sympathy has grown as well.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: In this unfortunate age of overpaid underachievers, Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs leads the majors in hits, runs scored and times at bat. He is second in home runs and batting average, and tied for third in the National League in runs batted in. And, everyone already knows that he is the best-fielding second baseman in the game.

title: From a Model to Just Another Farm
description: On this large collective farm, where the former government once demonstrated the virtues of Communist agriculture to foreign visitors, the fears of the 2,500 members far overshadow the hopes raised in this country by the coming of the West German mark.

title: Hungary Communists on Film With Terrorist
description: State television today showed a secret film of talks between Hungarian officials and the international terrorist known as Carlos about 10 years ago and portrayed him as a playboy who sought out women and stayed in luxury hotels.

title: Another Grief Observed
description: REBUILDING THE HOUSE

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q.Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar. Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off. The deck was last painted several years ago, and much of it is now peeling. Where the cedar wood is exposed, it is gray and dull looking.

title: No Gay Rights Vote In Massachusetts
description: Opponents of a Massachusetts law protecting homosexuals from discrimination cannot try to repeal it through a referendum, the state's Supreme Judicial Court has ruled.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: During a recent trip to Spain as a guest at the Macarena Sol Hotel in Seville, my cameras were stolen. This took place under the nose of my wife who only looked down to address a postcard. I think that you should warn travelers to Spain, especially in light of the 1992 Olympics and Columbus celebrations, that they should hold on to their valuables, even in the lobby of a four-star hotel.

title:
MUSIC;

State Symphony to Lead Irish Fete
description: LEAD: WHAT began as a last-ditch effort to prevent the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra from going on strike last fall has resulted in a music festival of international proportions.

title: Cazuza, Brazilian Singer, 32
description: Cazuza, a popular singer and composer in Brazil who emerged as a symbol in the country's fight against AIDS, died in his sleep today after a four-year struggle with the disease. He was 32 years old.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: Kirby Puckett. Who else can lead the league in hitting, drive in 100 runs, steal you a base and win the Gold Glove in one of the most active positions in the game?

title: Minority Businesses: The Need Is Money
description: OF all the challenges facing those who own small businesses, the most difficult is often borrowing the money needed to grow.

title: Taxes in Other Countries Buy More Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Post-Poughkeepsie
description: THE GOD OF NIGHTMARES

title: 9 States Unlawfully Jail Runaways, Group Says
description: A Federal law intended to stop states from locking up runaway juveniles has succeeded in keeping tens of thousands of them free, but the National Coalition for the Homeless says nine states are still violating the law.

title: Latchkey Summer
description: Some of the most popular baby sitters in the city are named Nintendo, Bugs Bunny and the Brady Bunch. Some of the most popular baby sitters in the city are 9 or 10 or 11 years old. School lets out at 3 o'clock. Mom and Dad get home at 6. Some people have their bigger children tend the small ones, and some have their children go home and watch television and wait for the sound of their key in the lock.

title: Grant Lets Lyndhurst Hire Education Curator
description: LEAD: WHEN Susanne Brendel-Pandich, director of Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, received a $75,000 grant from the Institute of Museum Services, she knew just how she wanted to use it.

title:
FOCUS: New Hampshire Lakes;

New Hope for Sales of Second Homes
description: LEAD: THE Lakes Region of New Hampshire is moving into the summer tourist season with real estate professionals hopeful that sales of second homes and vacation properties will increase this season after nearly two years of slow sales and plummeting prices.

title: The Executive Computer;   Worries About Radiation Continue, as Do Studies
description: New studies continue to raise the troubling possibility that even the low levels of radiation emitted by most computer monitors have the potential to cause health problems.

title: Manhattan, Not Hoboken
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Campus Life: Texas;   After 5 Decades, A Movie Theater Shuts Its Doors
description: A landmark campus-area movie theater has shut its doors. The Varsity Theater, which opened when Franklin D. Roosevelt was ending his first Presidential term, had long been a haven for hundreds of thousands of University of Texas students.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IN THE SHADOW OF THE DOME: Chronicles of a Capitol Hill Aide. By Mark Bisnow. (Morrow, $20.95.) Abscam, Angola, the Iran-contra affair, Wedtech, record deficits, the Reagan revolution, the rise of political action committees - in the 12 years Mark Bisnow served as legislative aide to Senator Hubert Humphrey, Representative John Anderson, Senator Robert Dole and others, Capitol Hill rocked with political drama.

title: Why Persist With the 'Armed Struggle'?
description: Despite their applause for Nelson Mandela, many Americans are uneasy about his insistent defense of ''the armed struggle'' in the fight against apartheid. Understandably so: violence that may once have been fully justified to Mr. Mandela now seems counterproductive in view of the startling changes in South Africa.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: Len Dykstra. Is there another ballplayer who brings a bigger grin to the face of any real baseball fan?

title: Cathie J. Martin, Professor, Weds
description: Cathie J. Martin, a daughter of Robert M. Martin of Lexington, Mo., and Mary T. MacKenzie of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to James R. Milkey at the home of his parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert K. Milkey of Granby, Conn. The Rev. Jennifer Phillips performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Kelly Healey Plans October Wedding
description: Kelly Ann Healey, a public relations representative, and Peter James Albano, a vice president and bond trader, both at Salomon Brothers in New York, are planning an October wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Healey of Barrington, Ill., have announced.

title: MOTHERS: TIRED OF TAKING THE RAP
description: Let's stop blaming mothers and turn our attention toward making the world a better place in which to raise children.

title: Headliners;   For the Short Run
description: On the way to his next attempt at getting himself into the White House, the Rev. Jesse Jackson intends to work on getting the District of Columbia into the union. Mr. Jackson announced last week that he would run for the newly created D.C. post of ''shadow senator,'' the main duty of which is to lobby Congress for statehood. Critics sought to diminish the importance of the unsalaried job, which Mr. Jackson is expected to win in November. Al From, head of the Democratic Leadership Council, said the shadow senator experience would not satisfy those critics of Mr. Jackson's Presidential ambitions ''who say he needs to prove he can govern.'' But Mr. Jackson argued that statehood for Washington, whose population equals that of Alaska, Vermont or Delaware, is ''the most important civil rights and social justice issue in America today.''

title: A Bitter Battle Rages Over Asbestos Claims
description: The Manville Trust was meant to compensate tens of thousands of workers dying or diseased from exposure to asbestos. But the two-year-old trust is already out of cash, because of higher than expected payments to early claimants and large attorneys' fees. Many victims will have to wait until 2015 to get any payments.

title: Time-Ravaged Tapes Pass On Their Priceless Music to CD's
description: To the delight of serious collectors, older recordings of outstanding musical merit are constantly being reissued on CD. Yet the process of transfer to the new digital format led to a sad discovery. Many priceless master tapes of yesteryear had deteriorated, seemingly beyond hope of restoration.

title: Eileen Reynolds, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Eileen Mary Reynolds, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Reynolds of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married yesterday in Newburgh, N.Y., to Ian William Weetman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Weetman of Whissel, Lancashire, England. Msgr. J. Bernard Caverly performed the ceremony at the chapel of Mount St. Mary College.

title: Louisiana Senate Sustains Roemer's Veto of Anti-Abortion Bill
description: The Louisiana State Senate today upheld the Governor's veto of a bill that would have created the strictest anti-abortion law of any state, all but killing any chances that the bill would become law.

title: Evening Hours;   A Macy's Party And a Tribute To Swimwear
description: On Wednesday, 475 guests of R. H. Macy's chief executive, Edward S. Finkelstein, were treated to an unobstructed view of Macy's annual Fourth of July pyrotechnics display over the East River. They included Macy's executives, their families and guests from the worlds of fashion and theater. They boarded the Dutchess of New York yacht for a leisurely dinner cruise around the harbor, docking on the Long Island City side of the river at sunset.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The history of the game is replete with accidents of various kinds. The first occurred in 1929 when Ely Culbertson took his foursome to Paris following a victory in London. The scoring was French-style ''plafond'' with which the Americans were not familiar and the host country had a small lead throughout.

title: The Power Behind All Those Ads
description: This year, for the third year in a row, owners of Acura automobiles ranked them the most satisfying in America in the prestigious J. D. Power Customer Satisfaction Index survey of product quality and dealer service.

title: Laldenga, Tribal Leader in India, 53
description: Laldenga, a leader of India's Mizo tribe who fought a secessionist war before joining mainstream politics, died today in London, the Press Trust of India reported. He was 53 years old.

title: ARIEL SHARON: TALKING TOUGH
description: Ariel Sharon is in a typically expansive mood. Midway through a late lunch at the Gush Katif cafe, deep inside one of the Gaza Strip's oldest Jewish settlements, he puts down his spoon, leans back in his chair and stretches his arms toward the panorama outside.

title: Outdoors;   A Farmer's Food for Thought
description: Many of the books that come my way from publishing houses for possible review deal with presumably better ways to outwit some species of fish or game animal, or describe in detail the twists and turns of foot trails that lead one through forest and mountain in various regions of this country.

title: MOTHERS: TIRED OF TAKING THE RAP
description: In referring to biological research on mental illness, Janna Malamud Smith states: ''Schizophrenia is no longer understood only as the product of a mother's intrusive and smothering behavior. (She may be a player, but hardly alone on the stage.)''

description: Psst! Have you heard? It seems Garry Trudeau is, just maybe, a secret stamp fancier.

title: BRUSSELS FINDS A MARKET FOR EUROCHIC
description: DEVIL-MAY-CARE, indifferent to propriety, perhaps even lsightly outrageous, the Manneken-Pis statue has served for centuries as the symbol of Brussels and as a stand-in for the typical Bruxellois. The little boy with the gentle smile, however, may be feeling his age as the city around him under-goes its transformation from simply the capital of Belgium to the capital of Europe.

title: Lift U.S. Sanctions on Transkei
description: LEAD: The positive changes afoot in the world today have produced new hope for oppressed peoples, a new demand for democratic institutions, new expectations for individual rights and a new desire for economic opportunity and free enterprise.

title: An Architecture That Set Out to Shake the World
description: It is convenient to forget that for a brief moment in the 20th century, the Soviet Union was a throbbing center of modern art and architecture, perhaps even the most advanced country of all in terms of its official level of taste. Modernism was not born there, but it could well be said to have reached its fastest, and in some ways its most promising, flowering in the Soviet Union. Where else, after all, could modernism's utopian, socialist leanings be in such perfect sync with everything going on in the realm of politics? Art as revolution, revolution as art: in the late teens and through the 1920's, art and revolution were as one, the new art the perfect embodiment of the new world the Leninists were making.

title: Gorbachev Heads Off Threat
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev brought his unruly Communist Party congress under control, heading off a threat to his leadership team. Page 4.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: Tony Gwynn, because he has done it all: hit, field and throw, run, and win longer and better and more consistently than anyone else.

title: Diligence and Pride Keep Old Skills Alive
description: THE steady rush of the Still River, which winds past the old grist mill in Brookfield, offers those who visit the Brookfield Craft Center one of many glimpses of the past. During the 1800's, the main building in the community housed the Brookfield Mills and general store, where townspeople came to gossip and to barter food, ironware, furniture and other goods.

title: Defiant Moscow Council Acts To Give Away All Apartments
description: The brash new City Council, opting for a utopian antidote to Communism, has voted to take the city's entire apartment housing stock from the state's control and give it away free to millions of hard-suffering tenants.

title: Our Disastrously Archaic Farm Policy
description: Our 60-year farm-policy civil war is increasingly devastating to American competitiveness. The Department of Agriculture will reward farmers for keeping idle almost 60 million acres this year - equivalent to shutting down all the crop land in California, Colorado, Kentucky, Louisiana, Montana and Wisconsin. Paying farmers not to work has become the foundation of American farm policy.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: Two influences, one American, one Soviet, have conspired to give Soviet players opportunities they never had before.

title: AIDS-Infected Children Often Treated Belatedly
description: FOR most of its victims, AIDS is a disease that might have been prevented.

Graham of Florence, S.C., at the Capt. Flanders House, an inn in Chilmark, Mass. Bernard Issokson, a justice of the peace in Tisbury, Mass., officiated.

When in Trouble, Start More

Mee Jr., whose theater works include ''The Investigation of the Murder in El Salvador'' and ''Imperialists at Club Cave Canem.'' The speech was delivered last month in Northampton, Mass., to the Theater Communications Group, the national organization of nonprofit professional theaters.

description: Sandra Alison Lane, a candidate for a master's degree in public health at Columbia University, and Jonathan Aaron Ballan, an associate at the New York law firm of Dewey Ballantine Bushby Palmer & Wood, plan to marry in September. Miss Lane is the daughter of Dr. Stanley L. Lane of New York and the late Sylvia Lane. Mr. Ballan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Ballan of Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Teachers Outline Needs For Students at Risk
description: LEAD: STUDENTS in large high schools who are in danger of dropping out or not working to their full potential should be served by alternative programs and taught by teachers who enjoy counseling as much as teaching, according to a survey of 50 teachers in five Westchester school districts.

description: President Bush told Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan today that the Administration would not oppose Japanese plans to resume its multibillion-dollar program of aid to China. But he urged Mr. Kaifu to slow down the aid plan and limit its scope.

Putting One's Legs to Good Use

Westerners are more accustomed to two-strokes in lawnmowers than in cars.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Yup, Camp Sounded Just Swell
description: LEAD: EARLY last spring, my husband and I were surprised to hear that our two older children wanted to go to sleep-away camp. I was immediately filled with mixed emotions. Their younger brother would have no one to fight with. I would not need to cook for every child in the neighborhood. Greenwich is a treasure trove of activities in the summer, but I wouldn't have any children at home to drive to and from all of these wonderful things.

title: FICTION
description: THE RED-HAIRED WOMAN: And Other Stories. By Sigerson Clifford. (Mercier Press/Dufour Editions, Paper, $9.95.) ''Imagination is everything in a world going fast to the devil with realism,'' says a character in one of the playwright Sigerson Clifford's delicious tales, which first appeared in several Irish newspapers and were brought together in 1989, four years after his death. The words describe a grandfatherly storyteller who could be Clifford himself, judging from the philosophy at work in these very brief pieces, which seem to be bits of local Irish lore molded into the form of the modern short story. Each entry in ''The Red-Haired Woman: And Other Stories'' is a quick, often profound glimpse of Irish life, mostly in the countryside. The characters appear, fall into a bit of trouble and get wherever they're going without a lot of palaver. The simple plots glisten with semiprecious gems of language. In ''The Go-Getter,'' for example, an immigrant returning from America tells us that the Irish hills ''had clean faces with every tooth of rock scrubbed until it shone like a shilling. There was so much blue in the sky it seemed as though the sky had fallen'' - a reflection not only of the landscape but of the legendary fear of the ancient Celts that the heavens would collapse. In other stories, the fears of modern Celts are also described. The mood of these characters is often suggested by the weather (''a cold night for January, with frost polishing the stars as we huddle closer to the Corner away from the teeth of the wind'') or by the look of their homes (''a small, thatched, tramp's hat of a house, limewashed a dirty white, with one tiny window like a mouse's eye peering at the passing world''). The most haunting story is that of a retired schoolmaster who recalls, with a smile, a student essay in its entirety: ''I went for a walk yesterday evening around by Mulvey's Mill. I saw nobody and nobody saw me.'' A few days later, he goes out for a walk on Christmas Eve, unobserved and alone.

description: It is refreshing to see a man like Joseph Fernandez take charge.

title: Fashion;   FOLLOWING ORDERS Stretch urethane bustier. To order from Frederick's of Hollywood. (800) 323-9525. Boa: Allan & Suzi. Skirt: Jeanette for St. Martin. Stockings: Fogal. Ring: Maria Snyder. Charles Eames chair: Full House;
description: In his pursuit of fashion novelty, Franco Moschino of Italy might well have thumbed through the Frederick's of Hollywood catalogue. So might Thierry Mugler of France, Katharine Hamnett of Britain or, for that matter, any number of world-class style provocateurs in search of new ideas. Leggy body stockings, lacy lingerie, slick bustiers - the venerable catalogue is rife with items that have influenced designers on both sides of the Atlantic. The most arresting of these have coolly made the transfer to fashion's runways. Catalogues, from steamy Frederick's to sunny L. L. Bean, have long been a source of design inspiration - some of it right for summer evenings. Conversely, many of the most talked-about notions to surface on international catwalks have been interpreted by the catalogues in racy, well-priced variations. Here are a few.

title: With Satay and Tiger Prawns, Fiery Thai Food Is a Hit in L.A.
description: There are at least 120,000 Thais living in the greater Los Angeles area today - more than in any other region outside Thailand itself. What has drawn them to the city? Prakas Yenbamroong, a Thai banker-turned-restaurateur who has himself been an L.A. resident since 1979, suspects that it has something to do with the area's climate, which he considers not unlike that of Thailand- and, he adds unexpectedly, with the city's profusion of Chinese and Mexican restaurants. Both, he explains, use many foodstuffs that Thais find familiar and appealing, among them rice, chilies, garlic and cilantro. ''One way or another,'' he adds, ''I can assure you that the food angle was important in making Thais feel at home here.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Tag Sale: Get Rid of the Junk, but Keep the Memories
description: LEAD: AT first, it appeared to be an ordinary Saturday morning on our suburban street. Youngsters were on their bikes; gardeners were on their knees.

title: What the Met Can Learn From Madonna
description: The history of classical-music performance since the time of Bach has been, in large part, a history of scale. Not musical scales, but scale in terms of size. As audiences and ensembles have grown, so have the spaces in which performances were to take place. That, in turn, meant brighter, louder instruments along with augmented performing forces.
