description: Mike Kingery hit a two-run single in the ninth inning and Gary Carter went 5 for 5 as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Chicago Cubs today, 10-9.

title:
ART;

Sculpture Show Is Feisty and Raucous

Adding to the pleasure is learning that the curator, Paul Brenner, did not set out to be contentious, nor did he attempt a survey of Connecticut art.

title: Charges on Raceway Project Revived
description: LEAD: AS the Town of Hempstead considers a zoning change to allow a $1 billion development project at the former Roosevelt Raceway, charges of possible fraud and special treatment involving the owners of the former raceway and prominent Republicans are being revived and rebutted.

title: Bach Repertory Heard At Summer Music 1990
description: LAST year at this time, concerts were filled with French music, for the French bicentennial. On Saturday, Bastille Day, the French flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal will be among the guest artists at the opening of Summer Music 1990 at Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, but the repertory is Bach.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Museum Is 90, but Young at Heart
description: On sultry summer days, when a child's toughest decision may be whether to sell lemonade or draw with crayons, the Brooklyn Children's Museum ranks as one of the more sophisticated - and fun - places to learn something.

title: Reclaiming Noble Gardens In Wales
description: Wild Wales, with its naturally picturesque landscape, gnarled trees and trickling water, has come into its own in the garden world. A number of important things have happened. First, with the founding last year of the Welsh Historic Gardens Trust in Llandeilo in the county of Dyfed in South Wales, there is a new focus on recovering abandoned and ruined gardens and parks. Two formerly neglected gardens, which recently opened near Llandeilo, inspired the formation of the gardens trust, which will encourage restoration and provide expert advice.

description: STARDUST

title: Jill Dara Suttenberg to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Suttenberg of Syosset, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Jill Dara Suttenberg and David Matthew Altshuler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Altshuler of Belmont, Mass. Miss Suttenberg, 24 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. An associate at Corporate Decisions, a Boston management consulting firm, she is also a saxophonist and the director of the Sunday Jazz Band at Harvard. Her father is an engineering department manager at the Unisys Corporation in Lake Success, L.I. Her mother, Judye Suttenberg, is a division sales manager in the Plainview, L.I., office of World Book Childcraft International, an educational publishing company in Chicago.

title: Technology Helps the Blind On the Job
description: AS technology spawns the production of higher-quality, less expensive computer, video and audio products, an increasing number of new tools are being made available to the blind and visually impaired that greatly widen their academic and career opportunities, experts say.

description: Rafael Rivera Garcia, a highly regarded Puerto Rican art professor who said the police, courts and city agencies left him defenseless against the terrifying harassment of a biased white neighbor, was acquitted yesterday of trying to murder the man.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: WHO is the best-known fictional character from New Jersey? Is it the Jewish American princess of Philip Roth's ''Goodbye Columbus''? The Hoboken longshoreman of ''On the Waterfront'' (''I coulda been a contender'')?

title: Wall Street;   If You Believe in Domestic Oil . . .
description: The stock market just can't seem to make up its mind about oil.

title:
DINING OUT;

An Informal Mexican Setting in Armonk
description: LEAD: IN an area chockablock with so-called upscale restaurants, the informal Mariachi Mexico offers welcome alternative dining. This tiny 11-table neighborhood restaurant, dwarfed further by the abutting post office, serves many of the familiar dishes of what in these parts passes for Mexican cuisine. But Mariachi's versions run a cut above the gloppy conglomerates found so often in other such restaurants.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Quincy, Mass.;

Lower Prices Move Condos
description: LEAD: PRICE reductions have spurred condominium sales in this waterfront city of 89,000 on Boston's southern border and opened the market to a new group - first-time buyers, often young.

title: South America
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from five weeks' travel in South America (Chile, Bolivia and Ecuador) and have been reading about the hooliganism in Moscow and State Department warnings regarding travel in Lithuania and other countries.

title: Science Fiction
description: In BEYOND THE FALL OF NIGHT (Ace/Putnam, $19.95), Arthur C. Clarke and Gregory Benford collaborate to bring forth a fascinating if ultimately unsatisfying chimera. The starting point was Mr. Clarke's first novel, ''Against the Fall of Night,'' which he began writing before his 21st birthday and which was first published in 1948 (after many revisions and time out for World War II) in a pulp magazine called Startling Stories. The young Clarke was a space-travel enthusiast before that was fashionable, and, as readers of his later books like ''Childhood's End'' and ''2001'' know, he is a scientific dreamer who can forge poetry from an engineer's blueprint.

title: Topics of the Times;   Mitch Snyder's Anger
description: Sometimes anger serves a social purpose. That was clearly true in the case of Mitch Snyder, who died last week at the age of 46. His anger about the condition of the homeless in America fueled a national cause.

title: The Region;   In Albany, Everything Important Seems to Happen at the Last Minute
description: It is only in the frantic final days of the legislative session, when dozens of new laws may be created in a single hour, that the New York State Legislature really seems to accomplish anything substantial.

title: The Unquiet Life Next to Building Sites
description: NINA SKLANSKY moved into her new apartment on West 55th Street last August and, boy, was she pleased with it. Then, on her first night there, through the windows and out of the walls came the BANG! and the CRASH! and the CLANNNGG! from the hotel being built across the street. ''It was like dinosaurs fighting out there,'' she said. Besides giving her second thoughts about her cherished apartment, the nighttime din from construction of the Rihga Royal Hotel soon made Ms. Sklansky part of a cause that engages more and more New Yorkers these days: the campaign against construction noise.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Shore Clothes (Regulation 1, Section C)
description: LEAD: NOT many people realize that the New Jersey Legislature had the great foresight and wisdom to institute a Jersey Shore Dress Code in time for the 1990 season. I will explain this code's impact on two of the 64 articles of clothing that are now subject to state regulation.

Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;

Old Tire Plant Rolling Again
description: LEAD: The owners of a 720,000-square-foot former tire factory in White Marsh Township are spending about $14 million on renovations to create a low-cost office and light-industry center.

description: COW

description: Q. Our family plans to visit Australia in October. We are interested in visiting an aborigine family. - Barbara Johnson, Brooklyn

title: Security Lapses Bring Rocky Flats Shutdown
description: Security lapses, including a metal detector that had been adjusted by workers tired of hearing it set off by their steel-toe boots, has prompted a suspension of more operations at the Government's Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant.

title: FICTION
description: FURORS DIE. By William Hoffman. (Louisiana State University, $18.95.) William Hoffman's 10th novel is an ambitious, well-written book. Its great theme is that the believer, the person of conscience and religious faith, is destined for destruction in our dissolute culture. Amos (Pinky) Cody is the son of a poor, alcoholic father and a mother who appears to be a religious fanatic. As a teen-ager, he witnesses the prevention of his father's arrest for public drunkenness. Vowing to work for the man who intervened, one Mr. DuVal, Pinky insinuates himself into a position performing odd jobs at DuVal's office, thus setting himself on a collision course with the boss's son, Wylie. Set in the coal country of West Virginia, ''Furors Die'' traces the lives of Pinky and Wylie through their teen-age and college years, and on into adulthood, marriage and careers. Predictably, the spoiled, privileged Wylie is nonchalant about everything from tennis to sexuality. Indeed, the major flaw in this novel may be that Wylie, who has no deep inner conflict or drive, is placed at its center. Pinky, his antagonist, is the sufferer and the tragic figure, the poor-boy-become-capitalist who is ultimately corrupted. The antithesis of Wylie, Pinky is distorted by greed and his envy of and admiration for the well-bred rich. Yet Mr. Hoffman stands back from Pinky, even occasionally satirizing him for his social and sexual ignorance. Despite its flaws, ''Furors Die'' is a quickly paced, well-plotted work that links individual moral corruption with larger concerns like social justice and environmentalism. It entertains while offering insight into some of the most important issues of our time.

title: Krone Set to Ride
description: Her workout aboard Howling Success was just that, Julie Krone said yesterday at Monmouth Park, where the jockey took the first step back toward her return to competitive riding. After riding the horse a half-mile, Krone declared herself ready to resume racing. Krone fractured a forearm Nov. 24 in a spill at the Meadowlands and had surgery twice. (AP)

title: All About/Reformulated Gasolines;   As Pressure Grows, Refiners Develop Cleaner Fuels
description: It is as if oil refiners had joined the Sierra Club. Company after company has come out with gasoline reformulated to be kinder to the environment. In this earth-conscious era, oil companies are competing to be green and clean.

title:
RECORDINGS;

Seasoned Performers Display Their Specialties
description: LEAD: Time was when a Bruno Walter felt himself unprepared to conduct Mozart's G minor Symphony until he had reached his 40's, and an Arturo Toscanini declared himself ''almost satisfied'' when he finally approved release of a recording of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. These days decisions regarding artists and repertory are too frequently made solely on the basis of expediency: to fulfill contractual obligations requiring a minimum number of releases per year, perhaps, or to capitalize on an artist's sudden rise to popularity.

title: Waltrip Hurt
description: The milestone race that Darrell Waltrip thought he would be in yesterday went off without him, just as the races over the next two months will probably do. Only hours after eating a piece of cake to celebrate what would have been the 500th Nascar race of his career, Waltrip wound up in a hospital on Friday night with serious injuries from a seven-car crash he was involved in at Daytona International Speedway in a practice run for yesterday's Pepsi 400.

title: The World;   Beyond Plain Vanilla: Immigration Has Accentuated Canada's Diversity
description: As the historical story goes, when Jacques Cartier, the French explorer, stepped ashore in 1535 at the rapids near what was to become Quebec City, he confronted a band of curious natives. Looking around at the pristine countryside, he asked them in French and sign language what they called that place. The Indians, looking about their humble village, replied ''kanata.'' It is the Huron-Iroquois word for ''settlement.''

title: Style Makers;   Hieu Dam, Bustier Designer
description: Hieu Dam is to the ordinary woman in Los Angeles what Jean-Paul Gaultier is to Madonna. Like Mr. Gaultier, she designs bustiers. In the last year, the 22-year-old designer, who lives in Los Angeles, has specialized in bustiers and bras - all lavishly ornamented with sequins, pearls, lace or safety pins. They are designed to be flaunted. Women wear her bustiers with leggings, miniskirts and sarongs - but mainly under suits, in place of camisoles or tank tops.

title: Postings: Community-Minded Savings;   Account Ability
description: Most thrift institutions these days boast about how much more they pay for customers' deposits than the competition, and some have gotten into financial trouble for being too generous. But the Dime Savings Bank of New York has a new program that boasts of paying less than the competition, and of letting the depositors provide the generosity.

title: Rock, Rap and Reggae Rolled Into One
description: The legacy of the 1980's is quick-change, recombinant rock - music that jumps from style to style without worrying about transitions or fusions. A wave of bands is knocking together rock, rap, funk, reggae and hard core, simultaneously honoring and defying pop's fragmentation.

title: How Officers in a Florida City Test Stun Guns: the Hard Way
description: Police officers here have been authorized to use stun guns as an alternative to nightsticks, but there is a catch: any officer who wants to use the device must be stunned by it first to know what it feels like.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Swapping Low Prices for High Density
description: LEAD: A Proposal by the Long Island Builders Institute that municipalities permit high-density housing on land zoned for commercial and light-industrial use has received mixed reviews from town officials and planners.

title: C. D. O'Connor, 92, Who Headed School For the Deaf, Is Dead
description: Clarence D. O'Connor, superintendent emeritus of the Lexington School for the Deaf in Jackson Heights, Queens, died on June 29 at New York Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: State Is Disappointed By Gambling Revenues
description: GAMBLING revenues for the 1990 fiscal year, which ended last week, were disappointing, state officials said. But they expressed hope that several changes in the state lottery would increase the state's take this year.

title: Fashion;   Refreshing a Summer Wardrobe
description: Clothes for a summer weekend: shorts, shirts, sweaters, easy jackets and, of course, pants. It's all very simple. Whether your weekends are spent in town or in the country, the formula is essentially the same.

title: Calling a Book a Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar. Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off. The deck was last painted several years ago, and much of it is now peeling. Where the cedar wood is exposed, it is gray and dull looking.

title: Barbara Ashbrook Wed in Washington
description: Barbara Ann Ashbrook and Sidney Freidberg were married yesterday at their home in Washington by Chief Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Colleen F. Gibbs To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. John David Gibbs of Arlington Heights, Ill., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Colleen Frances Gibbs and Cornelius DeForest Howland 3d, a son of Mrs. Cornelius D. Howland of Millbrook, N.Y., and the late Mr. Howland.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Hamilton, Ohio;

Guarantees Near a Landfill
description: LEAD: A PAPER mill creating an industrial landfill near here has put into place a program, 18 months in the making, to protect owners of property within two miles of the facility from any loss in resale value.

title: Kate Rentschler Wed in Michigan
description: Kate Mason Rentschler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Rentschler of Walloon Lake, Mich., was married yesterday to James Keith Ausbrook, a son of Perry C. Ausbrook of Washington and the late Dale Kimble Ausbrook. The Rev. Frank Kordek, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Cook, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Holy Childhood of Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Harbor Springs, Mich.

title: Letter From Tokyo: Brando, the Stones and Banana Yoshimoto
description: As a new generation of Japanese novelists achieves cult status in Japan, with books frequently selling millions of copies in hard-cover editions alone, publishers in New York and Tokyo are making a fresh effort to internationalize the market for Japanese fiction. Already some of the Japanese publishing houses have employed bilingual editors from New York and London to make sure that the translations do justice to the authors.

title: Style Makers;   Dominique Aurientis, Accessories Designer
description: In New York recently, Dominique Aurientis wore huge elephant-head earrings, half a dozen lapel pins, a scarf dangling golden charms, and two armloads of bracelets with gilded trimming. Of course, the jewelry was all of her own design, and marked by a soupcon of wit and a large dose of sophistication.

title:
ART;

Blurring Artistic Distinctions
description: LEAD: IN ''Out of Abstraction,'' the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum in East Islip, eight artists use the principles of abstraction as the basis for works that are rooted in reality.

title: The Broad Benefits of a Gasoline Tax Hike
description: Do you wish gas prices were as cheap as they were in the ''good old days'' of the 1950's? If so, you might be surprised to learn that you would be hoping for an increase in gas prices. After adjusting for inflation, Americans now spend some 35 cents less per gallon of gasoline than they did in 1950.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Read My Lips, Language Fogies
description: LEAD: I HAVE a psychiatrist friend who defected to Sweden some years ago and returns periodically with his latest blond wife to do research in a Westchester medical center. He says he has to relearn English on each visit. He is suddenly hit with expressions that did not exist a few years earlier. And when he utters what had been on everyone's lips just the other year, his colleaques look at him as if he is speaking

title: In Germany, a Warning From Heiner Muller
description: ''Most of my life I have been a victim of German history,'' says Heiner Muller, generally considered Germany's, both East and West, leading playwright. In 1933, when he was 4, his father, a socialist who opposed Hitler, was dragged off to prison. ''I have to deal with history because it has dealt so much with me,'' Mr. Muller says. ''Besides, on stage, you need an enemy. German history is my enemy, and I want to stare into the white of its eye.''

title: Suffolk Nurturing Movie-Making Talent
description: LEAD: IN the last few years, films like ''Sweet Liberty'' with Alan Alda and Michael Caine, ''She-Devil'' with Meryl Streep and Roseanne Barr, ''Wall Street'' with Michael Douglas and others have put Long Island on the movie map.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Do not delay applying fertilizer to woody plants, which need the summer months to ripen (harden) new growth. Spray fruit trees again to keep them insect-disease free for the summer-fall harvest. Protect rosebushes from fungus diseases. Last call to control woolly adelgids on hemlocks.

title: Question of the Week;   Who Is Baseball's Best Player Now?
description: Nolan Ryan. At the age of 43, he chalked up his sixth no-hitter last month. Only Sandy Koufax, with four, and Cy Young and Bob Feller, with three each, have pitched more than two.

title: Data Bank/July 8, 1990
Postings: Changes at C.A.I.;   Adding Services
description: A national organization little known to residents of condominiums, cooperatives and homeowner associations, but quite well known to the board members who run those forms of housing, is changing leaders and programs this month. The Community Associations Institute, with headquarters in Alexandria, Va., and chapters across the country, is to be run by its new executive vice president, Barbara Byrd-Lawler of Austin, Tex. She had been executive vice president of the International Association of Hospitality Accountants.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: POLITICAL CARTOONS

title: Where Were The Insights?
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Waggaman Becomes a Bride
description: Victoria Mackenzie Waggaman, the daughter of Mrs. Robert Waggaman of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mr. Waggaman, was married yesterday to Christopher Alfred Knopes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Knopes of Fairfax Station, Va. The Right Rev. Morgan Portius performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title:
FORUM;

A Different Savings and Loan Villain
description: LEAD: The savings and loan crisis, which may cost taxpayers $500 billion or more, was precipitated by the passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. This measure could not have been passed at a more inauspicious moment.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Light Meals and Salads, Salads, Salads
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Court-Martialed by Mom

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Sentence for Lie On Rape Charge Creates Debate
description: When a Nebraska judge last month found Elizabeth Irene Richardson guilty of making a false accusation of rape, he handed down a sentence for which even he knew of no precedent: he ordered her to apologize in half-page advertisements in four newspapers and 10 spot announcements on two radio stations.

title: Democracy Rally Crushed in Kenya
description: A demonstration calling for multiparty democracy and protesting the arrests of political opponents of the Kenyan Government was broken up today with police gunfire and tear gas.

title: A Collector Of the Unusual: Korean Ceramics
description: Many art and antiques dealers began as collectors, exploring the offbeat areas that others overlook. This was the case of Keum Ja Kang, a Korean newspaper photographer who came to the United States in 1963 on an assignment and decided to stay. After she completed graduate studies in Far Eastern art at Columbia University in 1975, Mrs. Kang started collecting in a field then considered rarefied but which is now gaining an enthusiastic following among museum curators and collectors: Korean art and antiques.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Let's Train People To Be Parents
description: LEAD: MELISSA wanted attention from the sympathetic counselor who spoke in her school about ''Good and Bad Touches,'' and fabricated a story about her father sexually abusing her. James wanted to impress a classmate and wrote her a letter saying his father whipped him with a belt. Janey hated her parents for not letting her hang out with her marijuana-smoking friends, so she ran away to a girlfriend's house and told everyone her parents kept her prisoner, placed brutal demands on her and ultimately kicked her out.

title: He Was There
description: THEN AND NOW

title: Nancy Whittaker To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip N. Whittaker of North Falmouth, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Nancy Crosby Whittaker and Neil Davin Charney, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Evan Charney of Boylston, Mass.

title: Jack Welsch, Wine Executive, 77
description: Jack Welsch, a wine distribution executive, died Wednesday. He was 77 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Food;   SAY CHEEEESE!
description: I grew up thinking cheese was something a little smaller than a breadbox, about the color of finger-painted pumpkins and as perishable as powdered milk. The only time I ever tasted the real thing was when my father was feeling flush enough to invest in a round of Colby longhorn to ration out in thin slices on saltines as a late-night snack.

title: Suzanne Dooley Becomes a Bride
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Dooley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Dooley of Saugerties, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Kingston, N.Y., to Charles Lee Quaintance 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Quaintance of Highland Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Frank J. Damis officiated. Melissa Carmichael was the maid of honor and John Fowler was the best man.

title: Patricia Vida and Michael J. Hallas Are Married
description: Patricia Sally Vida and Michael Jeffrey Hallas were married at St. Francis of Assisi Cathedral Church in Metuchen, N.J., by Msgr. Dominic A. Turtora. Mrs. Hallas is the daughter of Aniko Labarca of Manhasset Hills, L.I., and Laszlo J. Vida of East Brunswick, N.J., and the stepdaughter of Thomas A. Labarca. A graduate of Stetson University, the bride is a director of airline product development at Utell International, hotel representatives in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Americans Should Travel Wherever They Wish
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: American League;   A Royals Turnabout: Rookie One-Hits Tigers
description: Kevin Appier, a rookie, pitched a one-hitter and Kurt Stillwell keyed a three-run third-inning attack tonight as the Kansas City Royals beat Detroit, 4-0, repaying the Tigers for Jack Morris's one-hitter Friday night.

title: August Wedding For Miss Wagner
description: August wedding plans for MaryMoss Wagner and John Tracy Walker 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker 3d of Charlottesville, Va., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Wagner 3d of New York.

title: Boeing Expects to Trim More Jobs
description: The Boeing Company said last week that it expected to cut its work force in Washington State by another 2,700 jobs in the second half of 1990, bringing total job reductions for the year to about 5,600.

title: Winning Ugly, Losing Ugly, Just Plain Ugly
description: GOOD thing the television ratings have been so low back in the States. Otherwise, instead of having the World Soccer body worrying about the United States World Cup program for 1994, we might have the opposite problem of some lawmaker trying to ban the World Cup like so much controversial artwork.

title: Many Census Aides Are Denied Chance For Jobless Benefits
description: As thousands of temporary Census Bureau workers wrap up their work this summer, they are finding that they may not be able to collect unemployment checks because of a cost-cutting move by Congress six weeks ago.

title: On the Road in Iowa, 'The Greatest Thing'
description: ''CAN I tell you an incredible story?'' Norman Kornreich asked, his blue eyes wide, his arms flying through the air. He is sitting at the dining-room table of his home in Oceanside, L.I., with five years' worth of snapshots, cycling souvenirs and cloth patches heaped in front of him.

title: U.S. Plans $4 Billion Device That Failed Tests
description: Breaking its own rules on buying major new weapons, the Pentagon is pressing ahead with a $4 billion electronic radar-jamming device that has failed crucial flight tests on fighter planes it is designed to protect.

title: Kenyan Opposition Lawyer Asks for Refuge at Embassy
description: A prominent Kenyan lawyer, who has been in the forefront of the push for a multiparty democracy, has sought refuge in the United States Embassy in Nairobi, the American Ambassador said today.

title: Market Place;   How to View E-Systems Stock
description: FOUR years ago, analysts expected E-Systems Inc., which makes highly sophisticated military electronics, to elude likely cutbacks in Pentagon spending and prosper.

title: Yankees (30-50) Decide to Give It a Rest
description: The good news for the Yankees is that their next contact with a baseball won't be until Thursday. They are so desperate to get away from the game that Manager Stump Merrill canceled a Wednesday workout.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgarians Call On More to Quit
description: Student leaders called today for more resignations in Bulgaria's governing Socialist Party after protests forced out President Petar Mladenov.

title: Focus on Levi
description: WHETHER he likes it or not, Wayne Levi is starting to be noticed. With his third victory in 35 days last Sunday at the Greater Hartford Open, Levi became the first man of the new decade to win three tournaments in a season on the PGA Tour.

title: Bridge
description: A social headache, less common now than it once was, belongs to the hostess who plans two tables of Chicago after-dinner bridge and finds herself with seven players instead of eight. The solution, easy when you think of it, is ''shuttle dummy.'' Two tables are placed close together, and when one table has finished bidding the dummy crosses to the other to bid there. Another dummy becomes available, normally before a fourth is needed at the first table.

title: East Joins West To Enjoy Victory
description: Although the Teutonic triple that many Germans had been dreaming of fell through, they won the big one - the world championship of soccer - and East and West Germans alike poured into the streets today to celebrate West Germany's 1-0 triumph over Argentina.

title: What's New This Summer? 'Guerrillas' of the Airwaves
description: PRODUCERS from two of the five series CBS will broadcast this summer call what they are doing ''guerrilla'' television.

title: After Weeping for Mandela, Many Prepare to Savor Visit
description: For 30 years Willard Johnson fought an often thankless battle in Boston, protesting racial inequities in a country most Americans knew little about. He helped organize some of the earliest demonstrations against South Africa's system of racial separation and was even arrested for it once.

title: West Germany Wins Soccer's World Cup
description: West Germany won the World Cup for the third time yesterday when they defeated Argentina, 1-0, on a penalty kick by Andreas Brehme after a controversial foul in the 84th minute.

title: Corrections
description: The weather table for U.S. cities on Friday incorrectly reported the high temperature for Thursday in Washington. It was 99 degrees, not 113.

title: Fear of AIDS With Rape: How a Case Was Affected
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan have agreed to a reduced sentence for a defendant in a rape case in exchange for the man's promise to take an AIDS test and provide the results to his victim.

title: Painting the Pentagon Green
description: Senator Nunn has recently offered a plan to enlist the Pentagon's aid in saving the planet. Though the chairman of the Armed Services Committee's new interests may not be entirely unconnected to his old interest in safeguarding military spending, his ideas are worth considering on their merits. They open up potentially important areas for cooperation, and set off a number of alarm bells.

title: Greece and U.S. Sign 8-Year Pact Exchanging Arms Aid for Extended Use of Bases
description: Greece's new Conservative Government and the United States signed an eight-year agreement here today providing Greece with more than $1 billion worth of arms in return for the continued operation of American military bases in this country.

title: Shattering Glass Added To the City Symphony
description: To the Editor:

title: The Industry Fights Back Over Taxes
description: THE advertising industry has been waging a fierce battle with legislators who want to tax advertising or restrict ads for cigarettes and alcohol. So far, the intense lobbying by Madison Avenue and its clients has kept tax laws and regulations off the books.

title: Those in Art Case May Settle It Themselves
description: Opposing parties in the Quedlinburg art theft case now before Federal District Court in Dallas have resumed out-of-court negotiations, said a source close to the parties who spoke on condition that his name not be used.

title: McGovern Wins New Haven Open
description: Although there is big-time pressure on the Ben Hogan Tour, galleries tend to be on the small side. So Jim McGovern brought his own gallery today and went on to win the Ben Hogan New Haven Open.

title: Review/Music;   David Diamond Tribute At Waterloo Festival
description: The Waterloo Festival of the Arts, in its 15th-anniversary season, opened its classical-music series this weekend with a tribute to the American composer David Diamond, who turns 75 on Monday. Mr. Diamond's Partita (1935) was performed Friday evening at a festival chamber concert in Princeton, and his Symphony No. 3 (1945) was performed tonight, by the Festival Orchestra under its principal conductor, Gerard Schwarz, in the tent at Waterloo Village.

title: Lord, Geller To Be Merged
description: The WPP Group P.L.C. said Friday that it would merge two of its companies - Brouillard Communications and Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein Inc. - to form Brouillard/LGFE.

title: Save a Spot In the Hall
description: Now in his ninth major league season, Ryne Sandberg, at the age of 30, is having his best year statistically.

title: Reds' Armstrong Is All-Star Starter
description: Jack Armstrong of the Cincinnati Reds will start for the National League in Tuesday night's All-Star Game, Roger Craig, the league's manager, announced today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Soviet Magazines Testing the American Market
description: In the ultimate capitalist test, Soviet publications are gingerly making their way on to American newsstands in a market already saturated with foreign policy journals and glossy travel magazines.

title: What Students Read When They Don't Have To
description: While scholars debate what books should be taught in college, there is no debate about those that students are reading outside the classroom.

title: Brewers Win, 20-7, After Trailing by 7-0
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, who trailed by 7-0 in the third inning, scored 20 unanswered runs today and beat the California Angels, 20-7.

title: Eastern Europe: The Polluted Lands
description: As Eastern Europe struggles toward democracy, it must also grapple with a ravaged environment. Corrosive soot has fouled water and soil, and in blackened industrial cities the air is laced with heavy metals and chemicals. In a world ruled by production targets, there was no pressure to clean up.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Chronicle
description: An archaeologist wants to dig up the lawn of CHARLES KURALT'S vacation home in Essex, Conn., but the television newsman has been -where else - on the road.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., appointed James D. Varrato senior vice president for distribution services, replacing Paul W. Reese Jr., who is leaving the company in September.

title: Violence And Hypocrisy
description: Seldom has there been a more blatant case of blaming the victim than those pious American demands, during Nelson Mandela's visit here, that he renounce violence as a political instrument.

title: Israeli Joins Labor Race
description: A former Energy Minister, Moshe Shahal, declared his candidacy today to lead Israel's Labor Party, saying he would seek agreement with the United States on peace with Palestinians. Mr. Shahal, 56 years old, is an Iraqi-born lawyer and protege of the party leader, Shimon Peres.

title: Setbacks Are Seen for Bond Rally
description: Analysts and money managers say that the bond market rally that began in late spring has been sidetracked for the time being, but that it has not been derailed. Consequently, yield levels, which had been inching lower, are likely to have an upward bias over the next few weeks at least.

title: The Big Break
description: PHIL LOMBARDI and Greg Olson are starring in this season's poor man's version of the Wally Pipp and Lou Gehrig story.

title: Israeli Arabs Dissent, But Remain Loyal
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Transcending a Family's Dark Side
description: Falling Angels

title: Mullen Helps Veryfine And Loses Smartfood
description: When Mullen Advertising decided to promote Veryfine juices as an alternative to soda, the agency made one mistake.

title: New Tennis Racquet Plays It Straight
description: A design innovation on the widebody tennis racquet combines a round (rather than oval) head with a throat that is straight rather than bowed. The Orbi-Tech design from Spalding Sports Worldwide includes two models, both made of graphite, in 95- and 105-square-inch heads.

title: Retail Deal Expected For Trump
description: Donald J. Trump is set to announce this morning that France's largest retailer has signed a 25-year lease in Trump Tower in a deal worth tens of millions of dollars, bankers said.

title: The Rise of the Self-Published Best Seller
description: When John Javna and Julie Bennett were discussing how to publish ''50 Simple Things You Can Do to Save the Earth,'' they considered offering it to a commercial book company. ''But we wanted it out in a hurry at an affordable price, so we decided to publish it ourselves,'' Mr. Javna said. The $4.95 book, published under the imprint of Earthworks Press, has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 22 weeks - 10 weeks as No. 1.

title: Low-Cost State Condo Plan Is Criticized in Connecticut
description: A plan by the Connecticut Department of Housing to buy unsold condominiums at low prices for eventual purchase by low- and middle-income buyers is meeting resistance from many quarters.

title: Deep-Water Ports Offer Solution to Oil Spills
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Degenerate' Artworks Survive Triumphant Over Nazi Degradation
description: An exhibition that was staged by the Nazis to vilify artists like Picasso, Wassily Kandinsky and Paul Klee will be presented in Los Angeles next year, but under very different auspices.

title: Hitachi China Software
description: Hitachi Ltd. of Japan and a Chinese company will jointly develop Chinese versions of software that will connect Hitachi's general-purpose computer with China's personal computers, the Japanese company said last week. China's personal computers are compatible with the I.B.M. PC/XT and PC/AT. Hitachi said it hoped the venture, with the China Great Wall Industrial Corporation, would enhance sales of its general-purpose computers in China.

title: More Space Available
description: THE athlete as billboard is a familiar sight for spectators at sports events and a profitable venture for the athletes. So it's not surprising to learn that skiers have heretofore felt cheated by rules imposed by the International Ski Federation limiting the amount of space they can sell on their uniforms.

title: Deep-Water Ports Offer Solution to Oil Spills;   Loss of Older Ships
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cullen, 70, Host and Panelist On Many TV Game Shows, Dies
description: Bill Cullen, a host of television game shows for more than 30 years, died on Saturday at his home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. He was 70 years old.

title: People
description: * Malcolm Glenn has been named regional managing director for Asia at Leo Burnett International.

title: A Fallen Hero Is Dreaming of Gold in '92
description: It is an ending Hollywood might hesitate to write.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: DOG SHOW

title: PRETORIA ARRESTS 9 RIGHT-WINGERS
description: The South African police announced today that nine white men with known right-wing sympathies have been arrested in connection with a series of bombings in the last three months.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SEND PEOPLE, NOT CASH, TO ASSIST SOVIETS
description: President Bush plans to tell the United States' six main industrial allies this week that he is prepared to send teams of experts to the Soviet Union to help it rebuild rail and communications networks, grain storage sites, food distribution systems and other essential services, senior White House officials said today.

title: Beckenbauer Has Several Attractive Alternatives
description: Having today become perhaps the ultimate achiever in the history of his sport, Franz Beckenbauer has the luxury of choosing whether to take on a new challenge or to drift off into the hazy limelight enjoyed by very wealthy retired superstars.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

The Youthful Arrogance of 'Teach for America'
description: LEAD: In 1986, when I decided to teach high school in a Maine fishing village, I was exactly the kind of recruit that the much-publicized Teach for America program is seeking now: a magna cum laude graduate of a prestigious private college with a nearly completed master's degree from a demanding program.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Johnny Can't Add, Hiroko Can
description: In international education tests among industrial nations, American students usually come close to the bottom in math and science; the Japanese are always on top. More than 90 percent of Japanese children graduate from high school; close to 30 percent of Americans drop out. If a nation depends on the quality of its people, American children should be worried about their future competitors.

title: Charon Crushes Rivals In Oaks
description: Charon scored an overpowering nine-length victory yesterday in the $287,500 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park, and only one thing could have made her handlers happier: they almost wished that Go for Wand had been in the race.

title: West Germany Captures World Cup
description: West Germany won the 1990 World Cup tonight, defeating the defending champion, Argentina, in a match that typified the enduring themes of the monthlong tournament - few goals, nasty play and dull games.

title: Carol Coombs and John Kaplan Wed
description: Carol Lynne Coombs, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. F. Alan Coombs of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday to John Stuart Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Kaplan of Pittsfield, Mass. Rabbis Harold Salzmann and Alan Berg officiated at Temple Anshe Amunim in Pittsfield.

title: Metro Datelines;   600 Rikers Prisoners Skip Meals in Protest
description: Some 400 inmates at Rikers Island skipped lunch for a second day yesterday and 600 skipped dinner to protest state rules limiting the personal effects they can take when being transferred to state prisons, a New York City Department of Correction spokeswoman said.

title: For Incumbents, Savings Bailout Might Be Costly
description: Republican and Democratic challengers in Congressional campaigns across the country are seizing upon the savings and loan crisis as the issue they say will make many incumbents vulnerable this year.

title: Business and the Law;   For Lawyers, Few Big-Fee Deals
description: The rate of growth at many leading law firms slowed considerably in 1989, but the legal business was nonetheless highly profitable, a study scheduled to be released today has found.

title: Stephanie Hubelbank, a Lawyer, Weds
description: Stephanie Laura Hubelbank, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hubelbank of Bridgeport, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Michael Scheinman, a son of Phyllis Braff of East Hampton, L.I., and Graham M. Scheinman of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi S. Jerome Wallin at Congregation B'nai Torah in Trumbull, Conn.

title: Jamie Columbus Becomes a Bride
description: Jamie Lauren Columbus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Columbus of Rochester, and Richard Allan Glaser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Glaser of New York, were married yesterday by Rabbi Shamai Kanter in a garden near the bride's home in Rochester.

title: INSIDE
description: Mass Killings in Yugoslavia

title: Ford Plant for Hungary
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to spend $60 million to $70 million to build an auto-parts plant in Hungary, the state news agency said Friday. The plant, which would also import Ford cars to Hungary, would be built southwest of Budapest, it said. Ford plans to manufacture ignition coils and electronic fuel pumps at the plant. Production, which would start no sooner than 1993, would be entirely for export. The agency added that the value of the exports would be balanced by imports of Ford cars, starting with 2,000 vehicles this year.

title: Dr. Tibor Ham, 76, a Politician In Hungary and Physician in U.S.
description: Dr. Tibor Ham, a physician and a member of the Hungarian resistance to the Nazis in World War II, who fled into exile after the Communist takeover in 1947, died on Saturday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 76 years old. A son, Eugene, said Dr. Ham died of prostate cancer.

title: Shah Jewna Journal;   Village Women Earn Respect (and Rupees, Too)
description: To be a woman, 40 and unmarried in a farming village of rural Pakistan is virtually to count for nothing. About all the attention a single woman can attract is negative: social ostracism and sometimes physical abuse. But here in Shah Jewna, nobody fools with Jivni.

title: Ms. Mallin Weds James K. Hanson
description: Letitia Jane Mallin, the daughter of Joel M. Mallin of New York and Janice P. Mallin of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Kenneth Hanson, the son of Donald W. Hanson of Salt Lake City and Jeanne Morrison of Jamestown, R.I. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Pirates Defeat the Dodgers, 7-2
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8 (AP) -Barry Bonds and Jeff King drove in three runs each and Doug Drabek won his first game in a month as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Los Angeles Dodgers today, 7-2, and held on to first place in the National League East, a half-game ahead of the Mets.

title: Motorola Said to Seek License From I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is in negotiations to license its most advanced memory-chip technology to Motorola Inc., several Government and industry officials say.

title: Edberg Overcomes Becker To Regain Wimbledon Title
description: When the match was over and it was truly time to surrender his title to the man he had claimed it from last year, Boris Becker paused for a moment and took a mental snapshot of the surroundings that have been most conducive to his urge to terrorize his competition.

title: Some U.S. Arts Grants Turned Down in Protest
description: About 700 artists or arts groups so far have accepted grants made this year by the National Endowment for the Arts. Some have vowed at the same time to challenge the accompanying restrictions on the content of their work. But only a handful are known to have rejected the grants because of the restrictions.

title: Mines Kill Sri Lanka Soldiers
description: Tamil rebels detonated mines under a military truck and an armored car today, killing 8 Government soldiers and wounding 16, officials said. The mines, buried in a road near Vavuniya, 140 miles north of Colombo, went off as the vehicles passed over them. In Puttalam, north of the capital, President Ranasinghe Premadasa appealed to foreign governments to help start peace talks with the separatist rebels.

title: Bonnie Honig Weds Michael Whinston
description: Bonnie Honig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Honig of Montreal, was married there yesterday to Michael Dennis Whinston, the son of Dr. George J. Whinston of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Joan Aronson Whinston. Rabbi Sidney Shoham performed the ceremony at the Queen Elizabeth Hotel.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Outdoors: Salmon Madness in Ireland
description: FROM pub to pub the word was spreading throughout the village, spoken in quiet but urgent tones, as though a password was being given in some druidic rite. From McDermott's Bar to the Spa House, to the Castle Oaks Hotel and to P. J. Guerin's pub, which is the undisputed headquarters of the river rats, one heard: ''The fish are on the move!''

title: Ned Ball, 81, President Of Brokerage in 1970's
description: Ned B. Ball, a former president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, died Saturday at a hospital in Portland, Ore. He was 81 years old.

title: Brazil Backing Computer Imports
description: The office of an American multinational company here recently received a knock on the door of the sort dreaded by business executives across Brazil: it was the computer police.

title: 2 in Family Die in Bronx Fire
description: A smoky house fire, accidentally started by a child playing with a cigarette lighter, took the lives of a 43-year-old Bronx woman and her 4-year-old son yesterday in the Williamsbridge section, the authorities reported. A police spokesman, Sgt. Edward J. Burns, said the fire broke out about 4:15 P.M. at 3363 Wilson Avenue. Ethel Spigner and her son Randy were in the upper part of the home and apparently died from smoke inhalation when the fire developed downstairs.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 8:

title: Chronicle
description: When ANTHONY J. F. O'REILLY became the chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company 10 years ago, the company was smaller and less profitable. If success is measured by one's peers, Mr. O'Reilly has been successful indeed, since he was chosen as Chief Executive of the Year from more than 1,400 others.

title: Report Finds 638,900 Gun Crimes Yearly
description: Guns were used in 7 percent of the rapes, 18 percent of robberies and 22 percent of the aggravated assaults in the nine-year period studied by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics.

title: Heavy Schedule of Auctions This Week
description: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, an offering tomorrow of 30-year bonds by the Resolution Funding Corporation to finance the bailout of savings institutions and Wednesday's auction of seven-year notes.

title: From Liberian War, Tales of Brutality
description: A young man was stopped last night as he was trying to reach his home. It was dark, and long past Monrovia's dusk-to-dawn curfew.

title: Chronicle
description: Since February, KATIE KELLY has been teaching English to Amerasian children in Saigon. She left her job as television critic and commentator on WNBC-TV in December. She had been a schoolteacher in the 1960's and after vacationing in Vietnam in 1988, decided to return to Saigon.

title: At Second, He's First In the Class
description: RYNE SANDBERG will be the National League's starting second baseman in an All-Star Game for the sixth straight year tomorrow night in enviable circumstances. At the age of 30, he is being praised with unusual unanimity throughout the baseball world, cited as a likely most valuable player, on the verge of setting important records. And he will be making this showcase appearance in his home park, the Chicago Cubs' Wrigley Field, where the playing conditions dovetail with the talents he has developed.

title: Sizzling Mets Edge Braves
description: At the game's start, the thermometer read 99 degrees. An hour later, it had climbed to 102. Warm, to be sure, but nothing like the reading inside John Franco's cap with one out in the the ninth inning. That was off the chart. Franco, just a couple of outs away from the cool of the clubhouse and the relaxation of the All-Star Game break, stood on the lonely rise of baked clay, upset at a rut in the mound, concerned about the 2-1 lead over the Braves he had been charged with preserving and incensed with himself for having issued consecutive walks.

title: New Life for Hoboken's Ghost Waterfront? Vote to Decide
description: Brick and steel, bit by bit, the 90-year-old piers built here by German steamship lines to last for ages are reluctantly coming down, opening this Hudson River waterfront to a future filled with uncertainty.

title: A Better Neighbor Policy
description: Revolution is sweeping Latin America and Washington, sensibly, wants to encourage it. For too long, Washington has subordinated vital hemispheric concerns to ideological contests in Central America. President Bush's new economic program for the Americas signals a positive shift in priorities that can benefit Americans from Point Barrow to Tierra del Fuego.

title: Each Country's Agenda at the Economic Summit Meeting
description: UNITED STATES

title: Americans' Support for Israel: Solid, but Not the Rock It Was
description: Like many Americans, Donald Power long counted himself an admirer of Israel. A Federal labor mediator who lives here in Saginaw, he marveled at the courage and spirit of the small nation, a fledgling democracy so imperiled yet so determined to survive.

title: The Achilles Heel of Health Care Rationing
description: LEAD: Oregon's plan to deny certain health services to Medicaid patients is the latest and clearest acknowledgment that rationing will be necessary to control the rapid growth of the nation's medical costs. The state recently released a proposed ranking of medical services and announced it would pay only for care that ranks above a cutoff point determined by the availability of funds.

title: Nekoosa Unit's Ex-Chief To Lead Wausau Paper
description: The Wausau Paper Mills Company has named Arnold M. Nemirow president and chief executive to succeed William L. Goggins, who was killed in December in an auto accident.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We created a mythical image for Israel that neither Israel, despite all of its remarkable achievements, nor any other nation could ever live up to.''

title: G. Zambonini, 48, Architect Who Led A New York Atelier
description: Giuseppe Zambonini, an architect and loft renovator who founded the Open Atelier of Design in Manhattan, died on Saturday at his home in Atlanta. He was 48 years old. His death apparently resulted from a heart attack, a friend of the family said.

title: Accounts
description: * Weekend Exercise Co., a manufacturer of dance, aerobic and exercise clothing, to Henszey & Albert, with a budget between $1.5 million and $2 million.

title: Judge Rejects Tour of Merc
description: A Federal District judge has denied a request from jurors in the trial of three commodity traders that they be allowed to tour the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: West Side Co-op Acts Under Law and Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Drummond, 30, Artificial Heart Patient
description: Michael Drummond, who in 1985 became the first person successfully given an artificial heart transplant as a bridge to receiving a human heart, died Saturday at the University of Arizona Medical Center in Tucson. He was 30 years old and lived in Phoenix.

title: Lufthansa's Airbus Jets
description: Lufthansa A.G., West Germany's state-controlled airline, said Thursday that it had signed an order worth more than two billion marks, or about $1.2 billion, to buy 20 new Airbus Industrie A321 jets and to take options on 20 more. The A321 seats up to 180 passengers.

title: Page Buys 2 Publications
description: Page Group Publishing Inc. has purchased a pair of reader-written magazines in Beverly Hills and Brentwood.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Piles of Bones in Yugoslavia Point to Partisan Massacres
description: After the discovery of masses of human bones in secret graves in caves here and nearby over the last two weeks, a series of witnesses have come forward to report seeing large-scale shootings 45 years ago, painting a grisly picture of mass murder by the Communist Partisans led by Marshal Tito.

title: Lois Anzelowitz Wed in Princeton
description: Lois Beth Anzelowitz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Anzelowitz of Brooklyn, and Dennis Ronald Tanner, the son of the late Lillian Morrell Tavani of New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Eitan Weiner-Kaplow officiated at the Mountain Lakes House in Princeton, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: After failing to override a veto of what would have been an almost total ban on abortion, the Louisiana Legislature today passed a bill nearly as strict that is based on language the Governor has indicated he would support.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Budapest Memorial to Jews
description: Several thousand people crowded outside Hungary's main synagogue today as a memorial was dedicated honoring 600,000 Hungarian Jews killed during World War II. The memorial by the sculptor Imre Varga depicts a powerful tree, 33 feet across, shaped like an inverted menorah, or candelabrum, with leaves bearing the names of victims. The memorial of black granite and chrome steel on a red marble base stands on the mass grave of 6,000 Jews at the site of the entrance to the wartime Budapest ghetto.

title: Italy, Looking to the East, Seeks Economic Influence
description: With one collective eye fixed resolutely west and the other glancing hopefully toward the east, Italian business and Government leaders are working hard these days to keep their focus. If they can, they are convinced they will prosper.

title: Satisfaction Lead to Acura
description: The Acura luxury car division of the Honda Motor Company of Japan has topped the J. D. Power & Associates list of cars most satisfying to owners for the fourth year in a row, the marketing company said last week.

title: Sarah Gribetz a Bride
description: At Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., Sarah D. Gribetz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. H. Joel Gribetz of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Michael W. Stern, a son of Mrs. Wilhelm Stern of Riverdale and the late Dr. Stern. Rabbis Emily Korzenik and Abner Weiss officiated. The bride graduated from Barnard College and received an M.S. degree in journalism from Columbia University. Mr. Stern is an associate at the New York law firm of Hawkins, Delafield & Wood. A cum laude graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, he has a law degree from Boston University.

title: Ms. Rosenstock Becomes a Bride
description: Debra Lynn Rosenstock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Rosenstock of Plainview, L.I., , was married yesterday to Michael V. Goetz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Goetz of Philadelphia. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Big Hopes Meet Hard Reality
description: For Damon Bailey and Eric Montross, the distinctions between basketball myth and basketball reality sometimes blurred during their last three seasons in high school.

title: Henry J. Kuss Jr., 67, Negotiator Of Billions in U.S. Weapons Sales
description: Henry J. Kuss Jr., an international military consultant who was the Defense Department's chief arms salesman in the 1960's, died of cancer Friday at Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va., a family spokesman said. He was 67 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Deep-Water Ports Offer Solution to Oil Spills;   Use Floating Booms
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook;   The Welcome by Bush Is as Big as All Texas
description: The Group of Four went to the rodeo tonight, where they saw armadillo races, bull riding, barrel racing, calf scrambling, the Grand Ole Opry, an Old West village, cowboys and Indians, oil rigs, square dancing, a sheriff with silver spurs, Styrofoam cacti, a model of the space shuttle, horseshoe contests, 1,250 gallons of barbecue sauce and jalapenos, 500 pounds of onions, 5,000 servings of cobbler and carrot cake, and 650 gallons of lemonade and iced tea.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Techniques for Following Tennis's First Rule
description: LEAD: IT'S the oldest cliche in sports and the first command you hear when you take your first tennis lesson: Keep your eye on the ball. This is solid advice, but what does it really mean?

title: At More and More Jails, Smoking Is Forbidden
description: When he was sent to the Randall County jail here to await trial on charges that he beat his wife to death, Larry McPhearson knew he would lose his freedom. What he was not prepared to lose were his cigarettes.

title: Washington Talk;   Mystery for Court: Case Of the Dwindling Docket
description: The Supreme Court's 1989-1990 term ended late last month with an unsolved mystery: why are the Justice accepting fewer and fewer cases for decision?

title: Pittston Promotions Fill 2 New Positions
description: The Pittston Company, a coal producer, air freight carrier and armored car service, has named Joseph C. Farrell president and chief operating officer and David L. Marshall vice chairman.

title: Frenchman Buying 80% Of Adidas
description: Bernard Tapie, a French entrepreneur, politician and soccer team owner, has agreed to buy an 80 percent stake in Adidas A.G., the West German company that is one of the world's largest makers of sporting goods.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Democratic Hungary Nibbles on Political Fringes
description: Three months after parliamentary elections in which voters here chose to make a clean break with the Communist past, Hungary is still lingering in a prolonged state of transition, debating issues that many thought were behind them.

title: New York Told To Base Raises On Job Needs
description: As New York City begins contract negotiations with its largest municipal union today, a civic group says it should end the pattern of roughly comparable raises for all unions, in favor of a two-year freeze for uniformed workers and substantial pay increases for jobs with a shortage of applicants.

title: Harvard Varsity Coasts
description: Harvard won one final with ease and lost another with verve as the 151st Henley Royal Regatta ended here today.

title: Metro Datelines;   Vandals Set Fires In a Catholic Church
description: Vandals broke into a Catholic church on Long Island, setting fires and knocking over holy water fonts, the police said yesterday.

title: Metro Matters;   The Hazy Future Of Trying to Plan For the Future
description: Skeptics say strategic planning is for people you can't trust with the present.

title: Chile and U.S. to Begin Talks on Freeing Trade
description: Chile, one of the lowest-tariff countries in Latin America, will open negotiations with Washington this week about establishing a free trade zone with the United States, Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley said Friday.

title: British Papers Facing a Shakeout
description: The editor of The Financial Times recently sent his journalists a brisk memorandum urging them to cut costs. Among the measures he suggested were avoiding expensive restaurants, canceling some foreign trips, using public transportation rather than taxis to Heathrow Airport and sharply curtailing the practice of ''F.T. journalists taking each other out to lunch.''

title: Suzanne Kaufman, Photographer, Wed
description: Suzanne Kaufman, the daughter of Esther F. Kaufman of Brooklyn and the late Joseph A. Kaufman, was married yesterday to Lee McClure Come, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arnold B. Come of Larkspur, Calif. Rabbi Ari L. Fridkis performed the ceremony at CAMI Hall in New York.

title: PHYSICIANS CHIDED IN A CANCER STUDY
description: Physicians must act more aggressively when women find lumps in their breasts, a study of malpractice claims and lawsuits indicates.

title: Deep-Water Ports Offer Solution to Oil Spills;   Impartial Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention Deficit Is Traced to Inner Ear
description: To the Editor:

title: Catholic Parish Closings Bring Tears in Chicago
description: Sophie Kochaney sat in the ninth pew at St. Bridget Catholic Church today clutching a rosary as she has every Sunday for 51 years. But this time she went through a fistful of tissues and received communion with tears in her eyes.

title: Davis Takes Title, Stopping Breland
description: Aaron (Superman) Davis of the Bronx is the new World Boxing Association welterweight champion.

title: In the Zodiac Case, Still More Riddles Than Clues
description: Four months after the gunman who calls himself the Zodiac shot his first victim, the largest police task force assembled in New York City since the Son of Sam murders is still baffled by the central riddle of the case: how the gunman knows the astrological signs of his victims.

title: Article 151490 -- No Title
description: A $16 billion program over the next 20 years to improve transportation in the Hudson Valley was proposed this week by a special task force of the State Department of Transportation.

title: Chronicle
description: Racing fans in the Northeast will get their first look at WILLY T. RIBBS driving on the Championship Auto Racing Teams' Indy-car circuit next Sunday at the Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands. Rooting for him will be BILL COSBY, his backer.

title: Joy and Challenge Mix In Dancing of the Giglio
description: An ornate 85-foot tower, festooned with papier-mache lilies, angels and cherubim, bobbed and swirled through the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon as about 30,000 people crowded onto the normally quiet blocks around North Eighth and Havemeyer Streets for one of New York's oldest and liveliest festivals.

title: Zebra Mussel Threatens Economy and Ecology
description: Julie Kuberka stood on the edge of the Hudson River here, pulling in a laundry line cord with a white plastic tile at its end. Her assistant, Jennifer Curnow, sealed the tile in a plastic freezer bag, ready to be sent back to a laboratory for analysis.

title: RICO Reform: A Second Windfall for S & L Crooks
description: If the American people don't holler fast, the crooks who looted the nation's savings and loans are going to get off very cheaply.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Archer Outduels Beard
description: George Archer, who took a two-shot lead into the final round of the Northville Long Island Classic at the Meadow Brook Club, won a head-to-head battle with Frank Beard today to capture the Senior PGA Tour event.

title: Rome Is Big Enough for 3 Tenors
description: After a month as hosts of the World Cup soccer finals, Italians were ready for a spectacle of a different order, and they got it by the earful on Saturday night at the Baths of Caracalla. Tenors, anyone? Under a full moon, there were three of the world's greatest on the outdoor stage of the third-century Roman baths - Jose Carreras, Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti - appearing together for the first time through two and a half hours of operatic arias and popular tunes.

title: Israeli Jets Destroy Lebanon Base Linked to Party of God Terrorism
description: Israeli jets destroyed a base in southern Lebanon today that belonged to the pro-Iranian Party of God.

title: Metro Datelines;   Prison Letters Warn Youths About Crime
description: A Superior Court judge, hoping to gather vivid descriptions of criminal life that will warn young people away from lawlessness, has begun ordering convicted criminals to write him letters from jail.

title: As '900' Phone Lines Grow, Debate on Their Use Widens
description: George Burditt of Santa Barbara, Calif., won $1 million recently by being the first person to punch in, using the buttons on his telephone, the correct numerical answers to seven questions. He was the first winner of a new national contest that people enter by dialing a ''900'' telephone number, paying $2.99 for the call.

title: Laser Printers From Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce two lower-priced laser printers on Monday that it expects to help it stave off growing competition.

title: Dr. Jane Parnes Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Jane Robin Parnes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Parnes of Baldwin, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Nicholas Adrian Cataldo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Cataldo of Eatontown, N.J. Rabbi Cy Lowenheim officiated at the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Review/Music;   Rock-and-Roll With Hair
description: The group Faith No More, riding a hit album, ''The Real Thing,'' came to the Ritz on Friday night for a sold-out show. The band, from California, falls into a loose group of rock bands that add a handful of different musical styles to raw rock-and-roll, sprinkling punk and metal with other rock forms and rap. The mixture results in an odd audience, and the show drew everybody from recent college graduates to bikers, people wearing black leather and silver jewelry and India-print skirts, slam dancers and listeners. And as with most hard-rock bands, hair - long, tossed around and frequently brushed - was a theme throughout the show, both on stage and in the audience.

title: Great Neck Bridal For Ms. Meranus
description: Elizabeth Meranus and Menachem Lazaroff were married last evening at the Great Neck Synagogue in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Aaron Soloveitchik, a maternal great-uncle of the bridegroom. Mrs. Lazaroff is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Meranus of Riverdale, the Bronx. Her husband is the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Allan Lazaroff of Philadelphia.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Albania Says the West Delays Refugees' Visas
description: Albania accused Western embassies in Tirana today of delaying visas to some 6,000 refugees holed up in foreign missions there, saying that it had agreed to let them go West and that the delay was creating tensions.

title: 2/ Loaf Is Family Heartbreak in Egypt
description: In a tangled part of town called Boulaq, all narrow streets and gimcrack homes and children beyond counting, a man called Hamid told a story the other day that said much about the problems confronting President Hosni Mubarak in the Arab world's most populous nation.

title: Question Box
description: Close No-Hitters

title: George T. Eggleston, Leading Isolationist In World War II, 83
description: George T. Eggleston, a cartoonist, yachtsman, author, editor and isolationist who became embroiled in a national controversy in the 1940's, died Saturday in a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 83 years old.

title: United Stationers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Sales represent net sales; for the 1989 periods certain reclassifications have been included to conform with current year presentations.

title: People
description: * Jay Bacal, Burton Blum, Maurice Mahler and Mindy Rosengarten have been named senior vice presidents and group creative directors at Griffin Bacal.

title: German Fans Greet Team
description: Tens of thousands of flag-waving fans greeted West Germany's World Cup champions here today in a peaceful show of pride that was a stark contrast to Sunday night when four people were killed and hundreds injured after street celebrations turned violent.

title: Strawberry's Transformation;   Mets' Slugger Is Once Again Providing Consistent Power
description: For Darryl Strawberry, the pause for the All-Star Game, whatever its merits with respect to momentum, is certainly not bad for effect. It can't, after all, hurt either his stature in the game or his position at the negotiating table to let the magnitude of his last month sink in.

title: Becker Milk Co.  reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Springboard to Prep School: From the Bronx to Andover
description: Thirteen-year-old Diana Figueroa will leave her home in the South Bronx this fall for the distinctly different world of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. The distance in miles is small compared to the distance she has already traveled to win admission and the personal journey to come.

title: Court Refuses to Free a Jailed TV Reporter
description: The Supreme Court by a vote of 7 to 2 today rejected a request to free a Texas television reporter serving a six-month jail term for refusing to reveal the name of a confidential source.

title: F.F.O. Financial Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Roadway Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
Consumer Credit Rose By $3.9 Billion in May
description: Americans took out $3.9 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in May, 10 times the amount incurred only a month earlier, the Government said today.

title: Riggs National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $4.6 million from purchase of subordinated debentures, a pretax gain of $800,000 on sale of real estate, and a $10.6 million provision for possible losses primarily on commercial real estate loans.

title: Mobil to Pay Millions to Clean Up Vast Pool of Oil Beneath Brooklyn
description: Mobil Oil has agreed to spend what is expected to be tens of millions of dollars to clean up a vast and hazardous pool of oil that has been seeping under the streets of Brooklyn for more than 40 years.

title: Proposal to Sell Shares in El Al
description: Two United States investment banks have advised Israel to sell 51 percent of the state-owned national airline, El Al, the Transport Ministry said today.

title: A Summit Challenge: Farm Subsidies
description: The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations may arrive at decisions in Houston this week that can make or break the present Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks. If they listen to food exporting countries, especially in the third world, they will hear this: Open up markets, or forget about new trade rules on services and intellectual property. That message, so critical to trade and growth, needs to be heard.

title: Ban on Hunting of Whales Upheld
description: The International Whaling Commission has averted a threat to the five-year-old moratorium on commercial whaling. The threat was turned back on Friday when the American representative blocked a proposal that would have allowed a limited catch of whales in the Atlantic.

title: Howard Duff, 76, Hard-Boiled Actor In Movies and TV
description: Howard Duff, a character actor who played the tough private detective Sam Spade on radio in the 1940's and a colorful Southern sheriff, Titus Semple, on the television series ''Flamingo Road'' in the 1980's, died Sunday at his home. He was 76 years old.

title: Alpha 1 Biomedicals Inc. reports earnings for Year to March 31
Consultants Ponder Coming Elections
description: These are not the best of times for the men and women who produce political campaigns. Analysts, pundits and even some politicians are deploring the state of American campaigning.

title: Patricia C. Critchlow; Research Aide, 64
description: Patricia C. Critchlow, a retired administrative aide with the International Food Policy Research Institute, died Sunday at her home in Newburyport, Mass. She was 64 years old and lived previously in Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Alpha Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Net income

title: Search for Flood Dead Ends
description: The search for any remaining victims of last month's flooding has ended with the death count at 26, officials say. Seven people are still listed as missing since June 14, when floodwaters and debris hurtled down Wegee and Pipe creeks on the outskirts of this eastern Ohio town, but officials now believe those people were not in the area at the time.

title: New York City Spurs Anti-Apartheid Fight
description: A New York City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would further limit city business with banks or companies that have ties to South Africa and seek to reward banks that put pressure on the apartheid government there.

title: Chronicle
description: WILLIAM MEREDITH is joining the company of ROBERT FROST, WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS, EZRA POUND, MARIANNE MOORE, ELIZABETH BISHOP and some 40 other American poets honored by their colleagues for distinguished poetic achievement.

title: 2 G.M. Units Form Joint Subsidiary
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company and the Delco Electronics Corporation, both subsidiaries of the General Motors Corporation's GM Hughes Electronics unit, said they had formed a joint subsidiary to manufacture high-technology electronics. The new subsidiary, H E Microwave, will produce electronics for automotive and military applications.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Slow Times For Trade Publications
description: THE magazine industry certainly has its problems. The plunge in advertising pages for consumer magazines has been closely watched: Ad pages fell 6.5 percent in May, after a 3.5 percent drop for the first quarter of this year, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.

title: Chess
description: There are certain logical, positional problems that come up from time to time in various games without getting a clearcut solution. Often inaccuracies by both players disqualify the games as proper tests of the strategic values in question. Moreover, special features of these positions can also intervene to make proving a general point difficult. Nevertheless, on each occasion where you see one such enigma presented, hope is aroused that this time a final answer might appear.

title: Global Income Plus Fund Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Net income represents net investment income.

title: New Details in Book on Brawley Case
description: A new book on the Tawana Brawley case gives new details about how the black teen-ager fabricated her story that she had been raped by white men.

title: Athletics' Stewart Wins 20th Clemente Award
description: Dave Stewart of the Oakland Athletics, who has won 20 games in each of the last three seasons and pitched a no-hit game on June 29 against the Toronto Blue Jays, yesterday was honored for nonsporting achievements. The 33-year-old right-handed pitcher was named the recipient of the 20th Roberto Clemente Award, which is presented annually to the player who best exemplifies the spirit of the late Pittsburgh Pirates' Hall of Fame outfielder.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a computer technology known as virtual reality misidentified the television program on which Timothy Leary demonstrated such a system. It was the ABC News program ''20/20,'' not CBS ''60 Minutes.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: Designs for 'When the Midi Is Just Right'
description: Fashion is almost always in a state of flux, so it is curious that hemlines on the runways have remained stable for about three years. With surprising unanimity, leading designers in Europe and America have shown suits, dresses and, for fall, coats that are no more than fingertip length. An occasional below-the-knees style is seen on the runway and immediately dubbed dowdy.

title: King Jury Hears Tape
description: The jury in the Manhattan trial of Don King's breach-of-contract suit against James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, yesterday heard a tape of King made shortly after Douglas knocked out Mike Tyson in February.

title: Bulgaria's Renamed Communists in Disarray After Election
description: Despite their solid victory in elections to Parliament last month, Bulgaria's renamed Communists are acting like a party in disarray.

title: Anacin Account Shifted
description: Advertising agency executives yesterday confirmed a trade magazine report that Whitehall Laboratories, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, New York, had switched the $17 million advertising account of the pain reliever Anacin to Partners & Shevack from Young & Rubicam. Partners & Shevack is already the agency for Anacin-3.

title: Busch Fighting Tax
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, St. Louis, has begun a television and radio campaign attacking proposals to increase the Federal tax on beer.
