The ads, along with print ads sponsored by the Beer Institute in Washington, are being run in the districts of members of Congress involved in budget negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan for Galeries Lafayette to open a store on the site previously occupied by Bonwit Teller misstated the address. It is at 4 East 57th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. Fifth and 57th is the address of Tiffany's.

title: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television;   A Modern Life Lived in 50's and 60's Images
description: Some marketing expert seems to have taken a look at the enormous film and television library owned by Universal Studios and wondered why it wasn't doing more to generate income. Hey, how about a show in which the hero's behavior and attitudes are counterpointed with black-and-white clips from all those shows and old movies he watched on television while growing up in the 1950's and 60's? The supporting cast could include everybody from Bette Davis to Peter Lorre to Jack Benny. As they say in the business, what a concept!

title: Merrill Banker Quitting To Seek a Faster Track
description: Not too long ago, a career in investment banking was considered the fast track. In the 1980's, eager executives flocked to Wall Street to reshape companies and to get rich.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in SportsMonday yesterday comparing Ryne Sandberg of the Chicago Cubs with other great second basemen misstated the number of games played by Rabbit Maranville at second base. It was 513.

title: First Federal Savings Bank of Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $16,717,000 increase in loan-loss provision following examination by regulators for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: Homophobia: Scientists Find Clues To Its Roots
description: A RISE in hostile actions against homosexuals can be traced primarily to hatred based on fear and self-righteousness rather than to the AIDS epidemic, researchers are finding. Although polls show more Americans are beginning to accept homosexual men and women and support their rights, there has been a great increase in reports of anti-gay bias since the beginning of the epidemic. But rather than creating the new hostility, researchers have found, the disease has given bigots an excuse to act out their hatred.

title: Hong Kong to Try 5 Beijing Foes; Charge: Illegal Use of Megaphones
description: In a few days, the British Government will put on trial five prominent pro-democracy campaigners accused of using hand-held megaphones without a permit at demonstrations here. Critics say that the move is an attempt to appease the Government in Beijing.

title: Senate Set to Take Up Civil Rights Bill
description: With the White House and civil rights groups at an impasse, the Senate is scheduled this week to take up major civil rights legislation that President Bush has vowed to veto.

title: New York Is Reportedly Chosen For '92 Democratic Convention
description: The Democratic Party will hold its 1992 Presidential convention at Madison Square Garden, Democrats in New York and Washington said yesterday.

title: Britain Will Reopen Inquiry on the Titanic
description: Britain said today that it would reopen a 1912 inquiry into whether many of those lost with the Titanic could have been saved by a ship that was nearby when the liner sank.

title: Crownamerica Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: For the 9 months ended June 3, 1989, Crownamerica had an after-tax gain of $319,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of a U.K. subsidiary, and exchange gains of $147,000, or 14 cents a share; for the 9 months ended June 2, 1990, Crownamerica had exchange gains of $330,000, or 31 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr., the presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court for the First Department, referred incorrectly to a letter sent him by a judicial review committee. The letter, which Justice Murphy made public yesterday, said he had ''failed to exercise adequate supervision'' over the former Clerk of the Court, Harold J. Reynolds, in dealings with a judicial disciplinary committee; it did not specifically warn Justice Murphy against interfering with proceedings against lawyers. A corrective article appears today on page B1.

title: Growing Pressures for a Married Priesthood
description: Leo T. is a Roman Catholic priest who, like Catholic priests around the world, took a vow of celibacy when he was ordained. For the last 10 years, however, Leo T. has had a sexual relationship with a woman.

title: Our Towns;   At Jones Beach, A 'Public Sector' To Be Proud Of
description: By noon Sunday it was hot and hazy and there were 100,000 human beings at Jones Beach, including James Daw, a lawyer, and his wife and children. ''Well, the main reason we like Jones Beach,'' said Mr. Daw, ''is, as you can see, we're all alone.'' It was true. Mr. Daw was only a 15-minute walk from his car in the West End 1 parking lot, but Jones Beach is so big, there's always a place to be alone.

title: The Right to Attend a Trial
description: The trial of the District of Columbia's Mayor, Marion Barry, on drug and perjury charges brims with racial tension. The judge made matters worse by barring two prominent supporters, the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader, and Bishop George Stallings Jr., a former Catholic priest who heads a breakaway congregation. They had denounced the trial as a racist, political lynching. But as the U.S. Court of Appeals rightly says, they may not be kept from attending the trial on that account.

title: Cooling-Off Period Is Set At Eastern
description: Contract talks between Eastern Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association have reached an impasse and a 30-day period for cooling off will begin on Tuesday, the sides said today.

title: Benihana National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $140,000, or 2 cents a share for both the quarter and year, which represents provision for gain on disposition of frozen food division.

title: Texas Instruments Is Suing 5 Chip Makers Over a Patent
description: Texas Instruments Inc. asked a Federal court today to rule that five American chip makers must obtain licenses to continue using a technique for gluing semiconductor components to their base. Texas Instruments said the technique is based on a chip packaging method that it patented in 1977.

title: ROEMER IS SILENT ON ABORTION BILL
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer refused to say today whether he would sign or veto a strict anti-abortion bill that the Legislature quickly drafted and passed Sunday night.

title: In the Rushdie Affair, Terrorism Triumphs
description: To the Editor:

title: Education Group's Report Card for Fernandez: 'B Average'
description: After six months on the job, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has been graded ''B average'' by a leading New York City educational advocacy group.

title: Finding a Home for Last Year's Model
description: ANALYSTS say there are at least 40 million personal computers in use worldwide, and millions of new PC's will be added this year. To Alex Randall, that means there are at least 40 million used computers out there that will eventually need a new home.

title: Avantek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $204,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $248,000, or 1 cent a share for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: General Signal Sale Of Ultratech Is Set
description: The General Signal Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Ultratech Stepper division to a venture capital company and the division's employees.

title: Still a Cold War for Aliens
description: For 38 years, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has allowed the U.S. to bar foreign visitors whose ideas the Government finds offensive. The number of visitors kept out each year varies, but the Government maintains a list of more than 350,000 people to be excluded. At a time when world tensions are easing, that's an astounding victory of narrow-mindedness over good sense.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 17, 18 and 23 about a fatal flood in Shadyside, Ohio, and a map on June 23, referred incorrectly to a creek that overflowed. It is Wegee Creek.

title: Connecticut May Retry Daughter in Death Plot
description: Karin Aparo, who was acquitted last month on charges that she was an accessory to her mother's murder, returned to court today as her lawyer requested that she be treated as a youthful offender if she is retried on charges that she conspired to kill her mother in 1987.

title: Buyout Unit Finds Banks In UAL Deal
description: One month before a deadline for financing a $4.38 billion acquisition of the UAL Corporation, the employee buyout group has enlisted the tentative financial support of five major banks, according to United's unions and bank officials. But none of the banks have signed agreements to provide loans, and several obstacles remain to be overcome before the Aug. 9 deadline, including winning the support of a large group of nonunion United employees.

title: Thornburgh and Sessions Assailed for Traveling on Confiscated Jets
description: A Congressional report criticizes Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for their official travel aboard three executive jets seized from drug traffickers.

title: By Design;   In Pulsating Color
description: If you're planning to experiment with color, one way to swing into it is with a bright bag.

title: Sallie Mae Prices $600 Million Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced a $600 million issue yesterday in its regular monthy sale. The Government-sponsored public corporation usually sells short-term floating-rate notes on the Monday before the second Thursday of each month, The notes, due Jan. 10, 1991, were priced at par to yield 25 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill and are expected to begin trading today. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

title: Seven Oaks International Inc. reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $229,000 and $3,041,000 for the latest year and 1989, respectively. The latest year also included the utilization of capital loss carryforward of $173,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Riney Helps Foote, Cone In Creating a Parody Ad
description: ''High in the mountains of France, near a village called Combloux, there's a source of clean, crystal-clear water thas s as refshshg g any on Earth,'' says the folksy voice of Hal Riney in a television commercial that began yesterday.

title: Crestmont Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a penalty on prepayment of FHLB advances of $1,504,000. c-Net income The company said the fourth quarter loss was due primarily to the provision of $7.077 million for increased loan reserves, a writedown of real estate owned (''RED'') of $1.4 million, a write-off of $769,000 representing all of Crestmont's equity investment in a real estate development joint venture partnership, a provision of $528,000 for RED reserves, a provision of $500,000 for the potential costs of branch closings, and a reduction as a result of the examination findings in the value of excess mortgage servicing of $1.2 million. Loans charged-off in the fourth quarter amounted to $7.8 million, resulting in a remaining allowance for loan losses of $11.4 million, which was deemed adequate for circumstances existing at the present time.

title: A Toast of Optimism for the '94 Cup!
description: Praise flowed like Italian wine today, as officials of the world governing body for soccer and the organizing committee of the 1990 World Cup expressed unconditional joy over the monthlong tournament that ended Sunday night.

title: All-Stars Take On Wrigley's Tricky Winds
description: Jose Canseco, Cecil Fielder, Mark McGwire and Ken Griffey Jr., meet Wrigley Field, the windblown park that can make pitchers weep and the bleachers the most important place to be.

title: General Dynamics In Saudi Tank Deal
description: Saudi Arabia has signed a $3.1 billion deal to buy 315 M-1A2 tanks and support equipment from the General Dynamics Corporation, the Pentagon said today.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry On Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal investigation into whether the company issued false financial statements from April 1986 through March 1989. Western Union said that the S.E.C. was examining whether Western Union said that it believes its financial statements ''were accurate in all material respects'' and that it would cooperate fully.

title: Thinning Arctic Ice
description: Surveys by submarines have turned up evidence that ice in the Arctic Ocean may have been thinner in the 1980's than in the 1970's, and scientists have tentatively raised the possibility that the thinning might have been caused by global warming.

title: 2 Shuttle Veterans Grounded By NASA
description: FOR the first time, NASA yesterday grounded two astronauts for violations of its safety rules. One astronaut was involved in a fatal collision of stunt planes at an air show in central Texas last weekend. The two astronatuts are veteran shuttle crew commanders. ''It's the first time we've ever replaced members of a crew for disciplinary reasons,'' said Jeffrey E. Carr, a spokesman at the Johnson Space Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Newberry Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said loan loss provision was $22,500 for the latest and year-ago quarters and $45,000 for the latest and year-ago 6 months.

title: Witness Says He Gave Barry Cocaine in Mayor's Office
description: A local restaurateur testified today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial that he delivered cocaine to the Mayor in his City Hall office and saw him use the drug more than 30 times at places from Washington to the Bahamas.

title: Make Farm Programs Work as They Should;   Our Fiasco in India
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ASK Computer Systems, Mountain View, Calif., appointed Eric Carlson vice president for engineering and product operations.

title: Thrift Crooks in Jail
description: To the Editor:

title: First National Bancorp (Ga.) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Riveting and Withering on Grass
description: Parched was the password for the 1990 Wimbledon.

title: After The Cold War
description: ''The walls that once confined people and ideas are collapsing.'' With those words the leaders of the Western alliance celebrated the end of the cold war. They pledged their efforts to ''overcome the legacy of decades of suspicion.''

title: French Seek Niche With Trump Site
description: Annoucing that it would open its first American outpost in Trump Tower in Manhattan, Galeries Lafayette, France's largest department store, said it would specialize in women's clothes made in Europe in an effort to succeed in a neighborhood that contains some of the world's most fashionable retailers.

title: American Capital & Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: War-Crimes Suspect Seeks to Stay in Canada
description: A German-born rocket scientist who played an important role in the Apollo moon-landing program has begun a legal battle to stay in Canada as a visitor while he tries to regain the United States citizenship he lost six years ago as a result of war-crimes allegations.

title: U.S. Takes the Lead
description: Just when the noise level of complaints about lack of American vision in response to the new needs of Europe was reaching screech point, the Bush Administration came up with an impressive new plan.

title: Sentence in Rape Hoax Appealed
description: A woman who falsely accused a man of raping her appealed today to the Nebraska Supreme Court her perjury sentence, which requires her to pay for advertisements apologizing to the man.

title: Connecticut Indian Land in Legal Quandary
description: For more than 300 years, since one of the first Indian reservations in the New World was set aside near what is now Bridgeport, the law of Connecticut has been the law of all the lands within it.

title: Panel Hears How Federal Aid Profited a Savings Institution
description: A Senate subcommittee was told today that a Texas savings and loan association made up of 15 failed institutions earned huge profits as a result of Government subsidies, but made only four new loans in 1989.

title: 51 Albanians Fly to Prague and Quickly Receive Political Asylum
description: Fifty-one Albanians who had sought refuge in the Czechoslovak Embassy in Tirana, the Albanian capital, were flown to Prague early this morning, where they were granted political asylum, officials here and in Tirana said.

title: Cape Cod Bank & Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed the decline in earnings to a decline in the size of its loan portfolio and the continuation of a larger than normal provision for loan losses. For the latest quarter, Cape Cod Bank provided $1,255,000 for loan losses, resulting in a reserve of $4.9 million. This charge against income was $880,000 more than in the 1989 second quarter, reduced earnings by 21 cents per share.

title: Gorbachev Wins Fight On Leadership of Party
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today won a fight over the structure of the Communist Party leadership, limiting the prospect that he will be hobbled by hard-liners.

title: Flatbush Store Manager Held In Assault on Black Woman
description: A manager of a Korean grocery store in Brooklyn has been charged in an assault on a black customer that set off a boycott of the store.

title: New Trade Center in Washington: Will It Help or Hurt the Kennedy?
description: Work is to begin in September on a monumental $738 million structure to be known as the International Cultural and Trade Center. The complex, to be completed in 1995, is to be situated on Pennsylvania Avenue two blocks from the White House, and will also provide office space for a number of Federal agencies.

title: Larry Conrad Is Dead; Indiana Politician, 55
description: Larry Conrad, a former Secretary of State of Indiana, died Saturday at the Cardiology Hospital in Lyons, France. He was 55 years old. Mr. Conrad suffered a ruptured aorta while attending a conference in France last month and died after undergoing open-heart surgery, Gov. Evan Bayh's office announced. Mr. Conrad was a legislative assistant to former Senator Birch Bayh, the father of the Governor, in the 1960's and was chief counsel to the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on constitutional amendments from 1964 to 1969. He helped to draft the 25th Amendment, which deals with Presidential succession and disability.

title: Accused Judge Says Letter Shows He Is Cleared
description: One of the state's most powerful judges has released a confidential letter sent to him by a state judicial review committee, which he said cleared him of allegations that he had interfered with disciplinary proceedings involving lawyers.

title: U.S.O.C. Offers to Help in Drug Testing
description: The director of the United States Olympic Committee said that his organization would help The Athletics Congress untangle the web of controversy surrounding its drug-testing procedures by assuming responsiblity for testing.

title: Are Laws Needed On Canned Music At Live Shows?
description: With the best intentions, state legislators in New York and New Jersey are wading into a quagmire as they propose laws regulating the use of recorded music at live concerts.

title: Brick Brewing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Carrington Labs reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $22,000 for the quarter and $50,000, or 1 cent a share for the 6 months.

title: Denise Musnik; Advertising Executive, 58
description: Denise Musnik, an advertising executive in Paris, died on Friday at the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France. Miss Musnik, who was born in New York, was 58 years old and had lived in Paris for about 30 years. She died of cancer, a friend said. Miss Musnik was head of international communications for Publicis, the French advertising agency, and had previously worked for Glamour Magazine and Bonwit Teller.

title: Calton Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The company said revenues for 1990 included $13.1 million and $21.9 million for the sale of land for the quarter and 6-month periods ended May 31, 1990, respectively.

title: U.P.S. Deal Set
description: Mail Boxes Etc. signed a letter of intent to sell to United Parcel Service Inc. 400,000 shares of its common stock for $10.1 million and 400,000 warrants, each exercisable into one share of Mail Boxes common stock, for $1.2 million. If U.P.S. fully exercises the warrants, it would acquire about a 17.4 percent equity interest in Mail Boxes. The stock of Mail Boxes Etc. jumped $3 today, to $25, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Linear Technology reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Chronicle
description: DR. THOMAS STARZL, a leader in the transplantation of human organs, was resting comfortably in fair condition at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh yesterday after being hospitalized on Sunday with chest pains, hospital officials said.

title: Jerome Wolk; Lawyer, 73
description: Jerome Wolk, a lawyer and real-estate developer on eastern Long Island, died on Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 73 years old and lived in Great Neck.

title: Majestic Electronic Stores reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Denial by Thompson
description: The Georgetown University coach, John Thompson, in New York yesterday to promote Nike television commericals with a pro-education and anti-drug message, denied that the commercials were made in response to the recent controversy over high-priced sneakers.

title: Dow Up 9.16, to 2,914.11, in Light Trading
description: Stocks seesawed yesterday in persistent computer-assisted buying and selling programs before advancing slightly in light trading.

title: Talcon L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and included net gain of $833,000 on sale of partnership interest for both the quarter and 6 months. Average units were 5,706,000 for both 1990 periods; average units were 5,706,000 and 4,788,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share losses for 1990 periods were for Class B limited partnership units. The partnership recorded a gain from equity in operations of joint ventures in which it participates of $126,000 in the latest quarter, and a loss for the 6 months of $405,000, compared with a gain of $2,358,000 for the prior quarter, and a gain of $2,465,000 for the year-ago 6 months.

title: Lease Improves Trump's Financial Picture
description: The long-term lease that Donald J. Trump signed yesterday with Galeries Lafayette is worth between $50 and $65 million, bankers said.

title: Union Leader Vows to Win Pay Increases
description: Negotiations on labor contracts for New York City municipal workers opened yesterday with the president of the largest union vowing to extract wage and benefit concessions from a Mayor the union helped to elect.

title: Inquest Held 3 Christian Scientists Contributed to the Death of a Boy
description: Three Christian Science officials contributed to the death of Robyn Twitchell by discouraging his parents from calling a doctor, according to an inquest concluded three years ago and released last week.

title: Back Surgery For Lemieux
description: Mario Lemieux will have back surgery Wednesday but there is a 90-percent chance he will be ready for the start of the Pittsburgh Penguins' season, the team doctor said today.

title: Venezuela in Shift on Citgo
description: The Venezuelan state oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., no longer plans to sell the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it purchased in February from the Southland Corporation, a senior Petroleos official said today.

title: Talking Business; with Berry of Dominion Resources;   Electricity Use Expected to Rise
description: Because of the heat last week, the demand for electricity rose so greatly in Washington that the local power company blacked out parts of its territory, again raising the question of whether electricity supplies are adequate.

title: Unions Loath To Strike Daily News
description: Six months after the opening of what both sides knew would be difficult contract talks, the 10 unions at The Daily News remain far from a settlement with the management. But in recent weeks, they appear to have won some maneuvering room.

title: Safety-Kleen Corp. reports earnings for 12wks to June 16
Oil Production By Venezuela
description: Venezuela's state oil company Friday announced plans to increase production capacity nearly 50 percent in the next few years, despite a world oil glut that is driving prices down.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Fall
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose in slow trading yesterday as the negative reaction to the data on June employment continued.

title: Ex-Official in Prague Convicted of Abuses
description: The former municipal head of the Communist Party in Prague was convicted today of abusing power by ordering the police to deal harshly with anti-Government demonstrators. The ex-official, Miroslav Stepan, was sentenced to four years in prison. He said he would appeal.

title: Japanese Shrine Burns Down
description: A fire today destroyed an important Shinto shrine guarding sacred rice being grown for the coronation of Emperor Akihito. The police said they suspected anti-monarchist militants, who have said that they plan to disrupt Akihito's November coronation. They say the imperial system is a remnant of prewar nationalism. An official of the Akita prefecture police said there were no reports of injuries at the shrine in Akita, situated almost 300 miles north of Tokyo. No one was in the shrine when the fire broke out before dawn.

title: The Arts on Parade
description: A New Yorker at a small-town Fourth of July parade last week was thrilled by the bugle and drum corps, the floats and a veritable retrospective of fire trucks through the centuries. But what thrilled her most were those marchers who brandished banners for the National Endowment for the Arts. She liked their own small float, too - a city built of cardboard and colored a dark, dismal gray, over which was a sign that read ''A World Without Art.''

title: Chamber Society's Director Reins In After a Year
description: ''It's funny how a season's schedule turns out,'' said Fred Sherry, unpinning next season's Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center prospectus from a bulletin board in his office at Alice Tully Hall. ''You start out with certain instrumental combinations, and you don't have complete control over that, because it depends on who is available. In fact, if I have any regrets about my job it's that I would like to do twice the number of works I can fit in a season. Our programs are a distillation of the best things I can think of.''

title: Secom General reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for the latest quarter and year-ago periods are less than 1 cent.

title: Trying to Spare a Tree
description: COMPUTERS were supposed to lead to the paperless office. They haven't done so, and probably never will, but a program for the Macintosh called SuperGlue II can spare a few trees.

title: Scott's Hospitality reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $98,328,000, or $1.65 a share, mostly from the sale of the hotel division and other interests, for the latest year. Net income for 1989 included an extraordinary loss of $1,051,000. The company said the earnings improvement was due mainly to reduced financial expense during part of the year and a lower effective income tax rate. It said borrowing costs were lower as cash proceeds from the sale of the Canadian hotels division, a hotel in England and a U.K. transportation subsidiary were applied to reduce debt. The company said earnings from foreign operations were hurt by a stronger Canadian dollar. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Oce-van der Grinten NV reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Converted from Dutch florins at Dlf 1.9136: US$ 1.00. The nominal NLG 20.00 Oce share was split May 9 into five par value shares of NLG 4.00 each. For Oce's U.S. ADRs, which have always had a par value of NLG 4.00, the split means that one ADR equals one ordinary share.

title: Candidate Is Asked to Quit Church Position
description: A candidate for the State Legislature has been asked to resign from the parish council of a Roman Catholic church because he supports a woman's right to have an abortion.

title: Spectrum Information Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $102,000 and $530,000, or 2 cents a share, for the latest and prior years, respectively. The company said it narrowed its operating loss to $2,179,571 for the year end from its operating loss (before an extraordinary item) of $4,367,884 for the prior fiscal year. This represents an improvement in the loss per share before extraordinary item to 6 cents per share from 16 cents per share for the period. Revenues represent operating revenues. Fourth-quarter results were not immediately available.

title: Calspan Awarded Air Force Contract
description: Arvin Industries said its Calspan Corporation unit had been awarded a five-year contract to operate and maintain aerospace flight dynamics test facilities at the Air Force's Arnold Engineering Development Center in Tennessee. Total value of the contract over the five years is $276.5 million, Arvin said.

title: American Bank of Connecticut reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Europeans Accuse the U.S. of Balking on Plans to Combat Global Warming
description: Senior European officials at the economic summit conference accused the United States today of frustrating their efforts to reach a new accord to combat global warming.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Houston Summit

title: ISRAEL'S JETS RAID SHIITES IN LEBANON
description: For the second day in succession, Israeli fighter-bombers pounded bases belonging to the pro-Iranian Party of God in southern Lebanon today.

title: Market Place;   Cleaning Spills: Is It Profitable?
description: FROM the Exxon Valdez to the Mega Borg, when a tanker's oil hits the water these days, huge sums are spent on booms, skimmers and personnel for the cleanup. But there are no pure plays in oil-spill cleanup companies.

title: Accounts
description: * Australian Meat and Livestock Corp., to Brouillard/LGFE, for the Fresh Australian Range Lamb program.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING

title: Study Links Alzheimer's and Heart Attacks
description: IN a surprising finding from a study in the Bronx, two of the most common ailments of the elderly, heart attacks and Alzheimer's disease, have been linked for the first time.

title: Flexible Bond Trust Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Net income represents net investment income.

title: Rain and Cooler Trend Slow Alaskan Fires
description: Rain and lower temperatures over the weekend helped slow the spread of wildfires that have charred more than 550,000 acres of timber, but 2,100 firefighters remained on the job today.

title: Premier Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Loan loss provision was $5,965,000 and $9,549,000 for the latest quarter and 6 months, respectively; loan loss provision was $73,341,000 and $87,689,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said its management has determined that market conditions are not favorable for the completion of the asset restructuring plan in the form announced last year. At that time, the company proposed to spin off its non-performing assets into a separate bank, Florida Street National Bank, and to sell $112 million in investment grade securities and a similar amount of junk bonds. However, with the troubled junk bond market, the company said it decided to change its asset restructuring plan. The special assets division, which would have become the Florida Street National Bank, has experienced better-than-forecasted results relative to collection of the underperforming assets proposed to be sold to the Florida Street National Bank.

title: Judge Blocks Savings Sale
description: A Federal judge forbade the sale by the Resolution Trust Company of an insolvent savings institution to a Arkansas bank yesterday on the ground that the sale would violate that state's laws limiting branch banking.

title: Telescopes Peer Through Cosmic Dust Into Maelstrom at Galaxy's Center
description: ASTRONOMERS are peering deep into the heart of the Milky Way galaxy and seeing a riotous display of nearly every phenomenon of nature known to science, and possibly then some.

title: Paris Journal;   50 Years Later, de Gaulle's Glory Blinds France
description: Fifty years after France surrendered to Nazi Germany, Gen. Charles de Gaulle has once again come to the rescue, providing a series of competing anniversaries to help distract from wartime memories that many French would rather forget.

title: Careers;   Graduates Find Tighter Job Market
description: THIS year's college graduates are having a harder time finding jobs than did the class of 1989, say Lee J. Svete, director of the office of career planning at St. Lawrence University, a liberal arts college in Canton, N.Y., and Vicki Lynn, director of the career development center at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy.

title: Output Climbs in China
description: China's industrial output rose by 5.9 percent in June compared with the comparable period a year ago. It was the biggest monthly jump this year. The New China News Agency said today that the rate was evidence of a steady economic recovery from a stagnant period earlier this year. But diplomats said the figure might be artificially high because a great deal of production was lost last June in the aftermath of the military crackdown in Beijing against pro-democracy demonstrations.

title: Dukakis Delays a Rise In Massachusetts Taxes
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today delayed signing a $1.8 billion tax measure that the Massachusetts Legislature sent him on Saturday, instead asking the state's highest court for an advisory opinion on the constitutionality of the proposed tax increase.

title: 'Penny Stock' Broker Fined
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that it had fined a brokerage for defrauding investors who bought a ''penny stock'' of a small food producer.

title: Ford Extends Buyer Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had extended buyer incentives on most 1989 and 1990 model cars until Aug. 8. The incentives were scheduled to expire today. Incentives on Lincoln cars were extended to Sept. 26, the auto maker said. Ford's incentives range from $600 for the Aerostar mini-van and some pickups to $2,000 for the Lincoln Mark VII.

title: Jones Agency Hired For Trump Project
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, said yesterday that he had hired Caroline Jones Advertising as the agency of record for Trump City, his development project on Manhattan's West Side. The agency has been working on the account, whose size was not released, for several months.

title: Make Farm Programs Work as They Should;   For Truly Free Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Mailman, 88, Head of Philanthropy
description: Joseph L. Mailman, an investor and philanthropist who was president of the Mailman Foundation, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: Telling Nation's Fortune: Does Consensus See All?
description: In the mid-1970's, as Robert J. Eggert was about to retire as chief economist for RCA, he figured the company would want to continue his practice of conducting regular private surveys of what economic forecasters thought about the future. After all, he had begun the surveys with the encouragement of RCA's chairman, David Sarnoff.

title: California Amplifier Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Net loss

title: Why Math Drive in New York Schools Doesn't Stand a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: United Mobile Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Salvadoran Jesuits Told the Truth and Died
description: To the Editor:

title: Passport Travel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
An Investment Banker Moves to Brick Making
description: Philip R. Mengel, an investment banker, is moving from an abstract business to a concrete one, and from New York City to Reading, Pa., where the company he will head makes concrete products, bricks and other building materials.

title: Vroooooooooooooooom Ends in 'Here's Your $220 Summons'
description: John Mayak, a tour-bus driver from Pennsylvania, arrived in New York for the first time yesterday, so you can't blame him for being a bit surprised when a city inspector tapped on the door of his bus and presented him with a $220 ticket. For idling. Not a man to hide his feelings, Mr. Mayak got back into the driver's seat and gunned his engine, spewing a gust of exhaust over the inspector.

title: I've Overstepped My Powers? No Way
description: LEAD: In January, I issued Circular 37 to the community school board presidents in order to give the Chancellor a role in the selection of community school superintendents. I knew then that we would be challenged in court by defenders of the status quo and petty special interests. I also knew that a judge might not affirm what I believed then, and believe now, to be within the existing powers of the

title: Vincent Draddy, 83, an Innovator In Apparel Manufacturing, Dies
description: Vincent de Paul Draddy, an innovative manufacturer of sportswear who introduced the Izod and Lacoste knit shirts to America, died on Sunday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Takeover Rumors Lift Crown's Stock
description: The stock of the Crown Cork and Seal Company rose $2.25 today, to $63.125, on takeover rumors fueled by the death of its chairman, John Connelly, who was 85 years old. Mr. Connelly held 15.2 percent of the company's stock.

title: Q&A
description: Talking to Bambi

title: And for the G.O.P., Many Sites Contend
description: The Republican National Committee is considering many cities for its 1992 convention, including New York, Cleveland, Houston, San Diego, New Orleans, Miami, Anaheim, Calif., and St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: In Hong Kong, a New Confidence
description: To the list of fictional acts of derring-do attributed to the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, the popular cartoon characters, many in this British colony now add a real feat: helping rescue the Hong Kong stock market.

title: RF&P Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $3.9 million (pretax) of merger-related expenses. Investment income for the latest 6 months declined to $4.4 million from $10.1 million in the year-earlier period, which included a $6.8 million gain from the 1989 sale of a portion of the company's investment in Trailer Train Co.

title: CVB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per shares are fully diluted. Per share earnings for the year-ago periods have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected to shareholders on Nov. 6, 1989.

title: Communicable Diseases Masked Behind Doctors' Erratic Reporting
description: WHEN computer programmers talk about garbage in, garbage out, they could also be referring to the problems some health officials have with statistics that are important to the control of communicable diseases.

title: Bridge
description: Early in the century, even before auction bridge turned into contract, it was normal in many parts of the world for bridge columns to end with a double-dummy problem. Such problems rarely appear naturally, but the diagramed deal from the Spingold Knockout Teams in Chicago last August is certainly a candidate.

title: Manville Plan Urged By Judge
description: A Federal judge took the first steps yesterday toward consolidating hundreds of thousands of asbestos cases from around the nation into one large class action before him, in what he described as an effort to control the enormous legal costs.

title: DCNY Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Jury Starts Considering Case In 2d Child Molestation Trial
description: Raymond Buckey's molestation trial went to the jury today after Judge Stanley Weisberg of Superior Court delivered 30 minutes of legal instructions.

title: Brooklyn Man Pleads Guilty To a Subway Painting Fraud
description: A Brooklyn man who duped dozens of people into paying him ''insurance'' money while working on a bogus painting job in the subway system pleaded guilty to fraud yesterday, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, announced.

title: OPEC Output Slipped in June
description: Oil output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries fell by 420,000 barrels a day in June, to 23.26 million, mainly because of a sharp drop in Iranian production, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: Machine Technology reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said that gross margins improved to 42 percent for the latest quarter from 40 percent for the third quarter of 1989.

title: Prague's Plan to Aid Moscow
description: While the economic summit meeting in Houston is focused on the question of aid to the Soviet Union, hardly anything is being said about the fragile economies of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, which are suffering from the monetary and economic unification of the two Germanys. There is a way to address both issues simultaneously.

title: On Horse Racing;   Help Wanted for Filly Triple Crown
description: While everyone was busy lamenting the disintegration of this year's Triple Crown series for 3-year-old colts, the triple crown for fillies was quietly falling apart on its own.

title: 3d-Party Interest In Takeover Target
description: The General Instrument Corporation disclosed that it had been approached by an unidentified financial concern seeking information about the New York-based electronics company. The disclosure came as Forstmann Little & Company formally began its friendly $1.6 billion tender offer for the company.

title: Frances Vengen; Union Official, 93
description: Frances Vengen, a garment industry union official for 25 years, died on Wednesday at her home in Lake City, Fla. She was 93 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. There are no immediate survivors.

title: Oneok Inc. reports earnings for 12mos to May 31
description: Share earnings for year-ago 12 months have been restated for a 2-for- 1 stock split effective last quarter. The company said increases in earnings per share and net income in the latest 12 months are primarily the result of large writedowns of assets in the previous year which are no longer adversely affecting operations expense.

title: CHILEAN MILITARY DEFENDS KILLINGS
description: In an emotional national debate set off by recent discoveries of mass graves, the Chilean armed forces have defended the widespread executions after the overthrow of Salvador Allende Gossens in 1973 as a response to ''internal war'' instigated by Allende partisans.

title: Trade School Agrees to Pay For Violations
description: The largest chain of private trade schools in New York City has agreed to pay $850,000 for recruiting violations, the largest penalty ever assessed on a trade-school operator in the state.

title: New Musicals Project Puts 2d Production on Hold
description: The New Musicals program at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., has put its second production, ''The Secret Garden,'' on hold, and a refinancing of the program is being explored, the program's executive producer, Martin J. Bell, said yesterday.

title: Dr. Jacob H. Conn, 86, A Psychiatrist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Jacob Harry Conn, a psychiatrist and educator for 50 years, died Wednesday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 86 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Dick Turpin; Former Boxing Champion, 69
description: Dick Turpin, the first black fighter to win a British boxing title, died recently in Leamington Spa, English newspapers reported today. He was 69 years old.

title: Sex Differentiation
description: NEWLY discovered fossils of a tree-dwelling primate that lived in North America 50 million years ago show the earliest known signs of sexual differentiation in primate behavior, paleontologists say.

title: Books of The Times;   Primitive as a Mirror to Modern Eyes
description: Gone Primitive

title: Whose Game Is It, Anyway?
description: Some folks starting in the All-Star Game tonight in Wrigley Field, by dint of the fans' ballot, are not having years nearly as fancy as others who will be riding the cushions in the dugout.

title: Make Farm Programs Work as They Should
description: To the Editor:

title: Keystone Heritage Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Milastar Corp.  reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $170,000, or 8 cents a share. The company said net income for fiscal 1989 included a $4,482,000 non- recurring capital gain before taxes from the sale of a stock investment and a $450,000 increase in interest income.

title: Mitsubishi Trust in U.S. Options Deal
description: Eager to give its corporate clients worldwide an opportunity to deal in futures and options, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation of Japan said today that it would form a venture with the Chicago Research and Trading Group Ltd., one of this country's leading traders of options and futures.

title: Auto Makers Split on Tax
description: Sharp disagreement among Detroit auto makers over the need for a rise in gasoline taxes could reduce the industry's influence in the debate over reducing the Federal budget deficit, the American Automobile Association says.

title: Sandinista Protests Turn Violent; 4 Are Reported Killed in Managua
description: A faltering strike by Sandinista-led Government employees abruptly turned into a violent political showdown today as Sandinista workers and students built barricades and burned vehicles at major intersections throughout the capital, bringing it to a standstill.

title: A Wistful Glance Back At When the Wall Fell
description: The breach of the Berlin wall was probably Gunther Schabowski's greatest achievement, and it was also his undoing.

title: Marriott Corp. reports earnings for 12wks to June 15
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $12,000,000, or 11 cents a share, and $20,000,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Ford Cancels Plant In the Philippines
description: The Ford Motor Company has canceled plans to build a $150 million car-stereo plant in the Philippines because of fears about political stablility and security, the Trade and Industry Secretary, Jose Concepcion, said. He said Ford was now considering Indonesia for a new site.

title: U.S. PUSHES TO END FARMING SUBSIDIES
description: The leaders of the seven richest Western nations began their 16th annual summit conference in the tropical heat of Houston this afternoon, with an intractable dispute over trade policy threatening to disrupt the unity of the three-day meeting.

title: Two of Three Convicted in Futures Case
description: In the first of three trials stemming from the Government's undercover investigation of futures trading here, a Federal jury today convicted two traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange of cheating customers but acquitted a third defendant. The jurors were unable to reach verdicts on dozens of other charges.

title: Rangers Go With Youth And Deal For 2 Wings
description: The Rangers, rolling the dice and replenishing the supply of youth they had drained through trades, yesterday completed two deals for right wings about whom there are definite questions but for whom there could be bright futures.

title: Defense in Jogger Trial Argues Rights Violation
description: Defense lawyers in the Central Park rape trial tried to show yesterday that one of the defendants charged with attempted murder and rape of a jogger last year was arrested without first being read his rights.

title: Vincent Awaiting Word From Steinbrenner
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent, here to attend Tuesday's All-Star Game, said today that he had not heard from George Steinbrenner or Steinbrenner's representatives since Friday, when a two-day hearing into the Yankee owner's dealings with Howard Spira and Dave Winfield was adjourned. At that hearing, Vincent gave Steinbrenner until the close of business on Wednesday to tell him whether he would add any more information to what has already been compiled.

title: Patient's Right to Tissue Is Limited
description: In a case with far-reaching implications for research scientists and the biotechnology industry, the California Supreme Court ruled today that a patient does not have property rights over body tissues that may be used to develop new drugs or medicines.

title: Chase Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: John C. Carroll; Union Executive, 68
description: John C. Carroll, retired executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America, died Saturday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Forestville, Md.

title: Chance of Tuition Aid Keeps Needy in School, Study Finds
description: Minority students, often from families unable to send them to college, are staying in school longer when they participate in programs that guarantee college tuition to needy students who are academically ready, according to a study by the United States General Accounting Office released yesterday.

title: Point Richmond Journal;   Help Wtd: Exp Chef On Island W/Lux Vu
description: Buried in the classified advertisements of a recent Sunday newspaper was ''a once in a lifetime opportunity'' to earn upward of $60,000 a year running a bed and breakfast inn in a lighthouse at the junction of San Francisco and San Pablo bays.

title: Patterns
description: Fashion School Rolls Dip

title: Digital Communications Assn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain on disposal of assets of $4,372,000, or 30 cents a share. c-Included charge of $12,579,000 for research and development projects.

title: Deep Discounts By Continental
description: To attract impulsive leisure travelers, Continental Airlines is offering discounts of up to 65 percent on flights from its four hub cities during the next two weekends. The catch is that the trips must be booked before midnight tomorrow, and the travelers must return the same weekend they leave.

title: Tropical Rain Forest In Mexico Is Facing Destruction in Decade
description: THE largest tropical rain forest in North America is being razed even more rapidly than that of the Amazon and is likely to disappear altogether in this decade unless the Mexican Government takes immediate steps to halt its destruction, scientists and environmental groups here say.

title: Examination for Sasser
description: The Mets' catcher Mackey Sasser, who was hurt on Sunday in a play at home plate against the Braves, has strained ligaments in his right ankle and will be examined today by Dr. Warren Fiske, a team physician, the Mets said.

title: Oil Rig Count Falls by 9
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States declined by nine last week, to a total of 1,011, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago this week, the count was 825, Baker said. Baker Hughes's rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells.

title: Apartheid Foe Quits Pulpit in Scandal
description: The Rev. Allan A. Boesak, a Dutch Reformed cleric who gained renown in the struggle against apartheid, has resigned his ministry after acknowledging he had an extramarital affair with the niece of a former South African Cabinet minister.

title: National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Total assets were $2,100,000,000 and $2,300,000,000 for the latest and year- ago 6 months, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
Helen of Troy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
For Africa, a Nod at Democracy
description: The Organization of African Unity, a collection of more than 40 disparate countries, welcomed an independent Namibia at its annual gathering today, listened for the first time to Nelson Mandela but heard only elliptically about democracy.

title: Five Cubans Seek Protection
description: Five Cubans entered the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana today and asked for protection, an embassy spokesman reported. It is not clear whether the five are seeking political asylum in Czechoslovakia. Diplomats said it was the first time that Cubans had managed to obtain refuge in an East European embassy in Havana. Relations between thw two countries have soured since the fall of the Communist Government in Czechoslovakia last autumn.

title: Temtex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Sales figures for 1989 are restated.

title: Playing Their Own Game
description: With the World Cup and Wimbledon finally settled and the Tour de France still in early stages, international sports fans can turn this week to the World Games in Australia. Five teams are in Perth for the world championship of lacrosse - the United States, Canada, Britain, Australia and the Iroquois. Yes, the Iroquois, the fellows who invented the game, have their own team in the quadrennial playoffs for the first time.

title: Chronicle
description: The celebration of Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS'S 63d birthday today will continue a mayoral tradition of sorts: ELLEN HART STRUM, who was Miss Subways of 1959 and who now owns Ellen's Coffee Cafe at Broadway and Chambers Street, a stopping-off spot for City Hall denizens, will bake a pie for each of the Mayor's years.

title: New Microbial Agents May Help Kill Crop Pests
description: ARMIES of bugs and microbes, their powers enhanced in some cases by genetic engineering, are being unleashed in fields and laboratories in a widening effort to control destructive agricultural pests without resorting to chemical pesticides.

title: HarperCollins Buys 3 Jeffrey Archer Books
description: HarperCollins has bought the next three books of Jeffrey Archer, the English author who recently said he was offered $20 million for the books by an unnamed publishing house.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters in the Company News columns of Business Day on Friday misstated the relationship between the USAir Group and CCAir Inc., which has filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. CCAir operates USAir Express flights under a contract agreement; it is not owned by USAir.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The important question for 1992 is what kind of candidate does the Democratic Party nominate, not which city does the honors. Atlanta couldn't save our last nominee. New York is not going to do in our next one.''

title: EA Engineering, Science, and Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Americans Voicing Anxiety on Japan As Concern in Tokyo Seems to Soften
description: The American public's concern over the economic might of Japan appears to have risen sharply, heightening sentiment for limits on foreign investments, as Americans worry more about Japanese economic power than about Soviet military power.

title: WESTERN AID ISSUE SHARPLY DEBATED BY SOVIET LEADERS
description: Senior Soviet officials appealed today for Western economic help in moving the moribund Soviet economy toward a free market, but the issue has divided the Soviet Union almost as badly as it has split potential donor countries.

title: Tests Find Leak Clues On Shuttle
description: Space agency officials said today that a primary seal in a large pipe that carries liquid hydrogen fuel to the space shuttle is the ''prime suspect'' for causing leaks that have grounded all three of the spacecraft.

title: Cab of the Month
description: How slowly does traffic move in New York City on hot summer afternoons? A passenger in a taxi meditated on the subject as the crush of cars on Central Park West inched forward at the rate of one or two cars per traffic-light cycle. Then he was startled by a sight inside a cab inching along in the adjacent lane. Fastened to the dashboard, next to the clock, was a calendar.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BC Sugar Refinery Ltd., Vancouver, British Columbia, a sugar company, agreed to acquire 50 percent of Lantic Sugar Ltd. from Jannock Ltd., Toronto, for $110 million (Canadian).

title: Swiss Investor in Settlement
description: A Swiss investor has agreed to settle Federal charges that he bought shares of Rorer Group Inc. while possessing nonpublic information about a pending merger between Rorer and Rhone-Poulenc S.A.

title: INSIDE
description: Roots of Anti-Gay Bias

title: Golden Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Japan Air in Korea Link
description: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it would cooperate with Korean Air Lines to develop their computer reservation systems jointly. It said the companies would trade data bases and establish reciprocal access between Japan Air's Axcess computer reservation system and Korean Air's Topas system. Conditions for the cooperation have yet to be discussed, a statement said. It also said the airlines would cooperate in developing joint business strategies to compete with other computer reservation systems.

title: Federal Paper Board Co.  Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to June 16
description: The company attributed the sales increase to the acquisition of Imperial Cup Corp. in October 1989, and a full quarter of sales for Thomas Tait & Sons Ltd., the Scottish paper mill acquired in the second quarter of 1989. Both operations contributed to second quarter earnings.

title: In Northern Ireland, a Centuries-Old Conflict Is on the March
description: This is the ''marching season'' in Ulster, and the Protestant neighborhoods are bedecked with flags and banners and Union Jacks in celebration of the 300th anniversary of the Battle of the Boyne, where William III defeated Roman Catholic forces marching under the banner of the deposed Stuart King, James II.

title: Bernard Perricone, 60, A Quadruplet in Texas
description: Bernard Perricone, the youngest of the world's first documented male quadruplets to survive, died Sunday at a Nederland hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: 5 More Reported Killed in Kenya Unrest
description: Five people were reported killed in clashes with the police today as anti-Government protests spread from Nairobi to outlying cities. The authorities were told to use whatever force was necessary to quell the demonstrations, which have left eight people dead in the last three days.

title: Bidder for Hotel On W. 42d St. To Be Examined
description: New York City officials said yesterday that they would investigate allegations that a group that has bid to run a former welfare hotel on West 42d Street had collected rent at two buildings in Brooklyn even after it had been ordered to relinquish control because of poor maintenance.

title: What Fundamentalism Offers Arab World
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Let Them Eat Jerk,'
description: JERK-STYLE Jamaican barbecue is more prevalent than McDonald's along East 233d Street in the Bronx, and Allan Vernon is known there as Vernon, the King of Jerk.

title: Dekalb Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Monitors Ordered for Teamster Voting
description: A Federal district judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to put court-appointed monitors at every union local to scrutinize the 1991 election for national union officers.

title: Boddie-Noell Restaurant Properties Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fedders in Deal To Buy Emerson
description: The Fedders Corporation, a leading manufacturer of air conditioners, said it plans to acquire Emerson Quiet Kool from the Jepson Corporation. Terms of the transaction, which will combine two of the best-known names in air conditioners, were not disclosed.

title: Heekin Can reports earnings for Qtr to June 17
description: b-After losses of $3,000 in both the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses of $14,000 in both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Colorado Utility Offering Bonds
description: In its first offering since 1987, the Public Service Company of Colorado is selling $75 million in 30-year first-mortgage bonds due 2020 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Education;   The Lessons Learned When College Officials Run Public Schools
description: A year after Boston University became the first college to run an entire public school system, the schools of this poor, largely immigrant community are catching up but are not yet in the vanguard of public education.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Dole Food Executive Gets President's Post
description: LEAD: David A. DeLorenzo, an executive with the Dole Food Company for 20 years, half of that time in Central America as a manager of fruit-growing operations, has been named president of the company.

title: A True Test of Diplomacy: Feeding the Summit Leaders
description: The economic world focused on the business of the seven leading industrial powers here, but Houston's food community has been obsessed since April with the politics of culinary summitry. The chefs and caterers wanted to do their part to make Houston look good after so many years at the bottom of the oil barrel. They wanted everything to be perfect. So why was a chef from Dallas, Houston's archrival, chosen to be the chief cook for the two major summit dinners?

title: New Chief Is Named At Wilkinson Sword
description: Fred E. Hiller has been named president and chief executive of Wilkinson Sword North America, replacing Norman R. Proulx, who resigned from those positions in June, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Hiller, 50 years old, has been vice president of finance of the Atlanta-based razor and lighter company since 1986.

title: Chronicle
description: Gen. MAXWELL R. THURMAN, the commander of the United States invasion of Panama last December, was admitted to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington on Monday with a preliminary diagnosis of leukemia, the Pentagon has announced.

title: Textron Settles U.S. Charges
description: Textron Inc. has agreed to pay a record $17.9 million to settle a whistle-blower's charges that one of its subsidiaries supplied the Coast Guard with faulty helicopter engines, the Justice Department said today.

title: World Bank Is Beginning To Tap Smaller Markets
description: The World Bank began borrowing money in the smaller financial markets of the world yesterday when it became the first nonresident borrower in New Zealand.

title: Jailed Reporter Names Woman Who Aided Him, and Is Freed
description: A television reporter was freed today from the jail where he had served two weeks for refusing to identify a person who helped him get a telephone interview with a jailed murder suspect.

title: Dow Jones & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included one-time after-tax gain of $164.1 million, or $1.63 a share, in the first quarter. Excluding the gain from the 1989 period, first half 1990 earnings declined 29 percent. The company said net income in the second quarter and first half of 1990 was reduced 12 cents per share and 24 cents per share, respectively, by increased interest expense and goodwill amortization charges realted to the company's acquisition of Telerate Inc., which was completed in January 1990.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Orders Vote Monitors At All Teamster Locals

title: Mulheren Convicted Of Fraud
description: John A. Mulheren Jr., once an aggressive Wall Street speculator, was convicted yesterday of conspiring with Ivan F. Boesky to illegally manipulate stock prices, conduct sham transactions and exchange confidential market information.

title: Lockheed Leases Air Force Hangar
description: A subsidiary of the Lockheed Corporation said it had signed a lease to take over a hangar at Norton Air Force Base in San Bernardino, Calif. Norton is one of 86 military bases scheduled to be closed by 1994. The value of the lease was not disclosed.

title: 11 Drug-Cartel Figures Arrested in Colombia
description: The Colombian police have captured 11 leading members of the Medellin cocaine cartel in a big operation in the central part of the country, the news agency Colprensa reported today.

title: Ruth Brooks Littman And Jack Gross Marry
description: The marriage of Ruth Brooks Littman to Jack Gross took place yesterday at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Mark Winer performed the ceremony.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Book Notes
description: Appeal on Cheever The Illinois Appeals Court recently upheld a lower court decision that prohibited Academy Chicago from publishing its proposed collection of 68 stories by John Cheever. But Jordan Miller, vice president of the independent Chicago publishing house, said yesterday that he would appeal the court's June 27 decision. He also sounded eager to move on to other things.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Tin Group Nears End
description: The International Tin Council, which never recovered from the 1985 collapse of its plans to support the price of tin, said last week that it would vote on July 31 to disband. The Tin Council, made up of 22 tin-consuming and producing countries, no longer has any reason to continue after it settled its debts in March from a long-running case that followed the collapse of its buffer stock operations. The London office of the regulatory body has already closed.

title: Rinfret and London Slug It Out as Cuomo Steps Deftly Aside
description: While Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was campaigning upstate yesterday, two opponents spent most of a half hour in a Manhattan television studio challenging each other's credentials and credibility.

title: Salvador Rebels Say Hopes For Truce Have Grown Faint
description: Rebels said today that a cease-fire in El Salvador's civil war was more remote because the rightist Government refused to agree to reduce the size of the military and purge human rights violators from its ranks.

title: Rival Christian Forces Agree To End Skirmishing in Beirut
description: Opposing Christian forces agreed today to order their troops to stop shooting at one another.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgaria Convenes a Post-Communist Parliament
description: Bulgaria reached down to its roots today to convene its first Parliament elected in genuine elections after more than 40 years of Communist rule.

title: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: The company said sales in the latest first quarter sales were affected by having 13 fewer stores in operation and also a sluggish sales climate in several regions that should improve as the year goes along.

title: Top Hurdles Matchup
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the world-record holder in the heptathlon, and her teammate, Gail Devers-Roberts, a 1988 Olympian who set the American record of 12.61 in the 100-meter hurdles in 1988, will compete in the 100-meter hurdles at the New York Games on July 29, said Fred Lebow, the executive director of the New York Road Runners Club.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Levi Strauss Associates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Chronicle
description: When they get off the plane in Moscow today, 50 young American musicians from all over the country will have just two days before they meet and start rehearsals with 50 of their Soviet counterparts for a joint concert at the Moscow Youth Palace on July 19.

title: United Parcel to Alter Its Trucks In Los Angeles to Use Natural Gas
description: The United Parcel Service said today that it planned to convert its 2,700 delivery trucks in the smog-choked Los Angeles area to run on cleaner-burning natural gas in the first major step by a company to comply with strict new vehicle-emissions laws here.

title: White House Gases
description: Reduce greenhouse gases? The Bush Administration has again made clear, at the economic summit meeting in Houston, that it wants no part of an international timetable to limit emissions of carbon dioxide, which many fear will lead to a catastrophic warming of the earth's climate.

title: SUMMIT IS DIVIDED ON AID TO MOSCOW
description: The leaders of seven major industrial democracies effectively agreed today to go their own way on the matter of aid to the Soviet Union, European and American officials said tonight.

title: Rights Group Cites Abuses Around World
description: Using torture, murder and mass arrests, governments trampled the human rights of tens of thousands of people in 1989 to suppress conflicts stemming from ethnic or nationalist tensions, Amnesty International says.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a major breakthrough in alternative fuels that we think will be a harbinger of things to come.''

title: The Pop Life
description: A Literary Approach ''People don't have as much time to read as they used to have - that's why we need songwriting,'' Steve Earle said the other day. ''Songwriting is literature that you can read in your car.''

title: Waterfront Plan Loses, Barely
description: City residents today rejected by 12 votes a waterfront redevelopment plan with the Port Authority that municipal officials said would be a financial boon but that opponents charged would overwhelm the small Hudson River community. The vote was 4,418 against and 4,406 in favor of the plan, according to figures from the City Clerk's office. Under the plan, Hoboken would have leased 32 acres of waterfront land to the agency, which would have found developers to build 3.3 million square feet of residential and commercial properties.

title: An All-Star After Years In Nowhere
description: ''If I had gone into the front office before the season began and asked for a $15,000 All-Star clause in my contract,'' said Greg Olson, the catcher for the Atlanta Braves, ''I would have been laughed out of there.''

title: KEY RATES
Foreman Is Sparring With HBO
description: George Foreman isn't taking his marching orders these days from Home Box Office.

title: About New York;   Best of Friends Get Together, With Supervision
description: Edgar B. sat with his 6-year-old child, Edgar B. Jr., at a small table. Each week, the Bronx Family Court allows the father exactly an hour-and-a-quarter of closely supervised time with his son. This was it.

title: Norwest Merger
description: United Banks of Colorado, the largest banking company in the state, said yesterday that it was discussing a possible merger with the Norwest Corporation, the largest banking company in Minnesota. With $6 billion of assets, United Banks is about a fourth the size of Norwest. The two companies, which have been the focus of merger rumors, said no agreement had been reached. In over-the-counter trading, United Banks shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $20. Norwest dropped $1, to $21.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Former West Virginia Governor Is Sentenced to 5 Years for Graft
description: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced by a Federal district judge today to 5 years and 10 months in prison and a $170,000 fine for a variety of corrupt acts both in and out of office.

title: Accounts
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., to Pallas Advertising, San Francisco, for Viadent toothpaste and mouthwash, with a budget of $6 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a joint appearance by the tenors Jose Carreras, Placido Domingo and Luciano Pavarotti at the Baths of Caracalla in Rome on Saturday night misstated the extent of the television coverage.

title: Robert Carpenter Jr., Ex-Phillies Owner, 74
description: Robert Ruliph Morgan Carpenter Jr., the former owner of the Philadelphia Phillies, died of cancer Sunday. He was 74 years old.

title: Tyco Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: For the year ending May 31, 1989, the results of Mueller Co. have been included since the date of its acquisition on Sept. 30, 1988. The company said that beginning with fiscal 1991, its fiscal year will end on June 30 instead of May 31. As a result, its first fiscal quarter of 1991 will end on Sept. 30. The change will coordinate financial reporting between it and Wormald International Ltd., the operating assets of which are planned to be acquired by Tyco by the end of July. Wormald's fiscal year ends on June 30.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: CERTAIN lean, meaty fish, like halibut, swordfish and marlin, require utmost care in preparation to prevent dryness. If you barbecue or broil them, frequent basting is necessary. Sauteeing is less risky, but you must check frequently to avoid even the slightest overcooking. In this recipe for halibut with lemon sauce, I take the safest route, poaching. This method leaves the flesh moist and infused with flavor.

title: Jersey Central's Preferred Stock
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company, a unit of the General Public Utilities Corporation, yesterday priced $50 million in preferred stock in competitive bidding that was won by a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Education;   Atlanta School Chief Dismissed; Board Cites Lack of Trust
description: The school board has dismissed the Superintendent here, citing a lack of ''mutual trust and cooperation.''

title: McMahon Agrees To Become an Eagle
description: Jim McMahon, the quarterback who led the Chicago Bears to victory in the Super Bowl in 1986, yesterday agreed to a one-year deal with the Philadelphia Eagles as a backup to Randall Cunningham, the elusive passer and runner. McMahon understands the plans the Eagles have for him, according to Buddy Ryan, the Eagles' coach, who was the defensive coordinator for the Bears during their Super Bowl season. ''We have no problem,'' said Ryan, ''He was interested. He wanted to be an Eagle.'' No contract terms were disclosed. The 30-year-old McMahon was released after the season and became a free agent. (AP)

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sasser Injury Not Bad
description: Mackey Sasser, the Mets' catcher who was injured in Sunday's game in Atlanta in a collision at home plate with Jim Presley, was examined by the Mets' team physician, Fiske Warren, yesterday and was reported to be suffering from a sprained right ankle.

title: Chronicle
description: When MADONNA, in Rome on the latest stop on her round-the-world tour, came under attack from the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano. In an unusual commentary over a pop star passing through town, it declared her show to be sinful.

title: U.S. Team to Defend Title After 3 Decisive Victories
description: Three decisive victories in three days have cleared the way for the United States to defend its world lacrosse title on Sunday.

title: L.S.U. Center Is Making An Impact on the Court
description: Shaquille O'Neal sat on a bench outside his dormitory, shifting his weight in a futile effort to find a pocket of cool air on this hot, humid Minnesota night. Each time he would find a good spot, a relentless army of mosquitoes would chase him off it and O'Neal, the imposing sophomore center for Louisiana State University, would swat them away, much like he has swatted away the basketball competition at the Olympic Festival.

title: Domino's in Test With Burger King
description: Burger King will begin test-marketing six-inch Domino's pizzas at four of its South Carolina restaurants in September. The one-year experiment is aimed at the McDonald's Corporation's test of its own pizza in 200 of its restaurants.

title: The New Fancy Food Products
description: IF the annual International Fancy Food and Confection Show is a barometer of American taste, the culinary atmosphere is heating up. At the four-day trade show that ends today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, there appeared to be more salsas, mustards and other condiments and spice-flavored items than ever, especially among new products. In all, more than 20,000 products the industry calls specialty foods, intended for a select market, were on display.

title: Walesa Wants Reform Fast. He's Right.
description: LEAD: ''United we stand, divided we fall,''

title: On Plan to Build A Space Station
description: A panel of space agency experts has concluded that the nation's planned $37 billion space station will require nearly 75 percent more maintenance than predicted in even the most recent gloomy forecast.

title: Student Loan Marketing Association reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Evolution in Europe;   U.N. Said to Be Near Deal For Exit of 6,000 Albanians
description: A United Nations plan calling for the mass evacuation of an estimated 6,000 Albanians who have taken refuge in foreign embassies is close to being approved by the authorities in Tirana, European diplomats said today.

title: Brooklyn Youth Is Wounded in Dispute Over Coat
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn high school student was shot and critically wounded yesterday during a disputeover an expensive coat, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Wednesday about Gustave Harrow, Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York in the battle over the estate of the artist Mark Rothko, referred incompletely to the suit against Rothko's executors. The heirs accused the executors not only of mismanaging the estate but also of conspiring with the Marlborough Gallery in Manhattan to defraud it. The case resulted in a $9.2 million judgment against Marlborough and the three executors.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 2 about Gov.

title: Saudis Press Oil Cutbacks
description: Saudi Arabia held a meeting today of Persian Gulf oil ministers in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, on establishing a new OPEC output pact to end the overproduction that has sent oil prices plummeting.

title: Article 668190 -- No Title
