description: New York City has agreed to pay a total of $1 million to three men who sued the city after being tortured by police officers with an electronic stun gun while prisoners at a Queens station house, a lawyer for the city said yesterday.

title: Rangers Get a Center
description: The Rangers yesterday acquired Brian McReynolds, a center, from the Winnipeg Jets in exchange for Simon Wheeldon, another center. McReynolds, 25, had 2 assists in 9 games with Winnipeg and scored 18 goals with 41 assists for 59 points in 72 games with the Moncton Hawks of the American Hockey League last season. A native of Penetanguishene, Ontario, McReynolds was selected by the Rangers as their sixth choice (112th over all) in the 1985 entry draft. He was signed as a free agent by the Jets on June 9, 1989.

title: Books of The Times;   Fleeing the Nazis With a Jaguar That May Be Real
description: Max and the Cats

title: Bridge
description: Bidding that starts at the one-level is usually very accurate, like the operation of a watch. But if the opponents begin with a pre-empt, it is like throwing sand in the watch. Some good guessing is needed to be accurate, complicated by the fact that bad breaks are now more likely.

title: Drop in Worker Drug Use Found
description: The number of American workers and job applicants who have tested positive for drug use has declined in recent years, a company that conducts the tests said today.

title: Economic Scene;   Deregulation: The Good News
description: WHEN most people think about deregulation these days they are apt to focus on the dubious pleasures of selecting a long-distance phone company or pleading for service from the local cable television monopolist - or worse, on the sheer gall of the savings and loan bandits who made off with the keys to the United States Mint.

title: Vivigen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the decline in earnings, which began in the third quarter of 1989, was largely due to development of its new molecular testing capability and is now over. The company also said it began offering cystic fibrosis testing at the end of the most recent quarter, marking the first commercialization of its molecular genetic laboratory. The company expects that most of its future growth will come from this laboratory.

title: Rosewood, Insurer in Pact
description: The First Executive Corporation and one of its largest shareholders, Rosewood Financial Inc., plan to discuss a possible joint restructuring or recapitalization of the beleaguered insurance company, the two concerns said today.

title: Residents Worry As Suspect, 95, Returns Home
description: Last month, the police say, a 95-year-old Navy veteran entered an elderly neighbor's apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and bludgeoned her to death - thus becoming one of the oldest murder suspects in the city's history.

title: Anatole Chelnov, Encyclopedia Executive, 71
description: Anatole Chelnov, a retired vice president of the international division of Encyclopedia Britannica, died July 1 at his home in San Francisco. He was 71 years old.

title: Spas to Massage Both Body and Mind
description: STEVEN RUBIN, who founded a large oil brokerage firm, flees his life several times a year for the Maharishi Ayur-Veda Health Center in Lancaster, Mass., a serene and elegant retreat where the emphasis is on integrating the mind and the body.

title: Collaborative Research reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
Eric Warburg, 90, Investment Banker From Germany, Dies
description: Eric M. Warburg, an international banker and a member of the German banking family, died on Monday at his home in Hamburg, West Germany. He was 90 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Medical Holdings Inc., Dallas, said its American Medical International Inc. subsidiary, Beverly Hills, Calif., had completed the sale of its Swiss and Greek hospital companies for about $176.7 million.

title: As Families Emigrate, Hong Kong's Elderly and Afflicted Are Left Stranded
description: When Fung's family moved away from Hong Kong recently, they left her behind in a bleak, crowded Government home because Canada, their new country, would not accept the mentally retarded young woman.

title: State Dept. Tells Americans To Postpone Trips to Kenya
description: The State Department advised American citizens today to defer all nonessential travel to Kenya because of anti-Government strife there.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMEV Holdings Inc., New York, a unit of the Dutch company N.V. AMEV, appointed Gary N. Yalen chief investment officer of AMEV Asset Management.

title: Money Is Not a Factor as $3 Million Doesn't Mean a Thing
description: Using the tale of the financial tape, baseball's chosen few who gathered here for the All-Star Game tonight were not measured by their salaries.

title: Miscellany
description: * Ernest L. Arms, a longtime chief spokesman for Sears, Roebuck & Co., and David L. Wilkinson are forming a communications and media relations firm in Chicago, Arms-Wilkinson Communications Inc.

title: European Jobless Rate
description: The unemployment rate in the European Community has remained steady at 8.6 percent for the first five months of the year, the European Community statistical office reported on Monday. Unemployment ranged from 1.7 percent in Luxembourg to 16.6 percent in Ireland.

title: Foreign Companies in U.S. Cited Again on Tax Record
description: Congressional investigators and tax officials reported new evidence today that American subsidiaries of foreign automobile and electronics companies have been underpaying Federal income taxes, with at least $13 billion in back taxes now being sought by the Government.

title: Sikh Who Promoted Truce Is Shot to Death
description: A Sikh leader who helped fashion a brief truce between the Indian Government and Sikh militants was assassinated today in the capital of Punjab.

title: Review/Music;   Recalling the 70's Magic
description: When Jackson Browne released his first album 18 years ago, the Los Angeles-based singer and songwriter brought a deeply personal strain of romantic idealism to the folk-pop movement. Steeped in the utopianism of Southern California's hippie culture, Mr. Browne wrote visionary love songs and meditations that had dark premonitory undercurrents. His music, which blended traditional folk harmonies with echoes of cowboy laments and Protestant hymns lent his reflections an extra gravity. The singer's early club performances, in which his plain folk-pop singing was brilliantly supported by David Lindley on the violin still stand in memory as among the most entrancing pop concerts of the early 1970's.

title: A. Donald MacKinnon; Retired Lawyer Was 94
description: A. Donald MacKinnon, a lawyer with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley, & McCloy for nearly 50 years, died on June 21 at the Seabrook Health Center in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 94 years old and moved to Hilton Head recently from Summit, N.J.

title: Buyer of Savings Units Misled State Officials
description: James M. Fail, the Arizona insurance executive whose acquisition of 15 failed Texas savings and loan associations from the Federal Government is under Congressional scrutiny, has misled regulators in the past about his legal problems.

title: Education;   Fluency in English Required of Faculty
description: A new law in Pennsylvania requires all college and university faculty members, including graduate teaching assistants, to be proficient in English.

title: International Paper reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television;   A Trial as 'Inquest Into History'
description: Was John Ivan Demjanjuk in fact the prison guard at Treblinka known as Ivan the Terrible, as an Israeli court concluded in 1988, or was he a victim of mistaken identity, as he steadily maintained throughout the trial that brought him a death sentence? The verdict goes against Mr. Demjanjuk in ''Treblinka's Ivan the Terrible: The Demjanjuk Dossier,'' tonight's report at 10 on Channel 13's ''Intercom Prime Time'' series.

title: More South Africa Sanctions
description: A tougher and expanded South African sanctions bill was unanimously adopted by the New York City Council yesterday. The bill will expand existing laws that bar the city from doing business with companies that have ties to South Africa and will establish a rating system to judge the posture of banks in dealing with South Africa. When choosing among banks with comparable services at comparable cost, the law will direct city agencies to deposit or invest city funds in banks with the highest rating.

title: Bo Knows How to Pitch a Product
description: IN Bo Jackson's latest commercial for Nike Inc., there does not seem to be anything the versatile sports celebrity cannot do. Playing on the well-known Nike theme that ''Bo knows,'' the spot shows the professional baseball and football player in at least 15 sports roles, from surfing to soccer.

title: Willis Reese, 77, Professor and Expert In International Law
description: Willis L. M. Reese, the Charles Evans Hughes Professor of Law at Columbia University and the director of the Parker School of Foreign and Comparative Law at Columbia for 25 years, died on Monday at his home in Hughsonville, N.Y. He was 77 years old and also had a home in Hewlett, L.I. He died of colon cancer, a friend said.

title: SERVICE FOR SNYDER BRINGS CELEBRITIES
description: Mitch Snyder's memorial service was held here today with all the trademarks that had characterized the homeless advocate's life: Hollywood celebrities mingled with homeless men and women and 37 people were arrested at City Hall in a protest after the service.

title: Composing and Playing the Sounds for Silents
description: ''Oh, there's plenty of work available,'' the organist Lee Erwin cheerfully proclaimed the other day. Mr. Erwin's specialty, composing and playing soundtrack music for silent films, might strike some as an arcane and perhaps technologically redundant sort of work.

title: The Sunny Side of the Street
description: The law we learned in Physics 101 that two bodies cannot occupy the same space at the same time is getting its annual hot weather test on the sidewalks of New York. Back in January and February, streetwise walkers used the west side of the avenues in the morning and the east side in the afternoon, absorbing whatever warmth they could from the winter sun. Now, on the crowded summer streets, walkers look for shade on the other side of the streets.

title: A.T.&T. Layoffs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said the number of employees to be laid off in its Network Services Division had been reduced to 4,300, from 6,000, because many workers had accepted early retirement. The cuts, beginning in September, will affect workers in all states except Alaska, Delaware, Hawaii, Idaho and Vermont.

title: Service Merchandise Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Attributable to expenses associated with the company's recapitalization which totalled $19.8 million, or 24 cents a share, and $41.0 million, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income Sales represent net sales. The 1990 per share data and number of shares include issuance of 1,330,020 shares of restricted stock related to the recapitalization.

title: Return of Paramilitary Chief Prompts Strike Call in Haiti
description: Political and labor leaders called today for a general strike on Wednesday to protest the return from exile of the former leader of the brutal paramilitary force built by the Duvalier family to maintain its 30-year dictatorship.

title: AIDS in Black Women Seen as Leading Killer
description: AIDS is rapidly rising nationally as a cause of death among women aged 15 to 44 years old, and is the leading killer of black women in that group in New York and New Jersey, according to a new study by researchers at the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: POLICE OPEN FIRE IN SOMALI STADIUM
description: At least 65 people were killed when security forces opened fire on the crowd at a soccer match in Somalia, diplomats said today. The Government had said that only three people were killed when troops fired on people throwing stones at the President.

title: Castle & Cooke reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
NICARAGUA POLICE RAZE ROADBLOCKS
description: Hundreds of striking Sandinista workers and students stood aside and offered little resistance today as riot police officers and army bulldozer crews knocked down barricades that the protesters had built to stop traffic in a nationwide protest that began here Monday morning.

title: Soviet Aid: Short Reach
description: Sometimes the very struggle for unity undermines the semblance of unity, and such was the case, it seemed tonight, in the search here for a formula that would unite the seven leading democracies on the question of aid to the Soviet Union.

title: Dow Falls 23.27 in Heavy Program Trading
description: Stock prices sank yesterday in waves of computer-driven program selling that swept through the market most of the day.

title: Is Florio's Plan Stiff Medicine of Poison?;   It's the Only Cure
description: Robin Hood is alive and well, and working out of the State House in Trenton, New Jersey. You remember his motto - steal from the rich and give to the poor.

title: For the Bolshoi Ballet Director, Politics Looms as Large as Art
description: Yuri Grigorovich, the 63-year-old artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, says he never joined the Communist Party and finds it odd that he is in New York, as he put it the other day, ''discussing politics rather than art.''

title: Getting After the Savings and Loan Crooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings Office In Policy Shift
description: Savings and loan bailout officials approved a policy today that they hope will save taxpayers money by selling insolvent institutions before they lose value under Government control.

title: Dynamics Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
New York Health Care: A Big Step For Children
description: Like many parents who cannot afford health insurance for their children, Edith M. Harris has known the guilt of delaying her sons' vaccinations and treating their fevers with compresses rather than antibiotics.

title: For New York, Happier Days
description: The Democrats could not have picked a better time for the announcement expected today that they'll hold their 1992 convention in New York City. Much of the news emanating from the city lately has focused on racial strife, crime and a growing impatience of New Yorkers about life in their city. But as the Democrats' impending choice demonstrates, New York remains a vibrant political capital. Mayor David Dinkins deserves a salute for his energy in making that choice happen.

title: Some Arts Aid Recipients Must Justify Their Projects
description: New guidelines issued yesterday by the National Endowment for the Arts require grant recipients suspected of violating its restriction against obscenity to supply ''a written justification of the project'' and an explanation of how it complies with the language in the agency's 1990 appropriations legislation.

title: Review/Film;   Showcase of One-Liners For a Rock Detective
description: The person most likely to be entertained by ''The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'' need not be made aware of the film's existence. He's already on the screen.

title: English Soccer Clubs Readmitted to Europe
description: English soccer clubs were readmitted to European tournaments today without special conditions, ending a five-season ban imposed after the Heysel Stadium riot in Brussels in which 39 persons died.

title: Budget Talks Resume Amid Brewing Dispute Over Cuts in Military
description: After a break of almost two weeks for the Fourth of July recess, White House and Congressional budget negotiators resumed their bargaining today amid a brewing dispute among Democrats over military spending.

title: Sandra M. Schor, 58, Author and Professor
description: Sandra M. Schor, a poet, novelist and associate professor of English at Queens College, died on Monday at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. She was 58 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I., and in Manhattan. Her family said she died of cancer.

title: Eric M. Rogers, 87; Teacher Humanized Physics' Complexity
description: Eric M. Rogers, a professor emeritus of physics at Princeton University who was known for his exuberance in explaining complex principles to non-science students, died on July 1 during a visit to Cambridge, England. He was 87 years old.

title: Ending Interference On FM Broadcasts
description: A European consortium developing a system for digital radio broadcasting has come up with a solution for a problem that causes interference in FM radio broadcasts.

title: Eating Well
description: UNDER pressure from consumers, major food companies including the Keebler Company, Sunshine Biscuits Inc., the Kellogg Company, the Ralston Purina Company, General Mills Inc. and Pepperidge Farm Inc.have been systematically replacing tropical oils in their products with less saturated soybean oil.

title: More Jogger Pictures Are Admitted in Trial
description: The prosecution reached the midway point of its case in the Central Park rape trial yesterday, introducing additional photographs that showed the extent of the jogger's injuries.

title: Diana Corp. reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $6,714,000, or $1.81 a share, which included a gain of $14,661,000 and a loss of $7,947,000 related to disposition of operations. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $813,000. The company said the decrease in net revenues was principally the result of the sale of two subsidiaries by Entree Corp. and one subsidiary by Farm House Foods Corp.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: G.E. Sees Breakthroughs From New Diamond
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had created a form of diamond with an enhanced ability to transmit heat and light. Company spokesmen said it could lead to important advances in microchip design and new applications for lasers.

title: Davis Distribution reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $566,000. c-Net loss The company said the loss from discontinued operations in the latest year was related to the opening and subsequent closing of an experimental retail outlet. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Witness Says He Warned Barry to Curb Drug Use
description: Testifying for a second day that he supplied Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. with drugs, including opium, a Washington restaurateur said today that he warned the Mayor many times that ''enough is enough.'' The witness said he urged him to cut back on drugs and to stop taking chances about where and with whom he used them.

title: All Nippon Is Planning $3.3 Billion Jet Order
description: All Nippon Airways said today that it planned to buy about 30 medium-sized passenger jets for about $3.3 billion, substantially increasing its fleet.

title: John Henry Faulk Is Eulogized In a Gathering at Public Theater
description: About 250 friends, colleagues and admirers of John Henry Faulk gathered at the Public Theater on Monday evening to reminisce about the Southern humorist and storyteller who broke the entertainment industry blacklist of the 1950's.

title: McDonnell Revamps Unit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation's helicopter subsidiary said today that it had reorganized to focus on its commercial business because military spending was declining.

title: Business Technology;   Next, Digital Radio For a Superior Sound
description: Radio broadcasting is preparing for its biggest technological leap since FM technology was developed in the 1940's and 50's.

title: Alain Chapel, French Master Chef And Restaurateur, Is Dead at 53
description: Alain Chapel, regarded as one of the finest chefs in France, died yesterday while visiting friends in Avignon, France. He was 53 years old.

title: Mishima Anthology Wins Japanese Prize
description: A collection of Yukio Mishima's short stories translated by John Bester of Britain has won the first Noma Prize for Japanese literature in translation.

title: Atlanta Bishop Resigns, Citing Stress
description: Archbishop Eugene Marino, the first black to be appointed a Roman Catholic Archbishop in the United States, resigned today as head of the Atlanta Archdiocese, citing a need for ''spiritual renewal, psychological therapy and medical supervision.''

title: Many Drug Dealers Found With Jobs
description: Many street-level drug dealers in the District of Columbia hold legitimate jobs and spend less than four hours a day hustling cocaine, heroin and other drugs, a study made public yesterday says.

title:
Is Florio's Plan Stiff Medicine of Poison?;

It Will Murder The Middle Class
description: LEAD: My wife and I live in a pleasant New Jersey suburb that we chose for its excellent public schools for our two young children. We both work; we don't have much spare cash; we sure haven't noticed that we're ''wealthy.'' But Governor Jim Florio's school-funding program, which has now become law, designates our school district as one of 150 ''wealthy'' districts targeted to lose all basic state funding in the next few years.

title: On Rainy Night, National Stars Suffer Drought
description: An All-Star Game in Wrigley Field with two runs scored?

title: Not Too Late for Canada to Be 51st State
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Gordon Is to Read In Trinity Church Series
description: The novelist Mary Gordon is to read from her writing today at noon at St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway and Fulton Street. The reading, part of a free series sponsored by Trinity Church, was originally scheduled for last month, but had to be postponed because of activities involving the New York visit by the South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela. Miss Gordon, whose most recent novel is ''The Other Side,'' is to read from an unpublished work titled ''My Father's Death.''

title: U.S. Savings Agency Weighs Suit Against Bush's Son and Others
description: Federal regulators are considering filing a $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush, the President's son, and other directors and officers of the defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, seeking to recover some of the $1 billion in losses from speculative lending and insider transactions, officials said today.

title: Cuomo, Denying That He's Rich, Puts His Net Worth at $525,000
description: Trying to quash a spate of reports that have labeled him rich, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today released copies of a confidential financial disclosure form.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Czech Food Prices Increase 25% As Many Subsidies Are Removed
description: Prices rose an average of 25 percent at grocery stores today as the Czechoslovak Government ended subsidies on farm products and fresh and processed food. There was some grumbling, but on the whole there appeared to be widespread acceptance of the increases.

title: Research Profit Ruling
description: The California Supreme Court has ruled that patients have no right to share in profits if their blood or organs become the source of lucrative scientific research.

title: Senator Says A Bidder Urged Test of Telescope
description: The losing bid to build the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope called for a test that would have detected the flaw that has blurred its vision before it was ever launched into orbit, Senator Albert Gore Jr. said today.

title: Acquirer Of Savings Units Cited
description: James M. Fail, the Arizona insurance executive whose acquisition of 15 failed Texas savings and loan associations from the Federal Government is under Congressional scrutiny, has misled regulators in the past about his background and legal problems.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Down
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again and interest rates rose further yesterday despite a highly successful auction of $5 billion worth of new 30-year bonds offered by the Resolution Funding Corporation, the Federal agency charged with financing the savings and loan bailout.

title: Education;   Johns Hopkins, Divided, Looks to Low-Key Era
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, Steven Muller is not the president of the Johns Hopkins University.

title: For British Politician, Faded Dream Dies
description: Dr. David Owen turned 52 years old a few days ago, a month after the failure of his decadelong attempt to create a European-style Social Democratic Party outside the British Labor movement.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Czech Embassy Shelters Cubans
description: Two Cuban students seeking political asylum and five dissidents asking to tour Europe and return were staying in the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana today, presenting Cuba and non-Communist Czechoslovakia with a tricky diplomatic problem.

title: King Says His Goal Was a Title Rematch
description: Don King testified yesterday that the reason he made a ringside protest over a referee's long count during the the Mike Tyson-James (Buster) Douglas heavyweight title fight was to lay the foundation for his real objective, to get a Douglas-Tyson rematch.

title: Increases Voted on Rent-Stabilized Units
description: In a decision that dissatisfied both landlords and tenants, the New York City Rent Guidelines Board last night approved rent increases of 4.5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases in rent-stabilized apartments.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Galeries Lafayette's plan to open a store on 57th Street misstated the location of Henri Bendel. That store is at 10 West 57th Street, just west of the Galeries Lafayette site. The article also misstated the location of Saks Fifth Avenue in some editions. It is at 611 Fifth Avenue, seven blocks south of the site.

title: Devils Like Newcomers
description: Three of the Devils' most highly regarded prospects have signed multiyear contracts with the National Hockey League team, said Lou Lamoriello, the club president and general manager. Zdeno Ciger, Jason Miller and Jarrod Skalde signed their first professional contracts and will attend training camp in September.

title: Interco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $7,168,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $9,851,000, or 25 cents a share. Year-ago sales included Ethan Allen Inc., sold in the second quarter of fiscal 1990, and Senack Shoes Inc., the majority of which was also sold in the second quarter. Year-ago loss from continuing operations of $41,451,000 included a profit contribution of $12.4 million from Ethan Allen and Senack. The company said discontinued operations reflect the results of the balance of the apparel manufacturing group and the general retail merchandising group which the company is in the process of divesting.

title: S.E.C. Views Fund Moves By Brokers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering whether to install an early warning system to detect potential financial trouble at the nation's largest brokerage firms.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: High-Crime Areas Aren't Good for Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Court in Illinois Allows Cutoff of Man's Food
description: The Illinois Supreme Court cleared the way today for a stroke victim's guardian to seek withdrawal of the food and water that is keeping the patient alive.

title: As Democrats Prepare to Meet, the Spotlight Is Still on O'Neill
description: Four months ago, when Gov. William A. O'Neill announced that he would not run for a third full term as Governor, he seemed a beaten man.

title: Vernon Grant Dead; Book Artist Was 88
description: Vernon Grant, a magazine and book illustrator who was the creator of the Kellogg's cereal characters Snap, Crackle and Pop, died on Monday at a nursing home where he had been staying for several weeks. He was 88 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Chronicle
description: ELLA FITZGERALD was treated for exhaustion at a hospital in The Hague yesterday after becoming ill in her hotel. The 72-year-old singer, who was in The Netherlands to perform at the North Sea Jazz Festival, was admitted to the Bronovo Hospital on Monday and was in good condition, according to Dr. CLIFFORD BOOKER, a physician accompanying her.

title: Louis P. Singer, Investment Banker, 84
description: Louis P. Singer, an investment banker and a retired senior partner in Troster, Singer & Company, an over-the-counter securities concern, died on Monday at University Hospital in Denver. He was 84 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: SUPPORT FOR BUSH DECLINES IN POLL
description: In the first public opinion survey to be released since President Bush abandoned his ''no new taxes'' pledge, the Gallup Organization reports that just over half the public disapproves of his new stand while 4 out of 10 approve.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Ketchum Communications, working through the Advertising Council, has prepared an ad campaign for the State Department. The effort, which advises Americans on how to travel abroad safely, begins next month.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a German-born scientist seeking to regain his United States citizenship referred incorrectly to the V-2, a World War II weapon on which he worked. It was a ballistic rocket, not a flying drone or buzz bomb.

title: Chronicle
description: CALVIN KLEIN was released from New York Hospital on Monday after a six-day stay for treatment of injuries he suffered while horseback riding on Long Island. The 47-year-old fashion designer suffered two broken ribs and other injuries when he was thrown from a horse on July 3 in Bridgehampton.

title: Morrison Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to June 2
description: b-Included a loss of $2,493,000 from discontinued operations. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and a gain from discontinued operations of $424,000 for the year.

title: Red Cross Faulted on Tainted-Blood Reports
description: The American Red Cross has delayed reporting or has failed to report to the Federal Government hundreds of errors it has made in handling contaminated blood, a Federal inspector reports.

title: Ads That Bash the Japanese: Just Jokes or Veiled Racism?
description: American advertisers are stepping up their attacks on Japan and its people, attempting to thwart sales of Japanese products through commercials that feature ominous references to the late Emperor Hirohito, photographs of Samurai warriors, exaggerated accents and veiled ridicule of the Japanese physique.

title: Review/Theater;   A Carnival of Satire and Savagery, With a Karamazov as Ringmaster
description: Near the beginning of ''Father Was a Peculiar Man,'' an exhilarating evening of environmental street theater presented by En Garde Arts, an actor from the company of more than 60 performers approaches the audience and excitedly offers his theory of the significance of Madonna. By suggesting that sex is possible in the age of AIDS, he says, she is ''trying to become a Christ - she will link us together.''

title: Donations Decline For Public Service Ads
description: The donation by the media of time and space for public service campaigns dropped by 15 percent last year, to $1.04 billion, from $1.23 billion in 1988, the Advertising Council said yesterday.

title: Citing Extra Costs at 5 Airports, American Adds Ticket Surcharge
description: American Airlines, reacting to what it calls ''excessive charges'' imposed by five airports, plans to add ticket surcharges of $1 to $4 beginning next week for its flights from those airports.

title: Washington Talk;   White House Pins Hope On South Africa Leader
description: When F. W. de Klerk visits the United States later this year, there are no plans for a rally in Yankee Stadium, for T-shirts or for mayors to line up to embrace him.

title: Market Place;   Who Should Set Margin Levels?
description: With the financial futures industry fearing for its future, and some parts of the securities industry warning of a financial crisis unless there is reform, pressure is building for Congress to control just how much risk speculators can take when they use the futures market to bet on whether stock prices will rise or fall.

title: Evolution in Europe;   EAST BERLIN FINDS BOMBING SUSPECT
description: East Germany has identified a man now imprisoned on rape charges in West Berlin as a leader of the 1986 bombing of a West Berlin discotheque that killed two American servicemen, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Out-of-Control Car Kills Two Children And Hits Two Others
description: A boy and a girl playing on their front lawn in Rosedale, Queens, were struck and killed last night by a car that ran through a stop sign, apparently out of control, the police said.

title: Manhunt Readied as Zodiac Deadline Nears
description: Police investigators are bracing for a new attack by the Zodiac gunman early tomorrow and are preparing to conduct an enormous hunt for the elusive figure.

title: Food Notes
description: The Fish Eaters

title: Oracle Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said cash collections for the latest quarter were stronger than expected generating approximately $18 million in positive cash flow and reducing accounts receivable days outstanding at the end of the quarter to approximately 126 days from 146 days at the end of the third quarter. In accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No. 86, $8,195 and $2,995 net of amortization, were capitalized in the quarters, and $19,454 and $7,022 were capitalized in the fiscal years ended May 31, 1990 and 1989, respectively.

title: USX and 2 Union Leaders Convicted in Alabama
description: The USX Corporation and two United Steelworkers officials were convicted today of conspiring to provide the union officials with company pensions in exchange for major concessions in a 1983 labor contract.

title: Jets Select Syracuse Wide Receiver in Draft
description: The Jets continued to inject new life into their slumbering offense by taking Rob Moore, a Syracuse wide receiver ranked among the best collegians at his position, in the National Football League supplemental draft yesterday.

title: The Houston Summit;   The Text of the Political Declaration
description: Following is the text of the political declaration issued by heads of seven leading industrial democracies at their summit conference here today:

title: Suit Seeks to Bar Sale Of New Audio Players
description: A group of music publishers, including the songwriter Sammy Cahn, has filed a lawsuit seeking to halt the sale in the United States of new digital audio tape recorders, contending that they contribute to copyright infringement.

title: Cairo Journal;   With Islam in Vogue, Boutiques for the Pious
description: When Mona el-Rifai returned from a spell in Saudi Arabia eight years ago, she had become used to wearing Islamic dress and thought others might like to do so as well, so she opened a store.

title: Bill of Rights Gives Drivers No Privileges
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Digest
description: The Houston Summit

title: People
description: * Lorraine Alper-Kramer has been appointed senior vice president and creative services director of BBDO Los Angeles.

title: Daly Getting New Pact With Pistons
description: Chuck Daly, turning aside offers from network television and other National Basketball Association teams, said today that he would try to lead the Detroit Pistons to a third consecutive N.B.A. championship.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Penalty Against Maddox
description: New York State's highest court yesterday let stand a lower court order suspending Alton H. Maddox Jr., who represented Tawana Brawley and other clients in racially sensitive cases, from practicing law.

title: Al Merrill, Ski Coach, 69
description: Al Merrill, coach of the United States Nordic ski team in three Olympics and a member of the National Ski Hall of Fame, died Sunday at Curley Health Care Center. Mr. Merrill, who suffered a stroke two years ago, was 69 years old.

title: Backward Flow The Years
description: At last it seems possible to get younger. Growth-hormone injections have done the trick for a test group of men aged 61 to 81, according to last week's science news. Practically all of them perked up noticeably, regaining scientifically measurable amounts of the mustard commonly associated with younger men.

title: Double Celebration For French Cyclist
description: Ronan Pensec celebrated his 27th birthday today with as pretty a present as the Tour de France can offer: he received the yellow jersey of the overall leader.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Women Stereotyping Women
description: Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, predicts ''the feminization of power'' as more women win public office. Women politicians talk enthusiastically about the ''decade of the woman.'' Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic nominee for governor of California, says that a woman official can protect abortion rights more reliably than a man.

title: Evolution in Europe;   CONFRONTING FOES, GORBACHEV KEEPS PARTY LEADERSHIP
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev swept confidently to re-election as head of the Communist Party today, after confronting the party's hard-liners with a militant defense of the changes he has ignited in his society.

title:
Real Estate;

Office Plans Uncertain In Baltimore
description: LEAD: A GROUNDBREAKING last month for the 30-story, 450,000-square-foot Commerce Place building downtown marked the start of the only large new office structure begun in Baltimore this year. A weak office market has left the city with a high vacancy rate downtown.

title: Beach Towel a 9-5 Favorite To Win Meadowlands Pace
description: Despite drawing the outside position in the field of 10 horses, Beach Towel is still the overwhelming favorite in the $1,153,500 Meadowlands Pace on Friday night.

title: Brademas Plans to Step Down as President of N.Y.U. in 1991
description: John Brademas, who nearly doubled the endowment of New York University and helped transform it into a major research institution in his nine years as president, said yesterday that he intended to step down in December 1991.

title: C.D. Yields Are Lower For Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were off slightly for the week ended yesterday, the sixth consecutive week of decline.

title: John Connelly, 85, A Bottling Executive And Philanthropist
description: John F. Connelly, chairman of the Crown Cork and Seal Company and head of the Connelly Foundation, a Philadelphia philanthropic organization, died Sunday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: Frederick's of Hollywood reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 stock splits distributed Sept. 27, 1989 and June 15, 1990.

title: Figure in Bomb Inquiry Accused of Perjury
description: The man who became the focus of a Federal investigation of bombings that killed a Federal judge and a civil rights lawyer last year was indicted today on unrelated charges of perjury and bribery.

title: Video-Terminal Safety For Municipal Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting After the Savings and Loan Crooks;   Connecticut Bank Grab
description: To the Editor:

title: Nike Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Technologies Plans To Build Spaceport
description: The United Technologies Corporation plans to build and manage a commercial spaceport in northern Australia. The Bush Administration gave informal approval on Sunday to a plan for a United Technologies subsidiary, the USBI Company of Huntsville, Ala., to develop the spaceport. The base will be used to launch United States satellites on Soviet-built Zenit rockets for telecommunications customers.

title: Fathers' Rights On Adoption Are Expanded
description: New York State's highest court today widely expanded the rights of unwed fathers, ruling that a state law restricting their ability to intervene in adoption proceedings was unconstitutional.

title: Weis Markets reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Texas Savings Indictment
description: Edwin T. McBirney 3d, a flamboyant Texas financier, was indicted on 17 counts for actions at Sunbelt Savings Association. Page D1.

title: Plastibec LTEE reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $159,074. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Outdoors;   Canoe-Hiking Tours In Adirondack Park
description: One way to become acquainted with the stunning wilderness of New York State's Adirondack Park would be to join one of the canoe-hiking excursions offered by Adirondack Wilderness Tours.

title: T.W.A. to Join In Surcharge
description: Trans World Airlines plans to follow the lead of American Airlines and impose ticket surcharges on its flights from five airports, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Homicides Up by 22%, Police Statistics Show
description: The homicide rate in New York City rose 22.2 percent for the first three months of the year compared with the same period in 1989, the police said yesterday.

title: William F. Peiffer, 61, Builder and Manager
description: William F. Peiffer, a builder who helped coordinate the construction of the United States Embassy in Moscow, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.

title: Planters Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Execufirst Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Talking Deals;   Bid for Kay Stirs Bondholders' Ire
description: GIVEN the turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market over the last 12 months, holders of the highly leveraged securities should be accustomed to bad news. But the recent offer by Ratners Group P.L.C., the world's largest jewelry retailer, to acquire Kay Jewelers Inc. for about $410 million in a stock swap has left many of bondholders upset by what they regard as the sheer brazenness of the proposed transaction.

title: Imperial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected $273,000 gain on sale of investments for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: A article on Tuesday about labor negotiations at The Daily News referred incorrectly in some copies to a statute that empowers New York State to inquire into labor disputes. It is 49 years old, not 39.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Mandela Is Reported Ailing And Is Hospitalized in Kenya
description: Nelson Mandela, reportedly suffering from pneumonia, arrived in Nairobi today and was said to have been admitted to a hospital.

title: CHAMORRO MOVES TO PLACATE UNIONS
description: Seeking an urgent solution to violent political clashes that have shaken her Government, President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said today that she would reopen negotiations with Sandinista unions and political leaders if they acted to end recent protests and restore public order.

title: Right-to-Die Ruling Curtails Individual Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: In Rome, MADONNA's ''Blond Ambition'' concert drew a less-than-sellout crowd last night after weeks of protests against her by Roman Catholic organizations. She canceled a second performance because of low ticket sales and a general strike threatened by labor unions.

title: President Talks About a Family Matter
description: Near the end of a news conference yesterday after the economic summit meeting in Houston, President Bush was asked if he agreed with a suggestion by his son Neil that savings and loan regulators are conducting something of a vendetta against him largely because his name is Bush:

title: Moves at Bozell
description: Bozell has appointed Kim Gaynor general manager of Bozell Detroit. He will replace George Beech, who will remain a consultant to the Detroit office during the transition. Dennis F. Visich, the chief operating officer of Warwick Baker & Fiore, will replace Mr. Gaynor as executive vice president and director of client services at Bozell Dallas.

title: Treasury's Rule Upsets Note Sale
description: A ruling by the Treasury Department yesterday caught Wall Street by surprise and turned what had been expected to be a routine auction of $8 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes into a protest vote.

title: Robert Jensen Is Dead; Buildings Historian, 51
description: Robert Jensen, an architect and a historian of New York City's architectural past, died on July 4 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Teledyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $25,600,000, or 46 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,000,000, or 26 cents a share, and $49,300,000, or 89 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Income from continuing operations for the six months ended June 30, 1990 included a reversal of $7.7 million provision for income taxes which is no longer necessary as a result of the spinoff of Teledyne's insurance and finance subsidiaries on March 31. Results for 1989 are restated to reflect the company's former insurance and finance subsidiaries as discontinued operations and adjusted for the 5-for-1 stock split.

title: Right-to-Die Ruling Curtails Individual Liberty;   Case for Living Wills
description: To the Editor:

title: Even Ernie Banks Wouldn't Have Wanted to Play Two
description: Could it be that the baseball gods are still angry about those lights at Wrigley Field?

title: Dirty Schools: Will a New Contract Help Clean Them?
description: A little more than two years ago, before the signing of a contract hailed as the start of a new era in school maintenance, New York City school custodians cleaned classrooms every other day, cafeterias once a week and mopped floors three times a year. Head custodians were paid almost $20,000 more than the average teacher and about $7,000 less than the average principal.

title: 2 Sons of Super Bowl Installed As Favorites for Yonkers Trot
description: Two sons of Super Bowl, who in 1972 became the last winner of trotting's triple crown, were installed as the favorites in the two heats for Saturday's Yonkers Trot, the first leg of the triple crown.

title: Alfred Fuchs; Fur Broker, 90
description: Alfred Fuchs, a retired fur broker, died on Sunday at Parkway General Hospital in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 90 years old and lived on Bar Harbor Island, Fla.

title:
CURRENTS;

Suitable For, Well, Framing
description: LEAD: IF paintings keep going up in price, people may just start collecting picture frames. Miguel Oks, an architect in New Haven, seems to be anticipating that time. He has designed a series of gridded, faceted and even tilted wood and metal frames. ''I'm interested in a space created by the picture frame,'' he said.

title: Two Worlds of Washington: Turmoil and Growth
description: Every day, Ruth Ernst goes downtown from her northwest Washington neighborhood, from a subway stop that did not exist six years ago, to a law firm that had not been formed seven years ago, in a booming commercial center where four years ago metal grates covered decrepit storefronts and fear emptied the streets at dusk.

title: Nun Named to Head Covenant House
description: Sister Mary Rose McGeady, the senior Catholic Charities official in Queens who has more than two decades of experience working with troubled youths, was named president of Covenant House yesterday, succeeding the Rev. Bruce Ritter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: George E. Wheeler, 75, Professor and Gymnast
description: Dr. George E. Wheeler, a professor of biology at Brooklyn College, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan. He died of a cerebral hemorrhage, a stepdaughter, R. Khela Ransier, said.

title: Jamaica Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank said it converted to stock form from mutual form on June 21 so there were no shares outstanding or per-share results prior to that time.

title: Lomas Set to Sell 3 Insurance Units
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation said it would sell its three life insurance companies to an Indiana insurance company for $140 million in cash and $25 million in securities. The deal must be approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court, which is overseeing Lomas while it is protected under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.

title: Protests in Haiti Shut Businesses
description: Businesses closed and most public transportation halted throughout the capital today as political and labor leaders called a strike to protest the recent return from exile of two former Government officials widely associated with political violence and torture in Haiti.

title: Carolina First Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place;   Finding a Forum For Arbitration
description: THE legal view of where investors' disputes with their brokers can be arbitrated is becoming increasingly muddled. State and Federal courts disagree sharply; Federal regulators are undecided, and state lawmakers, sympathetic to the consumer, are adopting statutes that fly in the face of brokers' preference for industry-run arbitration panels.

title: Lazare Kaplan International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $768,000 and $1,688,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $719,000 for the quarter and $860,000 for the year. Sales represents gross sales.

title: Suntrust Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain of about $19 million from two purchase accounting adjustments on earlier acquisitions. c-Included pretax gain of $10.6 million from purchase of annuity for pension obligations in first quarter of 1989.

title: Review/Film;   Heading for Middle Age With Fear for Company
description: Salad-bar tortellini has never looked as pathetic as it does in ''No Picnic,'' where the black-and-white photography gives it the color and texture of dingy gray sweat socks. There are just a few close-ups of the dreary salad bar in Philip Hartman's 1986 film, which opens today at Anthology Film Archives after having made the rounds of several smaller film festivals. But it is precisely the kind of detail that Mr. Hartman relies on, along with Peter Hutton's vivid yet gloomy cinematography, in telling this wry story.

title: City National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to include the accounts of Warner Center Bank, which was acquired in a pooling-of-interests transaction on June 29, 1990.

title: People
description: * Richard Corelitz has been promoted to executive vice president of Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago.

title: Q&A
description: Squeaky Floors

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.B. Electrolux, a Swedish appliance maker, said it had won a contract, worth more than $100 million, to design and provide technology for a compressor factory in the Soviet Union.

title: Richard B. Bernstein, 66, Is Dead; A Pioneer in Modern Chemistry
description: Richard B. Bernstein, who pioneered a branch of science that studies details of the ultrafast processes that occur in chemical reactions, died in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday. He was 66 years old.

title: Robert Alan Roth; Lawyer, 40
description: Robert Alan Roth, a New York lawyer, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 40 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Houston Summit

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not easy for me as a father. It's easy for me as the President because the system is going to work and I will not intervene.''

title: Musicland Stores Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Characters Are Freed By Author, Freeing Him
description: Dennis McFarland says he is happy someone else will write the film treatment of his first novel, ''The Music Room.'' And he says he has no apprehension about what Hollywood might do with his story, which has received critical acclaim across the nation, especially for its lyrical prose.

title: Pacific National Financial reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company attributed the earnings decline to rising Canadian interest rates in the fourth quarter.

title: Cherry Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title:
CURRENTS;

Snack Stand for Central Park Ball Field
description: LEAD: THE song ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' often conjures up grassy playing fields, trees and softball. This is definitely the idea behind the Heckscher Field in Central Park just southwest of the 65th Street Transverse. Now it has a new refreshment stand to offer the mandatory hot dogs and soda pop.

title: Oshkosh Truck Awarded Contract
description: The Defense Department said that the Army had picked the Oshkosh Truck Corporation as the winner of a competition worth more than $1 billion to build 2,707 specialized Army tractor-trailer trucks.

title: Canseco Is Force for A's
description: Jose Canseco collected three hits, three runs batted in and his 23d home run as the Oakland A's outlasted the Minnesota Twins, 11-7, tonight.

title: Three Key Economic Issues Undecided as Meeting Ends
description: The leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies wrapped up their three-day meeting here today by proclaiming their united goal of fostering worldwide prosperity, but they hardly resolved the three main economic issues that had divided them at the outset.

title: McKeon Steps Down As Padres' Manager
description: Jack McKeon, who recently announced that he planned to step down as San Diego's manager at the end of the season to concentrate on his other job as the Padres' vice president of baseball operations, hastened that act yesterday by resigning his field job and bringing in Greg Riddoch to fill it.

title: Studies on Development of Empathy Challenge Some Old Assumptions
description: The forces that mold a child into a caring adult are coming into sharper focus with new findings that question assumptions held by parents and psychologists alike.

title: Rev. Edward Jurji, 83, Of Princeton Seminary
description: The Rev. Edward J. Jurji, a Presbyterian minister, retired educator and an author, died on Monday at his home in Monroe Village, a retirement community in Jamesburg, N.J. He was 83 years old and died of pneumonia, a funeral home representative said.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS HIS SON'S INTEGRITY IN SAVINGS INQUIRY
description: President Bush today gave a ringing emotional defense of his son Neil, who has been accused of violating conflict of interest rules in a Denver savings and loan case, but he promised to stay out of the proceedings and ''let the system work.''

title: Use Light Touch to Repair Furniture Fret
description: LEAD: Probably the most familiar type geometric ornamental pattern in furniture is the perforated gallery on the top of a small pedestal table. Early attempts at such fretwork left the wood lacking in strength; since it was cut from a single thickness of wood, the grain was necessarily short and weak at some points in the pattern.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 4 about a National Transportation Safety Board report on the crash of a USAir jet at La Guardia Airport on Sept. 20 misstated the model of the plane. It was a Boeing 737, not a 727.

title: Mead Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
H.U.D. Project On Ninth Street Halted by Judge
description: A judge ruled yesterday that the Department of Housing and Urban Development had violated its rules in approving funds for a low-income housing project on the Lower East Side. The judge issued a preliminary order blocking H.U.D. from proceeding on the project.

title: Everest & Jennings InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net interest expense of $2.17 million. Year-ago loss from continuning operations of $973,000 included net interest expense of $990,000.

title: Jogger Hard to Identify in Hospital, Friend Testifies
description: A colleague and former roommate of the Central Park jogger testified yesterday that his friend's face was so disfigured after she was beaten that it took him nearly 15 minutes to identify her at the hospital.

title: Hayes-Dana Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Polish Investors Angry
description: Dozens of angry investors besieged the office of a Polish financier today after it closed for lack of funds and a newspaper reported that the financier might have vanished abroad. The newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, said employees of Lech Grobelny, once Warsaw's best-known black market currency dealer, had closed his Safe Savings Bank after telling a prosecutor it had run out of money. A spokesman for the prosecutor's office said it was checking but had no evidence that a crime had been committed.

title: DeSoto Will Sell Off Most of Its Operations
description: DeSoto Inc., which has been fending off a hostile takeover attempt since last year, announced today that it planned to sell most of the company's operations and distribute the proceeds to shareholders.

title: U.S. and U.N. Food Agency Head for a Clash
description: The United States is heading for a new confrontation with the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, which threatens to suspend its vote next year, ending Washington's influence at the agency charged with promoting third-world agricultural development.

title: Former Casino Analyst Sues Trump
description: Marvin B. Roffman, the casino analyst who was dismissed by his Philadelphia brokerage firm in March after he criticized the Taj Mahal casino owned by Donald J. Trump, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in the Federal District Court in Philadelphia against Mr. Trump and the Trump Organization.

title: First Virginia Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Consolidated Papers reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Violence to Women, Not Rape Victim's Name, Is the Real Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Bickerstaff Resigns
description: Bernie Bickerstaff resigned on Tuesday night as vice president of basketball operations for the Seattle SuperSonics. Yesterday, he was hired as general manager of the Denver Nuggets.(AP)

title: Town & Country Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Sales represent net sales.

title: Don Bessent; Pitcher, 59
description: Don Bessent, a pitcher who was one of the Boys of Summer of the Brooklyn Dodgers, died of alcohol poisoning on Saturday. He was 59 years old.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REPLACING a broken window is not too difficult. But knowing how to proceed and working in a safe, orderly fashion assure the best results.

title: As Mets Surge Toward Top, Yanks Slumber;   After Slow Start, Everything Works
description: Ask Bud Harrelson the question: wouldn't the Mets have turned things around even if Davey Johnson had stayed as manager? And hear him answer, shrugging and smiling: ''We'll never know.''

title: N.B.A.'s Games Contribute To 16% Profit Gain at CBS
description: CBS Inc. reported yesterday that its net income had risen 16 percent in the second quarter, in part because of one-time gains from the National Basketball Association's games and lower programming costs.

title: Congress Unit Assails U.S. Information Policy
description: The Federal Government is ignoring scientific and technical information that could potentially be one of its most valuable weapons in the battle for high-technology international competitiveness, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment reports.

title: Fight to Preserve a Dylan Thomas View
description: Each year more than 26,000 people visit a simple three-story boathouse perched on the rocky shore of the Taf Estuary in Laugharne, on the south coast of Wales, the last and most famous dwelling of Dylan Thomas.

title: Ecuador's Debt Is Used To Create Scholarships
description: Harvard University and an educational foundation in Ecuador have agreed to begin a program of converting Ecuador's foreign debt into Harvard scholarships for Ecuadorean students, university officials announced Tuesday.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: THE days have become hot and steamy, but most of the time I don't notice. Where I work, in an office with two overachieving air-conditioning vents, the weather is always chilly.

title: Mecham Candidacy Challenged in Arizona
description: Evan Mecham was back in court today, defending his right to run again for the governorship, from which he was removed by the State Legislature in an impeachment proceeding two years ago.

title: Grieving for 2 Children Killed by Car
description: What Vincent Greco remembered most yesterday was how careful the 5-year-old was.

title: O'Toole's Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. Revenue figures for latest and year- ago quarters are not available.

title: Bandag Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Farm Credit Banks' Bonds Are Priced
description: The FFCB Funding Corporation priced $350 million in consolidated systemwide bonds for the Farm Credit System banks for sale yesterday through various securities dealers and dealer banks.

description: Security forces nearly captured Pablo Escobar, reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, but the fugitive escaped into the jungle, the police said today.

description: A National Collegiate Athletic Association subcommittee today approved recommendations for distributing $1 billion from the N.C.A.A.'s network television contract that include a formula to de-emphasize the monetary incentive for winning games in the annual basketball tournament.

description: The Senate today overwhemingly approved a crime bill that includes a temporary ban on the sale and manufacture of certain semiautomatic assault weapons, greater Federal assistance to law-enforcement agencies and an expansion of the number of Federal crimes for which the death penalty can be imposed.

description: Was Don King working behind the scenes to overturn the result of James (Buster) Douglas's 10th-round knockout of Mike Tyson?

description: Until about 11 o'clock this morning, the turn of events in Maylon Hanold's life had just about drained her faith in the adage that everything works out for best.

title: No Headline
description: Perhaps the worst part about the Yankees' long, dry summer is this: there are still 82 games to go.

description: Seven more Cubans seeking to leave the country entered the Czechoslovak Embassy in Havana early today, bringing to 14 the number there, an embassy spokesman said.

description: To the Editor:

Summer, Children And 'War of the Exes'
description: FOR legions of divorced fathers, a ritual is under way. A time of love and reunion, it can also be an agony of dashed hopes and recrimination. It is the extended summer visit with the children, an arrangement included in most divorce settlements, which in 9 of 10 cases give custody to the mother.

title:
CURRENTS;

Leaves, Flowers And China
description: LEAD: WITH Leaves, the tableware for Parkside, an Atlanta restaurant for which he was the architect, Frederic Schwartz took very literally the environmentalists' admonition to design with nature. Mr. Schwartz, of Anderson/Schwartz Architects in New York, created the pattern with Monica Banks, a New York graphic designer.

title: Cupertino National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Farmers calling for relief from the Government's free-market economic program blockaded roads across Poland today for two hours.

title: Summit Promise - and Shame;   But a Torpedo for Principled China Policy
description: The Houston summiteers had a chance to use their economic power to shape reform in the Soviet Union and China. They missed it. Regrettably, they failed to unite on how to help the Soviet Union. Shamefully, they winked at Japan's torpedoing of economic sanctions against China that were just beginning to yield results.

description: ON a recent Saturday, Debra Boast pounced on floral chintz fabric for her kitchen curtains. Who cares if the polish is not as shiny as normal?

title: Wheeler Peak
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it had received a preliminary expression of interest about an acquisition by the Wheeler Peak Capital Corporation. The company said Wheeler Peak had not submitted a formal proposal but had suggested a deal in which Public Service shareholders would receive $12 a share in cash and a portion of the common equity of the surviving company. The company's stock jumped $2 a share today, to $11.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Deal Maker Indicted In Savings Fraud Case
description: Edwin T. McBirney 3d, once a flamboyant young financier whose unfettered deal-making led to the creation and collapse of the Sunbelt Savings Association in the 1980's, was indicted today on 17 counts for his actions at Sunbelt involving a North Texas land development.

title: No Steinbrenner Contact
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent received no response from George Steinbrenner today, the deadline Vincent had set for the Yankee owner to decide whether he wanted to add information before Vincent completes an investigation of his activities.

title: Runaway Stolen Car Kills Boy, 4, And 2 Brooklyn Men Are Seized
description: A 4-year-old Brooklyn boy who had proudly told his friends yesterday that he was going to kindergarten this fall was struck and killed by a runaway stolen car a few hours later as he played with his bicycle in front of his Crown Heights apartment building, the police said.

title: Chronicle
description: MARVIN LIEBMAN, a prominent conservative in political circles, has announced his homosexuality in an open letter in The National Review. He said yesterday that he made the disclosure in the July 9 issue of The National Review in hopes of countering the ''homophobia'' that he said was evident in right-wing politics. Mr. Liebman, 66 years old, expanded on the letter in an interview in the July 17 issue of The Advocate, a Los Angeles magazine directed at gayreaders.

title: Canterbury Educational ServFices Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The company said year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

description: Year-ago quarter share earnings are less than 1 cent a share after dividends on preferred shares.

Mitchell Draws Line in Budget Talks
description: Hardening the battle lines with the White House over taxes, the Senate majority leader said today that he would not accept any budget agreement that lowered the tax rate on capital gains unless the deal also included a rise in the income tax rate paid by the wealthy.

title: Harmonia Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank converted to stock ownership from mutual ownership in November 1989 and therefore per- share figures for the year-ago quarter and 6 months are not applicable.

description: The Arkansas Attorney General was charged with theft today, accused of entertaining political allies and friends at taxpayer expense totaling thousands of dollars.

description: The criminals' nicknames seem to be borrowed from the comics: Big Olive, Petunia, Butter George, Sweet Talker, Baby Skull, Little Rat and The Professor.

title: Review/Television;   The Boycotting of a Korean Grocery in Brooklyn
description: The ''48 Hours'' correspondents on ''Simmer in the City,'' the report on the boycott of a Korean food store in Brooklyn at 8 tonight on CBS, cover many sides and angles of a dispute that has been at a stalemate for about six months. They talk with the store's owner, with leaders of the boycott and with its supporters and opponents, with Mayor David N. Dinkins, even with the movie maker Spike Lee.

title: WHALES' HIND FEET SHOW UP IN FOSSILS
description: Scientists have found the first direct fossil evidence that whales once had hind legs and feet and retained smaller but functional versions of them for more than 10 million years after they left the land for a life at sea.

title: Democratic Chief Considers Cutting Convention for TV
description: Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, said today that he was thinking of shortening the party's 1992 Presidential convention to help make it more interesting to television viewers and thus television broadcasters, both of whom have been tuning out.

title: Man Questioned on Dart Spree
description: A man was being questioned last night by the police in connection with a series of dart attacks on women in midtown Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column on March 9, about advertising to minorities, omitted a name among founders of the Mingo Group agency. In addition to Frank L. Mingo Jr. and Caroline R. Jones, they included Richard A. Guilmenot 3d. Mr. Guilmenot recently pointed out the error after a letter he wrote in March failed to arrive at The Times.

title: Excerpts From Economic Declaration by Chiefs of Seven Industrial Nations
description: Following are excerpts from the Economic Declaration issued today by the leaders of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada at the conclusion of their summit meeting:

title: Keane Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Sumitomo Unit's Offering Is a Japanese First in the U.S.
description: Sumitomo Bank International Finance Ltd., a unit of Sumitomo Bank Ltd., became the first Japanese bank to sell a subordinated debt issue in the United States yesterday when it priced $500 million in notes with a maturity date of July 15, 2000, through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: 51 Albanian Refugees Recall Repression and Hope of Asylum
description: The first Albanians allowed out of their country in its refugee crisis said today that the success of earlier asylum seekers and a desire to escape repressive Communist rule had prompted them to scale embassy walls in Tirana in hopes of settling in the West.

title: 19 Years Later, Father Asks New Inquiry on Police Killing
description: Even after 19 years, Thomas Emma keeps his pain packed in a box, dragging it out for anyone who asks. Marked ''Court Records,'' the box contains the facts and files that bring to life, time after time, the night in 1971 when Mr. Emma's 17-year-old son, Anthony, was shot and killed by a Paramus police officer.

title: KLLM Transport reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Joseph E. Wisan; Professor, 89
description: Dr. Joseph E. Wisan, professor emeritus of history at City College, died on Monday at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He died of complications after stomach surgery, the university said.

title: American Medical Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included charges of about $128.2 million related to merger expenses. c-Net income The company said third quarter results were affected by interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and asset writedowns. The company also said results were affected by expenses related to its acquisition of 86 percent of American Medical International Inc. last October.

title: Mexico Mine Bid Rejected
description: A judge has rejected a bid of $468 million for the Cananea S.A. copper mine and thwarted efforts to return it to private ownership.

title: Waterford Strike
description: Workers at Waterford Crystal glass works in Ireland ended a 14-week strike today after agreeing on cost-cutting proposals with management.The strike by 2,300 workers at Waterford's three plants began on April 5 over cost cuts, including the scrapping of bonuses for 500 glass cutters. Waterford said management and unions had agreed to refer issues on pay and conditions still in dispute to binding arbitration.

description: LEAD: ''Are we there yet?''

title: After City Hall: Job Limbo
description: LEAD: Government is the only sector I know in which accepting a promotion to a top appointive job means that, sooner rather than later, your career will end. As leaders change, you're cast out, precluded by ethics laws from pursuing your most logical private-sector prospects and looked upon, because of your government background, as unsuitable for other professions.

title: De Benedetti Wins Battle
description: The industrialist Carlo de Benedetti has regained management control of the leading Italian publishing company, Arnaldo Mondadori, after a bitter seven-month battle to oust Silvio Berlusconi.

description: Custodial Problems Persist In New York City Schools

description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Fear of Chaos Grows as China's Leaders Age
description: A young Government official paused over his dinner the other day when he was asked what the death of China's senior leaders might mean. ''Chaos,'' he replied glumly. ''Maybe civil war. It'll be back to the 1920's and 30's.''

title: Talman Home Federal S&L of Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $2 million in income from an insurance recover relating to a fraud loss charged off in previous periods. Loan loss provision was $1,000,000 and $2,000,000 for the latest quarter and 6-month period, respectively. Loan loss provision was $1,250,000 and $2,500,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6-month period, respectively. Total assets were $5,757,820,000 and $6,212,873,000 for the latest and year- ago 6 months, respectively. The company said net income was affected by the write-off of costs associated with a due diligence review in connection with a now-cancelled plan under which an investor group was to have acquired the company. Those costs could have been largely capitalized, had the transaction gone forward.

title: McCants Signs Big Pact
description: Giving up his senior year of eligibility at the University of Alabama apparently has proved to be a profitable decision for Keith McCants. The all-America linebacker, taken fourth in this spring's draft, has signed a five-year $7.4-million contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers that includes a $2.5 million cash signing bonus. (AP)

title: Hollywood Looks Beyond Mayhem For a Blockbuster
description: Midway through the 1990 summer movie season, Hollywood is awash in expensive action-adventure films and still looking for the one box office blockbuster that could dominate the market as ''Batman'' did last year.

title: Soviet Miners Strike for the Day, In Hope of Power and Better Life
description: The nation's coal miners held a daylong protest strike today to demand the resignation of the Soviet Government and greater local powers for industry and labor.

title: Review/Television;   New Doctor Adrift in Alaska
description: On a plane to Alaska, Joel Fleischman, fresh out of Columbia University medical school, is compulsively telling a complete stranger, ''I'm not kidding myself; Anchorage isn't New York.'' But, he adds, ''It isn't Cambodia, and it has five Chinese restaurants.'' Then, for no particular reason, he declares, ''Let's face it, Jewish doctors are not exactly an endangered species.''

title: Russell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Reader's Digest Fills Magazine Unit Post
description: The Reader's Digest Association has named Ronald L. Cole, the publisher of the United States edition of Reader's Digest, as vice president of its magazine publishing group. He will be replaced as publisher by John J. Donoghue, formerly the magazine's advertising sales director.

title: Chemical Bank Asian Operations
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation said it planned to move all its Asian treasury operations outside Japan into Singapore and close its foreign exchange operations in Hong Kong. Chemical will also close its branch office in Taipei, Taiwan. Its Taiwan customer service operations will move to other units in Asia, Europe and North America.

title: Dinkins Vows Glorious Show For Democrats
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins accepted the Democratic Party's gift of its 1992 National Convention to New York City yesterday, pledging to make it a ''glorious pageant of progress'' that would ''renew America's progressive values.''

title: New Therapy Shown to Fight Bone Loss in Elderly
description: The largest study ever conducted on osteoporosis has confirmed that a new treatment can strengthen elderly women's brittle bones and greatly reduce the risk of painful and deforming spinal fractures.

title: Apple Technologists Forming New Venture
description: Three well-known technologists from Apple Computer Inc., including perhaps its most distinguished programmer, Bill Atkinson, are forming a new company.

title: Walker Has Surgery
description: Kenny Walker of the Knicks yesterday underwent arthroscopic surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital to remove loose cartilage from his right knee. Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team physician, performed the procedure, which was a precautionary measure after the forward felt discomfort last season and missed 14 games.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS

title: C.I.A. Tie Asserted in Indonesia Purge
description: A dispute has developed over a report that 25 years ago, United States officials supplied up to 5,000 names of Indonesian Communists to the Indonesian Army, which was then engaged in a campaign to wipe out the Communist Party in that country.

title: Federal National Mortgage Assn reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: KEY RATES

description: The United States Women's Open, which begins today at the Atlanta Athletic Club, tends to separate the best from the rest to a greater degree than any other tournament in women's golf.

title: Amid Discord, Talks on Boat People Are Put Off
description: A 28-nation conference on Vietnamese boat people was postponed today when it became apparent that differences between the United States and Vietnam on one side and the Southeast Asian nations and Hong Kong on the other have not been bridged.

title: Lincoln Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank said earnings per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 6-for-5 stock split paid on May 15, 1990 and a 20 percent stock dividend distributed on May 19, 1989.
