description: Although the pianist and singer Nat (King) Cole died 25 years ago, his younger brother Freddy who is also a pianist and singer, has not yet managed to escape completely from his brother's shadow.

title: Seventh-day Adventists Vote To Bar Ordination of Women
description: The ruling body of the Seventh-day Adventist Church voted today to continue current practice and bar the ordination of women.

title: Breakfast in New York
description: Two years ago almost to the day, this man sat in a Soviet political camp, in punishment solitary, starving. He would not eat the thin gruel or the gray lump of bread that was his breakfast ration.

title: Trottier Disappointed
description: A week after being released by the Islanders for whom he had played 15 seasons, Bryan Trottier yesterday issued a statement titled ''Trottier Bids Farewell to Islander Fans,'' in which he said he hoped to play a minimum of two more years in the National Hockey League.

title: Federal Express Official Heads Smaller Concern
description: Judith A. Rogala, a senior vice president at the Federal Express Corporation, has left the overnight delivery company for an entrepreneurial career as the president and chief executive of Flagship Express Inc., a small, new aviation services concern.

title: Rear Adm. Paul Foley, Ex-Hofstra Official, 81
description: Rear Adm. Paul Foley Jr., former head of the Command and Staff Department of the Naval War College in Newport, R.I., and a retired Hofstra University official, died on Saturday at his home in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 81 years old and died of pnuemonia and congestive heart failure, his wife, Cornelia, said.

title: Clinic Settles Malpractice Lawsuit By Parents Who Had Septuplets
description: A fertility clinic has agreed to pay as much as $6 million to settle a malpractice lawsuit with a couple and their three surviving septuplets.

title: Net Up 4.5% At Motorola
description: Motorola Inc. today reported a 4.5 percent gain in its second-quarter profit from the period a year ago, partly because of international demand for its cellular telephone technology.

CURRENTS;

For a California Winery, Franco-American Design

title: Compromise Offered on Regulating Stock Index Futures
description: A key Senator offered a potential compromise today in the vigorous debate over the Administration's proposal for changes in the regulation of stock index futures.

description: It was, as President Bush described it on Monday, the first economic summit conference of the ''post-postwar era.'' And it turned out to be a kind of coming-out party for Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, reflecting the new, more subtle balance of power in the world.

title: Goodmark Foods reports earnings for Qtr to May 27

title: Architects Expand Use Of Glass Art
description: PEOPLE who live in glass houses have begun to color the door, etch the windows and cloud the view. The artists who create this haunting choreography - transforming the game of tag between sun and shadow into an architectural play of light - are glassmakers. And the modernization of their medieval craft is invigorating both architecture and art.

title: Summit Promise - and Shame;   A Chance, at Least, for Fair Farm Policy

But on the primary issue of agriculture policies, the leaders agreed to phase down protectionist subsidies.

title: Collins Reinstated
description: Tony Collins, the former New England Patriots running back who was suspended by the National Football League after testing positive for cocaine during a tryout with Indianpolis in 1988, has been reinstated by Commissioner Paul Tagliabue, league officials said yesterday.

title: From Genius To Bass Boat In 3 Hours
description: As a manager, Whitey Herzog seldom held team meetings. If he thought a player needed inspiration, he preferred to talk to him individually. But about three weeks ago, with the St. Louis Cardinals plodding along in last place in the National League East, he addressed his team. After his oration, he looked around the clubhouse.

title: Chronicle
description: PEARL BAILEY's left knee was replaced yesterday in a 55-minute operation at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. ''Everthing went according to plan,'' said the chief surgeon, Dr. RICHARD H. ROTHMAN. ''There were no surprises.'' The 72-year-old singer received a new knee joint of plastic and metal. Immediately after the operation her leg was placed in a machine to keep it in continuous motion. She is expected to start walking today, Dr. Rothman said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Action Industries, Cheswick, Pa., a marketer of housewares and giftware promotional programs, named as its chairman Sholom D. Comay, who will replace Ernest S. Berez, who is retiring.

title: Calendar of Events: Porcelain and Glass
description: Fine Service, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 860-6862.

title: Life Term and $19 Million Fine for Drug Boss
description: The head of a violent drug ring in Brooklyn was sentenced yesterday to life in prison and fined $18.9 million.

Labor Dept. Asks Rule Requiring Working Drivers to Use Seat Belt
description: The Government intends to adopt a rule requiring that the 35 million American workers who drive on the job wear seat belts, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole announced today.

title: Citing Study, Cuomo Urges a Drop in Milk Prices
description: In a practice that state officials called unfair and unfortunate, New York retailers reduced the price of milk only slightly this spring after the farm price of milk plummeted from the record levels of last winter, according to a state report released today.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Report Cites Concern Over Chip Industry
description: The National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors is expected to issue a report on Thursday stating that the American electronics industry is endangered by a decline in strength of the American companies that produce sophisticated equipment and materials for making computer chips.

title: Williams Is Selling 10.25% Debentures
description: The Williams Companies of Tulsa, Okla., is offering $150 million in 30-year debentures through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: New York City Is Urged to Buy Big Trump Site
description: A group of Manhattan elected officials urged the city yesterday to buy the 76-acre Penn Yards site owned by Donald J. Trump on the Upper West Side and oversee its development by private interests for the greatest public benefit.

title:
CURRENTS;

Where Bauhaus Embraces the Desert
description: LEAD: VISITORS to Palm Springs, Calif., may feel that it looks as if it were designed by one person. It turns out that much of it was, as Joseph Rosa writes in his book, ''Albert Frey, Architect'' (Rizzoli International, $29.95).

title: Metro Matters;   Toe in the Water: Cuomo Scouts '92 Convention
description: Welcoming Democratic National Convention delegates to his home state, the Governor eloquently quotes St. Francis. Five days later he accepts the Presidential nomination, allowing as how he had not aspired to the office and that he would have preferred a better candidate, but noting that ''from such dread responsibility one does not shrink in fear, in self-interest or in false humility.''

title: Men of Comiskey Fall in 13th Stanza
description: On a cool, foggy afternoon in Comiskey Park's final season, what looked to be the ghosts of championships past took the field today.

description: Beyond the debates on Bavarian cowherds and Japanese rice farmers, beyond the conventions on global forests and jousts on the Uruguay Round, a more subtle, personal roundelay was taking place this week.

title: What California Has Isn't Gerrymandering
description: To the Editor:

title: Perrier Regains Ground in Sales
description: Source Perrier S.A. said sales of its bottled water in the United States recovered in May to two-thirds of their levels a year earlier, compared with near zero after a benzene contamination led to a worldwide recall. ''We honestly didn't think we'd reach this benchmark until months from now,'' said Kim Jeffery, senior vice president of sales and marketing for Perrier's United States unit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Thompson's New Source Of Ideas
description: J. WALTER THOMPSON has found an usual way to come up with new advertising campaigns: it lets the research and account management departments do the job.

Sunwest Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest second-quarter results reflected a $3.3 million expense for a voluntary early retirement program. The bank holding company said the program will reduce future annual operating expenses by about $2 million.

description: DDB Needham promoted 10 employees to senior vice presidencies: Lauren Berger, Peter Gardiner, Judith Goldstein, Bob Huff, Alan Krinsky, Paul Manganiello, Carmine Marino, Joan Niborg, Steven Werby and David Wismer. The agency also named Gary Leeds treasurer.

Neil Bush Says Regulators Hid Clearing Proof
description: Neil Bush, the President's son, charged today that Federal regulators had acted ''with vengeance'' against him. He accused them of concealing evidence that he said would exonerate him of the allegations that he was engaged in a conflict of interest while serving as director of a Colorado savings and loan institution that failed in 1988.

title: Safeway Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: The company attributed the improvement in income for both 1990 periods to sales gains and improved gross margins. Sales of stores open more than a year rose 4.1 percent in the latest quarter and 3.2 percent in the latest six-month period.

title: Micro Bio-Medics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Review/Ballet;   The Bolshoi Tradition Lives On in 'Swan Lake'
description: The Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow opened Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with Yuri Grigorovich's version of ''Swan Lake.'' Nina Ananiashvili was a wonderful Odette-Odile, with the accent on Odile. Her Siegfried, Aleksei Fadeyechev, had the nobility that courses in his veins from another memorable dancer in the role - his father, Nikolai Fadeyechev.

title: Quebec Est Serieux
description: Down where I come from in the Old Confederacy, the idea of secession is no longer so appealing. Despite scare headlines, it's not as popular in Quebec as it once was, either. Now, even ''separatism'' is used avec soigneusement.

title: Dow Up 41.83 in Heavy Program Trading
description: Stocks advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading, with oil, high-technology and drug stocks leading the way.

title: Arts Figures Denounce Endowment On Grants
description: Artists, public officials and representatives of many local and national arts groups spoke out forcefully yesterday against the National Endowment for the Arts for its recent rejection of four grants that had been recommended to it.

title: Star Banc Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Educational Development reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Review/Music;   Mostly Mozart Opens, With Humor
description: Mozart worship is, on the whole, a healthy thing. It testifies to the possibility that vestiges of good sense may still be found in modern society. Still, it does no harm occasionally to face the truth: even he sometimes had to produce music when the fires of inspiration flickered low. One such work, ''Der Schauspieldirektor,'' a jocular singspiel known in English as ''The Impresario,'' served on Tuesday evening as the centerpiece of the opening concert of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: A Man's Place Is in Home Economics, Home Economists Say
description: LEAD: DON'T even think about asking a home economist of the 1990's if she plans to stay at home. Don't ask him, either.

title: Hartmarx Plans Store Closings
description: The Hartmarx Corporation, the apparel maker and marketer best known for its men's wear, said it would close 65 stores and sell its minority interest in its Robert's Mexican affiliate, resulting in a charge against second-quarter earnings of $51 million. Fifty stores will be closed this fall in the speciality stores group, it said, reducing the total in that group to 213. Fifteen Country Miss stores will also be closed, leaving 79, Hartmarx said the closings would allow it to focus on its strongest store locations. Hartmarx now owns about 35 percent of Robert's, a maker and retailer of men's apparel in Mexico City. Hartmarx's shares jumped $1 a share today, to $11.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, where the 9.6 percent gain was the 10th best of the day.

title: Right-to-Die Ruling Curtails Individual Liberty;   A Christian Version
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Recall Hundley
description: With Mackey Sasser sidelined for another four to five games because of a sprained right ankle, the Mets announced yesterday they had recalled Todd Hundley from their Class AA farm club in Jackson, Miss., to share catching duties with Orlando Mercado for the five-game weekend series against the Reds in Cincinnati.

title: Mercantile Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jury Finds Nursing Home Liable for Routine Neglect
description: A Federal jury in Mississippi has awarded damage verdicts to families of nursing home patients whose last years were blighted by neglect at a home run by the nation's largest nursing home chain.

title: LeMond Shows Form Of Old
description: Ronan Pensec proved today that he is the man to beat in the Tour de France and Greg LeMond showed that he is in condition to try to do just that.

title: Officer Dies as Mohawks and Quebec Police Clash
description: About 200 armed Mohawk Indians fought off a police assault today in a dispute over plans to expand a private golf course surrounded by tribal land. One officer was killed.

title: German Funds Frozen
description: East Germany said today that it had frozen 56 new hard-currency bank accounts containing tens of millions of marks on suspicion that the sums were amassed through illegal speculation. East Germany adopted the West German mark as its currency when the two Germanys merged their economies on July 1. A Government spokesman, Matthias Gehler, said huge sums had been deposited in some special exchange accounts set up by citizens before the economic union, prompting investigations of 60,000 cases.

title: Joe Appiah Is Dead; Ghanaian Politician And Ex-Envoy, 71
description: Joe Appiah, a Ghanaian political figure and former diplomat whose marriage to a white British woman attracted wide publicity in 1953, died on Sunday in an Accra hospital, a family friend, Henry Louis Gates Jr., said. Mr. Appiah was 71 years old and lived in Kumasi, Ghana.

title: In a Garden, Tea and Matrimony
description: LEAD: THE setting of the Sundial Herb Garden in Higganum, Conn., inspires weddings and teas. Herbs trimmed into low hedges form interlocking patterns in the knot garden, and geometric beds of lavender, sweet woodruff, yarrow, primrose and wood betony surround a sundial in an 18th-century-style garden. In the topiary garden, sculptured beds planted with herbs surround a splashing fountain.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 512 money market mutual funds increased $3.10 billion, to $385.83 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $215.40 million, to $91.82 billion. The assets of the 250 general-purpose funds were up by $763.50 million, to $133.98 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds rose $2.12 billion, to $160.04 billion, the institute said.

description: Leda Feldman Hanson and David Murray, the deputy director of communications for the State Transportation Department in Albany, were married yesterday. Justice E. Leo Milonas performed the ceremony in the courtroom of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

description: The Computer Sciences Corporation said it had ended talks over the possible acquisition of two subsidiaries of the Black & Decker Corporation. description: Through most of its history this has been an unmilitarized country. The Framers of the Constitution wanted it that way. To prevent a large standing army becoming a habit, they provided that Congress could not appropriate money for the military ''for a longer term than two years.''

description: Armed with new information about the viewing and listening habits of children, the Federal Communications Commission made a new effort today to impose a complete ban on what it considers indecent radio and television broadcasts.

title: Soviets Say 3 Died in Armenian Ambush of Convoy
description: Armenian militants attacked a convoy of vehicles in a disputed region of Azerbaijan and three people were killed in a battle between the attackers and Soviet troops, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Albany: More Errors Than Hits
description: Sadly, it's easier this year to list Albany's sins of omission than its achievements. The Legislature approved the state budget seven weeks late, at great cost to the taxpayer. It failed to revise the inequitable school aid formula to direct more money to New York City and other needy districts. It failed to impose new penalties for bias-related violence. It failed to ban the sale of semiautomatic assault rifles.

title: Barry Witness Says He Worried About Effect of Drugs on Mayor
description: Describing himself as someone who had shared drugs with Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and loved him like a twin brother, a Washington advertising executive testified today that he worried about the effect that frequent cocaine use was having on the Mayor's ability to govern.

title: Rockwell Stock
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said its board had extended the company's stock repurchase program by an additional $500 million. It said that the program was started in March 1986 and extended in $500 million increments in March 1987 and December 1988. Rockwell said that at current prices, the extended program would reduce common shares outstanding by about 7.5 percent. The company's stock rose 37.5 cents a share today, to $27.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Robert B. Davies, Accountant, 72
description: Robert B. Davies, a certified public accountant in Manhattan for 35 years, died on Wednesday. He was 72 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Curtiss-Wright to Pay $30-a-Share Dividend
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, a diversified aerospace components manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had declared a one-time dividend of $30 a share.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises
description: A surge in exports widened Japan's trade surplus by 27.5 percent in June, causing some analysts to believe that an 18-month shrinking of the trade imbalance may be over.

title: Oil Prices Surge as Saudis Agree to Reduce Output
description: Prices of crude oil and byproducts soared yesterday on the news that Saudi Arabia had agreed to reduce its oil output temporarily to bolster sagging oil prices.

title: U.S. Details Its Mandatory Food Labeling Plans
description: The Bush Administration today offered new rules for mandatory nutritional labeling on virtually all packaged foods, including tighter restrictions on claims that a product has low or reduced cholesterol.

title: Black Panelist at N.A.A.C.P. Session Accuses Studios of 'Jewish Racism'
description: Hollywood's leading film and television studios and executives were accused of ''Jewish racism'' this week at the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and several leaders of prominent Jewish organizations responded today, saying the incident damages relations between blacks and Jews.

title: House, 377-28, Approves Bill to Protect Disabled
description: The House of Representatives gave final approval today to legislation that would extend full Federal protection against discrimination to millions of Americans with physical and mental disabilities.

title: Contel Agrees to Takeover Offer by GTE
description: In a move that would sharply expand both its local telephone operations and its fast-growing cellular telephone business, the GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement with the Contel Corporation to acquire the Atlanta-based company in a stock swap. The deal would be worth about $6 billion, based on yesterday's closing stock prices.

title: Evelyn Klein Spitalny, Violinist, Is Dead at 79
description: Evelyn Klein Spitalny, a violinist who was the concertmaster in Phil Spitalny's All-Girl Orchestra, died on Sunday at a hospital in Miami Beach. She was 79 years old and died of heart failure, said the executor of her estate, Barton S. Goldberg.

title: Scents and Sport
description: Walk along a weedy roadside or an unmowed field, especially toward the end of a heavy summer day, and suddenly you are surrounded by surprising flowery smells from a couple of commonplace plants. The bright, heady scent is from honeysuckle, an aggressive and unwelcome vine that climbs everywhere. The musky scent comes from the gawky milkweed, whose clustered flowers summon up the poet's perfumes of Araby.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, an electronics company, said its stock plan of reorganization for emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection had been confirmed by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.

description: In China's first official response to criticism over the last week from the exiled dissident Fang Lizhi, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that his conduct was not worth discussing.

description: The battle over how to explain the largest tax increase in New Jersey history was joined by Gov. Jim Florio today, as he signed the bill to raise $1.25 billion in new income taxes. He described the action as property-tax relief for the middle class.

description: In one of the biggest mergers in French corporate history, the water utility Lyonnaise des Eaux will join with the construction company Dumez, creating a company with 100,000 employees and annual revenue of about $14.9 billion. The merger will be through an exchange of four Lyonnaise shares for three Dumez shares.

description: The Bush Administration reacted coolly today to some parts of a bipartisan Senate proposal to toughen Federal espionage laws, saying a number of the steps proposed were better left to the White House than to Congress.

description: The Cuban Government stood firm today in its refusal to negotiate the departure of Cubans seeking refuge in foreign embassies in Havana after the number of refugees rose to 15.

title: A Crime Bill Tainted by Death
description: The omnibus crime bill that passed the Senate this week contains good provisions: gun control, a police corps, money for local law enforcement. But they are heavily outweighed by misguided expansions of the death penalty. It's now up to the House to keep the good and eliminate the bad.

title: Foe of Kenya's Leader Said to Flee to London
description: A major critic of President Daniel arap Moi who took refuge in the United States Embassy during four days of violent anti-Government protests has left Kenya for London, the United States Ambassador said today.

title: Restaurants
description: In today's perilous marketplace, one might think it imprudent to tinker with a winning formula. Yet Richard Lavin, the affable and savvy restaurateur who owns Sofi on lower Fifth Avenue and Lavin's on West 39th Street, has done just that. He has taken the popular Sofi, which served inventive American food for three years, and made it northern Italian - a move that seems akin to converting the New York Mets to a soccer team. What's the point?

title: Silverado Asset Sale Is Challenged
description: Two board members of a Manhattan building have sued the Government to prevent it from selling 141 apartments seized at the building, One Harkness Place, as part of the savings and loan bailout.

title: Portsmouth Bank Shares Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Arlington Race May Have Only 6
description: The showdown at Arlington Park on Aug. 4 among Criminal Type, Easy Goer and Sunday Silence might just as well be a three-horse race. Only three others are likely to run and they seem to be gunning for no more than fourth place.

title: Transworld Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings for 1989 are adjusted to reflect 5-percent stock dividend paid April 18, 1990.

title: Olin Will Appeal Decision of F.T.C.
description: The Olin Corporation, a diversified chemicals maker, said it would appeal a Federal Trade Commission decision that its acquisition of some swimming-pool chemicals businesses and other assets from the FMC Corporation violated Federal antitrust regulations.

title: Top Marketing Official Leaves The Daily News
description: The Daily News announced yesterday that James Mason, its vice president of advertising and marketing, had resigned ''to pursue other business interests.'' The New York City newspaper would not elaborate, and Mr. Mason could not be reached to comment.

title: Wacoal Corp.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Share earnings represent earning per American Depositary Share, 5 shares of common stock. Results are on U.S. dollars; U.S. dollar amounts in this statement for fiscal 1990 represent translations of the Japanese yen for convenience only at the actual approximate exchange rate on March 31, 1990 of Y158 equals $1.00; for fiscal 1989, the prevailing exchange rate on March 31, 1989 of Y132 equals $1.00 was used.

title: Review/Film;   Looking to the Dead For Mirth and Inspiration
description: Current Hollywood thinking extends into the next world, but not very far. Being dead has lately been presented on screen as a character-building experience, but beyond that the current ghost films hedge their bets. The questions of just what ghosts can do, of what effect ghosts may have on others or even of how ghosts regard their new status are seldom even addressed. What seems most important is that ghosts come to the aid of their loved ones, and that the ghost film manages, at least on its own terms, to be sincere.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In view of my great responsibilities towards the people of Russia and in connection with the move towards a multi-party system, I cannot fulfill only the instructions of the Communist Party.''

title: Mrs. Dole Buckles Up - Again
description: As President Reagan's Secretary of Transportation, Elizabeth Dole was criticized for not pushing companies to install passive restraints - air bags and automatic seat belts - in cars. Then in 1984 she helped engineer Rule 208, a landmark law that induced many states to require manually operated safety belts. It had the further effect of persuading manufacturers to provide automatic devices. Six years later, 36 states and the District of Columbia have safety belt laws. And all new cars must be equipped with air bags or automatic belts.

title: Italian Climbs Into Lead; LeMond Gains
description: A day after he became the man to beat in the Tour de France, Ronan Pensec was beaten badly in an individual time trial and lost the overall leader's yellow jersey.

title: SPI Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Reflects $960,000 gain from efficiencies created by moving operations to a new facility in Spain earlier than originally planned, offset by related inventory and other expenses. Year-ago periods reflect one-time gain for fulfillment of a licensing agreement. The company said second quarter 1990 sales benefited from strong growth in international operations, particularly those in Mexico and Spain.

title: Baruch M. Bokser, 44, A Professor of Talmud
description: Baruch M. Bokser, a professor of Talmud and rabbinical studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Raytheon Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Carom Capital Corp.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said fiscal 1990 results included a $150,000 loss from discontinued operations and a $325,000 writeoff of its investment in financial institutions, and those of the prior year include income from discontinued operations of $133,000 and a gain of $232,000 on the sale of the company's precious metals business.

title: Computer Technology Suit
description: Two founders of an American computer company have filed a lawsuit against the Japanese farm equipment maker that financed them, charging the Japanese company with trying to take control of the computer maker's technology.

title: Review/Theater;   Shakespeare in the Wild West, in the Park
description: If Cole Porter and company could transplant ''The Taming of the Shrew'' to sedate, late 1940's Baltimore, why can't the New York Shakespeare Festival let Kate and Petruchio have their standoff in the wild, late 19th-century West? A. J. Antoon's rambunctious production of Shakespeare's comedy, at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, turns out to be its own best argument. With Morgan Freeman and Tracey Ullman, a theoretically unlikely yet entirely winning couple, at center stage, the entertainment is consistently more engaging than it may sound on paper. Were Mr. Antoon's ''Shrew'' a musical, it would be too broad to be ''Kiss Me Kate'' perhaps, but it could happily pass for ''Annie Get Your Gun.''

title: Cuomo Unafraid of Health Veto
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he would not care about the potential political fallout of vetoing a major health-care bill in this election year, but he said he has not decided whether to sign or kill the legislation.

title: Pathe Suit Names Time Warner
description: The Pathe Communications Corporaion filed a countersuit today in its attempt to negotiate a loan from Time Warner Inc. to help with the acquisition of the MGM-UA Communications Company.

title: Miller (Herman) Inc.(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $3,300,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: European American Banks reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Ceradyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Amos Neyhart, 91; Originated Courses In Driver Education
description: Amos E. Neyhart, an expert on automobile safety who originated driver education programs in the United States in the 1930's, died on July 5 at the Fairways Nursing Home in State College, Pa. He was 91 years old.

title: M.R. Beal Firm Adds Carmona
description: Two of Wall Street's leading minority-owned firms will join forces to compete better for the portion of Government business that is often reserved for minority-owned concerns.

title: English, Language of Summits
description: English is the lingua franca of summitry. At NATO summit meetings, France's representatives still make a point of speaking French in plenary sessions, but in the corridors they converse informally in English. At economic summit meetings, some leaders still rely on translators, but the sherpas who accompany them to the summit do their communique drafting in English. Of course, it's the English of technocrats, not the language of real life. That same bureaucratese trips all too easily off President Bush's tongue. He characterized the NATO meeting in classic Bushspeak: ''Some very interesting developments'' but nothing of ''bombshell dimension.''

title: Utah Medical Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brady Gives Views on Bill
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady acknowledged today that the Bush Administration would probably fail to persuade the Senate to pass all of its proposals to revise the regulation of the financial markets.

title: GEAC Computer Corp.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company said the decline in revenues during the latest year was the result of the sale of its Canadian financial division. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mission Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: On March 30 the company acquired Concord Commercial Bank in a transaction accounted for as a pooling-of- interests. Amounts for 1989 have been restated to include the totals of Concord Commercial Bank.

title: First Wachovia reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Harleysville National reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Structural Dynamics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: FED CONSIDERS CUT IN INTEREST RATES TO BOOST ECONOMY
description: Expressing concern that banks have become overly cautious in lending money, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that the central bank might need to cut interest rates to keep the economy moving ahead.

title: Eugene Levy, 63, Republican Member of New York Senate
description: State Senator Eugene Levy, a Republican from Suffern, N.Y., who had served in the State Legislature since 1969, died yesterday in Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. He was 63 years old.

title: Article 158790 -- No Title
description: Motel 6, the budget motel company, agreed today to be acquired by the French-based hotel giant Accor S.A. for $1.3 billion in cash, the two companies announced.

title: KEY RATES

LAW;

Beards on Policemen Become a Civil Rights Issue
description: LEAD: A civil rights ruling in Maryland has cast doubt on the legality of on-the-job grooming rules that require men to shave even though many blacks suffer from a painful skin condition that is rare in other groups.

title: Texscan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Off the Road and Into Commuter Express Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene;   Deep Divisions At Summit Talks
description: The Houston summit conference was a successful holding operation. In the face of conflicts over aid to the Soviet Union, the elimination of agricultural subsidies and actions to deal with environmental pollution and global warming, the leaders of the seven major industrial countries preserved their civility and produced a set of compromises that will enable them to go on working together a while longer.

title: Job Cuts Planned By Fisher-Price
description: Fisher-Price Toys, a troubled unit of the Quaker Oats Company, said it would cut about 245 jobs at its headquarters here, and that between 300 and 400 jobs would be lost when a shutdown of a nearby plant in Holland, N.Y., is completed by November. Until recently, the plant made molded plastic parts that were shipped to an East Aurora plant.

title: First Colonial Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $549,000 nonrecurring gain from freezing the company's over-funded pension plan for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: S.E.C. Proposals Seek to Limit Risk in Money Funds
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed new rules today intended to crack down on risky investments in the portfolios of money market funds.

title: A Messenger Is Arrested In Dart Case
description: A 33-year-old messenger in the Time-Life Building was arrested yesterday and charged as the mysterious attacker who blew darts at well-dressed women in midtown Manhattan.

title: Review/Film;   The Wrong Woman To Wrong
description: The life of ease to be found within the Le Quesnoy household involves polished silver, handsome children in private-school uniforms, a stern father with an important job and a pert mother who feels guilty over not having made enough place mats for the church fair. ''Life Is a Long Quiet River,'' with a title that refers to this family's sunny complacency, is a sly French comedy about the circumstances that reduce the Le Quesnoy children to eating ketchup sandwiches and sniffing glue.

title: Guardian Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oil Spill Compromise Calls for Double Hulls
description: A Congressional conference committee drafting legislation on oil spills decided today to require almost all oil tankers to be equipped with protective double hulls, phasing in the change over the next 20 years.

title: Review/Photography;   Beauty and Challenge In Modern Landscapes
description: One of the tasks of the art of the last 10 years has been to reconstruct the notion of natural beauty in the face of a seemingly endless onslaught against nature. Mankind's alteration of previously pristine spaces, from tropical rain forests to the very air we breathe, poses a challenge that is not only environmental, but also esthetic: can art reflect what is happening to the natural world while retaining its traditional attachment to the sublime?

title: Unitel Video Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 9-month results were negatively affected by merger agreement costs relating to the terminated merger agreement with Kenmare Capital Corp., lower earnings from 50 percent-owned affiliates and costs associated with a change in the management of the Hollywood division.

title: National Commerce Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Actors Back Arts Agency In Capital
description: Several of the nation's best-known actors went to Capitol Hill today in defense of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Public Needs to Know About Unsafe Products
description: To the Editor:

title: John H. Baer, Executive, 71
description: John H. Baer, a textile industry executive, died on Tuesday at the Hotel Norfolk in Nairobi, Kenya, while on a business trip. He was 71 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Jacob J. Alpern, 86, Steel Company Chief
description: Jacob J. Alpern, an owner of the Grand Iron Works, once the largest fabricator and erector of structural steel in New York State, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old. His family said he died of lung cancer.

title: Channel Home Centers Names Chief Executive
description: Channel Home Centers Inc., which runs 89 stores in Northeast and Middle Atlantic states, said yesterday that it had named Joseph Nusim, who has been operating a chain of warehouse clubs, to be its new president and chief executive, Mr. Nusim, 54, succeeds Leon Berger, 67, who is retiring after 18 years with Channel and who is a pioneer of the home center concept, which brings lumber, hardware, electrical and plumbing supplies and other goods for the home together in a one-stop shopping center.

title: Steinbrenner Replies
description: In a letter to Commissioner Fay Vincent, attorneys for George Steinbrenner have finally replied on the procedure for the remaining portion of baseball's investigation of the Yankee owner's activities. But Vincent declined to say today what the reply was.

title: Mets, Battling Reds, Win Big and Lose Small
description: Todd Hundley had seen Rob Dibble's fastball before, but only from a safe distance. Hundley was sitting in Wrigley Field 48 hours earlier, a spectator watching stars, a 21-year-old with a future more in front of him than at hand.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $266,000,000 from major business disposition and joint venturing and also included a loss of $261,000,000 from a provision for restructuring. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflected a 2-for-1 stock split effective May 5, 1990.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Macworld: Adversarial and Successful
description: Macworld likes to stir up trouble, as the magazine's July issue shows.

title: Stock of Computer Associates Drops
description: The stock of Computer Associates International Inc. plunged $6.25 a share today, to $10.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after the company said its results for the quarter ended June 30 were unlikely to meet analysts' estimates. The 37.9 percent decline in the stock's price was the largest of the day on the Big Board.

title: Scientists Discover the Gene In a Nervous System Disease
description: After three years of struggling to overcome frustrating technical snags and red herrings, scientists have isolated the gene that causes the disfiguring and sometimes fatal condition known as Elephant Man's disease.

title: Rubbermaid Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
German Knife-Wielder Insane
description: A woman who tried to kill West Germany's opposition candidate for Chancellor, Oskar Lafontaine, by attacking him with a knife is unfit to face trial and should be confined to a psychiatric hospital, prosecutors said today. They said that the woman, Adelheid Streidel, 43 years old, was schizophrenic and asked a court not to proceed against her. Miss Streidel stabbed Mr. Lafontaine in the neck with a butcher's knife at an election rally in Cologne on April 25. Mr. Lafontaine, a Social Democrat, was seriously wounded but has since recovered.

title: King Tells the Court Of Parrying Tactics
description: Don King yesterday ended about 13 hours of loquacious testimony over two and a half days in the trial of his breach-of-contract suit against James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, and John Johnson, his manager.

title: Dow Rises 37.13 to Set a Record
description: The prospect of lower interest rates and higher corporate profits pushed stock prices to record levels yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average surged by 37.13, to a new high for the blue-chip average of 2,969.80.

title: Unitrin Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Rose Isn't a Rose, Some Judges Say
description: LEAD: When Pierce Barker, a former student of mine, and Carol Frost got married and had a son, they named him Theodore Roth-Tubman. Pierce and Carol are free spirits who admired Philip Roth and Harriet Tubman and had no particular stake in insuring that their own patronyms would endure to the end of time.

title: Texas Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $10,725,000 and $14,973,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, which included $9,000,000 charge from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income

title: Louisiana Governor Tells of Quandary Over Bill to Ban Abortion
description: When Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana was elected three years ago, he overthrew the political establishment by promising to make the tough decisions that others would not face. Now he faces a decision that he says he is finding nearly impossible to make.

title: United Resolve Marked Conference on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheehan and Lopez Sailing As Women's Open Starts
description: Patty Sheehan and Nancy Lopez spurred each other to their best starts ever today in the United States Women's Open, the biggest tournament neither has ever won.

title: Rating of Time Warner
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said this week that it had affirmed Time Warner Inc.'s BB-rated long-term debt and B-plus subordinated debt and preferred stock ratings. The securities were removed from S.&P.'s Creditwatch, where they had been placed for possible downgrading. Roughly $1.5 billion of long-term debt and $5.6 billion of preferred stock are affected. Standard & Poor's noted that although Time Warner had agreed to guarantee $650 million of debt of the Pathe Communications Corporation for Pathe's proposed acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Company, the deal appeared unlikely to be completed.

title: The Talk of Sullivan County;   Victory Leaves a Prosecutor With an Orphaned Court
description: More than two years after the Sullivan County District Attorney's office asked, in an anonymous complaint, that a state judicial commission investigate the county court judge here, prosecutors have emerged triumphant in theory, if a little traumatized in practice.

title: Sunwest Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest second-quarter results reflected a $3.3 million expense for a voluntary early retirement program. The bank holding company said the program will reduce future annual operating expenses by about $2 million.

title: U.S. to Reimburse Meese for His Legal Bills
description: A Federal court awarded former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d Government compensation of $460,509 today for the legal fees he incurred while he was the subject of an independent prosecutor's investigation.

title: Hernandez Is Back
description: Another former National League most valuable player, Keith Hernandez, rejoined the Cleveland Indians in Seattle yesterday after completing a brief rehabilitation stint with Winter Haven in Florida's Gulf Coast League. The 36-year-old first baseman had 5 hits in 11 times at bat while testing his pulled left calf muscle. With the Indians, the former Met has a .208 batting average with 1 home run in 36 games.(AP)

title: Auctions
description: Greece to the Rescue

title: Republicans on the Attack In Savings and Loan Crisis
description: Unnerved by the rising public outrage over the nation's savings and loan scandal, the Republican Party opened an orchestrated effort today to blame the Democrats before the Democrats succeed in their effort to blame the Republicans.

title: Prime Bancshares Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank's stock first traded on July 27, 1989.

title: Susan L. Borden Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Laura Borden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Borden of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last evening at the Tam O'Shanter Club in Brookville, L.I., to Dr. Steve W. Rucker, a son of Gloria Rucker of West Orange, N.J., and Dr. Maurice Rucker of Alfred, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Davis performed the ceremony. Mrs. Rucker, a graduate of Colgate University, is a marketing representative in Rockville Centre, L.I., for Homedco Inc., a medical home care supply company in Fountain Valley, Calif. Her first marriage ended in divorce. Her father is a lawyer and an accountant in New York. Her mother, Francine Borden, is a former New York City schoolteacher. The bridegroom is an internist and nephrologist and an attending physician at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, L.I. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received his medical degree from the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Teledyne Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $25,600,000, or 46 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,000,000, or 26 cents a share, and $49,300,000, or 89 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Income from continuing operations for the six months ended June 30, 1990 included a reversal of $7.7 million provision for income taxes which is no longer necessary as a result of the spinoff of Teledyne's insurance and finance subsidiaries on March 31. Results for 1989 are restated to reflect the company's former insurance and finance subsidiaries as discontinued operations and adjusted for the 5-for-1 stock split.

title: A Pianist Champions John Field
description: ''The difficulty I've had this year is that I've been away from home so much, and that's something that takes getting used to,'' the pianist John O'Conor said the other day, speaking from his home in Dublin. Apart from complaining about the Irish rain - particularly when he heard it was sunny and warm in New York City - he was enjoying a two-week respite between concerts.

title: Pauperized Workers Are Price of 'Free' Trade
description: To the Editor:

Cray President Leaves In Rift With Chairman
description: Marcelo A. Gumucio, president and chief operating officer of Cray Research Inc., resigned yesterday, saying that he and Cray's chairman, John A. Rollwagen, had agreed that their contrasting management styles made it impossible to work together.

title: West Mass Bankshares Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: ISAAC STERN , who will be 70 years old on July 21, has been combining two of his loves - performing and parties - in birthday celebrations here and overseas. the violinist did so in Evian, France, on May 17, and in Paris on June 11 when he received the keys to the city. In New York on Oct. 16, a concert and party will be held in New York; on Nov. 15 he is to perform in London with his son Michael, 30, conducting the London Symphony Orchestra.

title: AT THE BAR
description: There is nothing odd about lawyers' showing up in the Albany City Courthouse. But over the past few months and continuing through the summer, a steady stream of lawyers are coming before the court in a most unusual capacity: as defendants.

title: Sherwin-Williams Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Killed as Train Crushes Van
description: A van loaded with children on a family outing to an amusement park was crushed Wednesday evening when it drove into the path of a train, the authorities said. Two children and a 25-year-old woman were killed. Three adults and five children remained hospitalized today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Whatever else the participants at the economic summit meeting accomplished, President FRANCOIS MITTERRAND of France came away with a new title: distinguished professor of architecture at the University of Houston. The title and an honorary doctorate of humanities was awarded in a hastily arranged presentation yesterday at the university's College of Architecture, the four-year-old building created by Philip Johnson after a design by the 19th century French architect Claude-Nicolas Ledoux.

title: Confounding Predictions, a Gunman Foils a Hunt
description: At 10:30 Wednesday night, a police dispatcher's voice crackled over thousands of radios: ''2230 hours. Operation Watchdog is in effect.'' Scores of detectives and hundreds of police officers spread out across New York City, and the hunt for the elusive man who calls himself the Zodiac gunman was on.

title:
A City in Transition;

Waterfront Housing for Perth Amboy
description: LEAD: Like other New Jersey port cities, Perth Amboy, which is on the Arthur Kill and the Raritan River opposite Staten Island, watched its waterfront crumble in the 1950's as businesses shut down or moved away. Today, Raritan Steel is the only major smokestack company left on the river's edge.

title: A $45 MILLION LOSS IS CITED ON LOANS TIED TO NEIL BUSH
description: As a director of a Denver savings institution, Neil Bush voted to approve loans for a close business associate that resulted in a loss to the Government of at least $45 million, according to documents released by Federal regulators.

title: A Convicted Killer Is Executed in Alabama
description: An Alabama man convicted of abducting and killing a woman in 1976 was executed in the electric chair early Friday after failing in his last two attempts to get a reprieve.

title: Who's Performing When
description: Serious Fun, an eclectic performance series, runs through Aug. 2 at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets to each performance are $20 or $25; there is also an $80 coupon book for any five shows. Information: 362-1911. Here is a schedule:

title: SI Handling Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Our Towns;   Future Scientist Asks, What Good Is the Moon?
description: In the basement of an old college lab with no air conditioning, a small group of bright junior-high students, mostly black and Hispanic, spend their summer days studying math, physics, chemistry. A University of Bridgeport professor, Richard Guerra, is trying to influence them to become engineers.

title: Crop Outlook Is Mixed
description: Supplies of corn and soybeans appear tight, while wheat supplies are swelling with a big harvest, the Agriculture Department reported today in its monthly crop report.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Wainwright's Sting

title: Pacific Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TV Weekend;   A Bitter Divorce That Ends in Death
description: Trying to do something about eroding audiences, the networks this summer are making efforts to offer viewers something more than the normal diet of reruns. NBC, for instance, has gone to Canada to acquire a four-hour television movie called ''Love and Hate,'' which will be broadcast in two parts, Sunday and Monday at 9 P.M. NBC eagerly points out that this was the highest-rated drama on Canadian television in 1989. Just in case, the network has added a juicy subtitle: ''A Marriage Made in Hell.''

title: Valero Natural Gas Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Refugee Ships Leave for Albania
description: Ships from three nations sailed today to a rendezvous off Albania in a sea lift of more than 4,500 Albanians seeking to escape their homeland, Europe's last haven for hard-line Communists.

title: A British Official, Stirring Outcry, Says Germans Are Taking Over
description: A senior British

title: Burlington Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,752,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $17,438,000, or 12 cents a share for the 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,351,000, or 5 cents a share and $26,106,000, or 17 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $265,611,000, or $1.77 a share for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Novellus Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Radiation Peril at Hanford Is Detailed
description: One in every 20 residents of 10 counties surrounding the Hanford nuclear weapons plant here absorbed ''significant'' amounts of radiation in three years ending December 1947, a panel of radiation and health experts said in a report released today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: At Lincoln Center, Festival Where Fun Is Serious Business
description: IN ''You Could Be Home Now,'' the solo piece by Ann Magnuson to open Lincoln Center's fourth annual Serious Fun festival at 7:30 tonight, this film actress (''Making Mr. Right'') and television performer (''Anything but Love'') is returning to the performance-art medium in which she made her reputation as an underground nightclub star.

title: Jogger Defense Case: Scattershot Approach
description: Halfway through the trial of three teen-agers accused of beating and raping the woman most New Yorkers know only as ''the jogger,'' the defense lawyers have been notable mostly for what they have not done.

title: In Coal Fields of Siberia, Memories of a Promise
description: ''What kind of masters are we?'' asked the miner, gray and lean and angry in his ebony moonscape of a workplace here in the rebellious coal fields of Siberia.

title: Hyannis Journal;   Rose Kennedy at 100: Still Very Much Rose
description: On Sunday, after Mass in her rambling seaside home here, Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy was sitting on the porch with her daughter Eunice Shriver and her grandson Robert Shriver.

title: P.L.O. Sets Condition on Sea Raiders
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization is prepared to discipline the group that attempted in May to attack Israel from the Mediterranean, once the United States agrees to resume and expand its discussion with the P.L.O , leaders of the organization say.

title: Manila Tourist Areas Hit by 6 Bomb Blasts
description: Six bombs exploded simultaneously before dawn today in the city's main tourist and financial districts, damaging several cars and buildings but causing no casualties, the police said.

title: Vacation Spa Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $666,000, or 4 cents a share. Share earnings for the latest and year-ago 9 months reflected preferred stock dividend of $525,000 in each period.

title: G.M.A.C. Prices A Note Offering
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is offering $200 million in senior notes due in 2005 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Market Place;   The New Charges Against Blinder
description: New charges filed yesterday against Blinder, Robinson & Company provided an unusual insight into the way the once high-flying firm became the nation's largest ''penny stock'' broker.

title: Wicat Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
CHRONICLE
description: For 10 years, the New York Public Library has bestowed its Literary Lions awards on contemporary writers, men and women whose works range from the urban sociology of Tom Wolfe to history in the making by Henry A. Kissinger or the novels of Toni Morrison and the plays of Edward Albee. Many of the 200 award recipients will be honored at the library on Nov. 8, at a dinner to raise money to buy books. BARBARA BUSH is the honorary chairwoman, but the work of preparation will be done by the three new co-chairwomen of the Literary Lions, MERCEDES BASS , ANN GETTY and ANNE MARION .

title: 2 Books By Rushdie Are Sold
description: Penguin U.S.A. and Granta Books of Britain announced yesterday that they had purchased the next two books of Salman Rushdie, the writer whose last novel led Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to say he should be killed.

title: Valero Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tolland Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: Dr. ARNOLD RELMAN , editor in chief of The New England Journal of Medicine, is to retire next June after 14 years at the helm of the prestigious chronicle of medical research. Dr. Relman, who is 67 years old, said he plans to write, teach and lecture. The weekly magazine is owned and published by the Massachusetts Medical Society, which is to form a committee to select a successor to Dr. Relman.

title: Kaydon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CNN Plans Experiment In 'Interactive News'
description: Cable News Network today announced the first experiment in ''interactive news'' by a national television network - a program similar to those run by smaller stations in which viewers vote on whether to see ''Godzilla'' or ''Planet of the Apes'' as the late-night movie.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: The Costs of Our Cold War Victory
description: LEAD: In 1947, George Kennan held out the hope that a policy of ''containing'' the spread of Communism, if it were vigorously pursued over several decades, would eventually lead to the ''break-up or the gradual mellowing of Soviet power.'' Today the mellowing or break-up of Soviet power is taking place before our eyes.

title: INSIDE
description: Legal Battle Over Beard

title: Hawkins Loses Another No-Hitter, but Not His
description: The Yankees are learning to expect the unexpected whenever Andy Hawkins starts a game, and they got it for the third successive time last night. Melido Perez pitched a rain-shortened six-inning no-hitter against Hawkins and the Yankees and led the Chicago White Sox to an 8-0 victory at Yankee Stadium.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Harlin the Active

title: Pirates Edge Padres By 4-3 in 15th Inning
description: Jeff King's two-out single down the right-field line in the 15th inning ended a bullpen duel and gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory tonight over San Diego, spoiling the debut of the new Padres manager, Greg Riddoch.

title: Sudan Forces Refugees Back to Barren Lands
description: In a new tactic in the seven-year Sudanese civil war, the Khartoum Government is forcing tens of thousands of refugees who fled to Khartoum from the south to return home, further straining food supplies in the famine-struck region, relief workers and village chiefs here say.

title: Liberian Army's 'Reign of Terror' Protested by U.S. and Other Embassies
description: What many residents of this city call a ''reign of terror'' by Government troops against unarmed civilians thought to sympathize with rebels in this country's six-month-old civil war has worsened in recent weeks, diplomats and Liberian and foreign journalists say, prompting several embassies to file official protests.

title: Investors Warned on Global Frauds
description: Small investors were defrauded of $1.1 billion in the last two years through international investment swindles, the North American Securities Administrators Association told a Congressional committee yesterday.

title: In Washington, a Battle About a Prosecutor
description: An attempt by Democrats to have an independent prosecutor appointed in the Neil Bush case brought an angry denunciation from Republicans today as the political battle over the nation's savings and loan debacle escalated.

title: Raritan Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Anthem Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mcorp Bank Sale
description: Mcorp agreed to sell its interest in Mbank Waco for an undisclosed amount to a private investment group led by Gerald J. Ford, chairman and chief executive of the Ford Bank Group in Lubbock, Tex. Mcorp said it expects to complete the sale, subject to regulatory and bankruptcy court approvals, before Dec. 1. Mcorp has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings since March 1989. Mcorp said it had also agreed to sell Mbanks in El Paso, Corpus Christi and Brownsville, but it did not name the buyers.

title: Hubco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Political Memo;   Goals Similar, but Florio and Cuomo Split on Strategy
description: Not long into their respective tenures as Governors of New York and New Jersey, Mario M. Cuomo and Jim Florio each audaciously expressed political philosophies of unapologetic liberalism.

title: Bacteria Role Is Hailed in Gulf Oil Cleanup
description: Texas officials said today that preliminary results on using bacteria to clean up an oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico were ''very encouraging.''

title: Cuomo to Move His Own Funds Over Apartheid
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who for years has berated Republicans for blocking his efforts to rid New York State of any possible links to South Africa, announced tonight that he was withdrawing his own money from two financial institutions that have been made targets by a prominent anti-apartheid group.

title: Six Nights for Sampling A World of Unsung Bands
description: IN the next six days, 400 bands from around the world will pile into Manhattan as part of this year's New Music Seminar, an annual music-industry convention. More than 30 nightclubs will overflow with the sounds of Spanish flamenco, Swedish hard-core, British hip-hop and industrial disco, German heavy metal and New York noise rock. Most of these bands will perform for little or no money in return for the chance to be seen in performance by the seminar's 8,000 registrants - record company executives, booking agents and other members of the music industry who have convened to promote their clients and seek out new talent.

title: From Bad to Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Graf's Toughest Foe: the Press
description: In past years she has left Wimbledon as a proud champion and been celebrated as a role model at home in West Germany. But last week Steffi Graf departed from London a deeply troubled young woman.

title: First Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank said the second quarter of 1990 included an after-tax gain of $7 million from the divestiture of 13 branches in Florida. The impact of the gain was offset by the addition of an equivalent amount to the unallocated portion of the allowance for loan losses. The second quarter of 1989 included after-tax gains of $2 million from the sale of investment securities. Year-ago 6-month included after- tax gains of $6 million primarily from the sale of mortgage servicing rights.

title: A. J. Talks Speed, Cars And Drivers
description: A. J. Foyt has had a few cars that conked out, sometimes at Indianapolis or Daytona. He's also been in a few that crashed.

title: Today Home Entertainment reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Disney Tells Mowgli's Tales
description: Its setting notwithstanding, ''The Jungle Book'' presents Walt Disney-style animation at its most urbane. First released in 1967 and last shown theatrically in 1984, this full-length animated feature, which opens nationwide today, has a droll wit guaranteed to keep parents as well entertained as their children. Surely this is the only Disney film in which the scathing and debonair George Sanders could have made so perfect and appropriate a villain.

title: Argonaut Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Current-year gains resulted primarily from the sale of investments in Earle M. Jorgensen Co. in response to a tender offer.

title: Farm House Foods reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $10,006,000 for the latest year and $9,696,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Review/Art;   Plaster as a Medium, Not Just an Interim Step
description: ''The Expressionist Surface: Contemporary Art in Plaster,'' at the Queens Museum, calls attention to the current prominence of plaster. With its modeled, carved, cast and rolled plaster, with its plaster boulders, tapestries, mannequins and horses, the exhibition suggests the many ways the material is now being used in sculpture, painting and installations. It also suggests why plaster can arouse strong feelings of affection and distaste.

title: Weekend Subway Disruptions
description: Beginning tomorrow, service on the N and R line will be disrupted for reparis for seven consecutive weekends. From 12:01 A.M. Saturday until 5 A.M. Monday, there will be no N or R service between 42d Street-Times Square and Queens Plaza and Queensboro Plaza. Work will continue through Aug. 27.

title: Liberty National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Farm Trade Discussed
description: Negotiators began discussing a compromise plan today to cut subsidies in world farm trade, a proposal that leaders of the world's richest industrial democracies backed at their economic summit meeting in Houston this week.

title: Marc Haas, Philatelist, Dies at 82; His Collection Netted $11 Million
description: Marc Haas, a philatelist and business executive, died on Sunday at his home in Burgenstock, Switzerland. He was 82 years old and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: A Clowning Bank-Robbery Caper
description: ''What kind of clown are you?'' a bank guard snarls at a man in a circus costume, who has wedged one giant red shoe in the door at closing time. Beneath his painted smile, Bill Murray assumes the most serious, sincere expression and answers sweetly, ''The crying-on-the-inside kind, I guess.''

title: Total System Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 New York Officials Attack Phone Request
description: Two senior state officials yesterday strongly criticized a $1.4 billion rate increase sought by the New York Telephone Company, and said that the New York Public Service Commission should reverse its decision to allow the company to choose what information in the rate increase request is labeled a trade secret and sealed.

title: Casino Revenues Rise
description: Revenues at Atlantic City's casinos rose 13.3 percent in June from a year earlier, helped by the $34.8 million net ''win'' reported at Donald J. Trump's new Taj Mahal casino, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission said today. Gaming revenues amounted to $258.5 million in the month, but only four casinos had higher winnings than in June 1989. Revenues at both the Trump Plaza and Trump's Castle declined.

title: Neworld Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Scientific Measurement SysFtems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Wayne J. Turnage, 47, An Operatic Baritone
description: Wayne Jackson Turnage, a baritone who sang with the Washington Opera and Opera Ebony, died at his home in New York on Monday after a long illness. He was 47 years old.

title: Patriots Reject Collins
description: The New England Patriots have told Tony Collins he doesn't fit into their future.

title: ACC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter revenue included $97,620 from Danbury Cellular Telephone Co. for business segement discontinued during the quarter; year-ago 6-month revenue included $1,975,873 from Danbury Cellular Telephone Co.

title: Space Program Builds America's Future;   Big-Science Bubble
description: To the Editor:

title: Marvin S. Pittler, Executive, 61
description: Marvin S. Pittler, vice president of manufacturing research for I.B.M. Research, died on Wednesday at his office in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The cause of death apparently was a heart attack, a spokesman for the company said.

title: Exabyte Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $34,000 for the quarter and $1,250,000, or 7 cents a share for the 6 months.

title: Nova Scotia Issue
description: A $300 million debenture issue by Nova Scotia was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 9.375 percent debentures due to mature in 2002 are offered at 99.36 percent to yield 9.465 percent, or about 95 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The notes, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

title: On Stage
description: Holmes's 'Swing'

title: Synovus Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Merchants Bancshares Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Presents Anti-Drug Curriculum for Schools
description: The Department of Education today issued a detailed program for drug prevention lessons that it will send to more than 120,000 school administrators across the country, in an effort to teach children skills for resisting drug use.

title: Filling In Pompeii Gaps by Computer
description: During the 242 years since their discovery, the ruins of Pompeii have been excavated, studied, looted, sold, admired and exhibited, and one might wonder whether the ancient Roman port could still harbor any surprises. But an exhibition that opened this week at the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art demonstrates that the appeal of Pompeii is as fresh and compelling as ever.

title: CPC International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Jazz;   From Ragged Rawness to Breathiness
description: The tenor saxophonist and composer Benny Golson, who started a six-night stand at Condon's on Tuesday night, likes to make connections. Mr. Golson's tone moves from the jagged rawness of Ben Webster to Lester Young's breathiness, but it's accompanied by an utterly contemporary harmonic sensibility. Not only is he a master of finessing a tune's harmony, where chords are subtly altered or substituted for one another, but he's more than willing to bull his way through a tune as well, taking a melodic motif and superimposing it over any unsuspecting chord that comes along.

title: Semiconductor Panel Backs Added Sematech Financing
description: The chairman of the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors said today that the committee still supported an increase in financing for Sematech, the semiconductor industry consortium.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Eating Outdoors

title: People
description: * Larry Weisberg has been appointed senior vice president for account services at Waring & LaRosa.

title: William M. Weil, Manufacturer, 89
description: William M. Weil, a retired manufacturer of specialized lighting, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Books of The Times;   Impoverished Woman Claws Her Way Back Up
description: The Lady of Situations

title: A.O. Smith Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Costly Proposals to Curb Asbestos Ignite New York City Debate
description: Proposals aimed at reducing the threat of airborne asbestos in buildings have set off a furious debate in New York City, which already has some of the toughest asbestos regulations in the country.

title: Drunken Flying Persists Despite Treatment Effort
description: Bruce K. is a pilot who flies Boeing 727 jetliners for a major airline. He is also a recovering alcoholic.

title: Sears Expects Steep Drop In Second-Quarter Profits
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it expects a sharp decline in second-quarter earnings because its Allstate Insurance group's catastrophe-related losses exceeded expectations and sales by the merchandise group were disappointing.

title: Congress Is Close to Regulating Price of Basic Cable TV Service
description: Pressed by widespread public anger over steep rate increases for cable television service, Congress is close to imposing modest controls over prices. But disputes over proposals aimed at fostering competition could derail the legislation and leave the industry a winner by default.

title: Semen Tested in Jogger Case Was Not That of Defendants
description: A scientific expert from the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified yesterday that a DNA analysis of semen found in the jogger in Central Park did not match any defendants charged with her rape and attempted murder.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A co-star of the television comedy ''Cheers,'' KELSEY GRAMMER, has been ordered to stand trial in Van Nuys, Calif., on a cocaine possession charge after failing to enter a drug-treatment program.

title: In Canada, an Environmental Disaster Looms;   Missed Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: A rare bas mitzvah will take place today in the eastern Chinese city of Kaifeng in Henan Province. YILING LIVIA CHEN-JOSEPHSON, a young New Yorker who is the daughter of a Chinese mother and a Jewish father, is scheduled to read from the Torah in a Kaifeng museum and to complete the ancient coming-of-age ritual with a few words of recently learned Chinese.

title: Evolution in Europe;   20,000 in Bucharest Demand Release of Student
description: More than 20,000 people gathered outside government buildings in Bucharest today in the biggest opposition protest since the December uprising that ousted Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator.

title: British Inflation at 9.8%
description: Britain's inflation rate, among the highest in the industrial world, climbed again in June, reaching an eight-year high of 9.8 percent, the Government said today. The increase in the retail price index, from 9.7 percent in May, was slightly below economists' forecasts. But the underlying rate of inflation, which excludes home loans and the poll tax, fell to 6.9 percent, from 7 percent in May, the Central Statistical Office said. Britain uses the underlying rate when it compares its inflation with those of other European countries, since other countries tend to exclude taxation and home loans from their figures.

title: Confident Ribbs Is Riding High
description: Sometime during the Indy-car race through the streets of Detroit on June 17, Willy T. Ribbs had the rush of self-confidence that drivers say makes racing so addictive.

title: Review/Dance;   An Odile as Harridan
description: Lyudmila Semenyaka, the best known of the Bolshoi Ballet's current crop of visiting ballerinas, can do better than the ''Swan Lake'' she proffered with alternating casualness and intensity on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Adiey, Deux Chevaux
description: This is a tough summer for the French. Bad enough that a reunited Germany will put an end to French aspirations to the leadership of Europe. Bad enough that the English are buying up half the Normandy and Brittany coasts as summer homes. But now, the truly inconceivable has happened: Citroen has announced that, after 43 years, the last Deux Chevaux will roll off the final remaining production line, in Portugal, at the end of the month.

title: Yes to Yeltsin on Pluralism, at Least
description: Mikhail Gorbachev remains hopeful that the Communist Party, still the only nationwide political force, provides the best vehicle for reforming the Soviet Union. Boris Yeltsin, arguing that hard-liners who still dominate party ranks are unreformable, now abandons the party to take a different path to radical change.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about an exhibition of art labeled ''degenerate'' by the Nazis misstated the dates. The show, ''1937: Modern Art and Politics in Prewar Germany,'' will be at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art from Feb. 17 to May 12, 1991, and at the Art Institute of Chicago from June 20 to Sept. 8, 1991.

title: A Douglas Counterpunch
description: The heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, did not get much time on the witness stand yesterday to respond to the testimony of his promoter, Don King, but he got his licks in as he left Room 443 at United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: Santucci to Go To Italy in Battle Over a Slaying
description: Ten years ago, a Queens restaurant owner named Jimmy Yu was shot and killed by a young holdup man who fled the eating place in Rego Park. Within weeks the police identified a 17-year-old resident alien from Italy, Anthony Sciacca of Queens, as the gunman.

title: Robert McKay, 70, Legal Scholar Who Led 1971 Attica Panel, Dies
description: Robert B. McKay, a former dean of the New York University Law School who led the New York State commission that investigated the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died yesterday morning in Reno, where he was to address the National Judicial College. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Contel Stock Gains Illegal, S.E.C. Says
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that illegal profits of at least $1 million were obtained from a sophisticated insider trading scheme in the stock and options of the Contel Corporation shortly before the company announced Thursday that it would be bought by the GTE Corporation.

title: McDonnell Stock Climbs on Rumors
description: The stock of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation moved higher today amid rumors and speculation about the struggling military contractor's future. McDonnell Douglas's shares rose $1.25 each, to $44.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pirates Extend Lead to Two Games
description: Pittsburgh turned a suicide-squeeze bunt and a hit-and-run single into two runs to back Doug Drabek's strong pitching as the Pirates beat the San Diego Padres, 4-1, tonight for their ninth victory in 11 games.

title: Pharmacists Can Spot Adverse Drug Reactions
description: To the Editor:

title: Fake Car-Inspection Stickers Spreading
description: Hundreds of counterfeit car-inspection stickers are turning up on cars in suburban New York counties in what motor-vehicle officials say is the largest such scheme they have seen.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about the discovery of a gene that causes a nervous system disease was mislabeled by The Associated Press and published in error in some copies.

title: Strain on Ethiopian City: Stranded Jews
description: Zewdu Sahelu, a 55-year-old Ethiopian Jew who has never been to school and can neither read nor write, arrived in the capital here two months ago from his farm, expecting to go to Israel.

title: New Push For Adjusting Of Census
