description: Mayor David N. Dinkins and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York stepped up their criticism of the Census Bureau today, charging that the accuracy of the 1990 census was imperiled by the agency's reluctance to correct its tally to make up for millions of uncounted Americans.

title: Beach Towel Wins by Nose In Rally at Meadowlands
description: Beach Towel rallied midway through the stretch tonight and captured the $1,153,500 Meadowlands Pace by a nose over Jake and Elwood.

title: Barry Prosecutors Close to Completing Case
description: After 19 days of testimony from 22 witnesses, the prosecution in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial announced today that it had almost completed its case.

title: Evolution in Europe;   To Albanians, 'Ciao Italia!' Means Haven
description: Tattered, penniless and weary, but jubilant just the same, thousands of Albanian refugees sailed today into Western Europe and, they were certain, to a better life.

title: Dead Batteries That Start
description: Recharging a dead automobile battery can now be as easy as flipping a switch.

title: Castle & Cooke
description: The shares of Castle & Cooke Inc. soared today in anticipation that the company would get a good price for its Dole Food Company unit. Castle & Cooke said late Thursday that it had been reached by several companies that wanted to buy Dole. Castle & Cooke's shares jumped $6 each today, to $36.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 19.7 percent gain was the second best of the day. Analysts said potential buyers for Dole included the Philip Morris Companies and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.

title: Deal Is Set For L.I. Papers
description: The former owner of Chanry Communications, a financially troubled chain of free weekly newspapers on Long Island, has agreed in principle to buy back the chain from E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company.

title: Mets Tell Strawberry Contract Talks Are Off
description: The Mets, conceding that they ran the enormous risk of losing their marquee player and facing a severe public backlash next fall, said today that they had broken off contract negotiations with Darryl Strawberry because of a ''huge gulf'' and would not resume them until the end of the season.

title: Report Urges Cutting New York Telephone Rates
description: The staff of the state's utility regulating board recommended today that a rate increase sought by New York Telephone be denied and the company be forced to cut its rates instead.

title: Books of The Times;   Israel's Master Spies: A Legend, With Lapses
description: Every Spy a Prince

title: Vikings' Browner Signs
description: Joey Browner, a strong safety for the Minnesota Vikings who has played in the last five Pro Bowls, has signed three one-year contracts.

title: Patents;   Third Company Offers Laser Eye Procedure
description: Just as a resolution appeared at hand in a bitter patent battle over a promising laser technology to correct near-sightedness and far-sightedness, a new complication arose this week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The late JOHN T. DORRANCE JR., the patriarch of the family that owns the majority interest in the Campbell Soup Company, left almost $30 million to each of his six grandchildren, who range in age from 5 to 18, according to his will, which was filed Wednesday in the Montgomery County Court in Norristown, Pa.

title: Technical Innovators Don't Start With Math
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents;   No Drill, No Novocain In Laser Dental System
description: American Dental Laser Inc. of Birmingham, Mich., obtained a patent this week on a laser system to remove tooth and gum decay without the need for drills, scrapers or even Novocain.

title: Letter: On Mega-Science;   'Big' Research Honors Human Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberian Disaster: Made in the U.S.A.
description: LEAD: The State Department often refers to a ''special relationship'' between Liberia and the U.S., even though it has been decidedly one-sided, to our advantage. What's really special about Liberia is U.S. strategic interests there. That is Washington's main concern and why, through the 10 years of the

title: Courtnall to Blues
description: The St. Louis Blues continued rebuilding yesterday, trading a center, Peter Zezel, and a defenseman, Mike Lalor, to the Capitals for Geoff Courtnall, a left wing. The deal came 12 hours after the Blues acquired Scott Stevens, a free-agent defenseman, from the Capitals. (AP)

title: Red Wings Replace Demers With Murray
description: Jacques Demers, who guided the Detroit Red Wings to the playoffs for three consecutive seasons before the team missed out last season with a 28-38-14 record, was dismissed as head coach yesterday. He was replaced by the former coach of the Washington Capitals, Bryan Murray, who will also be general manager.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the introduction to a table on Thursday listing the assets of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York characterized it incompletely. It showed assets of Mr. Cuomo's wife, Matilda, along with his.

title: Protester Told to Leave Site of King's Death
description: A woman who has engaged in a protest for the last two years by camping in front of the motel where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. died was ordered by a judge today to get out of the way of workers building a museum there.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Prague Will Pull Some Citizens From Cuba
description: Czechoslovakia is to evacuate its women and children living in Cuba as a diplomatic dispute with Havana worsens, Prague television reported today.

title: At Eastern, Optimism Despite a Glum Report
description: ''Worse in the near term, better in the long term.''

title: Bahamas Facing More Questions As It Buries 39 Drowned Haitians
description: Thirty-nine Haitians fleeing their impoverished Caribbean island drowned when their sailboat capsized and sank in choppy seas while being towed by Bahamian authorities, Government officials said.

title: The People Threat
description: Lucien Paye, head of the O.E.C.D., which groups 24 industrialized countries, was asked what worried him most on the horizon. U.S. budget and trade deficits? Protectionism? Recession?

title: Evolution in Europe;   Lower House in Poland Approves Bill to Make Citizens Stockholders
description: Parliament's lower house today approved a plan that would give every citizen a share in any of several thousand companies now owned by the state.

title: Sanders Back for Now
description: After being recalled from the Yankees' Class AAA Columbus farm club for the second time this season, Deion Sanders might be thinking about changing his nickname from Prime Time to Yo-Yo. But one thing the 22-year-old outfielder says he doesn't want to think about right now is his other athletic career, playing in the National Football League as a cornerback for the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Still Excluded After All These Years
description: Twenty summers after his book ''Ball Four'' was supposed to have destroyed the game of baseball as we know it, the leading pitcher of the Little Ferry Giants of the New Jersey Metropolitan League sat in his office and thought about his distinction in the history of the New York Yankees.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Text of Statement by Two Soviet Officials
description: Following is the text of the statement by Gavriil K. Popov, the City Council chief in Moscow, and Anatoly A. Sobchak, his counterpart in Leningrad, announcing their decision to quit the Communist Party, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Soccer's Disease: Commercialism
description: LEAD: The U.S. will host the 1994 soccer World Cup and is dreading it.

title: Evolution in Europe;   2 TOP CITY CHIEFS QUIT SOVIET PARTY AS CONGRESS ENDS
description: The Communist Party suffered additional major defections today as the Moscow and Leningrad City Council leaders quit the party and insurgent forces began moving slowly toward forming a national opposition coalition.

title: Genentech Net Off 45%
description: Genentech Inc. today reported sharply lower earnings for the second quarter because of expenses related to its planned merger with Roche Holdings Inc. It also told of a weakening in sales of its heart-attack drug, tissue plasminogen activator, possibly because of mounting competition.

title: General Instrument Up As New Interest Arises
description: The shares of the General Instrument Corporation rose today on the expectation that a new offer might arise to top the friendly bid of $1.6 billion made earlier this month by Forstmann Little & Company.

title: Cambrex-Cyanmid
description: The Cambrex Corporation, a chemical maker, said it planned to buy a large part of the American Cyanamid Company's textile chemicals business, including manufacturing plants in Charlotte, N.C., for undisclosed terms. It also said it intended to make the purchase through a new company in which Cambrex would have a majority interest. Cambrex, based in Bayonne, N.J., said it expected to complete the deal within 90 days.

title: Hooker Corp. Ex-Chief
description: The former head of the Hooker Corporation, the collapsed retailing concern, and his wife have declared bankruptcy, citing debts of nearly $400 million. George and Sheila Herscu filed debtors' petitions in the Federal court at Melbourne on Monday, which the court accepted. The Hooker Corporation was placed in receivership a year ago with debts of about $1.6 billion.

title: Airbus Industrie
description: Airbus Industrie declined to comment on a French newspaper report that the European aircraft consortium had sharply cut its losses in 1989. Airbus would say only that it expected to break even sooner than originally forecast. Quoting sources in the industry, La Tribune de l'Expansion, a Paris daily, reported that Airbus had cut its losses to $150 million last year, from $508 million in 1988. An Airbus spokesman would not comment on the estimates but said after the heavy outlay to build new aircraft, prospects looked good for the consortium.

title: Mercedes-Benz In Union Talks
description: A spokesman for Mercedes-Benz A.G. said today that the company was negotiating with unions to add special shifts at its factories to help meet rising demand from East Germany and elsewhere.

title: Dow Breaks 3,000 but Ends at 2,980.20
description: Amid signs that the Federal Reserve had acted to lower interest rates, the Dow Jones industrial average briefly broke through the magical 3,000 barrier yesterday.

title: Paul Laurent, French Communist, 65
description: Paul Laurent, a senior official of the French Communist Party, died of cancer on Sunday. He was 65 years old.

title: Three Indian Ministers Resign
description: Three ministers resigned from the Indian Cabinet on Friday, threatening the survival of Prime Minister V. P. Singh's coalition Government, an aide to a minister said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Robert N. Timmins, 60, An Investment Banker
description: Robert Nelson Timmins, a New York investment banker, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bancorp Hawaii Inc., Honolulu, said it would acquire FirstFed America Inc., Honolulu, a savings and loan holding company, and its units.

title: Chinese Dissident to Study in U.S. (and to Speak Out)
description: Fang Lizhi, China's most prominent dissident, said today that he planned to study in the United States for at least six months beginning in January. He also said that while he was there he would meet with exiled Chinese dissidents and speak out against his country's Government.

title: Baseball;   Steinbrenner Legal Strategy: Baseball Inquiry Was Unfair
description: Apparently concerned that he will receive a lengthy suspension from baseball, George Steinbrenner is preparing a legal attack based on the assertion that baseball's investigation of him was biased.

title: Arizona Court Says Mecham Can Run Again
description: The Arizona Supreme Court has unanimously ruled that former Gov. Evan Mecham can run for governor this fall despite his being impeached and removed from the office in 1988.

title: Concerns Grow About Marketing of Medical Alert Systems
description: The growing use of personal emergency-alert systems, devices of potential benefit to millions of older people, is giving unscrupulous businesses a chance to prey on some of the nation's most vulnerable consumers.

title: John F. Middlemiss, Lawyer, 91
description: Prof. John F. Middlemiss, a lawyer in Brooklyn and a retired law professor, died on Thursday at the home of a daughter, Nancy Palmer, in Fairfield, Conn., where he celebrated his 91st birthday on Sunday.

title: Manley Beasley, Evangelist, 58
description: The Rev. Manley Beasley, a prominent Southern Baptist evangelist who did not allow a longtime kidney ailment to keep him away from the pulpit, died of kidney disease on Monday in a hospital in Dallas. He was 58 years old.

title: Bail Denied for Dart-Case Suspect; His Lawyer Calls Evidence Flimsy
description: A lawyer for a Bronx man accused of blowing homemade darts at women said yesterday that the evidence against his client is flimsy and the charges motivated by the publicity surrounding the attacks.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Stung by Denial of Western Aid, Romanian Officials Say Aim Is Democracy
description: Stung by a decision last week by 24 Western nations to deny economic aid to Romania, Government officials here assert that this punishment was mistaken and that it will help keep Romanians impoverished while hurting the nation's efforts to set up a market economy.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Kohl Will Meet Gorbachev Today in Moscow on Unity
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will fly to Moscow late Saturday for some personal diplomacy with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hoping to convince the Soviet leader to drop his remaining objections to German unification within NATO, West German officials said today.

title: Democrats Retreating On Inquiry
description: Democratic leaders pounded the Republicans over the savings and loan scandal today. But the attempt to compel the Attorney General to consider appointing an independent prosecutor in the case of Neil Bush appeared to founder as Republican leaders threatened to retaliate by seeking an outside prosecutor to look into the actions of former Democratic leaders.

title: Yankees Get Hits but No Victory
description: Steve Sax got a couple of hits: a double and a single. Steve Balboni got a couple of hits: a single and his eighth home run of the season, a bases-empty shot in the fourth inning. Nobody on the White Sox got more than one hit, but that didn't stop Chicago from beating the Yankees, 3-2, at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Patents;   Using a Gene To Prevent Crop Spoilage
description: A biotechnology company in New Jersey won a patent this week for a method of preventing fruits and vegetables from spoiling by using genetic engineering to enhance their natural defenses against fungus.

title: Earl Stewart, Golf Coach, 68
description: Earl Stewart, who won two events on the PGA Tour and coached golf for 13 years at Southern Methodist University, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Remarks on Germany Prompt Tory Upheaval
description: Anti-German remarks by one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's closest Cabinet allies has plunged her Government into crisis and forced its deep divisions over the European Community into the open.

title: Mary B. Joy, Volunteer, 82
description: Mary B. Joy, a former official with the American Association of University Women who was also active in many other civic organizations, died on Wednesday at her home in Morris Township, N.J. She was 82 years old and died of congestive heart failure, her husband, Homer, said.

title: Starrett City Keeps Apartments Vacant Despite Waiting List
description: In the 20 months since the United States Supreme Court outlawed racial quotas that favored white applicants to the huge Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn, the black and Hispanic families who had sought apartments for years have remained stuck on a long waiting list.

title: Rain Strands 102 at the Women's Open
description: Any complaints that the United States Women's Open was being played under conditions that were too easy came to an abrupt halt today as the field sloshed around a waterlogged golf course in the midst of waiting out three rain delays.

title: Rights Bill for Disabled Is Sent to Bush
description: The Senate today completed Congressional action on a far-reaching bill to bar discrimination against people with physical and mental disabilities.

title: Westinghouse Profit Up 10.5%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said on Thursday that its net income increased 10.5 percent in the second quarter as broadcasting revenue and operating profit grew.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY, 14, 1990
description: Markets

title: Phillips Plan on Stock
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said on Thursday that its employee stock ownership plan would borrow about $400 million to buy about 15 million new common shares from Phillips.

title: Nunn Panel Cuts Pentagon $18 Billion
description: In the first Congressional action on the 1991 military budget, a Senate committee today approved a plan to cut $18 billion from the Bush Administration's proposal, and called for sharp troop reductions in Europe and cuts in the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.

title: Producer Prices Up Modest 0.2%
description: In a mixed reading on inflation, the Labor Department reported today that prices at the producer level rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in June but would have climbed much more without continued declines for energy and food.

title: Control Shift At Gallimard
description: In a decision that would remove France's leading independent book publishing company from family control, Francoise Gallimard has agreed to sell her 12.5 percent stake in Editions Gallimard to the Banque Nationale de Paris.

title: Wiper Inventor Awarded $5 Million
description: An inventor who spent more than a decade in court trying to win payments from auto makers for patents on the intermittent windshield wiper was awarded more than $5 million today against the Ford Motor Company.

title: Hopes Rise on Fixing Shuttle Leaks So the Fleet Can Resume Flying
description: The hydrogen fuel leaks on two space shuttles appear to stem from two entirely different problems in the fuel line, and space agency officials said today that the leaks should be relatively simple to fix so that the shuttle fleet can resume flying soon.

title: Review/Music;   Venerable Hanoverians Make New York Debut
description: The Niedersachsisches Staatsorchester - or Lower Saxony State Orchestra - from Hanover, West Germany, traces its history to 1636, the year Duke George of Calenberg established his residence in the city. That would make the orchestra 354 years old, 88 years younger than the Dresden Staatskapelle, and 107 years older than the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, two of Europe's better-known Methuselan ensembles.

title: Review/Music;   Against All Odds: A 'Village' Festival
description: For sheer feistiness, few classical-music series rival the Washington Square Music Festival, which has stood up to the vicissitudes of its Greenwich Village surroundings for more than three decades. In recent years, with the park overrun by successive drug cultures, the setting has often seemed unwelcoming, if not actively hostile. And now financial problems have arisen. The concerts are free, and grants for this year's programs reportedly failed to meet expectations, so even before the first concert, the festival announced the cancellation of the last, on Aug. 7.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   For Summer Driving
description: Automobile experts warn that if your car is not properly maintained in summer, a vacation could come to an unexpected stop. Make sure that lights, brakes and wipers are in good condition. The Automobile Club of New York says that a car's engine should always be properly tuned, and it suggests that the following items be checked before any warm-weather trip.

title: About New York;   Not Just Mortar Holds Together Church's Stones
description: Eddie Pizzaro grew up poor in Spanish Harlem. His father abused drugs, went to jail every so often and beat his precious mother in front of him. Out on the ragged streets, friend after friend seemed to fall inexorably into similar dismal traps.

title: New York City School Board Shifts Application Costs to Teachers
description: The New York City Board of Education, which until this month absorbed the full cost of substitute-teacher applications and most costs for prospective full-time teachers, has begun charging all applicants $104 in fees.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to change my life. I want to lead a better life. I don't want Communism.'' - Eno Vaso, an Albanian who fled to Italy. [5:5.]

title: The Right Role for the School Board
description: New York City's school system is at a critical point of transition. A new Board of Education, headed by Dr. Gwendolyn Baker, is about to begin what could be a constructive or destructive relationship with Chancellor Joseph Fernandez. Mr. Fernandez has made an impressive start in his first seven months on the job. Unless it has powerful substantive objections, the right way for the board to use its new strength is to support him.

title: Intergroup Move By Centaur Fails
description: The Delaware Supreme Court ruled that the effort by Centaur Partners L.P. to expand the board of National Intergroup Inc. had failed. The parties said the court had upheld National Intergroup's position that Centaur's proposal to amend the company's bylaws to increase the size of the board to 15, an increase of three members, required approval of 80 percent of the outstanding shares. Centaur's solicitation fell short of the 80 percent vote, they said.

title: INSIDE
description: Disability Bill Is Cleared

title: KEY RATES
Herbert Gilman, 65, A Marketing Pioneer For Discount Stores
description: Herbert Gilman, a pioneer in discount merchandising and the former chief executive of Ames Department Stores Inc., died on Thursday at Hartford Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: Hall of Fame Adds 2
description: Joseph F. Cullman 3d, a leading organizer of women's professional tennis events, and Jan Kodes, one of the leading men's singles players of the early 1970's, will be inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I., today.

title: U.S. Policy on Cambodia Shifts a Bit
description: In a break from past policy of shunning the Cambodian Government, the Bush Administration announced today that it had accepted an offer by Phnom Penh to cooperate in examining what could be the remains of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War.

title: 800 Numbers Are on the Way, Budapest
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Review/Theater;   Pop Star as a Nontraditional Romeo
description: Lured by the pop-star glamour of Roland Gift, an unusually youthful theater audience swarmed through the Staller Center for the Arts at the State University here this evening for the first of five performances of Shakespeare's ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Oka Journal;   Mohawks Make a Point: They Are Distinct, Too
description: Lucy Gaspe gazed up St.-Michel Street, past a crowd of reporters and television crews, past knots of police officers with pump-action shotguns crouching behind a wall of sandbags, to a barricade of upturned police cars and a front-end loader at the crest of the hill.

title: Newman Signs Hornet Offer Sheet, Leaving Next Move to Knicks
description: Johnny Newman, the Knick small forward, signed a free-agent offer sheet with the Charlotte Hornets yesterday.

title: Inmate Executed in Alabama For 1976 Murder of Woman
description: A black man convicted of murder 12 years ago read a statement denouncing the death penalty as racist and then was strapped into Alabama's electric chair and executed early today.

title: Music Festival in Japan Takes a Leaf From Tanglewood's Own Best Seller
description: Michael Tilson Thomas, the principal conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra, had his arms tightly folded and his face twisted in a mild scowl the other day as he sat in a recital hall in the back woods of Hokkaido, Japan's northern-most island. ''The percussion must be much, much more after the third bar,'' he said emphatically, as his comments rippled in translation through a newly assembled orchestra of young music students from the Korean countryside, the west coast of South America and the urban tangle of Tokyo. ''Try it again.''

title: In Canada, an Environmental Disaster Looms
description: To the Editor:

title: Days of Fruit Tramp's Painful Harvest Fade
description: Luther Henry Tindal, who is 45 years old and looks 60, and his wife, Linda, 34, rest on a dust-caked couch outside their $125-a-month cinderblock shack here, smoking discount cigarettes and drinking discount beer.

title: Vehicle Sales Rose 2.5% in Early July
description: Helped by strong demand for light trucks from General Motors and Ford, sales of American-built vehicles rose 2.5 percent in early July, the industry's second consecutive 10-day period of healthy sales gains.

title: Schools Chief in Los Angeles Says He'll Leave Next Year
description: The Superintendent of Schools here announced Thursday that he would resign at the end of the next school year.

title: Neil Bush, Meet Mr. Kafka
description: A terrible thing is happening to President Bush's youngest son, Neil. He is in danger of being turned into a sound bite.

title: O'Neill Recalls Former Glories in Address to Party
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, making his final address at a state convention as Connecticut's chief executive, spoke tonight of Democrats' past glories but offered no detailed guidance to a party that he conceded is now badly fractured.

title: Focus of Bombing Inquiry Is Held Without Bail on Separate Charge
description: A Federal district judge today ordered that the man who has become the focus of an investigation into two fatal bombings in the Southeast last December be held without bail after his indictment earlier this week on unrelated charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: Louise A. Baum, Executive, 64
description: Louise A. Baum, president of the Eastern Bag & Paper Company of Bridgeport, Conn., died yesterday at her home in Fairfield, Conn. She was 64 years old.

title: Esther L. Brown, 92, Social Anthropologist
description: Esther Lucile Brown, an author, educator and social anthropologist whose contributions led to major changes in nursing education and practice, died July 6 at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco. She was 92 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Your Money;   A Foreign Twist In Fraud Schemes
description: State securities administrators said in Congressional testimony this week that American investors, lured by promises of guaranteed high returns overseas, were defrauded of at least $1.1 billion in the last two years.

title: Rates Fall On Moves By Fed
description: The Federal Reserve took steps yesterday that lowered interest rates, a day after the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan, suggested that lower rates might be needed to stimulate the economy and alleviate a tightening of credit by major banks.

title: Albany Decrees Medicaid Spending, and New York City Pays
description: To the Editor:

title: Strong Increase of 0.5% Shown in Retail Sales
description: Helped by strong department store sales, overall retail sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. It was the first increase since January.

title: Rikers Melee Leaves 87 With Injuries
description: At least 40 correction officers and 47 inmates were injured on Rikers Island yesterday when 48 Muslim prisoners seeking revenge for the slashing of their religious leader stormed the cell of his attacker, correction officials said.

title: Sandinista Democrats, Please Stand Up
description: If the Sandinistas think their influence in Nicaragua's army, police and unions entitles them to force the elected Government of President Violeta Chamorro to share power, they don't understand what democratic politics is all about.

title: Religion Notes
description: O'Connor and Rome There was a great deal of speculation last month when John Cardinal O'Connor abruptly left a spiritual retreat in California and got on a plane for Rome. He had arrived in California just the day before from New York in anticipation of spending a week with other bishops from around the nation.

title: Diaper Debate: Cloth or Disposable?
description: Disposable diapers have become a symbol of a throwaway society. They squander resources and clog scarce landfills. To be environmentally responsible, parents should use cloth diapers, which can be washed and re-used many times. Or should they? A study of the comprehensive environmental impact of both kinds of diapers, conducted for Procter & Gamble by a prominent consulting company, suggests that neither has a strong advantage. That conclusion has some support within the environmental community.

title: QUAYLE DEFENDS BUSH'S TAX STAND
description: Vice President Dan Quayle sought to reassure a nervous group of Republican leaders today that President Bush did not simply kick away one of their best campaign issues when he acknowledged last month that tax increases would be needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Public Library Reaps a Communist Harvest
description: The current records of today's events are the stuff that tomorrow's historians will reconstruct their yesterdays on. In the case of the Communist world, the documentation has until recently been almost exclusively official, tailored to administrative demands, and this is most of what the New York Public Library has been acquiring for decades from those regions.

title: Bridge
description: Two publishers on opposite sides of the Atlantic, Robert Hale in Britain and Dover in the United States, provide a useful service by reprinting major works of bridge literature that have long been out of print. Two of these, each with a transatlantic author-publisher combination, are worth noting.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With a Change in Doctors
description: When a personal doctor retires or dies, long-term patients confront two problems: finding another doctor and obtaining medical records.

title: Subway Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Viola Is Erratic and Reds Prove Exploitive
description: From the season's start, Frank Viola has insisted that he doesn't focus on his statistics, being, among other things, suspicious that he might get dizzy from any high opinion of himself that might result. Tonight, his numbers weren't anything to get dizzy about.

title: Greek Orthodox Group Backs Married Bishops
description: Representatives of the clergy and the laity of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Western hemisphere have recommended that the church allow married priests to become bishops. The proposal, which would alter 1,300 years of Eastern Orthodox practice, would require an unusual consensus among Orthodox Christian bishops.

title: Salazar Returning
description: The name of Alberto Salazar first blazed across the world distance-running scene in 1980, when Salazar won the first of three straight New York City Marathons and snapped Bill Rodgers's string of four. Now almost eight years after his last victory in that 26-mile-385-yard event, the 32-year-old Salazar is planning to return to running in the Big Apple after several years of injuries and operations. Salazar will run the 5,000 meters at the second New York Games on July 29, said Fred Lebow, the meet's executive director.

title: Havel: Prison for Journalists?
description: ''Where you stand depends upon where you sit'' is one of the oldest saws in politics. On no issue does this hold more than on the issue of free speech.

title: Renee Smith Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerson Smith of Margate, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Renee Smith and Allan Jeffrey Borkow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Borkow of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Ms. Smith, 27 years old, is a painter and print maker in New York. She is a graduate of Carnegie-Mellon University and earned a master's degree in fine arts at Columbia University. Mr. Borkow, 26, is an associate in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell. He is a cum laude graduate of Harvard University with a J.D. from Columbia, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone scholar.

title: Suit May Be Filed Over Hales Trophy
description: An attempt to claim a historic trophy for the fastest time under power across the Atlantic Ocean has produced a controversy that seeks to separate commerce from sport.

title: Andrettis in Front At Meadowlands
description: When it comes time to figure out the Andretti family legacy, one item in the inheritance will be a front-row starting spot at the Meadowlands Indy-car race.

title: Patriarch Reaches Out to Embrace Far-Flung Flocks in Orthodoxy
description: Within 24 hours of arriving in New York City, Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I of Constantinople, spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians, presided over two services aimed at healing centuries-old divisions among Eastern and Western Christians as well as more recent divisions in his own flock.

title: Fashion: On the Lawn;   Dressing For the Kids At a Benefit In Bellport
description: For the last decade, the turn-of-the-century charm of Bellport, L.I., has had a particular appeal to those in the fashion business. In that time, a generation of designers, retailers, photographers and publicists has discovered the quiet charm of this bayside village.

title: Review/Concert;   A Quartet Makes Musical Worlds Collide
description: Picture the Allman Brothers and Boccherini as opposite banks of a river made wide with the passage of time. For musicians to plant their feet comfortably on one shore and then the other requires an agility of mind and body, a faculty that the Boccherini Ensemble pursued with earnestness at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night.

title: Harpists Without Halos Test Their Wings
description: A determined group of younger musicians, mostly women, is scrambling to find ways to bring the harp into the late 20th century. For an instrument that numbers diminutive angels and a Marx brother among its best-known virtuosos, that is no easy or straightforward task. Some harpists are following the Swiss star Andreas Vollenweider into New Age washes. Others, like Zeena Parkins and Deborah Henson-Conant are looking to redefine the harp's very nature in post-Cagean fashion.

title: Miss Thornton To Be a Bride
description: August wedding plans for Suzanne Thornton and Thomas R. DeNunzio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Thornton of Barrington, N.H.

title: Glassy Skyscrapers And Other Villains Of the Movies
description: If there were an Oscar for the best architecture criticism in a movie, ''Gremlins 2: The New Batch'' would win hands down. Who could put Donald Trump in his place more deftly than Joe Dante, the director whose movie takes as its target a horrifyingly sleek and impersonal glass skyscraper built by a horrifyingly sleek and impersonal developer named Daniel Clamp? It's a lucky accident of timing that ''Gremlins 2'' came out just as Mr. Trump's money woes were hitting the headlines, though it could surely not have been an accident that this movie's modest plot includes an Other Woman named Marla.

title: Politics on TV: Too Fast, Too Loose?
description: It has taken a decade for the message to sink in, but the advertising industry has come to accept the fact that consumers do not receive information only from the usual sources - network television, newspapers and magazines. They are continuously bombarded with sights, sounds and sentence fragments, often unconsciously, as they drive by billboards, glance at T-shirt logos and open their mail. Effective communication, ad agencies understand, involves manipulating all these images.

title: Ms. Sadik-Kahn Weds Mark Geistfeld
description: Janette Sadik-Khan was married yesterday to Mark Geistfeld at the home of her father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Orhan I. Sadik-Khan, in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers, a Congregational minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. DAVID LEFFELL;

Caution Can Decrease Skin Cancer Risk
description: LEAD: SKIN cancers were once primarily a disease of the elderly, thought to be caused by years of sun exposure. Malignant melanoma, one of the most deadly forms of the disease, - was uncommon. Not so today. Doctors say that increasing numbers of people in their 30's and 40's, and some even younger, have skin cancer.

title: SHORTWAVE LINKS TRAVELERS TO WORD OF HOME
description: American tourists have always had a way of seeking out offbeat places. This summer they may roam even farther afield than before, as Eastern Europe seems increasingly congenial to visitors. So chances are that vacationers abroad may find themselves at some point a long way from the nearest newsstand that carries English-language papers. Even if they manage to make out what the local press says, the only item about America may be a snippet of Hollywood gossip at the bottom of an inside page.

title: Works in Progressf;   Glyph Erosion
description: Since its discovery in Luxor, Egypt, in 1904, the tomb of Nefertari, favored queen of Ramses II, has been valued for its wall paintings. Its glyphs and murals, dating from the 13th century B.C. and presenting the queen as an elaborately adorned woman of great elegance, are testimony to the penchant of Ramses II - and his gift - for monumental display.

title: College Students, at Least, Aren't Apathetic
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Carnegie-Mellon;   A Different Beat: When Bagpiping Becomes a Major
description: Carnegie-Mellon University has always marched to the beat of a different instrument. Bagpipers lead the school's kiltie band onto the football field, and they lead the graduating classes in their commencement processions.

title: Forecast For 'Today': Cloudy
description: Bill Carter's article about the ''Today'' show anchor Bryant Gumbel - and the contretemps swirling about him - was refreshingly evenhanded and temperate (''Forecast for 'Today': Cloudy,'' June 10). But could any of us measure up to the kind of intense scrutiny Gumbel has received?

title: Stacy Dutton to Wed Mark Cunneen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick G. Dutton of Washington have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Stacy Maria Dutton and Mark James Cunneen, a son of Elizabeth White Cunneen of Meriden, Conn., and Robert J. Cunneen of Phoenix.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: Should honorable, decent men who personify Yankee Tradition (Yogi Berra and Dick Howser) have suffered the indignity and humiliation of being dismissed?

title: Hampshire College
description: Brown quotes one Hampshire student who found students at the University of Massachusetts overly distracted with test scores (''It was like a big high school''). It is likely that this attitude is due less to a lack of talent and creativity among students at the state-run university than to a desire to one day find a good job.

title: R. D. Rudman Weds Karen Greenberg
description: Karen Sydney Greenberg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Greenberg of New York, was married last evening in New York to Richard David Rudman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Rudman of Milwaukee. Rabbi Miriam Shapero performed the ceremony at the Mark Hotel.

title: LeMond Breaks Free to Close Gap
description: Everybody expected the Tour de France to get off to a new beginning today, and it did as Erik Breukink and Greg LeMond went on a long breakaway and made up nearly five minutes of their deficit on the man in the yellow jersey, Claudio Chiappucci.

title: East's Archives Reveal Ties to Terrorists
description: With every passing day, disclosures from secret files of the former Communist governments in Eastern Europe show more clearly that well into the 1980's, they gave sanctuary to Middle Eastern and Western European terrorist groups that were attacking Western targets, despite official denials at the time.

title: GRANT IS AWARDED TO CURB DROPOUTS
description: Mount Holyoke College and the city of Holyoke, Mass., will open a new public middle school this fall that is intended to be a model for fighting rising dropout rates among urban youngsters, especially Hispanic students.

title: William F. Weigel, Lawyer, 66
description: William F. Weigel, a New York City lawyer and the former chairman of the Westchester County Republican Party, died on Friday morning at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Mr. Bush and America's Greens
description: President Bush's next summit meeting might well be a cozy little chat in the Oval Office with a handful of environmental leaders. There's much common ground between them. But one would never know that from the poisonous and sometimes silly rhetoric that filled the air during last week's economic summit meeting in Houston.

title: College Students, at Least, Aren't Apathetic;   Dark Clouds on Horizon
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Hedda' Wears Brain on Her Sleeve
description: ''HEDDA GABLER'' is 100 years old, but the tantalizing title character in Ibsen's classic of demented psychology remains a puzzlement. The prevailing perception of Hedda as predator, ''a hopeless specimen of degeneracy'' or merely ''mean'' was epitomized by Brooks Atkinson's pronouncement in 1936: ''In cold fact, she is the most hateful woman in dramatic literature.''

title: 'Romeo and Juliet': Words of Love
description: FOR the first production of his last season as artistic director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, Paul Barry has hauled out an inauspicious ''Romeo and Juliet.''

title: Eastern Is Expected to Face Criminal Charges
description: A Federal grand jury is preparing to file criminal charges against Eastern Airlines, accusing it of faulty maintenance practices at La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports in New York and Hartsfield International in Atlanta, lawyers involved in the investigation said yesterday.

title: Ejection for A-Train Vagrants Tonight
description: In a move opposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Transit Authority plans to make a concerted effort tonight to eject vagrants sleeping on the A train who prevent employees from cleaning subway cars.

title:
Style Makers;

Don Marshall;, Milliner
description: LEAD: When her family gathers today for a week-early celebration of her 100th birthday, Rose Kennedy will wear a new straw hat in a rose hue slightly darker than her linen dress. It was made by Don Marshall, her hat maker for the last 20 years.

title: In Besieged Liberian Capital, Hunger and Sleepless Nights
description: The danger peaks near dawn, said a man named Jenkins, when Government soldiers, sometimes wearing masks, stalk the gates in front of the makeshift refugee camp within the walls of the American Cooperative School.

title: Is Tonality Pie in the Sky Or Pie in the Face?
description: Nothing is harder to kill than a good myth. Beat on it with hard facts, and it will hardly notice. Chop off its head, and it will grow another one by nightfall. Nothing, it seems, can put an end to a myth but its replacement by another myth.

title: Susan R. Plath Is Married To Michael E. Winston
description: Susan R. Plath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren J. Plath of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and Michael E. Winston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund P. Winston Jr. of Houston, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert F. Dorer, a minister of the Dutch Reformed Church of America, performed the ceremony at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Making Goodbyes Easier For the Fresh Air Fund
description: The Fresh Air Fund builds bridges between the woods of upstate camps and farms and the children of city streets and housing projects. And the fund builds other bridges, between the children and those who help the fund in ways large and small.

title: The Census: Why We Can't Count
description: When the nation's greatest and most troubled exercise in counting finally comes to an end - when the last form flicks through the machines, when the last enumerator turns in the last Questionnaire Misdelivery Record Nonresponse Follow-up, when the last lawsuit is filed - the 1990 census seems certain to stand as a bleak landmark in the annals of arithmetic. The United States Census has become an institution clinging to what many statisticians consider a myth: the idea that the Government can count the nation's population the way a child counts marbles - 1, 2, 3 . . . 249,999,998, 249,999,999, 250,000,000. The population is too large, too mobile and too diverse to count that way.

title: Colorado Prairie Dog Shoot Takes Place Despite Protests
description: The first Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot competition got under way today with more than 100 participants, despite protests by about two dozen supporters of animal rights.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: NASSAU FOLK FESTIVAL

title: Vaccinations
description: To the Editor: In the article ''New Phone Line Advises Travelers About Vaccines'' (Practical Traveler, May 13), Rosamond R. Dewart of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta was quoted as recommending allowing six weeks prior to travel for getting information on vaccinations. I suggest that travelers allow at least eight weeks.

title: Fiber Art: Beyond the Mundane
description: THERE is a surprising harmony among some plastic baskets, Op Art quilts and the 154-year-old converted gristmill where they are now on display at the Hunterdon Art Center. Both the center and the work in the ''Fiber as Art'' exhibition bear witness to their more mundane beginnings.

title: Jody Irish to Wed Clifford Farren Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Peter Irish of Chatham, N.J., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Joan Marie Irish and Clifford Anthony Farren Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Farren of Belmar, N.J.

title: Cabot Paley and Donald Thaler Married on L.I.
description: Cabot Barber Paley, a clinical social worker, and Dr. Donald Paul Thaler, a dentist, both in New York, were married yesterday. Judge Edward Horne of East Hampton Town Court officiated at Gardiners Marina in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Openings for the Homeless
description: The summer months tend to dull City Hall's conscience on the homeless problem: with no one likely to freeze to death, the lack of decent shelter seems less urgent. But warm weather also means the homeless are far more visible - a sad, glaring reminder of official neglect.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about bills adopted in the New York State Legislature misstated the status of one.

title: GORBACHEV MEETS WITH NATO'S CHIEF
description: Underscoring a search for new relations between the North Atlantic alliance and the Kremlin, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today received the leader of NATO and agreed to visit and address the alliance at its headquarters in Brussels.

title: Warning to Lamenters
description: I read that a former newspaper colleague of mine is so depressed by the way things are in the United States these days that he says it reminds him of Romania.

title: 'Looking Glass' Show Reflects Self-Images of 19th Century
description: LEAD: NINETEENTH-CENTURY Americans revealed much of themselves through their dress and appearance. The cut of the clothes, the quality of the fabrics, the accessories and cosmetics used were all indicators of their view of themselves and their place in society.

title: Political Crisis Grips India's Governing Coalition
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh offered his resignation on Saturday to his party's leader, who said later that he had rejected it.

title: Gastineau Is Thrown Out
description: Mark Gastineau's debut in the Canadian Football League was just as provocative as the sack dance that used to set off opponents in the National Football League. Doug Flutie's was just as spectacular as his college career.

title: Postings: 'Historic Preservation in Queens';   Nominees for Landmark Designation
description: With a sense of affection and urgency, two leaders of the landmarks movement in Queens have compiled an 88-page book titled ''Historic Preservation in Queens.'' It lists buildings that are official city landmarks or are on the National Register of Historic Places, as well as structures that were designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission but later stripped of landmark status by the Board of Estimate.

title: Vincent Studies Past for Help On the Decision at Hand
description: Fay Vincent's commissionership is relatively young. Yet, as he begins his deliberations on the fate of the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, he does so equipped with the knowledge of 70 years of precedent-setting acts by commissioners past.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Celebrating a Summer Graduation
description: LEAD: MY son graduated from high school last summer. June is, of course, the time for graduations, not mid-August. But this was the way he chose to do it, taking extra courses in summer so he could finish a year early. He was in a hurry to leave a place he had found confining and to get on with the next phase of his life, which seemed to him more real, more free.

title: Blue Cross: Traditional but No Stick in the Mud
description: To the Editor:

title: Forecast For 'Today': Cloudy
description: Originally, I regarded the Gumbel memo as a strange (and failed) attempt on the part of the network to add spice to the ''Today'' show by injecting controversy into it. Now it seems the memo is being used as a scapegoat for the poor decisions made by executives on the show.

title: A Never-Say-Die British Musical
description: SUMMER-STOCK theaters are those places in which young hopefuls in the industry can gain experience and where more-experienced hopefuls can hone their craft while waiting for that big break.

title: Equal Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth;   College Reviews Sex Case Rules; Editor Suspended
description: Dartmouth College is reviewing its procedures for dealing with sexual assault and harassment following two cases involving the editor of the college newspaper, who has been suspended over accusations that he sexually abused a woman student.

title: Local Law 10
description: To the Editor:
