Ways to reduce fat in one's diet.

title:
FORUM;

The Conflict of the 90's: Scarce Capital
description: LEAD: As the danger of global military conflict recedes, a different sort of global conflict seems likely to emerge. Its venue will be the international capital markets. One cause will be a substantial contraction of capital exports from the principal 1980's capital suppliers, Japan and Germany. Another will be rising demand for capital imports in Eastern Europe and perhaps the Soviet Union, in conflict with third-world claimants in Latin America, South and Southeast Asia, Africa and

title: American Express
description: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Europe, I discovered just how ''helpful'' the American Express office can be to American tourists. Since I had planned to meet friends in different cities, we relied on the various American Express offices as a means of leaving and retrieving messages.

title: In Opera, 'Live' Is Livelier, but Also Riskier
description: There are some things about a live operatic performance that a studio-made recording just can't duplicate. All the possibilities - inspiration, subtlety, revelation of a composer's work, seizure of a great moment, athleticism with its risk of disaster, simple music-making - are in play before an audience of flesh and blood, in one particular moment. The stakes are high and immediate.

title: Cardiac Surgery Unit Fights for Its Life
description: LEAD: WATCHING his progress on an X-ray monitor overhead, Dr. John Strobeck, a cardiologist at Valley Hospital here, gently snaked a tiny balloon catheter through his patient's circulatory system toward a dangerously narrowed coronary artery. With the balloon in place, Dr. Strobeck inflated it to compress the waxy cholesterol buildup and reopen the vessel.

title: Susan Dickson Story Wed
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Susan Dickson Story, a daughter of Howard C. Story Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Carol Dickson Story, was married yesterday to David Campbell Cator, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Cator of Portola Valley, Calif. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig officiated. Mrs. Cator, a graduate of Tulane University, was until recently the New York advertising manager of Better Homes and Gardens magazine. Mr. Cator, a graduate of the Unversity of California at Berkeley, is the Northwest advertising manager of Sunset magazine in Seattle.

title: Shoes or Shoeboxes At the Beach
description: Calling visitors to Cape May ''shoobes'' because they bring all their needs to the shore in a shoebox is certainly colorful (Cape May Journal, ''Facing the Tourist Season With Mixed Feelings'' but is at variance with the etymology or folk wisdom on Long Beach Island.

title: Yonkers Resolves Housing Obstacle
description: A TWO-MONTH disagreement between Yonkers and the builder of the first 142 of 200 units of court-ordered desegregated housing in the city was resolved last week, clearing the way for construction of the low-income units to begin next month.

title: Currency;   Surprises From the Fed
description: Last week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took the foreign exchange market by surprise, announcing Thursday that the central bank might ease interest rates because of dwindling credit from commercial banks and then, on Friday, actually pushing rates down slightly. The dollar fell sharply after his remarks but recovered some on Friday, partly because the June increase in producer prices was disappointingly high. This week Mr. Greenspan will give his semiannual explanation of Fed policy to Congress. Analysts will be searching for clues to what happens next. If Mr. Greenspan says there will be no further easing, the dollar's fall may slow. But many analysts expect the Fed to ease rates again later this year.

title: Soviets Have Outlined a Peace Proposal for Afghanistan, U.S. Officials Say
description: Bush Administration officials say the Soviet Union has floated the outlines of a proposal that could lead to a settlement of the 12-year war in Afghanistan.

title: Fashion;   What They're Wearing: The Bright Suit
description: Has black been banished? Probably not, but it has been pushed aside for the moment. These photos, taken at recent social events in New York, clearly show that vibrant colors have overtaken black as the sophisticate's choice. And it's not just the obvious shades, like red, that are being chosen, but juicier ones like orange and pistachio. As it turned out, these colorful costumes were harbingers of fashion to come. On the following pages are a few of the new fall styles.

title: The Ratio of Values, Dollar and Otherwise
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Birnie Weds Pedro M. Garzon
description: Karen A. Birnie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Scott Birnie of Oakville, Ontario, was married yesterday to Pedro M. Garzon, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Antonio A. Garzon of West Brighton, S.I. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: INDIA OF THE IMAGINATION ...
description: THE WORLD OF NAGARAJ

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Mont Belvieu, Tex.;   A Gas Leak Prods Exodus
description: After the leak was discovered, eight hydrocarbon-industry companies that store liquid natural gas in the salt dome agreed to buy out residents who wanted to move. They paid the cost of replacement homes and $1 a square foot for each resident's land. They also paid for relocation, figured at 10 percent of the cost of the land and the replacement home. Several houses, as well as the 58-year-old First United Methodist Church, were moved to new sites.

title: Ms. Bauerle and D. S. Potter to Marry
description: Ellen Ann Bauerle and David Stone Potter plan to marry in August. Ms. Bauerle is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bauerle of Delaware, Ohio; her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. David Potter of New York.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Teen-Agers Need Effective Parents
description: LEAD: AS a family psychologist, I have discovered a simple truth: children's emotional, psychological and behavioral problems are solved most quickly by changes in parent management skills, not by sending the children to experts.

title: Practical Traveler;   Getting Cash Abroad: Bank Cards Make It Easy
description: When my family and I first traveled to England in 1965, we carried an engraved-letterhead note from our bank in New York that would have done credit to Edith Wharton. It introduced us to a bank in the City of London that would cash one of our New York checks, in case we ran through our $10 ''tip pack'' of British currency and our traveler's checks. It all seems so Victorian now; the methods of getting money overseas are modernizing rapidly. In the latest wrinkle, the electronic cash machine, with the help of satellite technology, is following its users overseas.

title: An Explanation On Missed Vote
description: The July 1 edition reported that I was absent during the vote to approve a 43,000-square-foot terminal at the County Airport [''Legislators Seek New Compromise on Air Terminal''] . It was correctly reported that I voted for the proposed 24,000-square-foot terminal - which also went down to defeat during our June 25 meeting. A number of people have been speculating why I missed the vote on the 43,000-square-foot terminal. I'd appreciate an opportunity to explain my absence. I had attended the meeting of the Legislature and participated in the debate on both alternatives: the proposed 43,000- and proposed 24,000-square-foot terminals. I announced that I would be voting against the larger terminal and for the smaller terminal.

title: Cathryn L. Kishbaugh Becomes a Bride
description: Cathryn Lee Kishbaugh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Kishbaugh of Atkinson, N.H., was married there yesterday to Christopher Robert MacLean, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. MacLean of Waccabuc, N.Y. The Rev. Leslie L. Leavitt Jr. officiated at the Atkinson Congregational Church.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD:

title: IN HAITI, THUGGERY IS EASIER ALL THE TIME
description: With the return from exile last week of two figures associated with political violence and torture, one pessimistic notion seemed to resound clearly through the thick atmosphere of Port-au-Prince. For many, the return of Roger Lafontant, the former head of the Tontons Macoute, and Williams Regala, a top army officer under Jean-Claude Duvalier and successor dictatorships, showed how little ground has been gained in the four years since Mr. Duvalier was routed in a street revolution.

title: WORLDS IN COLLUSION
description: A ROMANCE OF THE EQUATOR

title: LOVE WALKED OUT, WEARING ONLY A SCARF
description: SEPARATE HOURS

title: Campus Life: Carnegie-Mellon;   Campus Police Dust Off Old Idea: Bicycle Officers
description: Students at Carnegie-Mellon University will soon be protected by a new campus security officer - the bicycle patroller.

title: Perspectives: Town-House Rentals;   Awaiting a Comeback in High-End Sales
description: It is not quite what they had in mind, but Irving Kovner and Jack Shafran have had no trouble finding tenants. What they wanted was buyers.

title: Figure in Slaying of Polish Priest Hints at Involvement of Superiors
description: The secret-police captain convicted in the 1984 killing of a pro-Solidarity priest has raised new questions about whether more senior officials in the Interior Ministry were involved.

title: Mexican Dishes at a New Address
description: WE first encountered Clyde's Mexican Grille and Bar (then Clyde's Mexican Cafe) late in 1988, ensconced in tiny quarters in a fitness club in Stamford. Now it is in a free-standing building (formerly occupied by the Gaslight and several other restaurants) on Route 1 in Old Greenwich.

title: Finding Time in the Sun For Homeless Children
description: LEAD: CAMP season had already begun, but Louis Hackett, supervisor of community relations at the County Department of Social Services, was at his desk still matching the last of hundreds of homeless and foster children and other children on public assistance with more than 50 day camps and a few sleep-away camps in

title: Is Laughter The Recipe for Love?
description: Laugh - love, commingled seemed to be the traditional remedy that Janet Pomeranz, in her bittersweet article found completely inadequate to cheer her out of her melancholia (May 27).

title:
Northeast Notebook: Pittsburgh;

Moving Up To Move-Ups
description: LEAD: Ryan Homes will open its fourth development for move-up buyers this summer, and it will be the most expensive yet, with prices ranging up to $250,000. The company, which started building moderate-priced housing for first-time buyers 40 years ago in Pittsburgh's southern suburbs, has since 1986 been building for families ready to move to more ambitious homes.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Snap old flowers off geraniums and cut them off pansies, petunias, snapdragons and other annuals to keep the plants blooming; formation of seed pods will stop flowering. If bloom is finished, cut stalks off astilbes, foxgloves, phlox, lilies, heucheras, delphiniums and other perennials to prevent seed pods. Dig, divide and replant bearded iris. Last call to pinch back mums to make plants bushy.

title: AFRICA'S IRON HANDS STRUGGLE TO HANG ON
description: When thousands of Zambians rushed onto the streets of Lusaka last month to celebrate what they thought was a successful overthrow of their longtime President, Kenneth D. Kaunda, they were expressing what citizens in many parts of Africa have been saying more and more: Africa's original big men have been around too long.

title: Anne Alley and Dan Morris Wed in New Mexico
description: Anne Lamberton Alley and Dan Casement Morris were married yesterday in an Episcopal ceremony at the Loreto Chapel in Santa Fe, N.M., by the Rev. Robbins Clarke. Mrs. Alley-Morris, 26 years old, is the daughter of Helen Lamberton of Baltimore and James B. Alley Jr. of Santa Fe. Mr. Morris, 30, is the son of Alexandra Casement Morris and Robert Brown Morris, both of Midland, Tex.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Springfield, Mass.;

New Housing For Mentally Ill
description: LEAD: A private nonprofit agency that develops affordable housing for people with mental disorders is buying a 9,600-square-foot firehouse here for $122,500 to convert into 15 apartments.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Take the Profits and Run
description: LEAD: CERTAIN wise suburban homeowners like our family members are now more vulnerable sitting ducks than the aviary species populating our sadly dwindling ponds. We are among those unfortunate folks who outsmarted ourselves by successfully selecting the site of what is most families' largest monetary investment, our house.

title: Betsy Guinzburg To Wed Next Year
description: The engagement of Betsy Guinzburg to Arthur Brian Markman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Markman of Edison, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Guinzburg of Englewood, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title:
FILM;

'Roger' and I, Off to Hollywood and Home to Flint
description: LEAD: There were omens. I don't believe in omens, but they were there, nonetheless.

title: SCREAMS IN THE NIGHT
description: BOHIN MANOR

title: Virginia Ehrlich to Marry Mathias J. Thoerner
description: August wedding plans for Virginia Ehrlich and Mathias Johannes Thoerner, a son of Baroness Teuffel von Birkensee of Feldafing, West Germany, and Hans Hofmeier of Tegernsee, West Germany, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. M. Gordon Ehrlich of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Cuba Said to Fire at Fugitive
description: A Cuban who tried to gain refuge in the Spanish Embassy here on Friday night was captured by Cuban police officers who fired shots as they followed him onto the embassy patio and then dragged him away, witnesses said today. The event was confirmed by Spanish diplomatic aides who asked not to be named. They said that Spain had issued a protest to the Cuban Foreign Ministry over the incident.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: NEXT STOP FOR MANKIND
description: MARS BECKONS

title: Are the Good Old Days Back Already?
description: Suddenly, the summer of 1990 is starting to seem like the summer of 1987. The Dow is setting records, deals are being done, insider trading allegations are flying and the stories about Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company make the leveraged buyout kings sound like geniuses again.

title: An Inverse Trompe l'Oeil
description: To the Editor:

title: Northeast Notebook: Newport, Me.;   What's Next After the Fire?
description: A fire that destroyed a large section of the historic downtown here in May has left the question of when and how to rebuild.

title: Sports of The Times;   Where Are Rizzuto's Old-Timers?
description: Before he put on a Yankee uniform for what he agreed would probably be the last time, Phil Rizzuto was finishing another cup of coffee.

title: Dams May Be Razed So the Salmon Can Pass
description: The Elwha River comes bouncing out of the high-country heart of this million-acre park, a surge of clean water that used to provide passage for some of the world's biggest salmon, the giant chinooks.

title: Another Riff: Kill the Mikes
description: To the Editor:

title: Forecast For 'Today': Cloudy
description: The seemingly harmless addition of Deborah Norville to the ''Today'' show to ''give Jane a jolt'' is every working woman's worst nightmare. Who would, after more than 13 years on the job, like to come to work and, without warning, find someone new at one's desk?

title: Malcolm Wiener Weds Carolyn Seely
description: Carolyn Talbot Seely, a counsel to Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, and Malcolm Hewitt Wiener, the founder and chairman of the Millburn Corporation and Comminvest, New York investment management companies, were married June 8. Iris McCleery, a justice of the peace in Ridgefield, Conn., officiated at the bridegroom's home there.

title: Special Museums From Subs to Nuts: Enough Already?
description: THE American Silver Museum, in Meriden, was supposed to open this summer, but the building is locked shut. The museum has run out of money, and while it seeks more support, some people in the state wonder whether Connecticut already has too many specialized museums.

title: Review/Theater;   From Trivia to Tragedy in 'Jersey City'
description: As the audience meets Magaly and Pa in ''Jersey City,'' Wendy Hammond's jarring new play at the Second Stage Theater, they are finishing their evening meal with a game of baseball trivia. Magaly, still tomboy enough at age 15 to prefer a catcher's mitt to a new dress for a present, knows what year Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle broke in as rookies, then stumps her dad with a question about what outfielder is named after a fruit (until she starts chanting ''Dar-ryl'' to give him a clue). They seem quite happy, father and daughter sharing a love of our national pastime. Moments later, Magaly's dad knocks her around the kitchen and rapes her.

title: Postings: Paying the Points;   50 Affordable Bronx Town Houses
description: 50 affordable two-family town houses nearing completion in the Crotona Park section of the Bronx, offered to pay the mortgage points for the first 25 buyers. A point is 1 percent of a mortgage, and most lenders charge two or three as an origination fee for a home loan.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended June 30

title: Big Dishes Come Back
description: Mark Twain considered reports of his death exaggerated. Likewise, the widely proclaimed demise of big-dish antennas (to receive satellite television) also turned out to be grossly overstated.

title: Managing;   Giving Less Time to Good Causes
description: Two years ago, internal dissension threatened to destroy the Shanti Project, the San Francisco nonprofit group that is one of the world's largest providers of care for people with AIDS. Its founder had stepped aside and Douglas P. Holloway, a member of Shanti's board, ran the group on a day-to-day basis for eight months while holding down a full-time job as an executive vice president of Wells Fargo & Company.

title: Taking a Course In 'Freshman' Mischief
description: The Komodo Dragon, an endangered 10-foot lizard that preys on small wild pigs, is not ordinarily much in the news. But in December 1984, a former organized crime figure named Charles Cantino, a k a Vincent A. Teresa, was charged with smuggling this and other exotic species into the United States.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: Definitely, without a doubt, Steinbrenner should be suspended. Unlawful activities should not be tolerated along with the downfall of such a once-respected baseball franchise.

title:
The View From: Lake Innisfree;

Saving the Environment in the Backyard
description: LEAD: WHEN participants in the county's first women's triathlon swim Lake Innisfree two weeks from today, they will be slicing through unobstructed water. The thick algae that blooms in summer has been removed and the tangled weeds have been cut down.

title: Lee Brooks Engaged To Michele B. Plotnik
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman Plotnik of Westwood, N.J., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, Michele Beth Plotnik, and Lee Warren Brooks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Selig Brooks of Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Who Will Call The Signals in 1990?
description: The chart below examines the quarterback situation for each of the 28 N.F.L. teams. Dates given are when rookies and veterans report to camp.

title: Lilco and Suffolk Differ on Court Ruling
description: LEAD: DIFFERING interpretations of a Federal Court of Appeals ruling that upheld a settlement under which the Long Island Lighting Company will repay its million customers $390 million offered clues last week about future legal battles between the company and its most enduring adversary, Suffolk County.

title: Dr. Kahn Plans August Wedding
description: Dr. Laura Helene Kahn, a staff resident in internal medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, and David Nathaniel Spergel, an assistant professor of astrophysical sciences at Princeton University, are planning an August wedding.

title: Pedigreed Pieces Haven't Lost Their Luster
description: So far in 1990, antiques enthusiasts have paid premium prices at auctions for the finest period objects. This comes at a time when there are indications in the market that the decade-old antiques boom may be on the wane.

title: Jet Door Sought in Sea for Accident Clue
description: Seventeen months after a cargo door blew off a United Airlines Boeing 747 south of Hawaii, sweeping nine passengers to their deaths, an effort to retrieve the door from an ocean depth of more than 14,000 feet is scheduled to begin late this week.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: JACK GANCE, by Ward Just. (Ivy, $4.95.) A young pollster with connections to the Chicago political machine becomes a White House aide and then a senator. Last year our reviewer, Judith Martin, said Ward Just ''is not only the most literary chronicler of the daily lives and moral dilemmas of contemporary politicians, bureaucrats, intelligence agents, military officers, diplomats, lawyers and journalists, but one of the few novelists even interested in depicting such people realistically.''

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   High-End Sales Are Down in Greenwich
description: In northeast Greenwich, 26 stately pleasure domes have been built at Conyers Farm, a 1,500-acre enclave resembling a contemporary Xanadu. Maintaining its private, pastoral quality is a set of covenants under which no more than 60 families may live on minimum lots of 10 acres, protected in perpetuity by deed restrictions.

title: Abortion Trap in Louisiana
description: In its zeal to enact the nation's stiffest anti-abortion law, the Louisiana Legislature has passed a bill that Gov. Buddy Roemer must veto if he holds to his own standards. A politician with a pro-life record, Mr. Roemer asked his Legislature to exempt victims of rape and incest from any new law.

title: Susan Lefkon Is Married
description: Susan R. Lefkon, the daughter of Roger Lefkon of Los Angeles and Carole Lefkon of Douglaston, Queens, was married last evening to Jeffrey L. Giniger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Giniger of Rock Hill, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnick officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Mrs. Giniger, 27 years old, is a sales representative at Vidi Vici, a fashion showroom in New York. She graduated from George Washington University. Mr. Giniger, 31, is an account executive at the Stollerman Design Studio in New York. He is a graduate of Baruch College.

title: Avon Keeps Ringing, but Wall Street Won't Answer
description: His round, jovial face and twinkling eyes belie it, but James E. Preston is getting annoyed.

title: Too Many Bosses, Too Few Workers
description: Before Americans can celebrate the decline of Communism, we should ponder why a Japanese eighth grader typically knows more mathematics than an American with an M.B.A., and whether our own decline can be far behind the Soviet Union's. I believe we can avoid that fate, but we need to make a number of fundamental changes in business, government and education if we are to continue to prosper.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: GEORGE WALKER;

A Career Composing Classical Music
description: LEAD: AT his first lesson in composition with Nadia Boulanger in Paris in 1957, George Walker showed her a work for solo voice that he had written. She studied it, then said, ''You are a composer, and this song is a masterpiece.''

title: Hers;   Prince Charming Comes Back
description: Just the other day it happened again: I was sifting through a rack of charming but inflationary baby clothes together with my friend Susan when she said, sotto voce: ''I talked to my cousin yesterday. She saw 'Pretty Woman.' She said she loved it, too.'' Although I doubt Susan's cousin loves the movie as much as does Susan, who's seen it three times, the list of suspects keeps growing. My friend Willa is up to four viewings. I myself have gone twice so far and have devoted several phone conversations to rapt discussions of the movie - one of which concerned the motivation of the Richard Gere character, at the sort of arcane level of discourse more usually to be found in a graduate seminar on ''Middlemarch.''

title: Private Beach Clubs Bring Neighbors Together
description: LEAD: AT the edge of one Stamford neighborhood - Auldwood, Lanark and Chesterfield Roads and Ocean Drive North - is a wide and sandy beach. It has a small picnic area, a basketball court, a volleyball net and a swing set and jungle gym for the smaller children. A lifeguard is on duty for most of the summer, and although the beach is rarely empty, it is virtually never crowded.

title: On the Road, Again
description: A recent Midwestern drive presented more than expected sights like the Gateway Arch, Sears Tower and Blue Water Bridge. The roads between scheduled stops revealed a four-decade evolution in American motoring. The Interstate highways enter the 1990's, like many of us who travel them, pushing middle age. Twenty-five years of growth pains have yielded to a steady state, with some key roads already graying. The mature highways are more predictable but less adventurous.

title: Life Within Earshot Of the Firing Range
description: If Michael Ziatyk of Larchmont thinks power mowers are disturbing [''Gardening Equipment Provokes a New Look at Noise Ordinances,'' June 24] he ought to come by and see what it is to live nearby a shooting range as we do here in New Castle.

title: THE ONE ABOUT THE SCHOLAR AND THE HERMIT'S DAUGHTER
description: LEAD:

title: Review/Dance;   Young Collaborators Offer Three Premieres
description: One of the big surprises of the American Dance Festival is the annual program by the Young Choreographers and Composers in Residence. Each summer, three choreographers collaborate on new works with three composers. It is impossible to predict what the results will be, and it is always fascinating to discover what young dancers and musicians have on their creative minds.

title: Jennie McAvoy to Wed Bart L. Landenberger
description: The engagement of Jennie Van Pelt McAvoy to Bart Lawrence Landenberger, the son of Jane Hamilton Landenberger of Bedford, N.Y., and the late John Landenberger, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. McAvoy of Tappan, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Will You Turn That Mower Off?
description: LEAD: WHEN we left the city for the suburbs, one of my greatest joys was leaving behind the early morning banging of garbage pails as the Department of Sanitation's minions collected our daily leavings. I did not know that the suburbs had their own version of this perennial problem. I soon discovered the worst.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Business section last Sunday reported on a Dallas company, National Spirit Group Inc., that conducts cheerleader training camps and sells cheerleading equipment. The article discussed the 1988 acquisition of National Spirit by the Prospect Group Inc. of New York and quoted Lawrence Herkimer, National Spirit's founder and chairman, as having said, ''We have never had a down year.''

title: Commercial Property: Office Leasing;   Law Firms Top Financial Houses in Rental Activity
description: In one of the biggest deals of a slow year, the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy has signed a 20-year lease for at least 330,000 square feet at One Chase Manhattan Plaza in lower Manhattan, with options that could bring its space to 750,000 square feet - or fully one-third of the tower.

title: Gorbachev Fills New and Less Powerful Politburo
description: The Communist Party significantly revamped its Politburo today, carrying out Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to separate the party hierarchy from the Government.

title: Town's Roots Are Tended With Love
description: GLADYS HUSTED OWEN stood next to an antique table dotted with five- and six-pound Revolutionary War cannonballs and gazed proudly at a watercolor of the Marquis de Lafayette. ''This was our most illustrious guest,'' said Mrs. Owen, her silver-and-white-flecked hair tucked neatly into a bun. ''We had a ball for him right here in this house. After the Revolution, he gave this portrait to our family.''

title: A Parent Behind Every Medal
description: When Elverda Commings introduced her 5-year-old son to swimming in 1979, her ambitions were confined to the local Boys Club in Blackjack, Mo. She paid the $5 membership fee and later, when her son began racing, she paid a modest meet fee of 75 cents per event.

title: Wall Street;   Close Ties at a Closed-End Fund
description: One of the popular Wall Street parlor games these days is buying closed-end funds at a discount. The rules are simple. Check the price of a closed-end fund, a fund whose shares trade publicly like common stock. Check the per-share market value of the fund's portfolio. If the fund's price is a lot lower than its net asset value, consider it a bargain. By that wisdom, Engex Inc. looks like a steal. The fund, managed by D. H. Blair Advisors, recently reported that its portfolio of growth stocks was worth $12.20 a share. Its shares are trading at $9.50 each. In fact, its shares have traded at a hefty discount through much of their market life.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: A recent study suggested that players should shuffle seven times to insure a satisfactory mix of the cards. It is unlikely that players accustomed to a perfunctory two or three riffles will change their ways, but a point to consider is the type of bridge being played.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: When you give up a rook for a minor piece - a bishop or a knight - the process is called an exchange sacrifice to indicate that even though each player has exchanged one unit, the value of the respective units is unequal. Yet, although a rook is formally worth approximately one and a half pawns more than a minor piece, the transaction is frequently a gain of material because the opponent must lose several pawns along with his bishop or knight.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: If baseball officials would avoid charges of being as imperious and mercurial as Steinbrenner himself, they will ask themselves this perhaps troublesome question before imposing any penalty: What would we mete out under identical circumstances to one of the more ''likable'' of baseball owners, such as Gene Autry or the late Tom Yawkey, Connie Mack or Walter Briggs?

title: Hampshire College
description: As the mother of a 1990 Hampshire graduate and a veteran of various academic ceremonies, I feel that the unique quality of the college is perhaps most evident at its graduation ceremonies. Instead of a mass of academic robes, there was a jaunty parade of individuals in costumes ranging from the outrageous to the conventional. Rather than the usual scholastic honors, the title of every student's senior paper was printed in the program.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

...And Don't Push Single Men, Either
description: LEAD: AT a recent party, I overheard a woman ask, ''What's wrong with him?'' She was referring to me, and her tone suggested she had just learned I was a 36-year-old bachelor. These days, the word prompts a litany of unpopular possibilities: Gay? Divorced? Disturbed? It wasn't always so.

title: The Summer's Fare: Readings to Musicals
description: THOSE who enjoy lively, thriving professional summer theater in Connecticut can hold onto a few signs of stability in an otherwise changing, shrinking - and Shakespeare-less - summer season.

title: Rescued Aerial Maps Show County of 1920's
description: LEAD: PRICELESS aerial photographs taken in 1925 and 1926, with views covering the entire 450 square miles of the county, are being preserved, catalogued and made more accessible to the public by the county's Division of Environmental Planning. The division has also retrieved aerial photographs taken in 1940.

title: NONFICTION
description: INSIDE TRACK: My Professional Life in Amateur Track and Field. By Carl Lewis with Jeffrey Marx. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Carl Lewis, the track and field superstar who has won six Olympic gold medals, is one of the world's greatest athletes. In his autobiography, ''Inside Track,'' Mr. Lewis focuses not on his athletic prowess but on the reasons why he has been unable to cash in on his celebrity. Here is a man who could have been the cover boy for Wheaties - he has been ''the world's fastest human'' for close to a decade and has won 62 straight long-jump competitions since 1981. And Mr. Lewis, only 28 years old, could well add to his Olympic booty in 1992. But while he makes a handsome living, Mr. Lewis writes that he does not have any major endorsements from American companies. For someone who says one of the first things he told his college coach was ''I want to be a millionaire,'' this has not made for a happy camper. Mr. Lewis blames the news media for casting him in a negative light. He also blames the Athletics Congress, the organization that governs track and field in the United States, for mishandling the sport in general, and specifically for attempting to undermine his commercial opportunities because of a longstanding feud between the organization and Mr. Lewis's racing team, the Santa Monica Track Club. Mr. Lewis makes many valid points and is particularly hard-hitting in his documentation of abuses in college recruiting and his criticisms of the Athletics Congress. However, he seems unnecessarily harsh on his rivals, such as the sprinter Ben Johnson and the long jumper Larry Myricks, and he uses ''Inside Track'' to take swipes at what amounts to an enemies list of just about anyone who has ever crossed him on or off the track. Written with the Pulitzer Prize-winning sportswriter Jeffrey Marx, ''Inside Track'' provides a revealing look at the underbelly of international track and field, but misses a precious opportunity to dissect Mr. Lewis's remarkable athletic talents and show the kind of grace and humility that might make him more endearing to corporate America.

title: Ban on Drug Is Sought in Florida
description: Animal-rights supporters plan to challenge a state decision allowing the use of a powerful class of steroids on race horses. They say the drugs pose a danger to both horses and jockeys.

title: Deborah Ellen Burton Weds Stan M. Wrobel
description: Deborah Ellen Burton, a daughter of Dr. Anna Burton and Dr. Murray E. Burton of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday at the couple's home in Ann Arbor, Mich., to Stan Michael Wrobel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Wrobel of New Port Richey, Fla. The Rev. Ward Hallman, a minister of the Unity Church, officiated.

title: A December Wedding For Jamie N. Kolodkin
description: The engagement of Jamie Naomi Kolodkin to Michael Howard Carus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Carus of Merrick, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Kolodkin of Stamford, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: Elizabeth L. Hiser to Marry Charles P. Hoban
description: August wedding plans for Elizabeth Lawrence Hiser and Charles Park Hoban, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Hoban of Lake Forest, Ill., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Hiser Jr. of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Postings: Restaurant on the Hudson;   A Marina Plus
description: A long-neglected stretch of parkland along the Hudson River in northern Manhattan will be the site of a 127-slip marina and 60-seat restaurant if a plan by the New York City Parks Department is approved.

title: U.S. Seeks to Deny Furnaces to Iraq
description: Concerned about the growing sophistication of Iraq's military, the Pentagon is leading a last-minute effort to prevent Baghdad from importing industrial furnaces that some experts say could be used to make components for missiles and atomic weapons.

title: A Fan's Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Theater Lures L.I. Students
description: LEAD: KATIE WILLIAMS of Garden City was eager to learn more about the theater after taking a course in stagecraft at Nassau Community College. But there were no programs in the region that captured the 20-year-old's interest.

title: Recycling: New Report, New Debate
description: NEW JERSEY residents are recycling more trash than anyone had expected, according to a new report that has already begun to intensify the incinerators vs. recycling debate.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Worship With Me At a Sacred Shrine
description: LEAD: OF the many religions protected by our Constitution, there is one rarely mentioned by name, never challenged in court and never tainted by scandal, and it is rapidly taking over whole communities on Long Island.

title: Buying a Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Zulu Leader Sharpens His Challenge to Mandela
description: In a tacit challenge to the African National Congress, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the principal Zulu leader, moved today to convert his movement into a multiracial political party and said that it must be reckoned with in future negotiations that the Government convenes on the nation's future.

title: Eligible At Age 14
description: At age 14 in her first year as a pro, Jennifer Capriati has already influenced women's tennis. Acknowledging her presence in the ranks among the top 20 players in the world, the Women's International Professional Tennis Council has revised its eligibility rules to allow the talented Floridian to qualify for the season-ending Virginia Slims Championships on Nov. 12 through Nov. 18 at Madison Square Garden.

title: An Albatross Named Shearson
description: It was a run-of-the-mill tombstone advertisement touting the underwriting by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. of a retail mutual fund. But the ad, which appeared in recent weeks, contained one change that spoke volumes about how the firm has been transformed in the past six months: Lehman Brothers was listed in the tombstone and the names Shearson and Hutton were missing.

title: Lael E. Conlon To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. Clark Conlon of Stamford, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lael Elizabeth Conlon and Gordon Stewart Kiesling, the son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Stewart Keisling of Princeton, N.J.

title: HEALTH CONDITIONS WORSEN FOR YOUNG
description: Conditions for children in New York City have deteriorated significantly in the last 15 years, with marked increases in infant mortality, reports of child abuse and the number of children living in poverty, according to an index tabulated by social scientists at Fordham University.

title: Fashion;   What's Coming: Lots of Color
description: Not missing a beat, American designers are picking up on pretty shadings and continuing them for fall. It gets really interesting when two or more colors are combined. Here are a few of the new looks that should soon be arriving in stores.

title: Postings: Brewster in Transition;   D'Agostino North
description: First came the villagers, then the weekenders, then growing numbers of resident commuters who ride the Upper Harlem Line and, finally, the office campuses with crew-cut lawns that have muscled their way in among the apple orchards and dairy farms of Putnam County.

title: Caroline A. Ewert To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Caroline A. Ewert to Richard A. Jaenicke, a son of Ann B. Jaenicke of Lancaster, Pa., and Henry R. Jaenicke of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Ewert of New York. A November wedding is planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Ease Up, Please, on Single Women...
description: LEAD: IT has happened again: Some conscientious soul more concerned with my business than her own managed in the course of polite conversation to suggest that as a 29-year-old single woman, I must be ready to pounce on any unattached man who crosses my path. We had just left a church service and were exchanging pleasantries, when she spied a man without a wedding ring in the coffee-hour crowd and suggested that I hurry over to put in a bid on him.

title: Elizabeth LightfootWed in Connecticut
description: Elizabeth Baxter Lightfoot, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Lightfoot of Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Nicholas Clements, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Havranek of Dorset, England, by the Rev. Dean C. Ahlberg at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: AFTERSHOCK IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Fenton Johnson's article ''Aftershock in San Francisco'' (June 17) left the mistaken impression that San Francisco's disaster planning is rooted in denial. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Running the Rapids Of Utah's San Juan
description: A white roar disturbs the canyon quiet. Roabie Johnson pulls a pair of pliers from the holster on her belt and draws a diagram in the sand: two parallel lines to show the course of the river, three or four circles to indicate rocks, and a series of peaks that stand for tail waves. ''These pliers are your boat,'' she says as she threads the tool through the circles and aims it directly at the peaks. ''Avoid the rocks. Avoid the holes. Hit the big waves head on. Always face your danger.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about budget cuts at Stanford University referred incorrectly in some copies to the distance between Stanford and San Francisco. The university is about 35 miles southeast of the city.

title: Syria Leader Visits Cairo, Mending Ties
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria arrived here today on his first visit in 13 years, a period of estrangement that began with Egypt's decision to sign a peace treaty with Israel.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   On L.I., a Preserve's Unspoiled Quiet
description: Just an hour from Manhattan, there is a place of peace and beauty in Nassau County where the only reminder of civilization is the occasional sound of a car on Route 106. In the Muttontown Preserve, birds, wild animals, forests and fields coexist, quietly recalling the Long Island of two centuries ago.

title:
LONG ISLAND Q & A: BEVERLY BIRNS;

Concern on Abused Women and Endangered Young
description: LEAD: DISTURBED by the rising level of domestic violence, the Long Island community is seeking ways to prevent the abuse that has led to the death of 12 women in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in the last two and a half years.

title: Campus Life: Cleveland State;   Sit-In Supports Departing Official For Minorities
description: A sit-in at Cleveland State University by black students protesting the departure of a vice president for minority affairs in a salary dispute moved into its third week Friday with no end in sight. The demonstration by the students, who are occupying the first floor of the Fenn Tower administration building, has led to intervention by the Mayor of Cleveland and, the protesters say, has produced two death threats against them.

title: Meals With Artists at Mostly Mozart
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival will open a series of pre-concert Meet-the-Artist ''Tastings'' tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Mailing Is Curbed in Vermont
description: Mailing privileges for Vermont lawmakers will be suspended through Jan. 1, 1991 as part of a cost-cutting effort. The Legislative Council, eight lawmakers who oversee internal business, this week notified the other 172 members of the House and Senate of several cost-savings measures. The changes included suspension of stenographic services, stationery and postage. A spokesman said the Legislature spent $20,000 on postage in the last year.

title: Forecast For 'Today': Cloudy
description: I was surprised that there was virtually no mention in your article of John Palmer, who was one of the big plusses of ''Today.'' Although we were all sad to see Jane Pauley leave the show, there are many of us who were sorry to see this highly respected, veteran news professional downgraded to second-string status.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Bistros With a Fresh New Look Or a Face That's Happily Faded
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times, and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Edith Livingstone To Wed in August
description: August wedding plans for Edith Anne Livingstone and Joshua L. Sheinkman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Sheinkman of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James R. Livingstone of Belmont, Mass.

title: The Return of TB: A special report.;   TUBERCULOSIS GERM RESURGING AS RISK TO PUBLIC HEALTH
description: Borne on a tide of AIDS, homelessness and drug and alcohol use, tuberculosis is re-emerging as a public health threat in the United States, particularly in inner cities.

title: Hampshire College
description: Yes, there are those of us who ''failed'' at experimental education, who caught the bus back to requirements and midterms and cumulative grade-point averages. And I don't think we are necessarily less self-reliant or less willing to take chances than the students who stayed.

title: Single-Parent Families Sharing Their Homes
description: LEAD: LAST spring, in the midst of a divorce, Taryn Melendez started looking for an apartment for herself and her two young daughters. Hoping to find a roommate with whom she could split expenses, she said, she ran advertisements in a couple of newspapers. But she found that most of the people who wanted to share housing did not want to live with children.

title:
ART;

Mixing Sunlight and Shadow
description: LEAD: EXHIBITIONS of American Impressionist paintings are being mounted everywhere these days, and the reason most often given is that they are what people like. Often one finds oneself asking if this is really true, whether they like landscapes in high-pitched color or, at the opposite end, totally gauzy palettes.

title: Homeless In America
description: The Better Homes Foundation, a nonprofit organization serving homeless families, has been in contact with more than 1,000 programs that deal with issues regarding the homeless. Many of these programs find ''substance abuse'' a growing problem. However, this does not mean that substance abuse causes family homelessness.

title: Zombie Assassins, Desert Rhythms and the Beats
description: Rock-and-roll, with its unbookish culture, seems an unlikely candidate to adopt a literary figure. But there is no longer any doubt that the perennial iconoclast-author William Burroughs has been given a lifetime pass to the rock-and-roll circus. The bassist and songwriter Bill Laswell, leading a loose assemblage of players he calls Material, recently drafted the writer to read excerpts from his latest novel, ''The Western Lands,'' as part of the album ''Seven Souls'' (Virgin 91360; CD and cassette). And last year, the group Manapsara released ''Queer: A Soundtrack to the Novel by William S. Burroughs'' (Sub Rosa, SUB 33017-22; all three formats, Belgian import), based on one of his early texts. Such tributes are no surprise, given that the 76-year-old Mr. Burroughs has been hanging around the outskirts of rock music since the 1960's, his influence spreading slowly.

title: Cone Is Right on Target
description: The rhythm was fluid, the location precise, the fastball flat-out fierce, all of which made the analysis in his own mind indisputable. David Cone, the right-hander for the Mets with the ability to turn an encouraging roll into a long run of brilliance, is gathering momentum.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Hartford, Conn. $500,000

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: If guilty, yes. If innocent, he should be allowed to return to his fraternity of selfish and arrogant owners, overpaid ballplayers, agents, and be forced to watch a Yankee game every day.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Pynchon, You're a Part of My Life
description: LEAD: THE recent publication of ''Vineland'' has me thinking that it is pungently ironic that such an elusive figure as Thomas Pynchon feels like an intimate companion. Here's my chronicle of a 22-year acquaintance, rich in the absurd and improbable coincidence that characterizes Pynchon's fiction.

title: Jennifer R. Gierke To Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of Jennifer Rae Gierke to James Alfred Mitchell, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul L. Mitchell of Melville, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Bradford M. Gierke of Tacoma, Wash., and Janet Rae McKay of Bellevue, Wash. A November wedding is planned.

title: Rent Regulators Can't Please Anyone, Even Themselves
description: The scene looked more like a stage production of ''Marat/ Sade'' than an important annual meeting of a government regulatory body. Hundreds of landlords and tenants stood on opposite sides of a large hall, stamping their feet and shouting down the members of the panel attempting to reach a consensus on the stage. Demonstrators carried placards around the room. A landlord in a kangaroo costume roamed the aisles. At one point, a landlord and a tenant got so carried away that they began to throw punches.

title: To the Dogs
description: In an attempt to ease some of the tensions between the cities of Cincinnati and Cleveland, Sam Wyche, the Bengals' coach, put himself at the mercy of the infamous ''Dog Pound'' fans in Cleveland on Friday and in doing so raised about $8,000 for the Salvation Army homeless and hunger programs in that city.

title: Fox in The Network Henhouse
description: Keenen Ivory Wayans, Executive Producer, Writer and star of Fox Broadcasting Company's ''In Living Color,'' had a problem. He and Tamara Rawitt, one of the show's producers, had developed a sketch that would push the Fox network's cutting-edge humor policy to its limit. Or break it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are concerned about out-of-sequence and vanity addresses. They're really proliferating. It's hard even for old-timers - but particularly for newcomers - to find their way around town.''

title: CHENEY DISPUTED ON PLANE'S MERITS
description: The fight between Congress and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney over the fate of the Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that ascends like a helicopter and flies like a plane, has heated up with the release of a study commissioned by the Pentagon at Congress's request.

title: St. Andrews Through the Caddy's Eyes
description: Forgive my lack of modesty, but I am the most experienced and the best regular caddie at the Old Course at St. Andrews. I have caddied there at least four times a week for the last 44 years, since I was 14 years old. Of course, it has been my great privilege to carry Arnold Palmer's bag there in three British Opens, as well as the 25 others he has played in. What can I tell you about St. Andrews? I've lived here all my life, and I still think it is a magical place. I think it when I make the 15-minute walk from my home to the Old Course at about 9 o'clock each morning. And I know I will think it walking up past the tremendous galleries this week with Arnold.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

A Furry Challenge At Herb Society's New Headquarters
description: LEAD: The Herb Society of America is putting fragrance to a test at its new national headquarters, which are adjacent to the Holden Arboretum east of Cleveland. The society hopes that planting a practical garden of scented plants and strewing it with sweetly perfumed soap will keep their landscape from becoming a breakfast buffet for nearby deer.

title: Q and A
description: Taking Tea in London

title: Wesleyan Student's Killing Is Tied to Drugs
description: A student militant at Wesleyan University who was once considered one of the university's most promising minority scholars was killed during a drug deal, a police affidavit says.

title: Taking a Number
description: In West Virginia politics, they do take prisoners. Last week former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced to become one, joining nearly a dozen state legislators, lobbyists and government workers who have been convicted on corruption charges in the last couple of years. Mr. Moore, who served two terms as Governor in the 1970's and one term in the late 1980's, pleaded guilty to Federal charges of extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and attempting to obstruct the grand jury that indicted him. The most serious offense Mr. Moore owned up to was the extortion of $573,000 from a coal company in return for arranging to have the company get a $2 million refund from the state fund that provides benefits for miners with black lung disease. He was fined $170,00 and sentenced to five years and 10 months in prison. He was ordered to report to prison on July 31.

title: Lawns Exact Price Some Won't Pay
description: WHEN 17-month-old Ari Winkleman toddles around his Hastings-on-Hudson backyard, his parents worry about the spills and falls he will take as he exercises his new-found motor skills. What they don't worry about is his exposure to pesticides on their property.

title: Dr. Glass Is to Wed Dr. D. M. Sacknoff
description: Dr. Andrea Leslie Glass and Dr. David Matthew Sacknoff, 1988 graduates of the New York Medical College and residents in internal medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, are planning an October wedding. The announcement was made by the prospective bride's parents, Judith R. Glass of Huntington, L.I., and Don B. Glass of Englewood, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Michigan State;   Anti-Drinking Bid Results in Seizure Of Fake Licenses
description: In an effort to crack down on what they said was an increase in under-age drinking, the East Lansing police have confiscated more than 700 fake driver's licenses from students.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Racing Faces New Drug Problem As Steroid Use Troubles Breeders
description: Amid the bluegrass of Lexington, Ky., this week and the breezes of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., next month, tuxedoed auctioneers will sell nearly a thousand sleek and blue-blooded yearlings for more than $200 million to dreamers and speculators searching for the next Secretariat.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Business inventories for May.

title: A Marriage Made Off Broadway Takes the Cake
description: On the steps of a church in Greenwich Village in Manhattan, a small crowd waits expectantly for a wedding to begin. Suddenly the bride appears and dashes inside. ''Don't look at the bride!'' her bridesmaids scream. ''It's bad luck.'' But everybody ignores them, for they have paid admission to attend. They are, in fact, witnessing ''Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding,'' one of Off Broadway's biggest hits. Now in its third year, the show grosses some $2.5 million annually.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

title: VULNERABLE LIVES
description: THE BODY AND ITS DANGERS

title: Giant Steps;   Germany Makes the Most of Its Newfound Power
description: There is no doubt in anyone's mind in London, Paris or Bonn that the Western leader who dominates the international agenda these days is not Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain or President Bush of the United States, but Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.

title: LEANING ON CONGRESS
description: LION IN THE LOBBY

title: PUBLIC & PRIVATE Conventional Wisdom
description: It was two hours into the New Year in Manhattan; the sidewalks were grubby with confetti, the back seats of cabs were full of drunks and the George Washington Bridge hung silver over the river. Just outside the Lincoln tunnel was a woman, working. She was wearing high heels, the bottom to a bikini, and a satin banner that said in glitter 1976.

title: Review/Dance;   L'Esquisse In Gothic Romance
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has a distinctively paradisiacal air these days. There is a sense that every inch of the newly landscaped, refurbished festival complex in the Berkshire woods has been happily taken over by dance, from the rustic benches and woodland ponds that offer performers and dancers in training moments of private meditation to studios brimming with classes and informal events that are open to theatergoers' casual inspection.

title: The French Seek Their Own 'Peace Dividend'
description: Having long pursued an independent military policy, the French Government is for the first time facing domestic pressure to reduce its arms spending in response to the changes sweeping the Warsaw Pact and NATO.

title: In Which They Served
description: To the Editor:

title: All About/Watches;   Watchmakers Are Ringing The Old Back In, as a Varied Industry Revives and Thrives
description: If the modern watch industry had a theme song, it would probably be Peter Allen's ''Everything Old Is New Again.'' Mechanical watches, which all but ceded the market to quartz movements more than a decade ago, are best-sellers again. Analog faces, the ones with big hands and little hands, have recaptured a chunk of the market from digital displays. Multifunction watches - mechanical or electronic, with alarms, stopwatches, even pedometers - are back in vogue.

title: By Horse Through Ireland's West
description: The horses and riders tread softly through the peat bog at the top of a windswept Connemara mountain. Manes and tails wave like the tall russet-tipped grasses of the bog. In the near distance are granite boulders and small pastures enclosed by serpentine lace walls, so called for the holes left for the wind. Bracken ferns fill in some fields; sheep graze in others. One is a graveyard with large Celtic crosses silhouetted against the sky.

title:

title: FICTION
description: AWAY FROM HOME: A Novel in Ten Episodes. By Penelope Farmer. (Victor Gollancz/Trafalgar Square/David & Charles, $19.95.) When it is pointed out to Elinor, the central character in the British writer Penelope Farmer's third novel for adults, that she is letting her feelings run away with her, she rails against the notion that people ought to have a sense of humor, a belief that she equates with not taking oneself seriously. In this collection of 10 chronological episodes, each set in a different locale, Elinor does indeed take herself seriously. The novel begins with her shatteringly lonely stay as a young student in a dismal pension in Munich, then moves to a disappointingly rain-soaked honeymoon in a broken-down tower in France and, as the years pass, on through an unrelieved succession of bad weather and dingy accommodations in places as far-ranging as India, Israel and Spain. But no matter where she is, Elinor's serious preoccupation with her unhappiness is a constant companion. What flashes of irony and humor there are in the book are curiously neutralized. In one chapter, for instance, Elinor finds herself on a kibbutz with her ''oversize, noisy'' lover from Brooklyn, an intellectual who, in searching for his Jewish identity, develops a passion for farming: ''Instead of going on about Norman Mailer and Allen Ginsberg, he told her more than she thought she wanted to know about turkeys.'' But irony needs distance, and even in this unlikely situation Elinor never releases her grip on angst but instead internalizes, in great detail, her sense of dislocation. The narrative structure of ''Away From Home'' is an interesting one, and it is clear that Ms. Farmer has a subtle and expressive command of language. But some perspective and, yes, some humor would have given this book a few more dimensions.

title: Tech Notes;   A New Lease on Life for the Printed Word
description: For libraries around the world, the enemy is time. Since the 1850's, when all-rag paper became prohibitively expensive, printing has been done on wood-pulp paper. But alum, a component in that paper, reacts with atmospheric moisture to form an acid that dissolves the wood fibers: books become discolored and brittle. A new process, developed by Akzo Chemical Inc. of Chicago and the 16-million-volume Library of Congress, may help. Books are first put into an airtight chamber where a vacuum draws out moisture. Next, diethyl zinc, a highly reactive gas, is piped into the chamber under modest pressure to neutralize acid, then removed. The entire computer-controlled treatment takes 60 hours. ''The process leaves books with an alkyline reserve which also protects them from acids in the air,'' said Richard F. Miller, Akzo's project director.

title: After Everything Came to Nothing
description: A LOT TO MAKE UP FOR. By John Buell. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) ''Strange that living should be so difficult,'' muses Stan Hagan, one of the three central characters in this quiet, sad, yet hopeful novel of people struggling to restore meaning and purpose to their lives. Stan, a recovering drug addict and alcoholic, comes to the small Canadian town of Ashton in search of Del Symons, a young woman he mistreated during the time of their mutual enslavement to ''pleasures now joyless that they couldn't stop pursuing.'' He is befriended by Martin Lacey, a retired farmer convalescing from a heart attack, who gives him room and board in return for his help in the small vegetable garden that Martin can no longer maintain alone. Stan and Martin are drawn together by their shared experience of ''having everything come to nothing,'' of finding that even the simplest routines have become acts of will, self-created bulwarks against a sense of isolation and futility that threatens to engulf them. Del, too, needs all her emotional resources just to get through each day. She's straight now, but her infant daughter was born addicted. Del, who cleans houses to support her child, has ''no dreams for the future, it was all she could do to live in the present.'' John Buell, the author of four earlier novels, writes with clarity and exactness of damaged lives and the strength that is needed to repair them. Because Mr. Buell refuses to dress up his characters' all too common problems in flashy literary clothes, ''A Lot to Make Up For'' may strike some readers as drab. Those who look more closely, however, will find a homely lyricism and a deep understanding of human nature that are far more satisfying than verbal pyrotechnics.

Annual Night in Venice Event Produces Frenzy of Preparation
description: LEAD: THE image of bright lights, music and revelry is not what most people expect from Ocean City 364 days of the year. But for the last 36 years, every July - this year on Saturday - this seaside community lets loose for its annual Night in Venice celebration.

title: Talking: 2d Homes;   Lessening Tax Bite on A Resale
description: The sale of a vacation home has never been blessed with the tax advantages that normally help to reduce or postpone indefinitely the capital gains tax due on the sale of a principal residence. This is a problem for the seven million households that the American Resort and Residential Development Association estimates now own second homes.

title: ... AND OF MEMORY
description: THIS MY PEOPLE

title: Connecticut Democrats Split in Peace
description: Connecticut's Democrats split over the choice of a candidate for governor at their state convention here today, forcing the first gubernatorial primary in 12 years. But the break was far less rancorous than many delegates had feared.

title: Over the Bounding Maine?
description: ''COME sailing with us,'' said our friends last week. ''Just bring a bathing suit and a book and relax. We'll do the rest.'' We found out that nothing is as relaxing as a midsummer sail, unless you count childbirth.

title: The Ratio of Values, Dollar and Otherwise
description: To the Editor:

title: Forecast For 'Today': Cloudy
description: Bryant Gumbel's prescription for ''Today'' may be responsible for the decline in the show's ratings, but that's what can happen when network executives mistake a star interviewer-newsman for a market researcher.

title: A Top-Rated Canadian Drama Crosses the Border
description: ''Love and Hate,'' a two-part mini-series beginning tonight on NBC, dramatizes one of the most sensational murder cases in Canadian history: Colin Thatcher, a millionaire rancher and the most flamboyant politician in Saskatchewan, was convicted in 1984 of murdering his former wife or having her murdered.

title: All It Takes Is One Bad Cop
description: It was Sir William Schwenck Gilbert - better known as the Gilbert of Gilbert and Sullivan - who had the good sense to observe (in his lyrics for Act II of ''The Pirates of Penzance''), ''A policeman's lot is not a happy one!''

title: OUR COSTLIEST WAR
description: THE RED KING'S REBELLION

title: Alison Friedman To Marry in Fall
description: October wedding plans for Alison Jennifer Friedman and Ens. Daniel Alexander Miller have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Friedman of New York. Ensign Miller is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor S. Miller of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Grocery Bag Re-use Nets Rewards
description: JANET MURPHY of West Hartford stood in line at the checkout counter of the Cheese and Stuff supermarket in Hartford and handed the cashier a wrinkled brown grocery bag and a green-and-white card. As she watched, the cashier punched the card. When all the holes in the card are punched, Mrs. Murphy will receive one dollar off on a purchase.

title: Three Cars Seized in Inquiry On Car-Bomb Killing on L.I.
description: Suffolk County homicide detectives have seized a workbench and two cars from the home of a Nassau County police officer in the investigation of the car-bomb killing of an undercover detective, law-enforcement sources said.

title: Easing the Task of Buying Lumber
description: BUYING lumber can be confusing. For example, any piece of lumber that is less than two inches thick and eight inches wide is called a strip; any piece less than two inches thick but more than eight inches wide is called a board.

title:
OP-ED;

Gorbachev Only Bought Time
description: LEAD: Like a star in the Moscow Circus, Mikhail Gorbachev stood astride two galloping horses at the 28th Party Congress, brandishing his whip first at one and then the other, to keep them from moving too far apart. Almost to the grand finale, the two horses - the conservatives and the reformers - foaming and bucking, were held together by the realization that otherwise there would be no circus act left.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: Merely to suspend Steinbrenner would be a tragedy. Nothing less than a forced sale of the ball club will rescue the legions of still-loyal Yankee fans and the team from the darkness and disgrace that this egomaniacal man has inflicted on us.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Family Business

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Salt is something associated with health - too little can cause fainting in hot weather and too much can raise blood pressure. But, salt is a necessity, especially in hot climates, and its use has been a curious amalgam of barter and currency for centuries. The word salary, for example, comes from the Latin salarium, which was the money paid to Roman soldiers to buy salt.

title: Alison Gregg Weds E. J. Corcoran 2d
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Margaret Alison Gregg, a daughter of Ambassador and Mrs. Donald P. Gregg of Bethesda, Md., to Edward John Corcoran 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Corcoran of Middletown, R.I.

title: Business Diary/July 8-13
description: INTERNATIIONAL

title: The Vegetarian Snacks of South India
description: AT 7 A.M. in the restaurant at the New Woodlands in Madras, more than 10 people are already waiting in line for breakfast. The scent of coconut drifts through the air as barefoot waiters race past bearing trays loaded with steaming white patties and large, fragrant pancakes. Madrasis and visitors pore over their morning papers, washing down patties and pancakes with small cups of sweet, milky coffee. As sure as the sun rises over the Bay of Bengal, another day begins with idlis and dosas, the all-purpose snack foods of south India.

title: Streetscapes: Morrisania Hospital;   A Tidy Relic of the 1920's Looking for a New Use
description: Hidden by surrounding buildings, the 1929 Morrisania Hospital complex in the Highbridge section of the Bronx comes on you by surprise. It's a full-block derelict, closed since 1976, but all the more surprising because it is such a tidy derelict, with its windows neatly removed.

title: Nancy Chadrjian and John P. Tumelty Are Married
description: Nancy Chadrjian, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, and John Philip Tumelty, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married yesterday at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I. The Rev. George Stack performed the ceremony.

title: FLORIO POPULARITY CRASHES IN SURVEY
description: Approval of Gov. Jim Florio's job performance has plummeted among New Jerseyans over the last three months, as they have reacted negatively to the multitude of tax increases he introduced in his first months in office, a new poll has found.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

Galway's Symbol of Friendship: The Claddagh Ring
description: LEAD: Across Wolfe Tone Bridge from Galway City, on the shores of Galway Bay, lies The Claddagh, a quiet village of tidy houses washed in bright paint, some of them named for saints.

title: Hampshire College
description: As the unofficially designated ''first dropout'' of Hampshire College (1971-72), I would like to describe my impression of the tumultuous first days there (''What's New at Frisbee U.'' by Chip Brown, June 10). Like many applicants, I was mesmerized by the promise of the truly ''progressive'' education described in the college's catalogue. But professors at Hampshire were new at this; some were so afraid they might infringe upon student freedoms that they did not interact at all.

title: SOME PRIMATES WEREN'T TO BE TRUSTED
description: THE DARK ROMANCE OF DIAN FOSSEY

title: Anne H. Rodgers Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Hurd Rodgers of New York and Darien, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Anne Helen Rodgers and Daniel Phillips Rice, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lowry Rice of New Orleans.

title: A Dissent On Thermography
description: Uncritical presentation of a controversial medical procedure, thermography (''Diagnoses by Photographing Body Heat,'' New Jersey Q & A, June 17), is both poor journalism and a disservice to readers, patients, the medical profession and the legal system, to name a few.

title: FICTION
description: BEN. By Max Schott. (North Point, $17.95.) '' 'Mom has a tumor in her brain. It's growing,' I said, brightly. To have a tumor in your brain - like a ship in a bottle - would be novelty enough alone, but to have one growing was nearly a miracle.'' Max, the young boy who narrates this novel by the author of ''Murphy's Romance,'' is naive enough to be fascinated and hopeful about desperate situations, yet he is honest and real enough that the reader never tires of him. At this time of family crisis, Max becomes fascinated with the title character, Ben Webber, a stablehand who works near Max's home in the California ranch country - and has troubles of his own. Chief among these is his wife, Audrey, a younger woman who keeps running off to do trick riding on the rodeo circuit. As the novel progresses, Max and Ben develop a close, though still oddly distant, relationship. When, for example, Max's mother dies and his father decides to marry her sister, Ben is sympathetic to the boy. ''Just because it's good for your dad and Anna,'' Ben tells Max, ''doesn't mean it's good to you.'' Throughout ''Ben,'' Max Schott flirts with the sentimental, but ultimately his characters' dignity saves them, from sentiment and worse. (Even when he's drunk and vomiting, notes Max, Ben ''did it all neatly, like a man who knew how.'') Finally, though, it is Audrey, the malcontent wife, who faces life with the most horse sense. If she loses her footing while balancing on two horses, she just drops ''down onto the back of one horse, before it's too late.'' And if it's too late? ''You just fall off,'' she says blithely, ''between the horses sometimes. They try not to step on you - they don't like squishy things under their feet.''

title: Off Track
description: When Rick Mears leaves his hotel this morning for the five-minute ride to the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford, N.J., where he will be driving in the Marlboro Grand Prix, you can bet he will allow a little extra time. Two hours, perhaps.

title: Books From The Times
description: LANGUAGE MAVEN STRIKES AGAIN. By William Safire. (Doubleday, $22.95.) What is a maven, anyway, and how is it different from a pundit or a boffin? How formal is semiformal? Which is worse, going bananas or going ballistic? When did anxiety turn into stress? William Safire's sixth compilation from his weekly column On Language in The New York Times Magazine - augmented with contributions from friends and readers, the Lexicographic Irregulars - addresses these and many, many other pertinent issues raised in the course of reading, writing, talking and listening in America.

title: With Time and Influence Evaporating, Aquino Finds Rivals All Around Her
description: As her shaky six-year term winds down and her rivals maneuver for 1992 presidential elections, President Corazon C. Aquino is trying almost desperately to preserve some political leverage.

title: Street Fair Killer Committed
description: David R. Peterson, the man found innocent by reason of insanity in the 1989 slaying of a 9-year-old girl at a busy street fair, has been committed to the state's only maximum-security mental hospital. The State's Psychiatric Security Review Board on Friday found that Mr. Peterson was a danger to the public and should remain at Whiting Forensic Institute in Middletown, a board official said. On July 28, 1989, Mr. Peterson walked off the grounds of Connecticut Valley Hospital in Middletown and made his way into town, where he bought a knife and fatally stabbed Jessica Short of Wallingford.

title: Army Plans to End R.O.T.C. at 50 Schools
description: The Army has announced that it will close its Reserve Officer Training Corps program at 50 colleges and universities at the end of the next academic year.

title: Lawmakers Vote to Reduce Allowances of Ex-Presidents
description: The House of Representatives voted Friday to trim the Bush Administration's request for office allowances paid to the four living former Presidents. It rejected a proposal to eliminate the allowances entirely.

title: Two Mamet Hallmarks: Pain and Failure
description: DAVID MAMET'S plays are populated for the most part by characters who are unable to establish meaningful relationships.

title: Taking Issue
description: Behind the success of Armand Hammer was not only his late wife, but also her purse, according to a lawsuit filed last week in Los Angeles. Robert Weiss, the executor of Frances Hammer's estate, charged that soon after their marriage in 1956, a struggling Mr. Hammer borrowed from his wealthy wife - paying little or no interest - to build Occidental Petroleum into an industrial giant and that some of Mr. Hammer's corporate assets rightfully belonged to Mrs. Hammer. He also charged that Mr. Hammer tricked his wife, who died in December, into signing away her interest in an art collection now worth $400 million, an interest that should now belong to Mrs. Hammer's neice and principal heir, Mr. Weiss's wife, Joan. Mr. Hammer the couple was making ''scurrilous charges'' to ''obtain these precious works for their private benefit.''

title: Wall Street;   The Week That Was for Investor Mario Gabelli
description: It was a lucrative week for Mario Gabelli, the New York investor who has long been predicting a wave of takeovers in the independent telephone market. Mr. Gabelli owns 8 million shares of Contel, whose stock leaped $7.125 a share Thursday on the news of its merger with the GTE Corporation. That deal meant a paper profit for Mr. Gabelli of at least $57 million, and most likely much more since he has been buying Contel for some time.

title: Fashion;   Swinging Into Summer Without the Wrinkles
description: ''Knits are the summer's answer to cashmere because they're soft and movable, and they feel good against the body,'' said Donna Karan, the fashion designer. ''They're thoroughly modern for the hot days of summer.''

title: Priscilla Singer To Wed in Fall
description: October wedding plans for Priscilla Singer and James Halper have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Singer of Harrison, N.Y. Mr. Halper is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Halper of Washington.

title: Homeless In America
description: In your article on the homeless, a Department of Housing and Urban Development official comments, ''We can't have socialism for the poor and capitalism for the wealthy.'' In fact, just the opposite is true. President Bush proposes to spend $700 million on housing programs for the poor, while the cost to taxpayers of bailing out the savings and loan industry is estimated at anywhere from $325 billion to more than $1 trillion. Just imagine if those numbers were reversed.
