description: You could spend a lifetime walking up and down Wall Street and never tread on Wall Street Plaza, circle Times Square endlessly and miss 2 Times Square and pace the length of the Avenue of the Americas without entering No. 1325.

title: Houston Scorecard
description: When the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations met last week in Houston, the three main issues of contention were trade policy, aid to the Soviet Union and the environment. Here, by David E. Rosenbaum, a New York Times correspondent who covered the Houston event, is a look at the issues, what the summit meeting produced and the outlook.

title: Summer Concerts in Enticing Settings
description: LISTENING to fine music in beautiful surroundings can add immeasurably to the delight, and this week there are several opportunities to enjoy concerts in esthetically pleasing settings.

title: TB Testing And Treating
description: Although tuberculosis can affect almost any organ, by far the most common form involves the lungs. Its symptoms include a cough, fevers, drenching night sweats, fatigue, weight loss and blood-tinged sputum. They can vary in severity. Some patients dismiss their symptoms as a smoker's cough while others have a serious pneumonia.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

title: Hampshire College
description: Education at Hampshire College encouraged a personal focus. Certainly, not everyone could handle the questions: What do you want? What interests you? In fact, many, for whatever reason -parents, Vietnam, economic status or self-indulgence - found they couldn't handle the absence of structure.

title:
ART;

Brooklyn Collection Shines on East End
description: LEAD: FOR years, the Brooklyn Museum has been one of the best places to study the development of American painting. Its broad collection resulted from generous donors and diligent curators, and an overflow of worthy paintings even prompted the museum to open a pioneering study-storage room some 25 years ago.

title: Outdoors
description: Great rivers cause anglers to fall in love.

title: ACCOUNTING FOR POLITICS IN THE BAILOUT DEBATE
description: ANTICIPATING that the political costs of the savings and loan scandal will begin to come due in the fall, Democrats and Republicans have begun to intensify their efforts to stick each other with the bill. The blame game reached new heights of vituperation last week as attention focused sharply on Neil Bush, the President's youngest son, and his role in the collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Institution in Denver.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Annadale
description: Although the Annadale neighborhood is flat, the district manager of Community Board 3 refers to it as ''the Beverly Hills of Staten Island.'' Situated on 1.8 square miles of the island's south shore, the community is one of the wealthiest in New York City. Some say Annadale owes its cachet to its lack of sewers. Under a 1968 New York City Department of Health ruling, building lots with septic systems can be no less than 100 feet by 100 feet.

title: Yanks Get Close but Fall Short
description: By the second inning yesterday, everything had fallen into place as it always does. The Chicago White Sox had seven runs, the Yankees had none, the afternoon at the Stadium was overcast and dreary, and people were booing, from the box seats to the bleachers.

description: LEAD: NOW that a state law requires all employers to have clear-cut smoking policies, hospitals on Long Island are looking for ways to comply.

title: Once Upon a Time, Berlin, Too, Was a City of Light
description: In the matter of the great city of Berlin, which is now in such a state of ebullition, I have a mental image that many people find perverse. My private Berlin has nothing of the pompous, bombastic, self-satisfied Berlin, all tuba and trombone and bass drum, that was the natural backdrop for the outbreak of World War I. As for the never to be forgotten abominations of 1933-45, they are nowhere foreshadowed. What I see in my mind's eye is a still young city, as yet unmarked by the Industrial Revolution, in which it would be hard to find an ugly thing.

A Stanford White Setting in Irvington

DANCE;

Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: NONFICTION
description: CLOWN PRINCE OF HOLLYWOOD: The Antic Life and Times of Jack L. Warner. By Bob Thomas. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) ''Moguls? Don't like the word,'' Jack Leonard Warner once said. ''It reminds me of some bad Turkish cigarettes I used to smoke.'' Yet for more than 25 years there was perhaps no better word to describe him as he helped run Hollywood and dictate the cinematic tastes of the American public. Warner (1892-1978), a onetime grocer who grew up in Youngstown, Ohio, was one of the four brothers who formed and shaped the Warner Brothers studios. Bob Thomas's new biography, ''Clown Prince of Hollywood,'' is a nimble, readable study of a man who, despite signal achievements in the early days of modern motion pictures, was often viewed as a frustrated comedian who desperately wanted to make people laugh. All Warner did was to revolutionize the modern movie: in 1927 he produced ''The Jazz Singer,'' the first talkie, and through the 1930's and 40's he played a role in selecting the actors and stories that would become ''A Star Is Born,'' ''Casablanca'' and other film classics bearing the Warner Brothers logo. Mr. Thomas, the longtime Hollywood correspondent for the Associated Press, peels back the wisecracking public persona to give us a glimpse at a complex man: the notoriously stingy tipper, the multimillionaire with torn underwear, the man of volatile passions (professional and otherwise). But Mr. Thomas has not written a warts-and-all biography. He offers insights into Warner's creative mind - with a workmanlike background on the genesis of Warner Brothers - and does so with language that is muscular and witty.

title: Taking Bows
description: The Chrysler Corporation had Lee Iacocca; New York University had John Brademas. Not that the university was on the verge of extinction when Dr. Brademas took over as president in 1981, but it was looking to grow and looking for a leader who knew where to look for money. Dr. Brademas did. He came to the university with 11 terms in Congress behind him and quickly became a familiar figure in the New York financial community. As he announced last week that next year would be his last as president, the 63-year-old administrator was widely praised for his role in nearly doubling N.Y.U.'s endowment from $287.3 million to $540 million while transforming the school into a major research institution. Along with adding new areas of study, he also added new places for students to live, building and buying 11 residence halls over the years. ''He's done a wonderful job,'' said Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of the N.Y.U. board.

title: The Fascination of Dinosaurs
description: In the recent interesting article about an exhibition of dinosaurs at the Monmouth Museum (''Don't Pet the Dinosaurs, Museum Hit Show Asks''), it was pointed out that in the first three weeks the exhibition drew 29,000 children and adults, illustrating the fascination that dinosaurs have for people of all ages.

A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 2 1 74 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 3 4 184 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work, revised and updated. 4 * 1 LIFE 101, by John-Roger and Peter McWilliams. (Prelude Press, $18.95.) Advice about coping with the human condition. 5 5 21 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $19.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business.

title: Health Agency Lists 8 Priorities for Region
description: A REGIONAL health-planning agency recently took a hard look at health-care issues in the lower Hudson Valley and concluded that there were eight priority issues urgently requiring attention.

title: Question Of the Week;   Should Baseball Suspend Steinbrenner?
description: No, George should not be suspended. Was Winfield suspended for his check to Spira, taking money from his charity for his own use, and holding back money that he promised to give to his foundation?

title: Nancy Carlson Is Wed to Timothy Berners-Lee
description: Nancy Carlson and Timothy J. Berners-Lee were married yesterday at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., by the Rev. George C. Bland. Mrs. Berners-Lee is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Bret Carlson of Fairfield. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conway Berners-Lee of London.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: 'In the Black': Spectacle at Kent Gallery
description: KENT has art galleries like cities have bars. The number has gone from zero to seven in less than seven years - roughly one per 350 inhabitants. With its vintage railroad station and a Main Street rich in clapboard buildings, the hamlet could never have been an eyesore, but there's no doubt that it has been overtaken by gentrification, gilded store signs and all. Can son et lumiere be far behind?

title: In New Music, Capitalism Meets the Fringe
description: The New Music Seminar started as a conspiracy in 1980. It was a gathering, in one rehearsal studio, of 200 people from the margins of the music business, outsiders plotting to get their music heard. Ten years later, the New Music Seminar is the biggest music-business convention in the United States. This week it will occupy a good part of the Marriott Marquis Hotel in New York with more than 7,000 people registered at $330 a head for an orgy of networking, deal-making and talent-scouting, like the Cannes Film Festival without topless bathing.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: By the Air to the Beach

title: Forecast For 'Today': Cloudy
description: The solution to NBC's ''Today'' problem is so obvious that it appears no one can see it. When a show is so clearly dominated, both in style and content, as ''Today'' is by Bryant Gumbel, there is no real way to ''fix'' the sliding ratings without also doing something about Gumbel.

title: Wife's Heir Sues Armand Hammer
description: The ownership of one of the world's most valuable private collections of art, that of the industrialist Dr. Armand Hammer, has come under attack in a Los Angeles court, as has Dr. Hammer's legal right to bequeath the works to the new museum bearing his name.

title: Clemson to Establish M.B.A. Program in Moscow
description: Students in the Soviet Union will be able to earn a degree that epitomizes capitalism, a master's in business administration, under a program that Clemson University is setting up in Moscow, the university announced today.

title: Lisa S. Garson Marries
description: Lisa S. Garson, a daughter of Louise A. Morris of Beachwood, Ohio, and Peter K. Garson of Pepper Pike, Ohio, was married last evening in Cleveland to Raymond A. DiPrinzio, a son of Yolanda DiPrinzio of New York and the late Mr. DiPrinzio. Rabbi Michael Oppenheimer and the Rev. David A. Novak, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Oakwood Country Club. Mrs. DiPrinzio, 28 years old, is the director of operations control at the Polo/Ralph Lauren distribution center in Carlstadt, N.J. She is a graduate of Amherst College, The bridegroom, 28, is a senior associate at Chemical Securities in New York. He is a graduate of the University of Michigan.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I'M not sure anyone has ever calculated an exact number, but thousands of New Jersey residents will pass up a world of discovery on the way to the Jersey Shore this summer.

title: What's New? Not Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: World Markets;   In Japan, Smaller Is Beautiful
description: What's going on in Tokyo? Why are some small stocks soaring and the lesser-known stock indexes at record highs? With the closely watched Nikkei 225 Index still floundering around 32,600, how can some forecasters still expect it to hit 40,000 - a new high - by the end of the year? And has Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, given a boost to market hopes with his surprising promise to lower American interest rates if credit for businesses and individuals remains too tight?

title: Bridgeport Celebrates Its Diversity
description: TRUMPET fanfares will introduce the 50th anniversary gala of the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival in Norfolk this afternoon at 3, followed by opera arias and vocal duets, short instrumental works of Bartok and Schumann, a Mozart String Quartet and other compositions. The performers, all members of the Norfolk faculty, include the trumpeters Allan Dean and Robert Nagel, the pianists Donald Currier, Ward Davenny and Joan Panetti, the oboist Ronald Roseman, the Tokyo Quartet and others.

title: A Onetime Aide to Bush Shows a Lobbyist's Magic
description: When Robert J. Thompson, a former aide to George Bush, promotes his abilities as a lobbyist, he promises to try to help prospective clients ''solve various problems they encounter in the Washington environment.''

title: Fashion;   Stylish Rainwear's as Welcome as Sun in Summer
description: Summer showers may suggest lighthearted frolic, but if they fall on a work day, serious protection is in order. Happily, new fibers and styling have produced coats that can do the job all year.

title: Investing Is One Thing, Insurance Another
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Coined 'Magical Realism'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwanese Drops Plan to Kill 30,000 Seals n South Africa
description: A businessman has dropped plans to kill 30,000 South African seals after protests by international animal rights advocates, the Government said today.

title: There's Been a Delay At New York's Airports; Stand By for Information
description: To the untrained eye, it seems a mystery. Flights to and from New York airports have increased less than 5 percent over the past year, but delays have in some cases more than doubled.

title: Mets' Marshall in Hospital; Ulcer Is Feared
description: The Mets' Mike Marshall, one day after engaging in an angry clubhouse quarrel with Manager Bud Harrelson over lack of playing time, checked into a hospital here today for what was initially described as a stomach disorder and feared to be a bleeding ulcer. Marshall, a first baseman, was scheduled to remain at Christ Hospital pending further examination.

title: Gypsy Moth Spraying: Other Views
description: Normally I enjoy reading Pete Dunne's ''In the Natural State,'' but he is dead wrong in his recent piece on the gypsy moth.

title: Campus Life: Mississippi;   New Graduates Prepare To Teach in Rural Areas
description: Armed with honors, degrees and noble ambitions, 25 of the nation's brightest scholars are going to battle for better education in some of the neediest schools in this state's rural areas.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PLAYS IN THE MAKING

title:
Your Own Account;

When the Music Stops
description: LEAD: Several weeks ago, Barbara J. Pope, partner in charge of executive financial services for Price Waterhouse in Chicago, and her husband were spending the weekend with friends at their weekend home on the shore of Lake Michigan. The hostess, who works for a Chicago bank, reported that her employer planned to cut the work force by 10 percent.

title: Taking a Rest
description: Job pressures are not limited to the secular world. When Archbishop Eugene A. Marino resigned last week as head of the Atlanta archidiocese, colleagues said he had been under ''a great deal of stress'' in a growing archdiocese with a shortage of priests. The 56-year-old Archbishop had temporarily relinquished his duties in May, when he entered a retreat after suffering chest pains brought on, his doctors said, by ''physical and psychological stresses possibly relating to cardiovascular functions.'' In announcing his resignation, Archbishop Marino, the first black to be appointed a Roman Catholic archbishop in the United States, said that his 175,000 parishioners needed ''a shepherd who is physically, spiritually and psychologically healthy.'' A colleague, Bishop Joseph Francis of Newark, said that the Archbishop had decided to resign with ''the welfare of the church uppermost in his mind.''

title: On One Philippine Village, All the Forces That Rend
description: The road from Lucena, the capital of Quezon Province, bogs down in mud miles from this fishing village at the base of the Bondoc peninsula.

title: Tipping a Hat to the Universality of Modern Dance
description: When Twyla Tharp is presented with the annual Samuel H. Scripps-American Dance Festival Award today for lifetime achievement in modern dance, she will not - as is customary - accept it in a theater. The annual $25,000 award was established by the festival 10 years ago specifically to honor modern dance and its creative personalities. True to form, Ms. Tharp has decided to dispense with the formalities at the festival's home on the Duke University campus in Durham, N.C. Ever the experimentalist, the choreographer has asked that the ceremony be replaced by a square dance in a gym.

title: Shipping Concern Faces $43 Million Penalty
description: A Federal district judge here says he will probably impose a $43 million penalty against a Japanese shipping company for keeping double books to avoid paying a crew of 21 Filipinos most of the wages called for under industry-union agreements.

title: Tokyo Tries to Rewrite Some Recent Bad Memories
description: Japan's Education Ministry, long criticized for sanitizing school textbooks that try to detail Japanese wartime atrocities and the nation's domination of much of Asia, has embarked on a new task: toning down accounts of recent political scandals.

title: Lifestyle;   Shhhhhhhhh! More Men Are Coloring Their Hair
description: The differences between men and women are slowly disappearing, at least in the hair salon. First, men ventured into unisex parlors for hair cuts. Then they tried perms. Now, more are getting color: highlights so locks look sun-touched, or dark streaks to emphasize the pepper rather than the salt.

title: Data Bank/July 15, 1990
Shades of Wild West In Quick-Draw Contest
description: LEAD: ONE Sunday afternoon in 1881, Wyatt Earp, Doc Holliday and Earp's two brothers, Virgil and Morgan, walked the streets of Tombstone, Ariz., to the O.K. Corral for a face-off with an ornery bunch of cow thieves. The experts estimate that the resulting legendary shootout lasted little more than half a minute.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

May I Borrow a Mower?
description: LEAD: SOME people object to the better-grass-through-chemistry approach of lawn services, but my objections are more fundamental. Lawn services deprive people of reasons to interact with their neighbors.

title: Study Finds Americans Want News but Aren't Well Informed
description: When it comes to the news, a survey indicates that Americans are both broadly interested and quite uninformed.

title: Cynthia Morris Martin Plans to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. William N. Martin of West Hartford, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Morris Martin and David Noah Brown, the son of Murton L. Brown of New York and Carol Z. Brown of Boston.

title: The Executive Computer;   Modem Makers Are Picking Up the Pace
description: Computers are getting faster, more powerful and more reliable, and so too are modems, the devices that allow two or more computers to share information over regular telephone lines. Fairly bristling with advanced circuitry, the new modems achieve their performance by taking over a lot of processing done by computer-based software communications protocols. ''The modem is doing much more processing than the computer,'' said Dennis C. Hayes, president of Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. of Norcross, Ga., which for many years has set the industry's standards.

title: Rolling on the Rogue
description: I have always loved rivers. I learned I could feel the rhythms of a river in a canoe. But I hoped that, in a whitewater kayak, I could become part of the river. So I ventured in May to Sundance Expeditions on the Rogue River in southwest Oregon for a nine-day kayaking course.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

A Generation Wasn't Supposed to Grow Up. But It Did.
description: LEAD: I AM really not one of those obnoxious baby boomers who sees portent in everything we do. But, he's going bald. It's not really that noticeable yet, but I can see it coming. We were renting a car - I was at the counter, he was across the street looking at the cars - when I saw it, that tender pink patch the size of a coin, like grass that's been walked on one time too many.

title: Specialty Magazines Whose Specialty Is New Jersey
description: IN a bookstore in Rockaway Township recently, a customer stood in front of an overstuffed rack looking for magazines about New Jersey. An assistant manager pulled five from the shelf. ''We used to carry only New Jersey Monthly,'' she said. ''These others are new to me.''

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Seeing the Wonders Of the World
description: LEAD: THIS may sound strange but I often try to let my mind be empty. When it's empty, I find I'm more open to the beauty of my surroundings and I see things that I might otherwise miss.

title: Campus Life: S.M.U.;   3 Sets of Proposals To Reduce Costs Win Cash Awards
description: Southern Methodist University has begun giving money to students and faculty and staff members whose proposals can help the school save money.

title: Bluemner's Vision of Landscape In Drawings and Watercolors
description: REBUTTING criticism of the 1913 Armory Show, one of the participants, Oscar Bluemner, contended that art was still ''largely misunderstood'' in America. Art is not meant ''to amuse or instruct,'' he said, nor is it to be taken as ''imitation of nature.'' Its purpose, rather, is to elevate and liberate by making ''articulate the life of its time.''

title: BEHIND THE SCREEN
description: WORKING IN HOLLYWOOD

title: Adrianne Benton Weds Robert Furniss
description: Adrianne Craig Benton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Benton of Evanston, Ill., was married yesterday to Robert French Furniss, a son of Susan W. Furniss of Fort Collins, Colo., and the late Norman Furniss. The Rev. George Conway, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: A Cool Respite In Highlands Of Malaysia
description: For the miners, rubber planters and colonial officers who made Malaya their main chance in the late 19th century, the sweltering lowlands must have seemed a trial, to be endured then just as now by repeatedly dousing the body with cold water.

title: Ms. Allen Plans To Wed in August
description: August wedding plans for Judith Gibson Allen and Paul Francis Mulkerrin, a son of Margaret Mulkerrin of Somerville, Mass., and the late Michael Mulkerrin, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Allen of Osterville, Mass.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Latest Study On Breast Cancer Leaves L.I. Women Still in the Dark
description: LEAD: THE French have a wonderful phrase, usually expressed with a philosophical shrug of the shoulders and reserved for those situations that demonstrate the nature of things. The saying, ''Plus ca change, plus la meme chose'' (the more things change, the more they remain the same), is unfortunately also appropriate when assessing the latest findings of the Long Island Breast Cancer

title: Opening Camp With the Quarterback Shuffle
description: After a tedious decision-making process that resulted in his becoming the No. 1 selection in the college draft, after signing a six-year, $15 million contract to play in his hometown for the Indianapolis Colts and after practicing at the Colts' training center for the last month, Jeff George took a vacation in Florida last week.

title: THE PATTERN IN 'THE YELLOW WALLPAPER'
description: TO ''HERLAND'' AND BEYOND

title: Championship Prospect Is Destroyed
description: Grand Canyon, headed for last May's Kentucky Derby until sidelined by injury, was humanely destroyed today after contracting laminitis, a frequently fatal disease of the hoof, Overbrook Farm said.

title: 'Reading Freud'
description: To the Editor:

title: Free to Speak, Bulgarians Aren't Sure What to Say
description: Bulgarians like Stefan Dankov are having a hard time deciding if these will be the ''good old days.''

title: Campus Life: University of Minnesota;   Women Dancers Will Be Allowed To Cheer Again
description: A ban on performances by the University of Minnesota's women's dance line at men's athletic events was rescinded last week by the university's president, Nils Hasselmo.

title: Dream Mile in Oslo Is Won by Falcon
description: Joe Falcon captured the Dream Mile, Carl Lewis won a close 100 meters and Jan Zelezny of Czechoslovakia broke the world record in the javelin tonight at the Bislett Games.

title: College Students, at Least, Aren't Apathetic;   The Most Put Down
description: To The Editor:

title: Savings and Loan Bailout, Soviet Style
description: Read my lips: No more savings and loan crisis.

title: Policeman Facing a Criminal Charge
description: A SCARSDALE police officer who said he had been shot in the line of duty has resigned from the police force and faces criminal charges because forensic evidence did not match his version of the incident, Robert A. Neary, an assistant county district attorney, has announced.

title: NOT ITS FINEST HOUR
description: AN AMERICAN LOOKS AT BRITAIN

title: Performing Troupes Blending Their Art
description: ROBBY BARNETT, an artistic director of the Pilobolus Dance Theater, said he felt ''a bit starry eyed'' when David Hays, the founder and director of the National Theater of the Deaf, suggested two years ago at an art function in Hartford that they collaborate on a new works. Though it was the first time that the leaders of the two Connecticut-based companies had ever met, Mr. Barnett said, he had long admired Mr. Hays troupe, founded in 1967.

title: Style Makers;   Lambros Milona, Designer
description: Just because his father, uncle and grandfather are furriers doesn't mean Lambros Milona has to follow in their footsteps. Although he grew up in the Milona workrooms on Seveth Avenue, he decided to veer slightly off the well-worn track. He set his sights on designing leather and suede ready-to-wear items.

title: Leaving the Groves of Academe for the Fruits of Painting
description: WHEN Virginia Woolf wrote about a room of one's own, she didn't specify which room. She didn't rule out the attic, for instance. Woolf, claiming for women writers the physical space in which to explore spiritual space, left self-image issues to later generations of feminists.

title: IS HE A MATCH FOR THATCHER?
description: The last time Neil Kinnock, the British Labor party leader, came to the White House, in March 1987, he had his work cut out for him, trying to convince President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Anglo-American special relationship and the NATO alliance would actually be strengthened if Labor won the elections that year.

title: Coach Arrested
description: Just two days after he signed a two-year contract to remain head basketball coach at Cleveland State, Kevin Mackey was arrested Friday night on a charge of driving while intoxicated as he left a suspected drug house, the police said. The school immediately suspended him without pay until more is learned about the case.

title: An August Bridal For Susan Parrish
description: August wedding plans for Susan Scott Parrish and Bruce Cordiner Judge have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, T. Kirkpatrick Parrish 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Lawrence A. Bianchi of Boston. Mr. Judge is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. Judge of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Ilene Podgur Is Married
description: Ilene Podgur, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Podgur of Brookline, Mass., was married last evening in Boston to Thomas Vogel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gunter Vogel of Heilbronn, West Germany. Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky officiated at the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Vogel, 28 years old and a graduate of Syracuse University, is the leasing manager at the Mutual of America Life Insurance Company in New York. The bridegroom, 30, is a co-owner of Communication House, an advertising and marketing agency in New York. He is a graduate of the University of Stuttgart and has both a bachelor's degree and a master's from the Art Academy of Stuttgart.

title: Design;   Suspended in Time
description: There were a lot of things Barbara Weiser didn't know. ''It never dawned on me,'' she recalls. ''Like most apartment dwellers, I didn't know that faucets didn't come on sinks or that pipes don't last forever.'' But as an owner of Charivari, the Manhattan clothing chain, she has a sure eye. For years, every time she passed this house she knew it had charm, even though she had never been inside it. And indeed, the structure was originally a ballroom that was part of a large Long Island mansion that still exists nearby. When Weiser bought the house, some of the original oak paneling was intact. So was an elaborate Victorian fireplace and mantel. But a staircase and Formica kitchen occupied a portion of the space where the ballroom had been.

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: East Islip $147,900

title: Quick Call Wins Tom Fool in Upset
description: Quick Call, who usually saves his best races for Saratoga, found a wet Belmont track to his liking yesterday and scored a front-running four-length upset victory over Sewickley in the $87,800 Tom Fool Stakes.

title: Dana Allen Planning to Wed
description: August wedding plans for Dana E. Allen and Benjamin F. Sands, a son of Sarah Darlington Sands of Merida, Mexico, and William F. Sands of Dallas, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Leonard Allen of Lebanon, N.J. Ms. Allen, 29 years old, graduated from Yale University and earned an M.B.A. degree from New York University. She is an investment banker at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The future bridegroom, 39, a Georgetown University graduate, is a vice president of the Garvin GuyButler Corporation, a broker and dealer in institutional capital markets in New York.

title: Review/Ballet;   The Bolshoi's 'Romeo and Juliet,' More Prokofiev Than Shakespeare
description: Ballets named ''Romeo and Juliet'' are not in short supply and most of those on the boards have been created by Western choreographers.

title: Data Verify Economy's Malaise: 16 States in or Near a Recession
description: The national economy has become so sluggish that 16 states, with more than a third of the nation's population, are in a recession or close to one, an analysis of employment data shows. And throughout the country, people are talking of stagnant wages, falling real estate prices, deeply indebted corporations and jobs that are getting harder to find.

title: Quebec Mohawks Keep Up Bridge Blockade
description: Indians locked in a land dispute with the Canadian authorities reversed themselves today and kept up their blockade of a bridge into Montreal.

title: Nancy Walworth Weds Robert Chant
description: Nancy Campbell Walworth, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James C. Walworth of Freeport, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration to Robert James Chant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Richard Chant of Bayport, L.I. The Rev. Daniel S. Harris 3d performed the ceremony, assisted by the bride's father.

title: U.S. Concern On Fake Bills
description: Computers, printers and copiers have become so sophisticated that United States currency and other securities can be counterfeited with remarkable accuracy, the Treasury Department said Friday.

title: Youth Shot Over a Coat Dies
description: A 16-year-old Brooklyn high school student who was shot last Tuesday during a dispute over an expensive coat died yesterday at Brookdale Hospital, the police said. The dead student, Peter Andrews, of 103d Street in the Canarsie section, was shot outside South Shore High School. A 14-year-old suspect, Wayne McIntosh, of Avenue B in the East New York section, now faces homicide charges, which will be considered by a grand jury, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman.

title: South Korea's Hopes For China Trade Ebb
description: Two years ago, the road to China was a winding, almost secret path for South Korean business executives, but one that was illuminated with hope. After a number of bitter encounters, that hope has given way to disappointment and frustration.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After three months of spirited exchanges between Jerusalem and Paris that required the personal intervention of Prime Minister MICHEL ROCARD, and the Minister of Culture JACK LANG, both of France, and the Director General of French Museums, OLIVIER CHEVRILLON, word came that ''formalities connected with the export'' of 103 works by MARC CHAGALL had been completed.

title: Economic Calendar Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.
description: Monday

title: People
description: * Bobbi Blair has been promoted to senior vice president for media at Buena Vista Pictures Marketing.

title: Teen-Ager Convicted in 1988 Murder and Robbery in Bronx
description: An 18-year-old Bronx man was convicted on Saturday night of robbing and killing a construction contractor who employed a friend of his in 1988.

title: Unseating Helms: Rival Charts His Uphill Climb
description: Harvey Gantt is telling the Harvey Gantt story, spinning it into a rich tapestry of the American Dream.

title: Jennifer L. Gentin Becomes a Bride
description: Jennifer Lynn Gentin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Gentin of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., to Mark Steven Lieblein, the son of Joan Lieblein and Dr. Jerome Lieblein, both of San Diego. Rabbi Hillel Silverman officiated.

title: Token Dance Wins Prioress in Upset
description: Token Dance sat behind a sizzling speed duel between the favorites and then whizzed by them through the stretch to post a two-length upset victory over Stella Madrid yesterday in the $882,950 Prioress Stakes at Belmont.

title: Report by World Bank Sees Poverty Lessening By 2000 Except in Africa
description: The first major study of the world's poor in a decade says that poverty is likely to decline by the year 2000, except in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Transit Police Eject Homeless From Train
description: Four men who appeared to be homeless and were sleeping in their seats on an IND A train were ejected without incident last night by transit police so that employees could clean the subway cars.

title: Review/Television;   On One Summer Day in 1989, a Firearm Harvest of Death
description: ''A Day in the Death of America'' is not an elegant piece of work, with its lurid photography, haunted-house music and hyped-up re-enactments. Yet the idea behind it, a recounting of some of the 61 deaths by gun that occurred in the United States on July 16, 1989, is powerful enough to hold you to your set. The grim anniversary is marked at 10 P.M. tonight on HBO.

title: No Excommunication Threats in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Thousands Rally at Kremlin To Shout Disdain for Party
description: Thousands of ordinary citizens marched and rallied outside the Kremlin walls today to demand that the Communist Party concede failure and turn its remaining wealth and power back to the nation.

title: Contenders Take a Back Seat
description: This was not the long-awaited day for Sean Kelly, the man who was and would again be king even if just for a day, if that day occurred in the Tour de France.

title: Roger Stern Is Married to Gail Seibel
description: Gail Cynthia Seibel and Roger Alan Stern were married yesterday at Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I., by Rabbi Laurence A. Kotok. Mrs. Stern is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Seibel of Seaford, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Stern of Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

title: Bernstein Cancels in Japan
description: Leonard Bernstein, suffering from what his doctors and managers said was exhaustion, is cutting short a three-week tour for a new music festival in this country and is returning to the United States for medical treatment.

title: Chicago's Thigpen Pulls Out the Stops
description: Bobby Thigpen, the Chicago White Sox relief pitcher, is not exactly a phenomenon, although it is somewhat phenomenal that he is suddenly the best late-inning closer in baseball.

title: No Excommunication Threats in Europe;   'In Our Opinion'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Suppose you wander into a strange club in another country and sit down behind one of the players. He holds the West cards shown in the diagram, and you wonder whether or not he is an expert. You are mildly surprised that he chooses to open one spade rather than one no-trump: It is obvious that he employs four-card major openings, and you suspect that he favors the weak no-trump opening.

title: Fairy Tales With a Moral: Don't Use Drugs
description: The communications industry will soon aim anti-drug advertising at children 6 to 8 years old, using as its medium not broadcasting or billboards, but bedtime stories.

title: Thankful at 104
description: To the Editor:

title: Dobsonville Journal;   Bulldozers Visit a Township, Followed by Misery
description: After waiting nearly five years in vain for a proper house, Calvin Mukondeli spent his savings of nearly $190 as a down payment on a prefabricated shack of wood and metal that he built for his wife and three children.

title: Kurt Eichenwald Is Wed to Dr. Pearse
description: Dr. Theresa Felicia Pearse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Pearse of New York, was married yesterday to Kurt Alexander Eichenwald, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Heinz F. Eichenwald of Dallas. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Dr. Richard J. Petranek Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Don't Expect Bailout To Stimulate Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. George Wythe, 96, A Former U.S. Official
description: Dr. George Wythe, a former Latin American specialist and section chief in the Department of Commerce, died on June 23 at a hospital in Vienna, where he had lived in retirement. He was 96 years old.

title: Seeing What's New in Now You See It, Now You Don't
description: Marie Blood regaled a standing-room-only crowd of several hundred here tonight with childhood reminiscences of her famous uncle, Harry Houdini, jumping off bridges, escaping from handcuffs and tickling her without using his hands.

title: Florio's School Aid Dream Is Town's Nightmare
description: Education officials here have finished projecting the impact of lost state aid under Gov. Jim Florio's new school financing formula. They say the figures pose nightmarish years ahead for the town's children and taxpayers.

title: Contel Chairman Is 80, But Shuns Retirement
description: After finding a safe berth for the Contel Corporation, with the proposed merger of Contel into the GTE Corporation, some might expect Charles Wohlstetter to feel that his work is complete and think about retirement.

title: Review/Opera;   A Plausible Semi-Staged 'Pique Dame'
description: Like Zubin Mehta, Seiji Ozawa seems eager to expand his operatic activities. Perhaps partly for that reason, he has taken to offering semi-staged operatic productions every summer with the Boston Symphony at its Tanglewood festival in the Berkshires. This year's installment was tonight's ''Pique Dame,'' and despite some reservations it turned out to be a genuinely effective realization of one of Tchaikovsky's masterpieces.

title: Yanks Swept as Boos Follow Mattingly
description: The ball settled into Carlton Fisk's glove, and then the boos fell around Don Mattingly like rain. They followed him from home plate to the dugout, where he sat on the bench and listened to the growing frustration.

title: Discussions Are Held On Fast Data Network
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and officials at a group of Michigan universities have quietly begun discussions with the Federal Government about creating a nonprofit company that would operate a high-speed computer network that could one day reach every home in the country.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Buckeye Financial Corp., Columbus, Ohio, a holding company, named Michael Thomas chairman and chief executive of its principal subsidiary, Buckeye Federal Savings and Loan Association.

title: Kenneth G. Zalkin, Lawyer, 46
description: Kenneth G. Zalkin, a lawyer, died on Saturday at the Ritz Tower in Manhattan. He was 46 years old.

title: Official Sees No Crime by Bush's Son
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that the Justice Department was not convinced that Neil Bush, the President's son, had engaged in criminal actions while a director at the failed Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver.

title: Another War - the One on Poverty - Is Over, Too
description: The New York Times headline on July 7 was exuberant: ''NATO Allies, After 40 Years, Proclaim End of Cold War.''

title: Critic's Notebook;   Now at a Theater Near You: A Skyrocketing Body Count
description: In ''Die Hard 2,'' the new film that is less a sequel to than a remake of the 1988 hit ''Die Hard,'' Bruce Willis uses an icicle to stab a man in the brain via the eye socket. Later, another unfortunate man is sucked into a 747's jet engine and comes out the other end looking like borscht.

title: Gen. George L. Mabry Jr., 72; Was Awarded Medal of Honor
description: Gen. George L. Mabry Jr., who won the Medal of Honor in World War II and later commanded American forces in the Panama Canal Zone, died Friday at Richland Memorial Hospital in Columbia, S.C. He was 72 years old and lived in Columbia.

title: Joseph P. Dougherty, Broadcast Executive, 66
description: Joseph P. Dougherty, a retired executive vice president of Capital Cities/ ABC, died on Saturday in Point Pleasant Hospital in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: A Final Test for the Board of Estimate
description: Two final decisions on pivotal land-use questions face the Board of Estimate before it ceases to exist under terms of the new City Charter. One decision appears easy; the other, difficult. They will be remembered as a test of wisdom and courage as the board closes its 90-year run.

title: Drama Is Past Tense in Georgia Race
description: Near the end of a debate on Saturday between the five Democratic contenders for governor, former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta said he wanted to sum up what distinguished him from his opponents.

title: 2 Airlines End Dispute
description: The Spanish state-owned airline Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana S.A. said it had reached an agreement with the AMR Corporation's American Airlines unit to resolve a four-month dispute on booking systems. It said more details of Iberia's flights to the United States would be provided to American Airlines' Sabre booking system.

title: Nabisco Refinance Plan Set
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said last night that it would begin its $6.9 billion refinancing program today, buying back some of its high-yield ''junk bonds'' in the open market, receiving additional equity and securing new bank loans.

title: Courts Are Undoing Efforts To Aid Minority Contractors
description: As a result of a recent Supreme Court decision, courts around the country are dismantling state and local programs that set aside contracts for companies whose owners are members of minority groups.

title: Showing of Pride For the Iroquois
description: The final standing of the 1990 lacrosse world championships may read four losses in a row for the Iroquois Nationals, but team officials are calling the Native Americans' return to international competition after a century's banishment a major success.

title: Some in Eastern Flock See Dream: Patriarch Worships in Manhattan
description: Maria Kollaris, a 70-year-old widow dressed completely in black, wept as His Holiness Dimitrios I, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, entered the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on East 74th Street.

title: 4 Children Are Killed in Car With 13-Year-Old at Wheel
description: With a 13-year-old girl behind the wheel while her uncle was using one hand to help steer, a station wagon went into a rain-swollen creek, killing four children, the police said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fred/Alan Takes to The Streets
description: AT first glance, the new campaign for Barq's soft drinks is nothing out of the ordinary, with shots of soda cans under the headline, ''So try 'em already.''

title: A Therapy Based on Tapping Your Feet
description: DURING running, the feet absorb a great amount of shock and transmit signals of distress to the legs, the back and other parts of the body. Now the growing field of reflexology offers runners a chance to use their feet as a source of comfort, healing and even runner's high.

title: Cummins Will Sell 27% Stake
description: The Cummins Engine Company yesterday announced a series of transactions that would give it an immediate infusion of $250 million in fresh capital in return for surrendering a 27 percent stake to the Ford Motor Company, Tenneco Inc. and Kubota Ltd. of Japan.

title: Adirondacks to Help Trout by Poisoning Rivals
description: Reachable only after hours of paddling and portaging through the northern Adirondack wilderness, Bessie and Nellie Ponds look like a fisherman's paradise. The waters are still and deep, and the woods are so quiet that a loon's call seems almost startling. But there is a problem: The fishing is lousy.

title: Mildred Falk Loew, Editor and Author, 79
description: Mildred Falk Loew, a former editor and part owner of The American Mercury magazine, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old.

title: 3 to Share DHL Stake
description: The Japan Air Lines Company, Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. and the Nissho Iwai Corporation, a Japanese trading company, agreed to take a combined stake of 2.52 percent in the DHL Corporation, the American holding company of the DHL World Express air-courier service. J.A.L. and Lufthansa will each own 1 percent and Nissho will buy the remaining stake, subject to the approval of the United States Government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We began putting nuts in our mouth and testing them on our teeth, and I must say our teeth are strong. We'll crack them.''

title: William Burrud, 65, Television Producer Of Nature Programs
description: William James Burrud, a television producer and narrator of nature shows and travelogues, died Thursday at his home in Sunset Beach, Calif., after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: A Decisive Victory For Michael Andretti
description: The Marlboro Grand Prix was the kind of Indy-car race in which Arie Luyendyk could finish fourth after driving his car toward the Lincoln Tunnel, Teo Fabi could finish third without brakes or a clutch, and Michael Andretti could win while keeping an eye on his fuel gauge.

title: A 'Manhattan Project' for AIDS
description: LEAD: I am so frightened that the war against AIDS has already been lost.

title: Airline Ruling In Argentina
description: Argentina's Supreme Court has removed a legal obstacle in the privatization of the Aerolineas Argentinas carrier, the official news agency said on Saturday.

title: Employers Can Do Something About L.I. Traffic
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROSE KENNEDY was briefly wheeled before a large group of relatives and guests who marked the family matriarch's 100th birthday celebration yesterday with a gathering on the lawn outside her home.

title: U.S. Must First Support Korean Democracy;   Lessons of the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Haagen-Dazs Account Dropped by Margeotes
description: Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss an-nounced Friday that it had resigned the Haagen-Dazs Company account.

title: Question Box
description: All-Star Sluggers

title: No New Nuclear Missiles for NATO
description: As Soviet forces withdraw from Eastern Europe and NATO moves smartly to reduce its dependence on nuclear weapons, it makes no sense for the alliance to consider deploying new tactical air-to-surface missiles. But NATO is planning to do just that if Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain, with President Bush's backing, has her way.

title: Hormone Therapy Seen to Cut Risk of Broken Hip
description: Women who begin hormone replacement therapy at or near menopause can sharply decrease their risk of having a broken hip in the next decade, a new study of 23,000 women has shown.

title: Royals Rout Red Sox, 13-4
description: Gerald Perry led an 18-hit attack with a single, double and three stolen bases as the Kansas City Royals scored three runs to break a sixth-inning tie today and beat the Boston Red Sox, 13-4.

title: Business Scene;   Unexpected Shift In a Labor Rate
description: AN era might be ending, unexpectedly. Americans have been jumping into the labor force in ever-increasing numbers since the 1960's, so that today about 66.4 percent of the working-age population holds jobs or seeks them. The problem is that the labor participation rate, as it is called, was the same 66.4 percent a year ago. Having risen year after year, it might finally be leveling off -and just when the Labor Department and many economists did not expect it to be.

title: Festival Ends Amid Questions
description: The 12th Olympic Festival ended this evening with solid reviews for a job well done, but also with a nagging question that has remained unanswered for the last five years: What does it all mean?

title: Corrections Detroit Set For Talks With U.A.W.
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers. At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers. Also, a chart with the article misstated the average hourly wage paid last year to workers at Honda of America. It was $15.32, including 77 cents for profit-sharing.

title: Powerboating: Women and the Sea
description: WOMEN who go to sea on powerboats tend to go along for the ride. Although a vast majority of the 15 million recreational boats in the United States are powerboats, it is not the women of America in charge of driving.

title: Diplomacy Fails to End Store Boycott In Flatbush
description: Little but the seasons have changed in front of the Korean-owned Family Red Apple grocery store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Acid Test for New Hearst Magazines
description: With virtually no advance publicity, Jupiter, a sprightly looking astrology magazine, appeared last winter on newsstands across the country. A second issue followed months later.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MAYOR DAVID N. DINKINS of New York was struck in the right eye by a tennis ball yesterday during a celebrity tournament match with MAYOR SHARPE JAMES of Newark at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens.

title: Review/Television;   Martin Scorsese as Seen By Friends and Peers
description: Public television's ''American Masters'' has been dedicating the first three weeks of its new season to film directors. So far there have been documentaries about Preston Sturges and John Cassavetes. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, there's ''Martin Scorsese Directs,'' an hourlong biography produced and directed by Joel Sucher and Steven Fischler, former film students of Mr. Scorsese. The probing isn't terribly deep, but the overall result is a helpful and engrossing primer on the life and career of one of this country's most consistently rewarding film makers.

title: Kodes All Smiles
description: JAN KODES of Czechoslovakia, who was inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame at the Newport (R.I.) Casino on Saturday, has had other things to smile about recently.

title: Mets Stumped and Silenced by 'Nasty' Reds
description: The Nasty Boys had their nasty stuff, a rude state of affairs that made for a very quiet, very polite exit by the Mets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;   For Networks, the Punch Line Is a Bigger Bottom Line
description: THE sound stages are being re-activated here this week as production begins on the fall season's television series. And the large majority of those stages will be filled with people telling jokes.

title: Market Place;   Digital Finally Follows a Trend
description: KENNETH H. OLSEN, the founder and president of the Digital Equipment Corporation, has always been a rugged individualist who has studiously avoided fads and fashions in the computer industry.

title: Metro Matters;   How to Crack The Blue Wall Of Police Silence?
description: On the same day recently that the New York Civil Liberties Union was criticizing the Police Department's ability to police itself, a police sergeant in Brooklyn was suspended after two officers accused him of brutality. Investigators are struggling to corroborate the allegation. Everybody agrees, though, that its source was unusual.

title: For Judge in Barry Trial, Prime Concern for Jury
description: When Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court here learned that he had been selected to preside over the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., he said he had two immediate thoughts: It was going to be an exciting episode in his judicial career, and he would have to sequester the jury.

title: In Iran, a Glimpse of Ankle Can Bring Out the Komiteh
description: ''My socks, my socks!'' the panicky Iranian woman said, throwing off her shoes and hurriedly trying to pull socks over her bare feet as the officer approached the taxi. Noticing that the young woman was accompanied by a Western visitor and apparently wanting to avoid an incident, the officer waved the car on without inspection.

title: Joseph Blumenthal, Typographer For Frost's Poetry, Is Dead at 92
description: Joseph Blumenthal, a publisher and typographer who printed special editions of Robert Frost's poems for more than 30 years, died on Wednesday at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 92 years old.

title: Gang Poses as Police in Bronx Robberies
description: An armed gang, its members impersonating plainclothes police officers and drug agents right down to their bulletproof vests and the red bubble on their car's dashboard, robbed and ransacked two multifamily houses in the Bronx on Saturday, the police said yesterday.

title: 'Harmony' And the Mets
description: THE newspaper story out of Cincinnati yesterday reported that Mike Marshall of the Mets had checked into a hospital ''for what was initially described as a stomach disorder and feared to be a bleeding ulcer.''

title: Rail Line Makes Debut In the Land of Freeways
description: With a mixture of fanfare and skepticism, Los Angeles this week opens the first leg of a multibillion-dollar, 150-mile commuter rail line intended to help save this car-choked city from a future of paralyzed roads and unbreathable air.

title: King Wins At the Open
description: After spending three rainy days shooting two of the best rounds ever played in a United States Women's Open, Patty Sheehan undid it all with two terrible rounds in one sun-drenched Sunday to lose the championship to Betsy King.

title: Waiting to Click
description: EARLY last month, Mike Kelley, a sophomore at Arizona State, was named the 1990 Baseball America player of the year as the country's best college player, joining an impressive list of previous winners, including Dave Magadan of the Mets, the 1983 winner; Oddibe McDowell of the Atlanta Braves (1984), Pete Incaviglia of the Texas Rangers (1985), Casey Close (1986), Robin Ventura of the Chicago White Sox (1987), John Olerud of the Toronto Blue Jays (1988) and Ben McDonald of the Baltimore Orioles (1989).

title: China-Soviet Venture Seen
description: The cautious process of rebuilding the strained relations between the Soviet Union and China have taken another modest step forward with a report here today that the first Chinese-Soviet joint venture in China will soon be established.

title: Ella Fran Gleimer Becomes a Bride
description: Ellen Fran Gleimer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sol E. Gleimer of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., to Richard Earl Hustead, a son of Mrs. Frank Driskill of Glendale, Calif. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor Howard Stahl officiated.

title: Argentine Thieves Slain, Igniting Debate on Justice
description: A few weeks ago, a man shopping in a suburban store heard the sound of glass breaking and ran outside in time to see two men getting into their car with the tape deck from his car.

title: Slovenia Hopes to Find New Role in Yugoslavia
description: Under pressure from the federal Government and burdened by economic problems, the newly elected leaders in the Yugoslav republic of Slovenia are pressing to forge a sovereign state and recast Slovenia's relationship with the country's five other republics.

title: GORBACHEV ORDERS CHANGE IN CONTROL OVER TV AND RADIO
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ordered today that the state broadcast monopoly be drastically revamped to allow a more democratic and competitive variety of broadcast outlets that might further shrink the Communist Party's power over national life.

title: Publishing World Is Shaken As Advances for Books Soar
description: Many publishers were irate three weeks ago after Dell Publishing agreed to pay $12.3 million for Ken Follett's next two novels. Now, having had time to think it over, they are even angrier, in part because HarperCollins quickly bought three books by Jeffery Archer, for what the British author said was more than $20 million.

title: INSIDE
description: World Poverty and Africa

title: U.S. Must First Support Korean Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: On Wall's Site, a Communist Garage Sale
description: Perhaps the surest sign that Communism is crumbling is that the price of its pieces is falling.

title: Marjorie Dermer Becomes a Bride
description: Marjorie Frances Dermer and Dr. Joshua Isaac Dorsky were married yesterday at the Davenport Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Rabbi Lawrence Raphael. Mrs. Dermer-Dorsky is a daughter of Mrs. Joseph Dermer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Dermer. Her husband is a son of Marsha Dorsky and Morris Dorsky, both of New York.

title: Ambulance Blockers, You're on Camera
description: To the Editor:

title: An American Is Watching the British Press
description: When it comes to criticizing the British press, nobody here beats an American, Bob Borzello.

title: World Farm Subsidies in Trade-Talk Spotlight
description: When international trade talks reconvene in Geneva on July 23, the negotiators will resume their long-stalled discussions of agriculture subsidies.

title: Carcasses of 23 Gray Whales Wash Up on Islands in Alaska
description: Twenty-three gray whale carcasses have washed up on two remote islands in the Gulf of Alaska, and scientists plan a study to determine why they died.

title: Expos Outslug Braves, 16-14
description: Andres Galarraga hit a three-run home run in the sixth inning and drove in the tie-breaking run with a ninth-inning single today as the Montreal Expos took advantage of poor Atlanta fielding for a 16-14 victory.

title: The Other Guy Did It
description: Ed Rollins, the able and usually unflappable Republican strategist, sounded defensive and more than a little panicky at his party's Chicago meeting last week. He was trying to claim that it was the Democrats who had ''sold out the taxpayers'' in the colossal savings and loan scandal.

title: New Chief of BBC Unit To Push U.S. Expansion
description: BBC/Lionheart Television International Inc., the distributor in the United States for the British Broadcasting Corporation's programming, has named Sarah Frank president and chief executive.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Putting Together the Pieces of an Unfinished Book
description: The covered arcades of Paris, wrought with iron and surmounted by sparkling ceilings of glass, have been among that city's most celebrated architectural features since the 19th century. But for Susan Buck-Morss, an associate professor of government at Cornell University, the arcades have been the focus of a lengthy task of scholarly detective work, an attempt to decipher a massive, mysterious, unfinished tome by a renowned critic and philosopher who has been dead for 50 years.

title: Laura Ioachim Marries Martin Reichel
description: Laura Ioachim, a medical student at the State University of New York Health Science Center in Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Martin Reichel, a resident in dermatology at the University of California Medical Center at Davis. Rabbi Stanley Bramnick officiated at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Wednesday misstated the type of magazine to be included quarterly with People magazine. It will be a version of In Health, a three-year-old magazine published by Time Warner and Hippocrates Partners; it will not be a new magazine.

title: Computer Lawsuit Criticized by Japanese
description: Kubota Ltd. said today that a lawsuit filed against it by two Silicon Valley entrepreneurs was ''baseless and irrational'' and suggested that the men were trying to enrich themselves.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 16:

title: Big Soviet Harvest Seen
description: The prospects are still good for a bumper grain harvest in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said last week. Total grain production is estimated at 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million in 1989, the department said in a report. That would be the largest since a record 237.4 million tons in 1978. Expected Soviet grain imports for the 1990-91 year that began on July 1 were unchanged from the previous forecast: 36 million tons, compared with 38 million in 1989-90.

title: One-Legged Runner Tries to Inspire Others
description: IN the world of track and field, a difference of 1.9 seconds separates Carl Lewis from Dennis Oehler. In life, however, there is a greater difference between the two men.

title: Southmark's Insolvency
description: A court-appointed examiner has charged that the Southmark Corporation's former top officers caused the collapse of the real estate concern and then concealed its failing financial condition with the help of outside auditors.

title: Brooke Hillary, Student, Is Wed
description: Brooke Elizabeth Hillary and William Elwood Schmearer 4th were married yesterday at the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Paul D. Alcorn. Mrs. Hillary-Schmearer is the daughter of Grace Harvey Fuller of Lindenhurst, L.I., and Norman Sheresky of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schmearer 3d of Pottstown, Pa. The bride, 27, is a candidate for a doctorate in clinical psychology at Hofstra University. She graduated from Colgate University and has a master's degree in psychology from the University of Miami.

title: At St. Andrews, the Memories Match the Mystique
description: BRITISH OPENS are unavoidably memorable when they are held at the Old Course in St. Andrews, Scotland.

title: Shots Are Heard
description: THERE is a touch of ceremony in the way traditional yachtsmen run their races. But the routine was interrupted during one of the first races of the Liberty Cup Regatta two weeks ago in New York Harbor. The marine division of the New Jersey State Police became part of the act, much to the chagrin of the race committee.

title: Capital Led the Nation In '88 Justice Spending
description: The District of Columbia spent $859 per person in 1988 for police protection, the courts, jails and other criminal and civil justice services, higher by far than any state and four times the national average, the Justice Department said in a report released today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHARLES KURALT has turned down a request by a group of archaeologists to dig up the front lawn of his Connecticut vacation house.

title: After 19 Killings, Many More Livery Cabdrivers Quit
description: Midway through a 12-hour shift in which he had driven from one end of the Bronx to the other for $9.50 and to points in between for lesser fares, Joe DeMaio parked outside the Thruway Private Taxi Company and explained why the killings of 19 cabdrivers this year have not frightened him.

title: Norris Is Released by A's
description: When the Oakland Athletics placed Carney Lansford on the 15-day disabled list today and called up two minor leaguers, they also released the pitcher Mike Norris, who was attempting a comeback after a six-year absence from the major leagues.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Books of The Times;   English: A Linguistic Success Story
description: The Mother Tongue

title: Outdoors: Dog Days, Trout Days, and Yesterdays
description: EVEN though it was late afternoon when Vic Pomiecko of Claremont, N.H., and I reached Chapin Pond, the heat was oppressive. It was not ideal trout-fishing weather. The surface temperature of the pond was 72 degrees, too hot for trout, which begin to languish when the water gets much above 65 degrees. No fish were rising, and our only hope was to plumb the depths with sinking lines.

title: Dinkins Appoints a New Sheriff to Collect Billions Owed in Fines
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has appointed a new city sheriff to head what amounts to an expanded central municipal collection agency that will seek to recover some of the more than $4 billion owed over the years to the city. About $2 billion is owed by motorists who have ignored parking fines and penalties.

title: Alejandro Galido, Philippine General, 54
description: Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido, a figure in the events of last December, when dissidents in the Philippine military failed in a coup attempt, died today of liver cancer, officials said. He was 54.

title: Romania Struggles to Improve Its Image
description: While Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister argues for a new political architecture in Europe and Poland's Foreign Minister concentrates on safeguarding his nation's postwar borders, Romania's new Foreign Minister, Adrian Nastase, has a different focus: helping his nation join the family of Europe.

title: KOHL SEES SOVIETS AMID UPBEAT MOOD
description: Smiling and bantering like old friends, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that they expected major progress in their talks on lifting the last obstacles to German unity.

title: Accounts
description: * Western Publishing Group, to Berenter Greenhouse & Webster for its Games Gang Ltd. division, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Revamped 'Brazil Inc.' To Make Case to Banks
description: Having started an overhaul of the economy and a striking removal of trade barriers, the Government of Brazil is now looking to the international financial community for support.

title: Sudan Asserts It Just Helps Refugees Go Back to South
description: The Government said on Saturday that it was helping about 190,000 refugees return to the south, where they had fled famine and civil war.

title: States Seek Tougher Drug Forfeit Laws
description: Federal prosecutors have captured public attention in recent years with their seizures of jets, mansions and office buildings owned by drug dealers. But state prosecutors, who handle 90 percent of all drug cases, find themselves frustrated by laws that generally restrict them to confiscating only the beepers, automobiles and cash in the possession of suspects when they are seized.

title: A Way to Drink and Dive
description: A scuba diver in Miami has developed a pouch that allows divers to drink fluids under water. The device comes with a collapsible bag that feeds beverages through a port in a specially designed mouthpiece.

title: Net at Federal Express Rises
description: The Federal Express Corporation said last week that its profits rose 5.1 percent in its fourth quarter but slumped for the year in large part because of the acquisition of Tiger International.

title: 125,000 Attend Base's Air Show, Billed as Panama Re-enactment
description: About 125,000 people attended an air show on Saturday that was billed as a re-enactment of the invasion of Panama, but the military, reacting to criticism of insensitivity to those who were killed, played down the event.

title: United States Tops Canada for the Title
description: Kevin Cook and Roddy Marino each scored four goals today to lead the United States to a rain-splattered 19-15 victory over Canada in the Lacrosse World Series championship game.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS WAY TO AID NASA
description: Concerned over recent troubles with the Hubble telescope and the space shuttle, the White House has been holding discussions on how to shore up support for the nation's space program, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: Little Change Expected for Rates
description: The bond market, which has so far this summer received help from both the President of the United States and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, may have a more difficult time finding new friends in the weeks ahead. But without further assistance, credit market analysts said, interest rates were not likely to decline much from current levels, and might even rise.

title: Good and Bad S & L Politics
description: Suddenly it's open season for savings and loan politics. Some House Democrats have been pressing for an independent counsel to investigate President Bush's son Neil. A clutch of Democratic and Republican Representatives feel the scandal's heat in their races for re-election. And both houses are rushing bills to beef up the pursuit of S & L crooks.

title: Covenant House's New Broom
description: Sister Mary Rose McGeady's priorities are very clear. She told an interviewer she's not aware of any more important job in America than ''taking care of our troubled young people.'' Fortunately for thousands of troubled young people, she's earned the chance to do just that, as the new director of Covenant House.

title: Sizing Up Germans: A Thatcher Symposium
description: A British newspaper reported today that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher convoked a daylong seminar of historians and German experts in March that discussed positive and negative aspects of the Germans.

title: Cutting Desk-Top Publishing Costs
description: IF you cannot justify the cost of software or more capable hardware needed to run a top-of-the-line desktop publishing program, you still might consider a low- or mid-priced offering. One of them, Avagio, produces handsome printed pages at a good price, and your present equipment may well be all you need.

title: Applause, Confusion On RJR Debt
description: Prices of some RJR Nabisco ''junk bonds'' soared - though not to expected levels - in heavy trading yesterday, as a $6.9 billion refinancing plan was generally well received by Wall Street.

title: Lake Shore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ashton-Tate Sells Software Product
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation said it was selling its dBase Mac software product to New Era Software Group Inc., a Miami-based company specializing in software for Apple Computer's Macintosh.

title: Flextronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
$73 Million Sought From Eddie Antar
description: A Federal District judge ordered Eddie Antar to turn over $73 million he made through his Crazy Eddie electronics empire. Federal officials say Mr. Antar, who has been missing since he appeared in court on Feb. 13, made the money with fraudulent record-keeping and insider trading at Crazy Eddie Inc., now defunct.

title: Chase Manhattan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Chase noted that its latest second quarter net was adversely affected by a $75 million increase over the year- ago period in the provision for possible credit losses, principally due to adverse conditions in certain domestic real estate markets. Earnings for this year's first half were adversely impacted by a $150 million increase in the provision for possible credit losses over a year ago.

title: Airsensors Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Latest results included first year of combined operations for Airsensors and Impco, acquired in March 1989.

title: Racial Suit by a Black Against a Black Fails
description: A Federal judge ruled today that a woman's poor attitude led to her dismissal by the Internal Revenue Service, not racial discrimination as she had charge in a lawsuit.

title: Our Towns;   All-Natural Food For the Dog Who Has It All
description: ''It's Shelbie's birthday?'' asked Jordana Bloom, petting a customer at her gourmet health-food store. ''It's your birthday, Shelbie? Did you tell Jeannette it's Shelbie's birthday?'' Jeanette Champsaur, star saleswoman at Lick Your Chops, was up front finishing a high-protein, high-fiber order for a new customer, Wizzy Wig. ''Shelbie's three?'' asked Ms. Bloom, petting the customer some more. ''Let's get her birthday gifts started.'' Would Shelbie like a freshly baked whole wheat biscuit with carobs? Perhaps some imported New Zealand mutton for Shelbie? ''Jeanette, it's Shelbie's birthday!''

title: Goodrich Net Increases 5.9%
description: The B. F. title: Larkin H. Farinholt, 84, Professor And Sloan Foundation Executive
description: Dr. Larkin H. Farinholt, a chemistry professor and foundation executive who held a number of scientific posts in Washington, died Thursday at the Long Green Nursing Home in Baltimore. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan and Leonia, N.J., for many years. A daughter, Kathryn, said he died of pneumonia. From 1960 to 1973 he was administrator of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation's $1.2 million-a-year program for basic research in physical sciences, which selects promising young scientists to receive grants as research fellows.

title: Bridge

Terrell Spurns Minors
description: The pitcher Walt Terrell is declining his demotion to the Pittsburgh Pirates' Class AAA farm club in Buffalo. ''He's not going to Buffalo; he's not even considering going to Buffalo,'' Terrell's agent, Alan Meersand of Manhattan Beach, Calif., said yesterday. On Saturday, Terrell, who had a 2-7 record, was given three days to accept or reject the assignment to the farm club. The right-hander's refusal to report means he will become a free agent and, if he is not traded, the Pirates will be responsible for paying off his three-year $3.6 million contract.(AP)

title: Review/Performance Art;   Ann Magnuson, a Cast All by Herself
description: At a time when New York City edges steadily toward chaos, it's no coincidence that Thornton Wilder's ''Our Town'' should exert a special fascination on local theater artists. Wilder's evocation of New England small-town life at the turn of the century serves as a central text for ''Route 1 and 9,'' the Wooster Group's theatrical collage about the decline of the New York. A full-scale revival of ''Our Town'' was subsequently mounted by the Lincoln Center Theater. And now the performance artist Ann Magnuson's one-woman show ''You Could Be Home Now,'' which opened Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival, uses the same play as a crucial point of departure.

title: The Education of Jim Florio
description: Gov. Jim Florio has courageously raised New Jersey's taxes, and his reward is a 19 percent crash in popularity. His experiment is being watched around the country by Democrats who wonder if voters can be persuaded to overcome their resistance to taxes. Mr. Florio doesn't deserve to be punished for his honesty, but he does need to explain better what he is doing and why.

During the second quarter, the company strengthened its reserve for possible loan losses by providing $186 million, an action that was prompted by increases in non-performing loans primarily due to deterioration in New Jersey's real estate markets and overall economic environment. In addition, in the second quarter, the corporation's allowance for other real estate owned was increased by $19 million. The company said that partially offsetting the additions to the reserves were non-recurring gains of $68 million from the sale of its credit card accounts and receivables, as well as the sale of securities backed by automobile and home equity loans originated by the company's lead bank, Midlantic National Bank.

But far from having the decency to sit down for dinner, most parasites in nature suck the blood, sip at the gastric juices of the intestines, pierce into the nourishing warmth of muscle tissue and otherwise leech rudely off the fluids and labors of their unwilling hosts.
