description: Every summer the power pack migrates to the Rockies, where the Aspen Institute holds its symposium on domestic and international affairs. This year, MARGARET THATCHER and PRESIDENT BUSH will speak to 400 government and business leaders at the institute's 40th anniversary symposium.

title: First Chicago Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter's earnings included tax benefits related to 1987's net operting loss and a gain of $13.5 million from the sale of First Chicago's merchant processing business of its bank credit card operations.

title: Education Consumers Should Have a Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Frequency Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Queens Pitcher to Jays
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have persuaded the pitcher Steve Karsay, who was 14-1 with Christ the King High School in Middle Village, Queens, last season, to forgo college and pursue professional baseball. Karsay was Toronto's first pick in the June free-agent draft. The 18-year-old Karsay said he signed a one-year deal and received a big signing bonus, but he refused to get into specifics. The right-handed Karsay, who had said he planned to attend Louisiana State, was assigned to St. Catharines of the Class A New York-Penn League. Also yesterday, the Texas high school pitching star Todd Van Poppel, who had said he would attend the University of Texas, signed with the Oakland A's.(AP)

title: Salick Health Care reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Ford Will Build Plant in Hungary
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would invest $80 million to build an auto parts factory in Hungary, joining its rival, the General Motors Corporation, in setting up shop in the Eastern European nation.

title: John Musser, 82, Dies; Weyerhaeuser Official
description: John M. Musser, an executive of the Weyerhaeuser Company and its affiliated businesses from 1934 until his retirement in 1978, died Saturday at his home in St. Paul. He was 82 years old.

title: Business and Health;   Programs to Keep Retirees Healthy
description: AT the Campbell Soup Company's fitness center in Camden, N.J., Bill Brown, a 79-year-old retiree, leads an exercise class called flexibility.

title: Savings Unit Hearings Set
description: An Arizona man who bought 15 failed Texas savings and loans from the Government despite previous problems with state regulators, has agreed to testify at a Senate hearing on the acquisitions, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum said today.

title: Intergraph Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $8,406,000 on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Great Lakes Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Great Pond Journal;   Son's Memory Lives On Under Trees He Loved
description: Deep in these Maine woods, where the summer nights are cold and ancient pine trees caress the sky, Jane and Jack Schultz nurse a grief that is at once profoundly public and private.

title: Fears of a Pi Gap Are, Well, Irrational
description: To the Editor:

title: New Vim and Vigor For the Y.M.C.A.
description: IT'S a typical morning at the branch of the Milwaukee Y.M.C.A. in this suburb. All through the building, there is a constant coming and going of men and women, mostly in running shoes and T-shirts, on their way to exercise class or weight training or a session on the running track that is suspended above the basketball courts.

title: Francis Parkman, 92, Ex-Headmaster In Massachusetts
description: Francis Parkman, the first president of the National Association of Independent Schools and a former headmaster of St. Mark's School in Southborough, Mass., died Sunday at the North Hill Health Center in Needham, Mass., where he had lived for the last four years.

title: Shuttles Can Fly Again Soon, NASA Predicts
description: Expressing optimism that fuel-leak problems can be corrected quickly, space agency officials said today that the nation's grounded space shuttle fleet could start flying again as early as mid-August.

title: Some Sturdy Old Dogs Show Up With a New Trick or Two
description: SOMETIMES, finding familiar pots and pans that have been cleverly redesigned, or tools with a new twist, can be more exciting than discovering brand-new equipment. In recent perusals of kitchenware shops, I came up with four new versions of common tools that would be worthy additions to any home cook's arsenal.

title: Vetoed Bill Protected Public Employees
description: To the Editor:

title: Pfizer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Included pretax gain of $39 million from the sale of the Dekalb-Pfizer Genetics Seed partnership. This compares to about $16.8 million included in other income from the company's share of the partnership earnings in the first 6 months of 1989. For the full year 1989, the company's share of the partnership's earnings was $8.2 million.

title: Decline Continues in Yields For Bank Funds and C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to ease during the week that ended yesterday. It was the seventh consecutive week of decline.

title: Banc One Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
An Updated 'Les Indes' by Rameau Enlivens Aix-en-Provence Festival
description: With summer arts festivals blooming like sunflowers across southern France, Aix-en-Provence is constantly required to demonstrate that the region's most established and pricey music festival has not grown staid and predictable.

title: Chronicle
description: Reading beats sleeping pills, PRESIDENT BUSH has concluded. When asked by one of a group of magazine publishers visiting the White House yesterday what he has been reading for fun, Mr. Bush began with a recitation of official documents.

title: A Nicaraguan Envoy Is Seized In Japan on U.S. Drug Charge
description: A Nicaraguan diplomat in Tokyo was arrested there yesterday on United States charges that he took part in a plot to smuggle millions of dollars of heroin into New York City.

title: LeMond Is Poised to Strike in Tour
description: With a magnificent ride over three major peaks in the Pyrenees today, Greg LeMond moved into second place in the Tour de France, only five seconds behind the leader, Claudio Chiappucci of Italy. The American appeared to burn off all his other opposition and position himself for his second successive victory and third over all.

title: Supermarkets Reach Out To Hispanic Customers
description: FROM the tortilleria of the Tianguis supermarket here comes the slap, slap, slap of women making tortillas by hand. On a Saturday afternoon, the market is in perpetual motion: women mix, shape and bake tortillas almost nonstop. The result is corn tortillas, flour tortillas (with or without lard), corn chips and tostados.

title: Upjohn Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $27,000 and $1,113,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: RADIATION RECORDS OF 44,000 RELEASED
description: Ending years of conflict over medical secrecy between independent scientists and the Government, the Department of Energy today released the radiation exposure records of 44,000 workers at its Hanford nuclear reservation here.

title: Wondering if Sanders Will Stay? So Is He.
description: They were never rivals, Deion Sanders said last night. That was simply a creation of the news media, something to stir competition. He always liked and respected Bo Jackson, he said. He even told Jackson that he admired him when the two of them were interviewed on a radio show in Kansas City two weeks ago.

title: Williams Rejects Pact
description: John Williams, the Cleveland Cavaliers' 6-foot-11-inch forward, has rejected a two-year contract offer for a reported $9 million from Il Messaggero Roma of the Italian League and will stay in the National Basketball Association, his agent, Mark Bartelstein, said last night.

title: A Lawyer to Trust
description: In an age marked by suspicion of both leadership and the legal profession, Robert McKay was in a trusted class by himself. Former dean and teacher at New York University's law school, he gave leadership to every cause that benefited the law, democracy and justice. When he died last week at the age of 70, he was in Reno to address the National Judicial College.

title: EATING WELL
description: MOST people's diets fall far short of the ideal set by organizations like the National Academy of Sciences, the National Cancer Institute and the American Heart Association: cutting back on fat, eating more fiber, reducing cholesterol, eating more fruits, vegetables and whole-grain foods.

title: Magazine Revenues Up
description: Magazine advertising revenues for the first half of 1990 rose a slim 1.6 percent, to $3.28 billion, compared with the period a year earlier, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Advertising pages fell 3.3 percent.

title: Hubbell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Reactor Designs Are Criticized in Report
description: Manufacturers designing a new generation of nuclear reactors overstate the safety benefits of new features, and their changes would leave the plants more vulnerable than current designs to certain kinds of accidents, according to a 200-page study released yesterday by a nuclear watchdog group.

title: No Headline
Race On for an Electric-Car Battery
description: Encouraged by serious consideration of laws that might make commercial production of electric cars practical within a decade, companies from small start-ups to some of the world's largest battery manufacturers are racing for a breakthrough in battery technology.

title: Head of Javits Center Says Major Expansion Is Needed
description: Barely four years after its completion, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center needs to expand by as much as a third - 600,000 square feet - to remain competitive and to attract the nation's largest trade shows, the acting president of the center says.

title: Rig Count Falls in Week
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States fell by 10 last week, to 1,001, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. It was the third consecutive week of decline. A year ago the count stood at 820.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AMERICA'S love affair with hamburgers is never more evident than in summer, when barbecue grills across the land send up smoke signals announcing the patties are on. As much as I like a hamburger made from freshly ground sirloin, it's fun to experiment with other types of burgers.

title: Book Notes
description: Dissident's Memoirs

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS

title: Son of a Former Faculty Member Is Held in Wesleyan Firebombing
description: A young man whose father was on the Wesleyan University faculty and whose cousin is accused of killing a black student advocate was charged today with the firebombing of the university's administration building.

title: TRW Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEALTH RISKS SEEN IN BLOOD PRESSURE JUST ABOVE NORMAL
description: Above-normal blood pressure, even if it is not high enough to qualify as hypertension, can permanently damage heart and blood vessels and increase the risk of heart attack, a new study says.

title: Subsidies for Artists: Is Denying a Grant Really Censorship?
description: Visitors to the benefit performance staged the other night for the Franklin Furnace, an avant-garde performance space in the TriBeCa section of Manhattan, heard angry protesters warn against what they perceived as Government censorship of the arts.

title: State Street Boston reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reynolds Metals Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
World Bank Considers Loan Charge Reduction
description: World Bank officials announced yesterday that the the bank's net income topped $1 billion in 1990, for the sixth year in a row, and that the institution would now consider reducing its borrowers' costs.

title: Polaroid Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Chronicle
description: DIMITRIOS I, Patriarch of Eastern Orthodox Christians, made an unscheduled stop on Monday on his tour of New York City. The Patriarch, 75 years old, consulted DR. ARIADNA PAPAGEORGE, an otolaryngologist, at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital. His car, with its ''Hellenic 1'' license plate, and a phalanx of bodyguards and police officers were not exactly inconspicuous.

title: McReynolds Revives, Sparks Mets
description: Concern, tension, panic - the words had begun to resurface through the locker room of the Mets. They were words, though, that had no discernible effect on Kevin McReynolds. But then most don't.

title: Bush Declares He Does Not Feel Left Out by Gorbachev and Kohl
description: President Bush sought today to dispel any suggestion that Germany and the Soviet Union had reached an independent agreement on German unification, saying the United States ''has been in the forefront'' on the issue since before the Berlin wall was opened.

title: Dime Savings Bank of N.Y.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $931,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,140,000, or 31 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary tax benefits of $2,791,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,120,000, or 31 cents share, for the 6 months, both from tax benefits from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: New Jersey Court Seen as Leader on Rights
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, in ruling last month that children in the state's poorest cities have a right to the same educational opportunities as children in wealthy suburbs, added to its reputation as a leader among state courts trying to expand individual rights by using State Constitutions, common law and their own body of case law as precedent.

title: Is Sanders Staying? He's Puzzled
description: The notebooks open and the tape recorders whir, and suddenly there is a crowd around him - just the way Deion Sanders seems to like it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Sovran Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Myth of Black Violence
description: LEAD: Are blacks, particularly young black men, more prone to violence than whites? The belief that they are is widely accepted by the public, media and government. Moreover, it is helping to generate a national effort among black leaders and academics to focus attention on inner-city black culture and its purportedly self-destructive and pathological underpinnings.

title: Just Say Cheese And No One Seems To Agree About It
description: WHAT with all the changes in the world, nothing can be taken for granted anymore. Just ask the American Cheese Society. The association of cheese makers, buyers and lovers convened in Manhattan last week for its seventh annual conference to consider this pressing question:

title: Youth Service Is New Route to Diplomas and Jobs
description: Rubber soles padded soundlessly along a hallway of Coler Memorial Hospital recently as Yaninth Maldonado guided an elderly man in a wheelchair to a nearby day room. With each step, Ms. Maldonado, a teen-age mother with an eighth-grade education, moved closer to her own goal: attaining a college diploma.

title:
Real Estate;

Waterfront Plans Argued In Hoboken
description: LEAD: THOUGH voters last week rejected a $600 million plan to rebuild a 32-acre section of Hoboken's crumbling waterfront, this city on the Hudson River opposite Manhattan is still a focus for commercial redevelopment projects. Two major proposals are being advanced by their supporters.

title: L.I. Town Votes Housing Project For Its Homeless
description: The North Hempstead Town Council cleared the way today for Nassau County's first permanent housing for the homeless when one Council member, after changing his mind several times, finally said he would support the plan for the six-family building.

title: New Store With Same Distinctive Shoes
description: THERE was Cher, face half-hidden by a big black hat, ordering five pairs of boots, size 8 1/2. It was midafternoon on Monday, and the new Susan Bennis/Warren Edwards shoe store at 22 West 57th Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, was off to an auspicious start.

title: Dominion Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WINE TALK
description: THE wine industry is in trouble, beset by neoprohibitionists and health groups and legislators who see it as a rich mine of untapped tax revenue despite falling sales.

title: Computer Screen Dumping Charged
description: Frustrated by what they say are the unfair pricing practices of eight major Japanese electronics companies, a small group of American makers of flat screens used in advanced portable computers filed an anti-dumping petition yesterday, calling for an investigation by the United States Government.

title: No Pact for Greschner
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that they would not renew the contract of Ron Greschner, the team's career leader among defensemen in goals (179), assists (431) and points (610), as well as the team's career leader in penalty minutes (1,226).

title: Soviets Report New Clashes In Central Asian City of Osh
description: New ethnic clashes have broken out in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia, injuring 27 people, the Tass press agency said today. It said the police fired warning shots to break up the fighting.

title: Tosco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the sales increase for the 1990 periods resulted in part from the inclusion of results of Seminole Fertilizer Corp., which was acquired after the year-ago periods were completed. Sales for the latest quarter and 6-month period also included revenues of $36 million and $90 million, respectively, from the trading of crude oil cargoes.

title: U.S. Drug Fighter Cites A Shortage as Positive
description: A senior Federal drug official testified today that a cocaine shortage in major metropolitan areas is ''the first positive development in domestic wholesale cocaine availability and prices since the onset of the cocaine epidemic.''

title: McGraw-Hill Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected a net gain equaled to 26 cents a share from the sale of properties. c-Included a credit of $8 million, or 16 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago periods were restated to reflect the formation of a Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing Co. joint venture as of July 1, 1989.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday misstated the year in which Jack Nicklaus played the British Open with a chance to win golf's grand slam. It was 1972, not 1982.

title: Savings Crime Bill Is Proposed
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives will propose a savings and loan enforcement package on Wednesday that will include a bipartisan national commission to examine the roots of one the nation's worst financial crisis as well as new legal weapons to fight crime in the savings and loan industry, Congressional aides said today.

title: Library Files Checked In Zodiac Investigation
description: Detectives seeking the so-called Zodiac gunman have obtained a subpoena for library records and are interviewing people who have recently requested books by an early 20th-century Scottish poet who practiced black magic, the police and library officials said.

title: Industrial Output Rises 0.4% On Auto and Utility Strength
description: A spurt in automobile production and a heat wave that increased utility output pushed industrial production up four-tenths of a percent in June, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Apply Lessons of Vietnam and El Salvador to Peru;   Human Rights Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization July 13 July 6 July 14 1990 1990 1989 Gasoline production, daily 7.2 7.4 7.4 Distillate production, daily 2.9 3.1 2.8 Gasoline stocks 215.6 213.6 222.9 Distillate stocks 114.7 112.7 110.2 Crude imports, daily 7.0 6.2 6.7 uknroduct ukn imports, daily 1.9 2.3 2.2 Crude stocks 385.3 380.6 331.9 Crude production, daily 7.1 7.1 7.4 Refinery utilization (%) 92.9 92.6 90.4

title: Union Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Profits Rise For Merrill And Schwab
description: Large investment banking fees helped to lift second-quarter earnings at Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm. Earnings also increased at Charles Schwab, the nation's largest discount broker, but fell slightly at Paine Webber Inc., a leading retail firm.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Split Over Awards

title: United Telecommunications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter results were significantly impacted by several non-recurring charges, totalling $72 million affecting the performance of United Telecom's long-distance division, US Sprint.

title: New York City Police Dept. Doesn't Want to Find Hate Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Perls, 84, Dies in Germany; Founder of Gestalt Psychotherapy
description: Laura Perls, a founder of the Gestalt school of psychotherapy, died Friday in Pforzheim, West Germany. She was 84 years old.

title: Doctor and His Family Die; Found Attached to IV Tubes
description: A physician, his wife and their two teen-age children were found dead in their home here today, intravenous tubes connected to their bodies.

title: Fears of a Pi Gap Are, Well, Irrational;   Job for Mathematicians
description: To the Editor:

title: Six Justices and Their Chief
description: Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court, who was appointed by former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne in 1979, is a former State Assemblyman and the son of the late David T. Wilentz, the former Attorney General who prosecuted Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh's son.

title: Hijacker Sent Back to Moscow, With a Message
description: A Soviet teen-ager who forced a passenger plane to go to Sweden last month because he was fed up with life in the Soviet Union was returned to Moscow today. Soviet officials hailed his extradition as a breakthrough in this country's struggle against a remarkable epidemic of hijackings.

title: Honeywell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,700,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and $13,400,000, or 35 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,800,000, or 34 cents a share, and $26,700,000, or 62 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Philip Rutledge, 84; Civil Engineer Led Professional Society
description: Philip C. Rutledge, a retired partner in Mueser, Rutledge, Wentworth & Johnson, a consulting engineering firm, died Saturday at Indian River Estates Medical Center in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in Vero Beach.

title: Two Held in a Robbery and Impersonation
description: An employee and a former employee of the Immigration and Naturalization Service have been arrested in connection with a Bronx robbery on Saturday in which the robbers posed as Federal drug-enforcement agents, the police said. A third suspect was being sought. The police were investigating whether the two suspects, a man arrested on Monday and a woman arrested yesterday, were involved in a similar robbery 12 hours earlier in the Soundview section. In that case, five robbers posed as police officers, said a police spokesman, Lieut. Raymond O'Donnell.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,506,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $6,203,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Giants and Jets Wait
description: As National Football League teams head into training camps this week and next, the draft choices who have signed contracts reached 80 yesterday, according to a count by the N.F.L. Management Council.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campaigns For Children Criticized
description: IN a wide-ranging attack on how some of the best-known American corporations market to young children, Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports magazine, released a study yesterday detailing what it denounced as increasingly pervasive and hidden advertising to ''America's most vulnerable consumers.''

title: Ethyl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,611,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter, which reflects income from aluminum, plastics and energy businesses spun off July 10, 1989 and $11,864,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months. Included in the year-ago quarter and 6 months income from continuing operations of $50,954,000, or 42 cents a share and $102,089,000, or 85 cents a share, respectively, included provision of about $2,500,000 after taxes for shutdown of Gallium Arsenide Wafer manufacturing facilities.

title: LABORITE GREETED WARMLY IN CAPITAL
description: The British Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock, was greeted warmly today by a Bush Administration that appeared eager to listen to his ideas, in sharp contrast with the icy reception he received from the Reagan Administration three years ago.

title: Six Soldiers Found in Florida AWOL From U.S. Spy Unit
description: Six soldiers missing from an Army intelligence unit at a sensitive National Security Agency eavesdropping post in West Germany have been apprehended in Florida and are the focus of a routine counterespionage investigation, the Pentagon said today.

title: Bor Journal;   Dinkaland, Where Cattle Are Treated Like Equals
description: To visit the cattle camp of Chief Alier Ayen, a Dinka tribesman, in the gray dawn of the southern Sudan is to see a gathering resembling ghosts.

title: Coca-Cola Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an equity loss from a discontinued operations of $457,000 in the quarter and $18,000 in the 6 months. Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1990.

title: Usinor-Sacilor Plans Purchase of Edgcomb
description: France's biggest steel company, the state-owned Usinor-Sacilor S.A., said today that it planned to acquire the Edgcomb Corporation, a privately held United States steelmaker. No price was given for the acquisition, which must be approved by Federal authorities.

title: Review/Pop;   A Triple Bill Takes Rock Back Toward Its Roots
description: Rock roots have grown twisted over the last decade. Before the 1980's, musicians who tried to hold onto roots were the conservative mainstream, battling newcomers who didn't respect old methods. But with the arrival of computerized music, mainstream rock developed amnesia, leaving it to cranks and fringe elements to reclaim handmade sounds and traditional formats. ''Roots rock'' is already a passe term, but the triple bill on Thursday night at the Ritz revolved around untamed guitar sounds, unmechanized rhythms, and echoes of the blues and country music.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Federal Signal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,288,000, or 15 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $209,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $337,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months. The company said extraordinary credits due to a gain on the divestiture of its Autocall Inc. subsidiary in April.

title: Sundstrand Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $10.3 million after taxes on the sale of a division. Latest quarter results included a loss of $7.4 million from the company's Brazilian operations. Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1990.

title: Commerce Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York to Fight Bunching of Unpopular Projects
description: For the first time, New York City has drafted guidelines aimed at ending its practice of putting a disproportionate share of programs for the homeless, the mentally ill and drug abusers in the poorest city neighborhoods.

title: Fine Career Oppty, Xlint Death Benefits
description: LEAD: I nearly spilled my morning coffee while reading an Associated Press news item about the problems the Department of Energy is having attracting people into a rapidly growing, challenging field involving time outdoors. The drawback is that the work involves sleuthing for, monitoring and cleaning up radioactive waste at nuclear weapons plants.

title: Nynex Denies 1988 Actions Raised Rates
description: The chairman of the Nynex Corporation said yesterday that the company had dismissed two purchasing employees and disciplined six others in the summer of 1988 for improper business activities, but he insisted that their actions had not resulted in higher telephone rates for New York residents.

title: Coach Is Suspended
description: Chuck DeBus of Santa Monica, Calif., the longtime coach of the Los Angeles Track Club and a former coach at U.C.L.A., has been suspended from track and field for life, The Athletics Congress announced yesterday.

title: It's Green and Red And Eaten All Over
description: IN 1917, John S. Gibson, a drugstore owner in Hope, Ark., created a friendly rivalry in the local watermelon patch by offering an annual cash prize for the largest melon. Since then, the farmers there have been partial to really big melons. Theirs are not the 5- to 8-pound icebox varieties, nor even the 30- to 40-pound melons that often show up in supermarkets, but giants of at least 100 pounds.

title: Manila Puts Quake Toll at 309 as Search Continues
description: Rescue workers continued to dig in piles of rubble for the dead and the living today, as Philippine officials said the earthquake on Monday had killed at least 309 people and injured at least 595.

title: Trade Deficit Increases Modestly
description: The nation's trade deficit rose modestly in May, to $7.73 billion, fueled by the economy's heavy reliance on oil imports and foreign automobiles, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Sharon Plan for Immigrants Derailed
description: An Israeli Cabinet minister and the Supreme Court both dealt blows today to Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's emergency program to provide housing for the huge influx of Soviet Jewish immigrants.

title: Dow Unchanged After Earlier Topping 3,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average broke through the 3,000 barrier for the third consecutive session yesterday, but fell back sharply and ended the day at 2,999.75 - unchanged from the day before.

title: Young Gains Berth in a Runoff To Run for Governor of Georgia
description: Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia finished first today in the Democratic primary but was forced into a runoff next month with Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta who is seeking to become the state's first black governor.

title: MORE FRIENDS SAY BARRY USED DRUGS
description: Two more of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s closest friends testified against him today in his drug trial, saying they had seen him use powdered cocaine and crack at least 30 times.

title: Details Are Given In Addidas Deal
description: Bernard Tapie, the French businessman who announced on July 7 that he would take over Addidas A.G., the West German sporting goods manufacturer, said here Monday that he would pay $290 million for an 80 percent stake and receive financing from eight French, German and Japanese banks. Mr. Tapie, a soccer team owner and Socialist member of Parliament, had not given details when he made his annoucement in Rome before the finals of the World Cup.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Monday misidentified the Deputy Chief in charge of the investigative bureau of the New York City Civilian Complaint Review Board. He is Kevin P. Farrell.

title: Synagogue Accord Is Reached To Allow Services in a House
description: Village officials and a group of Jews in Westhampton Beach agreed today to allow religious services at a house here, a lawyer said.

title: Great Western Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said resutls do not include the acquisitions on July 2, 1990 of the Centrust or Gibraltar-Florida franchises accounted for using the purchase method of accounting. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Market Place;   Gloomy Prospects Facing Retailers
description: DESPITE a slight rise in the latest store sales figures, American consumers are likely to remain reluctant shoppers for the rest of this year, according to store executives and industry analysts. And that grim outlook means no end is in sight to the difficulties facing most American retailers and their suppliers.

title: Bond Sells Assets To Lower Its Debt
description: Bond Corporation Holdings, the Australian-based conglomerate, said it had sold more assets to cut its debt of $6.67 billion (Australian), about $5.3 billion (United States). It said that in April it had sold its Observation City seaside resort in northern Perth to Pakwell Pty. for $77.34 million (Australian). The 337-room hotel was owned by Austmark International, a 47 percent owned subsidiary of the Bond Corporation.

title: Profit Up 32.5% At Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. announced today that its net income in its fiscal second quarter rose 32.5 percent as sales increased 2 percent.

title: Valentin Pikul Is Dead; Historical Novelist, 62
description: Valentin Pikul, a popular historical novelist whose books focused on Russia's sweeping upheavals, has died, the news agency Tass reported today. He was 62 years old.

title: Tokyo Is to Ban Fish Nets Early
description: Japan will stop drift-net fishing in the South Pacific this season, a year before the date set by a United Nations resolution, the Japanese Embassy said today.

title: Trying to Make a Right Out of Wrongs
description: To the Editor:

title: Interstate in Sale
description: First Interstate Bancorp said it had completed the sale of its consumer finance subsidiary, Nova Financial Services, to Transamerica Finance Group Inc. for $119 million in cash. Transamerica Finance, based in Los Angeles, is a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation. First Interstate, based in Los Angeles, said last March that it would sell Nova as part of its strategy to focus on relationship-oriented consumer banking and middle-market lending. First Interstate shares rose 50 cents today, to $39.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Lilly (Eli) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are diluted.

title: Three New York Bills to Veto
description: In their rush to adjourn, Albany legislators bowed to lobbying pressure and approved three ill-conceived bills. Gov. Mario Cuomo has no responsible choice but to rise above election year politics and veto them.

title: Number of Killings Soars In Big Cities Across U.S.
description: After an alarming increase last year, homicide rates have continued to soar this year, and experts attribute the rise to an increase in drug disputes, deadlier weapons and a tendency among more young people to start careers in crime with a gun.

title: VF Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that part of the 45-percent earnings drop in the latest second quarter was due to problems at its jeans operations and Jantzen division. Responding to low demand, the Wrangler and Lee Jeans division reduced production days and took charges of about 3 cents a share in connection with the closing of seven sewing plants. The earnings also included special charges of about 2 cents a share related to two small business sold in prior years.

title: Lawrence Zirinsky, 72, Real-Estate Developer
description: Lawrence Zirinsky, a real-estate developer, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lukens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago periods ended July 1.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: OUR friend, the Jackson Heights takeout gourmet, hadn't realized just how often she ordered Chinese food delivered or what a creature of habit she had become. Not until the other evening, that is, when she dialed and said, ''I'd like to place an order'' and from the other end came the friendly reply, ''Ah! Moo goo gai pan! How are you tonight?''

title: Wells Fargo Is Acquiring 130 Branches
description: The Great American Bank, a San Diego-based savings and loan that has had heavy losses, agreed today to sell its California branch network and other assets to Wells Fargo & Company.

title: Ohio Edison Co. reports earnings for 12mos to June 30
description: b-Reflected a $128 million, one-time non-cash write-off for certain nuclear construction costs for the year net income and share earnings.

title: Wells Fargo & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Loan loss provision was $75,000,000 and $100,000,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. Loan loss allowance was $813,000,000 and $664,000,000 for the latest and year-ago 6 months, respectively. Latest quarter results benefited from a $116.5 million pretax gain that resulted from the establishment of Wells Fargo's joint venture with Nikko Securities Co. Ltd., a Wells Fargo-Nikko Investment Advisors. Without the after-tax effect of the Wells Fargo-Nikko Investment Advisors gain, earnings for Wells Fargo & Co. for the latest 6 months of 1990 would have been $323.6 million, or $6.10 a share.

title: Fire Officials Charge Empire State Building Management in Blaze
description: A day after a fierce office fire in the Empire State Building left 38 people injured, the Fire Department filed criminal charges yesterday against the management of the landmark skyscraper, claiming that defects in the alarm system may have slowed the response of firefighters.

title: 2 Won't Be Charged in Bombing Case
description: Two members of the radical environmental group Earth First will not be charged with transporting the bomb that exploded in their car and injured them in May, lawyers for the two said today.

title: Big Donations Again Marking New York Political Campaigns
description: Big money is back in New York political campaigns after a brief respite in last year's municipal elections when New York City's new campaign finance law imposed sharp limits on individual and corporate contributions.

title: Paine Webber Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dealer Incentives At Ford Reported
description: The Ford Motor Company will offer sales incentives to dealers on some high-volume 1991 models and will increase advertising spending, according to a trade journal report. Automotive News said the incentives include a first-time-ever rebate of up to $500 on 1991 Ford Escorts. The incentives are in the form of a rebate to dealers, and the rebate amount will be based on the number of vehicles sold from July 10 to Aug. 8.

title: The President's English
description: President Bush greeted fellow summiteers at their meeting in Houston last week with a ringing but ungrammatical declaration that ''a new world of freedom lays before us.'' The major wire services and most newspapers - The A.P., U.P.I., Reuters, The Washington Post, Newsday and The New York Times, among others - reported it verbatim. But ''lays'' (incorrect) became ''lies'' (correct) in some other papers, including The Los Angeles Times, The Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Times and even Japan's Kyodo News Service.

title: G. E. Lawyer to Join Morgan
description: Philip A. Lacovara, a former Watergate prosecutor, is leaving the General Electric Company to become general counsel and secretary of Morgan Stanley Group, the Wall Street firm said yesterday.

title: Killer Is Put to Death By Injection in Texas After Appeal Denied
description: A former prostitute with a criminal record that began in his childhood was put to death today for killing a man he maintained had made homosexual advances.

title: Boatmen's Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
American Cyanamid Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $3,000,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $3,000,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,100,000, or 10 cents a share, and $16,500,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said that earnings from continuing operations of $108,400,000, or $1.13 a share, in the latest second quarter included a charge of about 8 cents a share related to the start-up of a titanium dioxide facility at its joint venture in the Netherlands, one-time costs related to the shutdown of an ammonia facility in Canada, and by a one-time gain from the divestiture of the formica laminate business in Brazil. The company also said the year-ago quarter and 6-month figures were restated to include the results of Praxis Biologics Inc., acquired on a pooling- of-interests basis.

title: Chronicle
description: JOE COCKER has scheduled a benefit concert for his neighbors in Santa Barbara, Calif., whose homes were ravaged by fire last month. The rock-and-roll singer lives less than a mile from the area where more than 524 structures, mostly homes, were burned.

title: Books of The Times;   A Soldier Who Supported New Deal Social Change
description: General of the Army

title: Manufacturers National reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest 6 months' results were affected by a first quarter $6 million provision for consolidation costs and a $4.8 million gain on an exchange of debt.

title: Review/Film;   Ugly, Deadly, Horrible Spiders That Are Funny
description: Cancel that camping trip, and fix those holes in the screens. Today brings the advent of ''Arachnophobia,'' a gleeful horror film about deadly, bad-tempered tropical spiders for whom the word ''itsy-bitsy'' is truly a black joke.

title: Rockwell International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $104 million, or 40 cents a share, from the March 1989 sale of the Measurement and Flow Control division. Latest and year-ago quarters reflect effects of a stock repurchase program.

title: Brooklyn Philharmonic Names a New Official
description: Vicki Margulies has been appointed the executive director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, the Brooklyn Academy of Music announced on Monday. Ms. Margulies is to replace Jerry McCathern, who left the orchestra after serving as its first executive director for about a year.

title: Intel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Treasury Issues Narrowly Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were very narrowly mixed in thin trading yesterday, as credit market participants sat back and waited to see what the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, says to Congress today.

title: Panel Warns of Risks in Global Trading
description: Warning of potentially serious risks to investors, institutions and the economy from round-the-clock trading in stocks and futures, an independent agency of Congress said today that it might fall to lawmakers to lay out regulatory policy toward the emerging global marketplace because ''it is not clear'' if the regulatory agencies share a ''common view.''

title: Citicorp Posts 37% Drop in Net
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that its earnings fell 37 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, despite continued growth in its highly profitable consumer banking businesses.

title: Los Angeles Schools Name Superintendent
description: William Anton, a longtime administrator in the Los Angeles County school system, has been named Superintendent, becoming the first Hispanic chief of the nation's second-largest school district.

title: How To Ease Traffic Jams
description: LEAD: Traveling, whether by car or plane, has become a daily frustration and inconvenience for Americans. Because of potholes and closed bridges, congested highways and airport delays, ''getting there'' often seems like going nowhere.

title: GTE Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for all periods were restated for a 2-for-1 stock split on May 23.

title: First Security Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for all periods reported have been restated to reflect the merger of United Savings Bank, Salem, Ore., into First Security Corp. on March 2.

title: Charles Schwab Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Grainger (W.W.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
5 POWERS REPORT GAINS ON CAMBODIA
description: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council announced today that they had advanced toward agreement on a peace formula for Cambodia, but they gave no hint that the warring factions were any closer to settling their differences.

title: People
description: * Joseph Bruce, Michael Garcia and Joy Sliwa have been promoted to executive vice presidents at Geer, DuBois Inc., while Steve Farricker, Allen Ginsberg and Nancy Korda have been promoted to senior vice presidents.

title: Soviets Make the Best Of New German Might
description: It will long be debated who won and who lost when Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave his blessing to the reunification of Germany.

title: Trustco Bank Corp N.Y.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cuban Linked to Terror Bombings Is Freed by Government in Miami
description: Orlando Bosch, a right-wing Cuban who is believed by American officials to be responsible for dozens of bombings aimed at the Castro Government, was released from jail here today in a deal with the United States Government.

title: Review/Television;   Identifying Genetic Defects and Dealing With Them
description: The hopes aroused by a new batch of medical miracles are examined in a moving way tonight at 10 on an ABC News Special, ''The Perfect Baby.'' The hour focuses on several sets of parents and children whose lives have been profoundly affected by the existence or prospect of some genetic defect. The host, Barbara Walters, seems worried that the laboratory advances that are enabling doctors to control wayward genes hold threats of genetic engineering.

title: Hubble Has Backup Mirror, Unused
description: NASA has a backup mirror for the Hubble Space Telescope that could have replaced the flawed mirror on the $1.5 billion craft and would even have been optically superior in some respects, astronomers said yesterday.

title: Keycorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Springs Industries reports earnings for 13wks to June 30
Don't Help Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Rose in Court Tomorrow For Tax-Case Sentencing
description: Having been banished from baseball for the rest of his life, Pete Rose will learn tomorrow if he has to spend part of that life in prison.

title: CBS Starts Taking Cues From Fox
description: CBS executives said here this week that the success of the Fox Broadcasting Company has changed the rules of prime-time programming and that CBS would now be interested in acquiring shows like Fox's ''Married . . . With Children.'' At a press conference on Monday to publicize the coming fall season, Howard Stringer, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said CBS was sending out a signal to producers of comedy shows that they will be given an ''open throttle'' to help change CBS's image as the ''stuffy, stodgy and old'' network.

title: KEY RATES
Manufacturers Hanover reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a special one-time restructuring charge of $100 million, or $60 million after-tax. The net also reflected issuance of about 20 million new shares since June 30, 1989.

title: First Florida Banks reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Constitution Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the 6 months included a gain of $730,000, or 7 cents a share, from change in method of accounting.

title: Norwest Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kill New Weapons for a Peace Dividend
description: Led by Sam Nunn, the Senate Armed Services Committee has sensibly trimmed $18 billion from the excessive $306 billion originally requested by the Bush Administration for defense in 1991. That's a lot better than Defense Secretary Cheney's proposed cut of $8 billion. But even the Nunn proposal falls far short of what's necessary now to reduce military spending by a reasonable 25 percent five years hence.

title: Air-India's Head Quits To Join Private Sector
description: Rajan Jetley, the 40-year-old chairman of India's Government-owned international carrier, Air-India, who streamlined the company and helped to make it profitable, said yesterday that he would resign.

title: Washington Talk;   Quayle Panel at Center Of a Space-Policy Shift
description: It is in the nature of vice presidents to yearn for territory where they can leave their mark, and so it is in the nature of Dan Quayle. For him, space is the place, and his instrument is the National Space Council, a White House-based interagency policy group of which he is chairman.

title: Three Drug Companies Post Strong Profits
description: Eli Lilly & Company, Pfizer Inc. and the Upjohn Company said yesterday that they had double-digit gains in profits and sales of drug and health-care products in the three months ended June 30.

title: Mellon Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $74 million on the company's sale of its Chicago- based finance company. c-After extraordinary credits of $5 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $29 million, or 72 cents a share, for the 6 months, both from the early retirement of debt.

title: Seagram to Cut Staffs in U.S.
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., a subsidiary of the Seagram Company, Montreal, said its House of Seagram division, which produces and markets distilled spirits in the United States, would cut 177 positions from its sales, marketing and support staffs.

title: Net Off 3.9% At Rockwell
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 3.9 percent on a 3.1 percent decline in revenues.

title: Chronicle
description: After 50 years and 990 radio broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera, Texaco will pick up the tab for three operas to be shown on public television next season. The operas will appear on two PBS programs, ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents'' and ''Great Performances.'' The bill is about $4 million, said JAMES W. KINNEAR, president and chief executive of Texaco Inc.

title: Iraq Threatens Emirates And Kuwait on Oil Glut
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today openly threatened to use force against Arab oil-exporting nations if they did not curb their excess production, which he said had weakened oil prices and hurt the Iraqi economy.

title: Youth's Recounting of Jogger Rape Is Read to Jury
description: One of the three defendants charged in the rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park confessed to his part in the attack, a New York City Police detective testified yesterday.

title: One Germany: Next Steps
description: Some dates are tentative.

title: National Lampoon's Two Top Officers Quit
description: The humor magazine National Lampoon said its co-chairmen and chief executives, the actor Tim Matheson and the producer Daniel Grodnik, had resigned.

title: Faith E. Andrews; Shaker Scholar, 93
description: Faith E. Andrews, an authority on the Shaker religious sect, died on July 6 at a nursing home in Pittsfield, Mass. was 93 years old and lived in Pittsfield.

title: New York State Bond Offering
description: The State of New York yesterday offered $225 million of general obligation bonds at competitive bid.

title: Red Sox Hit Into Two Triple Plays But Win
description: Minnesota became the first team in major league history to get two triple plays in one game last night, but it wasn't enough to overcome eight shutout innings by Tom Bolton as the Boston Red Sox beat the Twins, 1-0.

title: U.N. Chief Asks 5 Powers to Join in Mideast Talks
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has asked the five permanent Security Council members to help unblock the stalled Middle East peace process.

title: Groups Taking Aid Donations
description: American Friends Service Committee, Philippines Earthquake Assistance, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, Pa. 19102.

title: King, Douglas Reach Settlement
description: Don King and James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, settled their differences early yesterday morning. The settlement frees Douglas to defend his title against Evander Holyfield in September.

title: FMC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges from debt restructuring of $4,700,000 and $8,700,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Tartikoff Gets Promotion In a Realignment at NBC
description: NBC announced today that Brandon Tartikoff, the longtime president of its entertainment division, had been elevated to the new position of chairman of the NBC Entertainment Group.

title: Bridge
description: There are times at the bridge table when virtue has to be its own reward. The diagramed deal, played July 2 in a Pan-American Pairs in Washington, is an extreme example. Brad Moss and Michael Radin, both of Manhattan, bid superbly to reach the perfect contract, but emerged with the same score as those whose efforts were pedestrian.

title: Mackey's Double Life
description: Calling his wife ''a saint'' who lived with ''a devil,'' the suspended Cleveland State University basketball coach, Kevin Mackey, said yesterday that he had been living two lives, one as a public figure and family man, the other as an alcohol and drug abuser.

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Citicorp said net income in the first half of 1989 included a $77 million gain from the sale of Tokyo premises and $154 million of revenues from Brazilian cash payments since suspended. The company said the continued non-payment of interest by Brazil has resulted in a writeoff of $631 million relating to medium-and long-term exposure.

title: Intel Net Up Nearly 72%
description: The Intel Corporation, paced by strong sales of its microprocessors, recorded an increase of 71.9 percent in net income in the second quarter compared with a year earlier.

title: Group Reduces Multimedia Stake
description: A group of three investment partnerships led by Sandler Associations of Hewlett, L.I., said it had lowered its stake in Multimedia Inc. to 2.9 percent from 7.34 percent. Multimedia, based in Greenville, S.C., publishes newspapers and operates radio and television stations. The company has 11.3 million shares outstanding.

title: Chemical Banking Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included pre-tax gain of $114.7 million.

title: F.D.A. Critical Of Drug Lab
description: Eleven of 13 studies conducted for generic drug manufacturers by a Pittsburgh laboratory violated regulations of the Food and Drug Administration or standards of good laboratory practice, according to an F.D.A. inspection, the agency has said.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Something Pure'

title: Apply Lessons of Vietnam and El Salvador to Peru
description: To the Editor:

title: Coin Toss Will Decide an Election in Illinois
description: After a wrenching campaign, a razor-thin margin of victory, a tedious recount and months of haggling in court, a tight legislative race between a staunch opponent of abortion and an abortion rights advocate will be decided by a coin toss.

title: Avalanche Kills 40 Climbers in Soviet Central Asia
description: One of the worst tragedies in the history of mountain climbing has claimed the lives of at least 40 members of an international team killed Friday by an avalanche in the remote Pamir mountains in the Soviet Union near the Chinese border, according to Government reports.

title: 2 Germanys Cooperate In Retrieving Treasures
description: A church in East Germany is receiving help from West Germany to retrieve art treasures believed stolen by an American soldier at the end of World War II, a West German official said Monday.

title: 2 GERMANYS VOW TO RETAIN BORDER WITH THE POLES
description: East and West Germany agreed today to resolve Polish anxieties by promising to guarantee the postwar German-Polish frontier, and in doing so, the Germans all but guaranteed international endorsement of their own reunification by the end of the year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Hoosiers are no more anxious to live next to East Coast trash than the residents of the East Coast appear to be.''

title: Court Broadens Scope of Inquiry on H.U.D.
description: The special prosecutor in the case of Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Reagan Administration's Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has received a broad mandate to investigate those who received Federal housing grants from 1984 to 1988.

title: Home for Retarded Faces Legal Fight
description: New York City officials went to court yesterday to stop the state from closing a Greenwich Village residential center for severely mentally retarded adults.

title: An Odd Couple: Assad and Shamir
description: President Assad of Syria may have signaled an intriguing new flexibility during his remarkable visit to Egypt this week. Adroit American diplomacy could turn it into a new opening for Mideast talks. But that will require the Bush Administration to sell two strategic points:

title: Coke Income Rose 18.6% In 2d Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that its second-quarter profits rose 18.6 percent. The company's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, said he expected continued strong earnings for the rest of 1990 and for 1991.

title: Coors (Adolph) Co.  (O) reports earnings for 12wks to June 17
Midland Montagu Is Closing Government Securities Unit
description: The beleaguered Government securities business lost another primary dealer yesterday, as Midland Montagu, the international and investment banking arm of Britain's Midland Bank P.L.C., announced that it would close Midland Montagu Securities Inc. after an orderly winding down of business.

title: Prostitute in Article Is Ordered Released
description: An Oakland prostitute was ordered released today from jail where she was detained as the police sought to charge her with attempted murder. She had been arrested after Newsweek magazine quoted her as saying she continued to work despite being infected with the AIDS virus.

title: 100,000 Must Leave Fez
description: Morocco said today that the ancient city of Fez was falling into decay through overcrowding and that 100,000 residents would have to leave. The normal population of 120,000 has swollen to over 300,000 without any new houses being built, Moulay Ahmed Alaoui, minister of State without portfolio, told a news conference. Local authorities have set up a private company to build 25,000 apartments in satellite towns over the next five years to house the 100,000 people.

title: Review/Dance;   The Stars of New Works: Gloom, Doom and Angst
description: The gloom was pretty much unrelieved on Friday night at the handsome theater at the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts when the new Fiorello Festival presented the second of three programs of new and recent dance. Each choreographer represented - Zvi Gotheiner, Elisa King and James Sewell - had a sense of craft. But the solemnity of much of the choreography was eventually numbing, as was the length of the program and most of the pieces.

title: 21 Held in $1 Million Theft Of Food Headed for Needy
description: Twenty-one people and 6 companies on Long Island were accused today of systematically stealing more than $1 million worth of Government-subsidized food destined for schoolchildren, the elderly and the homeless.

title: Huffy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Eastern Europeans Lack Money to Study in West
description: Thousands of Eastern European students, eager to sample the educational offerings of the West, are seeking to matriculate at American universities, according to the United States Information Agency.

title: Senate Votes to Limit Debate On Provisions of Rights Bill
description: Seeking to encourage compromise by the White House, job discrimination, the Senate today voted to limit debate on a major bill to prevent job discrimination.

title: Fruit of the Loom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Joseph R. Corso, 81; Retired as a Justice Of a New York Court
description: Joseph R. Corso, a retired New York State Supreme Court Justice and a former State Assemblyman, died on Monday at Tisch Hospital of New York University. He was 81 years old and lived in Mattituck, L.I.

title: Shipping Trash Out of State Stirs Backlash
description: New Jersey and New York State are facing a growing national backlash over the rapidly increasing practice of trucking municipal garbage they cannot dispose of to landfills in other states.

title: G.O.P. in House to Fight Any Tax Rise
description: As the Bush Administration and Congressional Democrats sought to narrow their differences over taxes, restive House Republicans made plain today that they would vigorously oppose any tax increase.

title: United Telecom's Profit Down 55.1%; GTE Gains
description: United Telecommunications Inc. yesterday announced a 55.1 percent decline in second-quarter earnings and said it would lay off as many as 1,300 employees to contain rising costs at its long-distance telephone service subsidiary, the U S Sprint Communications Company.

title: About Education
description: A headline on the front page of The New York Times of June 13 said, ''A New Road to Learning: Teaching the Whole Child.''

title: Christmas 'Wrap-Off' for the Gifted
description: It was instant meltdown weather for Frosty the Snowman yesterday but one corner of the World Trade Center looked a lot like Christmas. Santa Claus, sweaty in a velvety red suit, was ho-ho-ing (''No seersucker in this line of work,'' he said) and nine ribbon-snipping store gift-wrappers were piling their creations under a tree. An artificial tree.

title: INSIDE
description: A Savings-Crime Proposal

title: In Land of Big, Ryan's Biggest
description: In Texas, parents reward the straight-A work of their grade-schoolers with tickets to see Nolan Ryan pitch. He has been praised by editorial writers and political columnists, courted by advertisers and Republican Party officials attracted to his wholesome country-boy image, exploited by makers of baseball memorabilia, who spot a sure thing, and idolized by thousands of wide-eyed youngsters whom he has met in autograph sessions for Texas charities.

title: Scott Paper Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the second quarter and 6 months of 1989 included unspecified special items that resulted in a net gain of 5 cents a share.

title: Banana Cream to Sour-Cream Raisin, Homemade Pies From the Heartland
description: THIS little town, a few miles off Interstate 94 amid the rolling dairy and corn country of western Wisconsin, is off the beaten path to the uninitiated, but it is clearly marked on the maps of pie lovers.

title: It's Only Money
description: ''Hot dog! That's where my money goes!'' is the refrain of an old drinking song celebrating some curious expenditures. Here is where money goes nowadays: LAWYERS STRIKE AGAIN ''Effectively out of cash.'' That's The New York Times's report on the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust. It was set up in 1988 to pay workers' claims for illness caused by inhaling asbestos fibers.

title: Apply Lessons of Vietnam and El Salvador to Peru;   Yanqui Intruders
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene;   Does Gorbachev Know Best?
description: SUPPOSE Mikhail Gorbachev threw a free-market party and nobody wanted to dance?

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Drug Used to Treat Premenstrual Pains Is Found Ineffective
description: A drug commonly used to treat the emotional and physical pain that millions of women suffer before menstruation does not work, researchers say.

title: Accounts
description: * Twin Tire Systems, Dallas, to the Dallas office of Ayer.

title: Madonna Talks End
description: Madonna will not be as ubiquitous as planned. Reebok International Ltd., the athletic footwear company, said yesterday that negotiations for an endorsement agreement with the pop singer and star of ''Dick Tracy'' had ended. ''Timing and schedules became the critical factors,'' a spokeswoman for Reebok said, referring to Madonna's current world concert tour.

title: Citizens & Southern Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Keystone Consolidated Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $2,777,000, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,369,000, or 78 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $1,540,000, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,385,000, or 43 cents a share, for the 6 months. Income per common and common equivalent share for the 1989 periods have been restated to give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split payable to holders of record on May 25, 1990.

title: E.W. Scripps Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $36.4 million as a result of an agreement with Persis Corp. to end joint operations of the Knoxville News-Sentinel and the Knoxville Journal. c-Net income

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $55.6 million from the sale of its majority interest in Coca-Cola Bottling Co. of Ohio and its ownership of Portsmouth Coca-Cola Bottling Co. The company said it established in the second quarter incremental reserves of $10 million for ''potentially uncollectible'' trade accounts receivable. The company also had restructuring charges of $9.3 million relating primarily to the planned standarization of its information systems operations.

title: Prague Announces a 50% Rise in Gasoline Prices
description: The Czechoslovak Government announced a 50 percent increase in gasoline prices today, to take effect Wednesday at midnight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day Is Selling Unit
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo has agreed to sell a public relations subsidiary, Jessica Dee Communications, to the firm's management. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Neil Bush's Trouble as Political Gold: A Colorado Candidacy Rises on Issue
description: Neil Bush's entanglement in the nation's savings and loan scandal not only is a staple of local news reports here but also a focus of Colorado politics in this election year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Fuqua Industries, Atlanta, a consumer products company, promoted James M. Bahin to senior vice president for operations and John F. Bartels to senior vice president and chief financial officer. Colin W. Brown was promoted to senior vice president, general counsel and secretary, and James R. Foster was promoted to senior vice president for finance and corporate development and treasurer.

title: Joseph Johnson Sr., 83, Western Union Official
description: Joseph D. Johnson Sr., a retired executive of Western Union International, died on Sunday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Huntington Station, L.I.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Review/Pop;   At the Palladium, 3 Groups From Spain
description: Though it seemed as if the mix-and-match pop music esthetic that began in the early 1980's might lumber to a stop in the 1990's, it hasn't. African, American and European pop music all greedily suck in cultures, easily available by travel and record collections. The result is a party where the old mingles with the new, where a sense of cultural movement, always exciting, momentarily blinds an audience to its differences, uniting it. So it was Saturday night at the sold-out Palladium, where three Spanish groups, each different from the others, pleased the audience equally.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AIG Acquisition Corp., New York, completed its tender offer for all outstanding common shares of Fischbach Corp., New York, an electrical and mechanical engineering concern.

title: 12 Cubans Surrender And Leave an Embassy
description: Twelve Cuban refugees surrendered unconditionally and left the Czechoslovak Embassy on Monday after fighting among themselves and holding five Czechoslovak diplomats hostage for more than five hours.

title: Garrard Jewelers Is Sold to Asprey
description: The British royal family's favorite jeweler, Garrard, was sold to Asprey P.L.C., a luxury-goods company, as part of a merger deal worth $:75 million, or $135 million. Asprey said it had agreed to buy the Mappin & Webb jewelery and silver group, which owns Garrard, from the Sears P.L.C. department store chain.

title: Senate Votes Import Curbs On Apparel but Veto Looms
description: The Senate, by a vote of 68 to 32, approved legislation today to curb imports of textiles and apparel.

title: General Manager Set For Fuji Bank in U.S.
description: Tomohiro Kamio has taken command of the New York branch of Fuji Bank as general manager, his first assignment in the United States.

title: Bosworth Is Waived After Failing Physical
description: Brian Bosworth, the brash but talented linebacker who signed an $11 million, 10-year contract with Seattle after he was chosen out of the University of Oklahoma in the 1987 supplemental draft, was waived by the Seahawks yesterday after failing a physical on the injured right shoulder that kept him out most of last season.

title: About New York;   A Touch of Class Sets Sail Away From Life's Care
description: The skyline of New York, one of the most compelling sights on this planet, was taking fuzzy shape through the haze. ''Pity it's a bit misty,'' said Robin Allen Woodall, master of the Queen Elizabeth 2.

title: Stanley B. Kurzina Jr.; Engineer, 85
description: Stanley B. Kurzina Jr., an engineer and manufacturing excutive, died Friday at his home in Wayland, Mass. He was 85 years old.

title: Kohl Outlines a Vision: A Neighborly Germany
description: A day after winning Soviet agreement to drop its objections to German unification, Chancellor Helmut Kohl extended the hand of conciliation and cooperation today and offered a vision of the first united German nation of the 20th century on good terms with all its neighbors.

title: Manslaughter Is New Charge In Vento Case
description: A grand jury filed superseding indictments yesterday adding manslaughter charges to earlier charges against John S. Vento and four other defendants in the Bensonhurst murder case, the Brooklyn District Attorney announced.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHERRIE ROLLINS, former public-affairs director of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, left her old desk on Friday and sat down to her new one on Monday, as director of news information for ABC News in New York. As for leaving government for the media, ''it's a chance to work for the other side,'' Mrs. Rollins said.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Escape Death After Being Trapped Outside Mir
description: Two Soviet astronauts walking in space were trapped outside the Mir space station on Tuesday when an airlock door failed to close, forcing them to use an emergency re-entry procedure as their air supplies ran dangerously low, Soviet press reports and American experts said yesterday.

Pausing only long enough to grab a drink and a breath, Viola for the Mets and Scott for the Astros raced like lightning through the other's teammates, trading shutout inning for shutout inning.

title: Senate Ethics Committee Urges A Denunciation of Durenberger
description: The Senate Ethics Committee recommended today that Senator Dave Durenberger be publicly denounced by the full Senate, ordered to pay restitution and possibly be punished by the Republican Party for what it called intentional breaking of Senate rules for personal financial gain.

title: Behind U.S. Reversal: Gains by the Khmer Rouge
description: Defense and intelligence officials say they are increasingly concerned that the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas are winning their war to oust the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government. The Bush Administration's announcement today that it is withdrawing recognition of the Cambodian rebel coalition and opening talks with Vietnam underlines that concern.

description: Aaron Asher, who resigned last week as publisher of Grove Weidenfeld, yesterday was appointed a vice president of HarperCollins. He will publish about 20 books a year under his own imprint, Aaron Asher Books.

Rooney Linked to Bets
description: The late Art Rooney, founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was described in court yesterday as a good customer of a man on trial for doing millions of dollars' worth of bookmaking. The comment about Rooney came in opening statements at the trial of Paul Hankish, whom the Government said started running a bookmaking operation out of Bridgeport, Ohio, in 1957.

title: Who Says A Factory Must Look Like One?
description: THE British designer David Mellor believes that Britain's post-World War II town planners made a ''major strategic mistake'' when they segregated the places where people worked from the places where they lived. ''I've always thought that manufacturing should be integrated with living and with the countryside,'' he said.

title: Charles Travers Davies, Insurance Executive, 80
description: Charles Travers Davies, who was corporate secretary and assistant to the president of the Hanover Insurance Company when it was in New York City, died on Tuesday at his home in Stratford, Conn. He was 80 years old Mr. Davies died of anemia, his daughter, Patricia Haas, said.

title: Blue-White Rhapsody: 300 Pieces of Old China
description: For lovers of antiques, the setting could not be better. First, the walk up a shaded brick path to an 1810 Federal-style mansion. Then through the big center hall, past 18th-century Chippendale serving tables, needle and petit point wing chairs and a Waterford chandelier. And on to the main ballroom, to find pieces of blue and white china from the 1700's to the present.

description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation appears to be turning itself into an example of how bankruptcy can sometimes have a rejuvenating effect.

description: As the political fallout from Neil Bush's involvement in the Silverado savings and loan scandal mounts, some top Republican strategists have concluded that he should make a deal with Federal regulators.

title: The Delights of Your Own Window Box
description: BETTER late than never when it comes to planting a window box garden. Shelves of colorful transplants continue to fill florist and garden shops, so it's possible to plant now and enjoy a vibrant display until frost.

title: Jackson Holds Out On Nuggets' Offer
description: Chris Jackson's agent says the Denver Nuggets will have to pay its first-round draft pick a minimum of $11.5 million for the guard's first five seasons in the National Basketball Association.

title: Oil Leaks Into Arthur Kill After 2 Barges Collide
description: A barge leaving Exxon's Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., slammed into a sister barge that was docked there yesterday, dumping 37,000 gallons of home heating oil into the Arthur Kill.

title: Home Builders See Recession And Blame the Savings Crisis
description: For the first time since the recession of the early 1980's, the rate of new housing construction has dropped for five consecutive months, providing further proof, home builders say, that the economic and regulatory fallout from the savings and loan crisis has pulled one of the country's biggest industries into a recession.

title: 2 Go Too Far in Test Drive
description: Just 90 minutes into his new job, an automobile salesman was accosted at knifepoint by his first customers, 19-year-old twins who proceeded to steal the car they wanted to test drive, the police said. The two led the police on a 12-mile chase before they were stopped and arrested on suspicion of armed robbery. ''It's sure a different way of starting a job,'' said the salesman, Steve Sacry.

title: Consolidated Rail Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Jeff King drove in five runs, four with a grand slam, to back Doug Drabek's pitching tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates routed the San Francisco Giants, 11-2.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, their virtual prisoner, is named head of state.

description: The mystery of what makes a man a man may never be solved, but scientists now think they know what makes a male masculine. They have found a key gene on the Y chromosome that seems to act as a master switch for maleness, transforming a growing human fetus that otherwise would become a girl into a baby boy.

title: East German Job Data
description: East German unemployment soared by 60 percent in the first two weeks of July to reach 224,000, Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt said today. She told the A.D.N. news agency that between 30,000 and 40,000 people were joining the unemployment lines weekly. Another 500,000 have applied for short-time work - a Government-sponsored halfway stage between employment and joblessness - since East and West Germany merged their economies along free market lines July 1, she said.

Manley Still Banned
description: Dexter Manley has been told by the National Football League that his reinstatement will not be considered until November, when he will have served one year of his drug suspension. Manley, a Washington Redskins defensive end, was permanently banned from the N.F.L. on Nov. 18 for his third violation of the league's substance-abuse policy. Manley, who said he had used cocaine and was an alcoholic, may apply for reinstatement after one year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the savings and loan crisis misstated the percentage of respondents in a Gallup poll who believed that neither the Republicans nor the Democrats were to blame. It was 10 percent, not 81 percent. Over all, 35 percent said the Republicans were more to blame, 19 percent said the Democrats, 16 percent blamed both and 20 percent said they did not know.
