title: Currents;   Sheets as Decor (Don't Climb the Wall)
description: DECORATING with sheets seems easy. Doing it is another story. ''For years we've seen rooms transformed with sheets in lots of decorating magazines, but we had no idea how to actually do it,'' said Margaux King, a producer at ONTO, a video production company. She, a colleague, Erika Lindberg, and Kay Jones, an interior designer, created ''Weekend Bedroom Makeover With Sheets,'' a 5-minute video on how to get those swags right.

title: Pulitzer Publishing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the decrease in net income in the latest periods was primarily attributable to lower profits in the publishing segment and increased depreciation and amortization with respect to the acquisition of WDSU-TV. In December 1989, the company sold WPTA-TV, Ft. Wayne, and acquired WDSU-TV, New Orleans.

title: United Television Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $63,435,000 associated with interest in Warner Communications Inc. c-Included income of $599,000 and $2,502,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, associated with interest in Warner Communications Inc. Interest and other income in the quarter increased to $2,951,000 from last year's $111,000, primarily reflecting earnings on the proceeds from dispositions in 1989 and 1990 of the company's interest in Warner Communications Inc. Interest expense declined to $28,000 from $1,965,000 in the prior year quarter, reflecting the 1989 redemption of the company's 14 1/2 percent subordinated debentures.

title: Dr. Richard M. Overholt, Surgeon And an Anti-Smoking Pioneer, 88
description: Dr. Richard M. Overholt, a chest surgeon who began crusading against smoking in the early 1930's, died on Monday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 88 years old and lived in Dedham, Mass. His family said he died of liver cancer.

title: Administrator at Tulane Named to Head Rutgers
description: Rutgers University today named the provost and graduate dean at Tulane University, Dr. Francis L. Lawrence, as its 18th president.

title: Finnish Scientists to Study Gravity in Eclipse
description: When the Moon eclipses the Sun this weekend, scientists in Finland plan to conduct a wide variety of experiments to test whether the gravity of one massive body can partly shield that of another.

title: Old Drug Is Found to Cut Heart Risk
description: In a large new study, a drug that had fallen out of favor as a routine treatment has dramatically cut the risk of fatal and nonfatal heart attacks among people who had previously suffered one.

title: 2 Southern Baptist News Chiefs Are Dismissed
description: A month after solidifying their control over the Southern Baptist Convention, the denomination's fundamentalist leadership dismissed the two top editors of the convention's news and information service.

title: Savings Bailout to Use Up Cash in 3 Months
description: Underscoring the need for an infusion of money soon to continue the costly bailout of the savings and loan industry, regulators will announce Thursday that they plan to spend what they have left to seize and sell failed savings and loans in the next three months.

title: Brothers Shift Duties At Bergen Brunswig
description: The Martini brothers are rearranging the management combination that enabled the two pharmacists from New Jersey to create the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, one of the country's major wholesale drug distributors.

title: First Illinois Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
4 Legends' Matchup Is Also Farewell
description: In Greek mythology, the Elysian Fields are the haven at the ends of the earth where the most exalted heroes go after death. At the Old Course, they are the sanctuaries of fairway between the hellish bunkers on the 567-yard 14th hole.

title: First Citizens Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: * Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, the telecommunications company, purchased Simborg Systems Corp., a hospital communications company, which it renamed Bell Atlantic Healthcare Systems. Terms were not disclosed.

DF Southeastern Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Some, 'No Beards' Is Painful Job Rule
description: For millions of men with coarse, curly hair there is no such thing as a smooth clean shave. For these men, shaving is painful because they develop razor bumps on the face and neck from the closely cut ends of hairs that imbed themselves to irritate and scar the skin.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST glues for home repair are strong and easy to use. Choosing the right kind can be confusing, but you can do most jobs with one of the first four listed below. The major ingredient is usually displayed prominently on the label. Since some glues are hazardous, they must be used with care; read and follow the manufacturer's instructions.

title: Bankers First reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2d Canseco With A's
description: Ozzie Canseco, the younger brother of Jose Canseco, has been called up from the Athletics' Class AA team to play alongside his brother in the Oakland outfield. The Huntsville Stars' manager, Jeff Newman, told the younger Canseco Tuesday night that Manager Tony La Russa of the Athletics wanted him to join the American League West Division leaders. He got word of the promotion after his 19th home run of the season for the Southern League team.

description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, today reported an 18 percent gain in its second-quarter net income.

description: LAURA ASHLEY did it first: marketed the English country-house life style, everything from romantic floral frocks to soft chintz fabrics and wallpapers.

title: Pioneer-Standard Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Jersey Court Protects Trash From Police Searches
description: Garbage left on the curb is private and the state cannot search through it without a warrant, the New Jersey Supreme Court has ruled.

title: First Michigan Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share earnings are diluted.

title: United's Nonunion Workers Agree to Join the Buyout Bid
description: The unions seeking to buy the UAL Corporation have reached an agreement with the airline's 26,000 non-union employees, bringing aboard the last employee group that had held out, representatives of the employees said yesterday.

title: Man Waving Shotgun Is Killed by Police
description: An apparently deranged man waving a sawed-off shotgun was trailed by a police team along several streets in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn yesterday, then shot to death by the officers while they tried to capture him as several dozen witnesses looked on in horror.

title: Net Surges At Philip Morris
description: Philip Morris Companies Inc., the world's largest consumer-products company and the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings surged 27.2 percent, to $948 million, or $1.03 a share, from $745 million a year earlier, or 80 cents a share.

title: Treasures With a Past, But Cheap
description: WHEN he went to buy his wife a desk, David Weinschneider couldn't believe the prices. ''I kept telling myself, there's got to be a cheaper way,'' he recalled.

title: Metro Matters;   Seeking to Make The Unpopular More Palatable
description: In Yonkers yesterday, Mayor Henry Spallone not only accepted a $95,000 payoff from a power broker but also held a news conference to announce it.

title: Close to Home
description: ''I KNOW what we should do,'' my oldest friend said after the takeout fish and chips and the California chablis. ''We'll go for a walk down Paper Street.''

title: Intermec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Lowered by a $1 million relocation charge and the higher overhead associated with its new facility as well as continuing weakness in sales to the Department of Defense.

American Ecology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $2,465,000 and $2,624,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, which reflects National Ecology Inc. which was sold November 1989.

description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included a reclassification of $5.9 million and $7.4 million, respectively, from the category of ''other income, net'' to ''interest expenses.'' These higher interest charges were not repeated in 1990.

title: East Side Developer Enlists a Close Adviser of Dinkins
description: In a textbook tale of politics and personalities, a developer's embattled effort to build a luxury apartment tower on the site of a landmark tenement complex in Manhattan took a twist yesterday that combined a debate, a delay and a hand from one of Mayor David N. Dinkins's closest supporters.

title: Tokyo Said to Tell China It Will Go Ahead on Loan
description: A senior Japanese official has told Chinese leaders here that despite the tepid endorsement its diplomatic opening to China received from President Bush in Houston it intends to push ahead, a Japanese official who attended the meetings said.

title: Review/Ballet;   A Tyrant With Self-Doubts, in the Bolshoi's 'Ivan'
description: Ivan the Awe-Inspiring, better known as the Terrible in the West, would seem an odd subject for a ballet. In 1975, Yuri Grigorovich's choreography and staging for the Bolshoi Ballet proved otherwise.

title: Rinfret Offers Cuomo Apology
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, who has quickly gained a reputation for ''shooting from the lip,'' apologized yesterday to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for one of his comments.

title: Washington at Work;   As Guerrilla or General, Gingrich Has a Mission
description: The morning Newt Gingrich heard about President Bush's turnaround on new taxes, he was so enraged, he says, that he slammed down the phone on John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.

title: Shad Quits as Chairman In Shake-Up at Drexel
description: John S. R. Shad resigned yesterday as the chairman of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, as the firm moved to put more outsiders on its board. The firm named Ralph S. Saul, a former president of the American Stock Exchange and one of the three independent directors on the board, to succeed Mr. Shad as chairman.

title: G.E. Unit Buys British Concern
description: The GE Capital Corporation, the financial services subsidiary of the General Electric Company, announced yesterday that it had acquired Burton Group Financial Services P.L.C. of Britain, which manages credit-card accounts and provides other services to retailers, for $329 million in cash.

title: Arvin Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $249,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After a loss of $420,000 for the quarter and income of $13,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: I.R.S. Inquiry Delays Talks on Stolen Artworks
description: An investigation by the Internal Revenue Service has stalled out-of-court negotiations between opposing parties in the Quedlinburg treasures case, now before Federal District Court in Dallas, a lawyer for the defense said yesterday.

title: Currents;   Architectural Tour Of British Towns
description: AT a time when Prince Charles has made people more aware of city planning issues than ever before, a new book by the British writer Mark Girouard, ''The English Town: A History of Urban Life'' (Yale University Press, $39.95), seems timely.

title: Leukemia Victim Can't Force Kin to Have Marrow Tested
description: A 12-year-old boy suffering from leukemia cannot demand that two half-siblings be tested to see if they would be compatible bone marrow donors, a judge ruled today in dismissing a lawsuit brought by the boy's father.

title: Review/Television;   New Entry in the Late-Night Stakes
description: Like everyone else in television, ABC is struggling to squeeze a bit more profit out of every hour in every day. The late-night schedule is one obvious target area, with its captive audience of insomniacs. ABC has done very nicely indeed with Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' at 11:30 P.M. Now, deciding to follow that think-tank format with some comic relief, the network is opening up its midnight slot Monday through Friday to ''Into the Night Starring Rick Dees.'' This may actually be the first late-night talk show in history to offer its viewers money if they stay tuned in.

title: Saudis Criticized Over Mecca Tunnel Disaster
description: The death of 1,426 Muslim pilgrims earlier this month in a tunnel stampede in Mecca has led to strong criticism of Saudi Arabia in several Muslim countries in connection with the disaster.

title: No Headline
description: AIR-CONDITIONERS that don't cool correctly often need new thermostats, control switches or fan motors, or perhaps just a thorough cleaning, said Ellen Elias, a vice president of Elgot, a family business that has been repairing air-conditioners for 45 years. She added that excessive noise might be caused by a manufacturing defect or improper installation.

title: A Subway Fire Delays Service For Four Hours
description: A smoky fire on tracks shared by three subway lines near the DeKalb Avenue station in Brooklyn stopped service for almost four hours during yesterday's evening rush and delayed more than 100,000 riders, the Transit Authority said.

title: Talking Deals;   Sour Investment By Pension Funds
description: A $425 MILLION deal that was widely heralded last year as the entry of American pension funds into Europe's real estate markets has been hammered recently by high interest rates in Britain, and the investors that took part in the deal have watched the value of the properties drop sharply in the last few months.

title: Republic New York Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Holyfield Files Motion Seeking To Fight Douglas on Sept. 21
description: Just when the heavyweight champion thought he was ready to climb back into the ring, another court matter may delay him.

title: Quipp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about vacant apartments in the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn misidentified the owner. The development, recently renamed Starrett at Spring Creek, is owned by Starrett City Associates, not the Starrett Housing Corporation.

title: Idex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits from tax loss carryforwards of $533,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,123,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $728,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,377,000, or 19 cents a share, for the 6 months, both from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Dow Falls 18.07 in Heavy Program Selling
description: Investors turned cautious yesterday amid heavy program selling, depressing stock prices for the first time in more than a week and leaving the Dow 3,000 level as a barrier still to be crossed.

title: Long Delay Seen in Patents For Genetic Engineering
description: The Patent and Trademark Office's slowness in issuing patents to companies developing genetically engineered drugs is worse than the agency says, according to new, still unpublished statistics.

title: Bridge
description: Several thousand players converging on Boston for the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which begin there tomorrow, will find one event already in progress. The Grand National Teams championship, which began at the grass-roots level eight months ago, is now down to 23 teams from all parts of the United States.

title: Comex Names New President
description: The New York Commodity Exchange yesterday confirmed the appointment of David A. Halperin as the new president of the exchange.

title: Times Co. Profit Dropped in the 2d Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that income in the second quarter fell to $26.8 million, or 35 cents a share, down 35.1 percent from net income of $41.3 million, or 53 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GORDON P. EATON is to be the new director of the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades, N.Y. Dr. Eaton, a geologist and president of Iowa State University, will take up his new duties at the observatory, one of the leading institutes of earth science in the world, on Nov. 1.

title: Comerica Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Alltel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated.

title: Market Place;   Paramount Gets No Rave Review
description: PARAMOUNT COMMUNICATIONS stock closed yesterday at 43, near its 52-week low of 40 1/2 and well below its 52-week high of 52 7/8. Behind the decline, several Wall Street analysts said, is the concern that the company has made a number of enormously expensive films including ''Harlem Nights,'' ''Another 48 Hours,'' ''Days of Thunder,'' ''The Two Jakes'' and ''Godfather III'' but that so far, none of those released have proved mega-hits to match their mega-budgets.

title: Beyond Murphy's Law
description: John Pike, the space specialist of the Federation of American Scientists, has observed fatalistically that recent troubling events at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration mostly reflect Murphy's Law in orbit: Anything that can go wrong will go wrong.

title: General Dynamics Loss Tied to Cost Overruns
description: The General Dynamics Corporation said today that it had a $240 million loss in the second quarter after setting aside $450 million to account for cost overruns on a new combat plane for the Navy. But the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, General Dynamics' partner in building the Navy plane, decided not to take a financial charge on the program and reported a profit of $57 million for the period.

title: Decorators Feel the Pinch As Jobs Wane
description: ''PEOPLE in this business are used to saying 'everything is fabulous,' '' a New York decorator said recently.

title: Parent & Child
description: RHODA and Bruce Miller's 19-year-old son, Marc, will leave home this fall to begin his junior year at the University of Delaware. But their two eldest sons, Bill, 22, and Jon, 21, are living at home in West Orange, N.J. ''indefinitely,'' Mrs. Miller said.

title: 80 SCHOOLS CHOSEN FOR NEW YORK TEST OF POWER SHARING
description: Eighty New York City schools have been chosen to begin Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's trademark experiment in power sharing among teachers, parents and principals, but scores of other schools have signaled a stiffening resistance to the Chancellor by staying out of the process.

title: Intergroup Proxy Battle
description: National Intergroup Inc. said today that it would offer Centaur Partners L.P. a seat on its board if it defeats the investment group's bid to gain three seats at the company's annual meeting next Wednesday.

title: Cash America Investments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arbitrator Finds 3d Case of Baseball Collusion
description: Major league baseball players completed a sweep of the collusion cases yesterday when an independent arbitrator ruled that club owners willfully acted against free agents by using a salary-offer databank in 1987 even though they had just been found guilty in the initial collusion case.

title: Street Theater Audience Must Make a Choice
description: ''The more aggressive you are as a member of the audience, the more you see,'' Mira-Lani Oglesby was saying. ''I know I always elbow my way to the front, every night I'm there.'' She's there rather frequently, being the co-author of ''Father Was a Peculiar Man,'' the theatrical event that is unfolding these nights in the streets of downtown Manhattan. From Wednesday through Saturday, 60 performers bring street theater to 160 audience members - quite literally, as they all traverse the cobblestones of the meatpacking district.

title: NASA WAS CURBED IN CHECKING MIRROR
description: A former head of the space agency testified today that the military restricted the number of NASA inspectors present when a defective mirror for the Hubble Space Telescope was made.

title: Gannett Co.  Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to July 1
description: Year-ago 13 weeks and 26 weeks ended June 25, 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JONATHAN POLLARD, who is serving a life sentence in a Federal penitentiary at Marion, Ill., for spying, is divorcing his wife, ANNE POLLARD. The papers were served yesterday to her bedside at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City.

title: Pyramid Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
New Sonoco President Plans Worldwide Focus
description: The Sonoco Products Company is not well known but it has been around for a while. It declared its 263d consecutive quarterly dividend yesterday and it also announced a new president and chief operating officer, Russell C. King Jr. Mr. King, 55, has worked for the manufacturer of paper and plastic products, which is the largest producer of plastic grocery sacks, since he got out of Wofford College, in Spartanburg, S.C., in 1956. He grew up in Darlington, S.C., not far from Sonoco's base in Hartsville, S.C.

title: Primary for Surrogate Attracts Big Spenders
description: Five candidates are likely to spend a total of about $2 million trying to win the Democratic nomination - and almost certain election - for one of two Manhattan surrogate posts.

title: San Francisco Treating Ex-Squatters as Guests
description: Most of the indigent men evicted from their sour-smelling bedrolls in a downtown park here the other day are now enjoying clean towels, catered meals, free telephones and the advice and comfort of caseworkers at two new shelters, where the homeless are invariably referred to as guests.

title: Apple Computer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
John Volkmann, 84, Psychology Professor
description: John Volkmann, professor emeritus of psychology at Mount Holyoke College, who specialized in the psychology of judgment, died last Thursday at his home in Northampton, Mass. He was 84 years old.

title: Art, and My First Dirty Word
description: When I was a little boy, my father spanked me when I was bad. It was my mother's duty to teach me to distinguish between right and wrong. When I stepped over the boundaries she had set for me, I knew I had him to answer to. She taught, he punished and I grew up.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace referred incorrectly in some editions to the outcome of the Alger Hiss case.

title: Apple's Net Up by 24.7% In 3d Quarter
description: Apple Computer Inc. today announced a substantial gain in net income in its most recent quarter but said it would probably report a decline in the quarter that has just begun.

title: Gannett Profits Decline 6.1%
description: Reporting its first quarterly drop since it went public 22 years ago, the Gannett Company said today that second-quarter earnings fell 6.1 percent from the comparable quarter in 1989.

title: A Dairy Town Doubts Brother Killed Brother
description: For as long as anyone here can remember, Adelbert Ward and his brother Bill were inseparable. Each morning they would ride into town together on their tractor - neither could drive a car -and order the same thing for breakfast.

title: Culling the Past to Embellish a Garden
description: ''In the summer, a lot of folk-art customers want to add something fanciful to the garden,'' said Thomas K. Woodard, owner of Thos. K. Woodard American Antiques & Quilts.

title: Bonds Fall as Inflation Rate Rises
description: Treasury bond prices sagged and long-term interest rates rose fairly sharply yesterday in response to disappointing inflation news and badly received testimony from the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Louisiana Legislators Take a New Attitude Toward Song Lyrics
description: The good times are rolling to a stop in Louisiana, where the State Senate has enacted a bill requiring warning stickers on albums with lyrics that advocate or encourage ''rape, incest, bestiality, sadomasochism, prostitution, homicide, unlawful ritualistic acts, suicide,'' as well as bias crimes and unlawful use of controlled drugs or alcohol.

title: Bronx Woman, 91, Is Killed In an Apparent Robbery
description: The body of a 91-year-old woman who had been beaten and stabbed to death was found yesterday in her Bronx apartment, the police said.

title: First Western Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Issues Asylum Rules Praised as Fairer to Aliens
description: The Bush Administration announced major changes today in immigration rules to protect the rights of aliens who seek asylum in the United States and fear persecution abroad.

title: Snap-On Tools Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: American Health Properties Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company sadi year-ago share earnings included $2.75 million one- time payment (25 cents a share) from American Medical International Inc. in consideration for certain lease amendments.

title: Profits Rise At 4 Large Drug Makers
description: Merck & Company, the world's largest drug company, said yesterday that its profits rose by 18.6 percent in the second quarter, which was in line with the company's forecasts of a slower growth in earnings after a 24 percent increase in all of 1989. Merck's sales in the quarter increased by 19.8 percent, surpassing analysts' predictions.

title: Prosecutor to Retry Youth in Mother's Death
description: The State's Attorney, facing intense public pressure to push for a second trial against Karin Aparo, moved today to retry the teen-ager on murder-conspiracy charges in her mother's 1987 death.

title: Sell Cars, Not Racism
description: American auto dealers are running ads that attack the Japanese, with slighting references to samurai warriors and physical stature. Such racism, a shameful response, is no substitute for making better cars. Disputing the cost or quality of Japanese cars is fair game; attacking their makers is not.

title: Garbo's Collection and a van Gogh Are to Be Sold
description: Greta Garbo's art collection -paintings by Renoir, Bonnard, Kees van Dongen and Alexei von Jawlensky - is to be auctioned along with her 18th-century French antique furnishings at Sotheby's in New York and London in the fall, Diana D. Brooks, president of Sotheby's in North America, announced yesterday.

title: Ball Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Organizers: Chip vs. Paper
description: THE computers I have been using are the size of small paperback books. They contain as much memory as desk-top computers did 10 years ago. Each can store over 1,000 telephone numbers and addresses, calculate spread sheets, keep my daily schedule and tell the time in over 200 cities.

title: Kroger Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
description: b-Net loss and after an after-tax loss of $3,940,318 from early repayment of $145 million of debt-related restructuring.

title: Constellation Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rolls-Royce Cuts
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the aircraft engine maker, said it would eliminate up to 800 jobs at its Bristol, England, plant. The cuts will be over the next two years, a company spokesman said. The plant, which employs about 8,000 people, makes military aircraft engines. The spokesman said the cuts were required because of the British Government's recent cancellation of an order for 33 Tornado aircraft.

title: Senate Votes to Give S.E.C. Wider Enforcement Powers
description: The Senate tonight approved a measure intended to strengthen the enforcement powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission by expanding the range of securities law violations for which it can impose civil penalties.

description: The company is a subsidiary of Eli Lilly & Co.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1989 have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split of outstanding common shares in May 1990.

WNET Names Director Of Public-Affairs Programs
description: Fred Noriega, a news producer and correspondent at WCBS-TV since 1975, will become the director of public-affairs programming at WNET, New York City's major public television station, on Aug. 20, the station announced yesterday.

title: Lutherans Punish 2 Churches for Gay Ordinations
description: After an extraordinary public hearing, thought to be the first by a church on the issue of ordaining homosexuals, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America suspended two congregations today for ordaining an openly gay man and two lesbians.

description: b-Net income

The company emerged from Chapter 11 on April 30. Share earnings information prior to the reorganization is not presented because it is not comparable to the company's post-reorganization operations or capitalization.

title: Karl Menninger, 96, Dies; Leader in U.S. Psychiatry
description: Dr. Karl Augustus Menninger, one of the foremost practitioners and advocates of psychiatry in the United States, died yesterday at Stormont-Vail Regional Medical Center in Topeka, Kan. He was 96 years old and lived in Topeka.

title: Alden Electronics Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to June 23
description: Year-ago period ended June 17, 1989.

title: MCI Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraodinary loss of $10 million from the early retirement of debt.

title: Chemical Plan for Securities From Allied Credit Accounts
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation said yesterday that two subsidiaries had developed a program to create securities out of the credit-card receivables of the Allied Stores Corporation, which has received protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Westcorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Homicide Is First in Tuckahoe in 15 Years
description: A 25-year-old woman was shot and killed on a much-traveled pathway near a Westchester County train station on Tuesday, and her father said today that she had moved from New York City because she thought it was too dangerous.

title: Review/Music;   Perlman And Ax
description: Though it may not rank up there with weighty issues like performance practice, the matter of who gets top billing in a concert program is not wholly negligible, since it can affect the way in which music is perceived. These days - perhaps always - billing has more to do with celebrity than with historical or musical sense, so it was altogether predictable that the violinist Itzhak Perlman would outrank the pianist Emanuel Ax in their joint recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival.

title: Star-Spangled Style Defines a Look And a Way of Life, Too
description: FOR years, people have been asking Mary Ellisor Emmerling when the American Country style will run its course. ''Never,'' she answers. ''It's just getting better and better. It's not a fad, it's a life style.''

title: Events: Antiques, Day Lilies and Gems
description: Catalogued Antiques, Westchester County Center, Bronx River Parkway at Central Avenue, White Plains; (914) 949-8900.

title: Despite Veto Threat, Senate Passes Civil Rights Measure
description: After failing to reach a compromise with the Bush Administration in last-minute negotiations, the Senate passed a major civil rights bill tonight in a form that President Bush has already threatened to veto.

title: A New Director At College Arts Center
description: A new director of the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College, Ralph Sandler, assumed his post on Monday.

title: Forschner Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago results are restated to reflect a change to the last-in, first-out method of accounting for inventories which resulted in reductions of $105,000 and $208,000 in income before taxes and 2 cents and 3 cents in net income per share from that previously reported under the first-in, first-out method for the three and 6-month periods ended June 30, 1989, respectively.

title: Inmate Loses Ruling on Procreation Rights
description: The Federal prison system can deny an inmate the right to father a child by artificial insemination, an appellate court panel has ruled.

title: Greenspan Sticks to Policy
description: The Fed chairman suggested interest rates would not drop soon, despite Administration pressure. But another rate is up: Consumer prices rose half a percent in June. Pages D1 and D5.

title: Alison Leggatt Is Dead; British Actress Was 86
description: Alison Leggatt, an actress who won renown in plays by John Osborne and Harold Pinter, died on Sunday, her family said today. She was 86 years old.

title: Killer Is Put to Death In Texas After Court Turns Down Appeal
description: A 33-year-old man with a criminal record that began when he was 12 was executed by injection early today for a 1980 murder.

description: b-Net loss The company said the increase in net income primarily resulted from the settlement of an audit by the I.R.S. Mid-America Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Iraq Speaks of Acts of War
description: Iraq warned fellow OPEC members today that it viewed violations of the cartel's production quotas as virtual acts of war, and accused neighboring Kuwait of stealing its oil over the last decade.

title: Brand Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock dividend paid this month.

title: Washington State Tax-Exempt Bonds
description: The State of Washington offered a total of $195 million in general obligation bonds in the tax-exempt municipal bond market yesterday.

title: Currents;   As 6 Artists Saw Cities Since 1910
description: ''THE URBAN LANDSCAPE,'' a show at the Philippe Daverio Gallery through Aug. 4, explores six artists' paintings, drawings and photographs dating from 1910 to the present.

title: Cray Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said it reported no revenue because it is in the development stage.

title: Magazine of the Right That Tripped Up a Tory
description: Its circulation is small, its stance conservative. Its editor is Dominic Lawson, the son of a prominent Tory. So when The Spectator became the magazine that brought down a senior Cabinet member in the Conservative Thatcher Government last week, some saw it as paradoxical.

title: Jefferson Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: The News Shuts Press And Cuts Some Jobs
description: In what it described as a cost-cutting measure, The Daily News shut down one of three presses last night at its satellite plant in Garden City, L.I., eliminating 15 to 20 jobs a night.

title: Piniella Expresses Anger at Steinbrenner
description: Lou Piniella, who served two terms as the Yankees' manager before being hired by the Reds shortly after last season, reacted angrily today to having his ''sports betting habits'' mentioned by George Steinbrenner during the Yankee owner's recent hearing with Commissioner Fay Vincent.

title: BBDO to Buy A Creative Atlanta Shop
description: IN a move calculated to increase the agency's creative firepower, BBDO/Atlanta announced yesterday that it would acquire Hutcheson/ Shutze, a small Atlanta agency known for its innovative work.

title: MacMillan Bloedel reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Roland de Margerie, French Diplomat, 91
description: Roland de Margerie, a French diplomat who played a major role in French-German reconciliation after World War II, died last week, his family said today. He was 91 years old.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cycare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included write-offs and provisions for restructuring charges related to the company's previously announced strategic redirection. c-Net income

title: ENDS RECOGNITION OF REBELS; AGREES TO TALKS WITH HANOI
description: In a major policy reversal, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d announced today that the Bush Administration was withdrawing its diplomatic recognition of the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, which includes the Communist Khmer Rouge, and opening negotiations with Vietnam on settling the Cambodian conflict.

title: Shawmut National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In Cambodia: Not a Moment Too Soon
description: ''We want to do everything we can to prevent a return of the Khmer Rouge to power.'' With those words, Secretary of State Baker has restored a measure of decency, and realism, to America's policy toward the tormented land of Cambodia.

title: United States Surgical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included for both periods a pre- tax gain of $4,394,000 which included receipt of $10,000,000 from the settlement of a patent infringement claim, less applicable legal expenses, and a $4,500,000 writedown of certain assets. All per share amounts and average number of common shares have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared on May 1, 1990.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Coordinated Apparel Inc., New York, a clothing manufacturer, named Richard T. Lewis president and chief operating officer. He replaces Frederick B. Dean, who becomes chairman and remains chief executive.

title: Merry Land & Investment Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Interstate Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $30.1 million, or 53 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. c-After extraordinary credits of $8.1 million, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $29.9 million, or 64 cents a share, for the 6 months, both from utilization of tax benefits; the 6 months also included income of $16,105,000, or 35 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Marxist Functionaries Prosper in New Poland
description: When the Solidarity-led Government began its ambitious program to convert the Polish economy to capitalism in January, Zenon Jurema was the general manager of the state-owned retail monopoly in this northern city.

title: Stanley Works reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest 6-month results included first quarter gain of $10 million, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of a drapery hardware business in Europe. The gain was partially offset by expenses of $7.1 million, for a contingency and aggregate expenses of $4.9 million for non-material items. Year-ago quarter results included a gain of $5.4 million, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of a portion of Stanley's investment in Max Co., partially offset by expenses of $2.3 million for environmental clean-up.

title: Price Index Surged 0.5% Last Month
description: Surges in the prices of food, housing and gasoline led to a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices in June, the Labor Department said today. The unexpectedly sharp rise followed two months of more modest advances and moved the annual rate of inflation up to 5.9 percent so far this year.

title: Sherwin-Williams, DeSoto In Deal
description: DeSoto Inc. announced it would sell its consumer paint business to the Sherwin-Williams Company of Cleveland for $80 million. The sale, which is subject to stockholder and regulatory approval, would complete a partial liquidation by DeSoto, based in Des Plaines, Ill., in hopes of avoiding a takeover by the Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York investment group.

title: General Dynamics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $500 million, representing $450 million of estimated cost overruns on the A-12 aircraft program for the U.S. Navy and $50 million of estimated costs overruns on the Sincgars radio contract with the U.S. Army for both the quarter and 6 months. The write-off after taxes was $330 million. The 6 months also included a net gain of $61.5 million, or $1.48 a share, from settlement of litigation. c-Net income and included a net charge of $50 million in the quarter and 6 months, related to a submarine program at the company's electric boat division.

title: Sealright Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $350,000 in the first quarter resulting from an 11-acre land transfer to Sealright from the City of Kansas City, Kansas.

title: Steinbrenner Hearing: Excerpts
description: Following are excerpts from George Steinbrenner's hearing before Commissioner Fay Vincent on July 5 and July 6, as released by the commissioner's office yesterday:

title: Summit Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $9,226,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Legent Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included first quarter charges of $975,000 related to the company's acquisition of Business Software Technology Inc. Fiscal 1989 earnings have been restated to reflect the November 1989 acquisition of Business Software Technology as a pooling of interests.

title: Omen for Young: Low Black Turnout
description: In his bid to become Georgia's first black governor, Andrew Young may have won a place on the runoff ballot Tuesday in the state's Democratic gubernatorial primary, but many of his campaign aides and other political observers said today that he had failed to generate the enthusiasm among black voters needed to win the nomination.

title: Peggy Mann Houlton, 65, Author Of Books About Drug Abuse, Dies
description: Peggy Mann Houlton, the author of more than 35 books and many magazine articles, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nuclear Waste Dump Will Fail, Study Says
description: The Government's approach to building an underground nuclear waste repository is ''bound to fail'' because it demands a level of safety that science cannot guarantee, the National Research Council said in a study made public today.

title: Rallying in the Pyrenees, Team Repays LeMond
description: Greg LeMond lost control of the Tour de France for 20 kilometers today, but he and his Z teammates rallied to prove the adage that professional bicycle racing is an individual sport practiced by teams.

title: U.S. Rests Case Depicting Barry as Drug Addict
description: The prosecution rested today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial after calling a final witness to bolster its contention that the Mayor regularly used drugs over the past six years and lied to investigators about that use.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Extra Patrols To Be Added For 7 Precincts
description: Stung by a steep rise in murders and robberies across New York City, the Dinkins administration announced yesterday that it would pay 200 police officers overtime wages each day to work extra shifts walking beats in seven of the most crime-ridden precincts.

title: Showbiz Pizza Time reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
TCF Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a reversal of tax benefits of $1,324,000. c-Net income and after tax loss carryforwards of $2,293,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,405,000, or 61 cents a share, for the 6 months. The company said the loss resulted from the balance sheet restructuring announced earlier this month that included the following actions: a $25 million second quarter provision for loan and real estate losses; the closing of its Texas thrift subsidiary and related writeoff of $13.1 million of goodwill; and the sales of mortgage- backed securities, collateralized mortgage obligation residuals, and loan servicing rights for a combined net gain of $224,000.

title: CHRONICLE
description: AUGUST WILSON and JUDY OLIVER plan to divorce, and Mr. Wilson blames it on work. The playwright, who has won two Pulitzer Prizes in three years, said that he has been home only about three months a year during the last five years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Marlboro Cup Pairings
description: Pairings in the Marlboro Cup of New York soccer tournament, Aug. 10 and 12 at Giants Stadium, were announced yesterday at a news luncheon at the ''21'' Club. The United States national team, the defending Marlboro Cup champions, will play Flamengo of Brazil in the second game of a doubleheader on Friday, Aug. 10. Sporting Lisbon of Portugal will play Alianza of Peru in the opener at 7 P.M.

title: Evolution in Europe;   U.S. Gives Soviets Menu Of American Expertise
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has given Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union a list of economic assistance projects the Bush Administration is prepared to undertake in the Soviet Union, a senior Administration official said today.

title: People
description: * Thomas De Francesco has been appointed director of marketing at the Reader's Digest magazine Travel Holiday.

description: b-Included a gain of $2,266,000, or 17 cents a share, from early extinguishment of debt and tax-loss carryforward. c-Included a tax credit of $55,000. Results for the latest quarter included a loss of $344,000 from sale of a division.
