description: b-Net income Latest periods' results included a $7 million charge to recognize a further decline in value of the assets of its real estate project in Nashville, Tenn.

title: Other Stars Who Have Served Time
description: In drawing a five-month sentence for two felony tax-evasion convictions, Pete Rose yesterday became the latest in a line of well-known athletes who have been incarcerated for deeds off the playing field.

title: Rangers Sign Two
description: The Rangers yesterday signed two defensemen: Kord Cernich, who had 11 goals and 25 assists in 46 games last season with Lake Superior State, and Eric Germain, a free agent who spent the last three years in the Los Angeles Kings organization, playing 59 games last season with New Haven of the American Hockey League.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said Canadian Airlines International had converted options to firm orders for three jets valued about $350 million.

title: MCA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.2 million for the quarter and $1,146,000 for the 6 months.

title: Unisys Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are after payment of preferred stock dividends totaling $26.9 million and $29.8 million in the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, as well as $53.7 million and $53.6 million in the latest and year-ago 6-month periods, respectively.

title: We'll Be Sorry if Japan's Money Stays at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: New European Telescope Called Equal to Hubble
description: While the space agency tries to overcome a crippling flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope, European scientists have developed a new type of ground-based telescope that promises to work as well as a perfectly functioning space-based instrument at a small fraction of the Hubble's cost.

title: 'Get Shorty'
description: I am an Elmore Leonard fan. I tell you this primarily so you will understand that I would never, ever, under any circumstances read a review of a new Elmore Leonard book. I am not even sure what I'm doing writing one, except that it gave me the opportunity to read the new Elmore Leonard before anyone else.

title: Rose Sentenced to 5 Months For Filing False Tax Returns
description: Pete Rose, baseball's career hit leader, was sentenced today to five months in a Federal correctional institution for filing false income-tax returns.

title: Corning to Sell Most of Iwaki Stake
description: Corning Inc. agreed to sell most of its 33.4 percent stake in the Iwaki Glass Company, a Tokyo-based manufacturer of industrial, consumer and laboratory products, to its partner in the concern, the Asahi Glass Company. Corning would not disclose the amount, but said the deal would result in a one-time gain after taxes of $18 million against its third-quarter earnings. Corning will own about 3 percent of Iwaki. A third of Iwaki's stock is traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange; Asahi will hold the rest.

title: DEALS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Economic Scene;   The Evidence Backs Greenspan
description: IN his testimony this week on the midyear state of the economy, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, seemed to be tiptoeing through a mine field, spread with the dangers of recession, inflation, a worsening budget deficit and a weakened financial structure in the private sector.

title: Slain Woman 'Loved Her TV' and Baseball
description: At 91 years of age, Susie White still did her own shopping, attended church on most Sundays, and enjoyed going on trips with the Senior Citizens Center of the James Monroe Houses in the Soundview section of the Bronx.

title: Unisys Profit Off Sharply
description: The Unisys Corporation reported today that its second-quarter profit fell sharply, blaming weak domestic sales in part for the results.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sonic Boom

title: Grumman's Chairman Resigns Unexpectedly
description: The chairman of the Grumman Corporation resigned unexpectedly yesterday. John O'Brien, an outspoken leader who is credited with guiding the aerospace concern through difficult times, is leaving the company immediately for ''personal reasons,'' a statement said.

title: Reds Lose Jackson
description: For the Cincinnati Reds' left-hander Danny Jackson, a torn rotator cuff couldn't have come at a worse time.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on Monday about the Richard Nixon Library, and a resulting correction in this space yesterday, referred incorrectly to the outcome of the Alger Hiss case in 1950. The charge on which Mr. Hiss was convicted was perjury, arising from his denial of having provided secret State Department documents to a confessed former Communist spy, Whittaker Chambers.

title: Commonwealth Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 6-month revenues included the effect of a rate rollback ordered by the state supreme court in May, and a refund ordered in June by the Illinois appellate court concerning Commonwealth's Byron 1 nuclear plant. The company recorded a net provision of $253 million for refunds in the State Supreme court case. In the Byron 1 case, it recorded a $208 million charge to cover court-ordered refunds.

title: Schlumberger Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $35,000,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: Progressive Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: World Lawyers' Group Cancels Kenya Parley
description: The International Bar Association announced today that it had canceled its annual convention scheduled in Kenya. The move came at a time of international criticism of the human rights record of the Government.

title: Rev. Nelson Thayer, A Drew Professor, 53
description: The Rev. Dr. Nelson Thayer, a professor of psychology and religion at Drew University, died yesterday at his home in Madison, N.J. He was 53 years old.

title: G.O.P. Whip Withdraws Opposition to Taxes
description: One day after lending his vocal support to a Republican resolution that opposed any tax increases, the House Republican whip today told budget negotiators that he was prepared to ''sponsor and support'' such increases.

title: Gallimard's President Wins Control
description: A bitter family battle for control of Editions Gallimard ended today with a victory for its president, Antoine Gallimard.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citicorp, New York named as a director H. O. Ruding, a former finance minister of the Netherlands.

title: Owens-Corning Fiberglas reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $1,000,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: A Nuclear Step and Maybe a Leap
description: In a transaction that could pave the way for building new nuclear plants, the Consumers Power Company said yesterday that it had arranged to sell a major part of a 19-year-old reactor to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, a reactor manufacturer. Consumers Power, the biggest utility in Michigan, had already announced that the Bechtel Power Corporation, which manages nuclear construction, would buy a share.

title: Higher Fares, Less Reward: New York Cabs Hit a Slump
description: The taxi industry in New York City has undergone sweeping changes in the last 18 months that have made the business less rewarding for drivers and owners.

title: KEY RATES
Moscow Sends Security Chief To Kirghizia After New Riots
description: The commander of the Soviet Union's security troops, Col. Gen. Yuri Shatalin, has flown to the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia to coordinate action after the killing of several more people in ethnic rioting, the press agency Tass said today.

title: Ripken Ties Errorless Mark as Orioles Win
description: Cal Ripken Jr. tied a major league record with his 88th consecutive errorless game at shortstop and drove in two runs with a first-inning double tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Chicago White Sox, 4-1.

title: Polish President Says He Is Willing to Yield Office
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist President of Poland, today expressed willingness to give up his office to a freely elected successor, perhaps as soon as this year.

title: BankAmerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included nets of $44 million, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and $82 million, or 43 cents a share, for the 6 months, both from cash interest payments by Brazil on medium- and long- term debt.

title: A Lesson From Vincent
description: The focus may have been on the best interests of baseball, but with 15 lawyers in the room, hardly excluding the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, it is not surprising that the talk at the commissioner's recent hearing into the George Steinbrenner matter got a bit lawyerly at times.

title: Barry's Bodyguards Testify That They Never Saw Him Using Drugs
description: Appearing as the defense's first witnesses, two of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s bodyguards testified today in his trial in Federal court that they had never seen him use or possess drugs.

title: Browning-Ferris Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $301,529,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,529,000 and $11,240,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations. The company said the loss for the latest 9-month included a $295 million charge related to the company's decision to discontinue its hazardous waste operations.

title: Leonard Rosenblatt, Executive, Dies at 60
description: Leonard Rosenblatt, former president and chief executive of Ausimont Industries, a multinational chemical company with headquarters in Waltham, Mass., died yesterday at Dana Farber Institute in Boston. He was 60 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Another Nixon Summit, at His Library
description: Almost 16 years after he resigned the Presidency in disgrace, Richard M. Nixon was hailed today as a statesman and a peacemaker as he presided over the dedication of the $21 million Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace in this small Orange County town.

title: Sunbelt-Case Plea Entered
description: The former chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas pleaded not guilty today to bank-fraud charges stemming from his efforts to finance a $700 million real estate deal in California.

title: University of Michigan Wins Race for Solar-Powered Cars
description: The Sunrunner, a student-built solar car that runs on ''the power of a hair dryer,'' today won a Florida-to-Detroit race by 32 sun-powered vehicles.

title: Tiozzo to Make Title Defense
description: Christophe Tiozzo of France makes the first defense of his World Boxing Association supermiddleweight title Friday night against Paul Whittaker of Kenner, La.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: INSIDE
description: South Korea to Open Border

title: Choice of Cell Irks Sharpton
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who on Wednesday began serving a 15-day jail sentence for disorderly conduct, complained yesterday that he had been made to sleep in a Rikers Island jail bed that had been occupied by a defendant in the Bensonhurst racial-killing case.

title: Outdoors, Concert Fare That's Serious And Rare
description: MANY concertgoers consider hearing music out of doors an inherently less focused undertaking than listening to a performance in a concert hall. That view is not groundless: outdoor concerts are often built on decidedly ''lite'' fare, and encourage the notion that the performances, like Baroque Tafelmusik, are being offered as pleasantly innocuous dinner music.

title: Pete Rose Won't Con The Kids
description: For Pete Rose, the first five months will be the easiest. He must report on Aug. 10 to an Ashland, Ky., ''minicamp,'' as it's known, that is still under construction across the street from a Federal medium-security slammer about a three-hour drive from the courthouse where he was sentenced yesterday for two felony tax-evasion convictions.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Third Avenue Summerfest, Third Avenue in Manhattan will be closed Sunday from 42d to 57th Streets from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Books of The Times;   A Pair of Authors' Fictional Collage of a Doomed Artist
description: Boone

title: Textron Has 21.6% Gain
description: Textron Inc. reported today that its net income in the second quarter was up 21.6 percent, to $72.1 million. The company said the earnings, which amounted to 80 cents a share, had improved from the $59.3 million, or 67 cents a share, it earned from April through June 1989.

title: Nynex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter and 6-month results included a $39 million pretax charge for an early retirement program.

title: Kubota Is Put in Middle Of an East-West Clash
description: For his first meeting with officials of Kubota Ltd. in 1986, Allen H. Michels decorated the offices of his Silicon Valley computer company with pictures of tractors. It was a sign of respect for the Osaka-based farm equipment manufacturer that was to end up investing $45 million in Mr. Michels's company, the Ardent Computer Corporation, over three years.

title: The 90 Points Of Light
description: LEAD: Dead cool, as Paul Mc-Cartney likes to say. His band is on a tear. The problem is the audience - same heads, only lots of them balding now, and they all had to get sitters. As the thirtysomethings wait for some power chords they know, their discomfort is duly noted by a reporter (well, me, actually).

title: Patchogue Clamming Is Back
description: Six years after a 750-acre area of Patchogue Bay was found too polluted for shellfishing, the state has declared the clams clean and reopened the waters. The pollution had stemmed from Patchogue's sewage plant, which was upgraded in 1985. The town of Brookhaven and Suffolk County tested the water and the shellfish for three years, and the State Environmental Conservation Department said Wednesday that shellfishing could resume. Brookhaven officials said the area would be open to clammers from December to March each year.

title: American President Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Bond Agrees To Resign
description: Alan Bond, the Australian entrepreneur with worldwide holdings in brewing, real estate and publishing, will resign as chairman of his company to appease creditors under an agreement announced today.

title: First Fidelity Bancorp-N.J.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Explosion Kills One and Injures 63 in Ohio
description: Two explosions ripped through a chemical plant on this city's North Side today, killing one worker, leaving another missing and injuring at least 63 people at the plant and in nearby homes and businesses.

title: Embalmed Body of Bulgarian Communist Is Taken From Mausoleum and Cremated
description: The embalmed body of the man regarded as the founder of Communist Bulgaria, Georgi Dimitrov, was removed from a mausoleum in Sofia's main square on Wednesday and cremated, news reports in Sofia said today.

title: People
description: * Allen Klein has been named senior vice president and group creative director at Leo Burnett Co.

title: Western Union Sweetens Offer
description: The financially troubled Western Union Corporation yesterday sweetened its exchange offer for bondholders for the fourth time, and a spokesman for the bondholders said he expected the offer would be accepted.

title: South African Communist on the Air
description: Joe Slovo, who as leader of the South African Communist Party evokes fear and loathing in many whites, went on a popular phone-in radio show here Wednesday night to answer questions about himself and his party, both of which were outlawed until February.

title: Textron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $9,500,000.

title: Big Profit For No. 3 U.S. Bank
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank, announced yesterday that its earnings declined 12 percent in the second quarter, but profits were still more than at any other banking company in the country.

title: Hercules Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $15,039,000, or 32 cents a share. The company said latest quarter and 6 months results included a non- recurring charge of $5.1 million related to the shutdown of a facility. Year-ago quarter figures included non-recurring gains of $2.5 million, or 5 cents a share, while year-ago 6-month figures included non-recurring gains of $8.6 million, or 17 cents a share.

title: 2 Brothers Admit Fraud Scheme; Judge Orders Fines of $1.2 Million
description: Two brothers who operate an electrical contracting company pleaded guilty yesterday to fraudulently billing the City of New York and agreed to pay fines of as much as $1.2 million, city investigators said.

title: Shadowy Bombing Case Is Focusing On Reclusive and Enigmatic Figure
description: He's a phantom, a reclusive loner with a mop of dark hair and hypnotic eyes who for the most part has gone though life without a trace.

title: Law;   Supreme Court Dissenters: Loners or Pioneers?
description: A Supreme Court term earns its place in history on the basis of its majority opinions, the arguments that prevailed rather than those the majority discarded or overlooked.

title: Leary Wins and Righetti Sets a Record
description: At a time in Yankee history when the avoidance of ignominy can be considered a sign of progress, Tim Leary made progress tonight.

title: PPG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $25 million related to the company's chemical business.

title: We'll Be Sorry if Japan's Money Stays at Home;   Far From a Free Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Panel Orders Raises for City Judges
description: A New York appeals court ruled today that some City Court judges are entitled to pay raises.

title: Edward J. Williams, Investor, 42
description: Edward J. Williams, senior managing director in the government securities department of Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banking and brokerage firm, was pronounced dead on Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 42 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Many Companies in Pennsylvania Reject State's Takeover Protection
description: When Pennsylvania passed the toughest anti-takeover law in the nation three months ago, the move was seen as a favor for the state's companies, protecting them from unfriendly bidders. But in the last couple of weeks, many of Pennsylvania's largest and best-known corporations, including the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the H. J. Heinz Company, have chosen to exclude themselves from that protection.

title: At the Movies
description: Rooker's Past

title: Chronicle
description: Mother Goose has inspired six leading illustrators of children's books to produce a limited-edition portfolio based on the captivating rhymes. Its sales are to help homeless children. The six, MAURICE SENDAK, CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG, BARRY MOSER, SEYMOUR CHWAST, DANIEL PALAVIN and GUY BILLOUT have been working separately on the ''The Mother Goose Collection'' for a year. They will come together in Manhattan next Thursday to sign and number the works at 2 P.M. at the United States Trust Building, at 114 West 47th Street.

title: Trump Phone Poll Skewed
description: A Cincinnati financier, Carl H. Lindner, organized a phone blitz that skewed the results of a call-in telephone poll on Donald Trump conducted for USA Today, the newspaper said today.

title: Germans to Unify Soccer Teams
description: Soccer officials from East and West Germany agreed today to merge their leagues and form a joint national team next year.

title: Review/Film;   Marlon Brando as Importer, Or Whatever It Is He Does
description: Daybreak. A cornfield. Two men in evening clothes. And a seven-foot lizard on a leash. These components of the final scene of ''The Freshman,'' a witty and enchanted comedy written and directed by Andrew Bergman, will not reveal anything worthwhile about how the film's mad plot finally resolves itself. But they may offer some indication of just how sweetly unpredictable and how warmly, enduringly peculiar Mr. Bergman's brand of humor can be.

title: Cone's Strikeout Toll Grows as Braves Fall
description: David Cone could soon be ready for marathons. The Mets right-hander last night turned in his fourth consecutive 10K-plus performance, striking out 11 as the Mets scored a 6-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium.

title: Signet Banking reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tennis Open Raises Prize
description: The men's and women's singles winners this year at the United States Open tennis tournament will each earn $350,000 and the doubles winners will earn $142,861 each from a record total of $6,349,250 in prize money.

title: Apple Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraodinary credits of $1,991,000, or 44 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,691,000, or 59 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Harris Acquisition
description: D. George Harris & Associates, an investment group, said it had agreed to acquire the soda products division of the Kerr-McGee Chemical Corporation, an energy and chemical company based in Oklahoma City, for $210 million. The division has 1,100 employees. The deal includes three chemical-processing plants in Trona, Calif.

title: 'Be Nice to the Germans'
description: Before a visit to Britain last spring by the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, Margaret Thatcher confidentially convened a seminar of experts to discuss Germany's past, present and future as a powerful reunited nation in the heart of a new Europe.

title: A 28-Year Clorox Man Is Named President
description: The Clorox Company, known for its bleach and other household products, announced yesterday that it had named Robert A. Bolingbroke as president and chief operating officer.

title: U.S. Jury Subpoenas Records Of South Carolina Politicians
description: A Federal grand jury here has subpoenaed the campaign records of all 124 members of the state's House of Representatives, and news reports here today said the inquiry was tied to an undercover effort by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in which lawmakers were offered cash in exchange for their votes.

title: Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wilmington Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Inland Steel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected a pre-tax charge of $17 million to settle a claim by a supplier.

title: Review/Theater;   Gotta Sing! (But Only if the Song's in a Failed Show.)
description: ''Ed Linderman's Broadway Jukebox'' has a nifty concept. On entering the John Houseman Theater, patrons are handed a list of 85 songs chosen mostly from unsuccessful shows of the last three decades and given slips of paper on which to vote for the ones they would like to hear.

title: Keystone Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chronicle
description: The first Frenchwoman to become a rabbi, despite some hostile reactions, will be installed in the synagogue of the Jewish Liberal Movement of France in Paris on Sept. 1. The rabbi, OAULINEcq BEBE, 26 years old, said recently that she was sure that God has a sense of humor and that her pioneering quest seemed a natural culmination of her studies in England and Israel, with support by American organizations.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TV Weekend;   Not So Tall in the Saddle, A Teacher Meets the West
description: Despite a violence quotient that might make ''Die Hard 2'' blanch, ''El Diablo'' is a splendid hoot of a western, a kind of tall tale told with a sly wink. Directed by Peter Markle (''Youngblood''), the Wizan/Black Films production is having its premiere on Home Box Office at 8 on Sunday evening.

title: Equimark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the decrease in revenues primarily to the sale of the company's homes in Michigan and Iowa. Year-ago quarter and 6-month results included pretax restructuring charges of about $120,023,000 and $128,104,000, respectively.

title: Georgia-Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOV. DUKAKIS SIGNS INCREASE IN TAXES
description: Given a push by an opinion from the state's highest court, a package of tax increases totaling more than $1 billion and intended to solve Massachusetts' fiscal crisis has been signed into law by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Give Screenwriters Credit for What They Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Hall of Fame Voting: How Rose Might Fare
description: Pete Rose, baseball's career hit leader, will go on the ballot for the Hall of Fame in December 1991. He would need 75 percent of the voting members of the Baseball Writers Association of America (last year there were 444 voters). Some of the voters were asked yesterday how Rose's prison sentence would affect their vote.

title: Seoul to Open Border With North Briefly
description: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea announced today that his Government would open the border with North Korea at Panmunjon for five days next month to permit citizens of North and South Korea to travel in each other's countries.

title: Dr. David Decker, Cancer Researcher, 72
description: Dr. David Decker, who developed two important drugs in the treatment of ovarian cancer, died of bone cancer Tuesday at his home here. He was 72 years old. Dr. Decker joined the Mayo Clinic in 1947 as a graduate fellow and became a consultant in 1950. He was chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology from 1969 to 1977.

title: Magazines' Ad Prospects Look Bleak
description: AS magazine publishers start negotiating with advertisers this month for advertising contracts for 1991, the publishers are faced with a bleak prospect. It is beginning to look as if some important advertisers are not very interested in magazines, and the downturn in advertising that began this year may pick up momentum next year.

title: Review/Art;   Linking Words and Images Explosively
description: Lorna Simpson's Conceptual-based art, which is currently the subject of a ''Projects'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, has a double theme: the oppression of blacks and of women. Combining large-scale photographs with words engraved on small plastic plaques, Ms. Simpson fuses these themes into a unity that is sometimes provocative, sometimes too simple and stylish for its own good.

title: Old National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Farm Subsidies: Milking Us Dry
description: LEAD: If the farm bill is passed by Congress in its present form, it will richly deserve the veto that the Agriculture Secretary, Clayton Yeutter, has recommended. Farm subsidies over the next five years would cost Americans hundreds of thousands of dollars for each full-time farmer in the nation.

title: American Express Net Rises 1.2%
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings edged up 1.2 percent from the quarter a year earlier and that revenues fell slightly.

title: Mack Trucks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $266,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $812,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: West One Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sounds Around Town
description: Much Trumpeting

title: Central & South West Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Central Bancshares of the South reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Life-Science Research Faces Legal Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman and Allen Pound Out A Tie at St. Andrews With 66
description: If the Old Course continues to take the kind of par pounding that was administered by the field today in the first round of the 119th British Open, the knobby moonscape fairways may look like a parking lot with a couple of speed bumps by the end of the championship.

title: China Faults U.S. Shift on Cambodia
description: China issued a stern and disappointed response today to the American announcement that Washington was withdrawing support for China's closest ally in Cambodia and beginning direct talks with Vietnam, China's bitterest rival in Asia.

title: Washington Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Firstar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place;   Integrated's Battle Over Partnerships
description: IN the world of investing, there are few better positions than that of general partner in a widely distributed partnership. The fees roll in, generally regardless of how well the partnership is doing, and it is difficult to lose the job.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Greek Orthodox Church and the New York visit of Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I of Constantinople referred incorrectly to Peter F. Vallone. He is the Speaker of the City Council, not the President.

title: Lady Ashton, 92, Dies; English Fashion Editor
description: Lady Ashton, better known as Madge Garland, who was fashion editor of English Vogue in the 1930's and founded the Royal College of Art's Fashion School, has died, according to news reports on Wednesday. She was 92 years old.

title: American General's Net Increases by 4.2%
description: The American General Corporation, the large Houston-based insurer that put itself on the auction block last May, said today that its net income rose 4.2 percent in the second quarter, to $198 million, or $1.65 a share.

title: United Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for latest periods included a pre-tax charge of $30 million related to the planned closing of a carrier compressor manufacturing facility in Syracuse, N.Y.

title: Champion International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ferro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Film;   Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Seals, Grown Up and in the Navy
description: What will Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles be when they grow up? On the evidence of ''Navy Seals,'' they are perfectly suited to be members of an elite Navy commando team. The men who fight Middle Eastern terrorists in this new action film are a mere step away from the adolescent Turtles in maturity and complexity of character, though they are not likely to come near them in box-office grosses.

title: American General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $86,603,000, or 65 cents a share, for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: The Bosch Case Does Violence to Justice
description: The release from jail of Orlando Bosch, convicted of terrorist violence and officially deemed a most undesirable alien, is a startling example of political justice. The Justice Department, under no legal compulsion but conspicuous political pressure, has let him out, winning cheers from local politicians - and squandering American credibility on issues of terrorism.

title: Bugno Wins a 2d Stage
description: Gianni Bugno of Italy won his second stage in the Tour de France today and it was again a big one, the traditional sprint at the end of the long, flat trip from Pau to Bordeaux.

title: Judge Upholds X Rating For Almodovar Film
description: A New York State judge upheld the X rating given to the Pedro Almodovar film ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' yesterday and said he inferred that Miramax Films, the distributor, had brought the suit for publicity purposes.

title: Arlington Losing Appealing Matchups
description: Easy Goer's retirement from racing on Wednesday not only stripped the Arlington Challenge Cup of most of its appeal, but also pointed out the dangers of predicating an entire race on the participation of a particular horse.

title: EG&G Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Won some, lost some, all interesting.''

title: Stotler Accepts Offer for Stake
description: A financially pressed commodity brokerage headed by the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, Karsten Mahlmann, said today that it had tentatively accepted an investor's offer to buy a substantial stake in the company.

title: Bias Seen Against Pregnant Addicts
description: Most women prosecuted for using illegal drugs while pregnant have been poor members of racial minorities, experts say, even though drug use in pregnancy is equally prevalent in white middle-class women.

title: Northern Trust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jets Sign Hector but Can't Agree On Terms With Top Draft Pick
description: The Jets agreed to terms yesterday with Johnny Hector, their leading rusher last season, but negotiations with their No. 1 draft choice, Blair Thomas, produced no agreement.

title: Occidental Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $20,000,000, or 7 cents a share, primarily due to a federal income tax benefit realized from the application of a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains, and $18,000,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the quarter also included an after-tax gain of $41 million from the sale of certain domestic oil and gas properties. c-Included an extraordinary loss of $4,000,000 and $13,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the quarter's extraordinary loss was from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: WHITE HOUSE BARS IRAQ FURNACE SALE
description: The White House moved today to block the shipment of three advanced industrial furnaces to Iraq because of concern that they will be used on nuclear weapons-related projects.

title: Citytrust Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included one-time gain of $3.4 million from sale of credit card portfolio. The company attributed the latest quarter loss to the loan-loss provision, the writedown of $3.5 million of real estate and lost interest income and collection expenses related to the ''high'' level of non-performing assets.

title: Caesars Seeks Rest Of Jersey Casino
description: Caesars World Inc. said it would begin a $22-a-share tender offer for the 13.4 percent of Caesars New Jersey Inc. that it does not own. The offer is valued at $47.9 million.

title: Scientific Link Is Still Missing In Jogger Trial
description: Offering what is believed to be their final forensic evidence, the prosecutors failed again yesterday to link scientifically three defendants to the rape and attempted murder of the Central Park jogger.

title: U.S. Says Envoy Suspected as Spy Tried to Resign on Eve of Hearing
description: Felix S. Bloch, the American diplomat who is suspected of spying for the Soviet Union, tried two weeks ago to quit his State Department job, the department said today. The effort came a few days before Mr. Bloch was to appear at a hearing to protest efforts to dismiss him as a national security threat, the department said.

title: Ralston Purina reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $71,300,000, or $1.11 a share.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: How Doctor of Law Degree Came About
description: To the Editor:

title: Pollution Raises Cost Of Bailout
description: Pollution problems at properties the Government has taken from failed savings institutions will add billions of dollars to the cost of the savings and loan bailout, Government officials and environmental experts said today.

title: Contracts Fill the Life of Steinbrenner
description: To followers of the life and times of George Steinbrenner, the seeming inconsistencies raised in his testimony at his recent hearing before the commissioner of baseball, Fay Vincent, add up to the consistencies in the history of the Yankees' principal owner.

title: Formal Reprimand of Rep. Frank Is Urged by House's Ethics Panel
description: The House ethics committee voted today to recommend that Representative Barney Frank receive a formal reprimand from the House for his relationship with a male prostitute, Congressional officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Remi

title: Glenfed reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $23 million gain, or 78 cents a share, from the sale of a major foreclosed land holding. The company said results reflect discontinued operations of three subsidiaries, Glenfed Development Corp., Glenfed Capital Corp. and Glenfed Financial Corp., which are in the process of being sold.

title: Multimedia Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,078,000 for the quarter and 6 months due to a loss from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Banks of Iowa reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Atlantic Monthly Wins Right to Book on Havel
description: Atlantic Monthly Press won the auction yesterday for the authorized biography of Vaclav Havel, the playwright who became President of Czechoslovakia last December. It plans to publish the book in the fall of 1991.

title: New York Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chrysler Expecting to Post A Big Loss in Third Quarter
description: The Chrysler Corporation acknowledged today that it expects to report a ''substantial loss'' in its third quarter, ending on Sept. 30.

title: S.E.C. Chairman Criticizes Proposal to Tax Stock Sales
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Richard C. Breeden, warned today that a proposed tax on the sale of securities could lead to an exodus of foreign investors from the nation's stock markets.

title: Courtroom Statements By Rose and the Judge
description: Following are the statement made by Pete Rose at his sentencing in United States District Court in Cincinnati and excerpts from the statement by Judge S. Arthur Spiegel, as reported by The Associated Press.

title: Goodwill Games Open With Large Turnout
description: Four years ago in Moscow, the Turner Broadcasting System, Ted Turner, president, set out to prove that leading international athletes might enjoy competing against one another in a major event even if the countries they represented did not necessarily get along politically.

title: Phelps Dodge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results represent net on preferred dividends and net applicable to common stock, except for the year-ago 6 months which represent preferred dividends and are fully-diluted. Results for year-ago periods have been restated to reflect the consolidation of the company's majority-owned foreign subsidiaries that were previously accounted for on the equity basis. Revenue represents sales and other operating revenues.

title: American Electric Power reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Wall Denies Silverado Intervention
description: M. Danny Wall, the former chief Federal regulator of the savings and loan industry, denied today that the closing of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver was delayed until after the 1988 Presidential elections to avoid political embarrassment for President Bush, whose son Neil was a Silverado director until August that year.

title: Ex-Sabre Loses Appeal
description: A New York appeals court in Buffalo has upheld a lower court's decision dismissing a lawsuit by a former Sabres star, Rick Martin, that charged the team with misdiagnosing a knee injury that ultimately ended his career.

title: Illinois Tool Works reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Our Towns;   The Porch War: Will 19th Century Win Over 18th?
description: Like many houses here, 128 Main Street was built in the colonial style around 1790. And like many such homes, during the late 19th century, as this became a tourist area, the colonials were embellished with Victorian-style additions, including a small front porch.

title: They're Young, Bright and Talented, And on Broadway
description: IF you're 10 years old and you want to be a firefighter, all you can do is play with the garden hose and wait. Major league baseball player? Join the Little League. But if you want to be a professonal actor - right now - you just might have a shot.

title: Yankees' Owner Waits With Apprehension
description: While expressing confidence about how his baseball future will turn out, George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he would find it difficult to accept a suspension and under no circumstances would he sell the Yankees.

title: Primerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Second-quarter results included net gains totaling $12.3 million which were largely offset by net losses totaling $11.1 million. The gains included $9.7 million from the sale of 6.3 million shares of its Fingerhut subsidiary in an initial public offering and $2.6 million from the sale of its investment in TransAtlantic Holdings Inc., which also completed an initial public offering. The $11.1 of losses were from its investment portfolio.

title: When Finding the Gold Can Take a Little Brass
description: Alice Mason entertains real-estate clients at dinner parties that make the gossip columns. Linda Stein, known as the broker to the stars, poses for paparazzi with movie actors and rock musicians. Edward Lee Cave escorts clients to charity balls, while Clark Halstead transports clients in a London cab refitted with accouterments from a London club.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Eating Outdoors

title: Los Ebanos Journal;   Time No Longer Stays Still for Ferry
description: In this sleepy community a few yards from the border, the boundaries between the United States and Mexico tend to blur.

title: Centex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Accounts
description: * Malden Mills, Lawrence, Mass., a maker of synthetic fabrics used in outdoor garments, to Mullen Advertising, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Wanted: Land For Dump Sites; Benefits Offered
description: One of the nation's largest waste-disposal companies wants to locate garbage landfills in New York State and in an unusual twist is asking for volunteers.

title: Bonn and Prague Leaders Plan to Meet Waldheim
description: Presidents Richard von Weizsacker of West Germany and Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia plan to meet Kurt Waldheim next Thursday, which would end four years of near-isolation for Austria's head of state.

title: Prostitute Was Paid For Newsweek Article
description: Newsweek has acknowledged paying an Oakland prostitute $60 after she posed for a photograph and told the magazine's reporter that she was continuing to work the streets despite being infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Canadian Prelate Quits In Clerics' Sex Scandal
description: The Archbishop of Newfoundland has resigned after charges that the Roman Catholic Church's hierarchy ignored or failed to deal effectively with three years of scandal involving allegations of sexual abuse against altar boys, orphaned youths and others by Roman Catholic priests and church laymen.

title: Manila Assesses Damage and High Cost of Quake
description: As the generally fruitless and frustrating search for survivors of Monday's earthquake continued today, Philippine officials began to assess the physical damage and weigh the costs of reconstruction.

title: T as in Treasure, Texas - and Theft
description: The Quedlinburg Treasure, slowly surfacing in Texas, is the stuff of a Dashiell Hammett novel. Like the Maltese Falcon, it provokes enormous greed. What it doesn't appear to provoke is a sense of shame among those delaying its return to its proper owner, a German church.

title: Bit Player to Top Hare, or, Hopping to Stardom
description: Bugs Bunny, the future movie star, publicly uttered his first ''Eh, what's up, Doc?'' on July 27, 1940, the day that ''A Wild Hare,'' a landmark Warner Brothers cartoon, was released. ''It's a convenient peg to hang a 50th anniversary exhibition on,'' said Brian Walker, exhibit director of the Museum of Cartoon Art in Westchester County. ''But of course, there's plenty of controversy over Bugs's true birthdate.''

title: ARCO Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $43,000,000, or 45 cents a share. The company said it changed from the deferred method to the liability method of accounting for income taxes, resulting in a 45 cents a share effect.

title: Port-au-Prince Journal;   Boldly, Duvalier Bullies Step From the Shadows
description: To hear Claude Raymond tell it, he is just one of several democratically inclined candidates who pin their hopes for an end to chaos here on elections in November.

title: When Reality Dawns
description: Representative Stephen Solarz of New York has been a principal shaper and supporter of American policy on Cambodia for years. The policy has been to isolate the Hun Sen Government in Phnom Penh as a Vietnamese puppet, aid two small non-Communist guerrilla forces, urge them into coalition with the Khmer Rouge and give the coalition Cambodia's seat at the United Nations.

title: ACCORD IS SOUGHT ON RIGHTS MEASURE TO AVERT A VETO
description: Supporters of a major bill to prevent job discrimination, approved by the Senate Wednesday night, said today that they would work with the White House to avert a veto.

title: Argentina Agrees to Sell Majority Share of Its Airline
description: Argentina, which agreed last month to sell its national telecommunications company to Spanish and American interests, has now agreed to sell a majority share of the national airline, Aerolineas Argentinas, to a consortium led by the Spanish airline Iberia.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Death of a Student Rebel: Who, Unmasked, Was He?
description: As a leader of the student protests that gripped Wesleyan University this spring, Nicholas B. Haddad cultivated an image as an angry young man with vague Middle-Eastern roots who knew well the ways of violence.

title: Biggs Withdraws
description: Carl (the Truth) Williams twice said he had back problems and pulled out of a scheduled heavyweight bout with Tyrell Biggs, the 1984 Olympic gold medalist. The match was rescheduled for a third time, next Tuesday in Atlantic City. But this time Biggs came up with an aching back and withdrew.

title: New Leader at Midway Air Is Looking to Philadelphia
description: Midway Airlines Inc., a mid-size Chicago-based carrier that is trying to establish a second hub in Philadelphia, has named Thomas E. Schick, the former president of Piedmont Airlines, as president and chief operating officer.

title: Law: At The Bar;   Here she comes to Wall Street: Miss America. Maybe.
description: Victor Hugo once declared: ''Greater than the tread of mighty armies is an idea whose time has come.'' And it may just be that in our litigious age - when, to cite one index, there are 100,000 lawyers in California alone - the time has finally come for Miss America to be a corporate lawyer.

title: From Rust Belt to Money Belt in Buffalo
description: There are not many bright spots in the New York economy these days, and one of the few can be found in the unlikeliest of places: Buffalo.

title: Review/Pop;   Raunchy Rap From the 2 Live Crew
description: The kind of show that the 2 Live Crew gave on Wednesday night at the Palladium got them arrested last month in their home state, Florida. In New York, it was easy to see what the fuss was about - lewd, crude four-letter words rapped to a hip-hop beat - and hard to imagine the performance as anything more than lowbrow comedy, hardly a serious threat to the moral tone of the republic.

title: Puget Sound Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Auctions
description: Of the Shakers

title: Pro Bono
description: * FCB/Leber Katz Partners has created a public service campaign for Girls Incorporated, the organization formerly called Girls Clubs of America.

title: U.S. Shift Dismays China
description: China issued a stern and disappointed response to the announcement that the United States was withdrawing support for China's closest ally in Cambodia. Page A2.

title: J.R. Carroll, 85, Dies; Philadelphia Architect
description: J. Roy Carroll Jr., a Philadelphia architect who was a former president of the American Institute of Architects, died on Tuesday at Crozer Hospital in Chester, Pa. He was 85 years old and lived in Swarthmore, Pa. He died after a short illness, his family said. Among Mr. Carroll's best-known designs were two Philadelphia landmarks, Prentiss House of the Presbyterian Board of Pensions and the headquarters of the American Society for Testing and Materials. He also designed the Philadelphia Airport terminal buildings and the Lister Hill National Center for Biomedical Communications in Bethesda, Md.

title: 75 Percent of Oil Spill Is Out of Arthur Kill
description: More than 75 percent of a 40,000-gallon oil spill in the Arthur Kill had been recovered or evaporated and the shipping channel was open to all traffic this afternoon, the United States Coast Guard said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers. At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers. Also, a chart with the article misstated the average hourly wage paid last year to workers at Honda of America. It was $15.32, including 77 cents for profit-sharing.

title: Bonn Says Foes' Spy Habits Persist
description: East Germany has stopped spying but the Soviet Union and most other countries of Eastern Europe have not given it up yet, the West German Interior Ministry said today.

title: Virginia Electrocutes Killer of an Elderly Neighbor
description: A 27-year-old man was executed today in Virginia's electric chair for the murder of an 87-year-old woman he had known all his life.

title: Multibank Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $468,000 and $2,759,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; year loss was from the redemption of debt, mainly the 8-percent convertible debentures. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $49,342,000. The company said the 1990 revenues are not comparable because on Jan. 31 it spun off to its shareholders the majority of the operations of the long- term care group.

title: First Alabama Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Bolshoi Star, a Relearning Experience Abroad
description: At first glance, Nina Ananiashvili might be a teen-age schoolgirl. Her small, heart-shaped face is solemn one minute, brimming with laughter the next. In repose, her long, thin limbs have an adolescent's gawkiness.

title: Seafirst Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Earnings Decline 6% At A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that its earnings had fallen 6 percent in the second quarter. It attributed the drop to lower equipment sales and rentals, higher income taxes and the costs of introducing a combination calling card and credit card.

title: Penalties Are Increased For Violence by Inmates
description: Seeking to stem a recent increase in stabbings and attacks in New York City's jails, correction officials said yesterday that they would increase the penalties for violence by inmates.

title: Dr. Marvin M. Fein, 66, Chemist and Executive
description: Dr. Marvin M. Fein, an organic chemist and research executive, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.

title: Editorial Notebook;   Who Lost Eastern Europe?
description: Bad news from abroad sometimes is brought home with such force that it rocks domestic politics. That's what happened in 1949; hard-liners asked insistently, ''Who lost China?'' And it's happening today in the Soviet Union.

title: Kohl Gets German Spotlight But Genscher Had the Vision
description: The man of the hour of German unity may be Chancellor Helmut Kohl, but the man who first saw it coming is certainly Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher.

title: Man With Shotgun Killed by Police Had a Record
description: The man who was killed in a fusillade of police bullets on Wednesday as he walked down a Brooklyn street waving a sawed-off shotgun and asking to see his wife was a house painter with a history of arrests, the police said yesterday.

title: Corrections Riegle Giving Money Back
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in Business Day yesterday about Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr.'s return of campaign contributions from the savings and loan industry referred incorrectly to contributions given him by the Phoenix developer Charles H. Keating Jr. In March 1988, Mr. Riegle returned $78,250 from Mr. Keating and his associates. That was not part of the $120,000 in industry contributions he returned to the Treasury on Thursday.

title: First City Bancorp of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hippocrates Apostle Dies at 80; Translated 9 Works by Aristotle
description: Hippocrates G. Apostle, an emeritus professor of mathematics and philosophy at Grinnell College who specialized in the works of Aristotle, died on Wednesday at his home in Grinnell, Iowa. He was 80 years old. The college said he died of lung cancer.

title: On Stage
description: Rhinos on Parade

title: Gateway Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Gillette Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said payment of preferred stock dividends affected share earnings in the latest quarter and 6-month.

title: Mackey Is Dismissed By Cleveland State
description: Eight days after he was rehired for two years, six days after he was arrested on a drunken driving charge, five days after he was suspended by the university and two days after he admitted to a cocaine and alcohol problem, Kevin Mackey was dismissed yesterday as basketball coach at Cleveland State.

title: Fujitsu Weighs Stake In a Computer Maker
description: Japan's leading computer company, Fujitsu Ltd., said today that it was considering whether to buy a stake in ICL P.L.C., Britain's sole maker of mainframe computers, in a move that could give the Japanese company a major European foothold.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Off 2.8% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest for the period ended July 13 decreased by 2.8 percent from a record level for the period ended a month ago. The decline amounted to 18.6 million shares. Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

title: Mattel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sherman Statue's Sculptor Wanted the Gilding Toned Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Ballet;   The Bolshoi Offers a New Ivan, With a New Fury
description: The Bolshoi really became the Bolshoi with Aleksei Fadeyechev's stunning local debut in the title role in ''Ivan the Terrible'' on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title:
Revitalizing a Neighborhood;

New Queens Condos Are Designed to Evoke the Past
description: LEAD: A new condominium complex has just opened in Glendale, Queens, with a design intended to complement the historic-district character of the older neighborhood that is adjacent to it in Ridgewood.

title: Washington Mutual Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Butler T. Henderson, Educator, 71
description: Butler T. Henderson, an official of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund for the last 18 years, died at St. Luke's Hospital on Monday. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Michigan National reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $8,325,000, or 54 cents a share.

title: Twist in Shaw Case
description: Federal Judge A. David Mazzone gave the Boston Celtics permission yesterday to serve as Brian Shaw's agent in breaking the guard's contract with the Italian team Il Messaggero Roma, for which he played last season.

title: Obscenity Guidelines Worry Opera
description: A member of the fund-raising department at the New York City Opera has expressed concern that the company's production of Arnold Schoenberg's ''Moses und Aron,'' which is to open on Sept. 22, might run afoul of new guidelines on obscenity, issued last week by the National Endowment for the Arts, because it calls for three naked virgins.

title: BellSouth Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Business Week Publishing Russian-Language Edition
description: Business Week, the weekly bible of the American business community, now has an audience in the Soviet Union.

title: Judge Clears Way for Trial Over Turkish Art at Met
description: A ruling by a Federal judge on Monday has opened the way for a trial to determine the ownership of a hoard of ancient artworks acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1966.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section yesterday about a decorating videotape, ''Weekend Bedroom Makeover With Sheets,'' misstated the running time. It is 45 minutes, not 5.

title: Georgia-Pacific Income Falls
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings were down 37.7 percent from a year ago, reflecting costs from its $5 billion takeover of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation.

title: Hawkeye Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hanoi's Partial Victory;   U.S. Shift on Cambodia Is Latest Example Of Pact With Moscow on Regional Disputes
description: The decision by the United States to alter its Cambodia policy and talk directly to Vietnam is another indication of the growing Soviet-American accord on regional conflicts, this time at the expense of Beijing, the main ally of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas.

title: Review/Photography;   No Shells or Vegetables, but Still Weston's World
description: The breathtaking exhibition ''Weston's Westons: Portraits and Nudes,'' which is to open today at the International Center of Photography, is remarkable first and foremost as a collection of exquisite prints by one of modern photography's essential figures. Focused on two important aspects of Edward Weston's career, the exhibition covers 1918 to 1945 and illustrates in microcosm the main turns in the photographer's stylistic development.

title: HomeFed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The per share earnings are primary but shares outstanding are diluted.

title: A Hudson Retreat Is Split by a Fight Over Development
description: Joan Lawlor Reilly remembers taking the 125th Street Ferry across the Hudson River to this sliver of a waterfront town where her parents rented a shack and some sweet shade from a Dutchman named Goethius.

title: British Plea to Workers
description: The British Government urged workers today to hold down demands for higher wages as the country's unemployment rate increased for the third straight month. The number of people out of work in June rose by 5,600, to a seasonally adjusted 1.62 million, or 5.7 percent of the work force, unchanged from May's revised figure, the Department of Employment said. At the same time, there was no slackening in the pace of wage increases. Average earnings in the year to May rose by 9.75 percent.

title: Chronicle
description: DREW E. ALTMAN, who last year withdrew his name from consideration as head of the agency that oversees the $100 billion Medicare program because of opposition from conservative Republicans, has found a warm reception at the HENRY J. KAISER Family Foundation. Dr. Altman has been named president of the philanthropy, whose $400 million in assets make it a significant voice in health care.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Citadel Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an insurance recovery of $1.4 million.

title: Piano at Caramoor
description: Daming Zhu, a Chinese pianist, is to play the Bach-Busoni Chaconne, Beethoven's ''Waldstein'' Sonata and works by Chopin in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, on Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., tonight at 9. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

title: Schering-Plough Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income per share and average shares for 1990 are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared on April 24.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a chronology yesterday about events of the last 15 years in Cambodia omitted an entry in some copies. The paragraph, for August 1989, should have read: ''Peace talks in Paris involving 19 nations and the four warring Cambodian factions collapse.'' In some copies the chronology also referred incorrectly to the Vietnamese installation of a Government led by Heng Samrin. It was in January 1979, not December 1978.

title: Dow Gains 12.13 Points, To 2,993.81
description: Stocks advanced yesterday in brisk trading but investors remained cautious amid a flood of earnings reports that are still carrying surprises. Programmed selling continued to dominate the market.

title: MCA's Profits Are Up by 6.7%
description: MCA Inc. said today that its second-quarter earnings increased 6.7 percent, to $44.8 million, or 54 cents a share, from $42 million, or 58 cents a share, on fewer shares in the period a year ago.

title: Lockheed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After a loss of $4 million from discontinued operations.

title: Becton Dickinson reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $47,389,000, or $1.20 a share, for the quarter and $55,954,000, or $1.40 a share, for the 9 months. Both periods included $44,658,000 from the sale of a business.

title: Greek Publisher and Editor Sentenced in Phone-Tapping
description: An appeals court has upheld the conviction of the publisher and the former managing editor of a Greek newspaper in the phone-tapping of the New York Times bureau in Athens, a court spokesman said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds increased $3.67 billion, to $389.91 billion, for the week ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 160 institutional funds increased by $2.99 billion, to $94.81 billion. The assets of the 251 general-purpose funds were up by $313.30 million, to $134.70 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $361.6 million, to $160.04 billion, the institute said.

title: 10,000 ROMANIANS PROTEST ARRESTS
description: More than 10,000 protesters rallied today in the western city of Timisoara, the cradle of the revolution against Nicolae Ceausescu, to urge the Romanian Government to free dissidents seized during unrest last month.

title: Treasuries Mixed in Slow Trading
description: The prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday, and the difference between short-term and long-term interest rates widened further.

title: No Headline
description: The sky is the ceiling for pop and jazz concerts around New York City this weekend.

title: Mozart and More
description: Mark Elder is to conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra in the Overture to Mozart's ''Idomeneo,'' the Mozart Piano Concerto No. 24, Tchaikovsky's Variations on a Rococo Theme, and Haydn's Symphony No. 90 at Avery Fisher Hall tonight at 8. Vladimir Feltsman will be the piano soloist in the Mozart, and Mischa Maisky will be the cello soloist in the Tchaikovsky. The program is to be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Review/Film;   Applying 1950's Cool To the 80's
description: Most high school seniors can't wait to get away to college. Audry sits at the breakfast table and explains why she's not going. ''Dad,'' she says in that parents-never-understand tone, ''history is coming to an end.'' Then she reads aloud from a favorite book about the various ways people might die after a nuclear blast.

title: Owner Gives Details Of 1974 Suspension
description: It was in 1974 that he became the first company executive ever indicted on felony charges in connection with illegal corporate contributions to election campaigns, but George Steinbrenner, who pleaded guilty to reduced charges and was fined later that year, remembers many of those long-ago events as if they happened yesterday.

title: Colgate-Palmolive Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $6.5 million, or 9 cents a share, from a real estate sale in England, for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: The Big Plunge on School Reform
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, has long promoted the idea that principals, teachers and parents in individual schools ought to share power. Now 117 of the city's 984 schools are ready to take up the challenge. In a system that already divides authority between a central board and 32 community boards, giving more power to individual schools is the ultimate decentralization plan, and it's off to a reasonable start.

title: Athos Menaboni, Artist, 94
description: Athos Menaboni, an artist whose paintings of birds were widely admired, died Wednesday. He was 94 years old.

title: Hasbro Net Off Sharply
description: Sharply lower sales during the last three months cut Hasbro Inc.'s second-quarter profits nearly 52 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, the company said today. The toy maker earned $8.7 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $18.1 million, or 31 cents a share. The results stem from dismal revenues of about $277.2 million during this year's second quarter, down 7.9 percent from $301.3 million.

title: A Medicaid Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Bancorp Hawaii reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Georges Dargaud, 79; Published Tintin Books
description: Georges Dargaud, who first published the popular Tintin books and the Asterix comic-book series, died Wednesday after a long illness, his publishing house said today. He was 79 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. Dargaud founded Dargaud Editeur in 1936 and took an active role in operating the publishing house until selling it to the Media Participation group in January 1989.

title: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $630 million. c-Net income Latest second-quarter results included a pretax gain of $16 million from the sales of the mutual fund and individual investor services businesses of the Lehman Management Co. division to a subsidiary of Salomon Inc., and a $9 million pretax gain from the sale of a 50-percent interest in Panagora Asset Management Inc. to Nippon Life Insurance Co. Latest six-month results included a $630 million charge related to a companywide expense reduction program announced in February as well as plans made in the first quarter to withdraw from, or curtail, certain business activities; an additional charge of $157 million from the cumulative effect on an accounting change; and a gain of $54 million related to settlement of litigation. Year-ago 6-month results included a $35 million pretax writedown of MCorp Securities, partially offset by a $16 million pretax reversal of reserves.

title: F.T.C. Won't Push Alcohol Ad Warnings
description: The Federal Trade Commission has declined to endorse legislation that would require health warnings in all alcohol advertising, including television commercials.

title: American Express Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net income of $26.5 million in the quarter and a net loss of $856.7 million for the 6 months, both from its Shearson Lehman Hutton unit. c-Net income The company said second quarter results included the costs of funding the $750 million convertible exchangeable preferred stock purchase from Shearson at the end of the first quarter.

title: Dean Foods Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $5.4 million, or 21 cents a share, from the sale of Baskin-Robbins stores.

title: American Telephone & Teleraph Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest figures included the results of Istel Group Inc., acquired in the fourth quarter of 1989, and two divisions of a subsidiary of Pacificorp Financial Services Inc., acquired in the first quarter 1990. The company said its second quarter and 6 months results included certain charges and credits, the net effect of which had essentially no impact on earnings. The charges, of about $100 million in cost of services and about $290 million in cost of products, were predominantly for restructuring plans. These included plans to restructure operations for producing microelectronic components and systems, and for reclaiming scrap metal. A credit of $400 million, also in cost of services, resulted from a net reduction in the reserves set up in December 1988 associated with the accelerated digitization of AT&T's Network. The reduction was made possible by efficiencies achieved in removing and disposing of obsolete equipment, and was partly offset by costs for force reductions and facility closings related to the network digitization program.

title: Nova Corp. of Alberta reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $30 million after-tax gain on the sale of its Grove Italia S.P.A. unit. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Interstate Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected partial recovery of bad debt from a major industrial customer of $1,669,000 for the year ended June 30.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about second-quarter earnings at Philip Morris Companies Inc. misstated the operating profit and volume gain of two units of its Kraft General Foods division. Only the Kraft international operations, not Kraft domestic, posted a 50 percent increase in operating earnings and a 5 percent volume gain. Another domestic unit of Kraft General Foods -General Foods USA - posted the same percentage gains.

title: Corrections

Riegle Jr.'s return of campaign contributions from the savings and loan industry referred incorrectly to contributions given him by the Phoenix developer Charles H. Keating Jr. In March 1988, Mr. Riegle returned $78,250 from Mr. Keating and his associates. That was not part of the $120,000 in industry contributions he returned to the Treasury on Thursday.

title: Six U.S. Judges Will Meet On Burden of Asbestos Suits
description: Acting like a rump judicial body, six Federal judges from around the nation whose dockets are swelling with asbestos cases are planning an extraordinary meeting soon to resolve tens of thousands of them.

title: Duke Power Co.  reports earnings for 12mo June 30
NASA STUDIES SHOW ITS SPACE STATION MUST BE SIMPLIFIED
description: The space agency said yesterday that the planned $37 billion space station would have to be substantially simplified to reduce its need for maintenance by robots and astronauts walking in space.

title: Uninsured? Go to Jail.
description: Driving south of the border without Mexican automobile insurance could land you behind bars.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an advanced new European telescope misstated its resolving power in some copies. It is 0.17 arc seconds, not 1.7 arc seconds. (An arc second is an angle equivalent to one-3,600th of a degree.) A diagram referred incorrectly to the type of telescope with a resolving power of 0.25 arc seconds. It is the best conventional ground-based instrument.

title: New York State Electric & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Washington Culture Center Delayed Over High Costs
description: Plans for the construction of a $738 million International Cultural and Trade Center on Pennsylvania Avenue were suspended this week when the Government agency that was to lease the building refused to sign the contract.

title: Desoto Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Furor Over Call to Sell Organs of Poor People
description: A politician's proposal that the county government sell the organs of dead welfare recipients has prompted such outrage here that some experts fear it will undermine efforts to solve a serious shortage of organ donors.

title: Kaman Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Feminist Artwork For University Library
description: The University of the District of Columbia today accepted the gift of ''The Dinner Party,'' Judy Chicago's mixed-media installation, at the university's Carnegie Library where itwill be on exhibition beginning in the fall of 1991.

title: Safety Agency and G.M. at Loggerheads Over Brake Problem
description: The Federal Government is urging the General Motors Corporation to recall some 450,000 cars because of a suspected brake defect. But the auto maker is refusing to do so, setting the stage for a possible court fight.

title: Tennant Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from an insurance settlement of $590,000, or 12 cents a share, for both periods; the 6 months also included income of $984,000, or 20 cents a share. from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Baseball;   Braves Keep Striking Out As Mets Win
description: The Mets' pitching rotation is on a roll, and last night, Sid Fernandez, dispensing his own brand of smoke before yielding to the heat, added his own spin to its momentum as the Mets defeated the Atlanta Braves, 6-1, at Shea Stadium.

title: Johnson Worldwide Assocites Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After a loss of $179,000 for the quarter and income of $60,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Danaher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: The company said latest figures included results from Easco Hand Tools Inc. after June 7.

title: Ethiopia's Long War Draws Closer to the Capital
description: In this ramshackle capital of two million, people are hoarding food and fuel, and long lines at the passport office attest to a rush to leave as a 30-year conflict draws closer from the countryside.

title: 'Pretty Woman' Finds Best Friend in Profits
description: The romantic comedy ''Pretty Woman,'' released in the movie industry's off season, could well become the highest-grossing film this year.

title: Giving Immunity Presents Hurdle for Conviction
description: The ruling by a Federal appeals panel today ordering new hearings in Oliver L. North's case demonstrates the enormous difficulties in bringing to trial a public official who has previously been forced to testify in a high-visibility case before Congress.

title: Seabrook at Full Power
description: The Seabrook nuclear power plant, for years the focus of the nation's debate over whether atomic energy is safe, reached full power for the first time Thursday night. New Hampshire Yankee, the operator of the $6.6 billion plant, said full power was reached at 9:52 P.M., the culmination of a series of power step-ups that had been under way since the Nuclear Regulatory Commission granted Seabrook a commercial operating license in March.

description: Share earnings are in units.

description: b-Included recognition of $5.6 million, or 34 cents a share, of investment tax credits.

description: The company said that during the latest 12 months $11.3 million of deferred investment tax credits were credited to income compared to $20.6 million a year ago.

title: Scientists Learn How Marijuana Works in Brain
description: Researchers plan to report that they have discovered receptors in the brain that are stimulated by marijuana, suggesting that the body produces a substance similar to marijuana and uses it to relieve pain and stress.

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Included pretax gains on sale of assets of about $6.1 million and $16.1 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6-month period also included a gain of about $10 million, or 12 cents a share, from the completion of a sale, leaseback and technology transfer agreement with Sony USA. c-Net income Year-ago quarter and 6 months ended June 25, 1989.
