title: Royals Make Moves
description: The Kansas City Royals yesterday put Bo Jackson on the 15-day disabled list, reinstated Bob Boone and delayed surgery on Bret Saberhagen.

title: Uni-Marts reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Morihiko Hasegawa, Toy Marketer, 62
description: Morihiko Hasegawa, president of Play-Jour International, a toy marketing company based in Tokyo, died on July 13 at St. Mariana Hospital in Kawasaki, Japan. He was 62 years old and lived in Yokohama. A Play-Jour spokesman said he died of cancer.

title: 5 New Jersey Troopers Acquitted In Disputed Beatings of 3 Drivers
description: In a case that had a trooper testifying against troopers, five members of the New Jersey State Police yesterday were acquitted of charges involving the alleged beatings of three motorists almost two years ago.

title: Detective Asked About Handling Of Jogger Case
description: A lawyer for a defendant in the Central Park jogger trial suggested yesterday that his client had been cowed and goaded into confessing by veiled threats of torture and lurid questions that challenged his masculinity.

title: Jason Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in April 1990.

title: Strawberry Causes Furor
description: Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, said yesterday that he would look into recent published comments of Darryl Strawberry in an effort to determine whether they violated rules concerning tampering.

title: Sandinistas' U.S. Friends: Case of Dashed Ideals
description: Americans who spent much of the last 10 years working in the United States and Nicaragua on behalf of the Sandinista Government now find themselves back in their cramped and dreary offices in New York, stunned by defeat, deserted by their constituency and searching for a new outlet for their dreams.

title: Heritage Media Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ahmanson Sells Its Headquarters
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company, a savings and loan holding company based here, sold its downtown headquarters building to a partnership between Kawasaki Enterprises Inc. of Japan and Takenaka & Company in Los Angeles. Ahmanson declined to disclose the sale price, but said it would record a $12 million pretax gain. Real estate industry officials said the building sold for $80 million to $100 million.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo June 30
How Silverado Recruited Neil Bush
description: The odyssey of Neil Bush and the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association began at a neighborhood dinner party in the spring of 1985, when he sat a few seats away from Michael Wise, said James E. Nesland, Mr. Bush's lawyer.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A $30 million lawsuit filed against GERALDO RIVERA by a woman who was arrested during a drug raid carried live on national television has been settled out of court in Houston for an undisclosed amount, lawyers for the two sides said yesterday.

title: No Appeal in False Rape Case
description: A woman sentenced to apologize in radio and newspaper advertisements to a man she had falsely accused of raping her will drop her appeal of the sentence, her lawyer said today.

title: The 'Quota' Dispute
description: In the painful history of the effort to integrate the country's offices, factories and educational institutions, there has been no word more emotionally loaded or universally shunned than ''quota.''

title: Ruddick reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: The company's Harris Teeter unit had sales of $293 million in the latest quarter, an increase of $20 million over the year-ago period.

title: The Met's March of the 'Macho He-Men'
description: ''All right, fellas, basically we need to know you can all march,'' the director called out to the 33 men gathered in a large underground studio at the Metropolitan Opera House. ''Start off on the right foot. For some unknown reason, probably something they do in Hungary, they all start on the right leg.''

description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: The fireworks were supposed to come in the first individual event of the Goodwill Games, with Matt Biondi, the Olympic champion, and Tom Jager, the world-record holder, in the men's 50-meter freestyle.

description: The Mexican Government, angered by the seizure in Guadalajara of a doctor accused in the torture and killing of an American drug agent, has asked the United States to arrest two men accused of involvement in the abduction.

description: Three men arrested on Thursday after a drugstore holdup were responsible for at least 20 robberies - and possibly as many as 40 - of small businesses and food stores in midtown Manhattan in the last two months, the police said yesterday.

title: Arteries Are Unblocked Without Drugs in Study
description: People with blocked coronary arteries who adhere to a strict vegetarian diet, engage in mild daily exercise and practice stress-reduction techniques can reverse the blockage, according to a study being published today.

Mario Cuomo's desk would weaken that discipline; it would guarantee pensions even for officers who turn brutal or corrupt. The case for a veto is clear.

The Pittsburgh Penguins signed the former Islander center yesterday, just two and a half weeks after Trottier was released by a team he starred with for 15 seasons and helped lead to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships.

Mr. Haddad knew, but was not related to, Kumar Viswanathan, who is accused in his killing, and Sudhama Ranganathan, who is accused of having fire-bombed the office of Wesleyan's president.

title: Yankees Come Close But Not Close Enough
description: The frustrations of a last-place team are not always humiliating. More often, they result from the small opportunities that slip away, the decisive moments that form a pattern, and the long deep breath from a manager whose team has just lost a game that easily could have been won.

title: Alaska Pipeline Reaches Accord
description: The operator of the trans-Alaska pipeline, which carries a quarter of the nation's domestically produced oil, has reached an agreement with state officials on measures to cut air pollution, ending a threat that the pipeline would be shut down. the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the consortium of seven oil companies that operates the 800-mile pipeline, had threatened to cut off an important source of oil as a deadline approached for compliance with an Environmental Protection Agency order. The E.P.A. notice of violation had chastised Alyeska for polluting the air in excess of levels allowed by state permits. A 30-day compliance period expired at midnight Thursday, Alaska time.

title: Scecorp reports earnings for 12mos to June 30
Philip Leacock, 72, Director of Movies And Dramas for TV
description: Philip Leacock, a film and television director, died on July 14 while on holiday in London with his family. He was 72 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif. No cause of death was given. The British-born Mr. Leacock, who made documentaries before taking on feature-length movies, had his first hit in 1950 with ''The Kidnappers,'' a family movie set in Nova Scotia. He also directed ''The Spanish Gardener,'' starring Dirk Bogarde; ''Innocent Sinners,'' with Flora Robson, and ''The Rabbit Trap,'' with Ernest Borgnine.

No Time for RICO 'Reform'
description: Just as the savings and loan scandal awakens the public to the costs of fraud, some members of Congress propose undercutting the country's most sweeping civil fraud law. The 1970 law is called ''Civil RICO,'' short for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations. It enables private citizens as well as government to seek triple damages for all kinds of commercial fraud. Its enemies call for ''RICO reform,'' but the measures they espouse more closely resemble fraud relief - for the crooks.

Weicker Jr., filled the Civic Center here tonight to start a two-day convention that is expected to culminate on Saturday with the nomination of Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury for governor.

A single ceiling fan barely moves the stale air in a basement chapel. Arms reach for heaven. ''Amens'' provide prayerful punctuation.

description: Mongolia holds its first free elections on Sunday. The governing Communist Party is expected to win, although its grip on power might be loosened. Mongolians are joining the demands for freedom and democracy that have swept across the Soviet bloc. In March, Parliament gave up the Communists' constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on power. Opposition groups have emerged, and campaign posters have begun to appear on streets in Ulan Bator, capital of the nation, which was established in 1921.

He is being replaced on alternate Fridays by FRANK CAPPIELLO and CARTER RANDALL. Mr. Rukeyser is to return to the program Aug. 17, the producer said.

title: Inside
description: A Question of 'Quotas'

title: Disputed Lockheed Contract Is Canceled by Navy
description: The Navy today dealt a major blow to the Lockheed Corporation, canceling a contract for the company to build a new generation of submarine-fighting aircraft because of what the Navy said was Lockheed's inadequate performance.

title: Egil Aarvik, Nobel Official, 77
description: Egil Aarvik, head of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, which awards the Nobel Peace Prize, died on Thursday, the news agency N.T.B. said today. He was 77 years old. The cause of death was not reported.

title: Folk Museum Homeward Bound
description: The Museum of American Folk Art's gypsy days are numbered. Three years from now, the museum is to reopen in new quarters - four floors at the base of a new 28-story office tower - at its old address, 49 West 53d Street. Construction of the building, designed by David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, is to begin next spring.

title: Virginia Executes Man for Murder
description: A man was executed in Virginia's electric chair Thursday night for the murder of an 87-year-old woman he had known all his life.

title: Du Pont Canada reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Lafarge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Ford Gets Offers For Subsidiary
description: The Ford Motor Company has received three bids for its aerospace subsidiary and may accept one within a week, a company spokesman, Thomas Rhoades, said. The bids were made by the Loral Corporation; a consortium including the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the Carlyle Group, an investment firm, and Aerospatiale, the French aerospace company, and a joint offer by Alcatel N.V. and the GM Hughes Electronic Corporation, a unit of Ford's chief rival, the General Motors Corporation.

title: Steinbrenner Loses in Bid for More Witnesses
description: Lawyers for George Steinbrenner failed yesterday in their effort to have Peter Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner; Dave Winfield, the former Yankee outfielder, and Howard Spira heard as witnesses in Commissioner Fay Vincent's investigation of the Yankees' principal owner.

title: Accord Reached on Cleanup of Times Beach
description: Federal and state environmental officials announced an agreement today intended to clear the way for the cleanup of dioxin-contaminated Times Beach, Mo., which has been deserted since 1983.

title: To Make Europe 'Whole and Free' . . .
description: LEAD: Ignored through most of its 15-year history, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe is an unlikely midwife to a new Europe. Yet it will probably fall to the 35 conference participants at a summit meeting later this year to lay the groundwork for what Secretary of State James Baker recently called ''the new European security system.

title: Chrysler Makes Plea To U.A.W.
description: The Chrysler Corporation, responding to its financial difficulties, said it suggested to the United Automobile Workers today that the company must have a more favorable labor contract than the ones that will be negotiated with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company this year.

title: Ziegler Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Universal Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Earnings for 1990 have been adjusted to reflect assumed conversion of the company's convertible debentures.

title: Meanwhile in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Hexcel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said included in second quarter and first half 1990 results were benefits of about 7 cents a share and 14 cents a share, respectively, due to the extension of the depreciation recovery periods of certain property and equipment to coincide with changes in business conditions.

title: Police Cleared In the Death Of a Suspect
description: The Bronx District Attorney's office yesterday cleared nine police officers of responsibility for the death last September of an unarmed mugging suspect who died in police custody.

title: Kansas City Southern Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.6 million for the quarter and $3.3 million for the 6 months.

title: Panatech Research & DevelFopment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Results for 1989 included the results of Allied Interstate Datanet Corp. and ASM Co., acquired in August 1989 and October 1989, respectively.

title: Man Tried to Extort Money From Forbes, U.S. Charges
description: A 24-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with trying to extort money from the late magazine publisher Malcolm Forbes and the Forbes family by threatening to damage the publisher's reputation.

title: Santa Fe Energy Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and for the 6 months included an accounting adjustment gain of $24,500,000, or 47 cents a share.

title: Otter Tail Power Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Perkins Papers Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Roto-Rooter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: The rock 'n' roll performer CHUCK BERRY has been charged with child abuse and possession of marijuana based on evidence seized in a raid on his home last month, according to the authorities in St. Charles, Mo.

title: SPX reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $52,900,000, or $3.88 a share, and $57,700,000, or $4.24 a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Net Up 6.9% At U S West
description: Spurred by cost-cutting in its telephone division, U S West reported today that its second-quarter earnings rose 6.9 percent compared with the quarter in 1989.

title: Oregon Steel Mills reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the Government's sale of savings and loan assets referred incorrectly to a mandate to the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the industry bailout. The maximum number of years for which it is allowed to lend up to 85 percent of the purchase price to buyers of large asset portfolios is 5, not 15.

title: Expos Lose Santovenia
description: Montreal's starting catcher, Nelson Santovenia, will undergo surgery for torn cartilage in his left knee today and will be lost to the Expos for at least six weeks. Santovenia, who is batting .191, was placed on the disabled list on Thursday.(AP)

title: Patents;   A Food Preservative That's Made Naturally
description: Researchers at Microlife Technics Inc. of Sarasota, Fla., which specializes in developing commercially useful bacteria, obtained a patent this week for a naturally produced food preservative that fights common molds.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Third Avenue Summerfest, Third Avenue in Manhattan will be closed tomorrow from 42d to 57th Streets from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Universal Health
description: An investment group led by members of the Bass family of Fort Worth raised its stake in Universal Health Services Inc. to the equivalent of 11.4 percent of the company's class B stock, from 10.3 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group said it had held, and expected to continue having, discussions with Universal's managers about its investment in the company. Universal Health Services is a hospital management company based in King of Prussia, Pa. The Bass group consists of Perry R. Bass, Nancy L. Bass and Lee M. Bass.

title: At Nynex, Dial N for Nightmare
description: Executives at the Nynex Corporation and its biggest subsidiary, the New York Telephone Company, are living a public-utility official's nightmare.

title: Tax Protest Shows Splits In New Jersey
description: A gathering of mayors from across New Jersey tonight was advertised by its host, Mayor Peggy Lasky of Holmdel, as a search for ''constructive reform'' of the $2.8 billion in higher income taxes and sales taxes that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through the Legislature.

title: Helms Aide Stirs Furor With Racial Accusation
description: The head of the N.A.A.C.P. and a black civil rights pioneer employed by Senator Jesse Helms have clashed over assertions by the Helms aide that some American black leaders are controlled by 15 powerful white men and are engaged in criminal and immoral activities.

title: Woodhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included net charge of $297,000 related to a lawsuit settlement.

title: Lindy Boggs to Quit House, Ending a Louisiana Dynasty
description: Representative Lindy Boggs, the second half of a political dynasty that began with her husband, Hale Boggs, 50 years ago, announced today that she would not seek re-election.

title: Warren M. Sperry, 90, Brain Chemistry Expert
description: Warren Myron Sperry, a neurochemist, died on July 11 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Health Warnings Issued as Air Pollution Builds Up
description: Air pollution was worse this week than it has been all year, and health advisories were issued throughout the Northeast as heat and stagnant air helped form ground-level ozone, a major component of smog.

title: 'Ulysses' Editors Clash in a Joycean Hades
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea Counters Seoul On Plan to Open the Frontier
description: North Korea today swiftly countered a South Korean challenge to open temporarily their heavily fortified border, laying down strict conditions before Koreans could cross between the two countries.

title: Some Good Things Grow With a Little Neglect
description: To the Editor:

title: REVIEW IS ORDERED
description: A Federal appeals court today suspended all three of Oliver L. North's Iran-contra felony convictions and overturned one of them in a ruling that threw into doubt the entire case against the former Marine Corps lieutenant colonel.

title: A Thousand Pointless Lights?
description: LEAD: We Americans pride ourselves on the extent of our charitable efforts. We can boast of nearly a million nonprofit philanthropic agencies, and both their number and income have been increasing for at least 50 years. They make up a system that performs many admirable and important tasks. But it's time we recognized that most of the benefits of philanthropy go to the wealthy, not the needy or even the middle class.

title: Aztar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,496,000. The latest quarter and 6-month losses from continuing operations of $21,675,000 and $15,872,000, respectively, both are after a pretax charge of $33,645,000 in connection with litigation. Year-ago quarter's loss from continuing operations of $8,091,000 is after a writeoff of $2.6 million of previously deferred pre-opening expenses.

title: The Hands That Caught Ryan's Heat
description: Jeff Torborg talked about his left hand, the hand that caught most of Nolan Ryan's booming fastballs in 1973 when the two players were with the California Angels. It was the year that Ryan, with his 100-mile-per-hour heater (give or take a mile or two per hour of smoke on a given outing), established the major league record for strikeouts in a season, 383.

title: Relocation, an Idea As Old as Moses
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

The Pacific View Lives On Happily
description: LEAD: ONCE upon a time, there was an ocean other than the Atlantic that lapped against a coast where artists made their homes. This ocean was called the Pacific, and it had a special way of reflecting light and creating atmosphere that many artists found very appealing.

title: Review/Rock;   Rock Icon Modernizes Sounds From the Past
description: Of all the ancient rock dreadnoughts supplying audiences with a vestige of the 1960's and early 1970's, Robert Plant has survived the best. Having shed the worst of his Led Zepplin mannerisms and left them to countless heavy metal bands, he's instead tried to work out a balance between the hippie experimentalism of Led Zepplin and the necessities of pop music making.

title: No Auditions, No Charge, Just Happy Music
description: IT was a quintessential Connecticut summer scene: the evening band concert in the gazebo on Fairfield's Sherman Green. Revelers of all ages listened to the band and watched the antics of the local children. Mothers chased errant toddlers through the maze of lawn chairs and blankets, and two little boys with their hands over their ears dared each other to ascend the steps of the gazebo, where the band played ''The Georgia Cakewalk.''

title: If We Don't Give Gorbachev Help, Europe Will;   Everyone Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Saved, for the Day
description: On a crowded bus from the airport into Manhattan, the driver picked up his microphone and addressed his captive audience. ''I feel it's my duty to warn you that at Grand Central Station there are hustlers who will rip you off.'' He described the people who offer to carry luggage or hail a cab, how they work in pairs and grab suitcases or pick pockets.

title: In Eastern Europe's Churches, Triumph Leads to Uncertainty
description: FOR four decades, religious believers in Eastern Europe lived under seige. Their buildings were confiscated, their ceremonies regulated, their publications censored, their youth groups outlawed, their seminaries closed, their professional careers blocked, their leaders spied upon, jailed, harassed, intimidated, bribed or even killed.

title: When Employees Face Commuting
description: The ''reverse commute'' and the suburban-to-suburban commute have become the most serious ground transportation problems in the country. The June 3 article ''Ranks of Reverse Commuters Expected to Grow'' touched the surface of the employee commuting problems during and after a company relocation.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

When It's Time to Move, the Heaviest Items Are Memories
description: LEAD: BECAUSE our move to New York 11 years ago was paid for by my husband's employer, we found no need to throw away the accumulations of our then 20-year-old marriage. And because we moved into a fair-sized house with plenty of storage, for 11 years we have just kept on accumulating.

title: Off Base
description: A Federal judge in Cincinnati said he saw two people in front of him last week: Pete Rose the living legend and Pete Rose the tax cheat. He sent them both to jail for five months. Rose, who batted his way on to base more times than anybody else in baseball, pleaded guilty to two felony counts of filing false income tax returns. The sentencing last week capped a slide from baseball grace that began more than a year ago when, as manager of the Cincinnati Reds, he was accused of betting on baseball games. He was subsequently banned from baseball for life. Then the Internal Revenue Service investigated him and found that Rose had failed to declare earnings of nearly $346,000 from card shows, personal appearances and the sale of baseball memorabilia. As part of his plea bargain, Rose will also spend three months in a halfway house and 1,000 hours in community service. Contrite, he said, ''I accept my punishment.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our den has a cement slab floor that is covered with squares of wood parquet flooring. This floor has no insulation and is cold in the winter. I would like to cover it with ceramic tiles. The wood squares are still firm and sticking solidly. Would it be possible to leave the wood flooring in place as insulation and then lay the tiles directly over this?

title: Telephone Update
description: New York City has 8,100 sidewalk pay phones. That should be plenty, if they all worked, and if long-winded talkers didn't monopolize the ones that do.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our den has a cement slab floor that is covered with squares of wood parquet flooring. This floor has no insulation and is cold in the winter. I would like to cover it with ceramic tiles. The wood squares are still firm and sticking solidly. Would it be possible to leave the wood flooring in place as insulation and then lay the tiles directly over this?

title: Fury Rising in Quebec Over Mohawk Standoff
description: For the last 10 days, Canadians watching television have been confronted with the stark image of Mohawk Indians armed as if for war, in camouflage uniforms, bandannas across their faces, blockading one of the most crucial transport arteries in the country, the Mercier bridge across the St. Lawrence River into Montreal.

title: After 'True Love' There Comes the 'Dog Fight'
description: There's probably no intersection in California that better sums up the crazy human mosaic of life than the one where Columbus Avenue meets Broadway.

title: Sarah Smith Wed To William Klein
description: Sarah Wheelwright Smith, the daughter of Mrs. Blake E. Vance of San Diego and Colin E. Smith of Berkeley, Calif., was married yesterday to William Renn Klein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Klein of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: PLAQUE TO FASCIST UNNERVES SLOVAKS
description: A dispute over a plaque put up to commemorate the Rev. Jozef Tiso, a Roman Catholic priest who headed Slovakia's pro-fascist independence government during World War II, has led many Czechoslovaks to ask where their new-found freedom is leading them.

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a vacation in Veracruz, Mexico, I would like your readers to know that the cost of renting a car there can be staggering. The least expensive air-conditioned car available from Hertz (a Chrysler Shadow) cost approximately $110 a day for a three-day rental. Considering that the best hotel in nearby Xalapa charges $40 a night and dinner for two with wine at a nice restaurant was approximately $25, it seems to me that Hertz has created a new version of highway robbery.

title: Japanese in the New York Region Begin to Feel the Sting of Prejudice
description: Japanese who have settled in the New York suburbs, whether for a temporary business assignment or for good, are starting to feel a backlash from their growing presence and the rising economic tensions between Japan and the United States.

title: A Show of 31 Paintings, Chosen From a Field of 200
description: THE exhibition ''New Jersey Painting Today'' is the first juried annual to be staged at Phyllis Rothman, the still newish gallery on Fairleigh Dickinson's Florham-Madison campus. The judge was Zoltan Buki, curator at the State Museum in Trenton, and from about 200 entrants he culled 31.

title: Margot Calogeras to Marry
description: Margot Calogeras and David Clark Pannett plan to marry in the fall. Ms. Calogeras, a daughter of Dr. Miriam Tauber of New York and Dr. Roy Calogeras of Wiesbaden, West Germany, is a cum laude graduate of Columbia University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Mr. Pannett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Pannett of Houston, is a music instructor at Columbia, where he received an undergraduate degree and two master's degrees and is a candidate for a doctorate, all in music.

title: Gretchen Johnson Planning to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Gretchen Ann Snow Johnson and Michael Francis Bigham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Bigham of Annapolis, Md., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Johnson of Pottersville, N.J.

title: Embattled Liberia Leader Expels U.S. Aide
description: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia expelled the United States military attache today, accusing him of providing support to the advancing rebels, as support for Mr. Doe diminished further within his own Government.

title: A New Taste (Afghani) in Huntington
description: HISTORIC Huntington Village now has an Afghani restaurant. Incongruous as that might seem, it is not a bad fit. Huntingtonians have long demonstrated their love for Greek food by supporting three storefront Greek restaurants within two blocks of each other. There are some similarities between the two cusines: souvlaki becomes shish kebab and baklava translates to bughluva.

title: Fashion;   Herald of Autumn: Catalogue in Mailbox
description: Free mail-order catalogues for fall are jamming mailboxes. The fashion stories they tell are midsummer's patio reading, filled with rich colors in fabrics and designs that evoke distant times and latitudes.

title: Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
description: The Mets should have learned from the Milwaukee Brewers, with Robin Yount, and continue their talks with Strawberry. Once he wins the National League's most valuable player award and becomes a free agent, his value will inevitably increase.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Off the Tourist Track, An Area Full of History
description: The one-traffic-light village of Red Hook sits inconspicuously in the northwest corner of Dutchess County, near the Hudson River, off the beaten track of the tourist trail that takes thousands of visitors each year to more popular attractions in Rhinebeck and Hyde Park to the south.

title: Christina Cassidy Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Cassidy of Loudonville, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Christina Cassidy and David Leslie Martino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Martino of Clifton Park, N.Y.

title: Castel Gandolfo Makes Ready for the Pope
description: It tends to be quieter when the town's chief summer resident is away, and so there was not much to do in the main square this day other than sit at the cafe and shoo flies.

title: Ms. Brodeur Wed To Chris Brewster
description: Adrienne Willets Brodeur, a legislative aide at the San Diego Board of Supervisors, and Bartlett Christmas Brewster, the captain of the lifeguard services division of the San Diego Park and Recreation Department, were married yesterday in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Valjeanne Paxton, a United Church of Christ minister and the bride's aunt, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Henry Hornblower 2d of Boston.

title: If Case Goes to Court, Vincent's Side Is Prepared
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent, forced by the George Steinbrenner case to learn quickly the history of baseball disciplinary proceedings, arrived at a conclusion: ''In situations where owners have been investigated by the commissioner, routinely they go to Federal court,'' Vincent said. ''Routinely they lose in Federal court.''

title: Postings: The Morton House on 42d St.;   A Bit of Fifth Avenue History
description: ''My mother would never have consented to my making my first appearance in a public room, so to Mrs. Morton's we went,'' the novelist Edith Wharton wrote, as she recalled coming out into society in 1879. ''Mrs. Morton's'' was a sturdy brick dwelling, with handsome arched windows, at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. Anna Morton lived there with her husband, Levi, a prominent banker who later became Vice President of the United States and Governor of New York.

title: Driving and Speeding On the Sprain Brook
description: The attention given to the challenge of unreasonable speeds and irrational driving behavior in the article ''Chasing Speeders on the Sprain Brook'' [July 1] , is encouraging; the details are more appalling and dismaying than expected. My fear of driving approaches others' fear of flying, and it depresses me to learn how justified is that fear.

title: NEW JOBLESSNESS STARTING TO PINCH IN EAST GERMANY
description: Three weeks after economic and monetary union with West Germany, the East is beginning to feel the pain of the transition to a market economy.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Is There Meaning To a Brain Tumor?
description: LEAD: ON Feb. 1 about 3:30 P.M., I woke up in the recovery room of a university hospital after a six-hour operation to have a brain tumor removed. It was only during the recovery period that I was able to understand what had happened to me and extract some meaning from a seemingly meaningless horror.

title: Bohemian Dumplings: Plebeian but Tasty
description: Dumpling dough must be beaten until it talks to the bowl, my mother used to advise as the thickening, sticky mass hit the side with a thwop.

title: Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
description: The Mets are prepared to make Darryl Strawberry an incredibly wealthy young man with a reported salary of $3 million to $4 million per year. They have also shown tremendous loyalty and sensitivity in supporting Darryl during his personal difficulties. If they choose to delay contract negotiations until after the season to avoid a distracting media circus, they are totally within their rights to do so.

title: Katherine Foote Is Married
description: Katherine Deming Foote, a teacher at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn, and Joseph Henry Haddock, an actor, were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Branford, Conn., by the Rev. Gary Smith. The bride, 25 years old, is the daughter of Imogen Howe Solem of Redding, Conn., and William J. Foote Jr. of Key West, Fla. She is a graduate of St. Ann's and Vassar College. The bridegroom, 28, is a son of Elizabeth C. Haddock and James C. Haddock of Dublin, N.H.

LEAD: WESTCHESTER, which has the largest homeless population per capita in the nation, will be one of five sites this fall where an effort financed by International Business Machines will seek to return some homeless families to self-sufficiency.

title: Beyond the Loom
description: For more than three decades Lenore Tawney has been a revolutionary figure in fiber art. In the 1950's she was credited with freeing weaving from the confines of the loom. She was one of the first to juxtapose areas of plain weave with areas of unwoven warp, to incorporate knots, braids, shells and feathers into her pieces and to create weavings intended to be hung away from a wall, adding a sculptural dimension to what traditionally had been a flat art. However, Ms. Tawney's works have won her little acclaim, apart from a small, ardent following. LENORE TAWNEY: A Retrospective (American Craft Museum/Rizzoli, $45), edited by Kathleen Nugent Mangan, an independent curator, is an unusually handsome catalogue published in conjunction with an exhibition at the American Craft Museum. Introductory essays by Ms. Mangan, Paul J. Smith, director emeritus of the museum, Katharine Kuh, an art critic, and Erika Billeter, director of the Musee Cantonal des Beaux-Arts in Lausanne, Switzerland, seek to provide a context in which the reader may appreciate the more than 100 photographs in the book. Especially arresting are the reproductions of Ms. Tawney's later works - exquisite collages, assemblages and boxes. It is in these that the artist's uses of found objects (pebbles, pages from rare books, eggs, bones) best illuminate her poetic vision.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our den has a cement slab floor that is covered with squares of wood parquet flooring. This floor has no insulation and is cold in the winter. I would like to cover it with ceramic tiles. The wood squares are still firm and sticking solidly. Would it be possible to leave the wood flooring in place as insulation and then lay the tiles directly over this?

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgarians in Turkish Regions End Strike Over Bias Charge
description: Bulgarian nationalists ended a five-day strike in predominantly Turkish regions today after Parliament promised to investigate their grievances.

title: Mutual Funds;   Balancing Retirement and Growth
description: LAST month, when he was named emeritus university librarian, Phillip Rosenstein was honored at a champagne bash for 250 people at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. But he still doesn't know what he will do later this month, when he actually leaves the Newark-based library, taking a big chunk of his pension money with him. ''I want the money to be safe, and grow, and be available if I need it,'' he said.
