(Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The actress's memoirs. $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 75 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 2 1 32 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 3 4 2 LIFE 101, by John-Roger and Peter McWilliams. (Prelude Press, $18.95.) Advice about coping with the human condition. 4 28 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The Third College Edition of a standard work, revised in 1988. 5 1 HOMECOMING, by John Bradshaw. (Bantam, $18.95.) How to find the child you once were that lives within you and use it to deal with today's problems.

title: 'Guest' Takes Early Gold
description: Dave Mora of Bloomington, Ind., an unofficial member of the United States team, became the first track and field gold medalist of the 1990 Goodwill Games today, winning the men's marathon.

title: Trying to Avoid the One-Genre Trap
description: Like many a contest winner before him, Barry Douglas has built his reputation on the bold Romantics - Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff, Liszt, among others. So his performance of the Mozart Concerto No. 22 in E-flat at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra conducted by Mark Elder, is thus something of a departure.

title: 28 Hurt as Bus Hits Girder On the Williamsburg Bridge
description: Twenty-eight people were injured yesterday when a city bus skidded out of control on a rain-slicked roadway and slammed into an elevated train stanchion as the bus was exiting the Williamsburg Bridge, the authorities said.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NUTMEG STATE GAMES

title: It's Cudweed and Crowberry! Hold That Native Flora List!
description: Two rare plants, the purple crowberry and the wood cudweed, have been discovered in New York State for the first time, the state botanist reported this week.

title: Tamil Rebel Bombing Cuts Off a Peninsula
description: Tamil rebels blew up the Elephant Pass causeway, cutting off the Jaffna peninsula in the north from the rest of the island, the military said today.

title: Ms. Anderson Weds James Ackerman
description: Susan Denise Anderson, a textiles designer in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Harold Ackerman, a sculptor and cabinetmaker in Saratoga Springs. The Rev. Charles O. Milford, a Baptist minister, and Rabbi Alvin Roth officiated.

title: Q and A
description: The Red House

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Labels Are Practical to Know What Is Planted Where
description: LEAD: As a gardener, I feel about plant labels the way Ogden Nash felt about billboards in his ''Song of the Open Road:''

title: Phoebe VaughnTo Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. George A. Vaughn of Princeton, N.J., and Warwick, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter Phoebe Hinman Vaughn to Andrew Willard Outerbridge, a son of Mrs. John Hollis Kaufmann of Somerset, Bermuda, and Colebrook, N.H., and Yeaton Outerbridge of Smith's parish, Bermuda, and Jamestown, R.I. An October wedding is planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Grandma's Advice Lasts a Lifetime
description: LEAD: ''WE know, we know,'' my children moan as I pull into the first parking space I see and quote my grandmother: ''A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.'' What they don't know is that lessons learned in childhood fade very slowly. Even when circumstances and life styles change, the early training tapes keep playing in the mind with brave Old World insistence.

title: Karen Finley's Rage, Pain, Hate and Hope
description: Karen Finley's subject is not obscenity. Her subject is pain, rage, love, lovelessness, need, fear, dehumanization, oppression, brutality and consolation. But obscenity is what will be on everyone's mind tonight, at Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival, when she performs her now notorious piece ''We Keep Our Victims Ready.''

title: Brennan's Liberal Legacy to a Divided Supreme Court
description: IN his nearly 34 years as a United States Supreme Court Justice, William J. Brennan Jr. weathered the ideological conflicts that occurred as the Warren Court was transformed into the Burger and Rehnquist Courts. During eight Presidential Administrations, his role changed from that of a cornerstone of the Court's liberal majority to the author of some of its most stirring dissents. When he announced his resignation last week at the age of 84, he had just finished a session in which his vote was crucial in a series of 5-4 liberal victories. He had earned a reputation as a supporter of civil rights and abortion rights, as an uncompromising foe of the death penalty and a champion of the notion that the Constitution is a living document to be interpreted according to current concerns.

title: Technology;   Delving Into the Consumer Unconscious
description: BASICALLY it looks like a desk lamp with a chunky smoked-glass body. In fact, it is Lee Weinblatt's People Reader, a device designed to surreptitiously monitor the way people react to magazine advertising. Behind the smoked glass are two tiny, remote-controlled video cameras, one that tracks eye movements and another that monitors which page is being perused. In a nearby office, technicians measure each dismissive glance and longing gaze.

title: Kyle-Beth Basson Is Married on L.I.
description: Kyle-Beth Basson and Steven Martin Hilfer were married last evening at Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I., by Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski. Mrs. Hilfer is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin E. Basson of Upper Brookville, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Hilfer of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Shiite Militias Continue to Battle in South Lebanon
description: Shiite Muslim factions fought another round of ferocious battles in southern Lebanon today, in which 30 people were killed and 45 were wounded, the police said.

title: Jean McDonough Weds W. R. Mattson
description: Jean Marie McDonough and William Ross Mattson were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy M. Johnson performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;

The Darker Side of Odilon Redon
description: LEAD: ODILON REDON (1840-1916) was almost two separate artists. The first was the semi-Impressionist master of the medium of pastel whose preferred subject matter was the faces of flowers. Preceding this creator of rare color was a graphic artist who explored the fantastic through visions, dreams and nightmares.

title: Taxes, S. & L.'s, Anxiety: Recipe For a Political Shakeout?
description: AFTER months of quiescence in American politics, the two parties are finally stirring, lurching into the 1990's and the uncharted political terrain beyond Reaganism.

title: U.S. to Limit Waste Burning at Rocky Flats
description: The Department of Energy has agreed not to burn waste containing plutonium and hazardous chemicals at the last two operable incinerators at its Rocky Flats weapons plant near Denver, unless it can win permission from the Colorado Department of Health or the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Bill Would Raise Minimum For Car Insurance Liability
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is facing a decision on whether to raise the minimum amount of automobile liability insurance that New Yorkers must carry. If he does so, lawyers say, bigger damage awards would result. But insurers warn that an increase could also mean more lawsuits that would drive up the cost of motorists' premiums.

title:
MUSIC;

Moscow Group to Teach and Play at Rutgers
description: LEAD: THE Moscow Conservatory will begin a four-week stay in the United States this week as part of an intensive program of music instruction and concerts at Rutgers University.

title:
The Executive Life;

When a Plug of Hair Is Worth a Pound of Image
description: LEAD: ''I LOOKED as though I had come from some sort of African tribal fertility rite,'' said Michael Prout, a 43-year-old program manager at the DCS Corporation, an aerospace engineering concern in Alexandria, Va.

title: Campus Life: Juilliard;   Four Musicians Take to the Road With Piano in Tow
description: Until June, much of what four young pianists from the Juilliard School knew about pianos was how to coax music from the keyboard. But by early this month they had also learned how to dismantle, pack, reassemble and tune the instrument.

title: Works in Progress;   On High
description: ''Near the heart, on top of the head, the right shoulder, other places, too,'' says Joel Ghivelder, listing the damaged regions on the mountaintop statue of Jesus that is perhaps Rio de Janeiro's most famous landmark. Ghivelder, an architect, is overseeing the restoration of the statue and the public space around its foundation, a project that began last March. ''About 15 percent of the area of the statue will be replaced,'' he says.

title: 'A Deed of Death'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chernobyl Syndrome
description: THE LEGACY OF CHERNOBYL

title: Three New York City Success Stories
description: Saving and rehabilitating old buildings has become so common in the last few years that it is tempting to think of the whole process as easy - after all, if no one is clamoring any longer to tear a landmark down, hasn't the hardest battle been won? Not necessarily: roughly 15 years passed between the departure of the New York City Police Department from its old headquarters at 240 Centre Street in Manhattan and that building's reopening last year as a strikingly elegant cooperative apartment building; an even longer period elapsed between the abandonment of the old Association Residence, a Victorian Gothic landmark on Amsterdam Avenue at 103d Street, and its reopening this past spring as the largest youth hostel in North America. And it was almost a decade between the time architects were hired to restore Borough Hall in Brooklyn and the completion of that work last year. Not one of these buildings had been in much danger of being torn down, at least not recently. All that time went to fixing them up, or trying to find the money to fix them up, not struggling to save them from demolition.

title: The View From: Trail Wood in Hampton;   Author's Beloved Fields Remain His Memorial
description: THE journey through Trail Wood, the Edwin Way Teale memorial sanctuary in Hampton, begins at a break in a stone wall opening into Firefly Meadow. Here a path bordered by wildflowers and furrowed grasses leads to the bridge over Stepping Stone Brook, where largemouth bass meander among the water weeds.

title: INSIDE
description: Opposition Rallies in Korea

title: Famous and Fined
description: WINNING the Indianapolis 500 brings a driver fame and fortune, but not immunity from the rules of racing as the 1990 Indy winner, Arie Luyendyk, has just learned.

title: In Portugal, Wheels of Misfortune
description: When I moved to Portugal last year after covering guerrilla wars in Ethiopia, Iraq and Afghanistan, I assumed I was putting the dangerous part of my life behind me. I couldn't have been more wrong.

title: Judith Ratner Engaged To Kenneth S. Geller
description: September wedding plans for Dr. Judith Barbara Ratner and Kenneth Steven Geller, a son of Sylvia R. Geller of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Edward Geller, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton B. Ratner of Tenafly, N.J.

title: Battling the Lethargy at Douglas
description: THESE should be happy days at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's sprawling Douglas Aircraft plant here. With demand from airlines booming, Douglas has a record backlog of orders for its MD-80/90 series of midrange commercial jetliners. Douglas, second in the commercial aircraft business in the United States to the Boeing Company, is within months of delivering the first of its new MD-11 wide-body jets. On the military side of its business, Douglas has solved technical problems that had dogged development of the Air Force's C-17 transport plane, and the first of the 120 airlifters the Pentagon wants to buy should be flying within a year.

title: Suzanne Gaba Is Engaged to Dr. James Aisenberg
description: October wedding plans for Suzanne Gaba and Dr. James Aisenberg have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Gaba of Rockville Centre, L.I. Dr. Aisenberg is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan C. Aisenberg of Boston.

title: Free at Last
description: BLACK VOTES COUNT

title: Streetscapes: The 1914 Stewart Building;   A Delicate Work of Ceramic in the Path of a Tower
description: ''I call it the Wedgwood Building,'' said Susan Tunick, president of the Friends of Terra Cotta, a preservation organization. ''There's nothing like it in New York.'' Indeed, the blue-and-white, terra-cotta building at the southwest corner of 37th Street and Fifth Avenue, built in 1914, is a striking example of the ceramic arts. But plans for a new tower adjacent to it may break this china doll and the tragedy would be that, in the end, it was for no reason.

title: Siegfried Who? The Limits of Fame
description: Siegfried Matthus counts as East Germany's most successful opera composer, with his works performed throughout Eastern Europe and, increasingly, West Germany. Up to now, however, apart from the ministrations of a few champions of his orchestral music, he has remained largely unknown in the United States. There are no recordings of his music in Schwann's current Opus catalogue.

title: Getting Caruso Right (And Horribly Wrong)
description: Nearly seven decades after his death, Enrico Caruso remains this century's most famous tenor, vividly present in 246 surviving recordings that trace the trajectory of his career and technique and attest to his influence on the art of singing. Although desirable for these reasons - and because of his crucial role in the history of recording - a good ''complete Caruso'' remained, in several LP projects, an elusive ideal.

title: THE POPPERS AND THE PLAINS
description: Your article on the Poppers suggests that they would allow Indians to live on the Buffalo Commons. Do they assume that these Indians are going to ''go native'' and cheerfully pose for photos as the deer and the antelope play for the amusement of the eco-chic on chartered covered-wagon tours?

title: Youth to Represent U.S. at Science Fair
description: LEAD: UNLIKE many of his contemporaries, 13-year-old Scott Ananian does not watch much television and does not like Nintendo. Given his druthers, he would rather take apart his computer.

title: Currency;   For Now, the Dollar Holds Its Own
description: Well, not much happened. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's semi-annual testimony to Congress on monetary policy was a little anticlimactic after he said the previous week that the Fed would lower interest rates to offset a credit squeeze. If anything, he signaled in his testimony that interest rates would not be moving lower again soon. So the dollar held its ground fairly well, even managing to rise against the yen by the end of the week. The higher-than-expected increase in the Consumer Price Index in June also provided support. But the downward pressure is still on the dollar as the economy struggles and the view persists that interest rates are likely to fall, especially if there is an agreement to reduce the Federal deficit.

title: 'Star Wars' Addition Is Criticized
description: A Congressional report has criticized the nation's ''Star Wars'' program, saying the recent addition of a new weapon concept has complicated and delayed the process of deciding whether the system is feasible.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

For Rural Hamilton, a Commercial Spurt
description: LEAD: Over the last decade, Hamilton Township has steadily been changing from a farming to a suburban character as myriad housing projects have sprung up within its 40 square miles. Now, the latest sign of this Mercer County community's growth is an emerging stock of commercial space.

title: Rebels Are Said to Block Food Aid to Ethiopia
description: The rebel army controlling most of the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea is blocking desperately needed famine relief supplies, members of the United States Congress and officials of the United Nations say.

title: Lighten Up, Wotan
description: To the Editor:

title: For Carl Reiner, The Comic Touch Is Hands-Off Magic
description: Remember the scene from ''Where's Poppa?'' in which the shy, mother-dominated lawyer played by George Segal tries to seduce the ethereal nurse played by Trish Van Devere while the two are standing upright on a bed that offers them no support at all?

title: Diacritical Critic
description: To the Editor:

title: Lip-Synching Can Make Music Sweeter
description: The recent fuss over canned music at live concerts assumes there's a con going on. The argument, put forth by rock critics and legislators, holds that real music must have real live musicians playing it. Anything else is aural Naugahyde.

title: Doris F. Serruto Marries
description: Doris Frances Serruto, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Serruto of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church to John Nelson Thomas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas of Plymouth, Mich. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray officiated. Mrs. Thomas, 25 years old, and her husband, 26, are graduates of Miami University in Ohio. Her father is the president of the R. D. Serr Company, a real-estate development and management concern in Chatham, N.J. The bridegroom is a law student at the University of Bridgeport. His father is the managing partner in the law firm of Sempliner, Thomas, Boak & Smith in Plymouth.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're all for peace. But there is something totally wrong about how this is happening.

title: One Man With a Purpose Takes On Heart Disease
description: The ''little guy out here in Omaha,'' as Phil Sokolof sees himself, has a new message for the giants of the fast-food industry. He has no plans to let up on them until he sees a lot of improvement in American diets.

title: Stories of 2 Ex-Wives Enliven Michigan Race
description: Here's the top of the political news from Michigan: Gov. James J. Blanchard, a two-term Democrat, has begun his campaign for re-election, facing a well-financed challenge from State Senator John Engler, a Republican.

title: Dr. Stricker to Wed
description: Dr. Barbara Stricker, a resident at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, and Dr. Michael Friedman, a resident at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, plan to marry next fall. Dr. Stricker's parents are Mrs. Norman Kaufman of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dr. Howard Stricker of Fort Lee, N.J. Dr. Friedman is the son of Lois Klaristenfeld of Fort Lee and Joseph Friedman of Oceanside, L.I.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Treasury Department's budget deficit report for June. Negotiators from 105 countries take part in trade talks in Geneva, through Friday.

title: Susan Staudohar Is a Bride
description: Susan M. Staudohar, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. Staudohar of Duluth, Minn., was married there yesterday at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Rosary to Mark D. Hill, a son of Mrs. Nicholas T. Popadiuk of El Toro, Calif., and James J. Hill of Mount Baldy, Calif. The Rev. Anthony Giudice officiated. Mrs. Hill, 31 years old, was until recently a vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. She is a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard University. The bridegroom, 31, is an account executive at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in San Francisco. He graduated from the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Judge's Killing Prompts a Challenge
description: IN 1950, when Congress first drafted a plan to financially protect the widowed spouses of Federal judges, the grim possibility that a justice would be assassinated was not within its collective memory. In the last 11 years, however, three judges have been murdered in connection with cases they have heard, the first such incidents since the pioneer days of the 1800's, and Capitol Hill has taken note.

title: Northeast Notebook: Philadelphia;   Rejuvenating Drake Tower
description: The 61-year-old Drake Tower in Center City is undergoing an interior renovation in a conversion from its primary use as a dormitory to an apartment house. It will be ''a New York-style apartment building, with a concierge, at Philadelphia prices,'' said Milton Cross, a spokesman for the development group.

title:
DANCE;

A New Ballet Salutes Beethoven
description: LEAD: THE resident choreographer of the New Jersey Ballet, George Tomal, salutes the triumphant spirit of Beethoven in his new ballet, ''Bravo! Beethoven,'' which will receive its premiere on Friday at 8 P.M. at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

title: Churchill and the Reluctant King
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   Immigrants for South Africa
description: More than 48,000 residents of Eastern Europe have inquired about immigrating to South Africa this year, the Government-run radio said today. A total of 375 immigrants from Poland, Yugoslavia, Hungary and the Soviet Union arrived in the first five months of 1990, the South African Broadcasting Corporation said.

title: Ms. Peterson Wed To Jan K. Elsbach
description: Kimberly Dee Peterson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Finley Marshall of Vermillion, S.D., was married yesterday in Sheffield, Mass., to Dr. Jan Kees Elsbach, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Elsbach of New York. Betsy Holtzinger, the Town Justice of Stockbridge, Mass., performed the ceremony at the weekend home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: Argentines See Spread of Poverty's Pain, and Start to Believe It
description: Along the waterfront, this river delta town northwest of Buenos Aires still shows signs of the fashionable summer colony that it once was: the rowing club, the pastel houses with gingerbread trim, and, a few blocks away, a train station that might have been plucked from rural England.

title: Woman's Tattoos Enliven Her Life
description: LEAD: ''I CALL it my magnificent obsession,'' Patricia Ball said proudly. ''I can't be an actress or a singer, but this is my way of expressing myself. I've made a complete metamorphosis from caterpillar to multicolor butterfly.''

title: Still Courted, 'Merry Widow' Is 85
description: SINCE its Viennese premiere in 1905, the Franz Lehar operetta ''The Merry Widow'' has been a high-spirited staple of the world's musical stages in innumerable translations and adaptations - not to mention filmed, danced, recorded and even ice-skated versions.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: Almost every stamp issued by the United States seems to point topical collectors in a new direction. The latest was occasioned by the issuance of a block of four stamps in March to honor great movies of 1939.

title: Awash With Seafood in Waterbury
description: ANY preconceptions one might have about the fare to be found at a cafe calling itself No Fish Today can be tossed out the window when the huge chalkboard menu is hauled to the table. The long list is awash with fish and seafood dishes, plus a handful of other choices.

title: Don't Tread On the Taxpayer
description: To the Editor:

title: A Windfall Nears In Inheritances From The Richest Generation
description: WITH the wealthiest generation of elderly people in the country's history reaching the end of their lives, economists are trying to predict what will happen to their money.

title: Fresh Air Fund Youths Get Connecticut Respite
description: There are 7,500 different stories that inner-city children tell of their Fresh Air Fund summers with a host family that takes them in for a two-week repreive from the summer streets. The stories take place in the woods or in a classroom, at a pool or a beach, during a rainstorm or in sunshine.

title: William Beckett, Paper Executive, 81
description: William Beckett, a former president of the Beckett Paper Company of Hamilton, Ohio, died Thursday at his home in Hamilton at the age of 81. The company said he had been in declining health for two years.

title: Ellyn Polishook To Marry in '91
description: April wedding plans for Ellyn J. Polishook and David H. Wander, a son of Arlene Wander and Philip Wander, both of New York, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Polishook of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Even Open-Minded Women Must Vote Their Own Best Interests
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa A. Ehrlich Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs Stephen Ehrlich of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Anne Ehrlich, to Emanuel Robert Pearlman, a son of Leonard D. Pearlman and Roberta C. Pearlman, both of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Anna Tobin Marries Paul D'Ambrosio
description: Anna Therese Tobin, a daughter of Judge Beverly C. Tobin and Edwin J. Tobin of Albany, was married there yesterday at St. James Roman Catholic Church to Paul Salvatore D'Ambrosio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas D'Ambrosio of Elmira, N.Y. The Revs. Richard Fragomeni and James Steuer officiated.

title: Let the Elderly Choose to Work or Not
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Ventura, Calif.;

Sweeteners To Sell Homes
description: LEAD: LIKE many residential developers in Southern California, the Weston Development Corporation of Los Angeles is trying to spur sales in a sluggish market by helping buyers to finance purchases of its new single-family houses and condominiums.

title: Advice for N.B.A.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Japan Isn't Playing by Different Rules
description: Slowly and almost imperceptibly, over more than a decade, America has been retreating from one of the most fundamental principles that has distinguished our nation from others: our faith in competition. We have been finding excuses to avoid competition and adopting policies to that effect, often, ironically, in the name of competitiveness. The words of the day are collaboration, relaxing antitrust regulations, managing trade, getting tough on dumping and protecting ''intellectual property.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

It's European? I'll Take It!
description: LEAD: WANT to make something look, taste, feel, smell better? Call it European, and you've got an instant hit.

title: Helen Shelton to Wed Maurice Holmes
description: The engagement of Helen Claudina Shelton to Maurice Lawrence Holmes, the son of Mary L. Holmes-Brown of Chicago, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Shelton of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Though golfers are accustomed to the idea of handicapping, it is a novel concept for tournament bridge players. A Handicap Knockout Team Championship was on the schedule of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Summer Regional in Manhattan a week ago. It provided for almost all participants a first taste of this type of contest.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Herbert Nelson, 76, Actor on Broadway And on Television
description: Herbert Nelson, an actor whose repertory ranged from Shakespeare to Broadway comedy to television drama and soap operas, died on Thursday at the Actors Fund of America Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 76 years old. A former resident of Leonia, N.J., he had lived in Venice, Calif., until last year.

title: Dandelions and Rabbits Need Space, Too
description: IT did not start out as a contest. The catbird was just singing from a branch of the pine tree with a long happy series of chortles, trills and burbles that made up a happy tune. The song sounded very much like the endless cheer of the purple finch, until the catbird was spotted from below.

title: Detailed Plans To Be Given To Cut Use Of Electricity
description: LEAD: PLANS that detail how the Long Island Lighting Company and the state's six other privately owned electric utilities will strive to sell less electricity to their customers are due to be submitted tomorrow to the State Public Service Commission.

title: Outdoors;   Atlantic Bonito: Swift and Strong
description: NO one would deny that the striped bass and the bluefish are the primary quarry of saltwater fly-fishermen from New Jersey to Cape Cod, but every once in a while you'll encounter a fly-fisherman who has been hooked by the Atlantic bonito.

title: BRUSH UP YOUR SHAKESPEARE
description: What is quotable? To quote, or what to quote, that is the question. Should I dress up in taffeta phrases or stick to russet yeas and honest kersey noes? (What is kersey, anyway?) Will a dab of Shakespeare daintily perfume my wit or just sound like the literary belching of a compulsive nerd? But that is not the question. Will anyone even notice that I quote Big Bard 55 times in this essay, or know where the quotations come from, or spot how I have changed them?

title: Victims of A Hidden War
description: ON the gouged, crumbling road from Phnom Penh to the southern Cambodian port of Kampot, a man weaves a bicycle awkwardly among the potholes. He is pedaling with one foot; the stump of the other is swaddled in a kramar, or cotton scarf, slung from the handlebar.

title: Gorbachev Rings the Doorbell of The 'Common European House'
description: IT is perhaps inevitable given the history of this century that Germans making deals with Russians would rouse a certain wariness. But when Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave his imprimatur to German unity, he was following a compulsion with deep roots in Russian history, and his gaze ranged far beyond Germany.

title: Impressionist Illustrator Is Recalled in Old Lyme
description: THE line dividing publicity from criticism is not as clear as it used to be. These days, dealers and museum personnel quite often get right to the point by asking reviewers to ''generate'' interest in a show and, upon encountering resistance, will invoke the popularity of the art, as if they are helpless in the face of public opinion.

title: Gayle Joan Miller Is Married to Martin Reingold
description: Gayle Joan Miller and Martin Reingold were married last evening at the home of the bride's mother, Estelle Sommers, in New Milford, Conn. Rabbi Stanley Davids officiated.

title: Public Ownership Is Good Public Relations
description: Sometimes public leaders lose touch with reality as they sit at their lonely pinnacle of power. Some never had much of a grasp to start with. Richard Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, is an example.

title: I-80's Exits To History In Nebraska
description: A lot of people drive across Nebraska; few linger. They get a bad case of lead foot as they barrel west on Interstate 80 trying to get the 450 miles of Nebraska behind them as quickly as possible. This is a shame. Nebraska is a place of clear light and calming vistas, of architectural landmarks, both majestic and humble, and many quirky little museums. Travelers can soak up some of the state's luminosity by simply easing up on the accelerator. A little knowledge about the region's history will give the unfolding panorama an extra blush and might prompt a traveler to stop and explore along the way.

title: Ms. Kalmanson Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Helene Michele Kalmanson to Brad Alan Epstein, the son of Dr. Raymond D. Epstein of Deerfield Beach, Fla., and the late Frances G. Epstein, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Martin L. Kalmanson of West Hempstead, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Postings: Betting on a $15 Billion Project;   Offices Near Atlantic City
description: Although commercial development has slowed to a snail's pace in much of the Northeast, a partnership of American and British builders thinks it has the right opportunity in an unlikely corner of the region: 10 miles west of Atlantic City, where ground has been broken for a 40-acre office project.They have named the complex Harbor Creek Office Park.

title: Cara Ivy Somach Is Engaged to Marry
description: Cara Ivy Somach and J. Robert Londin, lawyers in New York, plan to marry in October.

title:
Your Own Account;

The Hazards of Roll-Ups
description: LEAD: CONGRESS and the Securities and Exchange Commission are looking into the fairness of a complicated maneuver - called a roll-up - that combines several limited partnership investments into one new unit that trades on a stock exchange.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WASTED, by Linda Wolfe. (Pocket Books, $4.95.) The author of ''The Professor and the Prostitute'' tells the story of the jaded Upper East Side subculture of sex and drugs that gave rise to Jennifer Levin and Robert E. Chambers Jr., the friend who killed her late one night in Central Park. ''In the end, what makes this an excellent, valuable book is that it raises larger questions no less deserving of our attention and consideration,'' Michael M. Thomas said here last year. ''Drugs are an antidote to neglect, and neglect, this story tells us, is not something that begins north of 96th Street.''

title: Vacancy on the Court;   Brennan in His Own Words
description: On Interpreting the Constitution

title: Melissa Lamkin To Wed in the Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Lamkin of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Warren Lamkin to William Baldwin Kuesel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Kuesel of Darien. An October wedding is planned.

title: Wall Street;   The Zero-Coupon Twist to the Old Convertible Bond
description: THE market got news last week of two new pending issues of LYONS, one of the trademarked borrowing gimmicks from Merrill Lynch. A LYON, or Liquid Yield Option Note, is Merrill's zero-coupon twist on the old-fashioned convertible bond. Issued at a big discount from its value at maturity, a corporation's LYON gives the buyer the right to convert the bond into a fixed number of the company's shares, or an equal sum of cash, at the company's option. But it also guarantees a stated rate of return at maturity if it remains unconverted - and, of course, if the company remains hale and hearty.

title:
The View From: Mount Zion Church;

Outcome in Pool Campaign Quiets the Troops
description: LEAD: THE battle lines were drawn, the forces were marshaled. And a victory of sorts emerged. If the opposing side maintains that the outcome was determined largely by a different issue, those who campaigned to keep a municipal swimming pool off land adjacent to the 196-year-old Mount Zion Church here still believe their efforts were influential.

title: Postings: Calvin Klein Cosmetic;   Easing A Squeeze
description: A space squeeze in its Wayne, N.J., building is prompting the Calvin Klein Cosmetics Company, which makes and distributes the Obsession and Eternity fragrance lines, to spread out and move west. The company will lease a new 142,500-square-foot warehouse and distribution center that is being built for it in the International Trade Center in Mount Olive.

title: A Return to Jazz Standards, and a Bit Beyond
description: The neoclassic temper of 1980's jazz, exemplified by Wynton Marsalis's polished playing and his back-to-blues-and-swing philosophy, has lately taken shape as more than a one-man movement. Tireless proselytizing by the 29-year-old trumpet player against jazz's associating too closely with other types of music has instilled a revivalist spirit in an even younger generation.

title: Reviews/Dance;   A Rarity Is Part of Bolshoi Mixed Bill
description: For its final program of the season, the Bolshoi Ballet presented a mixed bill on Friday night at the New York State Theater that included two ''firsts.''

title: In the Balance, Court and Country
description: Only moments after Justice William Brennan's retirement, the politicians and interest groups began churning with speculation. Will the Supreme Court, teetering on its center, veer sharply right? How will President Bush exploit his first chance to nominate a Justice? Must we brace for a confirmation fight that could dwarf the Senate's 1987 brawl over Robert Bork?

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending July 7

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Dresses Just Looking For a Breeze
description: When it's hot, there is nothing like wearing a layer of air. That is what these billowing dresses provide, and it's a style that has it all over this summer's tight Lycra sheaths when city streets start to radiate.

title: Insolvent Bank Bought Cheaply With Help of Former Bush Aide
description: The Arizona businessman who secured $1.85 billion in Federal savings and loan subsidies with lobbying help from a former aide to President Bush was also able to buy an insolvent Oklahoma bank at a favorable price despite his failure to meet Federal standards for such purchases.

title: Taking a Pratfall on the Nastiness Threshold
description: Popular entertainment does, after all, have a revulsion threshold. Andrew Dice Clay should know. He stepped over it and is now desperately trying to salvage his career as a stand-up comic. At the beginning of this year, Mr. Clay was playing to standing-room-only at Madison Square Garden. A week and a half ago, he was restraining sobs on ''The Arsenio Hall Show,'' after whining that ''whenever somebody is on top, they try to bring him down - that's the way it is.'' You've got to ''believe in yourself and you don't listen to nobody,'' he said. ''That's the way it is.'' Mr. Clay is finally learning that that's not the way it is. And his possible professional demise is being effected not through censorship but widespread exposure. Even his most rabid fans are beginning to cringe.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 24 about travelers' safety in Athens referred incorrectly to a Greek restriction on visitors. Only passengers on charter flights from Europe are required to show proof of prepaid accommodation; the requirement has not been applied to Americans.

title: 'Presumed Innocent' Tackles a Tough Case
description: Almost everybody already knows who did the whodunit, so who'll buy a ticket to the movie? For ''Presumed Innocent,'' such is the cinematic paradox of literary success.

title: For van Gogh's Fans, There's Room at the Inn
description: A century ago, on the advice of his brother, Theo, and the painter Pissarro, Vincent van Gogh traveled from Paris to Auvers, a small village along the banks of the River Oise, where a certain Dr. Gachet awaited to treat him. Just 20 miles north of the capital, Auvers is ''far enough from Paris to be real country,'' wrote van Gogh in the first of many letters to Theo describing his new surroundings. Despite its healing effect on the former tenant of the asylum at Saint-Remy, Auvers would be van Gogh's final destination. His time there was one of intense activity - van Gogh made 70 paintings in as many days - culminating in the artist's suicide, exactly one hundred years ago this Friday, in the fields not far from his lodging.

title: 'Miss Daisy' Drives Into Westport
description: THREE of the American theater's most popular recent plays are included in this summer's repertory at the Westport Country Playhouse: ''The Cocktail Hour,'' which was seen early this month; ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' now playing, and ''Steel Magnolias,'' coming up on July 31.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Midland Park
description: LEAD: Quite unexpectedly they come into view, the cluster of sandstone mill buildings on seven acres along Waragraw Brook in the heart of Midland Park.

title: Is 'Quality' An Idea Whose Time Has Gone?
description: At the opening of ''The Magicians of the Earth,'' the gigantic exhibition of contemporary art in Paris last summer, I mentioned to another American art critic that I found the selection of Western artists troublesome. I also said that some of the non-Western artists were not very good.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Keep after insect-disease problems before they overwhelm the plants. Transplanting and dividing continues. Finish pruning, especially spring-flowering species. Last call to apply fertilizer to ornamentals so the new growth has time to develop and harden before cold weather. Keep up fruit tree spray and rose spray as protective measures against disease problems.

title: Why L. T. Deserves $2 Million
description: AT a corner table in LT's, his new restaurant on Route 17 not far from Giants Stadium, the proprietor's voice was firm.

title: If We Don't Give Gorbachev Help, Europe Will
description: To the Editor:

title: Managing;   Treasuring the Technology Guru
description: AT TRW Inc. and the United Technologies Corporation, the title is ''vice president of science and technology.'' At Merrill Lynch & Company, it's ''executive vice president for operations systems and telecommunications.'' Chemical Bank sticks with the plain-vanilla ''chief technology officer.''

title: 2 Dodgers Arrested
description: THE Los Angeles Dodger infielders Alfredo Griffin and Juan Samuel were arrested on assault charges early yesterday after an early-morning fight involving a bartender at a Pittsburgh nightclub.

title: Savannah
description: To the Editor: As one who has been doing research on the history of Savannah, I enjoyed Peter Applebome's piece on ''Savannah's Leafy Green Squares'' (Travel, May 13). I would, however, like to set the record straight on Savannah's Mickve Israel Synagogue, which Mr. Applebome notes, ''describes itself as the oldest Reform congregation in the United States.''

title: '86 and '87 Mazdas Recalled
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation on Friday recalled 102,548 of its 1985 and 1986 model 626 cars because of potentially faulty ignition switches. The company said the switch could wear out after extended use and affect the operation of the windshield wipers and washers, engine cooling fan, heater blower and air-conditioner compressor. Mazda is notifying owners and will fix faulty switches free. The company said no injuries were associated with the problem.

title: Growing Up as a Nuclear Guinea Pig
description: LEAD: I'm sitting in my tractor, and reality is sinking in. I've just finished taping several national television shows. As I step back into my world, the emotions keep rising up in my chest and I cry, uncontrollably at first. Then it feels good, so I sob silently to myself.

title:
DINING OUT;

American Cuisine and a Lakeside View
description: LEAD: THE name of a restaurant is often more enticing than the restaurant itself. For instance, diners drawn to the Sophisticated Otter on Seneca Lake in Sussex County will be disappointed on entering the restaurant because, despite the name, it is casual in the extreme.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Freehold $210,000

title: The Gielgud Who Refurbished the Australian Ballet
description: There will be a Gielgud at Lincoln Center this week, but this particular Gielgud will not be delivering stirring soliloquies from Shakespeare or taking to the stage in any physical way, except perhaps for a final curtain call.

title: A Company Stands on Its Own Feats
description: During the freewheeling 80's, when almost any company was fair game for raiders and other businesses willingly sold themselves, many American hi-fi manufacturers were gobbled up by foreign investors. What happened in the case of Analog and Digital Systems, better known to audio fans as a/d/s/, is all the more remarkable.

title: Getting Help For a Class Reunion
description: Recently I attended my first reunion of Asbury Park High School's class of 1949, and I can't recall ever having had more fun.

title: New Ideas Are Changing Nuclear Debate
description: A NEW generation of nuclear power plants - smaller, simpler and probably safer - is taking shape on the drawing boards. But rethinking the nuclear reactor is raising difficult issues for manufacturers and critics alike.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   The Season is Right For Gardens and Cafes
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Campus Life: Maryland;   Tenants Fighting With Landlords Against New Law
description: Two landlords and their University of Maryland student tenants have teamed up to challenge a Prince George's County law restricting student housing.

title: Measles' Risks Found Reduced by Vitamin A
description: Vitamin A supplements can significantly reduce the risk of death and serious complications in children with severe measles, a new study has found.

title: Japan Pays Up
description: The Japanese Government, good to its word, sent the World Bank a check for $7,706,000 last week in final payment on a highway loan. Japan? Borrowing? To build roads? Yes. Back in the 1950's and 1960's, when Japan was hardly an economic powerhouse, it borrowed $863 million from the bank for projects to rebuild its economy. Among 31 projects the bank helped finance were a company named Toyota and the celebrated bullet train between Tokyo and Osaka. The loan paid off last week, two days early, was for $75 million in 1965 to build a section of expressway between Tokyo and Nagoya.

title: Polo Matches Buoy Hampton Classic
description: LEAD: STEFANIE POWERS says that she has ''never respected stop signs in respect to gender.''

title: Southern Women in a Small Town
description: WHETHER or not a factual difference exists between Southern women and the rest of us, a mythology of the Southern woman does exist.

title: Bureaucracy Cup
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tech Notes;   Thwarting a Nuclear Tap Root
description: RESEARCHERS at the Batelle Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratory in Richland, Wash., have developed a way to inhibit the growth of plant roots for as long as 100 years.

title: Janet Guss Is Married
description: Janet Linda Guss and Charles Brian LaChaussee were married last evening at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Neil Borovitz. Mrs. LaChaussee is a research assistant at the Obesity Research Center at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Her husband is a legal assistant at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York and a student at New York Law School. Both are graduates of Trenton State College. The bride, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Guss of River Edge, N.J. The bridegroom, 26, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert LaChaussee of Whiting, N.J.

title: Safer Monitors Threaten the U.S. Computer Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Fite to Wed Jonathan C. Clay
description: The engagement of Whitney Ann Fite to Jonathan Chace Clay has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Fite of London, Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Nantucket, Mass. Mr. Clay is the son of Harris Clay of Augusta, Ga., and Mrs. Robert E. Carroll of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: Breaching Ethics for Love and Money
description: BOTH houses of Congress did some cleaning last week. A House panel voted to punish a Democrat who did wrong for a lover and a Senate committee voted to sanction a Republican who did wrong for cash.

title: Ann Halan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Halan of New Caanan, Conn., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Halan, and L. Crawford Brickley Jr., the son of Dawn J. Doyle of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mr. Brickley of Greenville, Tenn. The prospective bride and bridegroom are associates at the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts. Miss Halan graduated from Colgate University and Cornell Law School; Mr. Brickley from the University of Michigan and the University of Pennsylvania Law School.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article last Sunday about museums in Connecticut misstated the ranking of the Old State House in Hartford, by number of visitors. It is the state's sixth-largest tourist attraction, not the largest.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today misstates the title of a film starring Kiefer Sutherland and Emily Lloyd.

title: Festive Shakespeare at Boscobel
description: A MOST ingratiating company is treating us to the most pleasant and pure evening of Shakespeare in many a summer. Welcome to the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival where, for once, the appellation is apt. This is a festival that's truly festive. On July 12, ''Much Ado About Nothing'' began the group's third season under a tent on the sumptuous grounds of the 40-acre Boscobel Estate. Formal gardens and an apple orchard surround a pathway to the theater; a vista of the Hudson provides the background and an expanse of lawn and trees takes care of the play's setting. The growing, and in most aspects glowing, professional troupe has extended its number of performances to 12 (from six the first year) and its number of weekends to three.

title: Steinlen Wins Handicap
description: Steinlen, last year's champion American grass horse, went over the $3 million mark in career earnings yesterday when he led all the way to win the $500,000 Caesars International Handicap at Atlantic City Race Course in New Jersey.

title: World Markets;   France's Buying Binge Takes Its Toll
description: STATE-CONTROLLED French companies are breaking the mold. Rather than tending to their home market, they are aggressively buying abroad, both in Europe and the United States. Some, like Renault, are positioning themselves for the economic union of Europe in 1992; others, like Rhone-Poulenc, are pursuing the grander goal of a top ranking in their industry, worldwide.

title: Nancy J. Vawter Is Wed To Michael J. Jackonis Jr.
description: Michael Joseph Jackonis Jr. the son of Diana Jackonis of Princeton and the late Mr. Jackonis. The Rev. Dr. Wallace Alston officiated at the Nassau Presbyterian Church, assisted by the Very Rev. Ronald E. Joseph, an Episcopal priest.

title: Photo: Hazel Sabas, seated at left, Mui Cheuk Yin and Christine Abeling, right, performing in ''The Letter,'' by Silvia Unzueta. (Jay Anderson for The New York Times)Review.Dance;   Diversity From South Of the Border
description: A whole world of modern dance lies beyond this country's borders. The American Dance Festival is to be congratulated, therefore, for establishing the International Choreographers Workshop, which, with financing from the United States Information Agency and the Rockefeller Foundation, enables choreographers from overseas to gather each summer on the campus of Duke University to take classes, observe festival performances and exchange ideas.

title: Talking: Brokers;   Resolving Fears and Doubts
description: Regulatory authorities are receiving a growing number of complaints from buyers and sellers about the way they are treated by real estate brokers. New York State, for example, received some 3,000 complaints in 1989, up from 2,200 in 1987. This is resulting in a rewriting of regulations to better protect and educate buyers.

title: Northeast Notebook: South Portland, Me.;   City to State: Buy It Again
description: This city's government wants the state to buy 13.9 acres of oceanfront land with an asking price of $6 million. The catch is that the state recently handed over its title to a developer.

title: Flexibility Can Be Authentic, Too
description: The early-music movement, one of the most remarkable cultural phenomena of this century, evidently has attained a state of maturity that allows zealous disciples to question its underlying principles. I recently mentioned in this space thoughtful articles in Historical Performance, the journal of Early Music America, that reflected the fading of self-righteousness and amateurism in the movement. That welcome development could be linked to the recent plunge into the commercial mainstream of early-music performers and theorists like Roger Norrington, John Eliot Gardiner, Christopher Hogwood and Nicholas Harnoncourt. What was once a rigid sect has become, under the exhilarating pressure of success, a more pragmatic wing of the establishment.

title: THE GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: A.B. Duke to Leave Post as Chancellor Of L.I.U. Campus
description: Angier Biddle Duke announced his retirement yesterday as chancellor of Long Island University's Southampton campus, ending a long career in international diplomacy and academia.

title: Anne K. Howey to Marry R. T. Carson in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. George W. Howey of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Kristen Howey to Robert T. Carson, the son of Mrs. James Weatherstone of Summit and Benjamin R. Carson of Warminster, Pa. A December wedding is planned.

title: Suzanne Nachman and David Mercado to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Nachman Jr. of New York have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Suzanne Lynn Nachman, and David Mercado, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Mercado of New York.

title: Summer's Heroes: More Guts Than Glory FILM VIEW
description: In 1956, when John Wayne played his greatest role in John Ford's film ''The Searchers,'' he appeared as a lonely, embittered, deeply prejudiced figure, a mean-spirited warrior estranged from home and family. By the end of the film, Mr. Wayne's Indian fighter Ethan Edwards was able, quite literally, to close the door on those antisocial feelings and embrace his loved ones and a peaceful, quieter life.

title: August Wedding For Ms. Randall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Randall of Norwalk, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Juliet Farrar Randall and Lawrence Randolph Bailey Jr., a son of Mr. Bailey of Queens and Cora T. Walker of New York.

title: 'Anarchy' of Cheating Hits Palestinian Schools
description: Palestinian high-school seniors took final exams this week. But at many schools the examinations turned out to be tests of how blatantly they could cheat.

title: Home Market Opening Doors For First-Time Purchasers
description: After years of sitting on the sidelines because of soaring housing costs and high interest rates, first-time home buyers in the New York region are finally getting a break. The relief, say bankers, brokers and the buyers themselves, is in lower prices, cost-cutting incentives offered by both builders and individual sellers and more flexible loan policies of mortgage lenders and insurers.

title: HAITI WANTS U.N. TO MONITOR VOTE
description: Haiti has become the first United Nations member to request that its elections be monitored by the organization to insure that they are free and fair.

title:
Style Makers;

Miles Clay, Cabinetmaker
description: LEAD: Today's biggest home-decorating challenge may be to integrate the array of odd-sized black boxes that make up even the simplest audio and video system. In nearby Hollywood, the custom-made home entertainment centers of Miles Clay are in demand.

title: U.S.O.C. Watches Steinbrenner Case
description: Robert Helmick, the president of the United States Olympic Committee, said today that it ''seemed inappropriate'' to discuss any possible change in George Steinbrenner's relationship with the U.S.O.C. until the Yankee owner's problems stemming from a $40,000 payment to Howard Spira, a self-described gambler, had been resolved. But Helmick was confident that if Steinbrenner, who is a U.S.O.C. vice president, were disciplined by Fay Vincent, the commissioner of baseball, Steinbrenner ''would do what's in the best interest'' of the U.S.O.C. Helmick declined to comment when asked if that meant he would expect Steinbrenner to resign his Olympic post if he were disciplined by Vincent.

title: How Ted Turner Saved the World
description: TED TURNER is a notorious film colorizer from way back. He is also responsible for those soporific Atlanta Braves broadcasts into defenseless homes and taverns all over this land.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 22, 1990

The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan comes to the rescue of Americans fighting Colombian drug lords. 2 4 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) The murder of a gossip writer in New York. 3 34 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 4 3 BLESSINGS, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $5.95.) title: Public Ownership Is Good for Politicians
description: Richard Kessel's article (''Power Authority Is Necessary to Oversee Lilco,'' June 24) emphasizes the $5.5 billion cost of Shoreham. Let us examine the facts: Both Federal and State governments actively encouraged the building of a nuclear plant at Shoreham. After construction was well along, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission began to order hundreds of changes in design, and many completed and started structures had to be destroyed and new ones installed, beginning from scratch.

title: Dirt And Dignity
description: She walked into the courtroom, which was an accomplishment all by itself. ''She looked great,'' said one observer, ''for a person who's been beaten to death.'' By the time she testified, wearing a purple suit and assorted scars, it had become almost fitting that the only thing we did not know about her was her name.

title: Maria-Flora Miller, Student, to Wed
description: Late August wedding plans for Maria-Flora Miller and Anthony Michael Smoller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Smoller of Larchmont, N.Y., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Ava Mohas of Mill Neck, L.I., and Leverett Saltonstall Miller of Fairfield, Fla.

title: C-Span Dials Call-In Radio And Gets Quite an Earful
description: Is call-in radio a forum of democracy or a form of Bedlam? Is it a means of connecting in a society where aloneness threatens or an opportunity for a moment's solo in space? Is it an invitation to communication or to demagogy?

title: Baylor's Interview
description: THE thrills keep coming for Don Baylor, the former American League most valuable player (1979) whose five-team, 19-year playing career ended after the 1988 season.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Toni Jay to Marry Michael A. Asch in November
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry Jay of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Toni Georgenne Jay to Michael Alan Asch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Asch of Sands Point, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

Pueblo Pottery From New Mexico
description: LEAD: From the hard-packed earth of the central plaza at San Ildefonso pueblo, the view stretches over flat-roofed houses to the dark bulk of Black Mesa and up to the wispy clouds and a turquoise sky that promise another warm, gusty day in northern New Mexico.

title: Randall W. Hoffman, College Administrator, 77
description: Randall Walrath Hoffmann, a professor of English who had been an administrator at several colleges, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Tryon, N.C. He was 77 years old and had recently moved to Tryon from Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He died of heart failure, his wife said. Mr. Hoffmann was the dean of students at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., from 1951 to 1966. At the time of his retirement in 1974, he was director of the Human Relations Center at Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens.

title: Are Prospects Improving for Fishermen?
description: THE sign on the telephone pole near the Long Island Shore in Mamaroneck warns: ''Closed area. Taking clams and other shellfish from this uncertified area is prohibited. Violations are punishable by a fine, a jail sentence or both.''

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: When nature leaves no stone unturned, you get a smooth, sandy beach. When chess strategists leave no stone unturned, you get a whole series of jagged edges, White and Black taking turns at sharp victories.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth;   Student to Fight Sex-Abuse Charge And Suspension
description: A Dartmouth College student found guilty of sexual abuse last spring by the college's discipline committee and suspended until January will file a lawsuit against the college this week seeking to nullify the actions, his lawyer says.

title: Campus Life: Yale;   Putting a Limit On How Long Graduates Teach
description: An administration plan to eliminate up to a quarter of the teaching positions for graduate students is forcing academic departments to rethink how much time professors spend teaching and has prompted graduate students to threaten to unionize.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide today misstates the date for ''Turandot'' by the New York Grand Opera in Central Park. It will be performed on Thursday night, not Tuesday.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-13

title: Q and A
description: Marrying in Israel

title: >LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Bells Are Ringing

title: Furious About Cable
description: The Cable Act of 1984 freed cable television companies to gouge customers. And gouge is just what many of them did - with wretched service and unconscionable rates. title: A Toss-Up
description: Because Dwight D. Eisenhower landed on his face, Rosemary Mulligan expects to land in the Illinois State Legislature. Ms. Mulligan called ''tails'' last week when a state election official flipped an Eisenhower dollar to determine the winner of a tied March 20 Republican primary election. The coin toss came after months of courtroom haggling and several recounts found that Ms. Mulligan, a paralegal and political unknown, got the same number of votes as the incumbent, Penny Pullen, who has represented the wealthy suburban Chicago district for 14 years. The race attracted unusual attention because of the candidates' diametrically opposite views on abortion rights: Ms. Mulligan is for, Miss Pullen is against. Miss Pullen's attorney said he would appeal the court ruling that led to the heads-or-tails contest. ''I don't think the coin toss is a biggie,'' said Miss Pullen. ''It just determines who's going to make the appeal.''

title: The Ump's Side of It
description: BEHIND THE MASK: My Double Life in Baseball. By Dave Pallone with Alan Steinberg. (Viking, $18.95.) Every baseball umpire dons a mask to work behind home plate, but the former National League umpire Dave Pallone wore one off the field as well. The reason, Mr. Pallone reveals in his emotional memoir, written with the freelance writer Alan Steinberg, is that he is gay. Fearing that prejudice might cost him his job, Mr. Pallone kept his homosexuality secret from all but a few close friends throughout his 10-year career in the major leagues. But discrimination killed his career anyway, he asserts, as a result of false allegations about his involvement in a teen-age homosexual sex ring. The fact that he was forced to resign even after being cleared of all charges leads Mr. Pallone to assert in ''Behind the Mask'' that organized baseball itself is guilty of leading a double life. ''Publicly, it pretended to be inclusive and fair, but it was close-minded and biased behind its mask.'' Mr. Pallone also details the other controversies that characterized his career. Because he got his job by agreeing to be a scab during the 1979 umpires' strike, Mr. Pallone was ostracized by most of his colleagues from his first game to the last. He also received unwanted notoriety for the 1988 shoving incident with Pete Rose, in which the former Cincinnati Reds manager was suspended for 30 days after pushing Mr. Pallone while arguing a close call. Hot-tempered and tough, Mr. Pallone is not always easy to like, but he argues his case cogently. ''If you're gay, think about removing your mask,'' he concludes. ''Because unless more of us do that, the back-room politics of prejudice will continue to destroy productive careers and lives.''

title: NONFICTION
description: BLOOD EVIDENCE: A Story of True Crime in the Suburban South. By Craig A. Lewis. (August House, $17.95.) In the early morning hours of March 31, 1980, someone killed Kathleen Graham with a sledgehammer in her Shreveport, La., home. Her husband, who was in the bedroom with her at the time, displayed no emotion over his wife's murder. Lewis Graham never cried, cursed or became hysterical. Although he said a minor injury left him unconscious during the killing, Mr. Graham spoke freely and calmly with police, hoping they would find the intruders he said killed his wife. However, the husband instantly became the only suspect, reports Craig A. Lewis in ''Blood Evidence.'' Apparently blame focused strongly on Mr. Graham not because of motive or evidence, but because of personality: people simply could not believe an innocent man could possibly remain so outwardly composed (Mr. Graham, for example, wanted the house cleaned up immediately so the family could return home). Much was made in the trial about his self-containment, writes Mr. Lewis. ''The prosecution and defense disagreed on whether Lewis Graham was a killer or a victim, but they had to agree that his reactions to the murder were unusual.'' Mr. Graham, who was convicted of second-degree murder, has been in prison for almost 10 years now, never wavering in his story. The prosecution had a case, of course, primarily bloodstains and other circumstantial evidence. But what really convicted him, Mr. Lewis contends, was Mr. Graham's demeanor. Whether that conviction is just remains unconvincing to the reader. Mr. Lewis expanded this book from a 25-part series he wrote for The Shreveport Journal. He has clearly done his homework here, but leaves the reader with the frustrating feeling that the murder is still a mystery.

title: NONFICTION
description: TRIAL BY JURY. By Steven Brill and the editors and reporters of The American Lawyer. (American Lawyer/Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $12.95.) ''Trial by Jury'' is to litigation what sportswriting is to playing ball. It is a collection of articles, originally published in The American Lawyer, about 17 celebrated lawsuits of the 1980's. (Seven articles are written by Steven Brill, the magazine's founder and editor in chief.) Prominent are scene-by-scene analyses of courtroom tactics, post-trial juror interviews and lawyerly gossip about backstage deal making and judgment calls. This is solid reporting. And there is a good selection of interesting, important cases: Beech-Nut's unsuccessful defense against Federal charges of having sold flavored water as apple juice, Beulah Mae Donald's suit against the Klansmen who killed her son and the suit by Rose Cipollone's heirs against the Liggett Group, which had manufactured the cigarettes she smoked. Unfortunately, other pieces rehash old topics: Westmoreland v. CBS, Ariel Sharon v. Time, Pennzoil v. Texaco and Abscam. One also misses an editor's hand. These articles have not been revised, merely reprinted. There is no index. Lawyers' gambits and jurors' conflicts do not explain every verdict. One needs a context - a concern with the legal doctrines, institutions and problems around which courtroom dramas play out. Lacking this, too much of ''Trial by Jury'' is simply stale news.

title: Arts Administration: A Further Word
description: I appreciated your article on the ''exodus'' of arts administrators in the Westchester Weekly [''For Diverse Reasons, an Exodus of County Arts Administrators,'' July 1] . Overall, I think you conveyed my comments with accuracy. However, I am writing to clarify two statements attributed to me. While contrasting levels of Federal and New York State financial support for the arts, you stated that I pointed out that N.E.A.'s [The National Endowment for the Arts] annual funding of $170 million is about 70 cents per capita, while New York State's ''$280,000 costs the state taxpayer $3.10 (the figures are approximate).'' Actually, I referred to a New York State annual arts appropriation of more than $50 million - hence the $3.10 per capita figure. The $280,000 is the amount awarded to the Council for the Arts in Westchester by the New York State Council on the Arts, in 1989-90.

title: Talk Radio
description: There was a time, not long ago, when most of the publicity that Joe Slovo got consisted of diatribes from the South African Government, which regularly accused him of being the mastermind behind bombings and assassinations carried out by the African National Congress. For 40 years he and the organization he leads, the South African Communist Party, were outlawed. But in February the ban was lifted and last week Mr. Slovo came so far out of hiding that he appeared on a popular radio call-in program in Johannesburg. ''I think that it's a sickness of our society that when a white is associated with blacks, that he must be the mastermind,'' he told his listeners. With the Soviet empire crumbling, Mr. Slovo said he held fast to his Communist ideals. His wife, Ruth First, was killed in Mozambique in 1982 in a bombing believed to be the work of South African security forces. The couple's fight against apartheid was the basis for ''A World Apart,'' a popular film written by Mr. Slovo's daughter. ''One tries to change the system if one believes it is unjust,'' he said.

title: Cuba Blocks More Embassies
description: The Cuban police sealed off the Canadian and West German Embassies today and tightened a security cordon around the Spanish Embassy after nine more Cubans slipped through during the night and broke in. The latest arrivals brought to 18 the number of Cubans staying at the Spanish Embassy, further complicating a diplomatic quarrel that has strained relations between Madrid and Havana. Extra police officers were guarding the Italian Ambassador's residence, where four Cubans sought asylum on Tuesday after climbing onto the roof. Cuba has said it will not allow any asylum-seekers at foreign embassies to leave the country, saying they must surrender or stay there indefinitely.

title: A Fine Scottish Hand
description: Next to lunching on goat cheese and gelignite, one of the more dangerous things you can do in London is to mess with the National Gallery. Not only is it, inch for inch, as great a picture gallery as the world can show; it is midmost, inmost England. Gloriously situated at the north end of Trafalgar Square, it is the sanctuary of a specific sensibility and the stronghold for 150 years of a heroic view of art. Toward that sanctuary and that stronghold, protective feelings run hot. Right now, the National Gallery is in fine shape, thanks in part to American intervention. Late next spring, the new Sainsbury Wing, designed by the Philadelphia architectural firm of Venturi, Rauch and Scott Brown is due to be opened by the Queen. Several years ago, an American art enthusiast, John Paul Getty Jr., gave the gallery a $50 million???? pound sum for acquisitions. The French Impressionist and Post-Impressionist rooms are being given a long-overdue rehabilitation by Walter H. Annenberg, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James, who gave $5 million for the purpose. In addition, the National Gallery announced in May the coming five-year loan of 72 paintings by Cezanne, Seurat, Picasso, Braque, Miro and others from the collection of Heinz Berggruen, an American art dealer who lives in Switzerland.
