description: PATRIOTISM may be the last refuge of scoundrels, but it is often the first choice of companies seeking the ear of the investing public. Consider the case of American Spirit Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Returning Workers Trained for Real Jobs
description: A SIMPLE premise lies behind the Re-entry Program of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce: people who have been out of the work force a long time need training that prepares them for available jobs. Since its inception in 1986, the program has trained 400 people, placed more than 90 percent of them in jobs and earned the trust of employers in Middletown and neighboring communities in Middlesex County. ''It has worked,'' said the program's director, Edmund J. Gubbins. The program is geared to, but not restricted to, older workers. This fall, it will be extended to 25 people - most of them on welfare - who live in subsidized housing in Middletown.

title: LADIES' COMPARTMENT
description: While planning a recent solo trip to Europe, I received warnings from friends about the dangers of a woman traveling alone in Italy. My experience there confirmed that, in general, women are valued only as mothers or else seen as sex objects. However, I never had any problems because I refused to be intimidated. And regarding Stevenson's first caveat for female tourists, it seems there is little point in traveling if you don't engage in conversation with the people of the country in which you are traveling.

title: The Ant Man
description: E.O. Wilson doesn't make a lot of headway hiking through the Panamanian rain forest. Invertebrates distract him. He stops to poke. A wasp is acting strangely - he must see why. A bee clamps its mandibles onto his hand - no problem. He'll just observe it for a while. He snaps off epiphytes - plants that grow in the lower forest canopy - looking for nesting ants. With a chisel he chips off some bark and discovers an embiopteran web spinner. ''That's not too common,'' he says, impressed.

title: THE POPPERS AND THE PLAINS
description: Frank and Deborah Popper's plan for a Buffalo Commons in the Great Plains has great romantic appeal (''The Poppers and the Plains,'' by Anne Matthews, June 24). As a lawyer and conservationist, I spent considerable time several years ago on a similar proposal for eastern Montana - the Big Open - researching the practicalities of implementing such a scheme. The maze of land titles (Federal, state, county, railroad, private) made the land assemblage complex, but not impossible, provided that the private landowners were willing to cooperate. They definitely were not.

title: Sterling Oxford Edition Is Defining Luxury
description: ONCE in a while, if you do this right, you have to talk about cars that almost nobody drives. You have to write about Yugos, for instance. Or, at the high end, you put pencil to paper about the Lamborghini, which seems to exist solely for the covers of car magazines and for Lee Iacocca commercials. Or you write about the Sterling. Sterling is a British-Japanese hybrid, a samurai in knight's clothing. Its heart is pure Acura Legend, with all the spunk that that implies. But, skin-deep, it presents baronial couth. It is manufactured in Oxford by the Austin Rover Group and it is fairly wonderful. Unfortunately, few of us colonials seem to know that it exists.

title: Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
description: It is true that Strawberry has been scalding for the last six weeks, but his track record shows him to have had such spurts before. It is also admirable that he has chosen to change his life, becoming consistently more alert and determined.

title: When Beauty Shows No Mercy
description: THE TRANSPARENT MAN

title:
Rutherford Journal;

Plan to Restore a 1922 Theater's Glitter Stirs Hope and Doubt
description: LEAD: ''WHEN?'' is the question most often asked by residents of this southern Bergen County community about the proposed restoration of the Rivoli Theater here.

title: A Tale of Four Cities
description: WHERE I FELL TO EARTH

title: Berlin
description: Less than six months ago, preparing for a night out at one of East Berlin's theaters was a nerve-racking experience for the Western visitor: tickets had to be reserved well in advance through an East German Government agency and crossing from West Berlin involved standing in long lines at one of the two border crossings open to foreigners, Friedrichstrasse and Checkpoint Charlie. A mandatory exchange at the border of West German for East German marks was an additional inconvenience.

title: LeMond Takes the Tour Lead
description: It wasn't close. Greg LeMond sped away from Claudio Chiappucci of Italy in the showdown time trial in the Tour de France today and donned the yellow jersey of the overall leader for the first time in the three-week race.

title: Blacks and Jews Working to Build Bonds
description: LEAD: WHEN members of the volunteer fix-up crew from St. Mark's Episcopal Church here and Temple Emanu-El in Westfield met on a recent Saturday to repair the steps and paint the chimney and garage door of a widow's house in Plainfield, they found that a car parked in the driveway was in their way. It was locked, and no one had a key.

title: The Book That Wouldn't Die: A Writer's Last and Longest Voyage
description: By nature, our friend was a searcher. He had traveled through Africa and Asia and the Lowlands of Scotland, but his longest, most intricate journey was in the world of publishing. It was a journey that lasted almost nine years and began with a voyage on the Regina Maris, an early 20th-century sailing vessel on which our friend traveled from Boston Harbor to Newfoundland, then on to Greenland to chart the migratory patterns of whales. As it turned out, this voyage, taken in the summer when our friend turned 30, was also the beginning of a book.

title: Getting Close to Nature in Montana More Women Gaining Entry To Boardroom
description: ACCORDING to a treasured adage in the American West, Montana is what America was. And nowhere does that natural beauty and spirit better exist than in Glacier National Park, a one-million-acre pocket of purity tucked into the northwest corner hard by Canada. Glacier's awe-inspiring alpine vistas are easy to get to but hard to forget. The severity of its mountain geography and its location, slightly off the usual over-traveled Western park trek, have in a wonderfully quiet way helped preserve Glacier from the hordes of Winnebagos, trailers and over-burdened station wagons that clog the roadways at places like Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. Because of weather conditions, the upper reaches of the park usually do not open until June and the lower portions in April, but now is the time to plan a visit, since accommodations are limited and reservations often necessary.

title: Cambodian Says He Fears Risk of a Greater War
description: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the commander of his army, says the American shift of policy on Cambodia offers Vietnam an opportunity that he fears Hanoi will not seize, thus risking an intensification of the war in Cambodia.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 27 about Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses characterized Sotheby's incorrectly. It was founded by Samuel Baker, not by his nephew John Sotheby. A reader's letter pointed out the error several weeks after it occurred, and The Times inadvertently delayed a correction.

title: Us vs. Them Is No Longer Enough
description: THE Bush Administration's policy shift on Cambodia last week is the latest evidence of how the thaw in American-Soviet relations is transforming both superpowers' approach to regional conflicts.

title: Montubio Placed First in Brooklyn
description: Mi Selecto finished first but Montubio was awarded the victory in the $403,200 Brooklyn Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park after an unusual disqualification that made no difference to anyone who wagered on the race.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No Parties for the Party

title: Stitches of History: A Quilt Show in New Canaan
description: LEAD: AN exhibition of quilts called ''A Labor of Love, '' at the Town House Museum of the New Canaan Historical Society, is notable because the quilts ''are placed in a different context,'' said the society's president, Sunny Macdonald. ''As a costume museum, we've added dressed mannequins of the period and created background settings.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: On Language;   A Taste for Scrambled English
description: In Stockholm, There is a chain of fast-food restaurants where you can get, along with a risk of heartburn, what must rank as the ultimate in culinary oxymorons: a hamburger called a Mini Big.

title: Foundation Seeks to Restore U.S. Competitive Edge
description: An American philanthropy plans to spend millions of dollars to bring scholars and industrial leaders together in projects to restore the nation's competitive edge in manufacturing and trade.

title: Lois Maurillo Is Married
description: Lois A. Maurillo, a teacher at Public School 124 in Brooklyn, and John Yasko 2d, an inspector for Trans World Airlines at Kennedy International Airport, were married yesterday at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn by the Rev. Charles McLaughlin. The bride, the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Dominick F. Maurillo of Brooklyn, is a graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., and has a master's degree in social work from Fordham University. Mr. Yasko, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Yasko of Indiana, Pa., graduated from Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University.

title: Agriculture May Be Vanishing, but Farmers' Fairs Are Booming
description: AS farming vanishes from Connecticut, the popularity of country fairs, with events from jam judging to oxen pulls, is booming. But as the larger fairs draw ever-growing crowds and ever-growing traffic problems, and as all the fairs confront a shrinking pool of volunteers, some people see problems ahead for these events.

title: Program Traces Evolution of Ragtime Into Jazz
description: THE New World Consort, ensemble in residence at Wesleyan University, has given birth to the New World Jazz Orchestra, proudly calling it ''Connecticut's only concert ensemble specializing in the authentic re-creation of historic American music.'' Tomorrow evening at 6:30 (or Tuesday if rain makes a postponement necessary), the orchestra goes to Goodwin Park in Hartford with a program tracing the evolution of ragtime into American jazz.

title: Investigation of Vote Buying Shakes S. Carolina Capital
description: A Federal grand jury's investigation into the possibility of vast corruption in the South Carolina Legislature appears to be expanding rapidly and has left this capital city shaken.

title:
FOCUS;

Boston; 2 Projects Falter in the Cultural District
description: LEAD: TWO large mixed-use commercial projects, anchors for a city plan to transform the last major downtown development area into a cultural and entertainment district, are struggling to get under way despite the financial problems of the developers and a weaker office market.

title: Practical Traveler;   A New Rental Car Option: the Mobile Phone
description: LAST spring Continental canceled an evening flight out of Newark after two postponements, and at 10:30 P.M. I stood dismally in line to have my ticket revalidated for early morning. I was calculating when I could get to bed and when I would have to get up again when I saw the man ahead of me using a cellular phone to reserve a hotel room. ''Don't hang up, please,'' I implored, and he soon let me speak to the Marriott people. I made a reservation and when I got to the luggage area, the van was waiting.

title: Style Makers;   Barbara Blank, Tie Designer
description: She earned a master's in psychology at Harvard and studied art history in Italy. Now Barbara Blank designs ties. That isn't as illogical as it sounds.

title: Office Romance Makes Firehouse a Fire Home
description: In 1982, when Cecelia O. Salters became the first woman to join Ladder Company 9, most of her colleagues at the firehouse on Great Jones Street in lower Manhattan let her know they preferred firemen.

title: By Request, Gypsy Violins
description: Always playing, the violinist in his gold-embroidered blue tunic strolls to the table where a couple are halfway through their roast duck dinner and asks for their selection. As something is murmured, the fiddler strikes up the plangent opening bars of ''There Is Only One Girl in the World.''

title: Revolution in the Gallery
description: RUSSIAN ART

title: Talent and All the Right Connections
description: VILLAGE

title: Poland's Black Madonna
description: For six centuries, through Poland's wars and vacillating fortunes, the faithful have walked days, often the last distance on their knees, to revere the Black Madonna of Czestochowa. Painted on wood - legend has it by the brush of St. Luke - the doleful four-foot-high icon is the focus of the nation's spiritual life. The icon, known as the Queen of Poland, is credited with leading a group of monks holding out against a Swedish siege in 1655. More recently, the madonna's image was never absent from Lech Walesa's lapel during the Solidarity leader's struggle against Poland's Communist regime.

title: High-Tech Cooperation
description: To the Editor:

title: Is That a Dark Cloud or a Silver Lining for Aluminum?
description: THE earnings released last week by aluminum producers were, in a word, grim. But the companies appeared unfazed and said profits would start climbing soon.

title: Perspectives: 42d Street Redevelopment;   Picking Up the Pace of Preparing the Site
description: In the life of a longterm development project there are frustrating periods followed by bursts of progress. A condemnation order from a judge in April set off such a burst in the saga of New York City's effort to redevelop 42d Street from Times Square to Eighth Avenue.

title: Reeling Padres Transform From Contenders to Rebuilders
description: The San Diego Padres have executed one of the better magic tricks of recent seasons. They have gone from contenders to rebuilders right before their very eyes.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Double revenge is the motif of BLOOD TIDE by Robert F. Jones (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95). The book is about a father and his daughter. He, a former Navy man as strong and as patriotic as they come, was captured during the Vietnam War. He was put through excruciating torture and held up through it all. But on his return after the war he was accused of collaborating with the enemy. Somebody lied about him. He retired and began drinking himself to death.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Tea at Dusk in Tashkent Is a Ritual for Men Alone
description: By midafternoon the sun is as brazen as the male egos gathering in the dappled cool under a canopy of trees.

title: Hemlock Society Attracts Growing Attention
description: LEAD: THE Connecticut Hemlock Society, which advocates allowing terminally ill people to end their own lives or have a physician assist them in dying, is gaining more members and attracting greater interest since a recent United States Supreme Court decision in a ''right to die'' case.

title: Cubs Add to Streak, Beating Giants
description: Doug Dascenzo scored the tying run in the eighth inning on a balk by a reliever, Jeff Brantley, and Marvell Wynne raced home from second on Jose Uribe's error at shortstop as the Chicago Cubs defeated the San Francisco Giants today, 3-2.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Making of a Legend
description: LEAD: I AM looking through some old cartons in my attic when I come across the book ''Young Actor's Guide to Hollywood.'' I smile when I see the torn cover and wrinkled pages where so many corners are missing. For several magical years, that book was my bible, helping to guide me along the road to stardom.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

Jabes Goes Bell Jar
description: LEAD:

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Asking For Help Can Be Rewarding
description: LEAD: DURING a long hospitalization the spring before last, I underwent my first experience, as an adult, of nearly total physical dependency. Though I found it hard on my sense of self-sufficiency, I also found it enriching in ways I never anticipated.

title: Cheering On the Youngest Readers
description: IT is storming outside the Scarsdale Public Library. Rain streaks the windows of a cozy alcove in the Children's Room. There, a lineup of little ones sits, waiting to tell the ''listeners'' about the books they have read.

title: Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
description: The Mets' front office have let talent like Kevin Mitchell and Len Dykstra slip from their fingers. Now it would seem that Darryl Strawberry is next.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Style Makers;   Willy van Rooy, Shoe Designer
description: Willy van Rooy, 47 years old, is proof that there is life after modeling.

title: She Saw Wondrous Opportunities at Jacob's Pillow
description: Is it possible that a decade has passed since Liz Thompson became artistic director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival? At summer's end, Ms. Thompson, now the Pillow's executive producer, departs to head the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. She leaves the Pillow, a small but internationally known festival in Becket, Mass., a very different place from the one she found several years after the death of its founder, Ted Shawn. Today the Pillow is dynamic, vibrant, imaginative - just like Liz Thompson herself.

title: Erin P. Edwards Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Erin Paige Edwards to Stephen Louis Fairchild, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Fairchild of New York, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Gordon A. Edwards and Mikal L. Edwards, both of Brussels. A September 1991 wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on July 8 misstated the scope of discounts for older passengers on Amtrak. The 25 percent discounts do not apply to sleeping accommodations, club service or custom class.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE STATIONS OF SOLITUDE. By Alice Koller. (Morrow, $19.95.) In this account of her struggles with self-imposed solitude, the essayist Alice Koller discloses her most intimate secrets with startling nonchalance. She can get away with this because she stands as far away from us as possible and because her voice is strong and carries, not only from the New England and Virginia country houses where she has spent the past 28 years, but from the place just beyond the pale of human contact where she lives. With her three German shepherds for companionship, Ms. Koller has been stalking the stark American landscape Henry David Thoreau called ''the vantage ground of . . . voluntary poverty,'' where she leads the examined life. Utopia always looks great from a distance, and Ms. Koller draws us into hers with sentences as brooding and hushed as the hours before dawn in which she writes. The problem with utopia, of course, is that once you get there, there is not much to do. Ms. Koller's exemplary life provides a wealth of instructive anecdote - books she has written, houses she has rescued from disrepair, dogs she has nursed - but seems, ultimately, rather limited. And while each of ''The Stations of Solitude'' (designated by chapter headings like ''Moneying'' and ''Singling'') offers a beguiling rest stop on the road to self-knowledge, Ms. Koller lingers longer than she should on a rehash of the events that led up to her hermitic existence. Her main obstacle to contentment is apparently the doctorate in philosophy she earned from Harvard University but never put to use in a permanent academic post. This book's uneven tone calls to mind the patter of a brilliant but eccentric performer: it enthralls one minute and gets querulous the next.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Saving the Earth Through Laundry
description: LEAD: IN my house, the simplest things have become fraught with significance of late. Take laundry. It was a straightforward matter, once upon a time. The hamper got full, and I did the wash.

title: Ms. Weber Weds Karl-Erik Gude
description: Elizabeth Dorsey Weber and Karl-Erik Leopoldo Gude were married yesterday at the Scarborough (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George A. Van Arnam, a United Methodist minister who is an uncle of the bride.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Small Children Are Terrific Therapists
description: LEAD: PARENTS of small children have an exclusive advantage in the health-care field that is rarely discussed or written about: the rejuvenating effects of exposure to youth. The medical journals never explore this phenomenon, but abundant proof of the dramatic effects of this scientific wonder are readily available.

title: Rimbaud and Verlaine, Together Again
description: IN MEMORIAM TO IDENTITY

title: No Charges Sought Against Nuclear Official
description: The Justice Department has decided not to prosecute the former chief of staff at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, who was found by the commission's inspector general to have given false and contradictory information to Congress.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Dignified End For Special Clothing
description: LEAD: TUCKED away somewhere is your boyfriend's varsity sweater, which means more than a closet full of designer dresses. Or the Mets cap from the first time your dad took you to Shea. They're part of an elite wardrobe: clothes that wear us.

title: Sink It, and Link It
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIARY/July 15-20
description: Home Builders' Lament: Fewer New Houses, Fewer New Buyers

title: Sergei Paradzhanov, Armenian Director, 66
description: Sergei Paradzhanov, an Armenian film director, has died after a long illness, the official press agency Tass said today. He was 66 years old.

title: Home Field Has Defender
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Maura Moynihan, a Comic, Is Married To John F. Avedon, a Writer, on L.I.
description: Maura Russell Moynihan, a partner in the comedy team of Moynihan and Green, was married yesterday in Montauk, L.I., to John Franklin Avedon, a writer. The Rev. Ernest Campbell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Avedon of New York.

title: Ryan Wincing His Way to 300th
description: It seemed odd. When Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers hobbled out of the trainer's room in Arlington Stadium on Friday night with an ice bag taped around his right ankle and was met by a group of mostly local reporters, all of them asked about his back.

title: Bomber Away?
description: It seems that the Bush Administration doesn't consider Orlando Bosch that bad a guy, after all. Dr. Bosch, an anti-Castro Cuban who American officials say is responsible for dozens of bombings, including that of a Cuban airliner in Chile in 1976, last week was granted limited parole by the Justice Department, which had detained him in Florida for two years as an undesirable alien. Last year, when the Justice Department was trying to deport the former pediatrician, it said he had ''repeatedly expressed and demonstrated a willingness to cause indiscriminate injury and death.'' Though he was released under conditions that included a stipulation that he renounce terrorism, Dr. Bosch hardly seemed repentent. He called the agreement ''a farce,'' adding, ''They purchased the chain but they don't have the monkey.'' What brought about his release? The Justice Department was vague about it, but several powerful South Florida Republicans, including one of the President's sons, Jeb Bush, had lobbied on Dr. Bosch's behalf.

title: Wedding Planned For Ms. DeVecchi
description: Robert P. DeVecchi of New York and Florence Sloan DeVecch of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Lincoln DeVecchi to Peter Johnstone Smith, the son of Mrs. Albert Oliver Smith of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. Smith. A September wedding is planned.

title: MAGNET TRAINS' USE LIMITED, U.S. SAYS
description: High-speed passenger trains that ride on magnetic cushions are economically feasible in the next 10 or 20 years, but only on a relatively small scale, according to a new report by the Federal Railroad Administration.

title: TWO SIDES PREPARE FOR HARD BATTLE ON COURT NOMINEE
description: President Bush began discussions today on a successor to Justice William J. Brennan Jr., while liberals and conservatives immediately began organizing for what many predicted would be a bruising battle over the shape of the Supreme Court in the 1990's and the constitutional right to abortion.

title: Blue Jays Win, 2-1, on Homers
description: Dave Stieb gave up five hits in eight innings and George Bell and Pat Borders had bases-empty home runs today as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Oakland Athletics, 2-1.

title: All About/Cat Supplies;   Billions for Food, And Knicknacks to Boot
description: AS the popularity of cats continues to soar - at 58 million, they now outnumber dogs as household pets by about seven million - so does the market for feline-related products. Some are strictly for cats. But many others court the needs, whims and fancies of cat owners.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on July 8 about the reclaimed Aberglasney garden in Wales misidentified a structure. It was a stable block, not a cloister and terrace walks.

title: This Is the Summer of Frustration
description: LEAD: COMMUTING to New York this summer has been as bad as transportation experts warned it would be. Even the people who monitor traffic and suggest less congested routes to commuters are experiencing all-time-high frustration levels.

title: LADIES' COMPARTMENT
description: I understand that traveling alone in India can be an uncomfortable experience for a woman (Hers: ''Ladies' Compartment,'' by Martha Stevenson, July 1). But it is unfair to condemn Indian men on the basis of a problem that hasn't been solved at home. Stevenson should travel across the United States in a bus and see that gender relations are mired in medieval times, no matter where you are.

title: Restoration Encounters Head Winds
description: The Lettie G. Howard was a proud fishing schooner in her youth, carrying mackerel and cod from the cold Atlantic to markets like New York.

title: The Executive Computer;   When Computing Power Is Generated by the Lawyers
description: IT used to be that programmers, engineers and marketers were the centerpiece of the computer industry. Now lawyers are taking center stage. Dozens of computer companies are wrangling over copyright and patent issues, and some analysts fear that legal code, rather than software code, is emerging as the factor that will determine which companies and products will dominate the 1990's.

title: Review/Concert;   Norfolk Festival: The Happy Outcome of a Musical Learning Experience
description: Like the Music Center at Tanglewood some 40 miles to the north, the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival in northwestern Connecticut is celebrating a half-century of summer schooling for young musicians.

title: So Close To 3,000 - And Then So Far
description: Just when everyone knew the program traders were going to bail them out by buying stocks, they didn't. That may be the simplest summary of a week when the Dow Jones industrial average first failed to close over 3,000 by the smallest margin possible, and then saw prices crumble in the final moments Friday. The plunge sent the interest-sensitive Dow utilities to a 13-month low.

title: Prepared To Serve
description: HE is described as so eager to get started on the next phase of his life you'd think he was a bonus baby waiting for the opening of his first spring training rather than a rookie offender looking forward to his first incarceration.

title: Date Update
Commercial Property: Ladies' Mile;   Some Landmarks Languish as a Precinct Prospers By David W. Dunlap
description: Until recently, it did not seem too farfetched to imagine the Avenue of the Americas reclaiming some of its Gilded Age vibrancy south of 23d Street, where heroically scaled but long neglected department stores line the street.

title: At Play With All the King's Men
description: Chess is neither the oldest board game in the world nor the most difficult to master. For 14 centuries, however, judging from the wealth of innovative sets that survive, it has challenged designers and artisans on four continents.

title: Evening Hours;   Queen Awards And a Benefit For a Museum
description: On Monday, A.T.&T. and the National Coalition of 100 Black Women held their 8th annual Candace Awards dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $437,500

title: Lifestyle;   Keeping Cool While Moving Muscles
description: The wet look is back with a vengeance, as the fitness brigade - sticky, sweat-drenched, cradling water bottles - braces for another humid summer.

title: Arthur Tremain Hertig Dies at 86; Led Human Embryology Studies
description: Arthur Tremain Hertig, whose pioneering studies on human embryology contributed to the development by others of the contraceptive pill and in vitro fertilization, died Friday at Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: Soldier and General Alike To Feel Bite of Budget Ax
description: Driven by sharp budget cuts and a decrease in global tensions, the Pentagon is drastically shrinking its all-volunteer force, and the effort is causing anxiety at all levels of the military.

title: A Little Airport Delay Has a Multiplier Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: By The Beautiful Black Sea
description: In pictures and from the air, the Bulgarian Black Sea coast looks like a vacationer's paradise. The rolling hills of the coast meet the blue and green Black Sea along beaches of golden sand that seem made for swimming and sun bathing. Picturesque villages where each house is wreathed in grape vines, roses and house plants sprouting from oil cans and jars and old tires dot the coastal roads. Donkey-drawn wagons, heaped with hay and conducted by hunched and scarved women or blue-jacketed men, are almost as common as cars.

title: The Mute Swan Covers the Northeast
description: In the Long Island Journal item for June 24, ''Taking Aim at Swans'', the particular swan referred to is termed ''mute.''

title: Barton Gellman to Marry Tracy Sivitz in September
description: September wedding plans for Tracy Ellen Sivitz and Barton David Gellman have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Sivitz of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Message To the West
description: Neil Kinnock, leader of the British Labor Party, came to New York, delivered a serious speech before an important audience, raised an issue critical to the future of freedom in the Soviet Union - and then got the answer wrong.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Balancing Housing and Space for Offices
description: LEAD: A Manhattan developer is putting up an office building and condominiums side-by-side in Greenburgh, with the residential space planned in part for relocating companies that want to be sure good housing is available to their employees.

title: Jan Laurie Kreisberg Plans to Marry in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kreisberg of Garden City, L.I., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Jan Laurie Kreisberg, and Charles Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Rosenberg of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Ms. Kreisberg, 38 years old, graduated from American University and has an M.A. in sociology from the New School for Social Research. She is a paralegal with the New York law firm of Moses & Singer. Mr. Rosenberg, 36, graduated from Boston College. He is a marketing manager for Home Box Office in New York.

title: VACANCY OF THE COURT: An Activist's Legacy;   From Personal Liberties to Voting Rights, Brennan Led Way in Changing the Nation
description: Justice William J. Brennan Jr.'s departure from the Supreme Court brings to an end not only a remarkable judicial career but also an era in the Court's history.

title: Think Winds
description: To the Editor:

title: Carmella Welch Weds
description: Carmella Welch, a daughter of Carol Welch of Astoria, Queens, and the late William Welch, was married last evening to Michael Keyles, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Keyles of Sayreville, N.J. The Rev. James Covington and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. Mrs. Keyles received a bachelor's degree and a master's in education from Pace University. She is the manager of computer education at Prudential-Bache Securities in New York. The bridegroom, a graduate of Rutgers University, received a master's in computer science from Pace. He is a project manager for computer work station systems at Salomon Brothers in New York.

title: Faldo Surges Ahead by 5 Shots
description: Nick Faldo kept up the fastest pace ever set in a British Open today, one that even the hottest golfers could not catch and one that all but left Greg Norman buried in one of the claustrophobic bunkers of the Old Course.

title: Time for Colleges to Take Back the Field
description: THE word is out: big-time college sport, which had been moving rather impressively toward a new rectitude under the whip of a born-again leadership (mostly college presidents fed up with being truant officers), is about to go off the wagon again. Thanks once more to the willingness of television to sponsor debauchery, and the eagerness of college athletic departments to sucker in, half - or so it seems - of the major college programs in the country are said to be preparing to throw caution - and tradition, and common sense - to the winds in a wholesale realignment of who-plays-whom.

title: Data Bank/July 22, 1990

Food;

SANDWICHED TOGETHER
description: LEAD: Maybe it's because by summer's end i can no longer help eating with my fingers. Or maybe it's the Cape Cod vacations of my youth - afternoons spent picnicking on a splintery dock, eating chunky lobster rolls with coleslaw.

title: Priscilla Newton Weds Patrick Scobie
description: Priscilla Ann Newton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James C. Newton of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Patrick Sean Scobie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Scobie of Chippewa Falls, Wis. The Rev. David S. Hoag officiated at Christ Episcopal Church. Mrs. Scobie, 24 years old, graduated from the Westover School and cum laude from Wheaton College. She is the associate director of admissions at the Kent Denver Country Day School in Englewood, Colo. Her father is the chief of ophthalmology at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. Her mother, Dr. Mary Newton, is a professor of biology at Manhattanville College.

title: Design;   A Soft Touch
description: The sequence of pale rooms is devoid of pattern and color. The architectural details are subtle and correct. In each room, antiques are placed sparingly. The look is slightly unfinished - a brand of romantic modernism that is the unmistakable signature of Boston-based designer William Hodgins. In many ways, the style recalls the work of two great designers from earlier in this century: Billy Baldwin and Syrie Maugham. Like Maugham, Hodgins is a leading proponent of the colorless room, and like Baldwin, his interiors are at once tailored and highly personal. Hodgins dismisses such comparisons, however, preferring to discuss the new apartment in its architectual context. His two-bedroom home, in the Hotel Agassiz, an 1872 building that was one of the first apartment houses in Boston, has views of Commonwealth Avenue. Indeed, the setting is right out of a Henry James novel. The decorating is not. All the rooms have an open, airy feeling. But when the designer first found the space, it had been substantially modernized, stripped of its period details and arranged so that rooms were not properly oriented to take advantage of the windows. Hodgins moved walls, replaced mantels and added moldings, inventing the architecture he imagined the house once had. He installed dentil moldings throughout the apartment, except in the living room, which had higher ceilings. ''In this taller room, the moldings looked skimpy,'' Hodgins says. So he hired Robert Jackson, a trompe loiel artist, to paint the same style molding, only an inch and a half deeper.

description: THEME IS FITNESS

title: Wave Hill Forced to Disband Cultural Programs
description: Wave Hill, the park and cultural center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, will eliminate its concerts, dance series and art exhibitions and cut its staff by 20 percent during the next year.

title: Strawberry Hits 24th And Darling Wins
description: The shot rose into the misty night sky, straightened slightly as it approached its apex and crashed solidly into the foul pole in right field. The tiny white rocket, in addition to being a home run, was Darryl Strawberry's least controversial and most convincing campaign statement of the last 48 hours.

title: Should the Mets Have Called Off Strawberry Talks
description: Sign him now. Unless Strawberry signs a contract with the Mets before the season ends, he will be putting on another team's jersey, and it will be the biggest mistake the Mets have ever made.

title: H.U.D. Scandal's Lesson: It's a Long Road From Revelation to Resolution
description: IN the fall of 1989, when the scandals at the Department of Housing and Urban Development were one of the biggest stories in America, David Burns, a senior staff member in the department's New York office, asked his superiors in Washington for permission to talk with the press about past wrongdoing at the agency. He got the go-ahead and the story he told of political pressure put on department bureaucrats in New York during the Reagan years made national headlines.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: SUSAN WASHINGTON;

Duty on the George Washington Bridge
description: LEAD: FOR seven years Susan Washington has worked as a toll collector on the George Washington Bridge. She is one of 143 collectors at the 14-lane bridge spanning the Hudson River. According to officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, 100 million vehicles cross the bridge yearly.

title: About Men;   A Familiar Ring
description: Seven years after my father's death, I have begun wearing his ring. Not always. I wear it, talismanically, to weddings, funerals and other solemnities, on long drives toward meaningful destinations. I slip it on, I will sheepishly admit, for its powers.

title: Once More, Yankee Effort Goes to Waste
description: A double-play ball hits a seam and caroms off the shortstop for a single. The single leads to the decisive run. An opposing pitcher returns from the minor leagues with the resolve that the time has come to relax. A second consecutive complete game becomes a second consecutive loss.

title: GIAP REMEMBERS
description: Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese Communist commander, is certainly a man of deep commitment, and Stanley Karnow's fascination with his erudition and style is understandable (''Giap Remembers,'' June 24). But before we grant Giap an eminent place in the ''pantheon of military leaders,'' we ought to remember one thing. Progressive military thinkers since Karl von Clausewitz (the Prussian general and military strategist) have placed one criterion for brilliance above all others: the ability to bend an enemy to one's political will while incurring the least possible cost to one's own cause and causing the least possible devastation in contested areas.

title: Tax Reform Is a Gremlin in the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND

title: Armin Jordan: In Search of an Elusive Spotlight
description: Erato - the French label that had until last year been distributed here by RCA but has now been taken up by Elektra Classics - is back. And so, too, is Armin Jordan. Mr. Jordan is not especially well known on this side of the Atlantic, and there probably aren't a great many collectors who have been waiting in breathless anticipation for new releases from the Swiss conductor.

title: Photo: Daniel Harnett as Charles Manson in ''The Manson Family.'' (Dona Ann McAdams/''The Manson Family'')Review/Music;   A Theater Work About Charles Manson
description: John Moran still counts among the brighter lights of vanguard American musical theater. But it cannot be said that he has advanced his cause with his latest music drama, ''The Manson Family,'' which opened a two-night run on Tuesday at Alice Tully Hall as part of the Serious Fun series there.

title: Tax Increase: Challenges Amid the Furor
description: THE mounting grass-roots opposition to Gov. Jim Florio's tax package and school aid plan is posing difficult challenges for all sides involved in the intensifying debate.

title: Coyotes Can Still Enjoy Break From Hunters
description: New York State's coyotes can rest easy for another year. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced yesterday that the sponsors of a bill that would have allowed year-round coyote hunting in the Adirondack Park had agreed to withdraw it. In return, the Governor said the state would undertake a study of the state's ''coyote problem.''

title: The People Who Are Putting Taste Back on the Table
description: THE Quaker Oats Company saw boundless potential in the $7 million a year rice-cake business when it bought a small producer in 1985. Supported by the Quaker name and advertising budget, rice-cake sales took off as health-conscious consumers sampled the filling, 35-calorie, fat-free snacks. But then consumers discovered another thing about rice cakes: their taste value was about on a par with styrofoam. Sales rapidly diminished. ''We realized at that point,'' said Lyle G. Hubbard, a Quaker marketing executive, ''that we needed to get the product to taste good.''

title: MURDER IS CHARGED
description: A Bronx man who told the police he wrested a gun away from an armed robber and then fatally shot his assailant was arrested yesterday on murder charges, although a police spokesman said investigators thought the man had acted in self-defense.

title: Western Europe, Its Births Falling, Wonders Who'll Do All the Work
description: French families receive generous welfare and tax incentives to have more children, but to no avail. Mothers in France are no longer averaging the 2.1 children needed to insure a natural replacement of the country's population.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Air Fares Cut In California Price War

title:
THEATER;

By Candlelight, Martha Clarke Creates Three-Ring Theater
description: LEAD: As darkness falls over a big tent pitched on Herman Melville's estate here, a group of actors light candles and hold them up to see their way about the expanse of wood chips that is their stage. They go through several ''images,'' or tableaux, the building blocks of this work in progress: One sings a threnody while sitting on a brass bed stage center, another pushes a wooden ball three feet in diameter stage right to stage left, a couple crawl across the floor in a movement called a double serpent, someone recites lines from Whitman's ''Leaves of Grass.

title: Bush and the Court
description: For years, the liberal's nightmare has been the death or retirement of one of the three aged Justices who have prevented total domination of the Supreme Court by a conservative majority. Now the nightmare appears to have come true in the announced departure of the distinguished William J. Brennan Jr. That leaves a seat to be filled by President Bush, probably adding a sixth and conclusive vote to those of the five conservatives - Justices Rehnquist, White, O'Connor, Scalia and Kennedy - already sitting. It also means the loss of the Court's most influential, broad-gauged and skillful liberal presence.

But in ''Back to the Future, Part III,'' simple little Marty turns post-modern. He lands in the old West, calls himself Clint Eastwood and mocks western movie cliches as he heads toward a serious shoot-out on Main Street.

After 64 deals of regulation play the scores were tied, but a 12-board playoff gave victory to Doug Simson and Walter Johnson, both Columbus, Ohio, Jeff Meckstroth, Reynoldsburg, Ohio, Eric Rodwell, West Lafayette, Ind., and Dennis Clerkin, Bloomington, Ind.

title: Corrections

Young & Rubicam has handled some accounts, not all; McCann-Erickson Worldwide also handles several. All but one of the Young & Rubicam accounts were awarded last week to Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein, and the other account went to Waring & LaRosa.

title: Crossland Savings FSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income There were no per share earnings for year-ago periods after preferred dividends. The compay said results in the latest second quarter included $50 million in charges for writedowns of its portfolio of real estate assets to estimated net realizable value, writedowns of collateralized mortgage obligation residuals to estimated fair market value and loan loss provisions. Crossland said results in the latest second quarter included a $22.3 nillion net loss in real estate operations resulting from writedowns of $33.8 million in the value of certain of Crossland's investments in real estate, including acquisition, development, and construction arrangements, joint ventures and real estate owned, offset by $11.5 million in income related to acquisition, development, and construction and other real estate activity. There was also a $15.1 million writedown of Crossland's investment in collateralized mortgage obligation residuals from a book value of $27.9 million to $12.8 million resulting from the decision, at the request of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., to develop a plan to dispose of its investment in these assets. Crossland also took a $3.2 million writedown in anticipation of the impeding sale of a subsidiary.

title: Jockey Rides Wooden Winner
description: IN Julie Krone's eight-month journey back to racing after breaking an arm in a spill at the Meadowlands last November, she has had surgery twice and has spent months riding pleasure horses, weeks lifting weights, and days breezing horses at the track. But as Krone returns to riding at Monmouth tomorrow, her 27th birthday, a good deal of the credit for the jockey's comeback could go to a horse named Whinny.

title: Old, Weak and a Loser: Crack User's Image Falls
description: Crack has begun to get a bad name among a growing number of young people in New York City's poorest neighborhoods, according to some teen-agers, police officers and researchers who work on the streets. Rather than a challenge, something to test a teen-ager's mettle, they say, the smokable form of cocaine is gaining a reputation as a drug ''for losers.''

title: Women Are Giving Triathlons a Run
description: THOSE athletes competing in the Danskin sprint-distance triathlon in White Plains on Sunday are testimony to the growing popularity of the sport among women. The second (and only East Coast) race of the Danskin Women's Triathlon Series is an 800-meter swim across Lake Isle, followed by a 20-kilometer bike race down the Bronx River Parkway, followed by a 5-kilometer run on the parkway to the Kensico Dam. The series offers the only triathlons in the United States for women only.

title: The Wait On Death Row;   Legal Delays Thwart Death Penalty

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about abortion laws in East and West Germany referred incorrectly to the West's law. If two doctors certify that the pregnancy resulted from rape or causes great physical or emotional distress to the mother, abortion is permitted through the 12th week of pregnancy, not the 22d. Abortion is permitted through the 22d week in the case of severe genetic damage to the fetus, and at any time in an emergency involving the mother's health.

title: Casey Joins Celtic Staff
description: Don Casey, who was dismissed as head coach of the Los Angeles Clippers after last season, was hired yesterday as an assistant coach of the Boston Celtics. Casey, 53, joins the staff of Chris Ford, the former Celtic assistant who is taking over after the dismissal of Jimmy Rodgers.(AP)

title: Mr. Justice Brennan
description: It was only gradually, in the 1960's, that observers of the Supreme Court came to understand the influence of William J. Brennan Jr. When he retired last week, everyone knew. One student of the Court put it: ''He is the great expositor of modern constitutional law.''

title: Goodwill Games Losses
description: The Goodwill Games are creating losses of double the original estimate for Turner Broadcasting System Inc., Ted Turner told stockholders today, raising questions about the future of the competition. This year's games are likely to produce a loss in the same range as the $26 million from the inaugural 1986 Goodwill Games in Moscow, Mr. Turner said at the company's annual meeting here, where the games are being held.

Year-ago quarter and 6 months reflected an after-tax gain of $2.1 million, or 11 cents a share, from the disposition of a defense unit.

description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday switched the advertising account for Puritan oil from Grey Advertising to Ayer. Grey remains the agency for the company's Crisco shortening and oil products.

description: The Cuomo administration is ''burning the furniture for firewood'' by borrowing extensively, using one-time revenues to fill budget gaps and dipping into state reserve funds, Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor, said yesterday.

description: By trying to call Peter Ueberroth and Fay Vincent to testify at a reopened hearing, George Steinbrenner's attorneys were hoping to minimize any potential penalty by establishing that baseball had known about his relationship with Howard Spira and tacitly condoned it.

title: U.S. Tops Puerto Rico In Fight-Marred Game

title: Benefit Plan for N.B.A.

David Stern, the league's commissioner, said the program would be submitted for approval to the Federal District Court in New Jersey that oversees an antitrust agreement between the players and the league.

title: Power, at a Price
description: THE Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston, considered the technological leader in the personal computer business, has introduced two new computers that once again extend the definition of desktop power. Naturally, they also extend the price range as well.

title: New NCNB Notes Will Yield 10.2%
description: The NCNB Corporation offered $200 million of subordinated debentures yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Philharmonic in New-Music 'Horizons'
description: The New York Philharmonic will rehearse and then perform six new orchestral works during ''Horizons '90: New Music for Orchestra,'' to take place this week at Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 133d Street. Lawrence Leighton Smith, the music director of the Louisville Orchestra, will lead the orchestra in four open rehearsals tomorrow and Thursday, followed by a performance of the six works on Friday.

title: Campeau Granted Assets Extension
description: The Campeau Corporation said in Toronto that the Edward J. DeBartolo Company, a major American shopping-mall developer, has extended until Aug. 6 a stand-still agreement under which DeBartolo will not seize any Campeau assets without first providing nine days' notice. Campeau, a Canadian developer, owns the Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores Corporation, two American retail chains.

title: Market Place;   Wall St. Volatility Reflects Larger Economic Worries
description: A sharp fall in stock prices yesterday reflected growing worries over the health of the economy, especially the erosion of corporate profits, as well as a stock market that has grown increasingly fragile, some traders and analysts say.

title: Augat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chronicle
description: ALLISON ATLAS'sS search for a perfectly matched bone marrow donor has inspired 50,000 people in the United States and Israel to roll up their sleeves for blood tests. Although 10 patients have found donors because of the Atlas family's search, no such match has been found for the 20-year-old woman leukemia sufferer from Bethesda, Md., who has leukemia. In 10 days Miss Atlas is to receive an imperfectly matched transplant from her mother, ARLINE ATLAS, who was always considered a fallback, a spokesman for the family said yesterday.

title: Navy Suspends a Plan to Use Dolphins as Guards
description: Under mounting legal pressure from animal rights groups, the Navy has suspended its plan to use bottle-nosed dolphins to guard a nuclear submarine base.

title: The President Proposes

With impressive speed, President Bush has chosen his nominee to fill the Supreme Court vacancy created by Justice William Brennan's retirement. He believes that the public and the Senate will be impressed by the intellect, credentials and judicious fairness of David Souter. But he rightly acknowledges the Senate's right, indeed duty, to examine the nomination with the greatest care.

title: Paris Heat: Versace and Lacroix Open the Fall Shows
description: The haute couture shows opened with a blast of prints and color over the weekend. Gianni Versace set the stage for a sizzling display of fall fashions with minuscule outfits in fiery prints that barely covered the torso. Skirts that reached finger-tip level were on the long side. Except for the fairly elaborate swags and jewels, the ball gowns could have passed as swimsuits.

title: Truck Kills 3 Workers on I-95
description: Three highway workers were killed this morning when a flatbed truck rammed into two parked construction vehicles and a group of workers on the shoulder of southbound Interstate 95. The truck crossed into the right lane of the three-lane highway just after it had been closed so workers from AMI Industries of Meriden could repair guard rails, a state police spokesman said. Three AMI employees were killed. The truck driver, who was charged with misconduct with a motor vehicle, and two other employees were injured. The 9:50 A.M. accident forced the closing of southbound I-95 for more than five and a half hours, and northbound vehicles were backed up for over a mile.

title: The New York That's Here to Stay

Furthermore, it's going to be rubble within the next few months because a Japanese developer has something grand in mind for the site. So if anybody wants to see the place where Edith Wharton, nee Jones, made her debut into New York society, he'd better hurry to the corner of 42d Street and Fifth Avenue.

The caption read: ''Twin Piques.'' It was only one of many references. ''Every time I turned around I saw 'Twin Peaks,' '' Mr. Iger said.
