description: b-Included pretax gain of $1.87 million from sale of two banking units. c-Included extraordinary credits of $689,000, or 17 cents a share for the quarter and $1,343,000, or 33 cents a share for the 6 months. The bank said for the latest quarter and 6-month per share excluding the sale, per share earnings would have been 55 cents in the second quarter and $1.06 in the 6 months.

title: Southtrust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Harsco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Included pre-tax provisions of $54 million for the quarter and $58.6 million for the 6 months to cover future losses relating to cost adjustments for certain U.S. defense contracts.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: HEI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge from a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $7,000.

title: Sri Lankans Close to Rebels Quit Parliament
description: Members of a political party considered close to the major Tamil rebel group resigned from Parliament today to protest what they called atrocities by the military in its war against the guerrillas.

title: By Design;   Overalls, When Paris Sizzles
description: More men than one would want to see are sitting in outdoor cafes and strolling around the Left Bank wearing walking shorts and no shirt at all, not even an undershirt. No doubt the extreme heat explains this state of undress, just as it probably does the new street fashion glimpsed on women here.

title: Los Angeles Trolley Derails
description: A train on the new Southern California trolley line derailed Sunday when a four-inch-long metal wire became wedged between tracks, preventing the train from switching smoothly. There were no injuries. The Pico Station, at the downtown end of the 22-mile Long Beach-to-Los Angeles line, was closed for three hours.

title: Article in Pravda Says Anti-Semitism Is Rife
description: Anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union has reached alarming levels and threatens the process of political reform, a Soviet historian said in an article in Pravda on Sunday.

title: Western Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sun Microsystems' New Work Station
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., the leading vendor of engineering work stations, is expected on Wednesday to announce a new computer and an expansion of its distribution to include more personal computer retailers. The moves constitute a continuing effort by Sun, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., to broaden the market for its machines beyond engineers to people in business.

title: Mapco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
James Randall Creel; Judge, 85
description: James Randall Creel, a retired judge of the New York City Criminal Court, died on Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 85 years old and lived in Mill Neck, L.I.

title: Now for the Deeds
description: Everybody is complaining about leadership these days. Anyone who seems to be standing tall is across the border.

title: Communications Satellite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
American Network Group reports earnings for Year to March 31
Health Chief Denounces Agency Over Mishandling of Pap Tests
description: The New York City Health Commissioner denounced his department yesterday for ''outrageous insensitivity'' and ''betrayal of the public trust'' for allowing thousands of cancer tests on poor women to languish unread for up to a year in a city laboratory.

title: Inco Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest periods' results included an after-tax gain of $112.2 million, or $1.08 a share, fom the sale of its 20- percent interest in P.T. International Nickel Indonesia.

title: New Manager of Big Polish Steel Mill Puts His Private Experience to Work
description: The only managerial experience that Zygmunt Borek had to recommend him for a 28,000-employee steel plant was that he once ran a company with 62 employees.

title: Bridge
description: Two experts from the New York metropolitan region entered the Life Master Pair Championship on Friday, the opening event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, because they wanted to practice for the Spingold Knockout Teams competion that began today.

title: Edgard Feder; Music Critic, 81
description: Edgard Feder, a music critic, cellist and conductor, died at his home in Manhattan on Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: Suburban Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Exxon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary provisions for Exxon Valdez accident of $850 million for the quarter and $880 million for the 6 months; the 6 months also included income of $535 million, or 42 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Year-ago periods were restated to reflect adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 96, in the fourth quarter of 1989, retroctive to Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Jury in Child Molesting Case Reaches Verdict on 2 Counts
description: The jury in the McMartin Preschool child- molesting case told the court today that it had reached verdicts on two counts against Raymond Buckey but had deadlocked on the remaining six charges.

title: Chronicle
description: This week's issue of the Argentine newsmagazine Noticias was greeted with dismay and disbelief by politicians and government leaders over the weekend. There, revealingly wrapped in a honey-colored fox coat, with bare legs, was MARIE JULIA ALSOGARAY, who had just presided over the $5 billion privatization of the Argentine telephone company.

title: Review/Jazz;   Jim Cullum's Adventures
description: Jazz in July, the annual festival of ''hot jazz, ragtime, old-time and blues'' at the 92d Street Y began its sixth year last Tuesday evening with a program that emphasized that the series has established its own traditions.

title: No Compromise, Say Civil Rights Bill's Sponsors
description: Leading supporters of the civil rights bill in the House of Representatives said today that they had little interest in negotiating with the White House on changing the bill, which President Bush has threatened to veto.

title: Union Carbide Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest second quarter earnings included a non-recurring gain of 14 cents a share from the sale of the primary alcohol ethoxylates business of Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Co. to Hoechst Celanese Corp. This gain was partially offset by non- recurring charges totaling 6 cents a share representing litigation and other expenses associated with discontinued chemicals and plastics product lines or operations.

title: Scripps Howard Broadcasting Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bell Atlantic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding restated to reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split declared on March 16, 1990.

title: KEY RATES
Meritor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included total charge of $74.5 million from restructuring for both periods, and included in the total restructuring charge was a $337 million gain from the sale of 54 branch offices to Mellon Bank. The periods also included extraordinary losses of $91,000 for the quarter and $27,000 for the 6 months, both from early extinguishment of debt. c-After an extraordinary credit of $2,603,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $4,274,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 6 months, from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Americans Help Czechs Clean Up After the Soviets
description: An American environmental cleanup company is cleaning up the ecological mess left by Soviet military units after they withdrew from a base in northern Czechoslvakia, and two others have concluded contracts for similar work at other installations that Soviet troops are leaving.

title: Giving Sanctuary, Fairly
description: No sooner do refugees from persecution abroad arrive in the United States than, often, they face a maze of inconsistency as they seek asylum. Welcome new rules just issued by the Bush Administration at last promise to make the process more objective and fair.

title: Arrow Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Xerox Shifts To Y.& R. From B.S.B.
description: THE Xerox Corporation has awarded its corporate and product advertising accounts to Young & Rubicam's New York office. Xerox had been reviewing its corporate advertising, but decided to consolidate its estimated $30 million to $40 million media advertising account at Y.& R. The news was another blow for Backer Spielvogel Bates, which had handled the Xerox account since 1986. Recently, the agency lost the $5 million to $10 million Jhirmack hair-care account and the Fisher-Price toy account, which at one point had billed as much as $25 million. Late last year, it lost the $60 million account of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, a client that had been with the agency for 20 years.

title: No Headline
description: The frustrations in the professional life of Chuck Cary can be found in increments of five days, each time he takes the mound for the Yankees. The starting pitcher's cyclical hope of every-fifth-day has come and gone again and again, until now, when the distance between victories can be measured in weeks.

title: VanFed Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $805,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Amerada Hess Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said that corporate charges, including increased interest expense, net of earnings from other operating activities, amounted to $74.1 million in the latest first half, compared with $37.3 million in year- ago period.

title: Mighty Fire Ants March Out of the South
description: IN the annals of entomological villainy, few insects are as despised, as feared and as meticulously investigated as the tiny imported fire ant, which attacks humans, animals, plants, other insects and even electrical devices.

title: Reviews/Dancing;   A Role Debut in 'Ivan'
description: The role of Anastasiya in Yuri Grigorovich's ''Ivan the Terrible'' is rather like a delicate cream filling between two sturdy sandwich slices. The title character moves through the ballet's depiction of 16th-century Russia like a dark and brooding storm. His opponent, Prince Kurbsky, is a powerful warrior and worrier. But Anastasiya, whom is loved by both men, won by Ivan and betrayed by Kurbsky, has chiefly to live up to the standard set by Natalya Bessmertnova, for whom the part was created, a ballerina of pensive sweetness and an effectively languishing, lyrical body line.

title: Washington Talk;   Congress Less Tolerant On Colleagues' Behavior
description: Members of the House and the Senate dislike two things almost equally. One is to comment on each other's ethical behavior. The other is to cast recorded votes on touchy matters.

title: Paper in Dublin Will Automate
description: Ingersoll Publications Ltd. announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with unions at The Irish Press in Dublin that will allow the paper to install computerized typesetting equipment by the end of the year and to take other cost-saving measures.

title: Murder Witness Pleads Guilty in Drug Case
description: Gina Feliciano, a witness in the Bensonhurst murder case, pleaded guilty in Brooklyn yesterday to a misdemeanor charge of possessing cocaine.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Sunday about the dismantling of the Second Armored Division at Fort Hood, Tex., misidentified the vehicles shown. The front-page picture showed M-2 Bradley infantry carriers, and the picture with the continuation showed M-88 tank-towing vehicles.

title: Sir Hamilton Whyte, British Diplomat, 63
description: Sir Hamilton Whyte, a retired member of the British diplomatic service, died on Friday at his home in Ford, Sussex, England. He was 63 years old.

title: Park Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for 1989 are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective September 15, 1989.

title: Forschner Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect a change to the last-in, first-out method of accounting for inventories which resulted in reductions of $105,000 and $208,000 in income before taxes and 2 cents and 3 cents in net income per share from that previously reported under the first-in, first-out method for the quarter and 6-month periods ended June 30, 1989, respectively.

title: Gasoline Prices Steady
description: Gasoline prices, which normally go up this time of the year as more people take to the road on vacations, remained unusually steady during the last two weeks, an industry analyst said Sunday. The average national price for a gallon of gas, including all taxes, was 117.72 cents, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of nearly 13,000 service stations, completed Friday. That's an increase of five-hundredths of a cent over the previous survey of July 6. Wholesale prices rose about a penny a gallon over all in the last two weeks and that could mean prices at the pump will begin to rise soon.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Continental Fare Cuts Set
description: Continental Airlines said today that it was cutting fares by as much as 57 percent for travel during the next three weekends.

title: Viola Crumbles As Mets Lose
description: Monolithic teams like the Mets aren't supposed to lose this way, but tonight they did. And league-leading pitchers like Frank Viola aren't supposed to lose this way, but tonight he did.

title: Amoco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $471 million from the settlement of claims during the quarter of a dispute with Iran. Amoco said the gain of $471 million was offset in the latest quarter by $477 million of provisions for future environmental remediation costs and unfavorable currency effects of $22 million. The gain for the 6 months from the settlement was offset by provisions of $500 million for future environmental remediation and unfavorable foreign currency effects of $28 million. The company also said results for the year-ago 6 months were affected by special charges totaling $93 million.

title: Man Charged in Shooting Hoped to Join Police Force
description: The 22-year-old man charged in the shooting of a 9-year-old Brooklyn girl on Sunday is a former professional baseball player who had returned to his Brooklyn home hoping to become a police officer like his older sister, friends of the man said yesterday.

title: Why Faldo Deserves The Title
description: rrIn the years when Bobby Jones dominated golf, he was known as ''the mechanical man.'' Just wind him up and send him clicking around a course. But if Jones was golf's ''mechanical man,'' Nick Faldo is now its ''computer disk.'' Just program him and point him to the first tee.

title: Philadelphia Electric reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bush Presents Plan to Help Andean Nations Grow Non-Coca Crops
description: President Bush announced trade concessions, expanded agricultural development assistance and other measures to help Ecuador, Colombia, Bolivia and Peru, the main cocaine-producing countries of Latin America, to develop alternative exports.

title: Ukraine's Glittering Hopes
description: The Bank of England has begun searching its dusty archives to see if it can account for a barrel of gold supposedly deposited by a military leader from the Ukraine 270 years ago. Members of the the Soviet republic's new Parliament would like the gold returned.

title: Iraq Deploys Troops Near Kuwait Border Amid Dispute on Oil
description: American military officials are closely watching a new deployment of thousands of troops by Iraq along its border with Kuwait, where recent political tensions appeared to be escalating into armed posturing by the two Persian Gulf nations, Pentagon officials said tonight.

title: Boulevard Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Heart Cancer
description: Q.Does cancer ever develop in the heart?

title: Alimentation Couche-Tard reports earnings for Year to April 29
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $150,000 for the latest year and $270,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Northwest Seeking Deal For Eastern
description: Talks began yesterday to put together a plan for Northwest Airlines to buy a large part of Eastern Airlines while overseeing the liquidation of the rest of its assets for Eastern's unsecured creditors, people close to the negotiations said.

title: John R. Bond; Magazine Publisher, 77
description: John R. Bond, publisher of Road & Track magazine from 1949 to 1972, died Friday at his home here. He was 77 years old. He died of emphysema, family members said. Mr. Bond bought Road & Track, an automobile magazine, with his second wife, Elaine, said his son, John Jr. As publisher, Mr. Bond instituted staples of automotive journalism like the technical road test. In 1954 he wrote ''Sports Cars in Action.''

title: Westport Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Superior Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Bar Exam vs. the Law
description: In ''Rain Man,'' the autistic savant, Raymond Babbitt, played by Dustin Hoffman, could at a glance precisely count the number of toothpicks that had fallen from a box. It is a skill that would serve him well if he were taking the New York State bar examination today and the multistate bar exam tomorrow. The tests are absurd.

title: In Rarity, Utility Seeks Another in Midwest
description: In a move that is rare among utilities, the Kansas City Power and Light Company made a hostile tender offer yesterday for the shares of a neighboring utility, the Kansas Gas and Electric Company. Kansas City Power said the bid was worth $857 million.

title: Altered Models Of Assault Guns Elude U.S. Ban
description: The Bush Administration's ban on military assault-style weapons, criticized as a tepid response to drug-related violence when it took effect last year, has been weakened by a provision that allows redesigned versions of the weapons to be imported.

title: Savings Crisis Panel Sought
description: Three Senators called for the creation of an independent commission last week to investigate the causes of the savings and loan crisis. The Senators, Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri; Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, said they would seek to establish a commission excluding all current members of Congress and the Bush Admiinstration.

title: Southeastern Public Service Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Xilinx Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: The latest quarter represents the company's first quarter as a public company.

title: Marsh & McLennan Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Times Mirror Officer Expected to Head CNN
description: W. Thomas Johnson Jr., the former publisher of The Los Angeles Times and vice chairman of the Times Mirror Company, will soon be named president and chief executive of Cable News Network in Atlanta.

title: Chrysler And Hyundai Venture Off
description: With its domestic market share falling and doubts growing about its long-term viability as an independent car maker, the Chrysler Corporation canceled a small-car venture with Hyundai of South Korea today. The company also confirmed that it would build a low-priced version of its Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance compacts.

title: Beckman Instruments Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Larry Johnson to Stay
description: Larry Johnson, the power forward who helped Nevada-Las Vegas win the national collegiate championship last spring, said yesterday that he would return to play his senior season with the Runnin' Rebels, even though the National Collegiate Athletic Association has barred the team from defending its title. Johnson said, however, that he would have applied for the National Basketball Association draft if he had known the ruling, announced last week, was coming.

title: No-Shows: Taylor Leads Giants' List
description: The Giants opened training camp today with 74 players on hand and 13 absent. The absentees included such key veterans as Lawrence Taylor, Bart Oates, Maurice Carthon, Mark Collins and the entire starting defensive line: Leonard Marshall, Erik Howard and Eric Dorsey.

title: Edwin E. Hokin, 74, A Manufacturer, Dies
description: Edwin E. Hokin, retired chairman and chief executive officer of UNR Industries, died Thursday at his home in Chicago at the age of 74.

title: Stoneridge Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included charges incurred by the company's 52 percent-owned subsidiary, Orange-co Inc., aggregating $1.2 million and $4.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Martinez and Expos Shut Out the Pirates by 5-0
description: Dennis Martinez pitched a four-hitter and Tim Wallach drove in four runs, leading the Montreal Expos past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-0, tonight.

title: BHA Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Albany International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings included a gain of 10 cents on sale of real property in Sweden.

title: Prof. James D. Hart Is Dead at 76; Chronicled America's Literature
description: James D. Hart, a literary scholar who was a professor at the University of California at Berkeley for 54 years, died yesterday at his home in Berkeley at the age of 79. His family said he died of a brain tumor.

title: Rift Over Water On Indian Land Has Deep Roots
description: From the edge of this Hopi Indian village on the rim of the Third Mesa, with hot white sky and parched high desert as far as the eye can see, the splash of cool water can be heard.

title: Count of Oil Rigs Rises
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States increased by 21 this week to 1,022, according to Baker Hughes Inc., a maker of oil drilling equipment. This week's increase reversed a series of declines, including a drop of 10 rigs last week. A year ago, the count was 830. New Mexico's rig count was down by six, Louisiana lost four rigs and North Dakota dropped one rig. Texas, Pennsylvania and Ohio each gained three rigs.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

New Assignments At General Dynamics
description: LEAD: A week after recording a heavy loss on its Navy fighter jet program, the General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday that it was dispatching the company's president to Texas to help resolve the problems in that program.

title: Time Warner Reports A Loss of $189 Million
description: Time Warner Inc. yesterday reported a net loss of $189 million for the second quarter. If Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. had been merged at this time last year, the company would have reported a comparable loss. The company's revenues for the quarter rose by 4.4 percent, to $2.58 billion, from $2.47 billion in the previous quarter.

title: Oregon Metallurgical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $1,157,000, or 12 cents a share. For the 1989 periods, the interest on tax refunds reflected income before cumulative effect of accounting adjustment comprising of after-tax earnings from ongoing operations of $3,703,000, or 40 cents a share, and $1,342,000, or 14 cents a share, after- tax income from interest earned on tax refunds for the year-ago quarter; and $6,420,000 or 70 cents a share, and $12,412,000, or $1.33 a share, after-tax income from interest earned on tax refunds for the year-ago 6 months.

title: Alfa Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Solar Particle That Wasn't There Offers Enticing Clues to the Cosmos
description: A HIGHLY sensitive Soviet-American detector operating deep in a mine in the Caucasus region since the first of the year has failed to find any of the ghostly solar particles it sought, but scientists are more excited than disappointed.

title: Review/Theater;   Finley Mocks Her Critics In Her Art
description: Early in her powerful one-woman show, ''We Keep Our Victims Ready,'' Karen Finley mocks conservative critics who have denounced her work as obscene by offering her own satirical portrait of an American cultural landscape stripped bare by arts censorship.

title: Lone Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $1.8 million for the 6 months.

title: Judean Cave City Yields Trove of Ancient Secrets
description: THOUSANDS of people moved to this boulder-strewn meadow between the eighth and first centuries B.C. partly because of its proximity to trade routes. But the Biblical town of Maresha had another attraction, too: as much as anything else, it flourished because of its caves, hundreds of elaborate caverns forming an underground city that generations of dwellers carved out of the soft limestone just a foot or two beneath the surface.

title: Hartford Steam Boiler InspecFtion & Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Accor Is Gambling on U.S. Motels
description: The $1.3 billion deal by the French hotel and restaurant company Accor S.A. to purchase Motel 6, the Dallas-based chain of economy motels, may be the boldest move yet by two executives already known for their boldness and management skills.

title: Cytogen Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Minnesota Mining & Mfg reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reich & Tang reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Revolution as the Bolshoi Meets Capitalism
description: ''I'm the bandit who sold out the Bolshoi Theater,'' Vladimir Kokonin, the 52-year-old general director of Moscow's grand opera house, said in New York the other day. Just joking, of course, he added.

title: Closing the Chapter on Easy Goer
description: Imagine, for a moment, Easy Goer in a world without Sunday Silence.

title: Isabelle Liberman, 71, Authority on Dyslexia
description: Dr. Isabelle Liberman, an authority on reading disabilities who taught for 21 years at the University of Connecticut, died on Thursday at her home in Mansfield Center, Conn. She was 71 years old. Her family said she died of heart failure. Dr. Liberman wrote widely on dyslexia, and at her death she was a research associate at the Haskins Laboratories in New Haven, which is associated with Yale and the University of Connecticut.

title: Bemis Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Florida Prepares For Its Defense
description: The University of Florida has acknowledged six major rules violations during a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation but has disputed an allegation that the infractions demonstrated a lack of institutional control of the school's football and basketball programs.

title: Steel Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $250,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: INVESTMENT LINKS FORMER BUSH AIDE TO F.D.I.C. OFFICIAL
description: Two years after he helped buy an insolvent Oklahoma bank from Federal regulators, a former aide to George Bush invested $100,000 with a Federal official involved in negotiating the bank deal, according to public records and participants in the deal.

title: Soviet Is Said to Defect
description: Sergei Fedorov, a center for the Soviet national hockey squad that is participating in the Goodwill Games, has reportedly left the team to join the Red Wings of the National Hockey League.

title: RJR Nabisco's Parent Posts $108 Million Loss for Quarter
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the parent of the tobacco-and-food giant that recently refinanced part of history's largest leveraged buyout, yesterday announced a loss of $108 million for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $319 million in the comparable period last year. The improved performance exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Allies in Southeast Asia Criticize Washington's Shift on Cambodia
description: America's allies in Southeast Asia criticized Washington today for its shift in Cambodia policy, saying that without further progress toward peace they would work to keep Cambodia's seat at the United Nations in the possession of the current owners, the Khmer Rouge and their two guerrilla coalition partners.

title: Reviews/Ballet;   Departures Of Style In Bolshoi 'Highlights'
description: The Bolshoi Ballet presented a disappointing afternoon of dance in its ''Highlights'' program on Saturday at the New York State Theater. Part of the problem seemed to be a sticky floor that tripped more than one dancer and may have been responsible for some of the messy interstitial phrasing. But in general the dancers looked unduly second-rate.

title: New York City Needs Strategic Planning to Keep From Drifting
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers Trust N.Y.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Centel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $842,000 for the quarter and $3,183,000 for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3,403,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $7,428,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: NAVAJOS' LEADER IS ON TRIAL TODAY
description: After four postponements since January, the first of three fraud trials in a Navajo court will begin Tuesday for the suspended leader of the nation's largest Indian tribe.

title: Women Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: Burrell Edges Lewis in Goodwill 100 Meters
description: The world's fastest human of last year and this year proved again tonight that it's not Carl Lewis.

title: Talking Business; with Mooney of Cable TV Association;   Doubtful Outlook On Re-regulation
description: James P. Mooney is president and chief executive of the National Cable Television Association, a lobbying group for the industry. In 1984, he and his organization helped to insure passage of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, which allowed cable companies to set their own charges for basic cable service.

title: IBP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nathaniel Field; Accountant, 84
description: Nathaniel Field, a certified public accountant in Manhattan, died on Thursday in Providence Hospital in Anchorage. He was 84 years old.

title: Scientists and Planners Consider New Limits To Coastal Development
description: GROWING evidence that coastal erosion occurs continuously, not just in calamitous bursts like Hurricane Hugo, has led scientists, planners and some Federal disaster officials to urge a stringent new approach to limiting development along the nation's shoreline. Their campaign is opposed by many builders, property owners and others with a financial or political stake on the coast.

title: Natec Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ethics Inquiry Is Sought On Metzenbaum and Staff
description: The Senate Ethics Committee was asked today to open an inquiry into the conduct of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum and his staff on the Judiciary Committee in their investigation of specific savings and loan deals.

title: Harry Prebluda Dies; Biochemist Was 79
description: Harry J. Prebluda, a biochemist and consultant, died Saturday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 79 years old and moved to Miami Beach from Trenton 10 years ago.

title: House Votes to Bolster Enforcement by S.E.C.
description: The House of Representatives unanimously approved a measure today to broaden and strengthen the enforcement powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Greyhound Dial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $100 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The discontinued operations reflected the operations of Greyhound Bus Lines, which filed for bankruptcy protection on June 4, as a result of a work stoppage which began on March 1.

title: Asarco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Avemco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

McMillan Surprises Jets By Staying Out of Camp
description: Erik McMillan, the Jets' All-Pro safety, single-handedly doubled the number of veteran holdouts by not reporting for the opening day of training camp today.

title: NFS Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Maxxam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Independent Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rockefeller Foundation Starts Ecology Effort
description: THE Rockefeller Foundation is undertaking a $50 million global environmental program with the ambitious aim of curbing ecologically damaging practices of industrial and poor countries.

title: Gastineau on Waivers
description: Mark Gastineau, the former Jet defensive end who signed with the British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League on June 13, was placed on waivers yesterday, the club said in Vancouver.

title: Corrections
description: The Metropolitan Almanac section of the Weather Report last Tuesday misstated the year of the record high temperature for July 16. It was 1980, not 1989.

title: Noriega's Troops Now Form Police With U.S. Aid, Panamanians Say
description: Miguel Antonio Bernal, a respected Panamanian scholar and social critic, was eating dinner with friends recently in a restaurant when his companions noticed a man they recognized as their torturer during their detention under Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Nature Switches Roles For the Mating Game
description: STEREOTYPED though the behavior may seem, in most species it is the female animal who is the finicky one, and the males who vie with each other to attract her favors. Now researchers have found that, among katydids and crickets, nature's normal gender roles are sometimes reversed, with the male standing by as two or more female suitors rear up in a pitched battle for his affection.

title: Preaching to Brazil From Hawaii
description: Americans lecture Brazil on the shameless destruction of its tropical forests. They would sound less sanctimonious if the United States took better care of its own tropical forests, in Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF

title: Lubrizol Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: In an innovative financing, the Chrysler Financial Corporation offered $35 million worth of tax-exempt asset-backed securities late last week through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Detective Says He Tricked Jogger Suspect
description: A New York City police detective testified yesterday that he tricked one of the defendants in the Central Park jogger trial into confessing.

title: Regional Split in Cystic Fibrosis
description: Scientists who are studying the gene that causes cystic fibrosis, the most common hereditary illness among Caucasians, have found a link between a particular mutation in the gene and the severity of the illness. They said today that the severe form of the mutation is most prevalent in northern European countries like the Scandinavian nations, Germany and Holland and among people with northern European heritage.

title: Crackdown Set on Vans Serving as Gypsy Buses
description: They often use the same route numbers as city buses, stop at the same bus stops and charge discount fares - only $1, not the $1.15 that Transit Authority riders have been paying since January.

title: Exco Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Engineers Battle to Restart Pump to Halt Sewage Flow
description: Millions of gallons of raw sewage continued to flow into New York's rivers yesterday as engineers struggled to restart a giant pump needed to process all the waste received by the city's second-largest treatment plant.

description: Citing eroding construction-related markets, the Manville Corporation today reported second-quarter earnings of $52.6 million, or 41 cents a share, down 24 percent from $69.4 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier.

description: The Education Department said today that it would try to resolve a financial crisis at one of the nation's largest guarantors of student loans.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 15 about a resurgence in tuberculosis referred incorrectly to an assistant professor of medicine at Yale University. He is Dr. Lloyd Friedman.

title: Strife Holds Fast in Kashmir As 24 Are Killed in 24 Hours
description: Secessionist violence in Kashmir killed at least 24 people in a 24-hour period, the police said today.

Time Warner Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Time Warner accounted for its acquisition of a 59.3 percent common stock interest in Warner Communications Inc. as of July 31, 1989 and for its acquisition on Jan. 10, 1990 of the remaining capital stock of WCI as of Dec. 31, 1989 using the purchase method of accounting. The historical operating results of Time Warner for year-ago periods are supplemented by pro forma operating results which give effect to the acquisition of 100 percent of WCI as if it had occurred on Jan. 1, 1989. The pro forma results are presented for informational purposes only and are not necessarily indicative of the operating results that would have occurred had the acquisition been consummated on Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Chronicle
description: MARILYN QUAYLE is ''doing well at Bethesda Naval Hospital'' after weekend surgery, DAVID BECKWITH, a spokesman for Vice President DAN QUAYLE, said yesterday, adding, ''We expect her to return home sometime this week.'' The spokesman said the family did not want to disclose the type of operations, but published published reports have said it was for cervical cancer.

title: Review/Pop;   Musical Technology for Maximum Shock
description: The Wax Trax record label show at the Ritz last Tuesday night ground to a close with the appearance of M.C. 900-Foot Jesus and the final act, Thrill Kill Kult. Wax Trax, a Chicago-based label that often records groups loosely fitting under the title of industrial dance music, promotes music that has an ambivalance about modernity. At once using modern technology - both bands used just two musicians to create a full background for their vocalists - there was palpable feeling of dismay over the political and cultural mess the 20th century has become.

title: Comments by President On His Choice of Justice
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, when he announced the appointment of Judge David H. Souter as Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, as recorded by The New York Times through the facitilties of Cable News Network:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amtech Systems Inc., Tempe, Ariz., a maker of semiconductor equipment, said negotiations for the planned acquisition of Tystar Corp., , had ended because of the weak condition of the semiconductor equipment market.

title: Chess
description: Tournament competitors may be divided into two types: the front runners, who must have everything go right from the beginning if they are to triumph, and the resilient ones, who win despite an early setback. The 21-year-old Soviet grandmaster Vassily Ivanchuk belongs to the second group.

title: Stanley Shapiro, 65; 'Pillow Talk' Script Won Him an Oscar
description: Stanley Shapiro, a screen writer who won an Academy Award for ''Pillow Talk,'' a romantic comedy starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson, died on Saturday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here. He was 65 years old.

title: Compaq Offering 2 New Computers
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation introduced two high-end personal computers, the Compaq Deskpro 486/ 33L and Compaq Deskpro 386/33L, priced between $9,999 and $19,499 depending on configuration. It also announced a 486-based version of its Systempro line priced between $20,999 and $29,999. The computers, which approach the performance levels of engineering work stations and minicomputers, may be difficult for personal computer retailers to sell effectively, analysts said.

title: Ashland Oil Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Crown American Founder Moves Son to Key Post
description: Frank J. Pasquerilla, who built a small masonry contracting business into a large real estate company, the Crown American Corporation, is relinquishing more responsibility to his 31-year-old son, Mark E. Pasquerilla.

description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,374,000 and $5,942,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago results included one-time after-tax charge of $32.7 million to comply with environmental regulations.

title: Museum to Display Caribbean Costumes
description: More than 30 costumes and 20 masks used in religious celebrations by the multi-ethnic population of the Caribbean islands make up a traveling exhibition that is to open on Sept. 7 at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, in the Crown Heights section.

title: Senators Urge Compromise On Bill to Control Futures
description: In the face of heavy opposition from the futures industry, senators concerned about the possibility of another stock market collapse said today that a compromise was needed in the bitter battle over legislation to reform Federal regulation over the nation's financial markets.

title: Warning: Some of This Live Concert Isn't;   Consumer Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants to Give Guyton A Bigger Responsibility
description: One year and one day ago, the Giants waived Kenny Hill, their veteran strong safety, and gave the job to Greg Jackson, a rookie. In the season opener against the Washington Redskins, when Jackson was fooled on a play-action pass and gave up a 48-yard touchdown to Ricky Sanders, he lost the job to another rookie, Myron Guyton.

title: Tambrands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: America's allies in Southeast Asia today bitterly criticized Washington's policies on Indochina and refugees as inconsistent and counterproductive.

description: President Bush may get a third chance to appoint a member of the Federal Reserve Board if Martha R. Seger resigns.

U.S. Deploys Air and Sea Forces After Iraq Threatens 2 Neighbors
description: The United States has dispatched two aerial refueling planes to the United Arab Emirates and sent combat ships to sea in a rare exercise with the Persian Gulf nation after Iraqi threats to use military force against the Emirates and Kuwait, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: 4 Traders Are Charged
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission charged today that four traders on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange engaged in a conspiracy to use their advance knowledge of customer orders to make illegal profits.

title: Judging Barney Frank
description: Barney Frank, a bright, articulate and productive Congressman, has committed serious indiscretions in his personal dealings with a male prostitute. By his own admission he deserves the reprimand that the House Ethics Committee has proposed to the full House.

description: b-Included income of $23 million, or 16 cents a share, relating to Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc.'s business interruption insurance settlement.

title: Lawmakers Ask Broader Inquiry On Reagan's Housing Secretary
description: A House panel asked a special prosecutor today to broaden his investigation of former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. to determine whether Mr. Pierce illegally steered Government-related business to his former law firm.

An Investment Adviser Becomes a Private Bank
description: Morris W. Offit has a new bank named after him, the Offitbank.

description: A day after President Bush announced his choice of David H. Souter for the Supreme Court, a sharp dispute broke out today in Congress and among interest groups over how far the Senate should go in eliciting his position on abortion.

title: Schwab Agrees to Censure
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage firm, said on Monday that a hearing panel of the New York Stock Exchange had approved a settlement resolving a review of unauthorized trading of customer shares by Schwab's reorganization department. A separate review by the Securities and Exchange Commission has not been completed.

title: BRIEFS

description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, provided little hope today to politicians who want to see interest rates lowered and bank regulations eased.

description: When Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, moved earlier this month to challenge President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's monopoly of the Government banking system, it seemed that the two leaders were headed for their first high-stakes confrontation.

title: 3 Going to Trial Accused of Flying Jetliner Under Alcohol's Influence
description: In a case that is being watched closely by aviation experts and safety groups, three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying a commercial jet while under the influence of alcohol go on trial in Federal District Court in Minneapolis today. It is the first time that criminal charges have been brought against airline pilots for drunken flying, and the aviation industry is eager to see what precedent the court sets.

title: Lawyer's Questions in Jogger Trial Appear to Hurt Client
description: A defense lawyer in the Central Park jogger trial inadvertently elicited testimony from a prosecution witness yesterday that added incriminating details to the confession introduced by the prosecution.

description: Mongolians apparently have handed their Communist rulers a comfortable victory in the vast Central Asian nation's first free elections, according to results from first-round voting announced today.

description: A Parrot Without a Name

description: The trial of Peter MacDonald, the suspended chairman of the Navajo Tribe, was delayed again today after the Navajo Supreme Court ordered a review of his legal representation.

title: I.B.M. Stops Ads For P.G.A Event
description: I.B.M. will not broadcast television advertisements during the P.G.A. Championship next month because of racial exclusion at Shoal Creek Country Club, site of the golf tournament. A spokeswoman, Gina Chew-Holman, said today that when the corporation learned of the racial issue, ''we decided it would not be an appropriate vehicle for our advertising.''

Partially offsetting these benefits was a provision of $112 million for future environmental clean-up costs at certain U.S. locations; the 6 months also included a tax charge in international marketing and refining of $28 million. c-Included a $140 million loss on the sale of business operations in southern Africa.

description: When lawyers assess a candidate for the Supreme Court, they generally make comparisons to known judicial quantities. That is how the lawyers of New Hampshire are describing Judge David H. Souter, whom they have followed from private practice in Concord to the State Attorney General's office to the state and Federal bench.

title: Boots and Saddles For a New Breed
description: THE American love affair with the horse, born on the frontier and branded on the national psyche by movies and television, is thriving in the gentrified enclaves of horse shows, equestrian arenas, exclusive estates and the suburban settings of backyards.

Pact Reached To Save Water In New York
description: New York City, threatened with a state ban on all new building in a third of Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn and Queens because sewage treatment in those areas is inadequate, has agreed to enforce far-reaching water conservation measures.

description: Reflecting the 1989 periods, the company said because the transaction combining Marion Laboratories Inc. with Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc. to create Marion Merrell Dow was not completed until December 1989, standard accounting practices require that it compare its performance for the quarter just ended and for the first half of the current business year with that reported by Marion for the comparable periods a year ago.

title: Giving Polystyrene Another Chance
description: The machinery is deafening, the floors are messy, and the pungent air is thick with flies on a summer day inside the Plastics Again polystyrene recycling plant here, an hour's drive west of Boston. But the scene is enough to delight a plastic manufacturer.

L.P. and a gain of $3.5 million on sale of a stainless steel pipe and tubing plant. c-Net income and after a loss of $45 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months; both periods also included a gain of $112.3 million on sale of Eastern Steel division to a limited partnership, and a gain of $15 million for a favorable ruling on certain foreign export commitments, partly offset by a restructuring charge of $40.4 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He would be technically conservative, but not ideologically conservative, not like a Scalia.

title: Chrysler Offering
description: The Chrysler Auto Receivables Company offered $1 billion worth of securities backed by retail installment contracts on new or used autos and light trucks through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 8 3/4 percent securities, which have a final maturity of Aug. 15, 1995, were priced at $99.718, to yield 8.856 percent, which is 77 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the when-issued two-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The expected final maturity for the asset-backed securities is July 15, 1993. Ratings of AAA are expected from Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: TO many hot-dog aficionados, derring-do consists of slathering a dog with chili and cheese. Now consider how the counter staff serves hot dogs at the Wieners Circle, a stand on Chicago's North Side:

title: For Cable Watchers Only
description: Fans in the New York area who want to watch Nolan Ryan go for his 300th victory when his Texas Rangers take on the Yankees in Texas at 8:30 tonight are out of luck if they don't have cable or an accommodating friend or a handy bar that does.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RYAN CROCKER, a career diplomat with wide Middle East experience, has been named by PRESIDENT BUSH to be Ambassador to Lebanon, the White House announced yesterday. If he is confirmed by the Senate, the 41-year old diplomat would be one of the youngest American ambassadors, although he will not be heading for Beirut for a while.

title: Sears Reports a 29% Drop In Earnings for 2d Quarter
description: As it said it would several weeks ago, Sears, Roebuck & Company today reported disappointing second-quarter earnings, making already skeptical analysts even more concerned about the company's future.

title: RPM Inc. reports earnings for Year to May 31
Bush's Court Choice;   The Judge Speaks: Excerpts From Souter's Decisions in New Hampshire
description: In his seven years as an Associate Justice of the New Hampshire Supreme Court, David H. Souter wrote opinions in a wide variety of legal cases. Two months ago, he became a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, but has not yet written any opinions for that court. Here are excerpts from some of his New Hampshire rulings.

title: Electric Chair Tested on Vat of Water
description: Using a metal strainer, a pipe and a vat of salty water to simulate a human body, an independent expert has tested Florida's electric chair and declared that it works effectively.

title: Net Plunges At Two Big Brokerages
description: Reflecting the slump on Wall Street, two of the largest investment houses, the Morgan Stanley Group and Salomon Inc., reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were down sharply from the comparable period last year.

title: Review/Ballet;   An Australian 'Giselle' With the Fervor of Youth
description: By the time the Australian Ballet ended its opening night on Monday with a fiercely dramatic version of ''Giselle,'' the audience in the Metropolitan Opera House was beside itself, happily infected with the fervor that had wafted so wonderfully across from the dancers.

title: Eddie Quillan, Actor, 83
description: Eddie Quillan, an actor who played young heroes and boys next door in some of Hollywood's most memorable motion pictures, died here on Thursday. He was 83 years old.

title: INFECTED SURGEONS POSE LOW AIDS RISK
description: A surgeon with AIDS who operated on thousands of people apparently did not infect any of them with the AIDS virus, a study has found, suggesting that patients face a minimal risk of contracting the disease from such exposure.

title: Treasury Securities Fall Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell slightly and interest rates inched higher in light trading yesterday.

description: GOLF

title: Ryder System reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
60-Minute Gourmet
description: CHICKEN livers are not only among the most inexpensive meats, but they also are one of the most versatile. They can be used in stuffings, sauces, pates, terrines, in rice dishes and in scores of main courses. One of my favorite preparations calls for simply dipping the livers in seasoned flour and then cooking them in oil until crisp and browned. They are then served in a sauce of a dry red wine, chopped vegetables and seasonings.

title: McMillan Shows Up at Jets' Training Camp
description: Erik McMillan, the All-Pro free safety who was unexpectedly absent when the Jets' training camp opened on Monday, unexpectedly showed up late this afternoon.

title: Review/Fashion;   Montana Wins Paris Over With Clean Lanvin Look
description: Everybody loves a hero, especially one who has fallen and redeemed himself. So Claude Montana received wave after wave of applause as he walked down the runway this afternoon at the Palais de Chaillot after showing his second couture collection for the House of Lanvin. His first show for the house, in January, was a disaster.

title: Unit of Nynex Denies Overpayments Charge
description: Denying charges by New York Attorney General Robert Abrams and others, the New York Telephone Company said yesterday that its review of purchasing practices from 1984 to 1988 had found no evidence of financial improprieties.

title: CMS Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
O'Sullivan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Secret Memos by Police Are Sought
description: Two months after the discovery of confidential New York City police memorandums that defense lawyers say could lead to the reversal of scores of convictions, prosecutors are still culling through the cases behind closed doors and defense lawyers are clamoring for a list of the defendants.

title: At Last, Medicine Really Listens to van Gogh
description: A medical report being published today contends that Vincent van Gogh was not mad and did not have epilepsy, as has been speculated, but had a painful inner ear disorder that caused him to cut off his left ear and eventually to kill himself.

title: Bavaro's Knee Passes a Test
description: Mark Bavaro, who underwent ligament surgery on his left knee in January, went through his first contact work today at the Giants' training camp. Bavaro took several hits on the knee during the morning practice, and afterward he and Coach Bill Parcells were happy.

title: Seagate Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods included the operations of Imprimis Technology from the date of acquisition by Seagate. The acquisition has been treated as a purchase for accounting purposes.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: NEARLY every weekend Jordan Monkarsh begs, cajoles and even yells at people wandering along the boardwalk in this Los Angeles resort community, to get them to try the sausage from his stand, Jody Maroni's Sausage Kingdom.

title: Recruit Case Sentencing
description: The 80-year-old former chairman of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation could face a jail sentence in the Recruit Company stock scandal, Japanese news reports said today.

title: Rangers Sign Center
description: General Manager Neil Smith of the Rangers announced yesterday the signing of Ross Fitzpatrick, a 29-year-old free-agent center who played last season with Hershey of the American Hockey League, where he registered a league-high 58 assists and finished second in scoring with 103 points. He had been in the Philadelphia organization since 1982.

title: Reuters Net Rises by 27%
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the British news agency and financial information services group, said today that its earnings jumped 27 percent in the first half of the year, helped by strong sales in all big markets, particularly Europe.

title: Critic's Notebook;   English Theater Quick on Political Trigger
description: In the 1970's, during the heyday of the Joint Stock Company and other politically inclined theatrical organizations, English playwrights like Caryl Churchill, David Hare and Howard Brenton often reacted immediately to public issues. Faced with urgent political questions, the writers reached for their quill cudgels.

title: Hearty Food in an Idaho Cabin
description: THE log cabin lodge looked like a set from the back lot of a Hollywood studio shooting an old western.

title: OPEC Meets Today; Talks Are Clouded by Iraq's Threat to Kuwait
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are to begin a meeting in Geneva on Wednesday in the shadow of an Iraqi threat to use military force against Kuwait.

title: Plan for Fee At Airports Is Scrapped
description: American Airlines Inc. today withdrew plans to add surcharges of $1 to $4 at five airports that the carrier said were charging ''exorbitant and intolerable'' landing fees.

title: Book Notes
description: Of Shevardnadzi

title: Cooper Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest periods' results included Cameron Iron Works Inc., which Cooper acquired Nov. 29, 1989.

title: U.N. Relief Ship Is Recalled As Ethiopia Rebels Hold Port
description: Facing opposition from Ethiopian rebels, the United Nations abandoned efforts today to reopen an Ethiopian port through which it hoped to ferry food for about 4 million people at risk of starvation.

title: Sold! For $2.9 Million
description: A half-brother to Summer Squall, the 1990 Preakness Stakes winner, brought a top price of $2.9 million yesterday at the Keeneland July Selected Yearling Sale at Lexington, Ky. The bay colt by Seattle Slew out of Weekend Surprise was purchased by BBA (Ireland) for Tomonori Tsurumaki of Japan. The colt, consigned by Lane's End Farm near Versailles, will stay in America to race, said Noel O'Callaghan, a BBA director who signed for the colt. D. Wayne Lukas paid the second-highest price of the session, bidding $2.1 million for a chestnut filly by Secretariat out of Crimson Saint. During the session, 121 horses were sold for $47,895,000. The two-day sale totaled $82,370,000 for 234 horses, an average of $352,009.(AP)

title: Girl, 9, Hit by Stray Bullet, Dies; Suspect Offers a Not-Guilty Plea
description: A 9-year-old girl from Brooklyn died early yesterday, two days after being struck in the head by a stray bullet as she slept in her family's car after an outing at an amusement park.

title: Unions Prepare Boycott Against The Daily News
description: Labor leaders at The Daily News announced yesterday that they would organize an ''all-fronts boycott'' against the newspaper.

title: Irving Rosenthal, Insurance Executive, 82
description: Irving Rosenthal, a retired executive vice president of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Economic Scene;   Sticky Traffic, Slick Fixes
description: FRESH from their triumphs in Eastern Europe, free-market economists are pushing market solutions for problems closer to home. Markets are being touted as the most efficient way to save wildlife, improve public education and reduce acid rain. Could they also be used to tame the scourge of America's city-sprawls: the rush-hour traffic jam?

title: COMMITTEE PASSES A GUN RESTRICTION
description: The House Judiciary Committee approved legislation today to require a seven-day waiting period to buy a handgun.

title: Gingerly, Dow Gains 17.82 Back
description: Despite heavy program selling, stock prices recovered some ground yesterday in strong trading. But many investors remained cautious in the wake of Monday's big selloff.

description: In most American towns being a former bootlegger, smuggler, mercenary, gunrunner, gambler, saloonkeeper and womanizer would not, perhaps, be among the best credentials to become mayor.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Accounting Groups Split on Rule-Making
description: In a defiant challenge to the authority of the Financial Accounting Standards Board to set accounting policy, the leading professional group of accountants has alerted the board that it plans to consult the board's experts less often and that it may issue its own rules, even when the board staunchly opposes them.

title: A Captain 'On Stage' At Tables
description: LIKE so many people in his generation, Paul McLaughlin, a 30-year-old from Brooklyn, started waiting on tables as a way to make money while he was in college. ''I never took it seriously,'' Mr. McLaughlin said. ''My entire family is involved in investment banking.''

title: John Benedict, 57, An Editor of Poetry And of Anthologies
description: John G. Benedict, an editor and director of W. W. Norton & Company, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 57 years old.

description: b-Included special credits of $58 million for the quarter and $64 million for the 6 months. c-After special charges of $11 million for both periods.

description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation today reported a second-quarter loss of $11.2 million, compared with a loss of $5.2 million in the period a year earlier.

description: Robots have cleaned up nuclear power plants, assembled electronic devices and painted cars, but are they ready for one of mankind's oldest jobs - milking cows?

description: b-After a loss of $400,000 for the quarter and income of $29.6 million, or 61 cents a share, for the 6 months, both fom discontinued operations.

description: Economists, demographers and city planners say the population of New York City has continued to grow and is now larger than ever - 8 million - an assertion that challenges official estimates, demographic trends and conventional wisdom.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Election Dispute Splits East German Coalition
description: East Germany's three-month-old coalition Government lost its smallest partner today over the question of how to conduct the Dec. 2 all-German elections that will be the country's last official act.

title: 3 Are Hurt in Motel Explosion And Fire on New Jersey Shore
description: Three men were injured, one seriously, in an explosion and fire last night at the Marian Motel in Seaside Heights, N.J., the police said.

title: Holy Infringement! Batman Wins Award
description: A company that distributed wristwatches decorated with a logo resembling that of Batman has been ordered to pay more than $40,000 to the caped crusader's copyright owners.

title: Calm Senate, Restless House Prepare for Debates on Ethics
description: As the Senate prepared to open what is expected to be a low-key debate on Wednesday about Senator Dave Durenberger's ethical conduct, a leader of House conservatives today pledged to press for a harsher judgment there in the case of Representative Barney Frank.

title: Sasser's 2 Homers Get Mets On Track
description: There were cracks in the facade, all right: Darryl Strawberry, with two hits in 24 times up; Dwight Gooden, confessing that his pitching shoulder felt stiff; Kevin Elster, sidelined because his shoulder felt very stiff; Mackey Sasser, limping and chafing on a severely sprained right ankle, and the Mets losing 6 of 11 games when they should have been making their big second-half move.

title: Dow Chemical Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gary Reynolds, 40, Curator of Artworks At Newark Museum
description: Gary A. Reynolds, curator of painting and sculpture at the Newark Museum since 1983, died on Monday at Tisch Hospital of New York University Medical Center. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clark Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $20,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the 6 months, and after tax loss carryforwards of $2,133,000, or 12 cents a share, and $6,458,000, or 37 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $331,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $362,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months, and after tax loss carryforwards of $233,000, or 1 cent a share, and $725,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Computer Associates Intl reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: MARLON BRANDO planned to make a shrine out of the room where his daughter's boyfriend was slain, a lawyer said yesterday at a hearing in Los Angeles for the actor's son, who is charged with murdering the young Tahitian.

title: Bid to Curb Aid On Sugar Fails
description: The House and Senate easily defeated a proposal today to trim the United States sugar program, sidestepping charges that the subsidies hurt sugar-exporting nations and inflated domestic food prices.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IN the past six and a half years, Robert Pearson, a former hairdresser from London, has carved out an improbable niche as the owner and manager of Stick to Your Ribs, a barbecue restaurant that is widely regarded as the best in the New York region and possibly in the Northeast.

title: Fed Approves Sovran Merger
description: The Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that it had approved the merger between Sovran Financial Corporation, Virginia's largest banking company and the Citizens and Southern Corporation of Atlanta.

title: Few Heads Are Turned By Profits' Turnaround
description: The selloff in the stock market on Monday, which many analysts attributed to weak profits, actually came at a time when company earnings seem to be rising again.

title: Union Electric Co. reports earnings for 12mo to June 30
Borden Chemicals & Plastics L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Pepsico's Profits Climbed by 10.4% in the Second Quarter
description: Pepsico Inc., the world's second-largest soft-drink company and the nation's No. 2 operator of fast-food restaurants, said that earnings in the second quarter ended June 16 rose 10.4 percent, to $292.5 million, or $1.10 a share, from $264.9 million a year earlier, or $1.00 a share.

title: Pilgrim's Pride reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Morgan Stanley Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago second quarter's revenue included pre-tax gain of $51.5 million, primarily from the restructuring of the firm's investments in Essex Group Inc. and Silgan Corp. The net revenues for the latest periods totaled $504,199,000 for the quarter and $1,082,451,000 for the 6 months, compared with $631,568,000 and $1,165,687,000 for year-ago periods, respectively. Share earnings have been retroactively adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 common stock split, which became effective Feb. 27, 1989.

title: Dr. Louis M. Hellman Dies at 82; A Champion of Family Planning
description: Dr. Louis M. Hellman, a physician who as a Federal health official advocated public financing of birth control, abortion and voluntary sterilization for the poor, died Sunday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 82 years old and lived in Hydes, Md.

title: Amoco Cadiz Damages Set
description: A judge today ordered the Amoco Corporation to pay about $155 million in damages for a huge oil spill from the Amoco Cadiz tanker off the northern coast of France in 1978.

title: Mahlmann's Firm Fails to Sell Equity Stake
description: Stotler Group Inc., a financially troubled commodity brokerage headed by Karsten Mahlmann, who is also chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today that it had failed to obtain a much-needed infusion of capital from an outside investor group.

title: Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an after-tax charge of $125 million due to the first quarter non-recuring charge for the permanent impairment of certain assets and operations in Latin America. Sales represented consolidated sales.

title: Union Weighs 'Miss Saigon' Casting
description: Members of the Actors' Equity Association failed to decide yesterday whether the union would permit the English actor Jonathan Pryce to repeat his performance as a Eurasian when the hit musical ''Miss Saigon'' moves to Broadway from London.

title: Health-Care Rationing Takes From the Poor;   Medicare Capped in '84
description: To the Editor:

title: Donald M. Lovejoy, 93, A Retired Stockbroker
description: Donald Meston Lovejoy, a former general partner at Bache & Company, died on Monday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital in Connecticut. He was 93 years old and lived in Greenwich and in Gulf Stream, Fla.

title: Eight Possible Sites Selected For U. of California Campus
description: The biggest guessing game in California education circles over the last few years has been speculation on where the University of California Board of Regents will put a new $300 million campus.

title: Sewage Plant Pump Repaired
description: Engineers restored a damaged pump at the city's second-largest sewage-treatment plant yesterday afternoon, two days after an electrical fire shut down the plant and caused a major sewage spill into the East and Harlem Rivers. Four of five pumps are now available for use at the plant on Wards Island, said Tina Casey, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection. The department does not yet know when the damaged fifth pump will be ready for service.

title:
EDUCATION;

The Short, Unhappy Life of Academic Presidents
description: LEAD: For Derek Bok at Harvard and John Brademas at New York University, announcing their resignations meant the start of curtain calls after long, successful runs in the lead roles at their institutions.

title: Deadly Decision on Assault Rifles
description: The Alice-in-Wonderland world of gun control grows curiouser and, perhaps, deadlier. Just one year ago, gun control advocates cheered when President Bush banned foreign-made military assault rifles - the so-called Rambo guns favored by drug traffickers and other criminals. But now the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has decided to allow American distributors to import semiautomatic weapons that appear to have undergone only cosmetic changes.

title: It's Familiar Story for U.S. As Soviets Triumph Again
description: The United States is always starting over with its national basketball team, but the Soviet Union is not used to a major rebuilding program smack in the middle of a tournament.

title: Zenith Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss crom discontinued operations of $11 million. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.8 million for the quarter and $5.1 million for the 6 months.

title: Cardinal Distribution reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arrow Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Preferred dividends exceeded net income in year-ago periods.

title: Evolution in Europe;   K.G.B. Critic Is Charged
description: The federal prosecutor's office filed criminal charges today against a retired high-ranking K.G.B. officer, asserting that his public charges of abuses in the secret police had violated secrecy laws. But the target, former Maj. Gen. Oleg D. Kalugin, said he was immune from prosecution because he was recently registered as a candidate for a vacant seat in the Soviet Parliament.

title: Review/Television;   2 Shows Aim Young and Younger
description: In its never-ending quest for the fountain of youthful audiences, Fox Broadcasting tonight is offering the first episodes of ''Glory Days,'' whose heroes are four post-high school chums heading in different directions, and ''Molloy,'' all about a frisky actress just turned 13. Neither offers an occasion to break out the soda pop.

title: Northern Telecom Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Southwest Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ingersoll-Rand Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $8.5 million, or 17 cents a share, representing tax benefits from capital loss carryforward associated with the sale of its finance subsidiary.

title: KEY RATES
Chesapeake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest second quarter's earnings reflected an after-tax net gain of $800,000, or 4 cents a share, resulting from a $5.6 million pre-tax gain from the settlement of pension plan obligations through the purchase of annuities, offset by almost $4 million of charges for inventory and other writedowns in the company's consumer products business.

title: Talks End; Charges Seen At Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines has failed to reach a plea-bargaining agreement in a Federal investigation of past maintenance practices, and a grand jury is expected to indict the carrier this week on criminal charges, Eastern's court-appointed trustee and Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Vincent Has No Plan To Pursue Winfield
description: Dave Winfield and his relationship with Howard Spira will not be the subject of any further inquiry after Commissioner Fay Vincent wraps up his investigation of George Steinbrenner.

title: Alleghany Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter included a gain from the sale of 4.4 million shares of St. Paul Cos. for $280.7 million. The 1989 figures were restated.

title: Across South Africa, Shattering Days of Violence
description: As South Africa gropes toward negotiations between the white-dominated Government and the black majority, the nation is being torn by some of its worst violence in recent years.

title: Cultural Differences
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bridge
description: Young players made a big impression on the first day of Spingold Knockout play at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Four of the players who qualified last week to represent North America in the 1991 World Junior Championships advanced, and two of them scored a notable upset on a day in which form prevailed, both in the Spingold and the Women's Knockout.

title: A Needle, Three Miles Down
description: The Navy has developed such skill in recovering objects lost on the ocean floor that this week it embarked on a remarkably difficult search. It is seeking a cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jumbo jet en route from Honolulu to New Zealand.

title: Interpublic Group of Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $496,000 for the quarter and $3,435,000 for the 6 months. c-Included losses from exchange and translation of foreign currencies of $493,000 for the quarter and $1,318,000 for the 6 months. Revenue represented gross income

title: Wolohan Lumber Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Group Urges Limits On Outside Earnings Of Council Members
description: To eliminate potential conflicts of interest, sharp restrictions should be placed on the outside income members of the newly empowered New York City Council can earn in addition to their official salaries, a civic group said yesterday.

title: The Pop Life
description: Between the Lines

title: Marietta Net Climbs 8.7%
description: Earnings for the Martin Marietta Corporation, a leading aerospace and military contractor, increased in the second quarter because of the success of several space programs, the company said today.

title: Net Up at Chevron and Mobil as Texaco and Phillips Fall
description: The Chevron Corporation, helped by steady gasoline prices and demand in the West, where half of its refined products are sold in the United States, continued to outperform most major oil companies in the second quarter, posting a strong profit gain of 60.4 percent.

title: ITT Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $139 million, or 99 cents a share, fully diluted, on the sale of Alcatel for the quarter and 6 months. c-Included an after-tax gain of $18 million, or 12 cents a share, on sales of the European headquarters facility and an after-tax loss of $28 million on the sale of ITT Hartford's investment in Thompson McKinnon Inc. for both periods. Sales for the latest periods were impacted by $119 million for the quarter and $258 million for the 6 months, due to divestitures during 1989. The latest first half included a first- quarter gain of $47 million, after tax, or 33 cents a share, fully diluted, on the sale of the company's about 2 million share holding in Compagnie Generale d'Electricite.

title: The Right Way to Raise Taxes
description: An attitudinal dam broke when President Bush last month grudgingly acknowledged he could swallow new taxes. There was a wave of relief that finally the country could control its towering fiscal deficits. But now the rush has worn off and the Congressional budget negotiators are finally getting down to the hard part: deciding how to raise revenues.

title: Premier Industrial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec. 22, 1989.

title: Millipore Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ServiceMaster L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On Chefs' Attitudes
description: To The Living Section:

title: Kenjiro Takayanagi, Electrical Engineer, 91
description: Kenjiro Takayanagi, known as the father of Japanese television, died of pneumonia on Monday in a hospital in Yokosuka, company officials said today. He was 91 years old.

title: Blending Sports Management With Diplomacy
description: A year ago, Brian Gowdy was finishing a six-month academic internship in the Caribbean, teaching retarded children and adults how to play soccer and volleyball and trying to convince teachers that sports can enhance the quality of life for the retarded.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to slide during the week that ended yesterday. It was the eighth consecutive week of decline, and reflected a flight to quality caused in large part by a weak stock market.

title: Pepsico Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 16
