description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $5.5 million from writeoff of receivables due to a customer bankruptcy. c-Included net after-tax credit of $15 million, or 6 cents a share, which consisted of a gain from a decision to retain a Japanese bottling unit, reorganization charges, and a gain from a decision to retain a cookie plant.

title: Stalled Geneva Farm Talks Are Suspended for a Month
description: The United States and the European Community, failing to make progress at talks in Geneva in resolving a festering trade dispute over farm subsidies, suspended negotiations today for a month.

title: Health-Care Rationing Takes From the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Melville Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Evolution in Europe;   At Home State's Court, Opinions In a Direct, Uncomplicated Style
description: Until he became a Federal judge this spring, David H. Souter was a member of a five-judge state supreme court on which dissent is infrequent, opinions hardly ever contain a footnote, and a day's work is as likely to consist of a zoning appeal or child custody dispute as a case of constitutional dimension.

title: Souter's Blank Slate Just Won't Do
description: LEAD: In unveiling his nomination of Judge David Souter to the United States Supreme Court, President Bush announced with pride that he was ignorant of his candidate's attitudes toward such fundamental principles as the constitutional right to privacy.

title: 5 Years May Be Needed To Close Savings Cases
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, criticized for his sluggish response to the savings and loan crisis, told a Senate panel today that the Justice Department will need at least five years to prosecute the most serious cases of fraud at 100 institutions on its priority list.

title: Bumbling Yankees Lose One More Time
description: Deion Sanders may be gone within a week, back to the National Football League and a sport he once described as his wife, as opposed to his summertime girlfriend.

title: Penn Central Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gain of $74.7 million on sale of subsidiaries.

title: Suit Filed by Mitel Against A.T.&T.
description: The Mitel Corporation, a Canadian telecommunications systems manufacturer, has sued the American Telephone and Telegragh Company in a Florida court for taking ''predatory actions'' against it.

title: Overseas Investment Down in U.S.
description: Foreign investors shunned American stocks and Treasury securities in the first quarter of 1990, leaving the domestic markets with a net outflow of foreign investment in stocks and bonds for the first time since 1983.

title: Honeywell Spinoff
description: Honeywell Inc. today provided new details about the planned spinoff of its military and marine business. For each four shares of Honeywell stock, shareholders will receive one share in the new, free-standing military company, Alliant Techsystems Inc.

title: People
description: * David M. Biebelberg has been named senior vice president and group director at Griffin Bacal Inc.

title: New Focus On Service: Relearning a Lost Art
description: THE nonprofessional actor-waiter with the ''Hi, I'm. . .'' introduction who does not know ''Who gets the fish?'' is as much a part of the social history of the 1980's as ''Have a nice day.'' But at a time when the restaurant industry is suffering, the fallout is serious.

title: Oratory Cooled to Speed Budget Talks
description: Facing mounting pressure to conclude a budget deal before Congress adjourns for its August recess, President Bush and top Congressional leaders agreed today to cool their political oratory in hopes of spurring stalled negotiations on a $50 billion deficit-cutting package.

title: East Germans' Anxiety Dulls Thrill of Victory
description: Standing on the podium, their faces revealed a little of the happiness one might expect at such an occasion. These were medal winners, after all, and they tried to look the part.

title: Carter-Wallace reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a profile yesterday about Judge David H. Souter's selection for the Supreme Court misattributed a description of him. The comment, that he was ''about 135 pounds - and about 120 pounds of brain,'' was from John T. Broderick, counsel for the New Hampshire State Democratic Party and president of the New Hampshire Bar Association.

title: Gunman Kills Father and Shoots Baby
description: A 1-year-old girl sitting in her mother's lap was shot and critically wounded in Brooklyn yesterday morning when a gunman fired two shots at their car, killing her father, as they waited at a stop sign.

title: Playing the B46 Lotto: Will the Bus Show Up?
description: At 12:41 P.M. on a recent weekday, Bernice Cross leaned against the glass in a shady corner of the bus shelter at Utica and Church Avenues and began what has come to be known as the ''lotto wait.'' That's because the chances of a bus on the B46 line in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn running on time are about the same as winning the lottery.

title: The Exalted Victims on Ryan's List
description: Harry Spilman was agitated, and got Nolan Ryan on the phone. ''Nolan, how come I'm not on the list?'' he asked one day last summer to his neighbor in Alvin, Tex., and former opponent and teammate, Nolan Ryan. ''What list?'' asked Ryan. ''The list of every guy you ever struck out in the major leagues,'' said Spilman. ''There are 1,063 different players on it, and I'm not one. But you got me, too. One time.''

title: Taxpayers' Choice
description: If the authorities had taken the advice I gave them 15 years ago, this ridiculous quarrel about art, taxes, smut and politics would not be afflicting the most trivial minds of our generation.

title: In Switch, Israel Backs U.S. Radio Transmitter
description: An Israeli Government panel approved plans today for a powerful Voice of America radio relay station in the Negev, reversing an earlier decision to postpone the project pending an environmental study.

title: Archeologists Unearth 'Golden Calf' in Israel
description: Harvard University archeologists excavating Canaanite ruins surrounding the site of the ancient port city of Ashkelon have unearthed a ''golden calf'' that was an object of worship dating from the second millennium B.C.

title: TBS Uncertain It Will Support Another Goodwill Games in '94
description: Despite the Turner Broadcasting System's plans to stage the Goodwill Games in 1994 and 1998, the company's chief financial officer said today that a firm decision would not be made until the board of directors reviews the 1990 games, now under way.

title: Consolidated Edison Co. of N.Y.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ASYLUM-SEEKERS STRAIN CUBA'S TIES
description: An influx of Cubans seeking asylum in foreign embassies here has strained relations between the Castro Government and the country's two most important Western economic partners, Spain and Canada. Several unexplained incidents during the crisis have raised suspicions among some Western diplomats that Government agents have infiltrated the would-be refugees.

title: Stephen J. Riker Weds Ms. Baker
description: Margery Baker, a producer of special events for CBS News in New York, was married yesterday to Stephen Jonathan Riker, a real-estate executive in New York. Rabbi Alex Goldman performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: Red Grange Recovering
description: Harold (Red) Grange, the legendary Galloping Ghost of football, has been diagnosed as having Parkinson's disease but should be returning to his home in Lake Wales, Fla., after a few more weeks at an extended-care center, according to his wife. ''He won't be going dancing,'' said Muggs Grange, his wife of more than 49 years. ''But he's going to outlive all of us.''

title: A 33-Year Employee Heads Brown & Root
description: Brown & Root Inc., one of the world's largest engineering and construction companies, has named Bernard Pieper as its new chief executive.

title: Philip S. Bergman, Neurologist, 69
description: Dr. Philip S. Bergman, a retired neurologist, died on Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Buenos Aires Journal;   High Atop His Bicycle, a Comic Hurls Some Bolts
description: It's not because of his long battle with obesity that Enrique Pinti spends 20 minutes during each of his sold-out stage shows furiously pedaling a stationary bicycle while spewing a breathless assault on the Argentine national character.

title: Market Place;   Warnaco Grows With 'Junk Bonds'
description: AT a time when many manufacturers are acting more like retailers to keep their goods from gathering dust on the shelves, Warnaco Inc., one of the nation's oldest clothing makers, appears to go even further than most. One result is that Warnaco appears to be weathering a leveraged buyout so well that it expects to report its first annual profit since it was bought out in 1986 by the Spectrum Group.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the acquisition of the Ford Motor Company's aerospace unit referred incorrectly to the involvement of Shearson Lehman Hutton. Merchant banking partnerships managed by Shearson (but not Shearson itself) will contribute $150 million of equity in a joint venture with the Loral Corporation to purchase the unit.

title: Profits Up 9% At Interpublic
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said second-quarter earnings rose 9 percent, to $30.9 million, or 92 cents a share, from $28.3 million, or 84 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues rose 8 percent, to $342.4 million.

title: McGirt Has Surgery
description: James (Buddy) McGirt, the International Boxing Federation's top-ranked welterweight contender, underwent surgery yesterday to repair tendons in his left elbow that were torn during the third round of his 10-round victory by unanimous decision over Jose Leonard Bermudez in Atlantic City on Sunday. According to Dr. Jack Marzec, the attending sports medicine surgeon at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, L.I., McGirt suffered a complete rupture of the left bicep tendon in the left elbow while throwing a left hook.

title: b-Included $500,000 gain reFlated to termination of a penFsion plan.
description: Latest quarter's net income equaled less than 1 cent a share.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chemical Waste Management, Oak Brook, Ill., a hazardous waste management service, and UNC Inc., Annapolis, Md., an aerospace and aviation company, announced jointly that a CWM subsidiary had acquired for $24 million two UNC subsidiaries engaged in providing environmental restoration and waste management services to the Federal Government.

title: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Results for both 6-month periods reflected reductions in entertainment programming and sports rights at the ABC Television Network from historic costs to fair market values recorded in connection with the acquisition of ABC. These reduced costs benefited first half 1990 results by 15 cents a share and first half 1989 results by $1.15 a share.

title: Bush Addresses Dinner to Raise G.O.P. Money
description: President Bush came to a fund-raising dinner in New York last night to praise the Republican candidate for governor, Pierre A. Rinfret, but not to raise much money for him.

title: Sun Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Allegheny Power System reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Watkins-Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Included a gain of $514,000, or 6 cents a share, resulting from the settlement of a pricing dispute on a contract with the U.S. Government and the reversal of the related provision.

title: Bush's Court Choice;   Sununu Tells How and Why He Pushed Souter for Court
description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said today that he had assured President Bush that David H. Souter would uphold conservative values on the Supreme Court. He also said he had given ''strong personal support'' to Judge Souter at a key moment in the President's decision-making.

title: Knight-Ridder Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $56,761,000, or $1.09 a share, for the quarter and $56,566,000, or $1.08 a share, for the 6 months; both incomes from discontinued operations included gain of $55,522,000 on sale of discontinued television operations. Year-ago periods' results also included gain of $49,976,000, or 58 cents a share, from the sale of the Pasadena Star-News.

title: WESTERN LEADERS PLAN U.N. MEETING
description: President Bush and the leaders of six other major industrial democracies agreed at their summit meeting in Houston this month that they would all do their best to attend a ''world summit for children'' to be held here on Sept. 29 and 30, diplomats and United Nations officials said today.

title: 16 Seized in Thefts of Jewelry Later Fenced Through Stores
description: Sixteen people were arrested and charged yesterday as part of a ring that stole jewelry, precious metals, gems and rare coins and then fenced them through two of the members' jewelry stores in Manhattan, the Federal authorities said.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Move Back Up

title: Death in Arab Uprising
description: An 18-year-old Palestinian died today from wounds suffered in an earlier clash with Israeli soldiers, Arab reports said. It was the first uprising death from army gunfire reported in a month. The victim, Mahmud Helal Salame, was shot in the neck July 14 in a clash between soldiers and stone-throwing youths in the West Bank village of Beit Lid, Arab reports said. An army spokesman confirmed a Palestinian was shot by troops in Beit Lid during the mid-July confrontation.

title: ULSTER NUN KILLED WITH 3 POLICEMEN
description: A Roman Catholic nun and three policemen were killed today when a bomb ripped through a car near Armagh in Northern Ireland, the police said.

title:
Real Estate;

New Medical Projects Get Boston Push
description: LEAD: THIS city is stepping up its efforts to encourage the development of biomedical research and the biotechnology industry linked with the city's medical schools, teaching hospitals and research institutes.

title: Varian Associates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Afterr losses from discontinued operations of $15.2 million for the quarter and $16.7 million for the 9 months; the results for both periods also included a $31.9 million restructuring charge related to the phasing out of certain product lines, and other related expenses. c-Net income and after income of $100,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $1.1 million for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The losses from discontinued operations for the latest periods were related to the exit from several non-core businesses, primarily the electron device segment.

title: Tandy Introducing Home Computer
description: The Tandy Corporation will introduce a home computer today that the company said would be less expensive than the model introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation last month. I.B.M. introduced the PCjr in late 1983, but withdrew the product in 1985 after disappointing sales. Tandy, which was one of the first personal computer makers, has continued to sell to the home market and is now considered the leading maker of home computers by market researchers.

title: On a Remote Soviet Island, Lessons in Capitalism
description: A Los Angeles business professor and a Soviet economist have announced that they are introducing the nuts and bolts of capitalism to the inhabitants of the remote Russian island of Sakhalin, north of Japan, in one of the latest free-market experiments in the Soviet Union.

title: G.M. to Sell Trucks Fueled by Natural Gas
description: The General Motors Corporation today entered the market for vehicles powered by cleaner-burning compressed natural gas.

title: Article 990490 -- No Title
description: Milton Roy, a waste-water equipment manufacturer in St. Petersburg, Fla., said it would examine the bid but wanted to stay independent.

title: 76ers Select Shue As General Manager
description: Gene Shue, a player for 10 years and a coach for 23 in the National Basketball Association, began a new phase of his pro career when he was named general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers yesterday.

title: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflected $444 million of charges for non-cash interest primarily related to the company's leveraged buyout in 1989, as well as $308 million of other non-cash charges, including amortization of intangibles and depreciation. c-After income from discontinued operations of $22 million for the quarter and $34 million for the 6 months. The year-ago 6 months' results included RJR Nabisco from Jan. 1 through Feb. 8, on consolidated sales totaling $650 million, a net loss of $173 million, and income from discontinued operations of $24 million. RJR Nabisco Holdings' year-ago 6 months' results started Feb. 9 through June 30.

title: Yellow Freight System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $29.2 million, or $1.01 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Endowment Requests a List of Performers
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has asked Franklin Furnace, an avant-garde performance space in the TriBeCa section of Manhattan, to provide details on ''the identity of the artists involved'' and ''the nature of the work to be performed'' in its forthcoming season.

title: Warning: Some of This Live Concert Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net restructuring gain of $1.19 billion.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Down 13.2% in Mid-July Period
description: The market for new autos softened in mid-July, as sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell 13.2 percent compared with unusually strong sales in the period last year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE CHARLES, the heir to the British throne, has entered the world of commerce with what might be the ultimate upper-crust loaf, an organic bread named after his Highgrove Home Farm and bearing the Duchy of Cornwall crest. The Tesco supermarket chain began selling Wholemeal Highgrove yesterday for $1.07 a loaf in its stores in southeastern England. The bread is made from wheat grown without pesticides at Highgrove, 100 miles west of London, as well as from Canadian organic wheat.

title: About New York;   Nights of Glitz, A Velvet Rope And Memories
description: Today is the first anniversary of the death of 45-year-old Steve Rubell, that loquacious scamp who made his mark by being in the right place at the right time in a town where that is often all that matters.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ARCO, Los Angeles, promoted to senior vice presidents: Harrell E. Bilhartz Jr., who becomes president of ARCO Alaska; E. Kent Damon Jr., for planning and control, and Anthony G. Fernandes, who becomes president of ARCO Coal Co. William C. Rusnack, who was also named senior vice president, becomes president of ARCO Transportation Co. He replaces Harold C. Heinze, who is leaving the company. Marie L. Knowles was named vice president and controller, and Steven J. Shapiro was appointed vice president for corporate planning.

title: Tax Would Hurt Electricity's Role in Reducing Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncovered Short Sales of Active Nasdaq Issues Up 1%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported an increase of slightly more than 1 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended in mid-July.

title: Deficit Raises as Much Alarm As Illegal Drugs, a Poll Finds
description: The American public now cites the Federal budget deficit as frequently as it mentions illegal drugs as the most important problem facing the country, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Thruway Agency to Examine All of Its Bridges for Erosion
description: The Thruway Authority announced today that it had begun a $4.6 million two-year study of erosion under its bridges.

title: Bell South to Test Wireless Phones
description: The Bell South Corporation applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to test tiny wireless telephones in Atlanta over the next two years. Bell South said the test, which would involve up to 300 handsets, would use as much existing cellular telephone technology as possible. Some experts say that such a system, known as a personal communications network, could prove cheaper than current cellular telephone service.

title: Christie's Anticipates Record Auction Sales
description: Christie's International announced yesterday that it expected record worldwide auction sales of $2.4 billion for the 1989-1990 season, which winds down this month and is to end on Aug. 31.

title: Unisys Computers
description: The Unisys Corporation will offer new versions of its A Series and 1100/ 2200 mainframe systems. The new A16 model is currently available and priced between $1.75 million and $5.9 million depending on configuration, the company said. The new A12 model is also available and priced between $495,000 and $2.4 million. The 1100/2200 models range from mainframe to departmental systems and are priced from $115,000 to $8.8 million.

title: Tribune Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Times Mirror Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Included a gain of $23,056,000, or 11 cents a share, on the sale of timberlands.

title: Robinson Of Tigers Flirts With No-Hitter
description: Jeff Robinson of the Detroit Tigers lost a no-hitter on Mike Devereaux's leadoff homer in the eighth, but wound up with an 8-2 victory over Baltimore tonight behind a four-homer barrage.

title: Food Notes
description: A Bit of Texas Downtown Looking more like a truck stop than a cafe, the new Texas Tortilla Bakery, 36 Water Street (near Coenties Slip) in Manhattan easily satisfies a hunger for warm, fresh tortillas, mellow beans, lightly charred chicken or beef fajitas and salsa with a gentle kick. The bakery and cafe is open for dining in or taking out.

title: The Slimming Of Fat Fast Food
description: WHEN McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's announced in recent days that they would fry their potatoes in all vegetable oil instead of a mixture of beef tallow and vegetable oil, it was just one more sign that fast-food chains have learned a lesson: to survive in today's health-conscious society, they must provide more nutritious alternatives to double cheeseburgers and fried chicken.

title: Gooden Bothered By Stiff Shoulder
description: One year after suffering a torn muscle behind the right shoulder, Dwight Gooden acknowledged tonight that he had been pitching for the last couple of weeks with some stiffness behind the shoulder.

title: Barry's Defense Counters Witness's Testimony of a Sexual Assault
description: Charles Lewis, a leading prosecution witness in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial, testified today that he could not support a female acquaintance's charge that Mr. Barry had sexually attacked her.

title: Seaborne Guerrillas Shell the Residence Of Liberia's Leader
description: A rebel gunboat attacked President Samuel K. Doe's seafront executive mansion before dawn today and troops inside the fortified command post fired back, witnesses said.

title: A Pop(ulist) Quiz;   This man is:     (a) A designer of Nixon's 'Southern strategy'     (b) The Democrats' next Presidential candidate     (c) Kevin Phillips     (d) All of the above
description: Move over, Mario. Take a hike, Teddy. Amscray, Albert. The Democratic Party has found a new standard-bearer. He's young and a master of the nine-second sound bite.

title: Upper Broadway Loses Last of Its Fur Salons
description: From the curb in front of his shuttered shop, Robert Payne pointed south, then north along Broadway, at the east side of the avenue, then the west.

title: Weyerhaeuser Co. reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
Health-Care Rationing Takes From the Poor;   Compassion and Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillips Petroleum Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $101 million, or 41 cents a share, and income of $137 million, or 56 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. Year-ago 6 months' results included a gain of $21 million from the settlement of a pipeline dispute. Latest quarter included an extraordinary credit due to a gain from the settlement of a dispute with Iran and a gain from an accounting change. Gains and extraordinary credits on the latest 6 months were partially offset by a $90 million after-tax loss fom the sale of a unit.

title: Evolution in Europe;   As Yeltsin Sets Quick Tempo, Gorbachev Tries to Keep Beat
description: In a country where power has long been a game of older men, Boris N. Yeltsin's choice of a 32-year-old banking specialist to run the Finance Ministry of the vast Russian republic raised some eyebrows.

title: New York City Auctions $1.1 Billion in Tax Notes
description: The City of New York held a competitive auction of $1.1 billion worth of short-term tax anticipation notes.

title: Wings Seek Fedorov
description: The Detroit Red Wings, who made Sergei Fedorov of the Soviet Union a fourth-round pick in the 1989 National Hockey League entry draft, asked the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday to give a temporary work permit to the 20-year-old center in an application signed by Jim Lites, the Red Wings' vice president.

title: Smith's Food & Drug Centers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Valcom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
More Saatchi Sales Plans Are Reported
description: ROBERT LOUIS-DREYFUS, the chief executive of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, has had his hands full dealing with the financial problems of the advertising and communications giant. But one of the most nettlesome concerns for him lately is the steady stream of rumors about how far he plans to go in dismantling the London-based public relations, consulting and advertising conglomerate constructed by Charles and Maurice Saatchi.

title: On Deadline Day, Cuomo Vetoes 2 Bills Opposed by Dinkins
description: In a victory for the Dinkins administration, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today vetoed two measures that the Mayor's office had opposed.

title: Spiegel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Debate on the Fate Of Arts Endowment Is Postponed
description: The long-awaited debate on the future of the National Endowment for the Arts will be awaited still longer: it has been put off, probably until September.

title: Panel Says Ex-Bush Aide Claimed Millions From a Savings Unit Deal
description: A lobbyist who helped investors buy troubled savings institutions claimed to be entitled to a multimillion-dollar share in a deal providing $1.85 billion in Federal subsidies to one client, a Senate committee disclosed today.

title: New Leader Of Anglicans: George Leonard Carey
description: Bishop George Carey, a bishop for less than three years, was named today as the next Archbishop of Canterbury, spiritual head of the Church of England and 70 million Anglicans around the world.

title: Engel Retires After Plea
description: Bob Engel, the suspended National League umpire, pleaded no contest today to stealing baseball cards, then announced he was retiring from baseball.

title: Diceon Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Two Companies Out of Bidding
description: The General Instrument Corporation said two companies that had expressed an interest in the New York-based electronics concern are no longer interested in a transaction. Neither comForstmann Little & Company has already agreed to pay $44.50 a share, or $1.6 billion, for all of General Instrument's outstanding shares. After General Instrument announced this morning that one of the other parties had withdrawn from the bidding, its shares fell 87.5 cents, to $44.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading in the stock was halted before the company announced that the second party had withdrawn.

title: Pactel and Cellular Plan Midwest Venture
description: The Pacific Telesis Group and Cellular Communications Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to combine their cellular telephone interests in the Midwest in an equally owned joint venture.

title: AST Research reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bethlehem Steel reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included pre-tax charges of $50 million for the quarter and $105 million for the 6 months for restructuring of Bethforge division.

title: Brady Expects Some New Limits To Be Put on Deposit Insurance
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the Bush Administration was leaning in the direction of limiting individuals and businesses to a maximum of $100,000 in deposit insurance, whether in one or several accounts.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A 45-YEAR-OLD woman, noticing that her mother seemed depressed, asked her if the trouble was sexual problems. When her mother admitted to the daughter that that was the case, the daughter referred her to places where her parents might get help. And she gave her mother specific suggestions on how to make herself more sexually attractive.

title: Events: The Season Of Plants and Crafts
description: 40 Strong, Ward-Nasse Gallery, 178 Prince Street (Sullivan Street); (212) 925-6951.

title: Ayer's Ad Celebrates Certificate From Army
description: In a postscript to the long-running dispute between Ayer and the Army, the advertising agency took out a full-page ad yesterday in The New York Times yesterday (page A20) to announce that it had received a Certificate of Achievement from the Army for ''exceptionally meritorious service'' from July 1, 1967, to Jan. 1, 1987.

title: Grand Jury To Investigate Guardsmen
description: A state grand jury here is investigating whether officers in the New York National Guard stole tens of thousands of dollars earmarked for tuition reimbursement of Guard soldiers, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Massachusetts Lawmakers Balk at Budget and Re-examine Taxes
description: Rebelling against the latest attempt to resolve the state's budget crisis, Massachusetts legislators refused to approve a $13.7 billion budget and moved to repeal central elements of a $1.8 billion tax increase that was signed into law last week.

title: People
description: * Mary Conrad, Bill Daily, Steve Seyferth and Martin Sherrod have been promoted to senior vice president in the account management department of Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago.

title: Chronicle
description: Officials of the Koch administration continue their transition to the private sector. JAMES P. STUCKEY who, as president of the New York City Public Development Corporation from 1986 through 1989, managed a multibillion-dollar portfolio of city-sponsored commercial and industrial projects, will be the managing director of Gronich & Company, a real-estate brokerage and services organization in Manhattan.

title: Two Women's Magazines Have Setbacks
description: Yesterday was a cheerless day for the women's magazine field as Woman magazine announced that it would cease publication and Woman's Day was taken off the auction block because no one would meet its owner's asking price.

title: America West Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss of $1,005,000 related to the disposition of certain assets, and after a tax-loss carryforward of $1,232,000, or 8 cents a share. c-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $1,093,000 for the quarter and $4,722,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Drills at Giant Camp Have Collegiate Flavor
description: Bill Parcells, like most other pro football coaches, recites the party line about players who are missing from training camp. When he is asked whether it is frustrating to have eight Giants veterans and three draftees out because of contract disputes, he says he can coach only the players who are here.

title: Role for Ivana Trump: An American in Paris
description: Every fashion season has its off-the-runway star around whom photographers flock, taking endless shots for the newspapers and magazines of the world. The star has often been an actress like Sophia Loren, Faye Dunaway or Joan Collins (during the reign of ''Dynasty''), or royalty. Princess Caroline of Monaco still draws the cameras, as she did yesterday at the Chanel show, wearing a white Chanel blouse, white jeans and sneakers.

title: Mets Survive Late Scare And Hold Off the Phillies
description: Rocketing from one extreme to the other, the Mets zoomed into a 9-0 lead over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight with one of their best bursts of hitting of the season. But then they came within one line drive of squandering the entire performance when the Phillies rallied in the late innings, bunched seven groundball singles in a row for six runs in the ninth and nearly sent the Mets spinning to their most agonizing defeat of the season.

title: Sotheby's Says Sales Could Top $3.2 Billion
description: Sotheby's Holdings announced yesterday that it expected record worldwide auction sales of $3.2 billion for the 1989-90 season, which ends on Aug. 31.

title: Alleghany Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter included a gain from the sale of 4.4 million shares of St. Paul Cos. for $260.7 million. The 1989 figures were restated. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: WE did everything right. When we got there, on Friday night, we took deep breaths of the stock-scented air and said wasn't it wonderful to be out of that hot, sticky city. Then we strolled the grounds (six-tenths of an acre), disturbing a pair of dandelion-eating rabbits, and marveled at the sky. Only one or two stars are ever visible in the sky over New York, so we get pretty excited when we see constellations. Next we ate pasta while Fred Astaire sang and tapped and occasionally whooped so loudly we'd have waked the angels. There were no neighbors near enough to complain about ''She's Not My Girl'' and ''After You, Who?'' played at top pitch. We slept like babies.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: 3 Detained Lawyers Released In Kenya but Not 3 Politicians
description: The Kenyan Government today released three lawyers detained without charges three weeks ago but kept in prison three politicians detained in the same crackdown on advocates of political pluralism.

title: Sun to Sell Its Computer Work Stations in Stores
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., in a direct challenge to personal computer manufacturers, announced today that it would sell its engineering work stations through computer retailers.

title: Minds Are Bent by Sex In 2 Horror Thrillers
description: Lie to Me

title: Crystal Brands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $886,000 for the quarter and $846,000 for the 6 months.

title: Jury in jogger Trial Hears Last of 3 Confessions
description: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial yesterday heard the last of a series of confessions given by the three defendants in the rape and attempted murder case.

title: AMP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Intergroup In Proxy Loss
description: National Intergroup Inc. today lost a proxy battle with Centaur Partners L.P. as three Centaur candidates were apparently elected to National Intergroup's 12-member board.

title: Constar International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday describing the process used by the White House in selecting Judge David H. Souter for the Supreme Court referred incorrectly in some copies to Meldrim Thomson Jr. He is the former, not the late, Governor of New Hampshire.

title: Questions for the Judge
description: What is the one thing everybody wants to know about Judge David Souter of Weare, N.H.?

title: 'Old Man' of Jets Is Alive and Kicking
description: Pat Leahy took a good bit of good-natured kidding about his age yesterday after the Jets' new head coach, Bruce Coslet, was asked to evaluate the performance of the rookies in training camp.

title: It's Not Chic. It's Not Plain. It's Homey.
description: In a starkly decorated house on Long Island, a collection of china teapots shaped like English cottages seems out of place, a little pool of charm. The modernist who collects them (with some embarrassment) cannot fathom her passion for them. But Grant McCracken can.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Education page yesterday listing university presidents who have resigned or announced their resignations since June 1989 included an incorrect entry. Edward Bloustein of Rutgers died on Dec. 9, 1989, while president.

title: Shackleford to Italy
description: Charles Shackleford, a center-forward with the Nets who appears to have been shut out of playing time with the drafting of Derrick Coleman from Syracuse and the return of Roy Hinson from the injury list, will spend next season with S.C. Juventus of Caserta in the Italian League, Shackleford's agent confirmed yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Co., New York, appointed Scott C. Marden, a managing director, as head of its New York corporate finance group.

title: Dow Up 8.42, to 2,930.94; Investors Cautious
description: Stock prices continued to recover yesterday from Monday's huge selloff, but trading volume weakened and investors remained exceptionally cautious in an uncertain market.

title: Label Bill For Albums Is Vetoed In Louisiana
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer vetoed a bill today that would have required warning stickers on record albums with potentially offensive lyrics. The bill was the first in the United States ordering the use of warning labels on albums.

title: Textile Bill Advances
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved a textile import quota bill today and sent it to the full House. The bill would establish United States import quotas for each category of textiles, textile products and nonrubber footwear beginning this year. Imports from Canada and Israel would be exempt because those countries have free-trade agreements with the United States. The Senate passed the bill last week, but President Bush is expected to veto the measure if it is approved.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If there is a smudge on the Seal of the United States Senate, or on the Star of the North, as we like to call our state, I will work my hardest to polish both back to brightness.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about refugees in embassies in Havana referred incorrectly in some editions to the diplomats who voiced suspicions that Cuban Government agents were posing as asylum seekers. The diplomats were Western, but not West German.

title: Actors' Equity Attacks Casting of 'Miss Saigon'
description: The Actors' Equity Association said yesterday that it ''condemns'' the proposed casting of an English actor ''painted yellow'' in the leading role in ''Miss Saigon'' when the musical moves from London to Broadway.

title: Token Thieves? Listen to This: Now They Steal the Bus Itself.
description: Transit officials, already preoccupied with fighting subway token thieves and turnstile jumpers, must now find a way to foil a new type of adversary: the bus rustler.

title: Bridge
description: There were upsets in each of the major events at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here on Tuesday.

title: Gorbachev Sets Deadline for Militants to Disarm
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev set a deadline today for the disarming of militant groups and warned that troops might be sent if such groups continued to endanger the lives of the civilian population.

title: The Divorced Father
description: To The Home Section:

title: F.B.I. Investigates an Agent Accused of Avoiding Arrest
description: The Justice Department is investigating charges that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's top agent for South Carolina avoided a drunken-driving arrest with the help of the state's chief highway patrolman.

title: Metro Datelines;   Weicker Submits Petitions for Ballot
description: Former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., declaring, ''Politics will never be the same,'' filed petitions yesterday with what he said were 105,431 signatures, 10 times the required number, for a place on the November gubernatorial ballot.

title: Estimate Board Can Go Fighting for Clean Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Krone Returns Quickly To Winners' Circle
description: Returning to thoroughbred racing yesterday after eight months of recuperation from a Nov. 24 spill, Julie Krone guided an undistinguished 3-year-old maiden to victory in the third race at Monmouth Park.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LAYING bricks with plain sand instead of mortar is an easy way to pave areas like patios, walks and driveways. Bricks are arranged close together on a bed of packed sand surrounded by a border. After they are in place, more sand is swept into the crevices between them to prevent shifting.

title: Baker Hughes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $967,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $1,722,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months, both from tax credits.

title: Gerald Hedley Dead; Ar Restorer Was 41
description: Gerald Hedley, described by the National Gallery here as one of the world's leading experts in art restoration, died on Saturday in a mountaineering accident in the French Alps. He was 41 years old.

title: Amdahl Posts 41% Profit Gain
description: The Amdahl Corporation today reported improved revenues and earnings for the second quarter. Based in Sunnyvale, Calif., Amdahl produces mainframe computers compatible with those of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INDICTED IN SCHEME OVER MAINTENANCE
description: Eastern Airlines and nine of its managers were indicted yesterday on charges that supervisors at three airports routinely ignored vital repairs and maintenance and then falsified records to make it appear as if the work had been performed.

title: Pessimism Over Budget Talks Grows
description: White House and Congressional negotiators worked separately to prepare deficit-cutting proposals today amid growing pessimism among many Democrats that an agreement on next year's Federal budget could be reached any time soon.

title: Mitsubishi Executive Begins New York Job
description: Yutaka Hasegawa, who has moved several times in the last six years, hopes the new job he began yesterday as the senior executive officer of the Mitsubishi Bank's North American headquarters and general manager of the New York branch will lead to a bit of permanence.

title: Chronicle
description: JOHN DENVER, the singer and environmentalist, is joining forces with representatives of the Amway Corporation, the United Nations Environment Programs and the space agency to establish the Aspen Institute on Global Change. The institute will seek to enlist leading scientists to exchange ideas at summer seminars in Aspen, Colo. It would operate in conjunction with Mr. Denver's Windstar Foundation, established in 1977. ''This is not just another thinktank,'' Mr. Denver said. WILLIAM NICHOLSON, Amway's chief operating officer, said the direct marketing company had committed $500,000 to the institute, while RICK CHAPPELL, associate director of science at the Marshall Space Flight Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said NASA had contributed $40,000.

title: Q&A
description: Dull Counter Top

title: Critic's Notebook;   Television Brings Out A Melodramatic Side Of the Legal Process
description: As the first trial in the case of the Central Park jogger comes to a close, the loyal television viewer is again learning that the legal process is a category of melodrama. Trials that earn the most attention from local news and magazine shows, not to speak of docudramas, have all the elements of the nation's prime-time favorites: sex and violence, conflict and commotion. No one expects producers not to be attracted to these real-life crimes; they are made for television, life imitating bad art. The way they are treated, however, tends to divert attention from the fact that the law is really at work. Any viewer interested in that aspect of the case may be hard put to figure out what exactly is happening in the courtroom.

title: Apple Chip Deal Is Reported
description: Apple Computer Inc. is seeking an agreement with Outbound Systems Inc., a small Colorado computer company, that would allow Apple's key chips to be used in Outbound's machines, according to industry officials.

title: Cray Research reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Johannesburg Journal;   For an Afrikaner Weekly, Success Brings Bombs
description: When right-wing whites tried to blow up the newspaper office of Vrye Weekblad early this month, they paid the small Afrikaans-language weekly a sincere if terrifying compliment.

title: Making Glassware Whole Again
description: A SCRATCHED Art Nouveau Lalique plaque with a nymph face is in need of repair and a chipped chandelier prism needs grinding. Then there is the Baccarat lion with a severed tail, the cordial glass with a broken stem and the Steuben eagle with a broken wing. ''After it is polished, it will look like it was never damaged,'' said Augustine Jochec (pronounced JOE-check). He can fix them all.

title: A Breakthrough on Evolution As Guppies Change Behavior
description: The theory of evolution, so often cited but almost never challenged in an experiment in the real world, has withstood a rigorous test of one of its key elements.

title: Liberian Rebels, Pressing Their Attack on Capital, Raid Airfield
description: Rebels today attacked the airfield that was Monrovia's last link to the outside world and closed in on the city from two directions in some of the heaviest fighting for control of the capital.

title: Anheuser-Busch Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Yankees Lose but Still Spoil Ryan's Party
description: The people had come for a party, and Nolan Ryan was prepared to be the honored guest. He had talked about earning his 300th major league victory in style, of hoping to pitch a complete game if his recent back trouble did not persist. He spoke of his hope for his best game of the year. Instead, Ryan was left with his worst. But then, incredibly, so were the Yankees.

title: A Seaside Seating Spectacular
description: ALTHOUGH it is several blocks from the ocean in Santa Monica, Calif., the Gallery of Functional Art has created its own miniature seaside scene with sand, a 15-foot pier, a 12-foot-long bicycle path and a parking lot for one car.

title: Car Rental-Retailer Pact
description: Thrifty Rent-A-Car System will open offices in Montgomery Ward & Company department stores in 15 cities and will accept the retailer's credit card in all 24 of its Washington offices, Thrifty announced Tuesday. Thrifty, the fifth-largest car rental company in North America and a subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, will begin accepting Montgomery Ward credit cards on Aug. 1 in its Washington offices. The agreement calls for as many as 20 rental offices in Montgomery Ward stores by the end of the year.

title: Herbert Baldwin, 96, Ex-Official in Westport
description: Herbert E. Baldwin, an apple grower, legislator and first selectman of Westport, Conn., for 10 years, died on Monday in the Carolton Convalescent Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. He was 96 years old and lived in Westport.

title: Coslet Adjusting As a Boss
description: rrOut on the grass of the Jets' practice field yesterday, Bruce Coslet, the new coach, was wearing a white shirt, tan shorts, white socks and white football shoes. Peering through sunglasses, he moved from one group of players to another during drills, then stood off to the side as the offense ran through plays. Every so often he would talk to a player, like the rookie wide receiver who was unable to shake the cornerback covering him. ''You got to get open,'' he said, firmly. Spoken like a rookie head coach who has studied under some of the National Football League's most learned professors: Paul Brown, Bill Walsh, Sam Wyche, Forrest Gregg, Lindy Infante and Buddy Ryan. Only time will tell if Bruce Coslet is a head coach or just another touted assistant coach who couldn't adjust to the authority. But he seems to recognize the responsibility of being the boss.

title: Moynihan Calls Bush's Remarks About New York City 'Abusive'
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan today labeled President Bush's remarks about New York at a Republican fund-raising event on Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria ''abusive'' and ''beneath the Presidency.''

title: Acquisitions Firm Formed
description: Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. of London said yesterday that it was joining Eric Gleacher, former head of mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley & Company, to form a firm to be called Gleacher Morgan Grenfell Inc. that will do merger and acquisition work in the United States and abroad.

title: In Texas, A Portable Eakins
description: T-SHIRTS are the latest development in the saga of Thomas Eakins's painting ''The Swimming Hole,'' now in the Amon Carter Museum in Fort Worth.

title: Britain Approves Link With Sabena
description: The British Government cleared British Airways P.L.C.'s planned link with Sabena Belgian World Airlines. The decision came after an investigation that found that British Airways' intended 20 percent stake in Sabena would not operate against the public interest.

title: U.P.S. Getting Ready for Possible Walkout
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc., the nation's largest parcel-post carrier,is bracing for a possible strike next week, and its big corporate customers are already diverting packages away from the carrier.

title: Mattingly Out Indefinitely With Back Injury uf871>
description: Don Mattingly, sidelined for seven games recently because of a chronic back problem and struggling through his poorest professional season, agreed tonight to come out of the Yankee lineup.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Grey Advertising and the GCI Group, its public-relations subsidiary, have created a campaign for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Volunteer Public Awareness and Recruitment Campaign in New York.

title: Sanctuary for Liberian Victims
description: As many as 14,000 Liberian visitors find themselves stuck in the United States while a bloody civil war rages in their homeland. They need a safe haven until things stabilize. Even if the Bush Administration gives them temporary refuge, their plight underscores the need for Congress to formalize safe haven status generally for visitors who seek a port in a sudden storm.

title: 2 Steelmakers' Profits Decline
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday reported a 74 percent drop in second-quarter earnings while the Allegheny Ludlum Corporation posted a 38 percent plunge. Both steelmakers blamed lower steel prices for part of the deterioration.

title: Conair Buys Faberge
description: The Conair Corporation, a marketer of personal products and consumer appliances based in Edison, N.J., announced yesterday that it had purchased the Faberge Salon division of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. for an undisclosed price. Chesebrough-Pond's, a maker of personal products, is based in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Living With Antiques: When an Old Lock Balks
description: LEAD: An original working lock on a piece of antique furniture is usually the exception. ''Working'' means functioning well, with the mechanism responding smoothly and easily to the turn of the key. The body of the lock should fit well into its original grave, and for good measure the bolt should travel home unimpeded.

title: Commodities Firm Closing
description: A commodities brokerage firm headed by the chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade is going out of business because the company is unable to pay its debts.

title: Two Say They Did Not See Barry Use Drugs
description: Two defense witnesses in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s trial on drug and perjury charges today called into question earlier testimony that Mr. Barry used drugs on a 1986 cruise off St. Thomas.

title: Lead in Paint
description: To The Home Section:

title: Art of the Ashcan and Other Schools
description: FACTORY scenes, street scenes, portraits, abstract works - they are the kinds of images that bring to mind the early decades of the century. Twenty years ago Stewart Ross started collecting these evocative American paintings, which date from the 20's to the 50's.

title: FELLOW SENATORS VOTE TO DENOUNCE DURENBERGER, 96-0
description: The Senate took the rare step of punishing one of its own members today, denouncing Senator Dave Durenberger for bringing ''dishonor and disrepute'' to the institution through improper financial dealings.

title: Review/Dance;   Cast Changes in Australian 'Giselle'
description: In Maina Gielgud's production of ''Giselle'' for the Australian Ballet, the wilis (ghosts of jilted maidens) are seen for the first time as shrouded white figures, faces covered by huge bridal veils. They rise up from a horizon of mist, not from the usual stage wings, and surge toward the audience. It is a ''Giselle'' not to be missed.

title: Dow Chemical Profits Drop by 50%
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's No. 2 chemical maker, said Tuesday that its second-quarter profits slumped 50 percent, to $364 million, the latest in a growing list of companies to report disappointing results.

title: Chambers Development Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mandela Hints at Flexibility in Talks
description: Nelson Mandela suggested today that the African National Congress might consider compromises to achieve progress in formal negotiations with the Government on the country's future.

title: Alberto-Culver Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Healthier Savings Units Show a Drop in Losses
description: In what some saw as an attempt to put the best light on the savings and loan cleanup, regulators said today that losses were being stemmed at many institutions not under Government control.

title: House Backs Bush Veto of Family Leave Bill
description: The House of Representatives today failed by 53 votes to override President Bush's veto of a bill requiring employers to grant workers time off without pay for births, adoptions or emergencies in the family.

title: Columbia 'Junk Bond' Sale Set
description: In the single largest sale ever of ''junk bonds,'' the Columbia Savings and Loan Association said today that it had agreed to sell its entire portfolio of the high-yield, high-risk securities to a Canadian investment company for $3 billion.

title: Review/Theater;   Satiric Mileage From Public Figures
description: Harry Shearer's transition from comedy writer and stand-up comic to performance artist seems trapped in a holding pattern. As the closing act in ''The Men's Room,'' a three-part show on Saturday in the Lincoln Center Serious Fun festival, Mr. Shearer sought satiric mileage at the expense of public figures - with wavering results.

title: Summit Interpreter Moves On to U.N.
description: For years he was there when the Soviet and American leaders met, strategically in the middle, interpreting everything they said.

title: 2 More Cancel TV Ads
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and Anheuser-Busch yesterday joined the International Business Machines Corporation in canceling plans to run television commercials during next month's P.G.A. Championship at the all-white Shoal Creek Country Club.

title: Washington at Work;   Federal Reserve's Chairman Blends Eye for Politics With Fiscal Skills
description: An admiring colleague says Alan Greenspan at his desk, his coat off, hunched in front of his computer screen and pouring over economic data, resembles an archeologist studying the latest find in hieroglyphics or a mathematician proving a theorem.

title: Art of Questioning;   Some Jogger Defense Lawyers Fear A Colleague's Cross-Examinations
description: There's an old saying among lawyers that advocates should never ask a question they don't know the answer to.

title: Microsoft Net Increases 76.2%
description: Buoyed by strong initial sales of its new Windows 3.0 product, the Microsoft Corporation today reported a 76.2 percent rise in net income for its fourth fiscal quarter, on a 53 percent gain in revenue. The Redmond, Wash., company also became the first personal computer software company to exceed $1 billion in annual revenues.

title: Iraq Said to Prevail in Oil Dispute With Kuwait and Arab Emirates
description: Iraq appeared today to have won a political victory, forcing Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to reduce oil production and pushing the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices.

title: British Aerospace To Fight Ruling
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said it would appeal a European Commission order that it repay illegal Government subsidies it received when it bought the formerly state-owned Rover car maker. British Aerospace said it would appeal to the European Court of Justice the order to repay $:44.4 million, or about $80 million. British Aerospace bought Rover from the Government for $:150 million, or $272 million, in July 1988.

title: New Clues Emerge on a Fatal Hereditary Disease
description: Researchers have discovered a number of new clues to the cause of a baffling hereditary disease, Marfan syndrome, best known for its role in the deaths of the Olympic volleyball player Flo Hyman and the University of Maryland basketball star Chris Patten.

title: Commercial Rocket Launched After 3 Delays
description: A newly repaired unmanned rocket blasted into space today with a satellite that will use chemicals to transform the lines of Earth's invisible magnetic field into brilliant bursts of color.

title: GSD&M Keeps Account of Southwest Airlines
description: A week after it lost the Coors Extra Gold beer account, which billed about $20 million last year, GSD&M Advertising of Austin, Tex., averted another blow yesterday by surviving a review for the creative portion of the Southwest Airlines account.

title: Dallas Museum Neutral On German Treasure
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Deals;   Showdown Time At Bond Brewing
description: EXECUTIVES of indebted companies and battered investors in high-yield ''junk bonds'' may push companies close to the brink as they battle over their competing interests. A piece of the troubled empire of Alan Bond, the Australian entrepreneur, now appears headed for liquidation.

title: Review/Music;   Wanted: Perfect Mozart Performers
description: Lincoln Center's plan to program every one of Mozart's 626 opus numbers next season to commemorate the 200th anniversary of his death is both noble and dangerously overweening. If anything could make the miracle of Mozart into humdrum, it would be this kind of gather-all, which might appeal more to the stamp collector and statistician than to the music listener.

title: June Orders For Durables Fell by 3.2%
description: A large drop in demand for military goods like tanks and aircraft lowered orders for durable goods sharply in June in a new sign of economic weakness, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Du Pont And Merck In Venture
description: Merck & Company and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced a 50-50 joint venture yesterday to create an independent drug company with $700 million in estimated sales.

title: As Johnny Learns to Shop, Hiroko Learns to Think
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines;   Man Slain in Attack Was Murder Witness
description: The police are investigating whether there is a connection between the killing on Tuesday of a Brooklyn man, whose 1-year-old daughter was critically wounded in the attack, and testimony that the man gave in May in a murder case, officials said yesterday.

title: Consul Restaurant Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Pirates Step It Up When Challengers Nip at Their Heels
description: The Philadelphia Phillies nudged the Pittsburgh Pirates out of first place by a half-game on May 25. The Pirates returned to first the next day and proceeded to reel off a five-game winning streak.

title: Ulster Questions 2 in Killing Of Nun and 3 Police Officers
description: The Royal Ulster Constabulary said today that it had detained two men for questioning in an Irish Republican Army bombing on Tuesday that killed three police officers and a Roman Catholic nun who happened to be driving by.

title: Vote Delayed Again on a 364-Mile Pipeline
description: A Federal agency today further delayed a decision on a proposal to build a pipeline to carry natural gas from Canada to six Northeastern states. The agency voted to hold one more hearing.

title: Culbro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Organized Crime's Role
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh expressed doubt today that investigations of savings and loan collapses would uncover evidence of widespread involvement by organized crime.

title: Let 'Em Eat Cake
description: ''In the war on poverty,'' Ronald Reagan often said, ''poverty won.'' That used to be just Reaganite overstatement; but under President Bush, poverty can hardly lose.

title: Soviets to Sell Diamond Stockpile Through a Subsidiary of De Beers
description: In an effort to raise badly needly foreign currency for its beleaguered economy, the Soviet Union has agreed to sell its uncut diamonds through the international diamond cartel controlled by De Beers of South Africa.

title: Anheuser Net Up 10.2%
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies today reported record profits and sales for the second quarter as new brands aided growth at the world's largest brewer.

title: Bible Bounty
description: Ephraim perished because he worshipped Baal, the god the golden calf represented. And those who followed Ephraim's path, the Old Testament thundered, would be ''like the morning mist, like dew that vanishes early, like chaff blown from the threshing floor or smoke from a chimney.''

title: No Need to Reward Guests Bearing Gifts
description: LEAD: ''THAT'S what pots of jam are for?'' is a memorable line from John Guare's new play, ''Six Degrees of Separation.'' And the gift that a couple in the play receives from a house guest is familiar, too: a pot of jam tucked into a nice floral arrangement.

title: James Carey; Banker, 84
description: James Carey, a retired vice president of the Bank of New York, died on Tuesday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Outdoors;   Variety of Birds Offered At Shooting Preserves
description: rrA new directory of shooting preserves in this country and Canada is now available from the North American Gamebird Association.

title: A Big Round Table With a Story to Tell
description: EVEN at first sight, it seemed clear that there must be a story behind the huge, handsome, round table and the graceful mismatched chairs that surround it. ''It was made for a sea captain's family in Biddeford, Me., in 1820,'' said Morgan Rank, an antiques dealer in East Hampton, L.I., whose shop is dominated by the 7-feet-8-inch diameter table.

title: Curb on Some Program Trades to Be Tried
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved a one-year trial of a New York Stock Exchange rule that would curtail a type of computerized trading on days when the stock market swings widely up or down.

title: Probation for Harvey
description: Bryan Harvey, a reliever for the California Angels, has been fined $1,031 by a California court and placed on three years' probation after pleading guilty to driving under the influence last April. (AP)

title: Air Products & Chemicals reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $2.4 million, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of a business and a net charge of $900,000 from the early retirement of long- term debt. c-Included net gain of $7.8 million, or 13 cents a share, from the early retirement of long-term debt and the sales of land and businesses. d-Included net gains of $4.7 million, or 9 cents a share, from the resale of a 50 percent interest in a cogeneration project and $5.1 million, or 9 cents a share, from a power cost adjustment and the sale of businesses net of writedowns and provisions.

title: What New Policy Toward Cambodia?
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker's statement on Cambodia, while constructive, has produced more confusion than clarity on U.S. policy toward Southeast Asia.

title: Patricia Keane Mason; Gallery Owner, 62
description: Patricia Keane Mason, a former art gallery owner who was active in charities, died on Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center. She was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Fashion;   Saint Laurent's Fall Collection looks as Relaxed as He Does
description: All he has to do to attract attention is to walk down the runway. Yves Saint Laurent did that Wednesday morning, looking fit and proud in a natty beige wool suit, after his successful couture opening at the Hotel Inter-Continental. He was followed along the route by thunderous applause and was immediately besieged by photographers.

title: Vernon (Buster) Wiles; Stunt Man, 79
description: Vernon (Buster) Wiles, who worked as a movie stunt man in Hollywood and as a double for Errol Flynn, died Friday. He was 79 years old.

title: Study Suggests Menopause Doesn't Affect Mental Health
description: A new study suggests that contrary to popular belief, menopause does not cause stress or depression in most healthy women, and it may even improve mental health for some.

title: Expos Top Pirates on Rookie's Homer in 10th
description: Marquis Grissom, a rookie for the Expos, singled and scored the tying run in the bottom of the ninth, then hit his first home run of the season in the 10th, a three-run shot that gave Montreal an 8-7 victory today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Bail of $10 Million Set for Brando Son Charged in Killing
description: Christian Brando, 32-year-old son of the actor Marlon Brando, has been ordered to stand trial for murder in the fatal shooting of his half-sister's boyfriend and is being held on unusually high bail of $10 million.

title: Arson Charged As Fire Levels A Shantytown
description: A homeless woman involved in a lovers' quarrel set fire to a shack under the West Side Highway yesterday morning, setting off a blaze that reduced a shantytown to rubble, fire officials said.

title: Brunswick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included after-tax charges of $6.1 million for costs associated with production cutbacks and reductions in force in the company's marine segment.

title: Two Koreas Sign Pact For High-Level Visits
description: North and South Korea signed an agreement today for an exchange of visits this year by their Prime Ministers.

title: Cause of Kidney Failure Is Curtailed in Animals
description: Scientists have devised an experimental treatment that dramatically stops scarring from a kidney disease in animals and holds promise for preventing the same problem in humans.

title: Indian in Takeover Is Paroled
description: An American Indian charged in the armed takeover of a newspaper in Lumberton in 1988 has been granted parole from a work-release program in Charlotte. The Indian, Timothy Jacobs, received a six-year prison sentence in June 1989 after pleading guilty to second-degree kidnapping. Mr. Jacobs and another Indian, Eddie Hatcher, took over the The Robesonian on Feb. 1, 1988, holding 20 people hostage for 10 hours. They said they were trying to draw attention to racial injustices.

title: Castro, Standing Firm Against the Tide, Is Bracing Cuba for Harder Times
description: With an end to large-scale Soviet economic subsidies to Cuba in sight, the Government of Fidel Castro has begun warning people here to prepare for the worst.

title: Racial Tensions Are Down
description: LEAD: From what is said in much of the media, one would think the state of race relations in America had deteriorated to a postwar low. But nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Phone Company In Bond Offering
description: The Southern New England Telephone Company offered $100 million in 40-year bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Betz Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Frisson My Timbers
description: What is it that runs down your spine when you see movie scenes like the unforgettable moment in ''Wait Until Dark'' when Alan Arkin, seemingly dead, suddenly leaps across the room at the blind Audrey Hepburn? A shiver of fear? No, not if you mean to be, well, au courant. To judge by current journalistic fashion, you should be experiencing a frisson, a French term for shiver or shudder.

title: Tyson to Fight Stewart
description: Don King is back promoting fights only eight days after achieving what he called a total victory over James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, and his manager, John Johnson, in an out-of-court settlement of a breach-of-contract suit.

title: Tenneco Net Rises 14%
description: Tenneco Inc. announced today that its second-quarter earnings rose 14 percent from a year earlier. Net income totaled $206 million, or $1.61 a share, compared with $180 million, or $1.38 a share, in the 1989 second quarter. Revenue of $3.64 billion in the latest quarter was down slightly from $3.66 billion in last year's quarter. Earnings improvements were posted in the natural gas pipelines, automotive parts, shipbuilding and chemicals and minerals divisions, while farm and construction equipment profits fell.

title: Yields Down Only a Bit
description: Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report continued to decline in the week ended yesterday. The declines, however, were not significant.

title: For Dinkins, Ballroom's Fate Is Emotional and Sensitive Issue
description: Blocks from the apartment where he raised his children, a somber hulk of a building, rich with history and once stained with blood, haunts Mayor David N. Dinkins these days. It embodies a hero of his past and his hopes for his old neighborhood's future, challenging him to balance the two.

title: A New Focus Revives Storage Technology
description: Companies, like people, often emerge from a brush with disaster intent on making the most of their second chance. Few, however, have enjoyed a more impressive comeback than Storage Technology Inc.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: Revenue represented operating revenues.

title: Jail Term for Takeover Specialist
description: Donald C. Carter, the brash confidant to a generation of takeover artists, was sentenced yesterday to 16 months to four years in state prison. In March he pleaded guilty to one count of larceny and one count of tax fraud.

title: KEY RATES
Personal Health
description: Children are not the only ones who go on holiday when the school year ends. A little-known virus that causes mini-epidemics among elementary school children in April, May and June also takes a break.

title: Chronicle
description: It costs $5,000 to restore one horse on the antique carousel in Prospect Park and HILDY SIMMONS and ANITA NAGER are celebrating their 40th birthdays. Those numbers add up to a party tonight at the Prospect Park Picnic House, where Ms. Nager, the grants administrator for the Fund for the City of New York, and Ms. Simmons, a vice president of J. P. Morgan & Company, have invited about 150 friends for Brooklyn-brewed beer and a picnic.

title: Vice President's Wife Released After Surgery
description: Marilyn Quayle was released from Bethesda Naval Hospital today, four days after undergoing a hysterectomy, the Vice President's press office said.

title: Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it would start a print advertising campaign to convince parents of the importance of education. The ads, created by McCann-Erickson, are not wholly altruistic; they point out how the company's calculators and other products can help American children compete in the global economy.

title: O. C. Rowntree, 78; Led Mustard Company
description: O. Cedric Rowntree, a former chairman of the R. T. French Company, maker of French's mustard and other food products, died yesterday at his home in Rochester. He was 78 years old.

title: One of Britain's Pillars Is Testing Its Strength
description: Under its new editor, the former columnist Simon Jenkins, Britain's oldest and best-known daily newspaper, The Times, is trying to regain its former glory.

title: Peter A. Brandon, 76, Former Hat Executive
description: Peter Amman Brandon, a former vice president of a hat-design company, Mr. John, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: Colts Sign Zendejas
description: Max Zendejas, a place-kicker who has played for the Washington Redskins and the Green Bay Packers, signed a two-year contract with the Indianapolis Colts on Tuesday.

title: Obscene Album Charge Denied
description: A record store owner who refused to stop selling a 2 Live Crew album pleaded not guilty Tuesday to a charge of promoting obscene material. David Risher, owner of Hog Wild Records and Tapes, was released on a personal recognizance bond after a hearing before Judge Tony Jimenez 3d of Bexar County Court. Mr. Risher's lawyer, Bob Switzer, said he intended to show in a jury trial that the album, ''As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' was not obscene.

title: Souter and Senate: How Far Should Questions Go?
description: The nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court has reopened with particular ferocity a debate that has been going on for nearly two centuries over how far the Senate may go in exploring a nominee's views on the most profound public questions of the day.

title: As Johnny Learns to Shop, Hiroko Learns to Think;   Lengthen School Year
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines;   5 Indicted by U.S. In '89 Cocaine Seizure
description: The Federal Government announced the arrest and indictment of five men yesterday, including one described as a high-ranking member of the Colombian Cali drug cartel, in connection with the importation of five and a half tons of cocaine in 1989, the largest amount ever seized in New York City.

title: Chrysler Plans To Close Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would close a Canadian plant and consolidate all of its Jeep production at its Toledo, Ohio, complex.

title: Signature of Distinction: The Rise and Fall of a Legend
description: There are New Yorkers who say they live in a T. D'Alessandro building and do so in the knowing, complicitous tones usually reserved for boasting of landmarks by Stanford White or living rooms by Billy Baldwin.

title: NEW ORLEANS JURY ACQUITS OFFICIAL
description: The longtime District Attorney of New Orleans, Harry Connick, was acquitted today of Federal charges that he had aided and abetted an illegal gambling operation.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Are Higher
description: Treasury bond prices rose and long-term interest rates fell yesterday on evidence of further weakness in the economy and an indication that at least one key member of the Federal Reserve Board opposes the central bank's current stance on monetary policy.

title: Norfolk's Profit Falls 10.2%
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said today that its second-quarter earnings fell 10.2 percent from a year earlier, when the company had a one-time $13.6 million gain.

title: More AIDS Testing Recommended
description: Federal health officials are recommending that hospitals in areas with large numbers of AIDS cases should routinely offer testing for the disease to all their other patients.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: GE Aircraft
description: GE Aircraft Engines, a unit of the General Electric Company, said Air Afrique had placed a $150 million order for its CF6-80C2 high-bypass turbofan engine for eight Airbus Industrie aircraft. GE Aircraft said Air Afrique, an African consortium, is the largest operator of GE CF6 engines in Africa. With this order, Air Afrique will introduce the first A310-300 aircraft into the regional market in 1991.

title: Ex-Passaic Housing Official Admits He Lied to Congress
description: A former Passaic Housing Authority official admitted today that he lied to Congress during a Federal investigation of mismanagement in the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Metro Matters;   Risks to Cuomo If the Opposition Lacks Credibility
description: Despite his self-confidence and his apparent lead in public opinion polls, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo arguably cannot afford to debate his Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret.

title: When the Mind Goes Blank: Crisis for the Elderly
description: It can be a moment of dread for the elderly.

title: Stay Iraq's Scimitar, Together
description: Saddam Hussein has made Iraq a threat to peace and commerce in the Persian Gulf, and beyond. He started the savage eight-year war with Iran. He recently brandished missiles at Israel. And now he's picking on weak Kuwait. Unless Western and Arab nations react firmly and quickly, his bullying could ignite another war in the fragile Middle East.

title: For a Loved Poet, a Moscow Eulogy
description: A decade into death, Vladimir Vysotsky's bardic voice was heard at his graveside today, carrying in throaty scraps from the portable tape recorders of some of the tens of thousands of devotees who trooped past to honor his continuing lyrical power over the nation.

title: Britain to Cut Force in Germany by a Half
description: Britain said today that it planned by the mid-1990's to withdraw half of the more than 66,000 troops it has stationed in West Germany and to cut the nation's overall regular forces by 18 percent.

title: John Cleary, Ex-Chief Of Con Ed, Dies at 88
description: John V. Cleary, a former president of Consolidated Edison, died on Monday at the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., where he lived. He was 88 years old.

title: Miscellany
description: * Body Copy, a quarterly advertising trade magazine that was started in Los Angeles last year, will suspend publication, its publisher, David Breznau, said.

title: 3 Studios Pursue One Tale: Robin Hood's
description: Hungry for material for its stars, Hollywood has decided to revive the legend of Robin Hood. No fewer than three different companies have been jockeying for months to bring the hero of Sherwood Forest back to the screen in separate productions next year, well aware that at least one of those projects is bound to fall by the wayside.

title: At Love Canal, Land Rush on a Burial Ground
description: In Love Canal, the abandoned neighborhood built around 21,800 tons of buried toxic chemicals and sludge, lawns are being reseeded, roofs reshingled and houses painted a gleaming white.

title: Computer Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
