description: Year-ago first quarter included $870,000 in equity earnings from an ownership interest in Infonet, which Computer Sciences divested.

title: INSIDE
description: House Sustains Veto Of Family Leave Bill

title: Digital Has Its First Loss Ever
description: Feeling the effects of a changing computer industry, the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday reported the first quarterly loss in its 25-year history as a public company and declared a $400 million charge for retraining staff, closing operations and reducing total employment by 5,000 to 6,000.

title: Amdahl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are diluted.

title: Avon Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Occidental Notes Are Priced at $100
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation offered $150 million in senior 20-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: Clorox Assignments
description: The Clorox Company said it would reassign the advertising accounts for Pine-Sol cleaner and Combat insecticide, which it is acquiring from the American Cyanamid Company. Pine-Sol will go to the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam, while DDB Needham in Chicago will get Combat. The incumbent agency is Carrafiello Diehl & Associates, Irvington, N.Y.

title: As Johnny Learns to Shop, Hiroko Learns to Think;   Look to the Family
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: BRIEFS
description: * Caesars World Inc., Los Angeles, said it had started its $22-a-share tender offer for the 2,175,945 outstandinng shares of Caesars New Jersey Inc. common stock it does not own.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Federal Appeals Court Stays Killer's Execution in Florida
description: A Federal appeals court issued a temporary stay today 12 hours before Anthony Bertolotti was to be executed.

title: Captain in Alaska Oil Spill Loses License for 9 Months
description: The Coast Guard today suspended the captain's license of Joseph Hazelwood for nine months for his actions as the skipper of the Exxon Valdez when she ran aground off Alaska in March 1989.

title: Zambia's Leader Announces Plan to Free 1,000 Prisoners
description: Under heavy pressure to make political reforms, President Kenneth Kaunda said today that he would free more than 1,000 prisoners by the end of next month, including some accused of plotting to overthrow him.

title: Bronx Livery Driver Is Slain
description: A 61-year-old livery-cab driver was shot in the head and killed in a robbery in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. He was the 19th livery-cab driver and 20th cabdriver of any kind killed in New York City so far this year. The driver, George Fitzgerald, who worked for the Bessie Cab Company, was shot once in the head in front of 1155 Cromwell Avenue in the Highbridge section at 1:45 A.M. The police said the driver picked up a passenger who asked to be taken to the Cromwell Avenue address, where an accomplice might have been waiting.

title: He Was (and Is) The Architect To the Stars
description: LEAD: HOLLYWOOD celebrities were among his early clients. Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz lived in a house Paul Revere Williams designed for them; so did Frank Sinatra, Cary Grant, Betty Grable, Humphrey Bogart, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, Barbara Stanwyck and William Holden, who held Ronald and Nancy Reagan's wedding reception in his house.

title: New President in Line To Be Southeast Chief
description: Douglas E. Ebert, who left the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in the spring after 22 years, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Miami-based Southeast Bank N.A. and is scheduled to become the bank's next chief executive.

title: Allegheny Ludlum reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: Year-ago share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective July 2.

title: Airbus Contract Is Given to Rohr
description: Airbus Industrie will pay Rohr Industries $1 billion to supply 800 jets with engine nacelle systems, the aerodynamic structures that surround jet engines. In 1984, Rohr made a similar deal with the European consortium, involving 200 Airbus A320's.

title: Leftovers Become Sustenance For Needy
description: The dinner menu, once again, was to be United States Department of Agriculture canned pork, canned corn and rice at a homeless shelter here for 50 single men and women with children.

title: Ex-Broadway Dancer Killed in Bronx
description: A teen-ager who had danced on Broadway was killed in the Bronx early Tuesday morning when a sniper with a machine gun fired on his car and riddled it with bullets. The shots came from an apartment-building roof where young drug-gang members regularly shoot weapons for thrills, the police said yesterday.

title: Vapor of a Cleaning Solvent Is Linked to Cincinnati Blast
description: Vapors of a cleaning solvent leaking from equipment used to mix chemicals led to the deadly explosions and fire that rocked a chemical plant last week, a fire investigator says.

title: Souter Meets With Leaders of Senate In Session of Humor and Good Will
description: Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's choice for the Supreme Court, visited the Senate's Democratic and Republican leaders today in a relaxed atmosphere that reflected the absence of active opposition to his nomination so far.

title: Centerior Energy Corp. reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago 12 months results included the writeoff of nuclear plant investments.

title: Shuttle to Be Taken Off Pad After Work on Leak Fails
description: In spite of attempts to seal off leaks, hydrogen fuel seeped from the space shuttle Atlantis in tests today, and the craft will be removed from its Florida launching pad for more extensive repairs, space agency officials said.

title: As Baby Boomers Turn 40, Ammirati and BMW Adjust
description: Ammirati & Puris, the agency whose ads for BMW's ''Ultimate Driving Machine,'' Club Med and Waterford crystal helped establish the 1980's as the ''Me Decade,'' is doing an about-face.

title: Book Advances Stir Surprise, Not Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: CRI Insured Mortgage Assn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said comparable results for 1989 are unavailable because the company was not yet operating.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Dandees Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Saturday about a proposed acquisition by Watsco Inc. referred erroneously to stock action by the company. Watsco shareholders have not approved a reverse stock split.

title: Why Mowing the Lawn Is Fun Again
description: ALMOST as soon as I bought it 15 years ago, I wanted to get rid of my gasoline lawn mower.

title: Clifford Harvuot, 77, A Baritone at the Met
description: Clifford Harvuot, a baritone who performed regularly at the Metropolitan Opera from 1947 to 1975, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Metro Datelines;   Gunman Sentenced In Detectives' Deaths
description: A 26-year-old man was sentenced yesterday to the maximum of 52 years to life in prison for killing two New York detectives with another detective's gun on a highway in Queens in November.

title: Nicaragua's Economic Slide Led to Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: Bally Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $3,340,000, or 12 cents a share, from the early retirement of debt. c-Included a gain of $33.9 million, or $1.08 a share, on the sale of Bally's Aladdin's Castle Amusement Center subsidiary and charges of $8.4 million related to the planned relocation of several facilities and other items.

title: Turkoman Rugs Tell A Tale Of War
description: JOYCE LOWE, a rug buyer for the carpet-store chain Sandler & Worth, traveled to Pakistan in May and returned with a cache of colorful flat-weave rugs made by Turkoman nomads, refugees from Afghanistan. But while the techniques and colors are traditional, the designs reflect the experience of a country at war.

title: In the Nickname of Time
description: Centenary College, a small Methodist institution in New Jersey, takes its name from the fact that it opened in 1867, the 100th anniversary of American Methodism. Until last fall it had no nickname. Its teams weren't the Lions or the Tigers or the anything. So it ran a contest.

title: Robber Makes Fatal Mistake
description: An armed robber was shot to death early Tuesday after he burst into a motel room unaware that seven armed officers were inside setting up a drug trap, the authorities said. The officers were in adjoining rooms when Darnell Madison, 37 years old, brandishing a revolver, and Jacqueline Lynn Simmons, 21, entered. As Ms. Simmons was collecting wallets, one of the officers managed to draw his gun and shoot Mr. Madison, the police said. Ms. Simmons was arrested.

title: Lewis Wins Long Jump, Lengthens Streak to 64
description: Carl Lewis extended one of the most remarkable streaks in track and field history tonight, winning the men's long-jump competition at the Goodwill Games for his 64th consecutive victory in the event.

title: Blind Man Hikes 1,200 Miles
description: A North Carolinian has passed the halfway mark in an attempt to become the first blind man to walk the 2,143-mile Appalachian Trail. Since he left Georgia on March 9, Bill Irwin has hiked more than 1,200 miles over some of the roughest terrain in the East. The 49-year-old hiker, who is accompanated by his guide dog Orient, hopes to reach Mount Katahdin in Maine, the northern end of the trail, by October.

title: Bankers Set to Extend Trump Loan Deadline
description: Bankers are preparing to extend the deadline on the bridge loan that saved Donald J. Trump from bankruptcy as they continue to prepare the documentation for a permanent loan package, bankers involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: Computer Horizons Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Included a gain of $1,042,000, or 42 cents a share, from accounting change.

title: Longer Rest for Gooden
description: The Mets decided today to give Dwight Gooden two extra days to rest his stiff right shoulder, scratched him from his scheduled start on Friday, and said he would pitch Sunday against the St. Louis Cardinals in Shea Stadium.

title: Coast Distribution System reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed the increase in sales to the acquisitions of Griffin Marine and Mohawk Trailer Supply.

title: A Mingling of Antiques and Flowers
description: THEY met by chance a few weeks ago.

title: Market Place;   Western Union's Reorganization
description: AFTER six years of financial turmoil, including two close calls with filing for bankruptcy, a drastically smaller Western Union Corporation may be on the verge of emerging as a company that can meet its obligations.

title: Electronic Data Systems And G.M.A.C. in Profit Rise
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation posted solid second-quarter earnings gains, but profits slipped 21.3 percent at the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, which includes Hughes Aircraft and Delco Electronics.

title: Honduran Guilty of Kidnapping, Not Murder, of U.S. Drug Agent
description: A Honduran drug trafficker was found guilty today of racketeering, kidnapping and conspiracy in the abduction and killing of a Federal drug agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, and his pilot in Mexico.

title: Cigna Keeps Unit
description: The Cigna Corporation said it had decided to keep its individual financial services division, which had revenues of more than $600 million and net income of $61 million in 1989. The company said it received several offers for the unit over the last 18 months, but that none matched the value to Cigna of retaining the unit. It said the decision would not affect reported financial results or its current share-repurchase program.

title: B. J. Viviano, 79, Dies; Lawyer and Sports Star
description: Bartholomew J. Viviano, a lawyer who had been a college football star, died on Wednesday at his home in Sea Bright, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Knoll Being Sold To Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed to buy Knoll International Inc., a privately held maker of office furniture based in New York that has about 2,800 employees. The acquisition would make Westinghouse one of the three largest makers of office furniture. No terms were announced.

title: Burrell's Debut a Hit
description: Scott Burrell, who is attempting careers in both pro baseball and college basketball, is happy with his debut as a minor league pitcher with the St. Catharines (Ontario) Blue Jays of the Class A New York-Penn League Wednesaday night.

title: Wilbur S. Smith, 78, a Designer Of Major Transportation Systems
description: Wilbur S. Smith, a retired international transportation designer and developer, died on Wednesday at the Providence Hospital in Columbia, S.C. He was 78 years old and lived in Columbia.

title: Disciplinary Actions by the House
description: EXPULSION

title: TV Weekend;   Skip the Pen, Forget the Paper; Just Send Videos
description: CBS is having a promising run with original programming this summer. At 10 P.M. on Thursdays, the network is doing very nicely indeed with ''Northern Exposure,'' a show about a doctor from New York who moves to Alaska. And at 9:30 P.M. on Fridays, there is ''Wish You Were Here,'' the second episode of which can be seen this evening.

title: OPEC Moves Closer to a Pact on Production
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved closer today to an agreement that would set a ceiling on its 13 members' production of 22.5 million barrels a day and raise oil prices to at least $20 a barrel.

title: G.O.P. FAVORS LIMIT ON TAX DEDUCTIONS FOR LOCAL LEVIES
description: The Bush Administration and senior Congressional Republicans have agreed on a budget proposal that would limit the amount of state and local income taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal returns, Congressional officials said today.

title: U.S. Team Winner In Relays
description: The track and field competition of the Goodwill Games ended tonight with the United States and the Soviet Union winning events in which they have long excelled.

title: Boeing Net Nearly Doubles
description: The Boeing Company said its net income for the second quarter nearly doubled from a year ago because of continuing strong shipments of commercial airplanes. But the company said it continues to have problems in its military and space businesses, and it expects them to post a significant operating loss in 1990.

title: Goodyear, Citing Costs, Reports Loss
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's second-largest tire producer, yesterday reported a second-quarter loss of $9.4 million, reflecting costs associated with belt-tightening and reorganization.

title: How a School Grew, With Alumna's Help
description: When Filomen D'Agostino Greenberg of Coney Island first arrived as a student at New York University Law School, she found five small, cramped rooms in a single building east of Washington Square Park. The year was 1917.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about Pennsylvania companies' rejection of the state's takeover protection misidentified the nation's largest pension fund.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two weeks ago, after a 12-year court fight, DR. ROBERT W. KEARNS won a $5.2 million verdict against the Ford Motor Company for infringement on his patents for the intermittent windshield wiper. Yesterday, the 63-year-old former engineering professor at Wayne State University, was in the Montgomery County Detention Center in Rockville, Md., for failure to honor a separation agreement with his wife, PHYLLIS KEARNS.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The case of the perplexing pompano has been settled out of court. It started last August when JEAN-CLAUDE BAKER, the owner of Chez Josephine on West 42d Street in Manhattan, arrived with three guests at Sapore di Mare, a fashionable restaurantin East Hampton, L.I., owned by PINO LUONGO. By all accounts, Mr. Baker ordered pompano. The fish arrived. He said it was mushy and sent it back. The waitress said he would still have to pay for it. He agreed.

title: Earle Mack Wed To Carol Dickey
description: Carol Dickey, an interior designer in New York, and Earle I. Mack, the chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, were married last evening at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Bert Mack, in Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbis Israel Mowshowitz and Moshe Pomerantz officiated.

title: Notes and Bonds Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers watched the progress of budget negotiations in Washington and waited for a preliminary report this morning on how much the economy grew in the second quarter.

title: Times-Prentice Hall Venture
description: Prentice Hall and The New York Times will offer a program to help college students and professors use current events in studying major subjects, according to a joint announcement from the companies yesterday.

title: Ashton-Tate Plan
description: The Ashton-Tate Company, a computer-software producer based in Torrance, Calif., said it would introduce a new version of its dBASE IV software next Tuesday, but it cautioned against expectations that the product would help the company return quickly to profitability. A spokeswoman said the software, called dBASE IV Version 1.1, would be introduced to analysts and the media in New York. Ashton-Tate had a second-quarter loss of $12.6 million on revenues of $48.1 million.

title: Kenya Rearrests a Freed Lawyer, Saying His Magazine Is Seditious
description: One of three Kenyan lawyers formally released from detention on Wednesday was arrested again and charged today with publication of a seditious magazine.

title: New Faces: Adrienne Shelly and Robert Burke;   2 Performers Who've Lived Their Roles
description: Although 24-year-old Adrienne Shelly and 29-year-old Robert Burke are making their screen debuts in Hal Hartley's film ''The Unbelievable Truth,'' both actors seem to have known their characters inside out before even reading the script.

title: Review/Art;   The State of the City as Sculptors See It
description: EACH year the outdoor sculpture season seems to have more to say about the art and life of New York City. With some artists seeking exposure, others trying to define for themselves the meanings of public art, still others trying to leave their stamp on a street or square, and with all the artists now trying to wrestle with urban dramas for which it seems no author or director exists, the outdoor sculpture season has become a way of gauging not only the state of the art world but also the state of the city.

title: Coast S.& L. Reports Loss
description: Coast Savings Financial Inc., the parent company of a Los Angeles-based savings and loan association, said today that it lost $28.7 million in the second quarter after adding to its loss reserves to reflect problems in several real estate markets. In the period a year earlier, Coast earned $5.8 million, or 41 cents a share.

title: Review/Film;   Dreams of Glory Fueling A Short Bout of Gore
description: According to the standards by which deranged, joy-riding killers are measured, Georgina Grayson and Ricky Allen, an English showgirl and an American G.I. who teamed up in London in 1944, weren't much. Their spree took the life of only one victim, a taxi driver who gave the so-called cleft-chin murder its nickname. And it was fueled, on the evidence of ''Chicago Joe and the Showgirl,'' by the most pitifully tawdry and mundane of pipe dreams.

title: American People Need Stealth and Aegis
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Reaches an Accord On Legislation for Oil Spills
description: Negotiators representing the Senate and the House of Representatives today completed work on a compromise bill on oil spills, and lawmakers said final action on the measure was likely before the Congress takes its August recess.

title: Ousted Arts Official Gets New Federal Job
description: Alvin S. Felzenberg, who was asked to leave his job as senior deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts on May 25 by John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the agency, has been named executive director of the President's Commission on the Federal Appointment Process, a spokesman for the White House said today.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: New Jersey Will Benefit From Florio's School District Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 409690 -- No Title
description: The First National Bank of Chicago yesterday offered $700 million in securities backed by credit-card receivables through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc..

title: Arts Honors Announced
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced today that its 1990 honors will go to the jazz trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, the actress Katharine Hepburn, the opera singer Rise Stevens, the composer Jule Styne and the film director and writer Billy Wilder.

title: Senators Tell Souter What to Expect at Hearings
description: Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, spent a second day on Capitol Hill today and was told by both Democratic and Republican senators to expect to answer questions about his judicial philosophy and his views on the Supreme Court's role.

title: Compaq Profits Rise 24.3%; Sales Disappoint Wall St.
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its net income rose 24.3 percent in the second quarter, to $104.3 million, or $1.18 a share, from $83.9 million, or 98 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is an overall attitude out there that life is cheap.

title: Hunter Guard Charged In Stabbing of Student
description: A Hunter College student was stabbed in the chest in the lobby of his dormitory early yesterday morning by a security guard on duty in the lobby, whom the student had complained about, the police said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   2 HEADS OF STATE CALL ON WALDHEIM
description: Presidents Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia and Richard von Weizsacker of West Germany met with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria today, further eroding efforts over the last four years to isolate Mr. Waldheim diplomatically because of his war record.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article on the Media Business page on Wednesday about the Interpublic Group of Companies misstated the revenue effect of its exchange of an interest in Lowe Marschalk for more ownership of the Lowe Group. Since its completion in July last year, the transaction has reduced domestic revenue; it did not increase 1989 second-quarter earnings.

title: Market Place;   Investors Struggle to Value RJR Nabisco's New Issue
description: Investors are trying to determine the value of the new RJR Nabisco security that will be exchanged for some of the company's ''junk bonds.''

title: Mussorgsky's 'Pictures'
description: The guitarist Kazuhito Yamashita is to perform his arrangements of Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' and Bach's Cello Suite No. 6 at 5:30 P.M. on Sunday at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. The program is also to include Toru Takemitsu's ''Folios I, II and III'' and Fernando Sor's ''Variations on a Theme by Mozart'' (Op. 9). Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: Review/Theater;   Eluding the Language Police After Spanish Is Outlawed
description: By the time ''The English Only Restaurant'' ends, you wonder what language, if any, you have been hearing during its 90 minutes. It hardly matters; the meaning is beyond mere words. This wild musical farce by Silvio Martinez Palau, with music and lyrics by Sergio Garcia-Marruz and Saul Spangenberg, mauls the English and Spanish languages and lampoons the pretensions of upwardly mobile Latinos, the snobberies of English-speaking Americans, critics, the police, reporters, high fashion, trendy restaurants and many other absurdities that happened to catch the attention of the playwright and lyricists.

title: Bond Setback Is Reported
description: Australia's highest court reportedly ruled today that Alan Bond, the beleaguered entrepreneur, is unfit to hold broadcasting licenses.

title: British Utility In Loss for Year
description: National Power P.L.C., a Government-owned British electric utility that is preparing for privatization, today posted a loss of $:605 million, or $1.1 billion, for the year and said it would cut 5,000 jobs over the next five years.

title: Review/Film;   Who Killed a Prosecutor? Her Lover? Or Another?
description: A magician deliberately orchestrates his audience's suspicions as a means of concealing the real tricks of his trade. Scott Turow accomplished something very similar with ''Presumed Innocent,'' his spellbinding courtroom novel in which the narrator finds himself accused of having murdered a seductive co-worker. Mr. Turow's sleight of hand is so tremendously skillful that his novel is not even diminished by a knowledge of just where responsibility for this crime ultimately lies. The book actually improves with a second reading, when the author's tactics can best be appreciated.

title: The Cardinal, Comity and AIDS
description: New York State desperately needs 3,000 nursing home beds, mostly in New York City, for AIDS patients. It has received applications from various service agencies willing to sponsor 1,700. Among the sponsors is the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which promises to provide 400 beds, half of them almost immediately. The State Health Commissioner, David Axelrod, is naturally eager to act on this offer. But there's a problem.

title: Review/Fashion;   Givenchy and Valentino Revel in Luxury
description: Exquisite fabrics, intricate workmanship and plenty of jewel embroidery, the hallmarks of couture fashions, were the real stars of the last two major fall and winter showings. Hubert de Givenchy, now part of the LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton empire that controls Christian Dior and Christian Lacroix, appropriately dedicated his collection to ''luxury and quality.''

title: Panel Plans Special Services District for Times Sq.
description: A committee of Times Square business and community leaders announced plans yesterday to create a special district that would provide everything from sanitation to security services for Times Square.

title: Ex-BankAmerica Head Joins Investment Firm
description: Samuel H. Armacost, who ran the BankAmerica Corporation as it fell into crisis several years ago, has joined Weiss Peck & Greer, an investment firm involved in management buyouts and venture capital.

title: Ms. Boyd Weds Mr. Conner; Couple to Honeymoon in Jail
description: Sheila Maria Boyd and Jerry Conner, both of Brooklyn, were married yesterday in Queens Borough Hall. Afterward, they celebrated at Cobblestone's Restaurant, a few blocks away at 117-18 Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Auctions
description: Asian Gods in Stone

title: A Law for Every American
description: There have been many bill-signing ceremonies at the White House, but none quite like yesterday's. Under a hot summer sun on the South Lawn, more than 2,000 advocates for the disabled, many in wheelchairs, cheered mightily as President Bush signed a law that could bring 43 million handicapped people into society's mainstream.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the price paid by the Saatchi & Saatchi Company to buy two advertising agencies in 1986.

title: U.S. Inquiry Into Stock Transfer By Dinkins Ends Without Charges
description: Federal prosecutors have ended their investigation into Mayor David N. Dinkins's transfer of Inner City Broadcasting stock to his son without filing criminal charges, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew J. Maloney, said yesterday.

title: Big S.& L. Loss In San Diego
description: The Great American Bank, a troubled savings and loan in San Diego, reported a large loss for the second quarter because of the deterioration of its portfolio of Arizona real estate.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Bayou Bistro

title: Jet Safety Relishes Second Chance
description: Brian Washington has had a taste of the football world and a taste of the real world and right now, he thinks the football world is where he belongs. The Jets think he might be right.

title: Soviet Astronauts Shut Station's Faulty Hatch
description: Two Soviet astronauts closed a faulty hatch on their orbiting station today during a three-and-a-half hour walk in space, Soviet television said.

title: Dow Falls 10.15 Points, To 2,920.79
description: Stock prices weakened yesterday in sluggish trading, with investors continuing to show nervousness over disappointing earnings.

title: Fairs And Festivals
description: TODAY

title: Rinfret Interview: A Plan for Harlem
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor. It was conducted on Tuesday at The New York Times. Mr. Rinfret was accompanied by his campaign manager, Assemblyman John Faso of Kinderhook.

title: People
description: * Laura Eshbaugh has been named vice chairman of Whittle Communications.

title: Accounts
description: * Norwalk Furniture, Norwalk, Ohio, to W.B. Doner & Company.

title: Oyama Journal;   One Plum After Another; Still the People Leave
description: Three decades ago, when the enemy in much of rural Japan was poverty combined with brutal working conditions, this riverside farming town became a symbol of self-improvement by encouraging the local farmers to break their dependence on rice and experiment with cash crops, principally plums and chestnuts.

title: Castro Assails Spain for Standoff
description: In a speech marking the 37th anniversary of a guerrilla attack that began the Cuban revolution, President Fidel Castro bitterly criticized Spain today for the standoff involving refugees seeking asylum in its embassy here.

title: No Gamecock Sanctions
description: South Carolina's football program escaped sanctions today as the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced it had found no serious rule violations resulting from a steroid scandal that had led to prison terms for three former assistant coaches.

title: New York Hospitals to Urge AIDS Tests for Patients
description: The New York City municipal hospital system announced yesterday that it would encourage all of its adult patients to be tested for the AIDS virus, a shift aimed at helping tens of thousands of people who need treatment.

title: Microsoft On Profits
description: After reporting record earnings and revenues on Wednesday for its 15th year in business, the Microsoft Corporation cautioned today that its unusually strong profits were not likely to continue in the next fiscal year.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Betty at the Ballroom

title: Court Backs Go-Video In Suit Over Japanese
description: Go-Video Inc. said today that a Federal court had denied motions to dismiss its antitrust lawsuit against several Japanese manufacturers of videocassette recorders.

title: Ryan Loses Right Stuff In Quest for 300th Victory
description: Nolan Ryan, in shorts and sneakers without socks, sat thoughtfully in front of his locker cubicle in the Texas Rangers' clubhouse before Wednesday night's game against the Yankees. ''Butterflies?'' someone asked him. ''Always got butterflies before I pitch,'' he said, in his easy, Texas drawl.

title: Church Can't Afford to Spurn Married Priests;   Never Any Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Shulton Purchase
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said it had completed the purchase of the toiletries and fragrances portion of the American Cyanamid Company's Shulton Group, excluding the Pierre Cardin fragrance line. Under the agreement announced last month, Procter & Gamble acquired Shulton's Old Spice and Santa Fe men's toiletries and fragrances, and several other products.

title: Fire Kills 12 and Injures 25 in Lebanon as Fuel Truck Hits a Hotel
description: A fuel truck hit a hotel in eastern Lebanon today and burst into flames, starting a fire that killed 12 people and badly burned 25 others, the police said.

title: Liberian Rebels Said to Take Capital's Airfield
description: Liberian rebels have captured Spriggs-Payne Airfield, Monrovia's last communications link with the outside world, a rebel official in the nearby Ivory Coast said today.

title: Lawyer Challenges Police on Statement In Jogger Rape Case
description: A defense lawyer in the Central Park jogger case challenged the detective who handled his client's statement, accusing him of ''putting words'' in the youth's mouth.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Telecom Chief Gets MCI Post
description: O. Gene Gabbard, chairman and chief executive of Telecom USA, will become executive vice president and chief financial officer of the MCI Communications Corporation after the completion of MCI's acquisition of Telecom, MCI said yesterday. Mr. Gabbard, 50 years old, has led Telecom USA, based in Atlanta, since its formation in 1988 through the merger of his former company, SouthernNet, and the Teleconnect Company. MCI, the long-distance telephone company based in Washington, announced a $1.25 billion merger agreement with Telecom in April. William G. McGowan, 62, is chairman and chief executive of MCI.

title: BARRY SAYS F.B.I. IS AFTER BLACKS
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and his lead defense lawyer charged today that the Federal Government had an ''assault force'' of law officers that traveled the country singling out black officials for undercover operations.

title: Washington Talk;   Bush Stumps in 1990, Looking for 1988's Beef
description: The difference between the two parties may have come down to this: a can of Mace.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds increased $1.93 billion, to $391.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds rose $366 million, to $95.18 billion. Those of the 251 general-purpose funds rose $1.21 billion, to $135.91 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased $356.6 million, to $160.75 billion, the institute said.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: State Enters Labor Dispute At Daily New
description: Calling the labor dispute at The Daily News an explosive situation that could harm the regional economy, New York State's Labor Commissioner announced yesterday that he had appointed a fact-finding panel to help the two sides reach an accord on new contracts.

title: Silber Taps Public's Anger to Run a Strong Race in Massachusetts
description: Despite waging an unusual, provocative campaign that has broken many of the rules of politics and offended some women, blacks and the elderly, John R. Silber is running more strongly than expected in the Massachusetts race for governor and could be in position to win the Democratic nomination in September.

title: President Appointed At Plymouth Lamston
description: Robert Tammero, who has been president both of Bloomingdale's and of Abraham & Straus, the New York store divisions of Federated Department Stores, has been named president of the Plymouth Lamston Stores Corporation, which is owned by Tribeca Holding Corporation, a New York-based investment firm.

title: Review/Music;   A Hybrid Of Styles Encourages Bopping
description: Rock and jazz made incursions into chamber-music territory (or was it the other way around?) in ''Sonic Boom,'' Friday evening's installment of the Serious Fun series at Alice Tully Hall. The violinist Mary Rowell, the British keyboard sextet Piano Circus, the percussionist and vocalist David Moss and the Soldier String Quartet offered music that, for the most part, had a greater visceral than intellectual appeal. But the urge to bop, too rare at chamber concerts, is probably a good thing now and then.

title: Courage (Nerve?) in the Senate
description: It took some courage for the Senate formally to denounce Senator Dave Durenberger, but not much. Senator Durenberger's ethical violations were too blatant to escape the Senate's 96-to-0 judgment. What took courage - nerve is more like it - was the Senate's willingness to render ethical judgment on anyone.

title: A Dance Retreat Makes Changes, but Its Spirit Stays the Same
description: The road winds through green, heavily wooded hills and into a clearing, on the far side of which stands the theater made famous by Ted Shawn, who in 1933 founded the Jacob's Pillow summer dance festival and school. To the left stands a large, giddily striped tent that serves as a cafe and bar. Down the road, past the old farmhouse that has been turned into offices and the cabins that serve as dormitories and dance studios, an outdoor stage may be seen through the trees.

title: Earnings Plunge at G.M., Ford
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company yesterday reported sharply lower second-quarter profits. Both auto makers cited difficult market conditions in North America, and both were hit by economic disruption in Brazil that virtually stopped vehicle production there.

title: Angelo T. Acerra, 64, Bishop for the Military
description: The Rev. Angelo T. Acerra, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese for the United States Military Services, died yesterday at his home in Alexandria, Va., at the age of 64.

title: Pepsico in 3-1 Split
description: Pepsico Inc. said its board had declared a 3-for-1 stock split, payable Sept. 4 to shareholders of record on Aug. 10. The company also said its board had declared a regular quarterly dividend, as adjusted for the split, of 10 cents a share, payable Sept. 30 to holders of record on Sept. 14.

title: Our Towns;   God's Hand Seen In Deli Counter And 15 Aisles
description: Yesterday morning, Ellen Watson, who is 75, and her good friend Viola Walker were saying how lovely it was that the Governor and the Mayor were coming to dedicate the brand new Pathmark supermarket here.

title: 59th St. Bridgemarket Proposal Is Close to Fading Away
description: Having taken more than a decade to get virtually nowhere - stirring terrific controversy in the process - a plan to build an enormous marketplace in the vaulted chambers beneath the Queensboro Bridge now appears close to collapse.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Starrett City Withdraws Proposal To Offer Apartments to Soviet Jews
description: The owners of the Starrett City housing complex in southeast Brooklyn yesterday withdrew a plan to make apartments available to Soviet Jewish emigres.

title: Where to Get Teachers? It Could Be in the Army
description: Educators facing teacher shortages are working to mine a new source: the tens of thousands of soldiers due to be laid off as America's military forces shrink.

title: Assessing The Damage At Eastern
description: The indictment of Eastern Airlines on Wednesday on charges of ignoring maintenance and falsifying records could not have come at a more trying time for the carrier, industry analysts said yesterday. July is a peak travel season, and the airline has just begun an ambitious advertising campaign aimed at winning back business travelers and travel agents.

title: A Leg Problem Kept Souter Out of Service
description: David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, failed a medical examination by his draft board while a student at Harvard Law School in 1966 because one leg was found to be an inch shorter than the other, a White House spokeswoman said today.

title: At Caramoor Tonight
description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is to play Telemann's Sonata in A, Prokofiev's ''Overture on Hebrew Themes'' and the Schubert Octet (D. 803) at 9 tonight in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

title: Flow of Ethiopian Jews to Israel Is Back to Normal
description: The Governments of Ethiopia and Israel said today that the flow of Ethiopian Jews to Israel had returned to normal levels after a series of recent disruptions that had stranded thousands of Ethiopians in refugee camps.

title: Review/Film;   It's Love at First Sight, Even in the Age of AIDS
description: ''Would you still want to be my lover if I tested positive?'' Steven is still mourning his lover, who died of AIDS, when he asks Peter this tough, chilling question about the AIDS test. ''Men in Love'' would be a much better film if Peter, an exotic Hawaiian gardener, and Steven, a pale blond from San Francisco, had not fallen in love at first sight in a scene that features extreme close-ups of their star-struck eyes. These men are sitting on a beach in Maui before a post-card sunset, trapped in a soap opera tinged with new-age cosmic consciousness. But to the film makers' immense credit, Peter pauses effectively before he answers Steven's question; he is clearly considering his options and not indulging in melodrama.

title: Goodwill Games Uniting (Some of) World's Best
description: For years, sponsors and the organizer have been selling the Goodwill Games as a major world sports event. ''Uniting the World's Best,'' says the Games' promotional slogan. After a week of competition, the promise has been largely fulfilled except in track and field.

title: 2 Are Killed and 17 Injured In Soweto Railway Violence
description: Two people were killed and 17 wounded in two separate outbreaks of factional violence, the South African police reported today.

title: S.& L. Testimony Sought
description: Two developers who defaulted on loans to the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver were asked by a House subcommittee today to testify at a hearing next month. Representative Frank Annunzio, Democrat of Illinois, said he wanted to find out how the developers, William Walters and Kenneth Good, could still live in expensive homes and drive luxury cars while claiming they could not repay their loans. Neil Bush, the President's son, was on Silverado's board from 1985 to 1988, which has brought wide attention to its failure. Mr. Annunzio said if Mr. Walters and Mr. Good would not testify voluntarily, he would ask that they be subpoenaed.

title: Models For a Justice
description: Senator Warren Rudman of New Hampshire was asked the other day whether Judge David Souter especially admired any past members of the Supreme Court. Senator Rudman said he thought the Souter favorites were Justices Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. and John Marshall Harlan the younger.

title: Trade Talks Unsuccessful
description: Four days of global trade talks ended on a sour note today, with developing countries accusing rich nations of jeopardizing world commerce.

title: Earle Palmer to Acquire Franklin & Associates
description: Earle Palmer Brown, an agency with headquarters in Bethesda, Md., moved closer to its goal of becoming a major national agency yesterday by signing a letter of intent to acquire the San Diego agency Franklin & Associates Advertising and Public Relations.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Two Cultures

title: Gang Attacks 3 And Yells Slurs On West Street
description: Three men were attacked early yesterday by a gang that shouted anti-homosexual slurs at them in Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: How Commercial TV Can Pay for Public TV
description: To the Editor:

title: S.& L. Scandal: The Gang's All Here
description: LEAD: Like a herd of wildebeest sniffing a range fire yet unseen, Congress has stampeded.

title: Japanese Lessor Thrives Under Loose Regulation
description: In the staid world of Japanese finance, the Orix Corporation is like a jazz musician. It can improvise across the spectrum of financial markets more freely than securities houses and insurance companies here because, as a leasing company, it operates under a separate and more liberal regulatory system.

title: A Jazz Reunion in Brooklyn
description: WHEN Randy Weston and Max Roach join forces on Sunday afternoon for a concert in the Brooklyn Museum's sculpture garden, they will be celebrating their roots in more ways than one.

title: Brent Mydland, 37, Keyboardist In Grateful Dead Since 1979, Dies
description: Brent Mydland, the keyboardist for the rock band Grateful Dead since 1979, died yesterday at his home in Lafayette, Calif. He was 37 years old.

title: McEnroe in Quarterfinals
description: In an afternoon free of upsets at the Player's Limited International, John McEnroe, Michael Chang, Tim Mayotte and Jay Berger advanced to the quarterfinal round today.

title: SALVADORAN FOES IN RIGHTS ACCORD
description: In their first formal accord after a decade of civil war marked by brutality against civilians, negotiators for the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas agreed today to international verification of human rights.

title: Profits Off 26% At Whirlpool
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit tumbled 26 percent despite a 4.3 percent increase in revenue. The company cited economic troubles affecting its Brazilian operations.

title: 'Kids Club' Helps to Lift Burger King
description: AFTER a series of highly publicized marketing missteps Burger King may have discovered an effective tool to use in challenging rival McDonald's - children.

title: Mattingly Home in Indiana to Rest
description: Stumbling along on a course that could lead to a franchise record for losses, the Yankees face a series of decisions and deadlines that seem to have created an identity crisis.

title: G.E. Agrees to Pay $16.1 Million Fine For Pentagon Fraud
description: The General Electric Company, which was convicted in a jury trial in February of overcharging the Army for a battlefield computer system, agreed yesterday to pay one of the largest fines ever assessed for defrauding the Defense Department.

title: In the Bomb Sight: The Bomber
description: Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, says he will stop supporting the B-2, the nuclear bomber designed so cleverly that to enemy radar it's the size of a bird. He no longer sees a unique and compelling mission for the plane. Sam Nunn, his Senate counterpart, warns that the B-2 could fail in the Senate, too. Congress may thus vote to cancel the program with only 15 planes built out of a planned 75.

title: Battle for Family Leave Will Be Fought in States
description: Groups that favor giving workers unpaid leave to care for newborn babies and ailing relatives are preparing to lobby individual states for legislation to do what a Federal bill vetoed by President Bush would have done.

title: U.S. Weighs Sanctions on Iraq Over Baghdad's Oil-Dispute Tactics
description: The Bush Administration has started a wide-ranging review of American policy toward Iraq and will consider new economic sanctions and export controls as a result of Iraq's threats against two oil-producing neighbors on the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.

title: A Tardy Walk Down the Aisle Leads Straight To The Bench For a Couple (Of Young Lawyers).
description: The story could be called ''Saturday the Rabbi Arrived Late,'' though just how late remains in dispute. Or, if you prefer something more musical, it could be ''Get Me to the Synagogue on Time.'' It's also listed as Adler v. Frank in the Broward County Circuit.

title: Trial Date Set in Burn Attack
description: A Sept. 5 trial date was set yesterday for the youth accused of setting fire to David Opont, the 12-year-old who was seriously burned on the morning of March 7 in Brooklyn. The name of the suspect, who was 13 at the time of the attack, has not been released because of his age. He has been held in a juvenile detention center since his arrest, the night after the attack. Judge Joseph A. Esquirol Jr. set the trial date in Family Court in Brooklyn after rejecting a defense motion to suppress some identification evidence in the case.

title: Court in New Jersey Upholds Right to Sue Cigarette Makers
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that warning labels on cigarette packs and advertisements do not protect manufacturers against damage claims filed by smokers or their relatives.

title: U.S. Starts Removing Gas Shells in Germany
description: The United States began removing 400 tons of chemical weapons from West Germany today after environmentalists lost a last-ditch effort to stop the operation.

title: District of Columbia's Budget Clears House
description: The House on Thursday left intact funds for abortions in the District of Columbia but cut money for the city's university.

title: A 93% Pay Cut, to Just $1 Million
description: Paul B. Fireman, whose salary and bonus of $14.6 million last year as chairman and chief executive of Reebok International made him one of the highest-paid heads of a publicly held company, has agreed to take one of the biggest pay cuts ever, the company said yesterday.

title: Mandela Meets de Klerk on Plot Reports
description: President F. W. de Klerk met with Nelson Mandela tonight for what the authorities said were urgent talks on police assertions that members of the African National Congress and South African Communist Party had prepared a plot to overthrow the Government.

title: Mets Split and Share First Place With Pirates
description: The Mets split a doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals last night before 45,936 scoreboard-watching fans in Shea Stadium. But they still managed to reach a milestone when they sidestepped into a first-place tie in the National League East with the team they've been chasing all season, the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Museum to Store Stolen Art
description: The Quedlinburg treasures will be stored at the Dallas Museum of Art but not displayed there until a lawsuit contesting their ownership is settled, the museum announced yesterday.

title: Max Kamiel; Accountant, 85
description: Max Kamiel, a retired certified public accountant, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: More Setbacks for Bolar
description: Under pressure because of a generic-drug scandal, the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said on Wednesday that it would discontinue making 14 drugs and recall 4 other drugs.

title: United Banks And Norwest
description: The Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis-based banking company, said it had agreed to acquire United Banks of Colorado Inc., Denver, for about $440 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd., New York, a unit of American Express Co., appointed Suzan T. Picariello senior vice president and head of the Latin American and Caribbean region of the firm's consumer financial services group.

title: Juror Removed After Report of Phone Calls
description: A member of a Federal jury was removed by the judge from deliberations in a six-month-old money-laundering trial today after a report that the juror had telephoned members of a Colombian drug ring for more information about the case.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The crowd of 30,000 at the Padres-Reds doubleheader in San Diego on Wednesday night were not amused when ROSEANNE BARR, unfamiliar with the sound system, gave a shrill rendition of ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' When she finished, boos filled the stadium, and the comedian responded by reaching for her crotch and spitting on the ground.

title: U.S. Open Looking for a New TV Contract, Too
description: The United States Open, still looking for a more pristine alternative to its noisy, outgrown site at Flushing Meadows, is also looking for a new television contract because its $18 million agreement with CBS expires this year.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: U.S. Says Study Suggests Dentist Conveyed AIDS
description: Federal health officials yesterday reported evidence suggesting that for the first time a health professional with AIDS had transmitted the virus that causes the disease to a patient during a medical procedure.

title: Marshall Says He Never Heard of Bush's Nominee
description: Justice Thurgood M. Marshall, in remarks that were unusually candid for a member of the Supreme Court, left the clear impression in an interview broadcast last night that he thinks someone other than David H. Souter should have been nominated for a seat on the Court.

title: Church Can't Afford to Spurn Married Priests;   When Rome Listens
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: New Yorkers have become justifiably cynical about restaurants owned by celebrities. Over the years many flimsy places have opened to much fanfare and briefly attracted voyeur diners, only to disappear like second-rate summer movies. TriBeCa Grill, the ''Ten Commandments'' of movie-star restaurants, has much more going for it than just a stellar marquee.

title: Steinbrenner's Side Sought 48 Witnesses
description: The current baseball commissioner, a former commissioner, a district attorney, a hefty assortment of lawyers and investigators, Howard Cosell and a Bronx letter carrier were among 48 people whose names George Steinbrenner's attorneys presented as possible witnesses in his hearing before Fay Vincent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Chemical Co., Chicago, a petroleum and chemical company and a unit of Amoco Corp., said it would spend $200 million to expand olefins production at its Chocolate Bayou plant near Alvin, Tex.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Knicks Welcome Mustaf to Club Enthusiastically
description: He's a long, tall drink of water with the finesse of a small forward, a desire to play the power position, and according to the Knicks general manager, a probable future as an intimidating center.

title: Rinfret Urges Freeze On Spending by State
description: In a broad presentation of his fiscal policies if elected New York's governor, Pierre A. Rinfret says he would balance the state budget by freezing spending at its current level but would avoid sweeping cuts in state personnel and programs.

title: Man Tells of Stealing 13 Buses, Police Say
description: A 25-year-old from Queens who was arrested on Wednesday in the theft of a bus for a joy ride has confessed to taking 13 of the 22 buses that have been stolen in the last year, the transit police said yesterday.

title: Economic Scene;   Who Is No. 1? It's Hard to Say
description: WHICH country has the strongest economy in the world?

title: Middle-Distance Runner Has Come a Long Way
description: When Joe Falcon accepted a track scholarship to the University of Arkansas in 1985, making money from distance running or even achieving worldwide recognition were not very high on his list of priorities.

title: Review/Dance;   A Message About Women
description: The ingredients were good in Brenda Daniels's new ''Irises,'' presented last Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Ms. Daniels's dream of a dancer's body is long, slender and impressively lithe, with an amusingly blank, slightly insolent face topped by a spiky punk haircut. She has assembled a group of seven witty and able female dancers who occupy the stage with a teasing boldness. And her new three-part piece has its promise.

title: Goodwill: Dissidents And Luaus
description: rrIt has been widely reported that Soviet officials were not amused when a hockey player jumped to the Detroit Red Wings while he was supposed to be playing in the Goodwill Games this week.

title: LeMond Run Down
description: Greg LeMond is back on his bicycle, but he's hurting after his third Tour de France victory.

title: House, 408 to 18, Reprimands Rep. Frank for Ethics Violations
description: After an emotional and often rancorous debate, the House of Representatives voted today to reprimand Representative Barney Frank for ethical breaches involving his relationship with a male prostitute.

title: Jerry Zaks Goes to Work For Jujamcyn Theaters
description: Jerry Zaks, the Tony Award-winning director, has resigned as director in residence at the Lincoln Center Theater to accept a salaried, untitled position with Jujamcyn Theaters to develop plays and musicals for the company's five Broadway theaters.

title: Futures Bill Agreement Is Expected
description: The Bush Administration is close to agreeing to compromise legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission far less than the broad new authority it had wanted to regulate stock index futures, Congressional aides said tonight.

title: Dickerson Missing
description: Eric Dickerson was a no-show yesterday as veterans began arriving at the Indianapolis Colts' training camp. Dickerson, who has a $1.45 million contract this year and has said he wants to be traded, had told The Indianapolis News, ''Even if I was there, my heart and soul wouldn't be in it.''

title: Scientist Criticized for Dioxin Stand
description: A House subcommittee chairman accused a top Federal scientist today of improperly aiding the paper industry's campaign to loosen restrictions on dioxin pollution in water.

title: Disney Posts Record Profits
description: The Walt Disney Company today reported record sales and profits for the third quarter based on the continued strong performance of all of its three operating segments.

title: KEY RATES
On Stage
description: Short Stories in Song

title: Church Can't Afford to Spurn Married Priests;   Reappraisal Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ruling That Hobbles Historians
description: LEAD: Some years ago, I spent several days tramping the dismal swamps of eastern Georgia seeking the plantation where the black Walkers of Boston had served their time in slavery.

title: Stray Bullet Claims Another New York Child
description: A 3-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed yesterday when gunmen fired more than 18 rounds from semiautomatic pistols through a steel-covered door as he slept in his family's apartment. He was the third child killed in New York City this week by bullets apparently intended for someone else.

title: 2 Networks Say No To No Excuses Jeans
description: The new advertising campaign for No Excuses jeans, starring Marla Maples, is unlikely to appear on any of the three major television networks, having run afoul of their standards.

title: Church Can't Afford to Spurn Married Priests
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Photography;   Victorian Mother's Daughters: So Pure, So Romantic
description: Since irony seems to be art's most important product lately, appreciating the hyper-romantic sensibility of Victorian-era British photography requires a suspension of disbelief. True, the sugary tableaux of Henry Peach Robinson and the allegorical portraits by Julia Margaret Cameron may be viewed as precursors of the overtly fabricated art photography of the 1980's. But as much as post-modernists like Cindy Sherman may borrow from Victorian styles in their pictures, they remain profoundly skeptical of the expressive capabilities of photographs.

title: INSIDE
description: A Verdict in Camarena Case

title: Municipal Services Shrinking in Suburbs
description: Cities and towns across the New York metropolitan region are reducing services, sometimes drastically, under pressure from the slowing economy, declining state aid and a populace tired of ever-rising property taxes.

title: Bridge
description: One top-ranked team was ousted here Wednesday night in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, and another barely survived.

title:
Condominiums in the City;

Brooklyn Builder's Different Approach
description: LEAD: Residential neighborhoods with modest housing seldom attract the condominium builder unless a waterfront site or some other prime location becomes available.

title: I.C.I. Reports Drop in Profits
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. said today that its profit dropped 29.6 percent in the second quarter and announced that it was restructuring its fertilizer business.

title: Hector Torres Is Dead; Fashion Designer, 46
description: Hector Torres, a fashion designer, died July 7 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: His Story, Her Story

title: Why Voters Tune Out Political Messages
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   A Moscow Puzzle: Reforms First or Foreign Aid?
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has acknowledged that perestroika will not work without help from foreign friends, and Western economic analysts do not disagree. But they say they believe Mr. Gorbachev is putting the cart before the horse.

title: Books of The Times;   Portrait of a Tortured Artist in a Tortured City
description: Arrogance

title: Democrats Reject Offer On Campaign Spending
description: As the Senate nears a debate on revising Federal campaign financing laws, Democrats today rejected a Republican offer to place some limits on the contributions that candidates for the Senate may raise.

title: CSX Offers Notes
description: The CSX Corporation, a Richmond transportation holding company, offered $250 million worth of 10-year notes yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation. The 9 1/2 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, mature on Aug. 1, 2000. They were priced at 99.62 to yield 9.56 percent, 1.08 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes. The securities are rated A-3 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

title: New York Panel Allows Release of Phone Data
description: Three administrative law judges of the New York Public Service Commission ruled yesterday to allow the release of some of the documents that the New York Telephone Company had sought to label as trade secrets in its request for a $1.4 billion rate increase.

title: Abortion Issue a Magnet for A.B.A. Annual Event
description: Ordinarily, it might be difficult for many lawyers to get excited about the American Bar Association's annual meeting in Chicago next month, which will feature the typical round of seminars on legal issues, many boring and obscure.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Yeltsin Offers Bonus to Bring In Crop
description: Warning of a looming ''disaster'' as the nation's bumper farm crop goes unharvested, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, sought today to offer an incentive coupon plan to channel scarce consumer goods to workers who help bring in the crops.

title: Ramos to Play in Spain
description: Seeking to continue to pick up the kind of international experience members of the United States national team crave, Tab Ramos has signed a one-year professional contract with Figueres, a Second Division club in Spain. The announcement was made yesterday by the United States Soccer Federation.

title: Review/Art;   In a Show on the Issues, The Focus Is Outrage
description: ''Art in the Anchorage'' is a great way to beat the heat and feel it too. This seventh annual summer show of installation artworks, organized by Creative Time Inc., takes place in one of the city's greatest hidden interiors: the cavernous brick vaults of the Brooklyn Bridge's Anchorage (Brooklyn side), a space pleasantly immune to the waves of heat and humidity assaulting the Northeast.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on July 12 about Robert A. Roth, a New York lawyer, described his background incompletely.

title: Hampton, Giants' Top Draft Pick, Signs $2.6 Million Deal
description: The Giants' offensive backfield received a lift today when Rodney Hampton, this year's first-round draft choice, and Aaron Emanuel, the seventh-round choice, agreed to contracts.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Six New Or Recent Orchestral Works
description: Rehearsals are the private struggles by which public performance is made to seem effortless and trouble-free. There are those who would keep it that way. Symphonic music is theater too, they say. It employs its own artifices to bind listeners and music together; one is by hiding from the observer the intervening problems of learning and technique.

title: 2 Koreas Reach an Accord, Then Resume Abuse
description: Only hours after North and South Korea signed an agreement on Thursday for a historic first meeting between their Prime Ministers, hopes for rapid progress were dimmed when negotiations over a brief opening of the border next month seemed to collapse.

title: Boesky and Milken Granted Immunity by House Panel
description: A House committee voted today to grant the ''junk bond'' financier Michael R. Milken and Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted stock speculator, immunity from additional prosecution in order to get them to testify before Congress.

title: If You Want to Watch
description: Where Wien Stadium at Columbia University's Baker Field, 218th Street and Broadway.

title: Bill Limiting Cable TV Fees Is Approved by House Panel
description: The cable television industry moved closer to some re-regulation yesterday with the endorsement by a House panel of a bill to limit rates for cable service and the release of a Federal Communications Commission report recommending that some cable program producers that also own cable systems be required to sell their products to rivals.

title: A Cyprus Solution - Long Overdue
description: A ranking United Nations official familiar with the U.N.-sponsored negotiations on Cyprus's future recently told me that, in his view, of all the world's intractable problems the Cyprus situation is one that is clearly solvable. He said that progress depended on outside pressure on Turkey, especially by the U.S., to remove its troops from the island nation, and on insuring that the Greek and Turkish Governments fully participate in any agreement on Cyprus's future political structure.

title: Burgers in France
description: The Burger King Corporation, in cooperation with the French restaurant and hotel company Elitair, announced plans to open the first two fast-food restaurants at rest stops along France's national highway. One will be near Evry, southeast of Paris, on the A-6 highway. The other, a drive-through restaurant, will be near Bordeaux on the A-10 highway.

title: Phillies Rout heaton and Pirates
description: Charlie Hayes hit a two-run homer off Neal Heaton in Philadelphia's five-run first inning tonight, and Carmelo Martinez drove in three runs as the Phillies romped past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 12-4.

title: Columbia's Paul Plans To Retire Next Year
description: Al Paul, a member of the Columbia University athletic staff for 30 years and the senior athletic director in the Ivy League, announced yesterday that he would retire at the end of the next academic year, in June 1991.

title: Johnson Leads L.P.G.A. by Two
description: As some of the big names got off to poor starts, Chris Johnson, a nonwinner since 1987, shot a four-under-par 67 today and took a two-stroke lead in the richest event on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, the $1 million Mazda L.P.G.A. Classic.

title: Bonds Fall On Trump Swap Plan
description: The price of ''junk bonds'' backing Donald J. Trump's casinos fell yesterday on news that the developer was considering offering holders of the high-yield securities equity ownership in his casinos in exchange for a cut in interest payments.

title: Service for Rabbi Kelman
description: A service for Rabbi Wolfe Kelman, executive vice president of the Rabbinical Assembly for nearly 40 years, will be held at on Wednesday at 6 P.M. at the Park Avenue Synagogue at Madison Avenue and 87th Street. The participants will include Rabbis Arthur Hertzberg, professor of religion at Dartmouth College, and Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. Rabbi Kelman died on June 26 at the age of 66.

title: Scooters Increase, And So Do State Laws
description: Advocates and opponents of water scooters are disputing the crafts' safety, even as record numbers of the swift, agile boats ply waterways this summer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bemis Company, Minneapolis, a maker of industrial products, said it had entered into an agreement to acquire Milprint Inc., Milwaukee, a privately held maker of flexible packaging products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Whose Art Is It? A Dispute In Santa Fe
description: A dispute over a fresco has polarized artists in Santa Fe, N.M., and once again raised questions about such issues as an institution's responsibility to an artist whose work it has commissioned and the ultimate ownership of public art.

title: 2 Contractors' Ratings Cut
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced the debt ratings of two large military contractors, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation. Moody's Investors Service also cut the ratings of McDonnell Douglas.

title: Bridge
description: Almost all of the favored teams were still in contention today in the quarterfinal stage of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: James B. Smith Dies; Resort Owner Was 82
description: James Barker Smith, a retired resort owner, died Thursday at a nursing home in Portsmouth, N.H. He was 82 years old and lived in New Castle, N.H. His daughter-in-law, Brenda Smith, said he died of lymphoma. Mr. Smith bought Wentworth by the Sea in New Castle in 1946, when it operated only in July and August. In the following decades he built it into a major resort, open six months a year and employing more than 350 people. The hotel was sold in 1980 and closed after several changes of ownership.

title: Review/Jazz;   Swing Street And Images Of Basie
description: The swinging drive of the music and the boisterous enthusiasm of the audience suggest Saturday night on 52d Street in the 1940's. But it's actually 50 years later and 15 blocks south - the Monday night sessions of Roy Gerson's Swing Septet at Zanzibar and Grill, 550 Third Avenue, between 36th and 37th Streets.

title: Your Money;   New Software Offers Advice
description: Three new software packages offer great help in personal finance. Hyatt Legal Services' Home Lawyer and WillMaker 4.0 can help with legal matters, while Make Your Paycheck Last helps people keep their spending within their income.

title: Dinkins Still Receiving Contributions
description: Demonstrating that victory has a thousand fathers even in a non-election year, Mayor David N. Dinkins has received $974,173 in contributions since the first of the year.

title: Corrections Golf;   Bias at Private Clubs: A Test for Pro Golf
description: America's private golf clubs, stubbornly resistant to change and isolated from social turmoil, are facing the most rigorous scrutiny in their history because of restrictive admission policies.

title: Rebels Attack Center of Liberia Capital
description: More than 300 rebels invaded central Monrovia today and were locked in bitter street fighting with Government troops.

title: St. Vincent's Discovers a Financial Cure
description: A week after Margaret Broughal was brought by ambulance to St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, her left side immobilized by a stroke, physical therapists began helping her exercise her weakened body.

title: Dr. Albert Bowers, 60, Is Dead; Chemist Who Led Syntex Corp.
description: Dr. Albert Bowers, chairman and former chief executive of the Syntex Corporation, died Thursday at the University of California's San Francisco Medical Center in Palo Alto. He was 60 years old and lived in Palo Alto.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD:: Guidepost;   Refrigerating Food
description: If food that should be refrigerated is left at room temperature during the summer, it is likely to spoil in about an hour. And expiration dates on dairy products are less reliable in hot weather. Spoilage cannot always be detected, because sometimes the problem is in the toxins the food is giving off. At other times spoilage is apparent through color, odor or appearance. For more information, call the United States Department of Agriculture Meat and Poultry Food Hotline, (800) 535-4555, or the Cornell University Cooperative Extension Food Hotline, (516) 454-0900, weekdays from 1 to 3 P.M. Eastern time. Here are some foods and their shelf life under refrigeration, in days unless noted otherwise. $ Food Shelf Life Food Shelf Life Milk 4-5 Cream 10 Cheese 5-30 Eggs 4-5 weeks Beef 2 Chicken 2 Fish 1 Citrus fruit 1 week Berries, cherries 1-2 Peaches, pears 1 week Apples 1-3 weeks Tomatoes 1-2 Corn (in husks) 1-2 Lettuce 5 Spinach 3-5 Beans 1-5 Peas (unshelled) 3-5 Carrots 1-2 weeks Celery 1-2 weeks Onions 3-4 weeks

title: Why Family Doctors Are Sent to the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe: Moscow Journal;   Russian Finds a Haven In Her Solitary Museum
description: For the average Muscovite, the art of surviving with assorted strange families in a communal apartment is merely surreal on a good day, making do with noisome juxtapositions. But for Tatyana Kolodzei, who shares kitchen, toilet and corridors with an alcoholic in one bedroom and a transient day laborer in the other, the art is always avant-garde.

title: Mets Go To Top; Marshall Is Traded
description: The hits fell in, the runs poured in, so it didn't take long for the verdict to come in. The Mets, having spent the night circling the bases, couldn't help but be led to one conclusion: It not only felt good to be in first place in the National League East, it felt right. And it felt, with the Cardinals crushed by 10-1 and the Pirates for the moment in second place behind them, secure.

title: Shaw Relents, a Bit
description: Bowing under the pressure of a $5,000-a-day fine, Brian Shaw has agreed to break his contract with an Italian team, but he still doesn't want to play for the Celtics, his lawyer said this week.

title: Groups in Northeast Protest Plan to Cap Deductions for Taxes
description: Predicting devastating consequences for state and local governments throughout the Northeast, school boards, business groups and municipal officials in New York and neighboring states began a spontaneous protest today against a Bush Administration proposal to restrict the deductions for state and local taxes on Federal income-tax returns.

title: Letter: On Ecology;   Brazil's Small Share of the Greenhouse
description: To the Editor:

title: No Community Guilt In Racial Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: The Night Good Will Broke Out
description: Every one of those $26 million that Ted Turner is losing on the Goodwill Games was worth it Thursday night at a ball park here.

title: Two Filipinos Rescued 11 Days After Quake
description: Miners who heard cries of ''Help us!'' rescued two people on Friday from the rubble of a hotel that collapsed 11 days ago in an earthquake that killed more than 1,600 people.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: There are Broadway openings and then there are Broadway purifications.

title: Gordon A. Ewing, 77, Ex-Broadcast Official
description: Gordon A. Ewing, who directed United States radio programming in occupied Germany after World War II, died Tuesday at Thomas Hospital in Fairhope, Ala. He was 77 years old and lived in Fairhope. His family said he died of pneumonia.

title: Killer, 38, Is Executed in Florida
description: A 38-year-old man convicted of stabbing, raping and robbing a woman in 1983 was executed today after the United States Supreme Court rejected his assertions that Florida's electric chair was not working properly.

title: Yankees Sweep Doubleheader With Indians
description: At the end of the 13th start since Andy Hawkins was a winning pitcher for the last time, the handshakes and pats he received from his Yankee teammates tonight were heartfelt and unconditional.

title: Review/Dance;   A Fourth Cast for the Australians' 'Giselle'
description: David Ashmole, once with the Royal Ballet in Britain, and Miranda Coney were the fine new leads in the Australian Ballet's last performance of ''Giselle'' on Thursday night.

title: U.S. Drops Computer Case Against Student
description: Federal prosecutors in Chicago yesterday dropped felony charges against a 20-year-old college student in a computer crime case that has drawn national attention because of the civil liberties issues involved.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Bartholomew J. Viviano, a lawyer, misidentified and incorrectly described a Manhattan law firm where he worked after graduating from law school in the 1930's. The firm is Whitman & Ransom; it continues to operate.

title: Israeli Sees Chemical Option Against Iraqis
description: Israel can respond with its own chemical weapons if Iraq attacks it with similar arms, Science Minister Yuval Neeman said today.

title: Ertl Leads by 4 in L.P.G.A.
description: Sue Ertl shot a four-under-par 67 and took advantage of a quadruple-bogey by Rosie Jones today to take a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship.

title: New York City Schools Face $62.3 Million Budget Cut
description: New York City school officials announced plans yesterday to cut $62.3 million in planned spending for the coming school year, a figure that they said is likely to reduce the teaching force in some places and further tighten the central bureaucracy by as many as 350 positions.

title: An 'Ism' That Won't Go Away
description: LEAD: Six months of revolution in Europe have given nationalism a terrible name. The fashionable British literary magazine Granta built a recent issue around the ''ugly, ugly face of nationalism.'' And the Archbishop of Canterbury recently saw ''the specter of fresh and rival European nationalisms,'' and he urged Christian leaders to ''act together on a wider level than the nation-state.

title: Patents;   Administration Backs Bill on Biotechnology
description: The Bush Administration has agreed in principle with proposed legislation that would eliminate what biotechnology companies say is a legal loophole that allows foreign companies to evade some American patents.

title: In South Korea, Hope at Last In Budding Links With North
description: When the Berlin wall fell last year, South Koreans sat transfixed, their eyes on Europe but their minds on their own border of barbed wire, mines and tank traps, and they glumly concluded that it could never happen here. Now no one is quite so sure.

title: Social Security Panel Opposes Moynihan Plan
description: A bipartisan Federal advisory panel said today that it opposed Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security payroll taxes.

title: Defense Rests Without Barry's Taking Stand
