description: The defense in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. rested today, without putting the defendant on the stand.

title: Dow Drops 22.28 Points, To 2,898.51
description: Continuing fears of new earnings shocks, a decline in the dollar and heavy movement of money into short-term Treasury notes kept stock prices under strong pressure yesterday.

title: Saying 'I Do' to Cost More
description: In New York City, where it already costs a lot to do almost everything, it will be more expensive to do one more thing: get married. The city increased its fee for ceremonies performed by the City Clerk's office to $25, from $5, in a bill signed yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Ottawa Gesture to Mohawks
description: Canada announced today that it had bought a piece of land in an effort to help end a two-week armed standoff between the police and Mohawk Indians. But a Mohawk negotiator, Mavis Etienne, called the purchase ''a drop in the bucket.'' The standoff began after the village of Oka, Quebec, tried to expand a golf course on what the Indians call ancestral land.

title: For Peru's New Chief, a Litany of Ills
description: Alberto Fujimori, a political novice who is to take office as President of Peru on Saturday, faces the task of trying to save a nation traumatized by political terrorism, fiscal insolvency, galloping inflation and a drought that threatens the water and power supply.

title: Louisiana Abortion Bill Vetoed; Governor Calls It Too Restrictive
description: After weeks of deliberation, Gov. Buddy Roemer today vetoed legislation that would have severely restricted abortions in Louisiana, and angry legislators threatened to return to the capital and resurrect an even stricter abortion bill.

title: Religion Notes
description: On Praying for a Son There are few things that connoisseurs of antiquity enjoy more than a modern discovery that confirms the wisdom of the past. So, in recent weeks several students of the Talmud, the authoritative body of Jewish law completed in the sixth century, took pleasure in a report in the journal Nature about the discovery of a gene that determines maleness. The gene, the researchers report, begins its work in the seventh week of pregnancy, somewhere from the 43d to the 49th day.

title: Why Family Doctors Are Sent to the Country;   A Wasteful Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert S. Forman, 71, Lawyer on Long Island
description: Robert S. Forman, a lawyer from Long Island, died on Wednesday at his home in Sands Point. He was 71 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Eastern L.I. Spots a Dreaded Foe: The Brown Tide Surfaces Again
description: After a two-year absence, a mysterious algal bloom that devastated the bay scallop industry in eastern Long Island has reappeared.

title: Inquiry Set On Suchard
description: Swiss authorities have begun a formal inquiry into the possibility of insider trading in shares of Jacobs Suchard A.G. before the Swiss chocolate and coffee group agreed to be bought last month by the Philip Morris Companies for $3.8 billion.

title: Police Commissioner Named
description: The former police chief of Corpus Christi, Tex., was named today as police commissioner of Yonkers, City Manager Neil DeLuca said. The new commissioner, Robert K. Olson, was one of five finalists selected by the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police, Mr. DeLuca said.

title: Krieg Agrees to Pact
description: Dave Krieg, the Seahawks' regular quarterback for the last six seasons, has agreed to terms on a four-year contract with Seattle after missing eight days of training camp.

title: Unusual Labor Tension at U.P.S.
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc., with its almost egalitarian corporate culture and its deep roots as a high-paying union employer, might seem an unlikely target for a possible nationwide strike by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Korean Reactor Request
description: South Korea, which is negotiating to buy a nuclear reactor from Canada, wants to acquire more of the units, the president of Canada's nuclear agency said today. Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd. will submit a proposal next week to build a second 700-megawatt Candu reactor next to one in Wolsung on South Korea's southeastern coast. South Korea's national electricity company is expected to respond by the end of the year.

title: Deposit Insurance Rules
description: Notices of new rules governing Federal insurance on deposits in commercial banks and savings institutions have been mailed out in monthly bank statements.

title: New York Regents Drop Charges Against Former Medical Examiner
description: The New York State Board of Regents today dismissed all charges of misconduct against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the former Chief Medical Examiner of New York City, ending a five-year state investigation.

title: Mandela Urged to Drop Communist From Talks
description: President F. W. de Klerk has urged Nelson Mandela to exclude the leader of the South African Communist Party from negotiations on the nation's future, accusing the party of conspiracy to overthrow the white authorities.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Storage Technology Inc. misstated the year the company filed for bankruptcy protection and the year Ryal Poppa became chairman and chief executive. The filing was in 1984; Mr. Poppa assumed his new positions in 1985.

title: Review/Music;   A Rare 'Faust' by Schumann
description: Even before the rains came this evening, Schumann's oratorio ''Scenes From Goethe's 'Faust,' '' for vocal soloists, double chorus, children's chorus and orchestra, seemed ticklish fare for the small stage and outdoor acoustics of the Venetian Theater at Caramoor.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Digital Audio Tape
description: I marvel at the digital audio tape recorder I brought back from Tokyo last year, and at the portable DAT recorder I got there this year.

title: Soviet Alternatives
description: This is the Soviet Union's second city and none too pleased about it. People claim that Leningrad, with a population of some five million, sends 80 billion rubles a year to Moscow, and gets 20 billion back. The center deliberately puts Leningrad down and holds it back, they say, and they are just as aggrieved as people in minority Soviet republics.

title: Boy's Brother Was Target, Police Say
description: Detectives say they believe the gunmen who fired more than 18 bullets through a door in a Brooklyn housing project on Thursday, killing a 3-year-old boy, were trying to intimidate the boy's 19-year-old half-brother, a convicted drug dealer.

title: Review/Theater;   A Chekhovian Goulash With Odd Ingredients
description: When Ethyl Eichelberger is at his sharpest, his theatrical spoofs are sendups without being put-downs. This was the case with his one-man version of ''King Lear'' and his feminization of ''Hamlet'' (starring Black-Eyed Susan). With his new show, ''Das Vedanya Mama'' (at Performance Space 122), the result is less delirious than fragmented. As author, director and star, he has not clearly designated his target before making his assault.

title: About New York;   A 'Bum' Gleans The Discarded To Find History
description: Leo Hershkowitz grew up on the streets of the East Bronx, playing stickball, scurrying from the constabulary and thumbing his nose at authority. By the time he began school, his contrary course was set. When a teacher assigned a book, he'd read another. When given an essay topic, he'd write about something else.

title: Violence Shuts Ford's Brazil Plant
description: The Brazilian subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company has closed its plant in Sao Paulo state for repairs for an indefinite period, after striking workers went on a rampage for the third time in less than a week. Workers broke windows, damaged cars and computer terminals and started a fire in the administration building of the plant in Sao Bernardo do Campo.

title: LOSING BID OFFERED 2 TESTS ON HUBBLE
description: An unsuccessful bid for the contract to make the Hubble Space Telescope's mirrors called for a second company to double-check the grinding and polishing, a provision not offered by the company that eventually won the contract.

title: Citroen Model's Final Roll-Off
description: An automotive legend was bid a quiet adieu today. The last Deux Chevaux rolled off Citroen's assembly line here, ending 42 years of production.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgarian Interior Minister Quits Amid Furor
description: Interior Minister Atanas Semerdzhiyev resigned tonight after 1,000 demonstrators surrounded Parliament to protest a proposal that Todor Zhivkov, the deposed Communist dictator, be allowed to speak in closed session about his 35 years of authoritarian rule.

title: 7 Years Later, McMartin Case Ends in a Mistrial
description: The McMartin preschool child molesting case came to a conclusion today when a jury said it was ''hopelessly and irreversibly'' deadlocked in Raymond Buckey's retrial on charges of molesting three girls at the school. The judge declared a mistrial.

title: Newman Decision Near
description: Knick officials spent the day crunching numbers yesterday, trying to figure out whether to match Charlotte's offer to the free agent Johnny Newman or to let the scoring forward go to the Hornets without the possibility of getting compensation by trading him to another team.

title: Generic Case Sentencing
description: A Federal judge on Thursday sentenced the former president of a New York generic drug company to two years in prison and a $50,000 fine for making payoffs to employees of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Senate Votes Farm Supports For $54 Billion Over 5 Years
description: After more than a week of debate, the Senate approved legislation today to set the country's farm policy over the next five years. The program, which is expected to cost $54 billion, was approved 70 to 21.

title: New Signs of Weak Economy
description: The gross national product report indicated the United States was much closer to a recession than statistics had recognized until now. Page 29.

title: Congress Backs Curbs Against Iraq
description: The House and the Senate defied the Bush Administration today and voted to impose economic sanctions on Iraq, citing what lawmakers viewed as the human rights violations and increasingly bellicose policies of President Saddam Hussein's Government.

title: Ex-Farah Head Battles for Old Job
description: The former chairman and chief executive of Farah Inc. is trying to take back control of the ailing company that his parents founded 70 years ago, one of the nation's largest makers of men's slacks and casual clothing.

title: Junior Is Frightful, Freckled And the Bane of His Seniors
description: We aren't all blessed with Wordsworth's sense of childhood as a romantic idyll, but even hack film makers who think a malevolent orphan is raw comic material might show more imagination than they do in ''Problem Child.'' Junior is a red-haired, freckle-faced 7-year-old, a ringer for Opie on television's ''Andy Griffith Show.'' Imagine what would have happened if Andy and Aunt Bea had abandoned Opie at birth, and the unloved boy had turned into a child who writes fan letters to a famous murderer. That is the totally unfulfilled concept behind the movie.

title: Twentysomething - and Smart
description: LEAD: According to a Time cover story, my generation, which the magazine calls the ''twentysomething'' generation, is a ''lurking generation,'' with a hazy sense of identity and a short attention span. One of the few things that does distinguish us, according to Time, is what we are not.

title: Douglas-Holyfield Date
description: In an agreement reached by both camps, the heavyweight title fight between the champion, James (Buster) Douglas, and Evander Holyfield has been rescheduled from Sept. 21 to Oct. 25. The bout will still be held at the Mirage Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: U.N. Sees AIDS Toll Surging Among Women and Infants
description: At least three million women and children will die of AIDS in the 1990's, more than six times the number in the 1980's, the World Health Organization said in a report being published today.

title: OPEC IN AGREEMENT TO RAISE OIL PRICE BY CUTTING OUTPUT
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached an accord today calling for higher oil prices. This time Iraq, which has emerged as a powerful enforcer, will try to make the increase take hold.

title: New York Exempts Archdiocese From Requirements on AIDS Care
description: The New York State Public Health Council voted yesterday to exempt Catholic-operated AIDS nursing homes from requirements that patients receive condoms, safe-sex counseling, contraceptives and abortion services. The decision paves the way for the archdiocese to provide hundreds of beds to AIDS patients.

title: Hollywood Inspects Student Films
description: Even before New York University's Institute of Film and Television began its fifth annual invitational screening of student films here this week, the word had already spread across Hollywood: If you're in the market for fresh young talent, this is an event you can't afford to miss.

title: BYELORUSSIA JOINS SOVEREIGNTY MOVE
description: Another major Soviet republic, Byelorussia, approved a strongly worded declaration of sovereignty today, adding to the challenge facing the Soviet Government to accede to a vastly decentralized system.

title: Compromise on Regulation Of Index Futures Advances
description: A Treasury official said tonight that the Bush Administration would accept an agreement worked out among Republican and Democratic senators that would allow the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to retain most of its regulatory authority over stock index futures but would shift some power to both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Reserve.

title: Browns Officials Take Drug Tests
description: Cleveland Browns coaches and front-office personnel were among those tested for drugs by the National Football League on Thursday, and so was the team president, Art Modell.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Bush Will Let Japanese Buy Hercules Unit
description: President Bush said today that he would not block the sale of Semi-Gas Systems Inc. to a Japanese bidder even though the California company has a central role in the semiconductor industry's effort to overtake its Japanese rivals. Semi-Gas Systems is a primary supplier of gas distribution and control systems to American chip makers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: Yes, he was born in the U.S.A. But other than that, little is known of the baby born to BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN and his companion and musical colleague, PATTI SCIALFA.

title: Judge Souter's Future
description: History suggests that if Judge David Souter goes on the Supreme Court there's a good chance he will still be there in the year 2025.

title: Siemens in Pact
description: Siemens A.G. said it had agreed to develop and produce computer hardware in conjunction with Computer Elektronik Dresden G.m.b.H., a unit of VEB Kombinat Robotron Elektronik, an East German electronics group based in Dresden. Siemens, the big West German electrical and electronics concern, said production of Siemens computers in the Dresden plant will begin on Oct. 1. The Dresden factory will produce personal and larger computers mainly destined for markets in East Germany, the Soviet Union and other East European countries.

title: 17 Minutes Of Flying Fun
description: Continental Express Airlines hung out a help-wanted sign today for stand-up comedians to entertain passengers on its 17-minute flights between Cleveland and Detroit.

title: France Releases 5 Terrorists And Sends Them to Teheran
description: Five men convicted for acts of terrorism in France were released and sent to Iran today in what appeared to be a crucial step in a broader agreement between the French and Iranian Governments.

title: Pirates Knocked Out of First Place
description: Dennis Cook pitched five shutout relief innings and Charlie Hayes hit a home run and drove in two runs as the Philadelphia Phillies beat Pittsburgh, 5-3, tonight, knocking the slumping Pirates out of first place in the National League East.

title: U.S. and Soviet Teams Lead Goodwill Standing
description: It was just the other day that Bela Karolyi was talking about how the United States' female gymnasts were closing the gap on their Soviet counterparts, the best in the world since most people can remember. And here were the Goodwill Games to prove his point.

title: Weak Link Found for Fallout and Leukemia
description: Researchers have found a weak association between radioactive fallout from atomic testing in Nevada in the 1950's and leukemia rates in people who lived downwind, but they said the evidence was not strong enough to prove the tests caused the cancer.

title: Baker Hints at Direct Contact With Phnom Penh
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Washington might further modify its Indochina policy by opening direct diplomatic contacts with the Communist Government of Cambodia.

title: Steinbrenner Likely To Testify on Spira
description: The prosecutor in the Howard Spira extortion case said yesterday that he had yet to decide whether he would call George Steinbrenner as a witness. But the attorney for Spira said he would call the Yankees' principal owner to testify about his relationship with Spira if the prosecution did not.

title: Books of The Times;   Status of India's Women Offers Hope and Despair
description: May You Be the Mother of a Hundred Sons

title: DEMOCRATS FAVOR OUTLAWING PAC'S
description: Democrats said today that they would press for the elimination of political action committees, which are increasingly associated in the public mind with the influence of money on politics, when the Senate takes up legislation to revise Federal campaigns.

title: Diversionary Tactic on S.& L.'s
description: Several members of Congress propose creating a nonpartisan commission to dig out the full story of the savings and loan scandal. They make it sound like a serious attempt to rise above politics. It smells more like a refuge for politicians.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Discipline Within: Reserve vs. Rawness in Capitol
description: The rare rebukes of Representative Barney Frank by the House of Representatives and Senator Dave Durenberger by the Senate this week revealed as much about the behavior of the institutions as that of the two lawmakers themselves.

title: Investor Group To Acquire McGaw
description: An investor group led by James M. Sweeney, a health-care industry executive, said today that it has agreed to acquire McGaw Laboratories for $210 million plus what it called ''other consideration.'' The group has financial backing from Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. and the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. A spokesman for the investor group did not return telephone calls seeking elaboration.

title: Free Speech Doesn't Include Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Criticize Blood Tests on Captain of Exxon Tanker
description: More than a year after the skipper of the Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood, was publicly ridiculed as a drunk, a furor has erupted over whether a laboratory mishandled his alcohol test results.

title: Ethiopia's Jews Gain From Amity With Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Liz Claiborne Sets Discount Increase
description: Liz Claiborne Inc., one of the largest makers of women's clothes, said it would increase its discount for retailers who pay for goods within 10 days after the end of the month in which they receive shipment. The company said the new discount would allow retail accounts to ''overcome some of the increased costs of business'' without raising prices to consumers.

title: New York City Campaign Finance Audit Moves at a Good Pace
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Junk Bond' Deal Joined By Investor
description: A Hong Kong businessman, Li Ka-shing, plans to spend $150 million for a half-interest in an investment group that has agreed to buy $3 billion in ''junk bonds'' from the troubled Columbia Savings and Loan Association in California, it was announced today.

title: USX Will Pay $34 Million For Wastewater Cleanup
description: The USX Corporation has agreed to pay $34 million in costs and penalties for the cleanup of wastewater that was illegally dumped from its Gary, Ind., steel mill, Federal officials said today.

title: Ford-Cummins Accord Set
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Cummins Engine Company have agreed to several provisions intended to cement their new relationship, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Top West German Anti-Terrorist Is Slightly Wounded in a Bombing
description: West German terrorists set off a bomb by remote control next to a busy highway today just as Bonn's top anti-terrorist official was driving by. The official was slightly wounded in the neck and arm.

title: Youth's Father Says He Urged Park-Rape Lie
description: The father of a defendant testified yesterday that he told his son to lie - to admit raping and beating a jogger in Central Park -so that the police would let him go home.

title: KEY RATES
A Rising AIDS Toll: Women and Children
description: The World Health Organization estimates that at least three million women and children will die of AIDS in the 1990's; that estimate, which the W.H.O. calls conservative, is more than six times the number in the 1980's. Several million other children will be orphaned by the disease. Page 24.

title: Bush Defends Little-Known Souter
description: President Bush acknowledged today that his nominee for the Supreme Court was ''not the most well-known figure in the country,'' but he predicted that he would come through his Senate confirmation hearings in September with ''flying colors.''

title: Evolution in Europe;   East German Coalition Finds Accord on Election Formula
description: The East German Social Democrats decided today not to leave the coalition with Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and the Christian Democrats after an all-German parliamentary committee found a compromise for holding all-German elections on Dec. 2.

title: Patents;   New Method Of Prognosis On AIDS
description: Researchers affiliated with the University of California at Los Angeles have obtained a patent on an experimental test to predict whether a person infected with the AIDS virus will quickly develop symptoms.

title: Florio Is Sued Over Ban on Some Weapons
description: Gun owners sued Gov. Jim Florio today over a ban on some semiautomatic weapons.

title: Chang Eliminates Agassi; Sampras Upsets McEnroe
description: The $1.2 million Player's Limited International tournament became a little more limited today when it lost its marquee idol and its master craftsman in the space of two quarterfinal matches.

title: Ryan on Television
description: ESPN, the cable sports network, will televise Nolan Ryan's second attempt at his 300th victory when Ryan pitches for the Texas Rangers on Tuesday night against the Brewers in Milwaukee. The game will begin at 8:30 P.M. Eastern time.(AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: LEAD: Count PRESIDENT BUSH among those appalled at ROSEANNE BARR's rendition of ''The Star Spangled Banner'' at a Padres-Reds doubleheader this week in San Diego. While being booed for her off-key performance of the national anthem, she reached for her crotch and spat on the ground - a parody, she said later, of baseball players.

title: A Rich Reward For Colorado Coach
description: He had his University of Colorado team at the top of the national polls for most of last season, then took the undefeated Buffaloes to the Orange Bowl before taking it on the chin from Notre Dame. Now the university is taking care of Bill McCartney for the rest of his coaching career with a 15-year contract worth nearly $2 million. Agreement on the pact, worth $130,000 annually in salary, was reached Thursday in a meeting among McCartney; the school's outgoing president, Gorden Gee, and the athletic director, Bill Marolt.

title: AIDS Tests in Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Milton Roy Sets Sundstrand Talks
description: The Milton Roy Company, a waste-water equipment maker that recently received a $160 million buyout offer from the Sundstrand Corporation, said its board had authorized talks with Sundstrand about the unsolicited offer.

title: Candelaria to Blue Jays
description: The Minnesota Twins traded John Candelaria, a left-handed pitcher, to the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday for Nelson Liriano, a second baseman, and Pedro Munoz, a minor league outfielder.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''On issues like this, the extremes speak the loudest and with the most concerted voices.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about fire ants misstated Dr. Edward Vargo's affiliation at the University of Texas. He works at the university's Brackenridge Field Laboratory.

title: Shell Oil Net Drops 63.4%
description: The Shell Oil Company said today that its net income fell 63.4 percent in the second quarter, as earnings declined in each of its exploration, refining and marketing and chemical units.

title: Mental Patient Found Guilty In Pipe Killing of Counselor
description: A 27-year-old mental patient has been found guilty of using a metal pipe to kill a counselor making a required visit to his apartment.

title: David Goldway, 83; Led Marxist Journal
description: David Goldway, chairman of the editorial board of Science & Society, a quarterly journal of Marxist scholarship, died on Tuesday near his home in Truro, Mass. He was 83 years old.

title: Retrial for 3 Merc Traders
description: Three commodity traders accused of fraud and racketeering will be retried on March 5, Federal District Judge Ann C. Williams said this week. The jury was deadlocked in the original trial.

title: Some on House Panel Seek Bar to Northrop
description: Members of a House subcommittee said today that the Northrop Corporation should be barred from doing business with the Pentagon because of contract violations involving several of its weapons programs.

title: Avianca Offers Crash Survivors $75,000 Apiece
description: Avianca Airlines offered yesterday to pay $75,000 each to passengers who were injured or relatives of passengers who were killed in the crash of its Flight 52 on Long Island early this year, without requiring that they give up their suits against the airline.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 28, 1990
description: International

title: Evolution in Europe;   Israeli-Soviet Trade Ties
description: Israel and the Soviet Union agreed today to establish trade ties, Israeli officials said. The president of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Vladislav Malkevitch, said trade between the countries, which do not have diplomatic relations, could top $1 billion in four years. Direct trade stands at less than $10 million a year. ''We shall consider the delivery of raw diamonds for cutting and polishing in Israel,'' Mr. Malkevitch said. ''We want to see cooperation in agriculture.''

title: Homophobia at the N.E.A.
description: LEAD: John Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, has taken the unprecedented step of overturning four solo performance art fellowships that had been strongly recommended for funding by the peer panel.

title: Bertram Thorp Blake Jr., Executive, 71
description: Bertram Thorp Blake Jr., a retired paper company executive, died yesterday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 71 years old. Mr. Blake died of lung cancer, his wife, Margaret, said. Mr. Blake was executive vice president of the Paper Corporation of the United States, based in Manhattan, from 1966 to 1981, when he retired. Earlier he had been president of the Paper Corporation of New York and an executive with Bermingham & Prosser, a Manhattan paper company.

title: G.N.P. Rate Up Just 1.2% In 2d Period
description: July 31, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

title: Excluded From the House
description: A listing yesterday of House members who have been disciplined by their peers omitted those whom the House refused to recognize as legitimate lawmakers and who were denied their seats. This list gives their names and the reasons. YEAR MEMBER-ELECT GROUNDS 1823 John Bailey (Ind.-Mass.) Not a resident of district he represented. 1867 John Y. Brown (D-Ky.) Disloyalty during Civil War 1867 John D. Young (D-Ky.) Disloyalty during Civil War 1867 John A. Wimpy (Ind.-Ga.) Disloyalty during Civil War 1867 W. D. Simpson (Ind.-S.C.) Disloyalty during Civil War 1870 Benjamin F. Whittemore (R-S.C.) Malfeasance for selling appoinments to United States Military Academy 1900 Brigham H. Roberts (D-Utah) Polygamy 1919, Victor L. Berger (Socialists-Wis.) Violation of 1920 Espionage Act by publishing anti- war statements. Conviction was later overturned and he was seated 1967 Adam C. Powell Jr. (D-N.Y.) Involvement in court cases concerning tax evasion and libel, and use of Government funds for personal expenses. After Mr. Powell was re- elected in 1968, the Supreme Court ruled the House had acted improperly and he was seated in 1969.

title: TRINIDAD MUSLIMS PROCLAIM REVOLT
description: A small Muslim militant group attempted yesterday to overthrow the Government of the Caribbean republic of Trinidad and Tobago, seizing the national television station in the capital and claiming to have taken the Prime Minister and Cabinet hostage.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the second-quarter earnings of Time Warner Inc. misstated the change in the company's operating income. It rose 3.3 percent from the comparable period last year.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Climb
description: Prices of all Treasury securities climbed and yields fell yesterday amid new signs that the economy is closer to a recession than data had previously indicated.

title: Acting Silly About Color
description: Actors' Equity doesn't like the idea of a British actor ''painted yellow'' playing the lead role of a Eurasian in ''Miss Saigon'' when the musical comes to Broadway from London next spring. That, it says, would be ''an affront to the Asian community.''

title: Speaker-Shopping in New York's Bazaar
description: If visitors from outer space landed in midtown Manhattan, they could conclude from shop windows that the object of life on earth was to consume stereo cassette players, compact disk players, video cameras, television sets, radios, telephones, calculators, fax machines, hand-held computers and other electronic gadgets nestled among signs saying ''Sale!'' and ''Discount!''

title: U.S. Curtails 24-Hour Duty Of Its Flying Command Post
description: In a sign of budget constraints and a cold war thaw, the Defense Department has stopped the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that for three decades has been a symbol of America's readiness to wage nuclear war.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing members of the House of Representatives who have faced disciplinary action was incomplete. An omitted group, members whom the House refused to recognize as legitimate lawmakers and who were denied their seats, is listed today in a chart on page 6.

title: The Gorbachev Goal Posts
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney counts himself among the hard-line skeptics who oppose American aid to the Soviet Union and resist cuts in military spending. He told reporters that he had made a list of 9 or 10 ''tough'' steps he would regard ''as hard evidence that the Soviets have fundamentally transformed themselves.''

title: INSIDE
description: France Releases 5 to Iran

title: Republicans Demand a Budget From Democrats
description: Congressional Republicans, angry that a White House budget proposal calling for higher taxes has become public without a companion proposal from Democrats, demanded today that the Democrats produce one before Congress adjourns for its August recess.

title: With Bar Exams Over, Oates Reports to Camp
description: The last major piece in the Giants' offensive line fell into place today when Bart Oates, the starting center since 1985, reported to training camp four days late.

title: The Nation;   Ugly Reminders of the Oil That Went Underground
description: Underground oil spills are difficult to photograph or visualize - no beaches covered with black goo, no sticky birds. Yet even though they haven't received as much attention as the more dramatic above-ground spills, the subterranean accumulations probably pose as much of a threat to human health and are even tougher to clean up, environmentalists and government officials say.

title: Technology;   Heating, Cooking and Now - Driving
description: As the nation's cities grapple with air pollution from automobile exhaust, natural gas - best known for heating homes and cooking dinners - is drawing increasing attention as a clean-burning alternative to gasoline and diesel fuel. The General Motors Corporation said last week it would sell a minimum of 1,000 pickup trucks powered by natural gas starting next year, and United Parcel Service said recently it would adapt up to half its 100,000 delivery trucks to operate on compressed gas.

title: New Yorkers, etc.

This, of course, is rarely the case. How a once genuine inquiry has deteriorated into a rote phrase, generally uttered without feeling, meaning or caring, is a sad commentary on life today.

title: Barge Aground in East River
description: A barge carrying more than 2 million gallons of gasoline ran aground last night on a small East River island off 96th Street, just north of Gracie Mansion, but was pulled away without any fuel leaking, the authorities reported. A police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tima Mohrmann, said the barge was being pushed past Hell Gate by a tug of the Turecamo Coastal Harbor Towing Corp. when its nose grounded on the east end of Mill Rock Park at 8 P.M. The barge was freed by tugboats about 10:30 P.M., said Lieut. Comdr. Jeffrey Stark of the Coast Guard. No gasoline spilled, he said.

description: It took them to the last minute, but the Knicks finally ended the suspense over the future of Johnny Newman yesterday, by announcing that they had decided not to match the four-year, $5 million offer made by the Charlotte Hornets.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

Coming of Age Takes Backseat to a Mother's Memory Lane
description: LEAD: ''GUESS what?'' my son said. ''I'm going to wax your car. Vacuuming, the works. Aren't you happy?'' Happy wasn't quite the word I would have chosen. This wasn't exactly a selfless act. It was part of the carefully conceived plan of a young man preparing for the day, all too soon if my opinion counted, when he would be driving that very car.

description: At the Pulaski (N.Y.) The Rev. James Tschudy performed the ceremony.

title: Paris When It Sizzles
description: AN AVAILABLE MAN. By Patric Kuh. (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $8.95.) From the moment this first novel opens, one has the impression of having fallen into the clutches of a natural storyteller, a writer whose love object, in the end, is the city of Paris - Paris in summer, to be precise, sweltering and sinister, ravished by pleasure-hungry visitors and busloads of tourists who move through the streets ''like sharks through a sunken city.'' It's an appropriately decadent setting for the tale that the narrator, a Wall Streeter-turned-gigolo named Francis Buchanan, unfolds in a voice as smooth and dry as a glass of Montrachet. Rich, sexually restless women are his prey, the suites of the luxurious Hotel Meurillon his territory, all described with a tough, mesmerizing cynicism. When Francis becomes entangled with Emma Cullington, a beautiful, drug-addicted Texas heiress, the narrative of ''An Available Man'' assumes a distinctly purgatorial cast, as the liaison dangereuse moves from the drug dens of the Left Bank to the treacherous cantinas of Houston. That Patric Kuh has a gift for conveying a spirit of place, however sordid the atmosphere, is undeniable. It is only in portraying the novel's uniformly cold, sexually rapacious women that he disappoints - particularly with Emma. The essence of Francis' obsession with her never seems quite compelling, nor is there sufficient motivation for Emma's bent for self-destruction. There are too many moments, as well, when the minutiae of her sleazy, junkie-dominated world, however morbidly fascinating at first, simply become tiresome. Ultimately, Mr. Kuh's most bewitching and sensual female ''character'' is Paris itself - a city the author clearly knows well, and whose beauty and unsavory aspects he succeeds equally well in evoking.

title: Cocaine-Laced Drink Leaves Man in a Coma
description: A man who drank from a soft drink bottle containing dissolved cocaine is in a coma today, and Federal officials are investigating for links to Colombian drug smugglers. The officials said drug traffickers often smuggle cocaine by dissolving it in liquids.

title: Lifestyle;   Nothing Borrowed, But All Was Blue
description: The bride wore a white lace bathing suit, buoyancy compensator, mask and fins. Her scuba tank and snorkel were rented rather than borrowed, but there was certainly an abundance of blue.

title: Headliners;   Violating Secrecy
description: Oleg D. Kalugin may be the spy who talked too much. Mr. Kalugin, a recently retired senior officer of the K.G.B., caused a sensation in June when he told a gathering of Communist Party insurgents in Moscow that the state security police hadn't changed its ways despite all of the recent efforts to change its image. ''The backbone of K.G.B. activities remains as it was 10 and 20 years ago,'' he said. ''It is observation of political activities, gathering of information on political enemies, using agents for political purposes.'' The authorities were not pleased. Last month, Mr. Kalugin was stripped of his rank of major general and of his decorations. Last week, the federal prosecutor's office filed criminal charges, saying that Mr. Kalugin's public charges of abuses in the secret police had violated secrecy laws. Mr. Kalugin claimed that because he was recently registered as a candidate for a vacant seat in the Soviet Parliament he was immune from prosecution.

title: A Voyage to the Scrap Heap
description: The wrecked supertanker Mega Borg has begun a two-month trip to Pakistan, where it will be broken into scrap. A tugboat towed the vessel from the Gulf of Mexico on Friday afternoon, the Coast Guard said. The Mega Borg rested about 57 miles offshore since it was rocked by an explosion on June 8. Four crew members were killed and a fire raged for several days aboard the ship, which spilled 3.9 million gallons of light crude oil into the gulf.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: As a wearer of contact lenses, I have a problem. If I blink too quickly, or if I feel I'm about to get poked in the eye, my contact lenses decide to change positions. Usually they migrate to the white corners of my eyes, where they don't belong. This is a painful event that leaves me both teary eyed and temporarily blind.

title: Give the Customer What He Wants
description: When I used to visit suppliers, I generally started by discussing with the chief executive the development of our business together, how it was progressing, what problems they were meeting and how he thought we could improve matters. I then used to go on the factory floor, and the first place I would ask to see would be the lavatories and washrooms. Experience taught me that if they were clean and well maintained, generally the standards of the factory would be high.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: Would you like to have the opponent at your mercy, unable to undertake any sort of aggression while you maneuver to create one weak point after another in his position? One of the best ways to accomplish this is to stick him with the bad bishop.

title: When Black Feminism Faces The Music, and the Music Is Rap
description: Like many black feminists, I look on sexism in rap as a necessary evil. In a society plagued by poverty and illiteracy, where young black men are as likely to be in prison as in college, rap is a welcome articulation of the economic and social frustrations of black youth.

title: How to Replace Ceiling Tiles
description: ACOUSTICAL ceiling tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used both as new and replacement ceiling material. Although easy to install and excellent for absorbing sound, such tiles are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean. Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced. Acoustical tiles suspended in metal or plastic channels from a ceiling are easy to replace. To remove the old tile, push it upward, then tilt it and slip it out of the channels. Wear safety goggles to protect against dust.

The group, which last appeared at City Center in 1986, will present the New York premiere of ''Unetsu,'' by Ushio Amagatsu, a choreographer and a member of the troupe. This 10th anniversary visit, sponsored by the county and several corporations, also marks the first time a woman has conducted the Philharmonic here: on the podium will be Marin Alsop, the dynamic music director of the Eugene (Ore.) Symphony, the Long Island Philharmonic and her own Concordia Chamber Symphony.

title: Review/Opera;   A Handel Hero Dabbles in Politics
description: Updated operas - those old theatrical bodies dressed up in modern clothes - seem to come in two sizes: large and small. Handel's ''Tamerlano,'' by the Measured Breaths Theater Company at the Cooper Square Theater on East Seventh Street, measures somewhere between small and medium. Rather than dragging the director into the present with its compelling relevance, this production assumes newness as a virtue in itself and then searches for ways to justify it. Here Handel's rendering of an epical purveyor of war has had its purely political nature separated out and freeze-dried. Robert Press, who is responsible for this production, adds the fresh water of current events, and Tamerlano is reconstituted in the midst of American Presidential politics.

title: Campus Life: Michigan;   Opening in Poland: Observation Post For Researchers
description: While the recent upheavals in Eastern Europe have been watched with close attention here, most American academics are studying the transformations only from a distance. To help make first-hand observation easier, the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan is opening a branch office in Warsaw, in conjunction with the Polish Government and the University of Warsaw.

During KRON-TV's lavish 13-minute salute to Mark Thompson, the rock-concert promoter Bill Graham gratefully solicited Mr. Thompson's advice about scheduling headliners, and San Francisco Giants slugger Will Clark begged him for hitting tips.

Some are standing on lines, chatting. Others are leaning against tables or sitting on the floor, reading newspapers or doing crossword puzzles. All are waiting to speak with city examiners and clerks to process applications for building permits and certificates of occupancy.

Too quiet, say its advocates, who are urging education policy makers, teachers and parents to take another look at family life programs in the state to see if they can be improved.

title: Wall Street
description: IS there anything harder for a company to endure these days than the debt burden of one of those giddy, high-priced buyouts of the past decade? Yes - the debt burden of two of them. Just ask anyone down in Richardson, Tex., who can remember what Spectradyne, the hotel-room movie service, was like before the Bass brothers and Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, got hold of it.

title: Headliners;   Staying Ashore
description: The Exxon Valdez has a new name (Exxon Mediterranean) and a new paint job (bright red), and is back in the water again after a year of repairs. Her former skipper, Joseph Hazelwood, will remain beached for a while longer. Last week, an administrative law judge for the Coast Guard suspended his captain's license for nine months for his actions when the tanker ran aground off Alaska in 1989, causing the nation's worst oil spill. Captain Hazelwood, who was fired by Exxon and voluntarily turned in his license after the accident, is appealing his conviction in March on a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. In the latest hearing, he pleaded no contest to charges of consuming alcohol within four hours of sailing and of negligence in leaving the bridge. ''He's suffered enough,'' said his lawyer. ''He wants to do what he knows best - to be a seaman, a ship's captain. He wants to go back to sea and he wants to go back as soon as possible.''

title: The Impaired Should Not Suffer
description: Re: '' 'These People' Are Ruining Our Lives? by Warren Goldstein (July 1): It is appropriate that Mr. Goldstein's commentary appeared four days before July 4th, which is the celebration of our forefathers' signing of the Declaration of Independence, which declared the 13 Colonies independent of the oppressive rule of England's king. Mr. Goldstein alluded to an oppressive form of thinking, both to the possessor and the victim - bigotry. The victims of bigotry described by Mr. Goldstein are those who suffer from brain and emotional disorders.

title: Piedmont's Many Pleasures
description: Even if Piedmont did not have truffles, or one of the great national parks of Europe (Parco del Gran Paradiso), or the Borromean Islands, or the more refined and most varied regional cuisine in Italy, it would still be top of my list for travelers to Italy who have already made the grand tour between Rome and Venice.

title: The Tourists Are in Europe and Things Are Looking Up
description: By the year 2000, tourism may well be the world's biggest industry. Since the monuments travelers want to see are pretty much fixed, tourists are paying more and more for the dubious pleasure of seeing one another. For the last year, Martin Parr, a British photographer with an eye for the ordinary, has been documenting the thundering herd as homo touristus spreads across Europe.

description: Paying to Play in the Hamptons

title: Manchester's Pop Music: Escapism Without Escape
description: Blobby light-show shapes flicker and wobble on a screen. Musicians, scruffy in blue jeans or gaudy in flower-patterned shirts, play their instruments and shamble around the stage. Onstage and off, people flail the air in hippie dances. But amid all the appearances of a festive 1960's revival, the lyrics (if any) are often grim, while the beat is likely to be pumped out by a drum machine.

title: Lifestyle;   Modern Rapunzels Put Up Their Hair
description: Snake through the crowds on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn on any Saturday, past the Sno-Kone vendors selling winter's taste in summer flavors, past the stores that sell shorts and dresses and blouses at two for $5. Pass under a hand-painted sign and into a narrow three-story building so unprepossessing it gives no hint that you've arrived at the mecca of hair.

title: Cal-Ban Diet Tablets Present Health Hazard, U.S. Finds
description: The Food and Drug Administration says Cal-Ban 3000 diet tablets and capsules can cause throat obstructions, and it wants the products removed from store shelves.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Never Learned the Game of Life

title: Germaine Smith Engaged to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Bonnie Germaine Smith and Douglas Clark Proxmire a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Proxmire of Washington, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. R. Clyde Smith of Dothan, Ala.

title: Postings: Council Spoof;   Playing The Game
description: You will never find Councilopoly, the Land Use Game, on a store shelf next to Monopoly and Scrabble. If it were to be played by the rules, it would take at least 50 days to finish. And it would never be clear who won.

title: Rocket in a 'Star Wars' Test Goes Awry and Is Destroyed
description: An Aries rocket carrying electronic equipment to be tested for the ''Star Wars'' antimissile program went off course and was destroyed 31 seconds after it was launched, the authorities said Friday.

title: Evening Hours;   That Long-Ago Decade Known As the 90's
description: More than 500 guests, invited to appear in summer whites at the Museum of the City of New York, observed the 100th anniversary of the Gibson girl on July 19. They saw an exhibition of costumes from around 1890 and drawings by Charles Dana Gibson, and spread their picnic dinners throughout the museum. The beneficiary was the museum's fund.

title: The Man Who Gave Us West Germany
description: LUCIUS D. CLAY

title:
Northeast Notebook: Jamestown, R.I.;

Affordables Near Newport
description: LEAD: A nonprofit housing company's purchase of an apartment complex here will create the first subsidized housing for families in this small island community and will help to preserve scarce rental units.

title: Conviction Is Reversed in Child-Abuse Case
description: The conviction of a man on 22 counts of sexually abusing four toddlers has been overturned by an appellate court, which ruled that the police had no right to view a videotape of the abuse seized from the defendant's car.

title: A Murderer Rocked the Cradle
description: LEAD: A DEATH IN WHITE BEAR LAKE

title: Leslie C. Shields Wed in Delaware
description: Leslie Cunningham Shields, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson T. Shields of Greenville, Del., was married yesterday to Per Ivar Lundgaard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivar A. Lundgaard of Kennett Square, Pa. The Rev. John L. O'Hear, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the bride's parents' home.

title: Robber at Wrong End of His Gun
description: A 71-year-old Queens man wrested a sawed-off shotgun from a 26-year-old armed robber yesterday morning and then caused the intruder to shoot himself with his own pistol, the police said.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our toilet takes a long time to flush and sometimes keeps on running. The problem seems to be the float ball on the end of the float arm not clicking off when it gets to the top, and so the water keeps running into the tank. What can I do to correct this?

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Natural Surcease From Modern Ways
description: LEAD: I RECENTLY presented a program at the Bartlett Arboretum in Stamford about how the native Americans used plants for food and medicine. The subject, cumbersomely known as ethnobotany, does not have much current usefulness. Why, I thought, would 25 people roll out of bed on a Saturday morning, pay good money and sit for two hours to hear about a topic that seems irrelevant?

title: Innovations Dot a Menu in Sag Harbor
description: Webb City's looks, staff and clientele might logically lead diners to expect burgers, onion rings and Buffalo wings. Instead, great hot-weather matchups from far-flung Thailand, the Philippines and Mexico dot the innovative menu.

title: Karen D. Fessel To Marry in Fall
description: An October wedding is planned by Karen Diane Fessel and Jeffrey Bruce Kirschenbaum, the son of Russell Kirschenbaum of Piedmont, Calif., and Susan Wolfe of Tiburon, Calif. The prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Fessel of Barrington, R.I., have announced the engagement.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
description: Pete Rose's sentence was much too short. It should have been based on the damage he did to baseball's reputation, not on his own baseball records.

title: Streetscapes: Euclid Hall;   A Derelict Dowager Making a Modest Comeback
description: The 1903 Euclid Hall, covering the west blockfront of Broadway from 85th to 86th Streets, was among the most ambitious apartment houses of its time.

title: Mutual Funds;   Mr. Smith Goes to Magellan
description: Morris Smith, the new steward of the $14.3 billion Fidelity Magellan Fund, fills his small boxy office like a whirling dervish. He watches three computer screens, confers with several people and riffles through a pile of papers. Speaking at a rapidfire pace, he gives orders to the three traders who work exclusively for him. In between, he checks earnings just released on eight companies he follows, reads the file for an upcoming conference call with executives of a big French telecommunications company and checks the status of a takeover offer. Among other things. ''It's a whirlwind,'' he said. Clearly.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Mother Helen and Friend Helen, an Enduring Relationship
description: LEAD: BOTH are named Helen; it was a very trendy name at the turn of the century. My mother Helen and her friend Helen have known each other since 1926 (or 1929, according to Friend Helen) when they were both secretaries at The Edison Company. (Mother Helen still sometimes forgets to write her utility check to Con Edison.) About 25 years ago Friend Helen and her husband moved to a Connecticut town more than a hundred miles from New York.

title: ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN
description: James Nachtwey's photo essay on ''Romania's Lost Children'' (text by Kathleen Hunt, June 24) was striking and very sad, but I hope no one fails to see the relevance of this situation to our own in the United States. To disallow a woman's right to abortion and to limit the availability of birth control can lead to tragedy, not just for the women forced to bear children or forced to undergo illegal and unsafe abortions, but also for the unwanted children.

title: Headliners;   Lecturing on Lies and Rewriting History
description: As many Europeans look toward what they hope will be a brighter future, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia gave a pointed lecture last week to those with shadows in their past.
