title: Bush's Supreme Court Red Herring
description: In his surprise nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court seat left vacant by retiring Justice William Brennan Jr., President Bush portrayed himself as depoliticizing the appointment process, and the Court. The President said that he applied ''no litmus test'' to the candidate's views on volatile issues. And he said that, in Judge Souter, he had found someone who would ''interpret the Constitution and not legislate from the bench.''

title: Spare That Tree or Else
description: GREEN RAGE

title: Volunteers Are Sought For a Pro Golf Tourney
description: LEAD: VOLUNTEERS are needed for a major Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament to be held in New Rochelle, the first L.P.G.A. event in the New York City area to be televised, its promoters say.

title: All About/The Shuttles;   Clipped Wings Along the Northeast Corridor
description: It's Friday morning at La Guardia Airport and the shuttle business is even slower than usual. Richard F. Cozzi, wrapping up his first week as president of the Trump Shuttle, glances about anxiously, as if hunting for more passengers. A holiday that week has thinned the weekend rush; only a few people straggle into the Trumpterminal, ready to board a Trumpjet, sink into leather Trumpchairs and enjoy Trumpsnacks. At the other end of the airport, Pan Am's shuttle gates are equally desolate.

title: Christine DiBenedetto Weds
description: Christine DiBenedetto, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. DiBenedetto 2d of Little Neck, Queens, was married last evening to Stuart Pearlman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron S. Pearlman of Dallas. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the interfaith ceremony at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. Mrs. Pearlman, 25 years old, is a secretary at the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles advertising agency in New York. Mr. Pearlman, 31, graduated from Southern Methodist University.

title: Willie Loman In Elsinore?
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: Kansas;   Suit Charges School's Waste Tainted a Well
description: A suit charging that chemicals from a University of Kansas radioactive waste dump have leached into the well water of a home bordering the dump was filed in Federal District Court in Kansas City, Kan., last week.

title: A Romantic Staging For 'As You Like It'
description: The idyllic Forest of Arden, the setting of the pastoral part of ''As You Like It,'' has been variously assumed to be in England or between France and Belgium. But exactly where, Shakespeare did not say. Nor did he care, according to Isaac Asimov's ''Guide to Shakespeare.'' Why not, then, transpose the play's romantic entanglements to make-believe Irish woods and set its darker aspects in a nearby timeless town, instead of the 16th-century Usurper's Courts? Such appears to be the notion of Michael Murray, who directed the Phoenix Theater Company's ''As You Like It,'' the last of its three-play summer-repertory season.

title: Surprise No. 1 in All-Around
description: With all the surprise of a late-night rerun, the Soviet Union's female gymnasts outclassed the field tonight at the Goodwill Games, taking the first two places in the all-around competition.

title: Most Chileans Know Military Invented Plot
description: To the Editor:

title: Spike Lee and the 'Slavery' of the Blues
description: In one of the earliest sequences of ''Mo' Better Blues,'' Spike Lee's new film about jazz, the camera lingers almost lecherously over the womanly curves of a trumpet and saxophone. As simple as the shot seems at that moment, over the course of the movie it becomes a powerful and shifting metaphor, as Mr. Lee's concerns travel from romance to creativity to commerce and from satire to genuine tragedy.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Sunday about Arthur Tremain Hertig, an embryologist, misstated the affiliation of a colleague, Dr. John Rock. Dr. Rock, who died in 1984, was clinical professor of gynecology, emeritus, at Harvard University; he was not affiliated with the Carnegie Institution in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine on Jan. 28 about Russian nationalism mistranslated a comment from Valentin Rasputin, a Russian writer.

title: More Out of Social Security From Those Who Can Afford It
description: To the Editor:

title: Home on the Range
description: In the late 1800's, a wanderer nicknamed Yonkel the Mahzik (Mischief) showed up at Ellis Island wearing the dark coat of an Orthodox Jew, long sideburns and cowboy boots. An immigration official jostled him and Yonkel slugged the man and swore at him in a Russian-Texan drawl. When it was discovered that this strange cowboy was a United States citizen who had fought in the Civil War, Yonkel was readmitted into the country. The first Jewish Texan was one of the conquistadors, Gaspar Castano de Sosa, who set foot in the Lone Star State in 1590. Eight Jews fought at the Alamo, and when Texas joined the Union in 1845, its first Congressman was David Kaufman, a Jewish graduate of Princeton University. These and other funny and fascinating anecdotes are relayed by Natalie Ornish in PIONEER JEWISH TEXANS: Their Impact on Texas and American History for Four Hundred Years, 1590-1990 (Texas Heritage Press, P.O. Box 12765, Dallas, Tex. 75225, $39.95). Ms. Ornish, a Texas journalist and film producer, chronicles the lives of hundreds of influential Jewish merchants, buccaneers, ranchers, seamen, oil men, professionals, politicians and philanthropists. She includes profiles of the Sanger Brothers, who created the first dry goods store in Texas, and the actress Adah Isaacs Menken, known as ''the naked lady from Nacogdoches.'' This beautifully designed and carefully documented reference book is a historical ''Who's Who'' of Texas Jews.

title: It's Anchors Away for Unschooled Sailors
description: ''O.K., where are we?'' said Lennie Okoskin, 10 feet from the dock. As captain for an hour of a 21-foot boat with a 200-horsepower engine, Mr. Okoskin was a bit tense. A few miles from the historic Montauk Lighthouse, he was making history of his own. He was piloting a boat for the first time.

title: Kirsten Morehouse To Wed in September
description: Theodore C. Morehouse of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Mrs. Fredric J. Klink of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kirsten Morehouse to Matthew Alden Kenney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Kenney of Searsport, Me. A September wedding is planned.

title:
MUSIC;

Can a Bigger 'Night Music' Retain the Old
description: LEAD: ''I do not believe certain things belong in an opera house,'' says the conductor Paul Gemignani, who has worked both on Broadway and at New York City Opera. ''To my mind, there's no reason to do 'Guys and Dolls' in the opera house. I mean, why? It sounds perfectly good with a regular pit orchestra, because it's designed for that.

title: Memories of the Good Life
description: THE RAIN CAME LAST & OTHER STORIES

title: Yesterday's Playthings Meet the Old Toy Network
description: Metal toys made between 1860 and 1940 - in painted cast iron, lithographed tin, enameled steel and die-cast metal - are among today's most popular collectibles. They are also increasingly expensive. This year prices skyrocketed for metal cars, trucks and steam engines at two record-breaking auctions in April and June held in New Hope, Pa.

title: Campus Life: Texas;   Dean Delays Changes In a Disputed Course
description: University of Texas officials have derailed plans to focus a first-year English composition course on civil rights and affirmative-action court cases.

title: Review/Rock;   Country Blues and a Sense of Humor
description: One of the many pleasures of watching John Hiatt in concert is in sharing his obvious enjoyment in making music. Onstage, the Nashville-based singer and songwriter, who opened an engagement at the Bottom Line on Thursday evening, is an exuberantly antic figure who augments his raw-boned country-blues singing with a clownish sense of fun. His gleeful stage personality lends an extra dimension of humor to original blues- and country-flavored rock songs that often look at real-life events from a tilted, surrealistic perspective.

title: Appearances Worry Congress As S.& L. Shadow Lengthens
description: The months since the Senate Ethics Committee opened investigations into five Senators' intervention with Federal regulators on behalf of a savings and loan executive have created a climate of caution, very nervous caution, in Congress.

title: MARKET WATCH
description: When words don't persuade, a gun can help.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Coins, like people show the effects of age. When roughly handled, coins pick up scars. Exposure to the elements causes tarnishing and even mild acids will pit and erode a coin's surface. Beware! Any attempt to improve a coin's features, perhaps with a little scrubbing or buffing, can do more damage than benign neglect.

title: North Tarrytown At Crossroads On Revitalization
description: LEAD: THE plan to revitalize rundown sections of this village is at a critical juncture. In the next month, the village's Board of Trustees and Halpern Enterprises of Tarrytown will be negotiating a scaled-down version of the project the developer proposed last year.

title: Ideas & Trends;   Science Learns to Catch a Polluting Car in the Act
description: The fight for clean air has produced a new weapon, the environmental equivalent of a highway radar trap, that measures carbon monoxide from passing cars in a fraction of a second. The original idea was to pick out ''super polluters,'' but some government officials are now thinking about new approaches to pollution control.

title: On Language;   When Parentheses Are Transgressive
description: Rewriting the (Post)modern: (Post)colonialism / Feminism / Late Capitalism'' read the brochure advertising a conference that I attended at the University of Utah in March. The program was full of fashionable academic jargon - phrases like ''reified theory,'' ''(post)structuralist tropics'' and ''the racial subject'' - all of it standard lexical fare in the arcane world of literary criticism.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   A Succulent Turkey Sate, With Soy and Peanut Butter
description: Turkey breast is usually cooked in such a way that diners don't recognize what it is. Sometimes it is mistaken for chicken, but most of the time it is mistaken for veal.

title: Miss Hanna Wed To M. P. Morgan
description: Katharine Mohr Hanna and Matthew Perry Morgan were married yesterday at the Trinity Parish Episcopal Church in Lenox, Mass., by the Rev. Duncan R. McQueen. Mrs. Morgan is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hanna Jr. of Old Chatham, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Perry Morgan Jr. of Princeton, N.J., are the bridegroom's parents.

title: In the Context Of Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: Ghosts Must Catch The Spirit of the Time
description: Every age gets the ghostly lovers it needs. At a decisive point in the 1947 film ''The Ghost and Mrs. Muir,'' the audience finds itself hoping that Gene Tierney will break her engagement to George Sanders - she's the last to know he's a cad - and run into Rex Harrison's arms. Now, it's true that the sea captain Harrison plays is a ghost, so technically he has no arms. Only the young, beautiful, widowed Mrs. Muir can see or hear him. His disembodied state would put a terrible crimp in their social life, and delicacy prevents even mentioning something so impossible as their sex life. To root for the captain is to wish that a young woman chooses death over life. Why do we feel certain that this ghostly lover is the only man who can make her happy? A literal reading of the movie suggests the triumph of spiritual love over time, space and physical desire. Save that one for chivalric romances. We root for the ghost because he is Rex Harrison, handsome, deep-voiced and in his prime. On screen he is so strong a physical presence that Sanders seems like a wimp beside him, real or not. Harrison does no ghostly fadeaways, never walks through walls and only once scares off some unwanted guests. ''I am real,'' the seductive, bearded sea captain tells Mrs. Muir. ''I'm here because you believe I'm here.'' But this romantic moment does not make us believe in spirits. Instead, at some unconscious level, Harrison makes us suspect that when we're not looking, he and Mrs. Muir manage to overcome their apparent physical problems, and that being escorted to dinner parties by an invisible partner would be a small price for Mrs. Muir to pay. It is an extreme disappointment when the ghost leaves Mrs. Muir for her own good; doesn't he understand his power?

title: Water Conservation Begins With Lawns
description: GARDENERS in the Northeast are lucky. There usually is enough water to go around. But the Soil Conservation Service says that ''demand for water by humans is expected to double by the year 2000.''

title: Victims' Parents Denounce Abuser's Release
description: Parents in Great Neck, L.I., are upset at the recent release from prison of a teen-ager who was part of a group that sexually abused children during computer classes at the home of a former high school teacher there.

title: Fewer Dogs Ending Up in Pounds
description: LEAD: THE number of dogs being impounded and destroyed by municipal shelters on Long Island has been on the wane since about 1986, town officials report.

title:
THEATER;

At the Public, Drama Takes a Latin Turn
description: LEAD: The massive wave of new peoples coming to the United States from south of its border is having a pervasive effect on the cultural life of this country, whether or not we admit it. Central and South Americans, Caribs and Mexicans have brought with them a vivacity and a way of living that have infused many American cities with African, Caribbean and Hispanic popular culture.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

A Hotel Joins the Rush to the Riverfront
description: LEAD: First came the marinas, followed by the offices, shops and housing units that line New Jersey's 18 miles of Hudson River shore.

title: Jeanette E. Heinz Weds Thomas King
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jeanette Elisabet Heinz and Thomas Mackenzie King, both 1986 graduates of Stanford University. The Rev. John Bishop performed the ceremony. Mrs. King, 25 years old, is a daughter of Clifford Stanton Heinz of Newport Beach, Calif., and Barbro Engstrom Heinz Rudel of Stockholm and New York. The bride heads her own company, JEH Cellular, a communications company in Greenwich. Her father is a private investor. She is a great-granddaughter of Henry J. Heinz, whose bottled horseradish in 1869 became the first of the 57 varieties of the H. J. Heinz Company.

title: For Japan's Military, Some Second Thoughts About Where the Enemy Is
description: For 100 years Japan's military elite has been trained on this island of British-style red-brick buildings and rolling green lawns. First, it was for conquests in Asia, and over the last four decades for defending the Japanese islands against a possible Soviet invasion from the north.

title: Fewer Relocations, and Each Costs More
description: WHEN a 38-year-old engineer in Minneapolis was offered a new position in the New York City area, he hesitated, although professionally it was a big career advancement.

title: She had a Crush on Them
description: A SENSIBLE LIFE

title: Enigma Nominated For the Supreme Court
description: Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, unknown to the nation when Mr. Bush chose him on Monday, is known now as an earnest, erudite, diligent New Hampshire man.

title: Still Under Par, Jones Takes L.P.G.A. Lead
description: Rosie Jones overcame a bogey on the troublesome 16th hole today to shoot a one-under-par 70 and take a two-stroke lead over Cathy Johnston after the third round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship.

title: Murrow, Advocacy and the Medium's Power
description: Hero-worship is not among the afflictions common to journalists; their profession leads more often to exposing clay feet than shining up halos. But as ''Edward R. Murrow: This Reporter'' confirms, when journalists do find a hero, particularly in their own ranks, they do not stint on homage. At moments, the otherwise absorbing two-part portrait that begins tomorrow night at 9 on PBS seems to be the latest ceremony toward canonization.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended July 14

title: Learning Why to Say No to Drugs
description: For the last three years a program has been trying to combat drugs by emphasizing human potential over abuse and devastation, and it appears to be working, its participants say. Whether the participants are police officrs, teachers, parents or children, many echo the same feeling: hope and patience must conquer the curiosity induced by the drug pusher's outstretched hand.

title: Lou Whitaker, One of the Greats
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Memphis;

Historic Area Redevelopment
description: LEAD: THE Memphis Center City Commission and an architectural team are working on plan to guide the redevelopment of a historic 10-block area of north downtown known as the Pinch District.

title: Virginia Keeny, a Lawyer, Is Married To Sean K. Smith, a Ph.D. Candidate
description: Virginia Keeny, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spurgeon M. Keeny Jr. of Washington, was married yesterday in Los Angeles to Sean Kenneth Smith, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Smith of New York. Judge William A. Norris of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit officiated at the Wattles Mansion.

title: Left-Wing Press Feels New Squeeze in Turkey
description: It is more than three months since anyone has seen Dogu Perincek in public, and his wife says he is prepared to remain one of Turkey's best-known fugitives indefinitely.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester Developer Fees in Lieu of Open Space
description: A new state law that takes effect on Oct. 1 has broad implications for the acquisition of open space in Connecticut. It enables communities to charge developers a fee instead of requiring them to donate parcels of land for preservation.

title: Taking the Measure of Tape Performance
description: In choosing a brand of blank recording tape, viewers have little to guide them aside from each company's advertised claim to be the best. Independent assessments of tape performance based on stringent laboratory measurements are needed to bring an element of reason to the competitive melee.

title: The Networks' New Advertising Dance
description: Viewers of the new television series ''Northern Exposure'' on CBS Thursday evening could hardly miss the striking scenery and the quirky mooseburger meals depicted in the saga of a young New York doctor acclimating to a rugged Alaskan town.

title: Keeping Safe
description: To the Editor: I suggest installing zippers on the inside pockets of jackets as a protection against pickpockets. If possible, the wallet should be placed in a pocket lengthwise, with the opening at the top; since this is usually a tight fit, one must hold on to the jacket when taking out the wallet, which makes it very difficult for a pickpocket to get it out even without a zipper. On a recent visit to Italy I had no problems or losses using this method.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Time Has Come To Shed Shackles Of Digital Tyranny
description: LEAD: JUST as the words in our language control the way we think, the mechanical devices we use for clocks control our concept of time. The evolution of such mechanical devices, from early canonical clocks to the digital clock, has caused our consciousness of time to become increasingly removed from our natural sense of time and our own internal clocks.

title: Putting the Universe on Hold
description: To the Editor:

title: More Job Applicants Being Tested for Drugs
description: LEAD: MORE and more companies on Long Island are testing job applicants for drug use as part of pre-employment screening.

title: Camp Honors Director's 20 Years of Sharing
description: In her 20 years in Fresh Air Fund camps, Beverly McEntarfer has lived through a hurricane, a multitude of violent storms and a cabin fire. She has had to retrieve hundreds of lost children, not to mention a few runaways. And she has endured several broken bones, a nasty bout with a campwide epidemic of food poisoning and, she estimates, no less than 10,000 mosquito bites.

title: Mimi Mackay Has Wedding
description: Mimi Mackay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey B. Mackay of Shorewood, Minn., was married last evening at her home in Excelsior, Minn., to Lawrence David Bartimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Bartimer of New York. Rabbi Max Shapiro performed the ceremony.

title: Buzzing the National Parks
description: It is an early February morning at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument in southern Arizona. Several campers are sitting outside tents, listening to chirping desert birds, when a rumble begins to build and the ground starts to tremble. A few seconds later, two American fighter planes, perhaps 200 feet off the desert floor, tear over the campground with an earsplitting roar.

title: Nancy Nolan Is Married
description: Nancy Francelia Nolan, a daughter of Mrs. Charles D. Nolan and the late Mr. Nolan of Wayzata, Minn., was married there yesterday to Timothy Andrew O'Neill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew B. O'Neill of Queensbury, N.Y. The Revs. Thomas Kelly and John French performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Church. Mrs. O'Neill, 34 years old, graduated from St. Lawrence University. She is a bond trader with Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. Mr. O'Neill, 34, a graduate of Colgate University with an M.B.A. from Columbia University, is a vice president of the First Boston Corporation in New York.

title:
Allenhurst Journal;

Delay in Replacing a Closed Bridge Angers Merchants
description: LEAD: ON April 26, 1989, the Main Street Bridge, which connects Asbury Park to Interlaken, a stone's throw from Allenhurst's tiny business district, was closed to traffic. ''It was, to paraphrase someone, a day that will live in infamy,'' said Angelo LaValle, owner of Allenhurst Liquor and Deli, one of the small stores that line Main

title: Nick Pippin, 35, Dies; Founded AIDS Group
description: Nick Pippin, an actor and the founder of the People With AIDS Theater Workshop, died on Friday at his home in midtown Manhattan. He was 35 years old.

title: Robin M. Lentz and Glenn S. Worgan Are Wed
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa., Robin M. Lentz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Lentz of Ambler, Pa., was married yesterday to Glenn S. Worgan, a son of Joan B. Worgan of Erdenheim, Pa., and John Worgan of Philadelphia. The Rev. Anne Ritchings officiated.

title: A 5,000th Victory
description: When John Campbell recorded his 5,000th career victory at the Meadowlands on Friday night, he became only the seventh driver in the history of the sport to reach that milestone. The 35-year-old Campbell is a native of Ailsa Craig, Ontario, with career purse earnings of $85 million, a record. The career leader in victories is Herve Filion, with more than 12,000, and he is still driving. Campbell got his 5,000th victory driving the 2-year-old trotter Thunderball to a 1 1/2-length victory in a $20,000 elimination divison of the Niatross Stake. (AP)

title: Fashion;   Children's Wear That Bridges Seasons
description: The children are back from camp or soon will be, trailing worn or outgrown play wear behind them. Parents are not likely to invest in summer replacements, even if they could find them at this late date. But among the back-to-school inventory are a lot of bright, lightweight transitional clothes suitable for the hot days and increasingly cooler nights of August and September.

title: Ideas & Trends;   Now the U.S. Asks What Its Radiation Did in the Cold War
description: Against the backdrop of jubilation and expectation following the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, the United States is beginning to measure the painful human costs of the cold war in some American communities.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   When It's Too Hot To Fuss, They Don't
description: When the weather turns sticky, women can always keep cool with unfussy, basic clothing. It's a timeless, well-groomed, smooth style - in some circles, the ''Greenwich look'' - that high humidity won't wilt.

title: Pioneering Audio Design To a Consistently Musical Beat
description: Despite its present multi-billion-dollar size, the audio industry started small - in the traditional American fashion of free enterprise and better mousetraps.

title: Mining for Knowledge in Africa
description: CAMPING WITH THE PRINCE AND OTHER TALES OF SCIENCE IN AFRICA

title: Transit Agency's Plan: Tokens Outside Subway
description: Tired of waiting in long lines in the subway to buy tokens?

title: The Nation;   Criminal Charges Against Managers Send a Message On Airline Safety
description: When a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed up a 60-count indictment against Eastern Airlines charging faulty maintenance practices, Andrew J. Maloney, the United States Attorney, said the charges were meant ''to send a signal, not just to Eastern but to the entire industry.''

title:
MUSIC;

Student Ensemble Prepares for Tour
description: LEAD: CENTRAL NEW JERSEY will be host to an orchestra of some of the best young musicians from every state in the nation this week, when the 75 students rehearse and perform in North Branch in preparation for a concert tour to Finland.

title:
Northeast Notebook: Washington;

Renovating L'Enfant Plaza
description: LEAD: With new development increasing around L'Enfant Plaza, the owners of two of the four buildings in the 20-year-old, mixed-use project in southwest Washington are putting the finishing touches on a two-year, $35 million renovation.

title: Nicole Bachmann to Marry
description: Nicole Diane Bachmann, a daughter of Margot Bachmann and Eric R. Bachmann, both of New York, and Dr. Thomas Newman Fromson, a son of Marjorie Fromson of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late David Fromson, plan to marry in December. Miss Bachmann, 32 years old, graduated from the Dalton School and Hamilton College and has a master's degree in special education from Columbia University. Dr. Fromson, 34, has a pediatric practice in West Hartford, Conn. A graduate of Hobart College, he received his M.D. from the Medical College of Georgia.

title: Mary Joan Scheid and Clark DesSoye Are Married
description: Mary Joan Scheid and Clark James DesSoye were married yesterday at the Village Hall in Bronxville, N.Y., by George S. Pickwick, the Village Justice of Bronxville. Mrs. DesSoye, 37 years old, is the daughter of Mary Scheid of Canastota, N.Y., and the late John Scheid. A magna cum laude graduate of Fordham University, she is a secretary at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton.

title:
Your Own Account;

What to Say to a Stock Option
description: LEAD: Some time ago, a shop foreman in Harvey, La., came up with a good way to save his employer money. The company's chief executive was so pleased that he flew to Harvey and rewarded the foreman with 10,000 options to buy company stock at $3 a share.

title: Campus Life: Duke;   University Seeks To Raze a Symbol Of Tobacco Boom
description: Duke University, named for the tobacco family whose wealth started it in the 1920's, is trying to get out from under one of the last reminders of this city's tobacco boom-town days: a building that it fell heir to in 1988 and that the community wishes to retain as a historic treasure.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE GREENPEACE BOOK OF THE NUCLEAR AGE: The Hidden History, The Human Cost. By John May. (Pantheon, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95.) Coal-mine collapses and oil spills are front-page stories; the world of nuclear weapons and power plants, writes John May, exists in secrecy. ''The Greenpeace Book of the Nuclear Age'' seeks to provide a compendium of 45 years of bad news. Mr. May, the editorial director of Greenpeace Books, describes how the Nuclear Regulatory Commission evaluates mishaps at civilian reactors. In 1982, for example, there were 4,500 accidents at the 81 operating nuclear plants in the United States, but only 253 were considered particularly significant - and more than a quarter of the total were attributed to human error. This book includes not only the undisputed facts but the maybes. Mr. May discusses, for example, the high incidence of cancer among the cast members of ''The Conqueror,'' the 1954 John Wayne movie filmed in the Utah desert only 137 miles from the military's Nevada nuclear test site. Tendentious and frankly alarmist, ''The Greenpeace Book of the Nuclear Age'' may not be the last word in the nuclear debate, but it is a useful reminder that nuclear power is hardly an unmixed blessing.

title: Postings: The Center at Woodbury;   Another Discount Complex
description: Hoping to capitalize on the success of a retail magnet that has been attracting shoppers from across the region, a Fishkill, N.Y., development concern is planning a 20-store shopping center at the entrance to Woodbury Common, a complex of factory outlets about an hour's drive north of New York City in Orange County. The developer, the Dagar Group Ltd., said it was hoping to attract national and regional apparel chains such as Marshalls, T. J. Maxx and Dress Barn, as well as other discount stores.

title: Anti-Walesa Faction in Solidarity Meets in Warsaw to Draft Strategy
description: A new group drawn from the intellectual core of the Solidarity movement held its first national meeting today, a milestone in the division of Poland's once-united anti-Communist opposition into two competing political parties.

title: 9 Million Americans Respond to Plight of a Sick Boy
description: Craig Shergold, a 10-year-old English boy ill with a brain tumor, remarked last fall that he would like to break the world record for receiving get-well cards. Nine million Americans have responded, answering messages sent through a loose network of facsimile machines, office memorandums, neighborhood conversations and community newspaper advertisements.

title: Lisa Hulshizer Married to Eric Swats
description: Lisa Mueller Hulshizer and Eric Nichols Swats were married yesterday at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Neely H. Towe officiated.

title: ;   In the Attic, A Raccoon Steals the Peace LL)By ROSE ZELMAN
description: SOMETHING was wrong at our country house. It was late spring and my husband and I had just spent the week in New York City. For 38 summers we have split our time between our urban apartment and a suburban house, on a lovely, dead-end rural street, with a roaring brook for a backyard.

title: Photo: Martyn Fleming, left, and Steven Heathcote of the Australian Ballet duel as gladiators in Laszlo Seregi's production of ''Spartacus.'' (Tom Brazil)Review/Dance;   Hungarian Version Of Spartacus Tale
description: Laszlo Seregi, Hungary's leading choreographer, created his own version of ''Spartacus'' to Aram Khachaturian's ballet score of the same title in 1968. On Friday night, the Australian Ballet presented the United States premiere of Mr. Seregi's ''Spartacus'' at the Metropolitan Opera House in a recent restaging that will be repeated this afternoon to end the company's engagement.

title: Fake Mourners Shoot 5 at Gang Funeral
description: At least five people were shot at a reputed Chinatown gang member's funeral in Linden, N.J., yesterday when men posing as mourners dropped their bouquets and opened fire with machine guns and a shotgun on a crowd of 100 people, the police said.

title: Keeping Safe
description: To the Editor: Further tips for ''Staying on the Safe Side'' (Travel, June 24):

title: Music in Brooklyn
description: Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera will perform Benjamin Britten's opera ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' staged by Charles Jarden and conducted by Anton Coppola, at 8 o'clock tonight in the Prospect Park Band Shell in Brooklyn (Ninth Street and Prospect Park West entrance of the park, in the Park Slope section). Raindate is tomorrow at 8 P.M. The event is part of the Celebrate Brooklyn festival, which offers free weekend performances through Sept. 2. Information: (718) 768-0699.

title: How Many Bosses Does It Take . . . To Mange One Worker?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion;   Have Parka, Will Sparkle
description: It's a long way from the Arctic to the runways of Europe. But now the parka has re-emerged as a glamorous evening cover-up. Parisian and Milanese designers seem to have become enraptured with the parka's shape and have interpreted it in the most lavish of fabrics for their fall collections. It's an amusing idea - and also one that makes sense, since these new gussied-up versions are also warm and comfortable.

title: Works in Progress;   Scoop du Jour
description: In April, Pierre Bardina, a 24 year-old Frenchman, spent 111 1/2 consecutive hours in an aquarium in his hometown of Marseilles, a world record. You might expect that someone willing to spend so much time submerged would be interested in keeping the available waters clean. And indeed, Bardina, whose dual passions are diving and protecting the environment, performed the stunt to draw attention to a recent personal project.

title:
DINING OUT;

2d Look at a Japanese Spot in Thornwood
description: LEAD: DINERS who might have tried Cho Cho San several years ago and were disappointed in reluctant dining room service and mediocre food should take another look. The restaurant has come a long way. Snappy, attentive service, an active sushi counter and decent kitchen techniques have taken this eating spot out of the doldrums.

title: Racism Issue Shakes World of Golf
description: Reeling from criticism that it holds many of its most prestigious tournaments at private clubs with all-white memberships, golf has been caught in a moral issue so powerful that the social and political vacuum in which the game has long existed has probably been altered forever.

title: ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN
description: Anti-abortionists arm themselves with photographs of dead fetuses as evidence of the callousness of those who would have an abortion, or perform one. The photos of unwanted, institutionalized children in Romania are testimony to the far greater inhumanity of bringing children into the world without parents willing or able to care for them. The death of an unborn child is hard to compare with the dead stares of living children ravaged by neglect.

title: Economic Upheaval: The Toll in Poland; A special report:   EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;   For Poles, Road to Capitalism is Rough
description: More than six months after the Government of Tadeusz Mazowiecki imposed Eastern Europe's most ambitious program to create a market economy, Poles are struggling to adjust to a system with new opportunities and new risks.

title: INSIDE
description: Japan's Military: A New Role

title: 7 Are Killed in Military Helicopter Accidents
description: An Army helicopter crashed in training exercises Friday night, killing five soldiers and injuring eight, the authorities said today.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Must the U.S. Give Brazil and Iraq The Bomb?
description: Iraq, with modern armed forces numbering a million and with a leader driven by dangerous ambitions, started a war with Iran, threatens Israel and has rattled its saber against tiny Kuwait. Its President, Saddam Hussein, may not stop at threats if he can complete plans to build weapons of mass destruction.

title: Review/Opera;   Driving 'Turandot' In the Park
description: The summer season of the New York Grand Opera in Central Park either ended on Thursday evening with a production of ''Turandot,'' or it didn't. Before the performance, it was announced that the company was still trying to raise money to reschedule a performance of ''L'Elisir d'Amore,'' which was rained out on July 12.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 17 about Budapest misstated the location of the junction of three subway lines. A reader has written recently to point out that it is Deak Square, not nearby Vorosmarty Square.

title: ART VIEW/Edgar Munhall;   Cezanne's Peak Exhibits the Art of Compassion
description: For three days at the end of August last year a forest fire of epic force ravaged what must be the best-known natural totem of modern art - Mont Sainte-Victoire outside Aix-en-Provence, a site made familiar the world over by Paul Cezanne. The fire destroyed three villages, as well as some 12,000 acres of woods, moors and vineyards. No human lives were lost, but horses were, and countless fauna that inhabited the area. Witnessing the spectacle (I was renting a house at the base of the mountain) was as close to experiencing modern warfare as I ever hope to come.

title: The Unfathomable Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Lines Stir Concern on Health Risk
description: AMID growing concern over a possible link between electric power lines and cancer, New Jersey residents are mounting an increasingly vocal campaign against utility companies that want to string new wires throughout the state.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart last Sunday with the Mutual Funds column, about closed-end funds, misstated the closing price of General American Investors on Dec. 29, 1989. It was 18 1/8, not 8 1/8.

title: Rival Proposals for Purchase of Jay Land
description: A LONG-AWAITED decision by county legislators over acquisition of the Jay Property in Rye may face yet another delay, political leaders indicated last week, even though two proposals offering a choice of action are now officially before them.

title: Miss Chandler, Banker, to Wed
description: The engagement of Carole-Ann Chandler to Charles J. O'Shea 3d, a New York State Assemblyman from Long Island, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Chandler of Garden City Park, L.I. She and Mr. O'Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Shea Jr. of Point Lookout, L.I., plan a September wedding.

title: Review/Dance;   Choreography Workshop Lets New Creators Shine
description: The School of American Ballet's commendable New Choreography workshop, which presented its fourth annual program on Thursday afternoon at the Juilliard Theater, gives fledgling choreographers the opportunity to create ballets for young dancers enrolled in the school's summer session. The project also necessarily forces the choreographers selected each year to work under the kind of conditions that are typical today - giving them just under five weeks to create the ballet, using unfamiliar dancers, though with a full production at the end.

title: Campus Life: Syracuse;   A University Plays Host To Its Neighbors
description: Thirty-one residents, as young as 6 and as old as 18, from housing projects in this city are learning about fitness and advanced education this summer. But rather than sending them to camps, as in the past, the Syracuse Housing Authority has them working with a neighbor, Syracuse University.

title: Review/Dance;   New Insights Into 'Giselle' From the Australian Ballet
description: The Australian Ballet's ''Giselle'' is an absorbing piece of storytelling, full of vivid dramatic details that make the production - staged by the company director, Maina Gielgud, to the Adam score - freshly believable and affecting. And Anna de Cardi and David McAllister, who stepped into the roles of Giselle and Albrecht on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, made the ballet even more affecting.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our toilet takes a long time to flush and sometimes keeps on running. The problem seems to be the float ball on the end of the float arm not clicking off when it gets to the top, and so the water keeps running into the tank. What can I do to correct this?

title: Jill Kransdorf to Wed
description: October wedding plans for Jill Robyn Kransdorf and Gary Richard Baker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stanley Baker of Boca Raton, Fla., have been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome I. Kransdorf of New York. Ms. Kransdorf, 26 years old, and her fiance, 28, are graduates of Ithaca College. She is an account executive at Argenti, a sportswear manufacturer in New York. Her father is the executive vice president of Wertheim Schroder Investment Services in New York. Mr. Baker is a vice president of the BRI Coverage Corporation, an insurance brokerage in New York. His father, who is retired, was a textile executive in New York.

title: The Nation;   Blacks, Jews and 'This Thing That Is Suffocating Us'
description: A black California official's comment earlier this month that leading Hollywood film and television studios and executives are guilty of ''Jewish racism'' set off the latest troubled round in the sometimes strained history of relations between blacks and Jews in the United States.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Weed; pull up unwanted plants, which usurp valuable soil moisture and add them to the compost. Cut off faded flowers from petunias, snapdragons, geraniums, pansies, lilies, daylilies and balloonflowers to prevent seed pods from forming. Mail hardy bulb orders for fall planting.

title: Smart Street
description: PARK AVENUE: Street of Dreams. By James Trager. (Atheneum, $24.95.) It is to James Trager's credit that his detailed account of New York's plushest street breathes more life into the thoroughfare than is visible to the naked eye. There are several Park Avenues in addition to the rich residential one. There is the poor residential Park Avenue, the one of the barrio, up where the railroad tracks emerge from underground. There is the glassy Park Avenue of pretentious office buildings in the north 40's and the 50's. And there is an older, still more or less quiet Park Avenue south of Grand Central Terminal - which is, of course, the stunning centerpiece of the entire street. Farther downtown there is Park Avenue South, which is less lordly, and finally there are the half-dozen blocks of Fourth Avenue, which was Park's original name before it moved into more affluent circles. Like so many New York streets, Park Avenue represents change and various generations of architecture. Why, asks Mr. Trager, does Fifth Avenue have so many more big, ugly, modern apartment houses than Park Avenue has? He explains that Park Avenue, which had its beginnings as a railroad street, received its apartment houses during the early decades of the century, when building standards were high. When the Fifth Avenue mansions gave way to new builders after World War II, their replacements conformed to new architecture. Mr. Trager, the author of ''West of Fifth: The Rise and Fall of Manhattan's West Side,'' has studded his book with anecdotes about the great financiers, writers and society figures who have lived on Park Avenue. He appends a house-by-house chronological list of current Park Avenue buildings. There is no bus line on poshest Park Avenue and its relatively unpeopled sidewalks are far from chummy, but Mr. Trager takes the reader on an illuminating trip worthy of the carriage trade.

title: On Screen They're Playing Politics
description: Charles Dudley Warner was clearly a man before his time. If the American author and editor hadn't died in 1900, he would probably be suspected of having Earl Long and Belle Starr in mind when he wrote:

title: Four Cubans Give Up Refuge
description: Four young Cubans who had taken refuge at the Italian Ambassador's residence in Havana gave up and returned home, the Cuban state television and the Italian Government said today. Eighteen other Cubans remain at the Spanish Embassy, the only foreign mission still harboring refugees since a rash of requests for asylum began on July 9.

title: HOPE AND HEARTBREAK
description: It is chilling to think that $80 for a 96-hour work week is considered a virtual bonanza in the less-developed world - and that people are made to feel grateful for the opportunity to be thus exploited (''The Border Boom: Hope and Heartbreak,'' by Sandy Tolan, July 1). Tolan's moving article reduces the complex and impersonal laws of the global economy to their proper dimension - the human one.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

What Does It Mean to Be Old?
description: LEAD: OF the dozen or so old men who made up the minyan at the old age home I began visiting more than four years ago, only Mr. K and Mr. W are left. Mr. W cannot speak; he can only call out an indecipherable cry which I interpret as great joy at seeing me again, but for all I know may be rage that I do not come more often or that I do not understand what he is struggling to say.

title: Ornithologist Escapes Harm in Capsizing
description: Roger Tory Peterson, one of the nation's foremost ornithologists, said yesterday that he suffered ''the most critical incident of my life'' Thursday, when his boat capsized in rough waters off Maine.

title: Milkman, With More Than Milk, Continues to Make Rounds
description: LEAD: MICHAEL RAMOS recently bought into a 70-year-old Westchester business that many people think is extinct. He has 650 loyal customers, most of whom he has never spoken to and spends about six hours a day traveling the same few miles to serve them. He starts working in the dead of night and finishes around noon.

title: Variations on Ambiguity
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: Notebook;   The Race That Isn't a Race
description: Sparky Anderson, the dean of major league managers, knows a pennant race when he sees one, but he's not sure what he sees when he looks at the American League East.

title: A Man Called Into Action When Election Losers Demand Recounts
description: JOHN L. CARBONE is a practical man; he does not take sides in an election until after it is over. But, oddly enough, he often sides with the loser.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Paying Their Own Way, Almost
description: LEAD: BACK in the 30's, a certain population drifted around the country, changing jobs constantly, forming temporary personal relationships, living from hand to mouth. They were called vagabonds or hobos. Today they're called college graduates.

title: Confusion Reigns As Yankees Lose
description: Confused and frustrated, Chuck Cary went to the mound for the Yankees in Cleveland Stadium tonight uncertain of which pitches he was going to throw, how often he was going to throw them, and who would get the credit or blame for their success or failure. It should not come as a surprise that Chuck Cary lost again.

title: The Judge Not Chosen Is Less of an Enigma
description: President Bush interviewed her for the Supreme Court nomination for which he ultimately selected Judge David H. Souter. John H. Sununu, the White House Chief of Staff, hinted that she might be nominated for the next Court vacancy. But Federal Judge Edith H. Jones is not the type to let such heady attention affect her judicial demeanor.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
description: Ours is a nation of law, and Rose's arrogance ignored the law, for which he should pay the same penalty as any citizen.

title: THE PRIME OF PAT SCHROEDER
description: Susan Ferraro's fine article ''The Prime of Pat Schroeder'' (July 1) reports that the nine-term Representative from Colorado is known on the Hill as the ''lone wolf'' of Congress. From the listing of her many accomplishments and her obvious dedication to family issues and cutting of military waste, it would seem that we could use several hundred more such lone wolves in Washington.

title: MILITIA IN LEBANON DRIVES BACK ENEMY
description: For the first time since heavy fighting broke out in southern Lebanon two weeks ago, pro-Iranian fundamentalists lost ground today in fierce gun battles with a rival Shiite Muslim faction, security officials said. Sixteen people were reported killed and 50 others wounded.

title: Keeping Safe
description: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Russia, my husband and I gained first-hand knowledge about its ever-increasing criminal element.

title: REAGAN'S AMERICA: A CAPITAL OFFENSE
description: What exquisite hindsight! Kevin P. Phillips has discovered that Reaganomics was nothing more than a scheme to enrich the rich at the expense of the rest of us (''Reagan's America: A Capital Offense,'' June 17). Pity that he didn't catch on in 1980 or 1984, when his now apparent distaste for the scheme might have had some influence.

title: New Jersey Democrats Wary of Tax Issue
description: Saying they are getting little help from Gov. Jim Florio, who started it all, Democratic legislators are fighting a rear-guard grass-roots battle against a growing tax rebellion, and there are signs that some lawmakers are ready to concede ground in the face of a protest that will not go away.

title: The Brawley Battlefield
description: OUTRAGE

title: Jennifer Marron Weds T. R. Eldridge
description: Jennifer Ann Marron, the daughter of Donald B. Marron and Gloria Swope Marron, both of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas R. Eldridge, a son of Ann Eldridge Choate of Schenectady, N.Y., and the late Thomas S. Eldridge. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
description: The community-service sentence given to Rose was not fair. Rose was banned permanently from baseball. Yet part of his tax-felony sentence will be 1,000 hours of community service teaching baseball to deprived youth. The art of teaching implies transmitting values and ethical standards to students as well as skills of play. One must question what positive ethics and values ''Charlie the Hustler'' will impart to his pupils. Is it fair that these less fortunate children must receive misguidance from a confessed gambler and and tax cheat?

title: Children's Books
description: LAST SUMMER WITH MAIZON

title: Adventures in Style;   Have Parka, Will Travel
description: Not so long ago, Justine Strasberg was a hard-working Manhattan art director, with tidy routines and not much time to play. She liked her shoes polished and her shirts neatly done by the Chinese laundry around the corner. She had camped out before, but not anything hard-core, not anything like this. This was a four-month trek that began in London and wended its way through Central Europe and on to the Middle East. This meant extensive cohabitation with 20 strangers and no showers and certainly no Chinese laundries. But Strasberg coped. Her pivotal, pre-journey purchase was an orange DKNY parka, which doubled as a pillow throughout most of the trip. (Little did she know that parkas were hitting celebratory status on European runways; see pages 36 and 37.) ''I didn't want to look too goofy, and I didn't want to look 'regulation camping,' '' Strasberg says, ''but I needed something that would make the transition from Syria to the streets of Rome.'' At the right is a kind of snapshot collage by Strasberg of her odyssey: Above, Strasberg's tent; above right, the trusty parka; letters home (including the opus at right), and snippets from her diary.

title: A Cabal in the Kremlin
description: KHRUSHCHEV ON KHRUSHCHEV

title: Having Children Without Marriage
description: The June 10 ''Jerseyana'' article on Miss Mary Pomeroy's crisis pregnancy in 1874 speaks volumes about the decline of morality in America.

title: Review/Cabaret Julius LaRosa Pays Homage To Golden-Age Lyricists
description: ''Words are the most important thing to me in a song,'' declared Julius LaRosa early in the opening-night show on Tuesday of his three-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza). The singer, who was accompanied by Don Rebic (pianist), Art Koenig (bassist) and Don DiMarco (guitarist), went on to sing astutely chosen homages to the lyrics of Johnny Burke, Sammy Cahn, Mitchell Parish, Yip Harburg and Johnny Mercer.

title: An Athlete of Perception
description: A NATURAL HISTORY OF THE SENSES

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: ALARMED by an acrid stench that started filtering from the Mattabassett sewage-treatment plant in Middletown, Matthew Esposito called the State Department of Environmental Protection last November. Mr. Esposito, who lives near the plant, wanted the department to investigate.

title: Orchestrators Are Tired of Playing Second Fiddle
description: When the ''City of Angels'' composer Cy Coleman accepted his Tony award for best score last month, he thanked his producer, his director, his cast, his designers, the ''most awesome music group that I've ever worked with, and the best band in a Broadway pit ever.''

title: ROMANIA'S LOST CHILDREN
description: I was overwhelmed by the pictures of the children in Romania. As the mother of a multihandicapped daughter, I am fortunate to have help available at the Federal, state and local levels - physical therapy, vision therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy, cognitive and social stimulation. As a speech and language pathologist who works with children, I know how important it is to have such early intervention.

title: A Venerable Inn's Nouvelle Ways
description: THE latest reincarnation of the venerable White Hart Inn's restaurant may be the best yet. The inn, which is more than 100 years old, has recently changed owners and has had an elaborate refurbishing. Of greater importance to those interested in fine food, the dining room has been overhauled and a new chef, Kevin Schmitz, installed.

title: Bursts of Solar Energy Endanger Power Lines
description: Bursts of charged particles from the Sun sporadically cause huge surges of electric current through power lines on Earth, destroying transformers or tripping protective devices to take power lines and other equipment out of service and raising the possibility of widespread blackouts, utility experts say.

title: Revisions Sought in U.S. Food-Aid Program
description: Each year the United States sends so much grain to Egypt that the farmers feed loaves of bread to their cows.

title: 'Night, La Guardia
description: All the world loves the tale of a marooned traveler, but alas, those adventures aren't as picturesque as they used to be. Today, any ordinary vacationer may become stranded in a place like Palau or a Portuguese coastal village, with little money, knowing no one, forced to pass the night in a rental car. Lost traveler's checks, a wrong turn, a travel agent's blunder. Sure, a shipwreck has more panache, but these modern tales in which no kindly native offers help, no hotel clerk smiles understandingly, are as forbidding in their own way as ''Robinson Crusoe.'' ''What a shocking ordeal,'' the castaway will later tell you. ''I might have been killed!''

title: Galicia's Hard-to-Come-by Barnacles
description: Goose barnacles, bane of boatmen and certainly among the most unsightly creatures of the sea, are for all appearances inedible or, at the very least, thoroughly unappetizing. From a pointy pearly white and hard-as-rock shell, percebes, as these barnacles are called in Spain, extend into blackened leathery necks. Against all odds, however, barnacles are a greatly esteemed seafood in Spain, outranking prawns, lobster and langoustines in prestige and popularity and commanding almost double the sky-high prices of other crustaceans. Sweet, succulent, with something of a lobster consistency and flavor, fans say this seafood captures the pure taste - the very essence - of the sea as no other can.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Driving Miss Daisy

title: A Singer to Rival the Legends? Not Just Yet
description: It's a good thing the Metropolitan does not have to put on an opera Sunday evenings. On this past March 4, it would have had real trouble, because most of the roster was over at Alice Tully Hall. Without even trying to look, I saw Carol Vaness, Marilyn Horne, Neil Shicoff, Aprile Millo and several others; it was about the starriest crowd I can remember sitting in. They were there to hear Dmitri Khvorostovsky, a 27-year-old baritone from Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, who has accomplished the unusual feat of winning star-level invitations to the world's great houses and an extravagantly promoted, exclusive major-label recording contract, with next to no operatic experience under his belt. A few roles in Krasnoyarsk; one production of ''The Queen of Spades'' in Nice; that is all.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE subject is rocks. Rocks and television and what they have in common.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

The 'Great War' At Camp
description: LEAD: WE would wake up that morning, and electricity would fill the air. Something was different; something was coming.

title: To Reduce Violence, Decentralize Police;   Real and Deadly
description: Given the differences in size of the black and white populations, one can quickly calculate that the proportion of blacks reported to have committed such assaults is approximately three times the proportion of whites reported doing so, which confirms, rather than contradicts, the F.B.I. report based on arrest statistics.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 29, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $5.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords. 2 35 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 3 5 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) title: Campus Life: Oregon;   Family Housing Is Opened To Unwed Couples
description: The University of Oregon has opened its family housing to unmarried heterosexual and homosexual couples with children, but has kept it closed to such couples without children.

title: How to Fit In At Princeton
description: Oh, what is so rare as a sensible building that is not too sensible, a lively building that is not too lively, a comfortable building that is not - no, wait a minute. This building is just as comfortable as it ought to be, and pleasant to look at besides. It is the new Computer Sciences Building at Princeton University, a campus that is rapidly becoming one of the nation's most ambitious architecturally, and it was designed by the New York firm of Kliment & Halsband.

description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 7 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) title: Karen Issokson and Marc Silver Are Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Issokson of Hyannis, Mass., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Karen Lee Issokson and Marc Adam Silver, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Silver of Secaucus, N.J.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: BARBARA C. SALKEN;

What Role Does the Grand Jury Serve?
description: LEAD: A NUMBER of criminal cases in recent weeks have focused attention on the secret workings of grand juries in the county.

title: Circuit Breakers: Maybe They Work, Maybe They Don't
description: The embattled futures industry finally got a break last week, and it came in the guise of plummeting markets.

title: The World;   Romania Isn't Trusted, Within Or Without
description: After decades of eerily quiet summers under the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Bucharest faces a long hot summer. Tens of thousands of university students have taken to the streets to demand the release of a leader charged with inciting disorder at protests in June. Huge lines for meat and cheese stretch from bare-shelved stores onto the scorching streets while consumers grumble about hefty price increases for gasoline and bottled drinking water. Even the miners, the muscular Government supporters who flocked to Bucharest last month to chase protesters from the streets, are threatening to strike for higher wages.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: OTHER PEOPLE'S MONEY, by Arthur Lyons. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) A bidding war over stolen artifacts convinces the private eye Jacob Asch that museum directors and art collectors aren't necessarily such cultured people after all. ''Mr. Lyons has hit upon a subject worthy of his detective's intelligence in this art-is-hell caper,'' Marilyn Stasio said here last year.

title: Pipe Bomb on Israeli Beach Kills Canadian and Hurts 19
description: A pipe bomb exploded today on a crowded Tel Aviv beach, killing a 17-year-old Canadian tourist and wounding 19 people, officials said.

title: Robin Wilde Married To Richard Lauchnor
description: Robin Kim Wilde, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Dyke Wilde of Flemington, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Alan Lauchnor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Lauchnor of Schnecksville, Pa. The Rev. David E. Dietzel, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Packer Memorial Church at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Sports Violence Beyond Detroit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've been advising members, at a more accelerated rate, about how they ought to conduct themselves. I've said, 'I don't know how many more pictures I've got to paint for you. We've got rules and we've got rules. If you want to protect yourself, keep yourself well inside the parameters.' ''

title: Miss Walsh Wed To Andrew Rose
description: Sarah Eva Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Walsh of Fishers Island, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Andrew Beirne Rose, the son of Beirne Waters Richmond of Sedona, Ariz., and R. Peter Rose of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Edward J. Wisneski and Canon Robert T. Hollet, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church.

title: Searching for Judge Souter
description: To replace retired Justice William Brennan, President Bush has offered a mystery. It's been a long time since the nation asked ''Justice Who?'' about a nominee. Mr. Bush virtually challenges the Senate - his constitutional partner in staffing the Court - to find out what it needs to know about David Hackett Souter.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Campus Life: Michigan;   Critics Question A Plan to Send Students to Gaza
description: A decision by the University of Michigan student assembly to allocate $1,000 to help send two students with a delegation to the West Bank and Gaza Strip has met with sharp opposition from another student political group as well as members of the university's board of regents.

title: Fashion;   Dresses That Make Versatility a Virtue
description: The invitation is to a quiet little dinner in a restaurant or someone's home. It won't be formal, but a suit seems too businesslike and pants somehow too casual. What to wear? The answer, of course, is a dress. Nothing fussy or frilly, just a simple dress in a flattering color and a comfortable fabric.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Jamestown, R.I.;

Affordables Near Newport
description: LEAD: A NONPROFIT housing company's purchase of an apartment complex here will create the first subsidized housing for families in this small island community and will help to preserve scarce rental units.

title: Our Animals, Our Selves
description: CREATED FROM ANIMALS

title: Amy C. Cox Married to David S. Prall
description: Amy Caroline Cox, the daughter of Bernard S. Cox of Akron, Ohio, was married last evening to David Stuart Prall, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart E. Prall of Hewlett, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Union League Club in New York.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: Current events evoke the past: the unbundling of the Soviet-dominated Eastern Bloc intersects with the 50th anniversaries of the spread of Nazi domination in Eastern Europe.

title: Ban the Bag: New Haven Outlaws Plastic
description: LEAD: TODAY New Haven becomes the third municipality in Connecticut to ban some kinds of plastic packaging. But as the city's new rules go into effect, a new state law is taking the steam out of similar drives in other communities.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Dr. Harold J. Raveche;

At the Forefront of Computer Technology
description: LEAD: ENTER the computer world of megaflops, gigaflops and, potentially, teraflops. Your guide will be Dr. Harold J. Raveche, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: Where a Boom May Not Be a Boon
description: Expanded American trade and investment in the Soviet Union might prolong President Gorbachev's political life, but a number of American executives are beginning to sense that it could prove more a disaster than a boon for the American companies involved.

title: Pamela T. Dey, Writer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kinsley van Rensselaer Dey Jr. of Chapel Hill, N.C., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Pamela Tower Dey, and Matthew John Vossler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Vossler of Fairfield, Conn.

title: Laura A. Gussoff To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Laura Anne Gussoff to Douglas Adam Brown, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald S. Brown of Richmond, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Gussoff of Rye Brook, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

title: Terrell Returns
description: After Walt Terrell compiled a 2-7 record with a ballooning 5.88 earned run average, the Pittsburgh Pirates decided the right-hander was no longer major league material and released him after he refused a minor league assignment.

title: Amy Baldwin Strasenburgh MarriedTo Alexander H. Ware in Rochester
description: Amy Baldwin Strasenburgh, a daughter of Ruth B. Strasenburgh and Robert J. Strasenburgh 2d, both of Rochester, was married yesterday to Alexander Hopper Ware, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Winslow Ware Jr. of Richmond. The Revs. Kenneth Howard, a cousin of the bride, and Thomas Richards officiated at the First Baptist Church of Rochester.

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer error, a line was deleted from Flora Lewis's column in some copies on Saturday. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Fire I. Election An All-Time Low
description: As a former editor of The Fire Island News, a member of its founding staff in the 50's, an Ocean Beach resident and long-time observer of its politics, I found that the June 1 mayoral election hit an all-time low, even in this scrappy little village. And The Fire Island News scored even lower.

title:
DINING OUT;

Polished, Updated Northern Italian Fare
description: LEAD: TUCKED into a modest row of shops next to the Foodtown parking lot, Beaugard's glossy, raspberry-painted storefront, with shirred sheer curtains at the windows, shines like a little touch of Europe in the Bergen County community of Dumont.

title: Many Shrines for Worship
description: Pete Rose might not be so worried about being elected to the Hall of Fame if he were a racing driver. His chances would be better for numerical reasons alone: while major league ballplayers have to limit their aspirations to Cooperstown, racers can aim for any of six different halls of fame.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Fajitas' Counterpoint: Sweet and Spicy, Tart and Tangy
description: The popularity of fajitas is rising, though it is doubtful that those who first made them would recognize their modern permutations.

title: Yanks' Demise: A Theory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ART;

Montotypes and Monoprints Reveal an Elusive Freshness
description: LEAD: MONOTYPES and monoprints stand out from more common multiple prints by the quality of uniqueness. The artist paints on the copper plate or lithography stone and prints in the normal way - once only. In this way, the factor of the pressure inherent in the printing process enters in. In monoprints, some details remain on the plate so another print can be produced with variations.

title: Bronx Bombers, Or Nonbombers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Modern Pantheon Saves History's Words
description: THE rare book and manuscript collection of Yale University began in 1701 with a handful of books contributed by 10 ministers who met to found a college in the Colony of Connecticut. Over the decades, streams of other such gifts followed. Today, the Yale collection has expanded to some 500,000 volumes and more than a million manuscripts, which are now housed in a temperature- and light-controlled granite-and-marble building on the campus.

title: Shari Hoffman Plans October Wedding
description: An October wedding is planned by Shari Michelle Hoffman and Jack P. Baron, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence L. Hoffman of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced. Mr. Baron is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Baron of Morris Plains, N.J.

title: To Reduce Violence, Decentralize Police;   Self-Contradictions
description: To the Editor:

title:
Style Makers;

Gary Stewart and James Austin, Record Developers
description: LEAD: ''We don't believe in the gold record ethic,'' said Gary Stewart, vice president for artists and repertory of Rhino Records. He and James Austin turn fragments of popular culture into leading-edge style.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
description: No. Federal judges have life tenure, so they can make decisions with as little pressure on them as possible. Occasionally, they should be ready, willing, and able to hand down precedent-setting decisions. In my opinion, the Rose case was one of them. I would have leaned real hard on Pete, but no jail time. Two main reasons. He was an inspiration to millions of American boys for 24 long years as a player. Americans could very easily relate to him. He did not possess any great baseball skills. He made it big by sheer determination, dedication, concentration and hustle.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Here Are the Overlooked Pornographers
description: LEAD: ''MORALITY in Media Takes on Adult Stores'':

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: How Many Bosses Does It Take . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Property Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Babylon Opposes a Nynex Tower
description: LEAD: A LEGAL battle is under way between the Town of Babylon and Nynex over whether Nynex has the right to install a 130-foot-high transmission tower in East Farmingdale.

title: Guardian of Parking for the Disabled
description: When the police discovered that Pat Fletcher planned to patrol the parking lot outside the K Mart Shopping Plaza here to prevent able-bodied drivers from using spaces reserved for the disabled, they were skeptical.

title: The Last Best Site in Manhattan
description: Call it Lincoln West, call it Trump City or call it the old Penn Central rail yards along the Hudson River. Those 76 acres between 59th and 72d Streets constitute the finest remaining development site in Manhattan, a site again knotted in confusion and controversy. It's a Gordian knot that can be cut only by the sword of city and state government.

title: China Assails British Passport Plan for Hong Kong
description: China said today that it would not accept a British plan to give passports to selected people from Hong Kong and attacked the move as a violation of the spirit of a Chinese-British accord on the territory's future.

title: Style Makers;   Viola Sylbert, Fur Designer
description: Her first big success, in the 1960's, was a boxy coat of squares of rabbit fur outlined in leather bands. Viola Sylbert also designed poor-boy sweaters, knitted shifts and leather jackets as a response to French ready-to-wear.

title: Carey White Is Married To Christiana M. Carroll
description: Christiana M. Carroll and Carey Lee White were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph's on the Brandywine in Greenville, Del. Msgr. Paul J. Schierse performed the ceremony.

title: Not Enough Of Edberg
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sexual-Attack Suspect Arrested In Cape May
description: A man suspected in a series of aggravated sexual assaults in this resort town has been arrested, the police said today.

title: Season's First Hurricane Is Born in Atlantic
description: The first hurricane in the Atlantic in the new storm season was born today when a tropical storm's winds strengthened to 75 miles per hour, hurricane forecasters said.

title: Business Diary
description: COMPANIES

title: Edgy Toon Eases Into New System
description: Al Toon, an athlete always in control - of his body, his surroundings, his opponents - has been worried.

title: Testimony Begins in Lawsuit Over Effort to Aid Contras
description: Testimony has begun in the Federal trial of a civil suit pitting Eugene Hasenfus, the only survivor of a plane crash that helped to expose the Iran-contra affair, against Richard V. Secord, a leading figure in the scandal.

title: DATA BANK/July 29, 1990

Hers;

Small Fry Swearing
description: LEAD: I got back from Saturday morning errands to find the kitchen humming with excitement. ''Our son got asked out by a girl,'' my husband said, for once coming straight to the point.

title: Gardening;   A Special Collection of Day Lilies
description: If ever there was a flower for summertime, it has to be the daylily. If ever there was a place to see them in full bloom, it is at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Goodbye to All That
description: THE END OF THE COLD WAR

title: Whose Side Were They On?
description: LEAD:

title: A Landmark Church in Chappaqua Prepares for Restoration
description: LEAD: THE new mortar may not be the exact same mixture Horace Greeley devised, but that is about all that won't match the original when the Episcopal church of St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua is restored.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: LOUNSBURY POND;

Swimming Returns, but Only Briefly, to a Closed Park
description: LEAD: LOUNSBURY POND at the Blue Mountain Reservation here is quiet now, left to the dragonflies and the slow-moving fish. Canada geese skim its surface before the sun sets and in the early mornings.

title: Jasper Johns, Incessant Recycler of Images
description: Writing about Jasper Johns, it is often irresistible to quote, yet again, the artist's famous sketchbook note: ''Take an object. Do something to it. Do something else to it.'' Johns has built an influential career on these legendary instructions to himself and they illuminate the basic tenets of his art with increasing accuracy.

title: 1960's Troupe Celebrates 25 Years of Enthusiasm
description: For those who were alarmed by the shaggy hair and radical politics on college campuses in the 1960's, the traveling musical troupe Up With People was a comforting reminder that some of America's youth, at least, had interests other than insurrection.

title: Topics of the Times;   Louisiana's Example
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer gave the Louisiana Legislature's abortion bill a more careful review than it deserved. He found it wanting, devoid of minimum humane consideration for women. He deserves respect for his courage in vetoing the bill in the intimidating climate created by anti-abortion politicians.

title: D. L. Jenkins Wed To Ms. Gerstman
description: Ellen Kim Gerstman, the special events assistant at the School of American Ballet in New York, and David Larson Jenkins, a program representative at Columbia Artists Management in New York, were married last evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Lawrence Milder.

title: Kathleen Reilly to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Reilly Jr. of South Salem, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Kathleen May Reilly and Mark Gross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Gross of Sudbury, Mass. The couple, both 27 years old, are 1985 graduates of Dartmouth College. She works for her father as the executive director of the Richard J. Reilly Jr. company, a builder of platform tennis courts in Danbury, Conn. Mr. Gross has a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania and is to become an associate at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in September. His father is president of Penfield Sportswear in Nashua, N.H.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Reassessment Order Troubles Nassau
description: LEAD: A recent order by Justice Leo F. McGinity of the State Supreme Court requiring Nassau County to reassess all of its 360,000 one-, two- and three-family residences once again raises the question of how revaluation would affect homeowners.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: American Heritage Woven into Show on Historic Quilts
description: LEAD: SHARON CERNY OGDEN does not really consider herself a crusader. Yet whenever the opportunity arises, Mrs. Ogden, a quilter from Farmingdale who enjoys a national reputation in her field, has a message to deliver.

title: Surgery for Gubicza
description: If the Kansas City batters and baserunners had been as busy this year as the team physician, Steve Joyce, perhaps the Royals would not be at the bottom of the American League West.

title: Turin's Baroque Splendors
description: Turin, the capital of a small state half on one side of the Alps, half on the other, where the ruler spoke French and most of but part of the population Italian, is an improbable place for some of the best architecture in Italy, especially since it was invaded with great regularity by French, Spanish and Austrian armies; and yet in the 17th and early 18th centuries it became home to two architects of genius, Guarino Guarini and Filippo Juvarra, brought there by successive Dukes of Savoy.

title: Golf Course Development Gets Rougher
description: TO the 222 million Americans who do not golf, the line that forms before dawn at the Tamarack Golf Course in East Brunswick, N.J., may seem eerie, perhaps even cult-like. But to many of the nation's 25 million golfers, such bleary-eyed rituals are par for the course.

title: Topics of the Times;   RefleXions
description: What is it in popular culture that so exalts X? The letter is becoming so popular as to invite confusion. Nexus used to mean a connection between individuals of a group or members of a series. Now, spelled Nexxus, it refers to a brand of hair-care products; and spelled Nexis, it's the name of the Mead Data Central Company's computer system for retrieving information from newspapers and magazines.

title: Operatic Performances for Young and Old
description: DO warm nights and Italian opera go together? Yes, says the Opera Theater of Connecticut, which will offer a double bill of Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci'' for a two-weekend run at Andrews Memorial Theater in Clinton.

title: Read His Mind;   Bush's Enigmatic Choice for the High Court
description: ''I DON'T want to ruin my reputation,'' Judge David H. Souter said to the reporters on Air Force One on Friday. ''I have two words to say: Hi and goodbye.''

title: Dodging Hippos on the Zambezi
description: Long after leaving, images of Africa take root in the memory. For me, some that linger are braking for goats on a dirt road; brush fires that smell like perpetual autumn; driving through towns made up of ubiquitous landmarks - a gas station, a superette, a tearoom and a ''supermodern'' nightclub. There is also the wonder David Livingstone called ''God's Highway'' - the Zambezi River.
