It is still possible to experience this wide, lush landscape, and all the wildness that goes with it, silent and langorously, mercifully free of wheels and engines - by canoe.

title: Upscale Ideas for the Summer Picnic Basket
description: AS convenient as sandwiches may be to eat on a picnic, they are better at the beach or for lunch in the park than more refined picnic occasions, like an outdoor supper before a summer concert. When wine and bottled water are served instead of beer and soft drinks and when linen napkins replace paper, the menu calls for something more stylish than the typical sandwich and potato salad.

title: Managing;   Proper Conduct in the Workplace
description: Several years ago, Borden Inc. asked a dozen or so employees to devise a smoking policy for the company's Columbus, Ohio, headquarters. The group - comprised of smokers and nonsmokers, men and women, executives and secretaries, oldtimers and newcomers - set rules that were more restrictive than the smokers wanted but also stopped short of the total ban that many nonsmokers had been pushing.

title: Determining the Cost of Auto Insurance
description: In the June 10 article ''Changes Readied for Auto Insurance,'' the new auto insurance laws were said to create ''objective criteria that will define a good driver'' and thus help determine fair premiums. The plan calls for 75 percent of the drivers falling into a ''standard'' (good driver) category, 15 percent into a ''nonstandard'' category and 10 percent into an ''assigned risk'' class.

title: Correction
description: A letter to the editor on July 15 about college students' growing interest in dinosaurs referred incorrectly to the writer, Maurice B. Rosalsky of Englewood. A retired professor of geology at City College in New York, he did not also teach at the University of Florida.

title: Keeping Safe
description: To the Editor: Your review of security problems in tourist cities around the world was on target in describing the activities of the ''bag hustlers'' who surround midtown transportation terminals and harass people waiting for a taxi.

title: Headliners;   Adding to the Mix
description: Hong Kong has long been a mixture of Chinese and British styles and traditions but Dame Lydia Dunn has added another ingredient to the blend as the territory moves closer to becoming a part of China in 1997. Dame Lydia, a 50-year-old executive director of a British-run Hong Kong conglomerate, Swire Pacific Ltd., was honored on the Queen's birthday list in June with a life peerage, an honor held by only two other Hong Kong residents, both men. It means that one day soon she will join the House of Lords, a legislative institution that has symbolized British male gentry for centuries. She is one of the few Chinese women to have risen quickly in Hong Kong's British-styled society. Whether she can translate that into political power in Hong Kong is not clear. Some Chinese may view her as an emissary of Britain. As for the House of Lords, Dame Lydia said, ''Whenever I think about being introduced into that august body, I often think, 'I wonder what they think to have someone like me in their midst?' ''

title: Gas Tax Hike Could Help Us Kick Auto Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Property: Midtown Hotel Renovations;  $52 Million Drake Project Adds 2 Elevator Shafts
description: In Room 1510 at the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue, it is readily apparent that the current renovation is much more than cosmetic. An entire chunk of floor is gone, leaving a 8-by-9-foot hole through which one can easily glimpse Room 1410.

title: Outdoors;   For Striped Bass, Try Live Alewife
description: When shore fishing for striped bass in the Northeast slows down, as it always does in July and August, I begin thinking of using bait rather than lure or fly to woo those fish.

title: Quayle Aide Named a Judge
description: President Bush plans to nominate Diane Weinstein, counselor to Vice President Dan Quayle, as a judge of the United States Claims Court, the White House announced today. She would succeed Randall R. Rader on the court, which hears claims against the Federal Government. Her term would run for 15 years.

title: REAGAN'S AMERICA: A CAPITAL OFFENSE
description: The anti-Reagan forces will have to try harder. Extremes of income and wealth are a fact of capitalism, but one that is really beside Phillips's point. The Reagan era has brought the longest economic expansion in American history. What matters is whether the vast majority of Americans benefited from the expansion. They did: their real disposable personal income rose every year between 1982 and 1989. Whether the expansion created a few more billionaires is irrelevant.

title: Kenyan Human-Rights Lawyer Urges Economic Sanctions by U.S.
description: A prominent Kenyan human rights lawyer has called on the United States to press for democratic changes in Kenya by imposing economic sanctions similar to those in effect against South Africa.

title: DANCE VIEW/Marina Dolganova-Balanenko;   For a Russian, Modern Dance Is a New World
description: For three weeks this summer, she was the first Soviet journalist to visit the American Dance Festival, in Durham, N.C. This essay, written for The Times, was translated by Lynn Visson.

title: The World;   In Quebec, Yet Another Splintering
description: In English-speaking regions of Canada, many spy an enticing irony in the crisis currently gripping Quebec. In the midst of the French-speaking province's renewed debate over independence, it has found itself confronted by an angry minority of its own, Mohawk Indians. Just as Quebecers have claimed to be a ''distinct society'' within Canada, so too are we, the Mohawks have proclaimed from the armed camps they have established across two highways near Montreal. If Quebec is a nation unto itself, say the Mohawks, no less so are we.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.;

Builders Bet On Offices
description: LEAD: WITH three office buildings under construction and a fourth just finished, this city's downtown has become South Florida's most active center of new office development.

title: Garbo, Paderewski and a Skeptic
description: To the Editor:

title: New Accounting Proposal Create Nonprofit Anxiety
description: When a wealthy businessman said in 1986 he would donate $1.5 million to Princeton University, the school, as is usual for a nonprofit organization, decided not to show the revenues on its books until it had collected the money. It is a good thing, because the donor, Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager, was subsequently arrested on insider trading charges, putting him in no position to follow through on his pledge.

title: Feeling the Pinch in a Shorter Season
description: WHILE professional theaters await, on tenterhooks, the announcement of grants by the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, the consequences of cutbacks in general are already being felt by a number of summer theaters during the current shortened, uneven season.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
description: Pete Rose's sentence was certainly not unfair; in fact, it was rather light. Didn't Leona Helmsley receive about eight times the sentence that Rose received for committing the same basic crime? Giving Pete Rose a break in court just because he is a baseball hero is like giving an unqualified secretary a job just because she has a gorgeous body. It is silly to allow irrelevant considerations to stand in the way of making a rational and fair decision. On the ball field, Rose is a living legend to be admired by all. In court, he was a tax-evading criminal to be dealt with as any other tax evader.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Berkeley Heights $215,000

title: World Markets;   The Greek Market Takes Its Turn
description: In the months since the narrow victory last April of the conservative Government of Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis, the Athens stock market has soared. The tiny Greek market is up 200 percent for the year, and it is the leading performer by far this year in the group that analysts class as emerging stock markets.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JAY HOME REFURBISHED

title: Cards Halt Mets On Fatal Fastball
description: The afternoon haze had dissolved into a premature twilight, the scoreboard lights had melted into a blur of zeros and the sense of restlessness and distraction that had long before swept through the crowd had now crept across the field and into the dugouts as well. One swing of Willie McGee's bat, though, got matters focused in a hurry.

title: Miss Kolodzey Is Engaged
description: Jody Kolodzey and John Francis Hogan, doctoral candidates at the University of Pennsylvania, she in folklore and he in English, plan to marry next year. Miss Kolodzey, a daughter of Elizabeth J. Welman and George J. Kolodzey, both of Philadelphia, graduated from Temple University. Mr. Hogan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Hogan of Champaign, Ill., graduated from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Dr. Henry Harris;

Do Mothers Harm Children by Working?
description: LEAD: HALF of the women in this country with children less than 1 year old now work outside the home. Still, the question of whether women should combine paid employment with raising a family remains emotionally charged.

title: Secretly Linked to the Same Woman
description: FADO ALEXANDRINO

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: G.M. Chairman Roger B. Smith will drive the first Saturn car off the assembly line in Spring Hill, Tenn., the day before he retires.

title: A World Gone POW!
description: Face it, our century's guiding spirit has become the comic strip. The argot of POW! and ZAP! is an Esperanto available to all levels of society in all countries. What Orfeo and Euridice were to older civilizations, Mickey and Minnie are to our culture. It is difficult to sympathize with the hermetic sexual problems of Tristan and Isolde when one considers the grander issues of war, peace and political corruption confronted daily and often on Sunday, too, by Superman and Lois, Batman and Robin, Tracy and Tess. Cartoon pablum is the universal solvent in which Everyperson can periodically enjoy a good wallow.

title: Currency;   Sinking Against the Mark
description: The dollar moved into new territory last week. First, it hit a two-and-a-half-year low against the German mark on Monday as the stock market plunged. Then it fell further on Friday as the report on the American gross national product for the second quarter showed a very sluggish economy, one held above water only by the build-up of inventories. The dollar closed on Friday in New York at 1.6115 against the mark. It has not been this low since Jan. 5, 1988, when it closed at a dismal 1.5880. (The dollar surged to a close of 1.6380 on Jan. 6, 1988, after central banks bought dollars to support it.) But against the yen, the dollar is still holding its own. Despite the stock plunge and the weak report on G.N.P., the dollar was up slightly on the week at 149.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Of Course I'm Bringing Food to My Daughter at Camp
description: LEAD: SAY, I wonder how many bags of Jolly Ranchers I need to bring? This camp doesn't even allow food in the bunks. For the last two weeks, my wife and I have been getting ready to visit our daughter Merryl. Yes, this is her first time away from Mom and Dad for an extended period. Well, there was that trip her fifth-grade class took to Washington, but that was only for a week and she knew everyone.

title: Review/Pop;   Byrd and J.B. All-Stars: Funky Rhythm and Blues
description: They go by various aliases: the Pee Wee Ellis Assembly, Maceo Parker and Roots Revisited, the J. B. Horns and, on Wednesday night at S.O.B.'s, Bobby Byrd and the J. B. All-Stars. While the name and the lead singers change, the band has funk's Holy Grail at its fingertips when it knocks out the lean, punchy syncopations its leaders learned through years as James Brown's backing band. The All-Stars' set on Wednesday was a megadose of pinpoint rhythm, suave horns and gutsy singing. Like a great potato chip, it was the perfect mixture of grease and crunch, and after a two-hour set listeners shouted for more.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The Bolshoi Ballet season at the New York State Theater this month was much better than expected, not quite as excellent as hoped. To say the company has been in transition is to say nothing new, as that has been the case for the last decade.

title: Penny Scott Planning September Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Scott Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Penelope Ann Scott, and Philip Alexander Moss, a son of Mrs. Roland C. Sherrer Jr. of Salzburg, Austria, and New York, and Peter Bayard Moss of Chestertown, Md.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Tech Notes;   An Off-Road Rover - Far Off
description: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., is testing a new ''off-road vehicle'' - designed for Mars. ''Robby,'' as it's called, has an articulated body, a variety of sensors and stereo television cameras. The unmanned craft is designed to travel several kilometers a day. Two navigation strategies are being tested. One, the CARD (computer-aided remote driving) system, would allow a human operator on Earth to control the vehicle directly. CARD's drawback is that it takes up to 40 minutes to send a message between Earth and Mars. The other system, SAN (semi-autonomous navigation), would allow an operator to determine an overall route, but give the vehicle's computers the freedom to navigate on their own around obstacles like boulders.

title: Suzanne L. Siegel Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Siegel of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Suzanne Lisa Siegel, and Gary Burton Zenkel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Zenkel of Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Few Words About Lasix
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: About Cars;   How to Clean Up and Also Stay Happy
description: Constant readers will recall that I have a couple of old Cadillacs, a red '65 convertible and a black '66 Coupe deVille, both of which I love dearly. What they won't know is that like lots of car nuts, I have been under some pressure to get the family's fleet down to sensible size.

title: Dr. Katz Is Affianced
description: September wedding plans for Dr. Alyse Bryna Katz and Jay Evan Sicklick, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Sicklick of West Hartford, Conn., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Katz of New York. Dr. Katz, a resident in rehabilitation medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, graduated magna cum laude from Boston University, where she also received a medical degree. Mr. Sicklick, a lawyer in New York, graduated cum laude from both Colgate University and the Boston College Law School.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Track and Field: Solutions to the Crisis
description: Make no mistake, track and field is a sport in crisis. The public's confidence has been shaken by a seemingly never-ending series of controversies. As it stands now, for instance, only a statistician with an assist from a surveyor and a meteorologist could tell you what the marathon records are today. Money, agents, egos and conflicting priorities have many of America's best athletes avoiding each other, entering and withdrawing from events right up until race time.

title: In the Fight Against Urban Despair, A Fresh Face and a Firm Grip
description: AS a young caseworker in Manhattan in the mid-1960's, Audrey Rowe visited the home of a client, a high school dropout who lived with his mother. Their small West Side apartment was strewn with garbage and overrun by roaches, Ms. Rowe recalled, ''and the stench was enough to make you gag.''

title: Pipeline Chief Is Hopeful Despite Delay in Approval
description: ROBERT J. REID, the president of the gas-transmission company that expects to send a pipeline through seven western Connecticut communities, said he saw a silver lining in a regulatory agency's decision last week to delay the project.

title: Q and A
description: The Right to Buy

title: Jennifer D. Stiles Engaged to Wed
description: September wedding plans for Jennifer Daggett Stiles and Joseph David Morris have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. William Stiles Jr. of Port Jefferson, L.I. Mr. Morris is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Morris of Cliffside Park, N.J.

title:
The Executive Life;

The Art, and Even Danger, of Gift-Giving
description: LEAD: A few weeks ago, Norman Kurtz was in a panic. In preparing for an important business trip to Japan, the managing partner of the New York engineering firm of Flack & Kurtz had finally decided to bring his Asian business hosts silver pens from Tiffany & Company. But he had become frozen with fear after colleagues had warned him of Japan's most delicate gift-wrapping etiquette.

title: A Tax Debate Revived
description: The Bush Administration opened old political wounds this week when it proposed to limit the amount of state and local income taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal returns.

title: Jean Fourastie Is Dead; French Economist, 83
description: Jean Fourastie, an economist who helped oversee the reconstruction of postwar France, has died. He was 83 years old.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Sutton Place
description: LEAD: To New Yorkers and out-of-towners alike, Sutton Place instantly suggests status and affluence. The assumption is correct.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;

The Berkshires
description: LEAD: Think of the Berkshires as an island - a place set off from its surroundings by barriers as palpable as a moat - and the area's attraction for artists seeking seclusion, wealthy entrepreneurs seeking exclusion, 1960's hippies looking for an alternative life style, is as clear as the night sky reflected in the waters of the Stockbridge Bowl.

title: Steinbrenner Decision Tomorrow?
description: Even before Commissioner Fay Vincent held his hearing, George Steinbrenner and his advisers indicated that they expected at least a two-year suspension for the Yankees' principal owner. Now they expect to learn tomorrow if their expectations were correct.

title: Jennifer Topor Is Married To Michael McDermott
description: Jennifer Ann Topor, a painting specialist at the William Doyle Galleries, and Michael McDermott, a corporate bond salesman at J. P. Morgan Securities, both in New York, were married yesterday at Abbey Chapel of Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass. The Rev. Mark Stelzer performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. Mrs. McDermott, 23 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Topor Jr. of South Hadley. She graduated from Kenyon College. Mr. McDermott, 27, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul McDermott of Shrewsbury, Vt. A graduate of the University of Vermont, he is to enter New York University in September to study for a master's degree in finance.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Kimberly Grillo to Wed in September
description: Fred Grillo of Stonington, Conn., has announced September wedding plans for his daughter Kimberly Ann Grillo and David Hal Bernstein, the son of Diane Bernstein and Paul Bernstein, both of New York.

title: Lifestyle;   Earth Issues Lure a New Breed of Young Worker
description: Greg Terwilliger is one of a new breed of young environmentalists - a graduate of Landfill University and a sanitation man with a master's degree in business administration.

title: Washington Journal;   In a Public City, a Monument to Private Struggles
description: The nation's capital is not exactly a spiritual city, but it has its spiritual corners. It even has a small but valuable history of people close to power struggling with spiritual questions. One of them was Henry Adams, whose extraordinary monument lies off one of the least beaten paths in Washington.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Voorhees Is Realizing His Deferred Dream
description: Although Vern Voorhees was 6 feet 2 inches, he was overweight at 240 pounds. He smoked two packs of cigarettes a day. He was a prime candidate for a heart attack, and when that heart attack came in 1980, when Voorhees was 40, it changed the life of his only child, Barry.

title: Holmes vs. Patterson
description: It wasn't one of those monster boxing promotions with a multimillion-dollar guarantee and a network contract, so chances are you missed Larry Holmes in his last bout, an exhibition in Binghamton, N.Y., on June 23.

title: Headliners;   Moving Up
description: Bishop George Carey describes his career as ''rags to purple.'' The son of a hospital porter, he grew up in public housing in London and recalls sharing his brother's shoes. Last week, Dr. Carey, a bishop for less than three years, was named as the next Archbishop of Canterbury, the spiritual head of the Church of England and 70 million Anglicans around the world. He will succeed Archbishop Robert Runcie, who is retiring. Theologians said that the 54-year-old Dr. Carey has a combination of qualities that will translate into a forceful and progressive expression of Christian faith. He is, they say, a scholar and a leader of the Church of England's evangelical wing, which stresses traditional beliefs. Dr. Carey, describing himself as ''dazed and unworthy,'' said he would speak out on political and social issues as Dr. Runcie has done, sometimes riling Conservative Members of Parliament. Said Dr. Carey, ''I don't see my background as being a problem in this job.''

title: Paul M. Caliandro Is Married to Mary B. Uehling
description: Mary Birgit Uehling, a transportation analyst for the Boston Metropolitan Area Planning Council, and Paul Michael Caliandro, the manager of accounting operations at the State Street Bank in Boston, were married yesterday at the First Parish Congregational Church in Manchester, Mass. The bridegroom's father, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a Dutch Reformed minister who is the senior minister at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York, officiated.

title: The Executive Computer;   Liberating Machines From Keyboards
description: One big obstacle to a wider adoption of computers is the keyboard. ''I had not even touched a computer before I came here, because I never learned how to type,'' confessed a man recently hired as a senior marketing executive by a large computer company. He has now learned to type - and to use a computer.

title: U.S. Holds a 6-3 Lead After a Day of Cup Play
description: All three of the world's international titles in golf - the Ryder Cup for professional men, the Walker Cup for amateur men and the Curtis Cup for amateur women - are held by Europeans, but the United States took a step toward regaining the Curtis Cup today.

title: Backpacks That Become Luggage
description: There is a new breed of luggage on airport conveyor belts and on the backs of budget travelers in European streets. This is the ''travel pack'' or ''soft pack,'' which converts from a suitcase with a handle into a medium-sized backpack. The crucial difference between this luggage and a rucksack or big athletic bag with webbed handles is that travel packs have frames that distribute the load on your back.

title: Robin V. Zirilli Is Married to Stephen Jay Obie
description: Robin Virginia Zirilli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Zirilli of Montgomery, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Jay Obie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Obie of West Haverstraw, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph G. Farias officiated at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Haverstraw.

title: Christina Baker and David Kline Wed
description: Christina Joy Baker, a writing teacher at the University of Virginia, was married yesterday in Bangor, Me., to David Franklin Kline, an English teacher at the St. Albans School in Washington. The Rev. William S. Winston and the Rev. James Curtis officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Anything But Cancel
description: To the Editor:

title: A. G. Moore Weds Carolyn A. Kuehn
description: The marriage of Carolyn Armstrong Kuehn and Andrew Gibbs Moore, both 24 years old and 1988 graduates of Brown University, took place yesterday at the chapel of the Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, Conn. The Rev. Rolf Buchmann, a Lutheran minister, officiated. Mrs. Moore, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul G. Kuehn of South Windsor, Conn., graduated from Loomis Chaffee and was until recently a law student at Vanderbilt University, where her husband is studying medicine. The bride's father is a senior surgeon at Hartford Hospital. She is a granddaughter of the late Right Rev. Robert E. L. Strider, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of West Virginia.

title:
CONNECTICUT GUIDE;

Memory May be Gone, But Rituals Persist
description: LEAD: ''GIRLIE, come sit by me,'' implores Irma, beckoning to the empty place next to her on the couch. ''I want company.''

title: Helping Commuters Get Dinner To the Table
description: LEAD: THE van raced the train to the station, where the driver handed the tired commuter a package with this message: ''Borlenghi ai Quattro Formaggi!''

title: Namibia's Mighty Menagerie
description: We had encountered most of the resident menagerie - lions, elephants, giraffes, zebras, warthogs and antelopes of all sizes from the lumbering eland to the delicate steenbok. What we had missed was a rhinoceros. In most other game parks, our search for this endangered creature would have been futile, but Etosha National Park in Namibia has a healthy population of 300 black rhinoceroses.

title: Dr. David Chernoff to Wed Jill Sperber
description: October wedding plans for Jill A. Sperber and Dr. David N. Chernoff, a son of Shulamith S. Chernoff of New Haven and the late Dr. Hyman M. Chernoff, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Susan M. Sperber of New York and Dr. Norman D. Sperber of San Diego.

title: Consider Their Ways and be Wise
description: THE ANTS

title: Review/Jazz;   Two Young Saxophonists With a Taste for the 60's
description: Jazz's younger generation is obsessed with the 1960's, when the music reached its greatest harmonic and rhythmic complexity and then burst wide open into modal and free jazz. Christopher Hollyday and Courtney Pine, two saxophonists in their 20's who have steeped themselves in the music of the mid-60's, are sharing a bill through tonight at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street. Both have impressive technique in music that bespeaks ambition and determination; both are journeymen, not yet masters.

title: The Maestro Is a Molester
description: NEMESIS

title: The Tragedy of Detroit
description: It was in the Fall of 1986 that I first saw the devil on the streets of Detroit.

title: Focus: Maine;   Phasing In a Ban on Cottage Conversions
description: When Roger Timmons heard that the State of Maine planned to ban the conversion of summer homes into year-round dwellings in certain environmentally sensitive areas, he was plenty worried.

title: The Language Thing
description: Yes, the President talks funny. Yes, he gets tangled in wayward clauses and preppy adverbs, dangling predicates and galloping gerunds. Yes, he never met a pronoun he liked or a non sequitur he could resist. And no, they are not saving space for George Bush, between Edmund Burke and Cato the Younger, in future editions of ''The World's Great Speeches.''

title: Jamaica
description: To the Editor: Like another reader who was disappointed in one of the summer music festivals (Letters on Travel, May 6), I want to describe my experience with Jamaica's Reggae Sunsplash two years ago.

title: Susan Ziegler to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John K. Ziegler of Chatham and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Susan K. Ziegler and Albert Saltiel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alberto Saltiel of Oakbrook, Ill. Both are graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University. Miss Ziegler, 26 years old, is a credit specialist for the Sanwa Business Credit Corportation in Chicago. Her father is the chairman of Willcox & Gibbs, a maker and distributor of sewing-machine and electronics parts in New York. Mr. Saltiel, 26, is a marketing analyst at Jaguar Cars in Mahwah, N.J. He received an M.B.A. from DePaul University. His father is a physcian in private practice in Oakbrook.

title: The Rocky Road to HDTV
description: To the Editor:

title: A 3-Man Show at Blue Hill: Sculpture, Portraits and
description: CHARLES SEARLES and Oliver Johnson are American blacks, Robergeau Duverger is from Haiti and all three are showing their work at the Blue Hill Cultural Center. Unless a 1988 exhibition by contemporary Chinese artists can be counted, this is the first show based on ethnic identity that the center has staged in its seven-year career and one hopes it will be the last.

title: 'Metropolitan' Chronicles Preppy Angst
description: John Whitney Stillman is keenly sensitive to hairline distinctions within New York's upper middle class. In the eyes of this 38-year-old film maker, the difference between the East Side of Manhattan and the West Side - or between Edgartown and Chilmark on Martha's Vineyard - looms almost as wide as the rift between India and Pakistan.

title: Canada Proposes Settlement in Mohawk Standoff
description: After nearly three weeks of armed confrontation between the Quebec police and Mohawk Indians at two locations outside Montreal, the Canadian Government and the Quebec authorities have put forth a series of proposals to end the dispute.

title: LeMond Is Sore
description: After spending three weeks mostly bent over on a saddle it's not surprising that a fellow might want to spend some time on his feet. That, it turns out, is more or less what Greg LeMond has been wanting to do since winning his second straight Tour de France last Sunday.

title: Voter Support for Tax Cut Grows in Massachusetts
description: Fueled by widespread anger over Massachusetts' fiscal disarray, a tax-cutting proposal that would reduce the state's $13 billion budget by more than 10 percent is gaining strong voter support and sharply dividing politicians and business leaders.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: The World;   South Africa, Alone Again, Makes Way For Communism
description: Communism may be crumbling around the world, but in South Africa it is undergoing a curious renaissance. The South African Communist Party, which President F. W. de Klerk on Feb. 2 restored to legal status after 40 years as an banned organization, is launching itself as a full-fledged political party.

title:
ART;

Jackson Pollock, on a Modest Scale
description: LEAD: THE region's most historically significant exhibition so far this season is also the most modest in scale, for it consists of just six Jackson Pollock screenprints. They are on view through Labor Day at the Pollock-Krasner House and Study Center, East Hampton.

title: To Reduce Violence, Decentralize Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Leave Census as is, Republicans Urge
description: Republicans around the country are urging the Bush Administration not to make any statistical adjustment of census results to correct for an undercount of black and Hispanic residents.

title: Justice and Mercy
description: Perhaps there comes a moment in the life of every woman when she yearns to telephone an 84-year-old man she has never met and ask, ''How could you do this to me?''

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Our toilet takes a long time to flush and sometimes keeps on running. The problem seems to be the float ball on the end of the float arm not clicking off when it gets to the top, and so the water keeps running into the tank. What can I do to correct this?

title: Jane Barg Plans To Wed in August
description: August wedding plans for Jane Barg and Lewis Asher Scheindlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Scheindlin of Philadelphia, have been announced by Miss Barg's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Barg of New York.

title: The Man Who Would Be Feared
description: Saddam Hussein emerged from last week's OPEC meeting more than ever a figure feared and respected by his Arab brethren. The Iraqi President's threats against a tiny neighbor, Kuwait, expressed many things about him: his determination to lead the Arab world in what he sees as a just cause, his penchant for intimidating those who challenge him, and his willingness to carry a bluff to the edge of a precipice.

title: Innocence Among the Palms
description: NOVEMBER 1948

title: Service, Through Four Generations
description: LEAD: IN 1890 Morris and Sarah Levy, newly arrived from Germany, opened a store on Cortlandt Street in North Tarrytown to sell hand-rolled cigars. A hundred years later the store is the oldest continuous family business in the Tarrytowns, although it has undergone a few changes.

title: Talking: Co-op Taxes;   Auxiliary Income Is Liable
description: A long dormant tax threatens to gobble up a large portion of the auxiliary income that residential co-ops enjoy from such sources as interest on reserve fund accounts, operation of a laundry room or rental of professional or retail space.

title: ABORTION POLITICS ARE SAID TO HINDER USE OF FRENCH PILL
description: The French developer of a pill that induces abortion has asserted that worldwide distribution of the drug is being blocked by fears of American reprisals against its manufacturer and the World Health Organization.

title: MUSEUMS AND POLITICS  Time to Go Back To the Ivory Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spin Doctors of Early Music
description: What does early music have to do with history? In theory, everything. In fact, very little. At the beginning, the movement was frankly antiquarian - a matter of reviving forgotten repertories and, with them, forgotten instruments and performing practices. Nobody objected to that, nor did most musicians even pay much attention to it. Now, it seems, Early Musickers are performing almost everything. They have laid claim to the standard repertory, and attention must be paid. More than that, sides are taken - the movement in its present phase has become controversial.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was Pete Rose's Sentence Fair?
description: Pete Rose has used his status and his stats to engage in both unlawful and uncivil behavior. He was always a bully on the field and now it appears that this arrogant bearing has undone his personal life.

title: Greek Artists Share a Shinnecock Bond
description: LEAD: THE Greek word ''koumbaroi'' means brother-in-law or godfather, or in the more general sense, family or friend. The word symbolizes a special relationship that makes family feel like friends and friends like family.

title: Wedding in Philadelphia For Stephanie P. Coleman
description: Stephanie Patryce Coleman, a daughter of Mrs. John Konrad of Darien, Conn., and Fletcher Bennett Coleman, was married yesterday to James Carl Ruger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Worthington Ruger of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Ralph Waite, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Friends Meeting House in Philadelphia.

title: Food;   ODE TO SKEET'S
description: Darlington, S.C., is a normally peaceful town of white-frame houses with big porches on the front and azalea bushes in the yards. But every Labor Day, about 80,000 people show up on the outskirts to observe a Southern ritual called stock-car racing. I travel to Darlington several times a year myself, though no longer on Labor Day. I went to the race once and I'll never forget it. I couldn't hear a thing for weeks.

title: Jill Kaplin Is Engaged To Wed Andrew Herz
description: September wedding plans for Jill Kaplin and Andrew Herz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Herz of Larchmont, N.Y., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Maury Kaplin of Toledo, Ohio.

title: Scenes From Morocco
description: To the Editor:

title: 4,000 Mongolians Hold Rally On Eve of National Elections
description: More than 4,000 youths rallied today on the eve of a second round of Mongolian elections, cheering candidates opposing the ruling Communists.

title: The Woman Who Interviewed Hitler
description: LEAD:

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The World Junior Team Championships for players no older than 25 are now played in odd-numbered years. The first two, in 1987 and 1989, were played in Europe, and European teams were victorious. The American teams that competed were unable to mount a serious challenge, but matters may be different next year.

title: Partnerships for Third-World Growth
description: ''The private sector should be an engine for growth and prosperity,'' declared Sam Nujoma, President of the world's newest nation, Namibia, in his inaugural address last March. ''We look forward to a good partnership between the state and private sectors, because only through working together will our economy prosper.'' These are encouraging words from a man who until recently spoke the language of African socialism.

title: American League;   Red Sox Set Doubles Record
description: Boston set an American League record with 12 doubles, 3 of them hit by Wade Boggs, who also drove in 4 runs, as the Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers today, 13-3.

title: Ex-Banker to Noriega Is Convicted In Scheme to Aid Drug Traffickers
description: A former personal banker for the ousted leader of Panama, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, was convicted along with five other people today in a scheme to launder $32 million in profits for major Colombian cocaine traffickers.

title: On Your Own;   A 3-Piece Rowing Shell
description: A boat designer from Noank, Conn., has created a rowing shell that can be split into three pieces so it can be carried and easily stored. Robert Champlain, the shell's inventor, said his shell took about 10 minutes to put together. Fully assembled, it is 20 feet 3 inches long. When the three parts of the hull are put one inside the other, the unit is 7 feet long and 23 inches wide. The hull weighs 53 pounds.

title: Airport Project Shows Hong Kong's Unease
description: As planes land at Kai Tak airport here, they swoosh down close enough to the windows of buildings to make passengers feel like peeping Toms.

title: Siege at a London Nightclub
description: A gunman took more than 100 hostages in a nightclub here early today and demanded to be flown to Beirut before surrendering 10 hours later, the police said. The gunman was finally persuaded to leave his last six hostages and walk to the top of a flight of stairs, where officers were waiting, a police superintendent, Alex Edwards, said.

title: Reviews/Music;   Twists On Works Of Mozart
description: Perversely yet predictably, the numbing sense of routine that has at times crept into the Mostly Mozart Festival over the years has particularly affected the most familiar works of Mozart himself, pieces like the ''Serenata Notturna'' (K. 239) and the Symphony No. 39, which opened and closed the concerts on Friday and Saturday evenings at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Goodwill Games;   Twin Swimmers in Harmony
description: Sarah is more ambitious, wears more conservative clothes and feels more inhibited in large groups. She also has more freckles. Karen has a more sarcastic sense of humor, takes a more casual approach to life and is less sure about her future. Her haircut is funkier.

title: Gail Anne Berson Weds in Providence
description: Gail Anne Berson, the executive director of admission and student aid at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., was married yesterday to Jay Selwyn Goodman, a professor of political science at Wheaton. Rabbi Leslie I. Gutterman officiated at Temple Beth El in Providence, R.I.

title: A Modern-Dance Troupe in China Stretches the Limits of Tradition
description: In the right hands, official restraint has long served as the subject of penetrating art, an old lesson that was taught with renewed poignancy here this week in the powerful debut of China's first modern-dance troupe.

title: Radio Freelancers in Israel Paid By Government-Supported Studio
description: For the last four years, the Israeli Foreign Ministry and a Jerusalem radio studio have run a covert program in which radio reporters were hired by the studio and given Government guidance on what they should report to radio stations around the world, participants in the program and other Government officials say.

title: Watching the Work of Playing Music
description: In 1983, the New York Philharmonic closed its season with a two-week series of Horizons concerts and symposiums, which explored recent scores of a lush, Romantic sort. In the seasons that followed, neo-Romanticism remained the central focus, with other current styles added for perspective, but in 1987, the orchestra dropped the series.

title: Deadlock Is Broken on California's Budget
description: The California Legislature, breaking a record 28-day deadlock, has sent Gov. George Deukmejian a $55 billion budget and 18 related bills on fees, taxes, savings, budget cutting and prisons.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 29:

title: Account
description: * Polaroid Corp., to Siboney Advertising, New York, for Hispanic marketing.

title: Chronicle
description: After five whirlwind days in Washington, JUDGE DAVID H. SOUTER, PRESIDENT BUSH'S nominee to the United States Supreme Court, got a lift home to New Hampshire aboard Air Force One as the President headed for his summer home in Kennebunkport, Me.

title: Another Survivor Is Rescued From Philippine Hotel Ruins
description: Rescue teams recovered a man alive today from the ruins of an earthquake-shattered hotel in the Philippines. He had been buried for 14 days, radio reports said.

title: Tennis;   U.S. Tops Soviet Union To Win Federation Cup
description: With Gigi Fernandez providing a fresh spark and Zina Garrison recovering from a loss in singles, the United States gained a 6-4, 6-3 doubles victory over the Soviet Union today to win its 14th Federation Cup tennis title in 28 years.

title: Jonathan Miller Resigns As Director of Old Vic
description: Dr. Jonathan Miller will resign as the artistic director of the Old Vic when the current season ends in March, the owner of the theater has announced.

title: Absolute Power? Yes, Absolutely
description: During a hearing before Commissioner Fay Vincent on July 6, George Steinbrenner engaged in a philosophical discussion with Vincent on the powers that enable a commissioner to investigate any act suspected to be ''not in the best interests of baseball,'' powers that have led to the commissioner's inquiry into the Yankee owner's activities.

title: Slow Book Sales? Off to the Shops!
description: Isabel Geffner spent two days at the Shakespeare & Company bookstore on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last week, unpacking boxes of books, stocking shelves, setting up displays and fielding questions from customers about what to read on vacation and where to find a book entitled ''Sex After Sixty'' - a ''gift book,'' the customer stressed.

title: Tool Orders Rose 27.2% Last Month
description: Reflecting a surge in exports, orders for American-made machine tools rose 27.2 percent in June from the level of May, the industry's trade association says in its monthly report. But economists cautioned that the rise did not reflect significantly higher spending on capital improvements in the United States.

title: Lageman Making Noticeable Changes
description: The Andrew Dice Clay T-shirt was gone today, but Jeff Lageman was still wearing the pony tail, the ripped blue jeans, riding his Harley Davidson and building his reputation as the unforgettable character of the Jets' camp.

title: Low-Budget Candidate Pressing Campaign in Connecticut
description: Never mind that William J. Cibes Jr. had only $44 in his campaign account for governor as recently as the middle of this month, or that he thinks the state needs an income tax on wages to make wealthy people pay more, or that few Connecticut residents know who he is anyway. Mr. Cibes is the low-budget candidate who roared.

title: Queens Boy, 3, Killed by Car
description: A boy celebrating his third birthday Saturday night was struck and killed by a car driven by a drunken driver in front of his home in Ozone Park, Queens, the police said. The boy, Anthony Jabar, was pronounced dead at the scene at 104-53 124th Street. The driver, Peter Soomdat, 19, of Jersey City N.J., was charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

title: Where Price-Cutting Causes Pain
description: The growling of lawn mowers, that ubiquitous sound of suburban summers, is music to the ears of executives at the Briggs & Stratton Corporation, the world's largest maker of lawn mower engines. Briggs engines made here have been the heart of American mowers for generations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Busch Spots Fight Rise In Beer Tax
description: ONE of the newest campaigns from Anheuser-Busch is steeped in ''America the beautiful'' sentiment, with shots of farmers walking through their fields and working men at lunch, as an announcer explains how the country was built by people willing to give their fair share.

title: Mexico - America's Next Iran?
description: LEAD: During his speech on ''Enterprise for the Americas,'' President Bush called Cuba the lone holdout in ''a resurgence of democratic rule'' in the hemsiphere. But Mexico, where honest elections have not been held in more than 30 years and political repression is growing, should be added to the list of countries resisting the global trend toward freedom.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East Europe's Gypsies: Unwanted Refugees
description: The week that the Calderash family decided the town of Lugoj,, in Romania, was too unsafe for gypsies, they sold their horses and pigs, packed some bags and boarded a bus going west.

title: Television;   Risks of Being Shot Down Are Rising for the Networks
description: THE fall television season, always billed as a time of high promise, looms this year as a time of high risk for the networks.

title: Ban Lifted, Communists Gather in South Africa
description: Despite the retreat of its ideological allies in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, the South African Communist Party re-launched itself as an open movement today - 40 years after it was outlawed as a threat to Afrikaner nationalism and white minority rule.

title: Brazil Shifts Debt's Priority
description: President Fernando Collor de Mello says the Government will give precedence to economic recovery and growth over the payment of foreign debt, according to press reports published today.

title: Robin B. Cooper, A Student, Weds
description: Robin Beth Cooper, a student at the Minnesota School for Professional Psychology in Minneapolis, and John Howland Fleming, an assistant professor of social psychology at the University of Minnesota, were married yesterday at the Sheraton Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. Rabbi Shimon Berris and the Rev. C. Parke Street 3d, an Episcopal minister, officiated.

title: People
description: * Michael Cannon has been appointed president and chief executive of FCB/Maqueda, Mexico.

title: Mortgage Rate Down
description: Interest on fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.98 percent last week, down from 9.99 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released last week by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the second consecutive week that fixed-rate mortgages were below 10 percent. The last time that occurred was in mid-January. For one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.41 percent, up from 8.39 percent last week. The rates do not include the fees known as points.

title: Most New York Teachers Back Power Sharing
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: Shortly before leaving for a vacation in England last week, a multimillionaire couple from Farmington, Pa., were intrigued by a newspaper article they read about the buying of British titles. So after settling in at Claridge's in London, JOSEPH A. HARDY and his wife, DOTTIE, asked their tour guide about the possibility.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Private Lesson on Moscow Potholes
description: The new governing powers of this abominably potholed city have rebuffed the state's sluggish road workers and hired an aggressive private contractor to repave Moscow's Ring Road as a kind of giant advertisement for can-do capitalism.

title: Bridge
description: A tough battle for the Spingold Knockout Team title was in prospect today at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals. Contending were teams led by Jim Cayne of Manhattan and John Mahaffey of Winter Park, Fla., and after 42 deals of a scheduled 64 Mahaffey led Cayne by 39 international match points. When the same teams met in the same event a year ago Cayne won by 3 and went on to win the title.

title: Article 123090 -- No Title
description: During the first quarter of this year, savings and loan associations sold ''junk bonds'' with a face value of $1.3 billion, according to a study by K. H. Thomas Associates, a bank and savings industry consulting firm in Miami.

title: For Steinbrenner, Waiting May End Today;   Suspension Called Likely
description: The ramifications of two December events six years apart will converge today when Commissioner Fay Vincent, barring a last-minute snag, announces his decision in the George Steinbrenner case.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Y.& R. Fills Position In Government Relations
description: Young & Rubicam has named John Rindlaub, a senior vice president, as director of industry and government relations, a new position. The agency noted the ''increasing pressure'' on advertisers from governmental bodies, and the recent naming of Alexander Kroll, its chairman and chief executive, as vice chairman of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Sanders Refuses To Repay Falcons
description: Upset by the confrontational posture of one of his two employers, Deion Sanders, the sometimes Yankee outfielder and at-other-times Falcons defensive back, said today he would not return a portion of his $2 million signing bonus to the Atlanta club if he decides to extend his baseball commitment into the football season.

title: British Esquire Planned
description: A British edition of Esquire magazine will make its debut next March, the Hearst Magazine Company said last week. Lee Eisenberg, Esquire's editor in chief, will be the new magazine's editor. Esquire, a life-style magazine for men with a monthly circulation of 734,000, is also published under foreign licenses in West Germany, Hong Kong, Japan and Italy.

title: In Marrow Donor Lawsuit, Altruism Collides With Right to Protect Child
description: A father's efforts to save his leukemia-stricken son with the bone marrow of the boy's half-siblings has ignited a court fight here and raised the question of whether society should compel to help others.

title: Metro Datelines;   Gypsy-Cab Driver Fatally Shot in Bronx
description: A Bronx gypsy-cab driver was shot and killed Saturday night when two men tried to rob him, the police said.

title: Washington Talk;   Hot Words Of a Justice Are Hardly A Surprise
description: It is so rare for a Supreme Court Justice to speak up in any manner about public affairs that jaws dropped last week when Justice Thurgood Marshall let loose with a string of acerbic comments on the latest Supreme Court nomination.

title: No-Hitter Eludes Garrelts Of Giants
description: Scott Garrelts, bidding for baseball's record eighth no-hitter of 1990, lost it with two outs in the ninth inning on a single by Paul O'Neill as the San Francisco Giants beat the Cincinnati Reds, 4-0, today.

title: Hanoi Aide, Praising U.S., Sees Hope of Cambodia Pact
description: Reacting to the American policy shift on Cambodia 11 days ago, Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam said today that he was optimistic about a settlement of the Cambodian conflict. He said Hanoi agreed with Washington that the main issue now was how to get to ''free, fair and democratic elections under international supervision.''

title: Sharon Steel Pact Reached
description: Victor Posner, the Miami financier, has agreed to pay the Sharon Steel Corporation $7.5 million to settle legal actions against him by the company and its creditors, a Federal Bankruptcy Court trustee says.

title: Books of The Times;   On Putting Pen to Paper, Or Fingers to Keyboard
description: On Writing

title: A Crumbling Pool Divides a Neighborhood
description: Larger than a football field and graced with majestic architecture, the McCarren Park swimming pool was considered a wondrous place when it opened in Brooklyn in 1936.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: TENNIS
description: LEAD: DURING this year's United States Open at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, there will be eyes checking out the whole scene for more than lobs and volleys. They will be looking for things like improved food service, bottom lines and, yes, even that elusive something called ambiance.

title: Review/Television;   CNN Documents 'a Fiscal Disaster'
description: ''S.& L.'s: The Full Story'' distributes blame evenfistedly among Democrats and Republicans, in the White House and in Congress, for what it calls ''a fiscal disaster.'' Tonight's punchy program, at 9 on CNN, is the first prime-time hour produced by the cable network's new special assignment division, headed by Pamela Hill, the former ABC News producer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Barrie Goldstein Is Married To Justin Steffin Ebersman
description: Barrie Lynn Goldstein, an assistant New York State Attorney General, was married yesterday to Justin Steffin Ebersman, the director of investment sales and a vice president of the Sulzberger-Rolfe real-estate company in New York. Murray Kessler, a justice of the peace of New Milford, Conn., officiated at the couple's weekend home in Roxbury, Conn.

title: Agreement on Monitoring 6 School Goals
description: Governors at their annual meeting approved a plan today to monitor the progress of national education goals, but only after they were assured that the monitoring committee would include more governors.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Australian Ballet Presents A Veteran as Spartacus . . .
description: The Australian Ballet invited Gyorgy Szakaly, a principal dancer with the Hungarian State Ballet, to take on the title role of Laszlo Seregi's ''Spartacus'' on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: Charles C. Bassine, Businessman, 81
description: Charles C. Bassine, a businessman who was a benefactor and trustee of number of New York City hospitals, died on Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Palm Beach. He died of cancer, his daughter said. Mr. Bassine was the former chairman of Spartan Industries, a sportswear company that merged with E.J. Korvette in 1966. Mr. Bassine was an overseer at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a fellow of New York University and a trustee of Montefiore Medical Center, Rockefeller University and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. He helped found Brandeis University and North Shore University Hospital.

title: Alaska Road's Opening Starts Battle
description: The Mount McKinley Gold Camp looks more like a gravel pit than a campground, but it has an unusual attraction: It sits at the end of a forbidden 92-mile road that Alaskans have longed to drive.

title: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future;   The Constant Phoenix
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Take Two From the Indians
description: Hours before the Yankees would complete a doubleheader sweep for the second time in three days, one potentially memorable instant at the conclusion of 3 hours and 40 minutes of slipshod baseball allowed the long-tormented fans of the Cleveland Indians to respond to the crack of Candy Maldonado's bat with a sound somewhere between a gasp and a shriek.

title: Labor Dept. Wants to Take On Job Bias in the Executive Suite
description: Even as it is fighting Congress over a major civil rights bill, the Bush Administration says it is looking for a way to curb job discrimination in a realm that the Government has never really touched: the white male echelon that rules the nation's largest corporations.

title: INSIDE
description: Negotiations in Trinidad

title: Student Dies; Whose Fault, Japanese Ask
description: It was a few seconds before the start of high school, and as usual several students were dashing to arrive before the close of the entrance gate. But this time, a 15-year-old girl fell, and a teacher slammed a heavy metal gate into her head. She died later of a concussion.

title: Patrick Butler, Foundation Official, 89
description: Patrick Butler, who helped establish the Hazelden Foundation as an international leader in the treatment of alcoholism and drug addiction, died Saturday after a four-month illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Allied Stores' Debt Plan
description: The Allied Stores Corporation has received bankruptcy court approval of an unusual borrowing arrangement to help it continue operations through its Chapter 11 reorganization.

title: Bruno Kreisky, Austria's Leader For a Record 13 Years, Dies at 79
description: Bruno Kreisky, who dominated Austria's public life as the nation's longest-serving Chancellor from 1970 to 1983, died yesterday at Lainz Hospital in Vienna. He was 79 years old.

title: Cuomo Assailed By Daily News On Labor Panel
description: The Daily News criticized Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday in an editorial, saying he had ordered the creation of a ''completely unjustified'' fact-finding panel to look into the labor dispute at the newspaper.

title: Sports of The Times;   The Fire This Times
description: A DISCREET but firm sign at the driveway entrance to the resplendent Winged Foot Country Club in Mamaroneck, a leafy suburb of New York, reads ''Private.''

title: Photo: Joe Falcon winning the mile ahead of Maurice Smith and Marcus O'Sullivan yesterday at the New York Games. (Michelle V. Agins) Track and Field;   Lewis Triumphant Despite the Winds
description: Stiff winds slowed some record attempts, but Carl Lewis, Joe Falcon, Ana Quirot, Danny Everett and Greg Foster all turned in strong performances yesterday at the second New York Games, bolstering hopes for the meet's future.

title: Israel Seizes 8 Arabs In Bombing at Beach That Killed a Tourist
description: The police in Tel Aviv arrested eight Palestinians from the occupied territories today on suspicion of planting a pipe bomb on a crowded beach that killed a young Canadian and wounded 18 other people on Saturday.

title: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports World Specials
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Desiree Coleman, Singer and Actress, Weds Mark Jackson, Basketball Player
description: Desiree Coleman, a singer and actress, and Mark Jackson, the point guard with the New York Knicks, were married yesterday at the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, the Democratic Representative from the Sixth Congressional District in Queens, who is the pastor of the Allen church, and the Rev. John H. Boyd.

title: Overseeing East German Transition
description: A year ago, Walter Romberg was a mathematics professor with an interest in economics. Today, he is East Germany's Finance Minister, faced with melding his nation's moribund economy with West Germany's economic juggernaut.

title: An Office That Has the Capital's Ear
description: When Congress suspects that an Administration has ignored or covered up a problem, it dispatches a collection of faceless auditors to investigate. Typically, the General Accounting Office finds the problem worse than anyone suspected.

title: GOVERNORS ASSAIL PROPOSAL FOR LID ON TAX DEDUCTIONS
description: The nation's governors, Democrats and Republicans alike, today attacked a proposal to limit the amount of state and local income taxes that could be deducted on Federal tax returns as yet another attempt by the Bush Administration to push more of the burden of closing the budget gap onto states.

title: Goodwill Games;   Yugoslavia Tops U.S. in Final
description: Yugoslavia's basketball team lost one player to a an apparent sprained ankle and two centers to personal fouls tonight but had enough poise and depth to defeat the United States, 85-79, in the final of the Goodwill Games tonight.

title: Treasury's Only Sale Will Be of Bills Today
description: Treasury financings this week are limited to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late Friday the rate on the Treasury three-month bill was 7.54 percent and, for a six-month bill, it was 7.42 percent.

title: On Hills, It Was Like Riding a Kangaroo
description: To the Editor:

title: Accepting The Blame;   In a Scandal, Should The Top Heads Roll?
description: In a number of recent cases involving questionable corporate practices, chief executives have chosen not to abide by Harry S. Truman's credo. The buck stopped with someone lower down.

title: Reviews/Dance;   . . . And Newcomer to Role
description: With his mop of blond curls and his relatively slight build, Greg Horsman would not seem a likely choice for the title role in ''Spartacus,'' the story of a larger-than-life hero who led a slave rebellion against the Romans in 74 B.C. But Mr. Horsman offered a thoroughly convincing interpretation of the character when the Australian Ballet presented ''Spartacus'' on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, in a production choreographed by Laszlo Seregi.

title: One Germany, One Carolina
description: LEAD: First the Berlin Wall came down, hacked into historical oblivion and the deserved ignominy of the souvenir racks.

title: The Wrong Medicine
description: The clear possibility of a recession has been raised by revised Government figures showing that the economy struggled only to a 1.2 percent annual growth rate in the second quarter. So why are White House and Congressional negotiators urging each other on to a tax increase?

title: After Heady 1980's, Homeowners Face a Hangover of Foreclosure
description: Mortgage foreclosures are soaring in the New York metropolitan region as growing numbers of property owners are overwhelmed by crushing real-estate debt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Report

title: The Rape Was a Lie, The Verdict Abusive
description: LEAD: Here's another bad idea: A Nebraska judge has ordered a woman convicted of falsely accusing a man of raping her to apologize publicly to the man by placing half-page advertisements in every newspaper in her county and paying for prime-time radio spots on two local stations. In addition, she was sentenced to six months in jail and put on two years' probation.

title: Strong, Silent Resurgence Of the Old Manual Mower
description: Even as the price of gasoline-powered lawn mowers has dropped in recent years, more people have been turning to the old manual mower, apparently enjoying the exercise it affords and its quiet operation.

title: On Your Own;   Fat-Tire Bikers Try to Behave
description: THE scene is a hiker's nightmare. You are taking a quiet walk in the woods on a summer afternoon. Suddenly, a mountain biker comes barreling around the next bend in the trail, head down, feet hard on the pedals. You shout to him to slow down. He won't.

title: Ms. Magazine Returns With New Spirit, but Without Ads
description: Ms. magazine is back. Or, as the people at Ms. like to put it, the post-patriarchal magabook has arrived.

title: Looting and 3 Fire Deaths Follow Blackout in Chicago
description: Looting broke out overnight on the West Side after a fire at a generating plant left 40,000 customers without electricity, the authorities said today.

title: If You Wash Diapers
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Scene;   So Far, No Shock For Consumers
description: AMERICAN consumers rarely cause a recession. Even when their incomes are barely rising, which is the case today, they somehow manage to spend enough to keep the economy afloat. Only a national shock seems to frighten them into cutting back so drastically that a recession becomes unavoidable. And so far in 1990, that shock has not come.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Hungary Averts A Direct Ballot For Presidency
description: Called on for the second time in less than a year to vote on how they want to elect a president, Hungarians stayed away from the polls in droves today, dashing the hopes of former Communists for a foothold in national politics.

title: Urban League Leader Calls Equality Essential to U.S.
description: Citing projections that members of minorities will make up a larger and larger part of the nation's work force, the president of the National Urban League said last night that the United States must grant them equality not merely out of a moral imperative but for ''its own economic self-interest.''

title: Venezuela Lifts Gasoline Prices
description: After months of wavering, the Venezuelan Government said last week that it would raise domestic gasoline prices. A similar move last year brought rioting.

title: Gooden Is Back In Top Form
description: For Dwight Gooden, the moments of truth that would make up perhaps the most important 48 hours of his season began late last Friday afternoon, hidden from public view deep in the bullpen at Shea Stadium.

title: U.S. and Asian Allies Deadlock Over Boat People
description: Three days of talks between the United States and its Southeast Asian allies have failed to break a deadlock on how to treat thousands of Vietnamese refugees who continue to arrive on foreign shores every year.

title: Student Loan Move Studied
description: A taxpayer bailout of a troubled guarantor of student loans would not cost more than $100 million, an Education Department official said last week.

title: Review/Opera;   An East-West 'War and Peace' Is Part Lyricism, Part Realism
description: Although the Goodwill Games have been a box-office misfortune so far, reportedly running more than $20 million in the red, at least one of this host city's gestures in behalf of East-West understanding has been an astonishing success. The Seattle Opera's $2 million production of Prokofiev's rarely performed ''War and Peace,'' an ambitious effort to squeeze Tolstoy's sprawling novel into a theatrical frame, is playing to sold-out houses and earning roaring approval from audiences. The third of eight scheduled performances, on Friday evening, strongly underlined the work's strengths and did much to make its clumsiest scenes tolerable.

title:
On Your Own;

100-Mile (800-Furlong) Test of Stamina
description: LEAD: SOMETIME around her 40th birthday, with her three children grown and with time to spare, Julie Suhr longed to rediscover the pleasures of her youth. She bought a horse. ''Some people get a convertible when they turn 40,'' recalled a laughing Suhr, who hadn't ridden in 20 years. ''I got a horse. I got the convertible, too, but it's on blocks in the garage.

title: Outdoors: The Kingly Sport of Salmon Fishing
description: FOR the last 20 years, I have never fished for Atlantic salmon more than once or twice a year, and it may be that my relatively rare encounters with that marvelous game and food fish account for the fierce anticipation that precedes each excursion.

title: Fire Guts 85-Year-Old School
description: An early morning fire today gutted the 85-year-old Cos Cob Elementary school, town officials said. First Selectman John Marginot said the damage was extensive. A fire dispatcher said he had seen only one room left standing. The school, which was built in 1905 and was used for kindergarten through fourth grade, will not be open in September. Last year it had nearly 300 students enrolled.

title: Istanbul Journal;   Where 16 Synagogues Stand Among the Minarets
description: The carved portals of the Holy Ark are virtually brand-new at the Neve Shalom synagogue. So are the stained-glass panels above it and the marble tiles on the surrounding wall and on the pulpit floor.

title: Heritage and Pageantry At Powwow in Queens
description: More than 300 years after the Matinecock Indians traded away much of what is now eastern Queens, dancers in buckskin pants and feather headdresses swayed to the rhythm of drums during the weekend against a backdrop of Little Neck Parkway traffic.

title: Figure in Contra Aid Effort Says Bush Reportedly Knew of It in '86
description: An organizer of the secret supply network for the Nicaraguan rebels says he was told that Vice President George Bush was informed of the illegal operation in 1986. That assertion has been repeatedly denied, not only by Mr. Bush, but also by several other participants in the operation.

title: Game Shows Return as Prime-Time Contestants
description: During the 1950's, ''The $64,000 Question'' and ''Twenty-One'' were big hits on prime-time televison. That era is long gone, but the appearance of ''Super Jeopardy'' and ''Monopoly'' on Saturday evenings this summer on ABC has rekindled hopes among some producers that game shows are coming back to prime time.

title: Stanhome's New Chief Began With Summer Job
description: Alejandro Diaz Vargas, who first worked for Stanhome Inc. in a summer job in a distribution center in Puerto Rico, has been named the company's chief executive, arriving at the top post at the age of 45.

title: Jennifer Ginsberg Weds P.E. Libre
description: Jennifer Rachel Ginsberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Ginsberg of Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Eugene Libre, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Libre of Bethesda, Md. Robert Gillette, a justice of the peace and leader of the Congregation for Humanistic Judaism of Fairfield County, officiated at the Unitarian Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Review/Pop;   The Blue Nile's Mystical, Majestic Ballads
description: In ''The Downtown Lights,'' one of several majestic ballads on the Blue Nile's recent album, ''Hats,'' Paul Buchanan, the Scottish folk trio's lyricist and lead singer, invites a companion to share his vision of the evening cityscape as a map of love.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Columbia Bond Buyer Sees an Opportunity
description: LEAD: The Gordon Investment Corporation, a merchant bank affiliated with one of the largest instititutional brokerage houses in Canada, was little known in the United States - until last week, when a partnership it controls agreed to pay $3 billion for the ''junk bond'' portfolio of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, which was hurt badly by its investments in the high-risk, high-yield bonds.

title: Federal Beer Tax Hike Is Just Piling It On
description: To the Editor:

title: Nader Brings 'Community TV' to Buffalo
description: When Buffalo's cable-television system agreed this year to carry a local low-power television station, Channel 58, one of the companies that provides the station with syndicated programming raised the rates it charged to reflect the larger audience.

title: Evolution in Europe;   4 European Nations Planning a New Focus on North Africa
description: Increasingly alarmed by the potential for unrest in North Africa, four southern European nations have begun organizing a major international initiative to bolster political stability and economic development in the Mediterranean region.

title: Calls for Economic Changes Rise Among Chinese Officials
description: After a two-year freeze on the process of opening China's state-controlled economy to market forces, a growing number of Chinese economic officials are openly calling for a wave of changes, arguing that without further liberalization China's march toward development may reverse.

title: For Steinbrenner, Waiting May End Today;   Yanks' Profits Not Just Gravy
description: George Steinbrenner's New York Yankees may by an artistic flop, but financially they not only lead the major leagues but also appear to have become the major source of cash to support Steinbrenner's foundering business empire.

title: Peaceful Waters
description: FOR the last month, 15 teen-age Soviet sailors have been getting a taste of sailing American-style from such bastions of capitalism as the Larchmont and Stamford yacht clubs. At the same time, a similar number of American boys and girls from Westchester, Long Island and Connecticut have been competing in waters off the Soviet Union.

title: 5 Swimmers in Niagara Almost Take a Big Dip
description: A quick dip could have been fatal for five French youths who went snorkeling Saturday about 150 feet from the brink of Niagara Falls, the police said.

title: Golf;   Player Makes a Stand
description: In 1969, anti-apartheid demonstrators at the P.G.A. Championship in Dayton, Ohio, threw a drink in Gary Player's face. This year, Player is siding with the protesters.

title: Lower Interest Rates Called Likely
description: A strikingly weaker view of the economy than the one that existed just a few short days ago has altered psychology in the credit markets, increasing the chances that interest rates will move lower in the weeks ahead, analysts say.

title: Golf;   Daniel Captures L.P.G.A. Crown
description: Beth Daniel shot a 66 today to overcome a five-shot deficit and win the Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship, her first major title in 12 years on the tour.

title: Golf;   U.S. Wins, 14-4, Taking Curtis Cup
description: The United States recaptured the Curtis Cup, the most prestigious international event for female amateur golfers, with a 14-4 victory over the Britain-Ireland team today at Somerset Hills Country Club.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Chronicle
description: ZSA ZSA GABOR spent the weekend in jail, but might have enjoyed it more if the meals had been catered and she'd been able to bring one of her fur coats.

title: North's Prosecutors, in Shift of Strategy, Consider an Appeal
description: Stung by a Federal appeals court decision that set aside Oliver L. North's conviction on three charges and overturned another outright, Iran-contra prosecutors are increasingly pessimistic that they can meet the appellate panel's rigorous standards to prove that their case was not influenced by Mr. North's testimony to Congress.

title: The New Arrivals; Immigrants Reshape New York;   Young Immigrant Wave Lifts New York Economy
description: For the fourth time in its history, New York City is being resettled and reshaped by migration.

title: Lender Backs Raynes Deal
description: Martin J. Raynes, the New York real estate broker and converter of cooperatives, has reached a tentative agreement with his leading bank lender that will reduce his equity interest in the troubled Lincoln Towers, a huge cooperative conversion project on the West Side of Manhattan, bankers said yesterday.

title: Mourners Returned Fire, Police Say
description: Mourners at a gang member's funeral apparently shot back at the two or three men, believed to be from rival groups, who opened fire at graveside in what law-enforcement officials say is an escalating Chinatown feud.

title: A Family Farm Since 1785 Holds On
description: When Art and Phyllis Lain sell their last cows in August, their Orange County farm will be added to the statistics of former dairy farms. Unlike the others, though, it will remain in agriculture, continuing as one of the oldest farms in the United States still being worked by the same family.

title: Premier of Trinidad Offers to Quit if Rebels End Coup
description: Trinidad and Tobago's security chief said today there was scant hope of an early breakthrough in negotiations for the release of Prime Minister Arthur N .R. Robinson, who was taken hostage on Friday in a coup attempt by Muslim rebels and reportedly wired to explosives.

title: Metro Matters;   Which Mayor Knows Best On the Boycott?
description: Who's right about how best to end the boycott by black protesters against a Korean-owned grocery store in Brooklyn: Mayor David N. Dinkins or his predecessor, Edward I. Koch?

title: How Not to Honor Malcolm X
description: An unusual coalition of preservationists, civil rights advocates and militant groups is threatening a worthwhile project that would benefit all New Yorkers. At issue is the future of the Audubon Theater and Ballroom, where Malcolm X was assassinated 25 years ago.

title:
Market Place;

Talks by Chrysler Lift Some Hopes
description: LEAD: NOT since 1982, when the Chrysler Corporation was struggling back from the brink of bankruptcy, have the auto maker's shares attracted so much attention.

title: Lebanon Battles Block Red Cross Ambulances
description: Artillery exchanges between rival Muslim Shiite factions prevented Red Cross rescue teams from evacuating dead and wounded in southern Lebanon today as the main Amal militia force consolidated strategic positions it captured from the pro-Iranian opposition.

title: India Trying To Shore Up Its Tourism
description: The shutdown of the major tourist attractions in the Kashmir because of violence there and an overbooked domestic airline have forced the Indian Government to take new steps to bolster its tourist industry.

title: Ms. Ornstein Wed To Robert Carter
description: Holly Anne Ornstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ornstein of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Mitchell Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Carter of Scarsdale, N.Y. Judge Peter C. Dorsey of the United States District Court in Hartford, officiated at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Cracks in the Colossus
description: Washington has staked a lot of money on big-science programs like the Freedom Space Station, the Superconducting Supercollider and the Human Genome Project. These mighty ventures are cast in the mold of such past triumphs as the Manhattan Project to develop atomic weapons or Project Apollo to land men on the moon. But they are just as likely to be colossal failures. Big science has three serious flaws.

title: Hurricane Weakens to Storm
description: The first hurricane of the 1990 Atlantic storm season, was downgraded to a tropical storm this evening as it headed toward open ocean. Forecasters said the storm, Hurricane Bertha, could kick up high surf along the Southeast coast. Born as a tropical depression off northeast Florida, Bertha grew quickly Saturday into a storm with winds of 75 miles an hour. At 6 P.M. today, its maximum sustained winds were near 70 mph, centered about 360 miles east-southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C.

title: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future;   Beyond Metternich
description: To the Editor:

title: Emigres in New York Trying To Reach Families in Trinidad
description: New Yorkers with family and friends in Trinidad and Tobago said yesterday that they had spent the last three days hunched over telephones trying to make contact with loved ones in the island nation.

title: Review/Concert;   Where Chamber Music Is Learned and Performed
