description: For 40 summers, music's young professionals and advanced amateurs have been coming to the tiny campus of Marlboro College to get away from concert halls, managers, press agents and the people who write reviews like this one.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, the chemical and fuel company, named James A. Maish president of the Amoco International Development Co. William L. Wishlinski will replace him as president of the Amoco Chemical Co. in Europe.

title: Rider Retains Jump Title
description: Heisman and his rider, Michael Matz of Collegeville, Pa., won the $100,000 Crown Royal Grand Prix for show jumpers at today's closing session of the annual Hampton Classic Horse Show. Matz also won the event last year, aboard Schnapps.

title: Raiders Seeking An Identity
description: NOT long ago, the saying goes, the Los Angeles Raiders' arrival in town meant locking up your children. The Raiders were nasty, dirty, physical and tough. The Raiders, in their black and silver uniforms, exuded confidence from the moment they emerged from the tunnel until the final gun, and they were always entertaining, seemingly always on top. They offered memorable playoff performances. They won big in Super Bowls.

title: President of Soviet Republic Seeks U.S. Business Deals
description: Like a one-man chamber of commerce, the President of Kazakhstan, the second-largest republic in the Soviet Union, is trying to convince Americans that his mineral-rich region would be a good place to do business.

title: Problems Could Delay Proposal By Oregon to Ration Health Care
description: Oregon's effort to become the first state to ration government health care based on a list that gives priority to preventive measures has run into problems and could be delayed as long as a year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This case is important to the United States of America, because it shows that those who sit in the ivory tower of society, the bankers in the gray suits, they don't touch the dope, but they should know that if they violate the law and they are convicted, they're going to jail.''

title: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future;   War-Crimes Suspect
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Know Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines;   F.A.A. Investigating Stratford Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating Sikorsky Memorial Airport after discovering what it said were serious violations in management and safety.

title: Question Box
description: First on the Fourth

title: Reunified Germany Offers Hope for the Future;   Why Not Frankfurt?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines;   Car in a Drag Race Kills 2 in Brooklyn
description: One of two cars drag-racing on a street in the East New York section of Brooklyn went out of control last night and killed two men who were watching the race, the police said.

title: Raise Taxes, or Punish Big Cities?
description: Now that President Bush has grudgingly accepted the idea of tax increases, Congress at last is tackling the dirty job of proposing which taxes to hike and by how much. Last week, the White House and senior Congressional Republicans floated a plan to limit the amount individuals can deduct for state and local income taxes.

title: Amy B. Brown Is Wed To Brian Mendelsohn
description: Amy Benson Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Brown of Lancaster, S.C., and Brian Mendelsohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mendelsohn of Moorestown, N.J., were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents by Judge Jay Yoccum of the Moorestown Municipal Court.

title: Wave Hill Gets Pledge to Restore Programs
description: An anonymous donor has pledged $150,000 to Wave Hill, the park and cultural center in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, to help restore its concerts, dance series and art exhibitions, Wave Hill officials said yesterday.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   The Limits Of 'Limited'
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent's decision removing George Steinbrenner as general partner of the Yankees will strip Steinbrenner of much - but not all - of the power he now enjoys in running the team.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   'The Best Interests of Baseball'
description: Here are the pertinent clauses in the Major League Agreement from which the commissioner derives the power to gather information, to impose penalties and to make those penalties binding.

title: Rinfret Renews Call for Death Penalty
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, used the killings of young innocent bystanders in New York City to lend some emotional power today to his call for the death penalty.

title: Business Index
description: Companies

title: Israel and Rights
description: Israel was created in response to savage inhumanity, and more than most countries it avows humane ideals. Perhaps understandably, then, any criticism of Israel for violating human rights touches sensitive feelings. Some supporters find denial easier than looking at the facts.

title: Frohnmayer Concedes Arts Agency Faces a Lag in Public Confidence
description: John E. Frohnmayer, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, today acknowledged that both Congress and a substantial section of the American people have lost faith in his agency, but he insisted that new legislation or guidelines were not necessary to correct the situation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, the computer maker, completed the sale of its printed circuits operation to Acsist Associates Inc. for undisclosed terms.

title: Paris, in Perspective: Outdoors to Outrageous
description: French couture fashions in the week just past can be divided into two parts: clothes that can be worn in the street and clothes that are so ornate they should be sheltered by limousines, palaces and private homes.

title: Tisha B'av, a Fast Day, Helps Bridge Judaism's Secular and Religious Sides
description: For some people Judaism is a culture; for others a religion.

title: Growth in Jobs Shifts to Losses in New York Region
description: After slowing to a crawl for more than two years, the regional economy has shifted into reverse, shedding 8,000 jobs in private industry in New York City and 7,000 such jobs in northeastern New Jersey in the five months ended in May.

title: Entering the Kitchen
description: SOME people say there is no such thing as a home computer, that it is a fiction on the order of Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny and No New Taxes. A computer is a computer, they say, and it is becomes a home computer merely by operating in a house rather than in an office.

title: G.M. Greets 1st Saturn Car With a Closed Ceremony
description: Eight years after committing the General Motors Corporation to a compact-car project called Saturn, Roger B. Smith drove the first customer-ready version of the car off an assembly line in Spring Hill, Tenn., today - the day before he is to retire as chairman.

title: LTV Net Rises Sharply
description: The LTV Corporation, the military contractor and steelmaker, said today that its second-quarter net earnings more than doubled. The company, which is operating under bankruptcy court supervision, reported net income of $76.6 million, or 59 cents a share, compared with $30.3 million, or 21 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Its revenues fell to $1.59 billion, from $1.66 billion. The company said the 1990 quarter included a $44.3 million gain from the sale of its stock in a stainless steel maker. The 1989 quarter was reduced by a $30 million special charge on the writedown of costs on a plant for manufacturing advanced aircraft compounds.

title: Steinbrenner Satisfied He Was Not Suspended
description: George Steinbrenner, who was forced yesterday to resign his 17 1/2-year tenure as the Yankees' general partner, was described by his lawyer as ''satisfied with the resolution.''

title: Weaker Limit on PAC's Is Proposed
description: Three days after Senate Democrats proposed banning campaign contributions by political action committees, the party's leaders in the House today unveiled a proposal that would only limit such donations.

title: Famed 'Country Club Prison' Is to House Violent Inmates
description: The nation's most famous minimum-security Federal prison, whose inmates have included Ivan F. Boesky and H. R. Haldeman, is being upgraded to a higher-security one.

title: Review/Television;   What Works With Whom In Advertising
description: The news from ''Sex, Buys and Advertising,'' tonight's NBC News Special, at 10 P.M., is as follows: Advertising is big business because ads sell merchandise; Hollywood stars earn millions for 30-second spots; agencies compete for clients and increasingly target special groups like Hispanic and teen-age audiences; you can't trust ads to tell the whole truth.

title: Governors' Idea Rejected
description: A proposal by Democratic governors for a national commission to investigate the savings and loan crisis was rejected today by the White House. ''We do feel it is unnecessary to create another bureaucratic body,'' Stephen Hart, the White House deputy press secretary, said in Washington. The governors' proposal expressed concern about the effort to solve the crisis and requested the creation of the panel. It is to be voted on by the full body on Tuesday.

title: Jimmy DeSana Dead; Photographer Was 40
description: Jimmy DeSana, a photographer known for his witty and occasionally gently erotic color images, died on Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 40 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. DeSana was born in Detroit on Nov. 12, 1949, and moved to New York City in 1973. He had his first exhibition in 1979 at the Stefanotti gallery on West 57th Street. With such artists as Cindy Sherman, Richard Prince, Laurie Simmons and James Casebere he helped to make photography an important part of the art scene of the early 1980's.

title: Judge Asserts Cost of Barry Trial Could Have Been Courtroom Issue
description: After six weeks of questioning 43 witnesses about accusations of drug use by Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., prosecution and defense lawyers turned their attention today to finer legal points of the Mayor's trial, arguing about what instructions the court should give the jury before it begins its deliberations.

title: John Inglis, 89, Dies; Led Accounting Firm
description: John B. Inglis, a former chairman and senior partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 89 years old and had lived in Northbrook, Ill.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bulgaria's Ex-Dictator Says He Won't Testify Now
description: The country's former Communist dictator, Todor Zhivkov, today indefinitely postponed his plans to appear this week before the national Parliament in an open televised session.

title: The Media Business: Advertising: Addenda;   Accounts
description: * Escada Beaute Ltd., to Audour, Soum, Larue, Paris, the French affiliate of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, for Escada Fragrance perfume, with an estimated budget of $4 million.

title: Mary A. McCarthy, Professor, 41; Active in Father's Presidential Bid
description: Mary Abigail McCarthy, a professor at Yale University Law School who was highly visible in the political campaign waged by Eugene J. McCarthy, her father, in 1968, died on Saturday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford, Conn. She was 41 years old and lived in Branford.

title: South Africa Is Cultivating Its Ties With Moscow
description: An announcement that the Moscow Circus plans to tour here next year has dramatized the new relationship that South Africa is cultivating with the Soviet Union and some of its Warsaw Pact neighbors as a consequence of political changes in southern Africa and Eastern Europe.

title: When 'Bum' Becomes 'Bomb,' a Bus Becomes a Bedlam
description: It all started when a passenger on a Greyhound bus shouted, ''There's a bum in the bathroom!''

title: News Analysis;   A New Fear of Japan
description: Hardly a month goes by without a warning from a Western Government agency or university that the growing dependence on Japanese microelectronics in the 1980's was only a start. In the 1990's, the theory goes, Japan will parlay the talents it used in largely dominating the making of advanced computer chips to displace - if not acquire - the West's biggest computer makers.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Company News;   Arkla Will Merge With Diversified
description: Arkla Inc., one of the nation's largest natural gas companies, will merge with Diversified Energies Inc., the parent of Minnegasco Inc., a Minneapolis-based natural gas distributor. Under the agreement, shareholders of Diversified will receive between 1.575 and 1.752 shares of Arkla common stock for each Diversified common share. The exact number of shares will be determined based on the trading price of Arkla just before the transaction is completed.

title: Patterns
description: The Right Thing in Brooklyn

title: Profits Scoreboard
After 60 Years, Scientists Return To Fossil 'Paradise' of the Gobi
description: WITH the lowering of another cold war barrier, American paleontologists have roamed the Gobi Desert of Mongolia for the first time in six decades, finding a new reptile species related to the Komodo dragon, identifying promising sites for future excavations and recapturing some of the exotic flavor of the most celebrated fossil-hunting expedition of this century.

title: Ryan Trying Again
description: After failing against the Yankees in a bid for victory No. 300 last Wednesday before a home crowd at Arlington Stadium, Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers is scheduled to try again tonight, against the Brewers at County Stadium in Milwaukee.

title: Debate on Job-Bias Bill Turns to Issue of Damages
description: As the House prepares to vote Wednesday on a bill to combat job discrimination, attention seems to be shifting from the divisive issue of quotas to the equally difficult notion of monetary damages for victims of intentional discrimination.

title:
Books of The Times;

The Lure of Mars and the Long Road Leading to It
description: LEAD:

title: Eastern's Woes Tied To Pressure
description: Many Eastern Airlines maintenance supervisors, including those indicted last week on charges of falsifying records, were trapped between the airline's aggressive management and its militant unionized workers, interviews with people at many levels of the airline show.

title: Bond Prices Continue Strong Rise
description: Continued strong demand for Treasury securities sent prices soaring and interest rates tumbling yesterday.

title: Chronicle
description: LEAD: RICHARD G. DARMAN, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, fell on wet steps at a McDonald's restaurant outside Washington over the weekend, requiring 100 stitches, most of them in his face, his spokeswoman said.

title: Our Towns;   Locking Up Town Openness With a Deadbolt
description: Political squabbles in Milan used to be the generic small-town sort; the Democrats fought with the Republicans, the year-round folks fought with the weekenders and everyone fought about the leaky landfill. That was before Vince Scelba was elected town supervisor.

title: Rio Journal;   Brazil's Idol Is a Blonde, and Some Ask 'Why?'
description: When Rosane Collor, the wife of Brazil's President, wanted to collect food for children's nurseries in Rio, she turned to Xuxa.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Foes of Abortion View 'Right to Die' As Second Battle Over Life and Death
description: Invoking a familiar refrain, the speaker at an anti-abortion convention here condemned ''the taking of innocent human life,'' and urged a passionate battle against what she said history would record as ''the most horrible story of the 21st century.''

title: Teacher Corps Shows Hope, Not Arrogance
description: To the Editor:

title: Shanghai Stock Market
description: China's first full-fledged stock market since the Communist takeover will open in Shanghai in December, a newspaper report said today. A national securities exchange will open in a new building equipped with computer terminals linked to trading counters in the port city and around the country, the official Liberation Daily reported. Shanghai, which had one of Asia's largest stock exchanges before the Communist takeover in 1949, opened a small stock-trading counter in 1989 for cash purchases and sales as well as resales of Government bonds.

title: Schools in Utah Sued On Graduation Prayer
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit today against two school districts that permit prayer at graduation exercises and other functions.

title: 1.2 Million People See Van Gogh Exhibition
description: The ''Vincent van Gogh Retrospective,'' an exhibition of nearly 140 works by the Dutch artist, drew a record 1.2 million visitors over four months, the show's organizers said today. People camped out through the weekend in hopes of seeing the show before it closed on Sunday, the 100th anniversary of the artist's death.

title: Chronicle
description: LEAD: The actor RICHARD WIDMARK ''had a fight with his lawn mower'' Sunday evening at his home in Roxbury, Conn., and was in satisfactory condition yesterday at a local hospital after undergoing surgery on his lower left leg and foot, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Less Pie in the Star Wars Sky
description: President Bush has decided to decide in 1993 whether to proceed with early deployment of space-based defenses. That puts him in the imprudent position of having to choose before the new Star Wars system is adequately tested.

title: Cambodian Ordeal Began in U.S. Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Saturday about bias at private golf clubs misidentified Hall W. Thompson in some copies. He is the founder, not the owner, of the Shoal Creek Country Club in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Souter Is Linked to Anti-Abortion Brief
description: In 1976, while David H. Souter was New Hampshire Attorney General, his office submitted a brief to a Federal appeals court arguing that the state should not provide Medicaid funds to pay for abortions, which the brief called ''the killing of the unborn.''

title: 2 BARGES LEAK OIL IN HOUSTON CANAL
description: The Coast Guard estimated today that 500,000 gallons of oil had spilled into Galveston Bay from two barges that collided with a tanker in the Houston Ship Channel over the weekend.

title: Burial Workers Mourn at Grave Of Slain Girl, 9
description: Grief is a familiar emotion among the century-old tombstones and plastic floral arrangements that line the grounds of the Cemetery of the Evergreens in Brooklyn. But yesterday morning, when a white coffin containing the body of 9-year-old Veronica Corales was lowered into the earth, the heartbreak touched even the gravediggers.

title: Shots Through Door Kill a Bronx Infant Playing in a Walker
description: A 9-month-old boy playing in his walker was shot to death yesterday by a gunman who fired repeatedly through the door of the child's grandmother's apartment on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx.

title: Changes by Moody's Affect $40 Billion in Municipal Debt
description: Revisions of municipal bond ratings in the first half of the year have affected more than $40 billion in debt, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday. The ratings on nearly $19.5 billion in debt from 102 issuers were upgraded, while those on almost $21 billion in debt of 84 issuers were downgraded.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Avco Financial
description: Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., is offering $100 million in 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1995 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are offered at a price of 99.75 to yield 8.95 percent, or about 85 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the noncallable issue was rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: City Trees, Revisited
description: Replacing trees with buildings and concrete can contribute to an increase in air pollution, a new study says.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: INSIDE
description: Explosion Is Feared In Atom Waste Tanks

title: Steinbrenner's Control of Yanks Severed
description: George Steinbrenner was banned yesterday from further involvement in the management of the New York Yankees because of his three-year association with, and $40,000 payment to, a man the commissioner of baseball called a ''known gambler.''

title: New Musicals Project Closes Down
description: The New Musicals program at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., has closed down because of disappointing revenues after presenting only one production, ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' its producers announced yesterday.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Prague Priest Worries How Churches Will Use Liberty
description: Last November, the Rev. Vaclav Maly was a revolutionary. Now he is a pastor. Once a leading spokesman for the Civic Forum movement, which toppled Czechoslovakia's Communist Government, the young Roman Catholic priest passed up the prospect of a Government post to take charge of a parish in a working-class section of Prague.

title: Finance/New Issues;   GMAC in Pricing Of 8.75% Notes
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation yesterday priced $300 million of 8.75 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.649 to yield 8.84 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   Spira Case Just One Chapter in Stormy, 17 1/2-Year Adventure
description: It was 17 years and 6 months ago that George Steinbrenner began his chaotic reign as head of a group that bought the Yankees in the winter of 1973. Not a day, it seems, has gone by without some kind of storm in his ownership.

title: Company News;   Guilty Plea On Billing By Ametek
description: Ametek Inc., a military contractor, pleaded guilty today to two criminal charges of making false statements to the Federal Government and agreed to pay $5.2 million in civil and criminal fines to settle accusations that it had overbilled the Government for sonar systems used on Navy submarines.

title: Clemens Defeats White Sox With 2d Shutout in a Row
description: Roger Clemens worked out of early trouble and earned his second consecutive shutout tonight as the Boston Red Sox beat the Chicago White Sox, 3-0.

title: Ex-Guard Convicted For the Kidnapping Of a Federal Agent
description: A former Mexican police officer was convicted today of kidnapping and other charges in the slaying of an American drug agent in Mexico, but was acquitted of murder.

title: Police Ignored Warnings on Age Of Jogger Suspect, Witnesses Say
description: Defense witnesses testified yesterday that detectives questioned Yusef Salaam about an attack on a woman jogger in Central Park last year despite their repeated protests that he was only 15 years old and could not be questioned without a parent or guardian present.

title: New York Limits Use of Sex History in Trials
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed legislation today that will make it harder for defense lawyers to ask questions about the sexual histories of crime victims like Marla Hanson, the slashed model, or Jennifer Levin, who was slain in Central Park.

title: U.S. to Test New Atomic Waste Disposal Plan
description: Researchers at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant will test a method that uses microwaves for disposing of hazardous waste, officials said today.

title: Martin's Widow Sues
description: Billy Martin's widow, Jill, filed a lawsuit in Binghamton, N.Y., yesterday against the man who authorities say was driving the truck in which Martin, 61 years old, the former Yankee manager, was killed in an accident last Christmas night.

title: Boston Journal;   In Furor Over Photos, An Echo of City's Past
description: ''Banned in Boston'' is a cliche with a long pedigree: It began with the Mayflower.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   A Finding Based On 2 Key Premises
description: Following are excerpts from the text of the decision by Commissioner Fay Vincent in the matter of George Steinbrenner.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   What Led to the Downfall
description: Here is how the relationship developed between George Steinbrenner and Howard Spira, leading to the decision yesterday to end Steinbrenner's control over the Yankees.

title: SAVINGS REGULATOR SEEKS $100 BILLION FOR BAILOUT IN '91
description: The Government will need $100 billion from taxpayers in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 to continue its current pace of closing and selling off hundreds of failed savings and loans, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, told Congress today.

title: White Sox Send Kittle To Orioles for Bradley
description: The Chicago White Sox traded the first baseman Ron Kittle, their leading home-run hitter this season, to the Baltimore Orioles yesterday for the outfielder Phil Bradley.

title: Army Discounts Spying by 6 Who Left West German Post
description: Six soldiers absent without leave from an intelligence unit at an electronic eavesdropping post in West Germany are not spies for a foreign power and have been discharged, the Army said today.

title: Use Pentagon Cut For AIDS Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Hidden In a Gap In Rings Of Saturn
description: SEEING ripples in the outermost major ring of Saturn, scientists predicted where they should find a small but previously unobserved moon whose gravity was causing the disturbance. They looked through images from the Voyager 2 spacecraft, and there it was: a small, bright object no more than 12 miles wide, the 18th moon to be identified orbiting Saturn.

title: Herbert Jenkins, 83, Former Police Chief In Atlanta, Is Dead
description: Herbert T. Jenkins Sr., the Atlanta Police Chief in the civil rights protests of the 1960's, died July 20 at his home in Atlanta. He was 83 years old.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Large Loss For Circle K
description: The Circle K Corporation, a convenience-store chain that sought bankruptcy protection last month, said today that it had a large loss in its fourth quarter, which ended on April 30.

title: Rising Incidence of Brain Tumors Is Drawing Attention and Concern
description: A BRAIN tumor has long been the most terrifying of malignancies, feared for its lethality and its position at the source of all thought and emotion. And now experts say the incidence of brain cancer may be on the rise.

title: Company News;   Rorer-Rhone Link
description: Shareholders of the Rorer Group Inc. are expected to give approval on Tuesday to Rorer's merger with a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the giant French pharmaceutical concern, to create one of the world's top 10 drug companies. Approval of the $3.2 billion deal is assured because Rhone-Poulenc already controls 50.1 percent of Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa. But a spokesman said Rorer was seeking support from other shareholders.

title: Lining Up for Life
description: What's unsettling about standing in line is the all-too-real possibility that somebody's going to sneak in ahead of you. If what you're waiting for is a movie seat or a restaurant table, losing your place is only an annoyance. If it's a heart or kidney, losing your place is sometimes the difference between life and death.

title: Washington at Work;   The New Spokesman for the Republicans: a Tough Player in a Rough Arena
description: Much of America watches the Sunday morning talk shows with brunch and coffee and considerable detachment. But here in Washington the shows are a blood sport, and Charles Black entered the arena on Sunday morning with a grim and wary look.

title: Business and Health;   Medicaid Fight By Drug Makers
description: THE Bush Administration wants to cut $300 million from the $5 billion for drugs that Federal and state governments plan to spend next year in the Medicaid program for the poor. With matching cuts by the states, the estimated saving could be $536 million.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   For Fans of Yankees, Decision Is a Winner
description: The Yankees are in last place in the American League East, their best player, Don Mattingly, is on the 21-day disabled list, and last night, Deion Sanders, one of several young players the Yankees are hoping to rebuild with, left the team.

title: A Modern Dance Duo Who Are on the Wall
description: They met in dance class. Shortly thereafter, they found themselves dangling together from the Bir Hakeim Bridge in Paris.

title: Impersonator Wants To Portray Still Others, This Time, Onstage
description: It shouldn't surprise anyone that David Hampton wants to be a professional actor, considering the success he has had as an amateur. Posing as Sidney Poitier's son, he gained access to the homes of many prominent New Yorkers in 1983, and his deception inspired ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' John Guare's hit play, which opened in June at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Bobby Day, Band Leader, 60
description: Bobby Day, a singer and band leader who recorded ''Rockin' Robin'' ''Little Bitty Pretty One'' and other doo-wop hits of the 1950's, died on Friday. He was 60 years old.

title: Flower Sellers' Ruthless Competition
description: At an intersection near Times Square, passers-by on either side of Broadway can follow the scent of flowers in every direction. There are vendors with bouquet-laden shopping carts. There's a couple who make flower arrangements under an umbrella. There's a mobile fruit stand with a floral section. There are arguments.

title: No Joy For Yanks, Despite A Victory
description: In the emotionally charged stands at Yankee Stadium, the noise began long before the home team would win a baseball game. The radios had spread the words of the baseball commissioner Fay Vincent. The news that George Steinbrenner had been forced to resign his role in running the team was quickly transformed into a celebration.

title: A Gene Therapy Nears Approval
description: THE first attempt to treat seriously ill children by inserting new genes in their blood cells neared final approval yesterday, as an important Federal subcommittee voted 12 to 1 in favor of the proposal.

title: By Design;   Lace, But Not the No-Frills Kind
description: Even if she is dressed in jeans and a T-shirt, a Parisian woman is probably wearing something lacy underneath. Lovely lingerie is one thing Frenchwomen consider a must.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about convictions in a money-laundering case misstated the role of one defendant in some copies.

title: Company News;   Bull's Losses Rise; Layoffs Scheduled
description: The French computer company Groupe Bull S.A. said losses for the first six months of 1990 were three times larger than in the corresponding period last year. It said in a statement that it planned to cut 3,000 jobs this year to streamline manufacturing and research operations in North America, Ireland and France.

title: Notebook;   Minor Surgery Sets Back Bavaro
description: Mark Bavaro, the Pro Bowl tight end for the Giants who underwent serious surgery on his left knee in January, underwent another operation on that knee this morning. The latest surgery was minor, and Coach Bill Parcells said Bavaro should be ready to resume practice in a week to 10 days.

title: Children's TV Workshop Head to Step Down
description: Joan Ganz Cooney, the founder of the Children's Television Workshop, announced yesterday that she would step down in October as the company's chairman and chief executive officer. The workshop created ''Sesame Street,'' which became one of the world's most widely seen television programs.

title: British Legislator, Foe of I.R.A., Is Killed by a Bomb at His Home
description: In the latest of a series of terrorist attacks in Britain, a Conservative member of the British Parliament who was an outspoken critic of the Irish Republican Army was killed today when a bomb planted in his car exploded at his home, the police said.

title: House Considers Restriction on Advertising by Telephone and Fax
description: In a move to address the problems caused by new technology, the House of Representatives approved legislation on Tuesday to restrict the transmission of unsolicited advertisements by telephone and through facsimile machines.

title: Wang Has Loss in Quarter
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. reported today that it had a quarterly loss of $496.7 million after the final costs of its corporate revamping wiped out earnings.

title: Market Place;   Mutual Funds Are Resilient Despite Last Week's Plunge
description: Mutual fund investors seem to have generally shrugged off last Monday's sharp break in the stock market, and cash continues to be drawn into stock funds, mutual fund executives said yesterday.

title: Finance/New Issues;   Westinghouse 5-Year Notes
description: The Westinghouse Credit Corporation is offering $150 million in five-year notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I've changed his ownership interest from general partner to limited partner. There has to be a new general partner selected reasonably soon and approved by me and the major league clubs.''

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   Owner's Son Not New To Club
description: Hank Steinbrenner, who may succeed his father, George Steinbrenner, as the principal owner and general partner of the Yankees, first emerged on the baseball scene at the end of the 1985 season, when he began attending Yankee staff meetings at Yankee Stadium and the club's planning meetings in Tampa, Fla.

title: President Is Named For MIPS Computer
description: MIPS Computer Systems Inc., which grew out of a Stanford University research project six years ago, hopes to become a company with $1 billion in sales this decade and has named Charles M. Boesenberg as president to help reach the goal.

title: British Aerospace Deal
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that it had signed a deal with Oman for 16 Hawk jet fighters worth a total $:200 million, or $367.5 million. The company said it would deliver the jets by 1994. Oman had said it would buy an unspecified number of the planes but gave no details on the value of the order.

title: Morley R. Kare, 68, Physiologist Who Researched Taste and Smell
description: Morley R. Kare, director and president of the Monell Chemical Senses Center, a research group in Philadelphia devoted to studying taste and smell, died yesterday at his home in Narberth, Pa. He was 68 years old.

title: Arkansas Set To Join S.E.C.
description: The University Arkansas is expected to announce Wednesday that it is joining the Southeastern Conference after 76 years in the Southwest Conference.

title: Silverado Case Disclosure
description: Neil Bush, the President's son, who is accused by regulators of conflict of interest as a former director of a failed savings and loan, continues to deny the allegations but has agreed on some facts in the case.

title: Company News;   Oshkosh Trucks
description: The Oshkosh Truck Corporation said it would lay off 3 percent to 4 percent of its 2,000 employees to increase its competitiveness in the heavy-duty truck market. The specialty-truck manufacturer reported a third-quarter loss of $2.5 million, compared with a profit of $4.5 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Chronicle
description: LEAD: ELIE WIESEL will be at Connecticut College this week to take part in the accouncement of a chair of Judaic studies in his name. The chair is the result of a $1.4 million gift from JO ANN MYERS, an alumna who is the director of the Birmingham, Ala., Jewish Day School. Mr. Wiesel, a survivor of Auschwitz and a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, said he was honored and wanted the study program to encompass Jewish history, literature and philosophy.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies on Saturday about a study of the health effects of atomic testing in the 1950's referred incorrectly to the results of the study. As the article stated, the study found a weak link between atomic fallout and leukemia, not a weak leak.

title: Macintosh Power For Non-Power Users
description: WINDOWS 3.0, the new Microsoft graphical interface, gives high-end MS-DOS computers much of the power and ease of use of the Macintosh. But what about those who don't use high-end computers? To rephrase an early Mac slogan, what about the rest of us? To find out, I installed Windows on a mid-level computer of the type still found in many homes and offices, and still selling in large, though decreasing, numbers: an AT-class machine (that is, one using the 80286 processor) with a 30-megabyte hard disk, V.G.A. color graphics, a 12-megahertz rate, a megabyte of internal memory and a mouse. This is a preliminary report on the combination.

title: Review/Ballet;   The Bolshoi Brings Out Its Rarefied 'Giselle'
description: The Bolshoi Ballet did not perform ''Giselle'' during its recent season in New York. But the company from Moscow, which is touring the United States through September, gave balletomanes in the Washington area a glimpse of its current version of the venerable Romantic ballet over the weekend.

title: Man's Body Found in Rubble From Blast in North Carolina
description: Investigators found a body of a man in the rubble of a gutted downtown block today while looking for clues to the cause of a weekend explosion that destroyed at least eight businesses, a Federal agent said.

title: A Deer Comes Back From the Brink in India
description: Sustained by conservation measures, the Indian brow-antlered deer, once thought to be extinct, is making a comeback in the humid marshes and unique wetlands of Keibul Lamjao, a small national park in the country's remote northeast.

title: Samuel Umen, Rabbi, 73
description: Rabbi Samuel Umen, a writer and teacher who held pulpits in Michigan and Maryland and at Temple Adath Yeshurun in Manchester, N.H., died Saturday at Elliott Hospital in Manchester, where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Consumer Spending Up 1% in June
description: Personal spending rose 1 percent in June, the strongest gain in five months, the Government said today. The Commerce Department report suggested that consumers have been keeping the nation's weak economy out of a recession.

title: Ball to Pay $1 Billion To Make Acquisitions
description: The Ball Corporation announced today that it would spend more than $1 billion to make acquisitions that would nearly triple its sales.

title: Stocks Up on Belief in an Interest Rate Cut
description: A growing belief that the Federal Reserve may take steps to lower interest rates to revitalize the economy pushed stock prices higher yesterday.

title: William J. Kenney, Banker, 67
description: William J. Kenney, a former senior vice president of the Bank of New York, died on Sunday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan and Spring Lake, N.J.

title: The Message of Stray Bullets
description: There is no evidence that Ben Williams, age 3, Yaritimi Fruto, age 1, or Veronica Corales, age 9, ever knew each other in life. But the three New York City children are linked in death: during a single week, all were innocent victims of gunfire intended for others.

title: Careers;   Shortage of Skilled Workers Is Expected
description: IN 1967, Herman Kahn, the late founder of the Hudson Institute research organization, took a look ahead in a prescient book titled ''The Year 2000.'' He accurately predicted that United States corporations would have increased needs for skilled employees and training programs, that Japan would play a leading world economic role, and that commerce and industry in this country would extend in unbroken lines along highways between major cities, like the route from Boston to Washington.

title: Rebel Group in Trinidad: Fierce Offshoot of Islam
description: Caribbean scholars and experts on Islam in the West Indies say the militant Muslim group that staged a coup attempt in Trinidad last week is one of many new religious movements that have emerged in the region in recent years, challenging governments and established religious organizations.

title: Fernandez At 6 Months
description: Joseph A. Fernandez is running up against the jagged realities of the New York City school system.

title: Q&A
description: Itching and Scratching

title: New Eye on Nature: The Real Constant Is Eternal Turmoil
description: IN a revision that has far-reaching implications for the way humans see the natural world and their role in it, many scientists are forsaking one of the most deeply embedded concepts of ecology: the balance of nature.

title: The Media Business: Advertising: Addenda;   People
description: * Michael Ewing has been promoted to vice president and associate creative director at Lord Einstein O'Neill& Partners.

title: UAL Stock Down by $6.125
description: The UAL Corporation's stock price tumbled today amid indications that an employee group's $4.38 billion buyout plan had run into financing problems.

title: Yankees, Sanders Have a Parting
description: The brief, controversial and uncertain major league baseball career of Deion Sanders came to an abrupt halt yesterday when the Yankee organization ended contract negotiations that would have extended his commitment to baseball and could have led to a legal struggle.

title: Cetus Drug Is Blocked By F.D.A.
description: The Cetus Corporation suffered a setback today when an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration said it could not yet recommend that Cetus's flagship drug, interleukin-2, be approved for use.

title: Chess
description: There are a number of hurdles to be surmounted to win a tournament, and these days some of them are rather young. There was a time when almost any opponent under 20 years old could be written off as a threat to a grandmaster, but with the vast improvement in the quality of chess publications and their proliferation among students everywhere, those days are gone forever.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpha Microsystems Inc., Santa Ana, Calif., a computer hardware and software company, appointed David A. Young vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: Company News;   Trefoil to Buy Child World
description: Trefoil Capital Investors L.P., a new investment partnership backed by Roy E. Disney, said today that it planned to acquire Child World Inc., the second-largest toy chain, after Toys ''R'' Us, in a deal worth about $157 million.

title: On Horse Racing;   One Survivor's Rain- and Jet Fuel-Streaked Saratoga Crystal Ball
description: Saratoga Race Track in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., opens for the 122d time tomorrow afternoon, and one crystal ball says the meeting will unfold as follows:

title: Gorbachev Must Hurry
description: Mikhail Gorbachev pulled the plug that choked the Soviet system. Now other people are swarming to the surface with ideas that go far beyond his program for reform. They are no longer talking about reform, but about ''a fundamental new approach.''

title: The Media Business: Advertising: Addenda;   Victoria Uses Old Charms On Readers
description: AT a time when women's magazines have been particularly hard hit by a decline in advertising, there are a few publications that have not lost their charm.

title: Fujitsu To Buy ICL Stake
description: In the biggest expansion by a Japanese computer company into Europe, Fujitsu Ltd. will pay $1.29 billion for 80 percent of ICL P.L.C., Britain's only manufacturer of mainframe computers, the two companies announced today.

title: Psychologist Defended
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT IS URGED TO COUNTERATTACK
description: Republican Congressional leaders pleaded with President Bush today to help them repair the political damage caused by the disclosure of an Administration proposal to limit Federal deductions for state and local income taxes and to increase Federal taxes on alcohol.

title: Drug Kingpins Must Pay the Ultimate Penalty for Their Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   How the Commissioner Has Used His Power
description: Here are the key disciplinary actions against owners, managers and players taken by the comissioner since the office was established in 1921.

title: Steinbrenner Whine Fails 'Smell Test' Paris, in Perspective: Outdoors
description: George Steinbrenner's reign of tyranny as the Yankees' principal owner was also a reign of propaganda. Whatever the problem, he shouted loud enough and long enough that it was always somebody else's fault. When the team stumbled, it had to be the fault of the dismissed manager, the dismissed pitching coach or the dismissed players. When a trade backfired, it had to be the fault of his ''baseball people'' in the front office.

title: Nassau, Sludge Scofflaw, Pays Big Fines
description: Only nine local jurisdictions in the nation, all in the New York region, still dump sewage sludge in the ocean, and eight of them are on their way to complying with a Federal law that makes that illegal at the end of 1991. All except Nassau County. Every day that the county violates a compliance agreement it signed last year with the Environmental Protection Agency, it is fined $22,000. The county has paid more than $600,000 to the Federal and state governments so far, and the longer officials wait, the steeper the fines get.

title: Bat-Swinging Man Attacks 2 Strolling Inside Central Park
description: A man and a woman were beaten by a man wielding a bat as they walked near Conservatory Pond in Central Park last night, the police said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Ukraine Asks Moscow To Return Its Recruits
description: The Ukraine, stepping up its defiance of Moscow, called today for the return of all Ukrainians doing compulsory service in the Soviet armed forces.

title: Company News;   Varity Plans Move And Reverse Split
description: The Varity Corporation, the 143-year-old Canadian manufacturer formerly known as Massey-Ferguson, said it plans to move its headquarters from Toronto to the United States. Varity's chairman, Victor Rice, told shareholders at the annual meeting: ''More than 80 percent of our shareholders are U.S. residents; most of our North American employees are in the U.S., and U.S.-based customers will account for some 50 percent of our 1990 revenues.''

title: Accountants Fear S.& L. Backlash
description: The nation's accountants may soon feel a backlash from the savings and loan crisis.

title: Bridge
description: An astonishing turnabout in the final 16 deals gave the victory in the Spingold Knockout Teams to the defending champions, headed by James Cayne of Manhattan, at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Sunday night.

title: Heat Is More Lethal When It Is Unusual, Researchers Find
description: WHAT New Yorkers and other Northerners consider a heat wave often feels like a routine summer day to residents of Dallas or Phoenix or Jacksonville. Now scientists say that such feelings are not just a matter of discomfort, but also of life and death. Heat, they have found, generally begins killing people at lower temperatures in New York and other Northern cities than in the South and Southwest, where people are more acclimated to hot weather.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the case of Oliver L. North referred incorrectly to a July 20 decision by a Federal appeals court. The decision set aside Mr. North's conviction on three charges in the Iran-contra case and overturned one of the three charges, not an additional charge, outright.

title: Explosion Could Release Radiation at Hanford, U.S. Panel Warns
description: In the most authoritative and pessimistic official study to date, a Government advisory panel led by a former chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has warned that an explosion could rupture tanks that store millions of gallons of extremely radioactive waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Germans Who Want Russians Out Vs. the Russians Who Want to Stay
description: Like Soviet military installations everywhere in this country, the Soviet Army base for the 12th Guards tank division and fighter-bomber air regiment just outside this lake resort is surrounded by a whitewashed stone wall. It runs for miles through the scrub pines, marred at its central point by the huge black graffiti letters spelling out ''Russen Raus.''

title: Campeau Plan Is Rejected
description: Shareholders of the Campeau Corporation rejected a plan today that would have allowed the sale of its Canadian real estate and diverted proceeds to its troubled American retail subisidiaries, Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: Teacher Corps Shows Hope, Not Arrogance;   How to Keep Them
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Nem di Gelt' (Take the Money)
description: LEAD: A guy I'd thought was my friend played me a tape of Andrew Dice Clay, this hotshot kid comic from Brooklyn with the filthy mouth. After listening to a few gags, I realized Clay needs no introduction. What he needs is an act.

title: The Textile Bill's Awful Bill
description: The Senate has overwhelmingly approved a textile bill that would impose a vicious cost on U.S. consumers, violate existing American trade agreements and undermine international trade talks. Three big strikes, yet the House is poised to approve similar legislation, perhaps this week.

title: Review/Television;   How Police Chiefs See the Crime Problem
description: August 1, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

title: U.S. Condemns Killings
description: The White House today condemned the massacre of Liberian war refugees as a ''senseless act of terror'' and repeated earlier appeals for all sides in the civil war to negotiate an end to the fighting.

title: Chinatown's Old Gangs Give Way to Violence and Fear
description: In Chinatown, once considered an oasis from many kinds of crime, residents and business owners are nervous these days about a recent surge in violence that they blame on Vietnamese gangs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the second-quarter report on the gross national product misstated the change in personal income. It rose at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter; it did not decline.

title: Connie Chung to Scale Back Series
description: In a setback for the third-ranked network's news division, CBS News announced yesterday that the newsmagazine series anchored by Connie Chung would be replaced on its fall prime-time schedule at Ms. Chung's request.

title: Kurri to Italian Team
description: Jari Kurri, who helped the Edmonton Oilers win five Stanley Cups and became the most prolific scorer in the National Hockey League among European players, is off to Italy to play hockey.

title: Sleuths Zero In on Cause of Telescope Flaw
description: ARMED with solid clues, intriguing rumors and even tips from amateur astronomers, a small army of scientific sleuths is slowly closing in on the cause of the flawed mirrors in the $1.5-billion Hubble space telescope.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on July 23 about legislation to expand reporting requirements on foreign investors in the United States misidentified the Japanese company that bought a controlling stake in Rockefeller Center.

title: Astere Claeyssens, 66, Professor of English
description: Astere E. Claeyssens, a professor of English at George Washington University, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago, where he was visiting. He was 66 years old and lived in Washington.

title: America Is No. 1. It'll Stay No. 1.
description: Since the late Reagan years, we've heard a media and political refrain: the U.S. is in decline; it has lost world political and economic leadership; Japan is the coming No. 1 power.

title: Squabbling Italian Coalition Holds On
description: When Italy took over the six-month rotating presidency of the European Community on July 1, it looked as if the Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti had found itself a model insurance policy.

title: Decision on Steinbrenner;   'I Have No Comment,' Says Spira
description: The man whose barrage of wheedling phone calls led to the $40,000 payment that ended George Steinbrenner's control of the Yankees was uncharacteristically circumspect last night.

title: How Insurers Drove Up Costs of Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Lobbyist Is Refusing to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 - Robert J. Thompson, a former aide to George Bush, says he will not appear Tuesday before a Senate subcommittee that is looking into his role in helping a businessman with a history of legal problems acquire 15 insolvent savings and loan associations from Federal regulators in 1988.

title: KEY RATES
Mets Maintaining Patience on Elster
description: Bud Harrelson, the manager with the tough talk and the hard blue eyes, stood squinting into the sharp sunlight one evening recently as Kevin Elster swung a bat inside the practice cage nearby.

title: Francis J. Little, 56, Orchestra's Director Of Public Relations
description: Francis J. Little, the director of advertising and public relations for the New York Philharmonic, died early Monday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 56 years old.

title: ACCORD IS STALLED IN TRINIDAD SIEGE
description: Progress toward a peaceful settlement of a coup attempt by Muslim rebels was uncertain tonight after three days of tense negotiations mediated by a Anglican cleric.

title: Tough Abortion Law at Issue
description: The fight over the toughest state abortion law in the nation entered Federal Court today as a group of doctors and abortion clinics asked a judge to throw out main sections of the law.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

A Key Officer Is Picked For Western Digital
description: LEAD: Kathryn A. Braun, one of the nation's highest-ranking female executives, has been promoted to executive vice president in charge of all business operations at the Western Digital Corporation, a computer equipment maker based in Irvine, Calif.

title: A Day of Fine Tuning on Vincent's Decision
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent decided more than a week ago to permanently ban George Steinbrenner from running the Yankees. At 9 A.M. yesterday he unveiled his decision to the Yankees' owner.
